articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia readying strikes on nuclear power system, Zelenskyy warns
articles.trailText: Kyrylo Budanov arrives in US heading delegation for further talks on peace proposals. What we know on day 1,425
articles.summary: Ukraine’s president Volodymyr Zelenskyy warns Russia is preparing new strikes on the country’s nuclear power infrastructure, exacerbating winter energy shortages and undermining allied efforts to end the war. After a briefing by defence intelligence chief Oleh Ivashchenko, Zelenskyy said Moscow shows no willingness to negotiate. Kyrylo Budanov, recently appointed head of the presidential office, has led Ukrainian negotiators to Washington to finalize security guarantees and economic recovery plans with US envoys including Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, with hopes of signing a deal at the Davos forum. Meanwhile, Russian attacks on Kharkiv, Sumy, Kyiv and Odesa regions have killed civilians and crippled power and heating facilities. To stabilize the grid, Ukraine is importing up to 50% of its electricity and receiving generators and solar panels from Lithuania.

articles.title: Trump’s tariff threat is an attempt to divide Europe and quash opposition over Greenland
articles.trailText: Using one of his favourite weapons to win an argument, the US president underlines the unstable nature of any deal he makes
articles.summary: President Trump threatened fresh tariffs on eight European countries—including the UK, Norway and six EU states—over opposition to his Greenland gambit, effectively stalling ratification of the 0% tariff US–EU trade deal agreed last July. EPP and S&D blocs refuse approval, Renew has joined calls to halt ratification. The UK’s narrow tariff pact also hangs in the balance amid separate steel and tech-law negotiations. Seen as a tactic to divide Europe, the move prompted an emergency EU ambassadors meeting and highlights the unreliable nature of deals under Trump.

articles.title: Macron: ‘No amount of intimidation’ will change EU nations’ course on Greenland
articles.trailText: French president calls tariff threats ‘unacceptable’, while Sweden’s Ulf Kristersson warns EU will not be ‘blackmailed’ by US
articles.summary: After US President Donald Trump on January 15 announced 10% tariffs from February 1 and 25% from June 1 on Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the UK, the Netherlands and Finland for opposing his proposed Greenland purchase, President Macron condemned the threats as 'unacceptable intimidation' and affirmed France’s commitment to Denmark’s sovereignty and Arctic security. Swedish PM Kristersson and Norwegian PM Støre likewise rebuffed US 'blackmail' among allies. European Council’s Costa and Commission’s von der Leyen warned such tariffs would damage transatlantic ties and risk a downward spiral. EU ambassadors will hold an emergency session while MEPs signal pausing US trade deal ratification. Denmark seeks constructive talks; analysts label US measures a negotiating tactic.

articles.title: Keir Starmer says Trump’s threat to impose tariffs over Greenland ‘completely wrong’
articles.trailText: Prime minister and opposition politicians condemn threat to impose 10% tariff unless deal reached to buy the Arctic island
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s threat to impose a 10% tariff on the UK and seven NATO allies from 1 February—rising to 25% by 1 June unless Greenland is sold to the US—drew cross-party outrage. Labour leader Keir Starmer called the move “completely wrong,” insisting Greenland’s future lies with Denmark and its people, and urging collective Arctic security. Conservative Kemi Badenoch warned of added business burdens; Lib Dem Ed Davey, Reform’s Nigel Farage and Labour’s Stella Creasy demanded unity and stronger European ties. Ex-security adviser Peter Ricketts recommended a calm, EU-wide response and private diplomacy to resolve the dispute.

articles.title: Israel objects to White House’s pick of leaders for ‘board of peace’
articles.trailText: Country says some appointments to the group, which will oversee the administration and reconstruction of Gaza, are ‘contrary to its policy’
articles.summary: Israel has formally objected to uncoordinated White House appointments to its proposed Gaza “board of peace,” citing conflicts with Israeli policy. The interim body, part of Donald Trump’s 20-point ceasefire plan to supplant Hamas, would oversee governance and reconstruction in Gaza. Announced invitees include Erdoğan, al-Sisi, Tony Blair, Javier Milei, and US figures Marco Rubio, Steve Witkoff, Jared Kushner, with Trump as chair. Its two tiers—the founding executive board and a Gaza executive board supervising the National Committee for the Administration of Gaza—face acceptance uncertainty. Key obstacles remain: Hamas disarmament, aid access amid continued Israeli restrictions and civilian casualties, and security force composition.

articles.title: The fate of the planet’s coastlines depends on how fast Antarctica’s ice sheets melt. We don’t know what’s coming
articles.trailText: Some regions of the continent have enough ice to push up sea levels by 15 metres if they all melt, but researchers don’t yet fully understand the consequences
articles.summary: Antarctica’s ice shelves don’t directly raise sea levels, but thinning from ocean-driven basal melt lets the inland ice sheet flow faster into the sea, risking up to 15 m of global sea-level rise if fully lost. Dr Ben Galton-Fenzi’s team synthesized nine models to estimate recent melt under shelves at 843 bn tonnes per year—equivalent to the Nile’s annual discharge—while satellite data show a net loss of 93 bn tonnes from 1992 to 2020. Sub-shelf Argo float data revealed warm water undermining Totten and Denman shelves, the latter holding enough ice for 1.5 m of rise and poised for unstable retreat. Key uncertainties remain in melt rates and how the influx of cold freshwater could disrupt global ocean circulation—outcomes tied to future greenhouse-gas emissions.

articles.title: Newborn baby becomes eighth to die of hypothermia in Gaza this winter
articles.trailText: Despite the ceasefire, more than 100 children have died in the territory since October
articles.summary: Since October's ceasefire in Gaza, over 100 children have died, including eight from hypothermia this winter. On Jan 16, 27-day-old Aisha Ayesh al-Agha was brought too late to Khan Younis' Nasser hospital after freezing temperatures. Reports by Physicians for Human Rights and University of Chicago Law’s Human Rights Clinic show that from January to June 2025 Gaza recorded 2,600 miscarriages, 220 pregnancy-related deaths, 1,460 preterm births, 1,700 underweight neonates and 2,500 NICU admissions. Fuel shortages, medical blockades, displacement and bombardment have decimated maternal and newborn care. Unicef warns winter storms and inadequate shelter are worsening infant fatalities.

articles.title: Yoweri Museveni wins Ugandan election as opponent condemns ‘fake result’
articles.trailText: Museveni’s opponent, Bobi Wine, alleges that members of polling staff were kidnapped and called for peaceful protests
articles.summary: Yoweri Museveni won Uganda's presidential election with over 70% of the vote, securing a seventh term amid an internet shutdown and fraud claims. Opposition leader Bobi Wine denounced the “fake results”, accusing security forces of raiding his home by helicopter, cutting power and CCTV, and kidnapping polling staff. Biometric voter ID failures forced manual registers, prompting allegations of ballot stuffing. Police denied arresting Wine but clashes killed at least seven. Observers, including Freedom House, deem Uganda “not free”. At 81, Museveni has ruled 40 years, removing term limits and jailing opponents.

articles.title: Ali Khamenei says thousands killed in Iran protests, some in ‘inhuman, savage manner’
articles.trailText: Supreme leader blames US for death toll and calls Donald Trump a criminal for support of demonstrations
articles.summary: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei acknowledged for the first time that thousands died in two weeks of protests, some ‘inhumanly’ killed, and blamed the US, calling Trump a ‘criminal’ for backing demonstrations. A senior cleric demanded execution of ‘armed hypocrites,’ labeling protesters as Israeli and US agents. Authorities released footage of alleged foreign saboteurs. Rights groups report over 3,090 killed and 22,100 arrested amid an ongoing internet blackout. Exiled royal claimant Reza Pahlavi renewed calls to overthrow the government and urged Trump to intervene.

articles.title: ‘It will take a generation’: Iranians abroad on the protests – and change
articles.trailText: We asked some of those who have family in Iran to tell us their views on the current crisis
articles.summary: After Reza Pahlavi’s Washington plea for Western support to oust supreme leader Khamenei, and amid Trump’s oscillating threats and claims of a pause in executions, protests in Iran have slowed, with estimates of 2,000–12,000 killed. Iranian expatriates voice varied responses: Roya in Switzerland relies on scarce calls to check on family, rejects both monarchy and foreign military aid, urging grassroots change. UK-based teacher Reza warns that true reform will take a generation. Students Rose and Mani press Trump for urgent intervention and regime change under Pahlavi, while Germany’s Hana cautions that outside meddling risks civil war and instability.

articles.title: Guterres warns of ‘powerful forces’ undermining ‘global cooperation’
articles.trailText: In historic speech to mark UN’s 80th anniversary, secretary general makes impassioned plea for multilateralism and international law amid drastic US funding cuts
articles.summary: In a speech marking the UN’s 80th anniversary at London’s Methodist Central Hall, António Guterres warned of “powerful forces” undermining global cooperation and urged renewed commitment to multilateralism and international law. He highlighted the climate crisis, record heat, surging fossil fuel profits, algorithm-driven online falsehoods and a new arms race as existential threats, noting world military spending hit $2.7 trn. Guterres decried US cuts to $2 bn in humanitarian aid under demands to “adapt, shrink or die,” and pledged UN reforms to make it more agile, coordinated and responsive.

articles.title: Greenland crisis: Europe needs the US, but it also needs to stand up to Trump
articles.trailText: US president’s increasingly bellicose demands for control of the island may force the EU to draw a line in the snow
articles.summary: Facing Trump’s bid to purchase Greenland, European leaders have largely tolerated his defence-spending demands but now see a sovereignty red line. Denmark’s FM Lars Løkke Rasmussen and Greenland’s Vivian Motzfeldt rejected US annexation talks as reckless. NATO allies counter Trump’s security rationale by deploying French, German and Nordic troops, while the EU mulls Arctic summits, doubling aid and even freezing ratification of the US trade deal to uphold Danish sovereignty. Officials warn the crisis tests Europe’s willingness to stand up to Washington amid dependency on US security, as Brussels seeks deeper transatlantic dialogue and fortifies Greenland’s resilience.

articles.title: The Iranian state silenced protests with brutality. What now for Iran’s opposition?
articles.trailText: Grieving, bruised and divided on the wisdom of foreign-backed revolt, how can the Iranian people achieve change?
articles.summary: The Iranian government crushed recent nationwide protests with unprecedented violence, leaving the opposition inside Iran grieving, divided, and under a communication blackout. Reformist president promises proved hollow and foreign support remains elusive. Exiled figurehead Reza Pahlavi faces credibility challenges over unfulfilled promises of strikes, US intervention and monarchist nostalgia amid state TV propaganda framing protesters as foreign pawns. Internal exile coalitions fracture over strategy—from violent revolt to non-violent resistance—while moral authority may shift to imprisoned activists like Narges Mohammadi and Mostafa Tajzadeh.

articles.title: Iran plans permanent break from global internet, say activists
articles.trailText: Report claims unrestricted online access will be a ‘government privilege’, limited to individuals vetted by regime
articles.summary: Filterwatch activists reveal Iran is executing a confidential plan to permanently break from the global internet, restricting filtered international access to regime-vetted users after 2026 and confining others to a monitored national intranet. The blackout, active since January 8 amid a brutal crackdown on protests, uses Chinese-enabled high-capacity middleboxes and whitelisting tools. Iran’s domestic network hosts state-approved apps and sites but has no external links. Critics warn the shift will inflict massive economic and cultural damage while cementing authoritarian online control.

articles.title: How Madrid’s Prado Museum is trying to avoid becoming like ‘the Metro at rush-hour’
articles.trailText: The famous gallery, home to masterpieces from Goya and Velázquez, is exploring how best to preserve, and improve, the visitor experience
articles.summary: Prado director Miguel Falomir warns that after a record 3.5 million visits in 2025, the museum risks oversaturation—“we don’t need a single visitor more”—and is piloting measures to preserve visitor quality. Proposals include optimized entrances, limits on group size and stricter no‐photo enforcement. A Guardian visit in mid‐January found 90-second entry queues and manageable crowds at Bosch’s Garden of Earthly Delights, Goya galleries and Las Meninas, while peripheral rooms remained almost empty. Visitors from Stockholm, Murcia and local members praised the balanced experience and efficient cloakrooms and audio guides.

articles.title: Mark Carney in China positions Canada for ‘the world as it is, not as we wish it’
articles.trailText: PM’s visit to Beijing seen as a welcome reset to relations in a ‘new world order’ but critics worry what trade deal could mean for Canadian workers
articles.summary: During his first Beijing visit in nearly a decade, PM Mark Carney secured a “preliminary but landmark” agreement with China, signalling a reset in bilateral relations and acknowledgment of a “new world order.” A provisional deal allows up to 49,000 Chinese EVs into Canada, cuts Chinese tariffs on canola, lobsters, seafood and peas, and reflects Carney’s bid to diversify exports beyond the US, which absorbs 70% of Canadian shipments. While hailed as a strategic partnership enhancing Canada’s autonomy, critics warn it risks domestic jobs, overdependence on China and underplay security and human-rights concerns.

articles.title: Uganda’s opposition leader ‘taken by army’ as Museveni nears re-election
articles.trailText: Bobi Wine flown to unknown location, his party says, hours after security forces allegedly killed 10 of his campaigners
articles.summary: Opposition leader Bobi Wine (Robert Kyagulanyi) was seized by security forces—his NUP party says an army helicopter landed at his Kampala home Friday and flew him to an unknown location—as President Yoweri Museveni surged toward a landslide victory with 74% of early votes. Held under effective house arrest during an internet blackout, Wine alleged mass fraud and urged protests. At dawn, troops reportedly stormed senior NUP MP candidate Muwanga Kivumbi’s house, killing 10 campaigners; police disputed the account, calling them armed “goons.” Wine condemned the killings, decried “insanity” of the regime, and vowed resistance. Final tally is due Saturday.

articles.title: Son of former shah says he is ‘uniquely positioned’ to lead Iran as he predicts end of regime
articles.trailText: Reza Pahlavi sets out ambition to lead country his father once ruled, but many question his level of popular support
articles.summary: Reza Pahlavi, son of Iran’s ex-shah, predicted the Islamic regime will collapse and claimed he is uniquely positioned to lead a successor government. Speaking in Washington amid nationwide protests and a crackdown that has left thousands dead, he urged the West to provide “targeted intervention” against the Revolutionary Guards’ leadership—no boots on the ground—to hasten the regime’s fall and save lives. Though exiled since 1979 and lacking clear popular backing, his name has surfaced in chants. He proposes referendums on Iran’s future and says elements of security forces already pledge loyalty to him.

articles.title: CIA chief visits Maduro successor as Machado vows to become Venezuela’s president
articles.trailText: John Ratcliffe meets Delcy Rodríguez in Caracas less than two weeks after his agents helped to oust her precedessor
articles.summary: CIA Director John Ratcliffe flew to Caracas to meet acting president Delcy Rodríguez less than two weeks after US agents helped abduct Nicolás Maduro. Meanwhile opposition leader María Corina Machado, sidelined by US support for Rodríguez, vowed on Fox News that she would become Venezuela’s first elected female president. Machado even presented her Nobel Peace Prize medal to Donald Trump to regain favor, but experts say Trump trusts Rodríguez, whom he praised as a “terrific person.” Rodríguez, backed by Maduro allies, has opened Venezuela’s oil sector to US firms and promises stronger US ties, effectively sidelining Machado’s opposition movement for now.

articles.title: Trump threatens tariffs against those who oppose him taking Greenland
articles.trailText: President raises pressure on European allies as US envoy says deal to take island ‘should and will be made’
articles.summary: President Donald Trump threatened 25% tariffs on countries that oppose his bid to annex Greenland, calling the Arctic island vital for US national security. US envoy Jeff Landry said a takeover “should and will be made” as a bipartisan congressional delegation of 11 lawmakers visited Denmark to support Danish-Greenlandic leaders. Denmark agreed to boost Greenland’s emergency preparedness amid NATO troop deployments. White House claims of a deal to cede Greenland were denied by Danish and Greenlandic ministers, who instead formed a technical working group.

articles.title: Starring role for ‘Kardashian jetty’ as Venice visitors seek peeks of Bezos wedding sites
articles.trailText: Tourists keen to see island where couple exchanged vows, seven-star hotel where they stayed and paths trodden by their celebrity guests
articles.summary: Since Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sánchez’s June wedding in Venice – dubbed “the wedding of the century” and estimated to have injected €957.3 million into the local economy – tourist demand has shifted from St Mark’s Square to bespoke Bezos tours. Guide Igor Scomparin leads U.S. visitors to the ‘Kardashian jetty’ outside Gritti Palace, San Giorgio island, the Aman hotel, Scuola Grande della Misericordia and the Arsenale yacht party venue. Highlights include celebrity water-taxis, Murano glasses, Friuliane shoes and tales of inflatable crocodile protests and a missing designer dress.

articles.title: Trump pushes for disarmament of Hamas as second stage of Gaza ceasefire begins
articles.trailText: US president also calls for return of final Israeli captive’s remains from group, which has refused to give up weapons
articles.summary: Donald Trump issued an ultimatum to Hamas, demanding immediate disarmament and return of the final Israeli captive’s remains as phase two of the US-brokered Gaza truce begins. Hamas demilitarization, Israeli troop withdrawal and expanded humanitarian aid remain unresolved, with Hamas refusing to surrender arms. The US plan calls for dismantling tunnels, full heavy-weapon surrender and a firearms buy-back scheme. Trump will chair a ‘board of peace’ with Tony Blair, Jared Kushner and ex-UN envoy Nickolay Mladenov, overseeing a 15-member technocratic Palestinian NCAG led by Ali Shaath. Gaza’s reconstruction, amid airstrikes, winter storms and at least 100 child deaths since October, faces a UN-estimated cost above $70bn.

articles.title: Giving Trump the Nobel peace prize medal is ‘absurd’, say Norwegian politicians
articles.trailText: US president criticised for accepting medal awarded to Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado
articles.summary: Norwegian politicians denounced Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado’s decision to present her Nobel Peace Prize medal to US President Donald Trump as “absurd” and invalid, noting the award cannot be revoked, shared or transferred. Socialist Left leader Kirsti Bergstø called Trump a “classic showoff” unworthy of the prize, citing his threats to invade Greenland. Centre party head Trygve Slagsvold Vedum and former Oslo mayor Raymond Johansen warned Machado’s gesture damages the prize’s reputation and risks politicising one of the world’s most prestigious honours. Trump hailed the gift on Truth Social.

articles.title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro finds novel way to reduce 27-year sentence: reading books
articles.trailText: Former president convicted for coup plot to take advantage of law that knocks four days off jail term for each book read
articles.summary: Former President Jair Bolsonaro, sentenced to 27 years for plotting a coup, is using Brazil’s law that deducts four days from a prison term per book read. A Supreme Court judge approved his request; the mandatory reading list covers Brazilian works on Indigenous rights, racism, environmental issues and dictatorship-era violence, plus global classics like War and Peace and Don Quixote. Inmates must submit written reports to earn sentence cuts. Known as an avowed non-reader, Bolsonaro was moved to a maximum-security prison in Brasília this week.

articles.title: ‘An attempt to break people’: Bucha holds out amid Russia’s weaponisation of winter
articles.trailText: Russian attacks on Ukraine’s power plants as severe frost set in have been described as ‘crimes against humanity’
articles.summary: Bundled engineers in Bucha fight to thaw frozen generator filters at -12C to sustain water supply as Russian air and drone strikes on power plants amid -20C frost deepen rolling blackouts. Energy rationing leaves cafes open only intermittently and prefab housing for displaced families shivers with heaters frozen. Bucha’s newer distributed grid offers resilience compared to Soviet-era plants Russia knows well. With a state of emergency, 20 days of energy reserves, and Kyiv importing power, the SBU calls these strikes crimes against humanity. Mayor Anatolii Fedoruk warns Moscow aims to break people, yet Bucha endures as in 2022.

articles.title: Ferraris for all and wine on tap: satirical candidate shakes up Portugal’s presidential election
articles.trailText: The campaign by ‘Candidate Vieira’ mirrors the country’s growing anti-establishment sentiment
articles.summary: Manuel João Vieira, a comedian, is contesting Portugal’s 2026 presidential election as 'Candidate Vieira,' pledging Ferraris for all, wine on tap, AI-driven utopia and other surreal promises. His satirical campaign, fueled by viral AI memes mocking traditional ads, channels growing anti-elite sentiment in an 11-candidate race where far-right leader André Ventura and Socialist António José Seguro vie for a likely first-round runoff, the first in 40 years. Though polling at roughly 1%, Vieira’s absurdist platform captivates younger voters disillusioned with mainstream politics and challenges misinformation. While the president holds limited legislative powers, including the right to dissolve parliament and veto laws, voters see the absurdity as a critique of political apathy.

articles.title: South Korea sentences ex-president to five years in first martial law verdict
articles.trailText: Yoon Suk Yeol’s conviction for obstructing own arrest separate from main trial that could lead to death penalty
articles.summary: A Seoul court has handed former president Yoon Suk Yeol a five-year prison term for mobilising presidential security to block his own arrest, abusing power and falsifying documents in connection with his December 2024 martial law decree. Presiding Judge Baek Dae-hyun branded his conduct a flagrant constitutional breach. This ruling is separate from Yoon’s main insurrection trial—where prosecutors seek the death penalty and a verdict is due on February 20—and will be appealed. He faces seven additional cases, including alleged drone provocations, while his wife and ex–prime minister await verdicts this month.

articles.title: Canada PM hails strategic partnership with China to adapt to ‘new global realities’
articles.trailText: Mark Carney holds talks with Xi Jinping on rare Beijing trip as Canada seeks to diversify trade links away from US
articles.summary: Canada PM Mark Carney hailed a "new strategic partnership" with China after his Beijing talks with Xi Jinping, the first Canadian leader's visit in eight years, aimed at adapting to "new global realities." They agreed a preliminary tariff-cutting deal, including 49,000 Chinese EV imports at preferential rates, and revived ministerial talks on clean energy and fossil fuels. Carney's pivot seeks to curb Canada's heavy US reliance by doubling non-US exports; China currently buys under 4% of Canadian goods. After years of trade spats and the 2018 Meng Wanzhou fallout, both sides aim to reset ties and broaden cooperation in agriculture, energy and finance.

articles.title: Khamenei regime will not be able to keep control of Iran, says dissenting film-maker
articles.trailText: Jafar Panahi, director of Palme d’Or winner It Was Just An Accident, says Iranian leaders want to destroy country
articles.summary: Filmmaker Jafar Panahi, speaking from the US, predicts Ayatollah Khamenei’s regime cannot sustain its rule after its lethal crackdown—killing over 2,500 amid protests over economic woes—and near-total internet blackout signalled a coming massacre. Oscar hopeful for Palme d’Or winner It Was Just an Accident, Panahi warns the state’s ongoing savagery will perpetuate violence. Sentenced in absentia for “propaganda,” he plans to return. While he deems collapse inevitable but timing unpredictable, he cautions Western engagement as if confronting rational actors and endorses a unified, referendum-led transition, noting calls for Reza Pahlavi’s return.

articles.title: Julio Iglesias denies sexual abuse claims of two former female employees
articles.trailText: Women allege Spanish singer subjected them ‘to inappropriate touching, insults and humiliation … in atmosphere of control’
articles.summary: Julio Iglesias has publicly denied allegations by two former employees—Rebeca and Laura—who claim that in 2021 he subjected them to non-consensual touching, insults and humiliation at his Dominican Republic and Caribbean residences. The women, a domestic worker and a physical therapist, allege anal and vaginal penetration with fingers and unwanted kisses, and file charges of sexual assault and human trafficking at Spain’s Audiencia Nacional. They say medical tests for STIs were enforced and hope their complaint will encourage other victims to speak out. Iglesias calls the accusations false and vows to defend his dignity.

articles.title: Friday briefing: How the Robert Jenrick saga exposes a hollowed out Tory party
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: A sudden dismissal appears to have forced the hand of the most senior Tory to join the ranks of Reform so far
articles.summary: Robert Jenrick, former shadow justice secretary and ex-leadership contender, was abruptly dismissed, stripped of the whip and suspended by Tory leader Kemi Badenoch over an alleged plot to defect in a way that would damage colleagues. Hours later he emerged on stage with Nigel Farage as Reform UK’s highest-profile recruit, denouncing the Conservatives as “rotten” and “failed.” The dramatic scalp exposes deep fractures in the Tory party, challenges Badenoch’s authority, bolsters Farage’s effort to recast Reform as a credible governing alternative and signals potential further defections on the centre right.

articles.title: BTS named their new album Arirang. What is so striking about their choice?
articles.trailText: The title is loaded with meaning for all Koreans, and will give fans globally an insight into the folksong culture that shaped the world’s biggest K-pop group
articles.summary: BTS announced their comeback and world tour with a new full-length album, Arirang, due 20 March. Named after Korea’s most beloved folk song, Arirang symbolizes journeys from despair to hope and exists in over 60 versions with some 3,600 lyrical variants. It served as a protest anthem under Japanese colonial rule and remains a shared cultural bridge between North and South Korea, now UNESCO heritage. By choosing this title, BTS reaffirms their Korean roots over globalized K-pop trends and invites millions of fans to rediscover a core cultural heritage through their music.

articles.title: Death of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s son prompts calls for overhaul of Nigeria’s healthcare sector
articles.trailText: Pleas for scrutiny of system fraught with accusations of negligence after one-year-old’s death in hospital
articles.summary: Nigerians demand urgent healthcare reform after bestselling author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie’s 21-month-old son died following an alleged propofol overdose at a Lagos hospital. Adichie and husband Dr Ivara Esege have sued for negligence amid chronic power outages, staff shortages, dilapidated facilities and surgeon errors. A 1:9,801 doctor-patient ratio worsened by 16,000 doctors emigrating. High-profile cases—from scissors left inside a patient to ventilator mishaps—and cultural stigma highlight weak regulation and secrecy. Advocates hope this tragedy triggers accountability, transparency and a comprehensive overhaul of Nigeria’s public health sector.

articles.title: Rightwing leaders endorse Viktor Orbán in Hungarian election campaign video
articles.trailText: Italy’s Giorgia Meloni and France’s Marine Le Pen among figures showing support for Hungary’s prime minister
articles.summary: An online campaign video by Viktor Orbán features endorsements from rightwing figures—including Italy’s Giorgia Meloni and Matteo Salvini, France’s Marine Le Pen, Germany’s Alice Weidel, Austria’s Herbert Kickl, Czech PM Andrej Babiš, Serbia’s Aleksandar Vučić, Argentina’s Javier Milei and Israel’s Benjamin Netanyahu—promoting Orbán as a bulwark of national sovereignty, cultural roots and peace in Ukraine. Ahead of the 12 April vote, polls show him trailing challenger Péter Magyar amid economic stagnation and corruption concerns, prompting Fidesz to tout Orbán’s global networks as an asset. Observers warn the outcome’s symbolic weight for the broader illiberal-populist movement.

articles.title: María Corina Machado presents Trump with her Nobel peace prize medal
articles.trailText: Trump heaped praise on the Venezuelan opposition leader for presenting him with ‘her Nobel peace prize for the work I have done’
articles.summary: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado presented her 2025 Nobel peace prize medal to Donald Trump at the White House, lauding his ‘principled action’ for Venezuelan freedom despite Nobel rules barring transfer. The symbolic gift follows Trump’s January 3 capture of Nicolás Maduro and his surprise endorsement of Maduro’s vice-president Delcy Rodríguez as acting president over Machado. Analysts view Machado’s gesture as an attempt to win back US support amid her movement’s diminishing influence. Rodríguez denounced the US intervention but expressed willingness for diplomatic talks in Washington.

articles.title: Iran protests appear to slow under weight of brutal crackdown
articles.trailText: At least 2,637 people have been killed in the unrest, with Iranian authorities saying they have ‘no plan’ to execute protesters
articles.summary: Iran’s mass protests have waned under a harsh security crackdown that has killed at least 2,637 people and jailed tens of thousands. After President Trump threatened military strikes and boasted 800 executions were halted, US envoys warned all options remained on the table, drawing Russian, French and British divisions at the UN. Tehran intensified internet blackouts, seized Starlink dishes and aired forced confessions. Originating on 28 December over economic hardship, the unrest has spread nationwide, prompting G7’s threat of additional sanctions while analysts doubt imminent regime collapse.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian attack destroys Kharkiv energy facility as UK pledges emergency support
articles.trailText: Response crews at work following strikes in Ukraine’s second city as Britain commits £20m after Zelenskyy declares energy emergency. What we know on day 1,423
articles.summary: Russian forces destroyed a major energy facility in Kharkiv, plunging millions into darkness in a winter air campaign, Mayor Ihor Terekhov said. President Zelenskyy declared a state of emergency, chaired damage-assessment meetings and reported new strikes in Kyiv, where 300 apartment blocks remain without heat after 9 January attacks. Britain pledged £20m for emergency power and heating in homes, hospitals and schools, and Norway granted $200m. Prime Minister Svyrydenko eased curfews, extended Kyiv school holidays and relaxed power import rules. IMF chief Georgieva visited Kyiv to advance an $8.1bn lending plan. Opposition leader Tymoshenko faces anti-corruption charges.

articles.title: Could Labor’s hate speech laws damage Australia’s free speech? Here’s what you need to know about the contentious bill
articles.trailText: Coalition, Greens and free speech advocates have expressed concern about the bill, which looks set to fail in its current form. Here’s why
articles.summary: Labor’s hate speech bill would criminalise hateful expression, create a “hate group” register, a gun buyback scheme and new visa powers. Critics—including the Coalition, Greens, civil libertarians, universities and human rights bodies—warn its rushed drafting risks subjective rulings, a chilling effect on speech, journalism and research, and excessive ministerial discretion. Greens and Liberals won’t support it as is, pushing for clearer definitions, academic exemptions and stronger protections for free political communication.

articles.title: Spanish police break up gang that used swimmers to hide cocaine on ships
articles.trailText: Almost 2.5 tonnes of narcotic seized and 30 people arrested after 15-month investigation into drug-smuggling network
articles.summary: After a 15-month probe triggered by a 88kg October 2024 seizure in Mijas, Spain’s Policía Nacional arrested 30 suspects and seized 2.475 tonnes of cocaine and assault weapons. Investigators uncovered a Balkan-Colombian cartel network using the ‘monkey’ technique—young swimmers to load drugs onto Europe-bound container ships and armed teams to intercept them near Gibraltar. Operations off Cádiz and Portuguese waters netted 1.4 tonnes and armed stowaways. Authorities also recovered boarding ladders, eight luxury vehicles, €166,000, jewellery and later a record 10-tonne cocaine haul off the Canary Islands.

articles.title: Anger in Iceland over incoming US ambassador’s ‘52nd state’ joke
articles.trailText: Thousands sign petition calling on Iceland’s foreign minister to reject Trump ally Billy Long’s nomination
articles.summary: Thousands in Iceland have signed a petition urging Foreign Minister Þorgerður Katrín Gunnarsdóttir to reject Donald Trump’s nominee Billy Long as US ambassador after he joked that Iceland should become the 52nd US state. Reykjavík’s foreign ministry has sought clarification from the US embassy, and over 3,200 people condemned the remarks as offensive to Icelandic sovereignty. Long later apologised to Arctic Today, insisting his comment was a jest sparked by friends joking about the US special envoy to Greenland. Icelandic MPs warned the quip exemplifies growing US disregard for small states and raises serious Arctic security concerns.

articles.title: Gulf states and Turkey warned Trump strikes on Iran could lead to major conflict
articles.trailText: US allies’ lobbying appears to have helped persuade president to hold off for now on military assault
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Turkey and Oman mounted a last-minute campaign urging President Trump to postpone planned airstrikes on Iran, warning of regional chaos. Saudi Arabia barred US overflight, while FM Prince Faisal bin Farhan held calls with Iran, Oman and Turkey. Tehran’s outreach—led by FM Abbas Araghchi’s visits to Arab capitals—and its portrayal of Israel as the greater threat have eased tensions. US evacuated key personnel from al-Udeid airbase amid Iranian threats. Gulf states, wary of Iranian proxies yet fearful of state collapse, and Turkey advocate renewed dialogue.

articles.title: Opposition candidate Bobi Wine claims ‘massive ballot stuffing’ as Uganda goes to polls
articles.trailText: Wine calls for voters to ‘reject the criminal regime’ on tense day of voting as some poll stations remain closed for hours
articles.summary: In Uganda’s Jan 14 general election, opposition leader Bobi Wine alleged “massive ballot stuffing,” an internet blackout and the abduction of his party agents by security forces as voters faced delayed openings, missing ballots and faulty biometric kits. President Yoweri Museveni, in power since 1986 and seeking a seventh term, has tightened repression—tear-gassing rallies, arresting hundreds and suspending rights groups—to neutralize the youthful pop star’s momentum. Wine urged Ugandans to “reject the criminal regime” amid fears of post-vote violence. Observers say Museveni’s control over state resources, constitutional amendments and a weakened judiciary make his victory almost certain, raising questions about succession and the future of democratic reform.

articles.title: California refuses to extradite doctor over abortion pill: ‘Not today. Not ever’
articles.trailText: Gavin Newsom says state will reject Louisiana’s ask, citing laws protecting providers from out-of-state prosecution
articles.summary: Gov. Gavin Newsom denied Louisiana’s extradition request for California-based Dr. Remy Coeytaux, indicted under Louisiana’s criminal abortion statute for mailing abortion pills via Aid Access to a patient in October 2023. Citing California’s shield law, Newsom vowed to protect providers from out-of-state prosecution. Louisiana AG Liz Murrill labeled the stance as condoning “illegal, medically unethical” abortions. Coeytaux faces fines and up to 50 years hard labor if convicted. The dispute, reminiscent of New York’s refusal to extradite another aid-access doctor, underscores interstate clashes over abortion policy.

articles.title: Prado cannot be like ‘the Metro at rush hour’, says Madrid museum’s chief
articles.trailText: Record 3.5 million visited in 2025 and plans are afoot to ensure gallery does not become overburdened like Louvre
articles.summary: In 2025 the Prado museum in Madrid welcomed a record 3.51 million visitors—an increase of 56 000 on 2024 and 816 000 over a decade—yet director Miguel Falomir insists “the Prado doesn’t need a single visitor more.” With 65% of guests from abroad, Falomir wants more Spaniards to reclaim this cultural treasure. To avoid over-tourism woes like the Louvre (8.7 million visitors in 2024) and its director’s warning of a “physical ordeal,” the Prado’s new “Plan Host” will optimise entry flows, cap group sizes, enforce a no-photo rule, and prioritise visit quality over raw numbers, safeguarding masterpieces such as Velázquez’s Las Meninas and Bosch’s The Garden of Earthly Delights.

articles.title: Dutch far-right activist Eva Vlaardingerbroek appears to lose right to UK visa-free travel
articles.trailText: Influencer, who promotes conspiracy theories and anti-immigration rhetoric, posts notification that her ETA has been cancelled
articles.summary: Eva Vlaardingerbroek, a Dutch anti-immigration influencer known for “great replacement” conspiracy rhetoric, has had her UK electronic travel authorisation revoked after the Home Office deemed her presence “not conducive to the public good.” Hungarian prime minister Viktor Orbán reposted her notification and invited her to Hungary, where she spoke at CPAC in 2024. In London she joined a far-right protest with Tommy Robinson, calling for “remigration” of migrants. The ETA cancellation forces her to apply for a visa. Critics in the US and UK—including Liz Truss and MP Rupert Lowe—accuse the government of stifling free speech, following previous bans on extremists.

articles.title: Boeing knew of engine defect on UPS plane that crashed in Kentucky, report says
articles.trailText: US transportation safety board releases initial report on November 2025 crash that killed 15 people in Louisville
articles.summary: NTSB's preliminary report found Boeing alerted MD-11 operators in 2011 about failures of the spherical bearing race securing engines to wings but deemed it not a safety-of-flight issue, advising only routine inspections. On 4 November 2025, a UPS MD-11F's left-wing engine caught fire and detached after takeoff from Louisville, killing three crew and 12 people on the ground (including a victim who later died). The part had failed four times on three aircraft. UPS and FedEx briefly grounded their MD-11 fleets, and lawsuits allege UPS negligently kept planes flying despite known defects.

articles.title: Abortions at record high in England and Wales ‘driven by cost of living’
articles.trailText: Providers and doctors say lack of access to contraception another reason for the 11% rise in procedures in 2023
articles.summary: Official data show abortions in England and Wales rose 11% in 2023 to 23.0 per 1,000 women—the highest since 1967—driven by the cost-of-living crisis and limited contraception access. Providers report long waits for GP appointments, prescription delays and scarce method choice, while emergency contraception remains underused. Rates remain highest among women aged 20–24 and have doubled for those over 35 since 2013. Early medical termination now accounts for 89% of procedures by nine weeks, with 72% managed at home via telemedicine, highlighting its role in improving access.

articles.title: ‘Bigger and lower’: bull in Dutch painting once had much larger testicles
articles.trailText: Experts at the Mauritshuis in The Hague believe Paulus Potter toned down The Bull to respect 17th-century sensibilities
articles.summary: The Mauritshuis in The Hague has revealed via 18 months of X-rays and conservation work that Paulus Potter’s 1647 masterpiece The Bull originally featured much larger, pendulous testicles, which he later halved to conform to 17th-century decorum. Conservators Abbie Vandivere and Jolijn Schilder note similar prudish edits followed controversy over Potter’s Pissing Cow for Princess Amalia van Solms. Looted by Napoleonic troops in the 1790s, The Bull—celebrated for its lifesize scale innovation—was triumphantly returned after Waterloo. Now on public display behind glass, the fully restored composition conceals Potter’s initial bolder anatomy beneath his final paint layer.

articles.title: Spain’s meteorologists subjected to ‘alarming’ rise in hate speech, minister warns
articles.trailText: Environment minister says attacks on social media affect perceptions of meteorology and denigrate researchers’ work
articles.summary: Spain’s environment minister, Sara Aagesen, has alerted prosecutors to an alarming rise in hate speech and online attacks targeting meteorologists and climate researchers. Citing ministry-commissioned studies, she notes that 17.6% of posts on X include personal attacks, denigration and climate denial, with 49.1% featuring emergency denialism. Researchers warn that sustained social pressure can deter scientists from public engagement, hamper the spread of accurate data and fuel conspiracy theories about weather manipulation. Aagesen offers full support to prosecutors, stressing the vital role of scientific communicators in combating climate disinformation.

articles.title: Greenland’s defence is ‘common concern’ for Nato, Danish PM says as European troops fly in
articles.trailText: British troops among those to take part in joint exercises as Trump’s desire to own Greenland still ‘intact’ despite talks
articles.summary: Mette Frederiksen declares Greenland’s defence a “common concern” for NATO as dozens of European troops—including units from France, Germany, UK, Norway and Sweden—arrive for Operation Arctic Endurance scoping missions. The deployments aim to reassure allies after Donald Trump’s renewed threat to seize Greenland and assert US security needs. A NATO working group on Arctic security will follow. Greenland PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen emphasizes self-government and that the island is “not for sale.” Denmark plans a larger, rotational Arctic force; NATO debates adding air-policing to its Arctic posture.

articles.title: Greenland: new shipping routes, hidden minerals – and a frontline between the US and Russia?
articles.trailText: Key maps show the growing strategic importance of Greenland as Arctic ice melts under global heating
articles.summary: Greenland’s melting ice—27% drop in Arctic sea extent since 1981–2010—unlocks new commercial passages: the northern sea route (“Polar Silk Road”), north-west passage and central Arctic corridor. In 2025, container ship Istanbul Bridge cut China–UK transit to 20 days; Bering Strait transits rose 175% to 665 in 2024. Strategic stakes surge: US missile base at Pituffik, Trump’s hawkish purchase talk, NATO expansion, Russia’s Arctic bases, China’s “near-Arctic” push. Beneath receding ice lie 1.5 Mt of rare earths at Kvanefjeld and Tanbreez, drawing global mining bids.

articles.title: British diplomat expelled from Russia after ‘baseless’ accusation of being a spy
articles.trailText: Moscow’s allegation that unnamed diplomat is affiliated with UK secret service comes ‘out of desperation’, Foreign Office says
articles.summary: Russia has expelled an unnamed British diplomat, accusing them without evidence of ties to UK intelligence and giving two weeks to leave. Moscow’s foreign ministry, citing info on the diplomat’s alleged secret-service affiliation, warned of a swift “mirror” response if Britain escalates. Deputy head of mission Danae Dholakia was summoned for the notice. The UK Foreign Office condemned the move as “malicious and baseless,” attributing it to Kremlin desperation and undermining diplomatic norms, and is weighing retaliatory measures. This follows regular UK-Russia tit-for-tat expulsions since the Ukraine war and last year’s removal of a British diplomat and spouse on similar spying claims.

articles.title: Trump says Iran has told him ‘killing has stopped’ as he pulls back from strike threats
articles.trailText: US president says he has been assured by Tehran ‘there’s no plan for executions’ of protesters
articles.summary: Trump said he’s been told by Tehran killing of protestors has stopped and executions aren’t planned, so he’s paused strikes. He offered no verification. Recent protests in Iran have seen thousands killed amid a government crackdown now purportedly halted. Israeli and Arab leaders urged US restraint to avoid escalation. The Pentagon stood down alert bombers, and US embassies curtailed staff movements. Iran denies execution plans; a death sentence for a protester was reportedly postponed. Global reactions included an UN emergency Security Council meeting and G7 warning of sanctions, while oil prices fell on eased conflict fears.

articles.title: How ‘day zero’ water shortages in Iran are fuelling protests
articles.trailText: Supply failures are dramatic example of way climate crisis threatens basic human needs – and with it political stability
articles.summary: Iran’s sixth year of drought has pushed Tehran, Mashhad and Tabriz to the brink of “day zero” water failure, with southern districts already dry and nightly cuts widespread. Reservoirs feeding the capital are 11% full, prompting threats to evacuate if rains don’t arrive. Protests over “water, electricity, life” have met crackdowns. Rapid warming, dam misuse and overexploited groundwater—after sidelining ancient qanat tunnels—have eroded supplies. Cross-border competition intensified as Afghanistan’s new Pashdan Dam captures 80% of the Harirud’s flow to eastern Iran. Combined with inflation, sanctions and subsidy reforms, chronic scarcity risks further unrest and underscores how climate and mismanagement jeopardise political stability.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Is your body really full of microplastics?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Numerous studies have found evidence of microplastics in the human body and warned of the risks to our health. But in the race to research this new field scientists may have drastically overstated the dangers
articles.summary: Good morning. Microplastics pervade every environment – from Everest to ocean trenches – and earlier studies reporting their presence in human cells, brains, placentas and testicles made headlines. But recent scrutiny by environment editor Damian Carrington and other chemists shows up to 18 high-profile papers may reflect false positives arising from methods like pyrolysis GC-MS misidentifying fats as plastics. Without standard protocols, quantification remains unreliable, so reported extreme body burdens are likely overstated. Microplastics still circulate in food, water and air, and prudent measures to limit exposure are advised while the field develops more rigorous assays and rejects expensive, unvalidated ‘plastic blood cleansing’ cures.

articles.title: Is it the end of the line for one of India’s most distinctive garments?
articles.trailText: The bandhgala jacket will no longer be part of the formal uniform for Indian Railways staff, following claims it symbolises a ‘colonial mindset’
articles.summary: Indian railways minister Ashwini Vaishnaw has removed the bandhgala – the high-collared “princely jacket” introduced as formal staff uniform in the late 19th century – calling it a symbol of a colonial mindset. Menswear designer Raghavendra Rathore, descendant of Jodhpur royalty, argues the bandhgala originated in Mughal courts and Rajput states centuries before British rule, evolving through adaptations like polo jackets and tight breeches. While British military tailoring influenced trims, he stresses the coat remains a uniquely Indian expression of royal tailoring. As Modi’s government pushes to eliminate colonial legacies, the choice of a replacement uniform remains uncertain.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy declares energy emergency as cities shiver
articles.trailText: Night-time temperatures dip close to -20C; minister outlines major problems with desertion and conscription evasion. What we know on day 1,422
articles.summary: Ukraine’s president Zelenskyy declared a state of emergency in the energy sector after Russian strikes cut power and heat amid sub-20°C nights, ordering boosted imports, 24/7 repair crews and new warming centres with curfews lifted where safe. He criticised Kyiv’s slow response, setting up a coordination HQ under Denys Shmyhal. Ex-President Trump blamed Ukraine for stalling peace talks, diverging from EU and US views. The EU plans a €90bn loan allowing non-EU arms purchases. Defence minister Fedorov flagged 200k deserters, conscription evasion, a ₴300bn funding gap, but highlighted private missile and robotics growth. The US renewed talks on Lukoil assets.

articles.title: Iran crisis explained: what we know so far
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says ‘there’s no plan for executions’ in Iran, as Iranian airspace closes and reopens, and some western countries urge their citizens to leave
articles.summary: Iran reopened its airspace after a near-five-hour closure amid US–Iran tensions. President Trump said he’d been told execution plans in Iran have been halted, while Iranian FM Abbas Araghchi denied any intention to carry out hangings and confirmed a stay for Erfan Soltani, the first protester sentenced to death. The US requested an emergency UN Security Council meeting; some US, UK, Indian, Spanish, Italian and Polish personnel were evacuated and citizens urged to leave via land routes. HRANA reports 2,571 killed and over 18,100 arrested. G7 ministers warn of more sanctions over the crackdown.

articles.title: US and UK military withdraw some personnel from Middle East amid Iranian threats
articles.trailText: Tehran closes its airspace to almost all flights after threatening to strike US bases in Middle East if it carries out pledge to intervene in Iran
articles.summary: Amid threats by Iran to hit US bases if Washington intervenes, US and UK pulled staff from Qatar’s al-Udeid air base; Tehran briefly shut airspace and carriers like Lufthansa rerouted flights. Donald Trump, while keeping military options on the table, claimed “on good authority” Iran halted executions of protesters—though HRANA records 2,571 killed and 18,100 detained in nationwide unrest. Iranian FM Araghchi urged diplomacy, neighbors warned any strike could spark a region-wide war, and the US State Department urged citizens to leave Iran. First anti-government protester Erfan Soltani saw his execution postponed.

articles.title: Execution of condemned Iranian protester postponed, family told
articles.trailText: Family stayed up until dawn waiting for news of Erfan Soltani who was due to be executed on Wednesday
articles.summary: Erfan Soltani, a 26-year-old clothing shop employee from Karaj, was the first Iranian protester sentenced to death amid nationwide unrest sparked by a currency crash. Arrested Jan 8 after joining demonstrations, he was denied access to a lawyer and swiftly condemned. His execution, scheduled for Jan 14, was abruptly postponed without explanation after his family endured sleepless nights. Rights groups highlight his case—over 18,000 arrests and 2,571 deaths reported—as emblematic of Iran’s rapid, arbitrary trials that label dissenters “enemies of God” to crush protest.

articles.title: Trump insists Greenland is crucial for national security after Denmark talks
articles.trailText: Talks fail to solve ��fundamental disagreement’ over Arctic island controlled by Copenhagen
articles.summary: Donald Trump insisted Greenland is vital to US national security, claimed Denmark cannot defend it, and pressed for US "takeover" after talks with Danish and Greenlandic ministers ended in deadlock. Denmark’s foreign minister and prime minister rejected any seizure, vowed enhanced Danish-led NATO presence. France, Germany and Norway pledged troops for a multinational Arctic force. A US-Denmark-Greenland working group was agreed to address security concerns while respecting Danish sovereignty. EU leaders, including von der Leyen and Macron, backed Greenland’s right to self-determination; Americans largely oppose forceful annexation.

articles.title: US announces start of second phase of Gaza ceasefire
articles.trailText: No details given of committee members who will run territory but they are expected be technocrats, not politicians
articles.summary: US special envoy Steve Witkoff announced on social media the launch of phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, centred on forming a “national committee for the administration of Gaza” staffed by 15 Palestinian technocrats (some linked to Fatah) to oversee daily governance, disarmament of unauthorized forces, reconstruction and demilitarization. Committee start awaits approval by Trump’s yet-to-be-established “peace board.” Despite Israel’s partial troop withdrawal and reduced bombardment, hostilities persist and the return of final hostage Ran Gvili’s remains is demanded to avoid “serious consequences.” Oversight to be by UN veteran Nickolay Mladenov. Talks in Cairo also cover further Israeli pullback, Rafah opening and aid flows.

articles.title: Venezuela regime claims release of political prisoners is sign of new era
articles.trailText: NGOs estimate that there are still close to 1,000 political prisoners in Venezuela despite claims by new leaders
articles.summary: Venezuela’s acting president Delcy Rodríguez hailed the recent release of 406 political detainees as evidence of a “new political moment” following the US-backed seizure of Nicolás Maduro. Rodríguez vowed more frees while dismissing NGOs like Foro Penal, which estimate 800–1,000 prisoners remain, accusing them of “lying” and charging families. Despite claimed mass releases, independent groups have verified far fewer. Critics warn repression persists—phone searches, arrests of Maduro-critics—and a state of emergency orders capture of US-attack supporters. The US welcomed detained Americans’ release; Trump canceled further strikes. Meanwhile, Washington seeks oil-tanker seizures and resumed embassy talks.

articles.title: Why western diplomats are wary of predicting end days for Iran’s regime
articles.trailText: Failure to foresee shah’s fall in 1979 was diplomatic disaster, but experts see little indication of mass defections now
articles.summary: Recalling the 1979 diplomatic failure to foresee the shah’s overthrow, Western envoys now caution against predicting Iran’s regime collapse despite mounting protests. Academic analysts report no large-scale defections from the leadership or IRGC, noting regime unity behind security crackdowns. Reformist voices like President Masoud Pezeshkian briefly urged dialogue, but hardliners led by Supreme Leader Khamenei, the IRGC and parliament speaker Ghalibaf have dominated. The unprecedented lethal repression, crippling censorship and economic grievances underscore an unsustainable status quo, hinting that only deep economic reforms targeting IRGC interests could provoke a genuine split at the top.

articles.title: Gaza war leads to 41% fall in births prompting allegations of reproductive violence
articles.trailText: Israel’s war in Gaza has caused high numbers of maternal and neonatal deaths, say two reports
articles.summary: Two joint reports by Physicians for Human Rights and the University of Chicago Law School document a 41% drop in Gaza births between Jan–Jun 2025, with 2,600 miscarriages, 220 pregnancy-related deaths, 1,460 premature births and 1,700 underweight newborns. They attribute this to Israeli strikes on hospitals and the al-Basma IVF clinic, blockade-induced shortages and forced displacement, arguing it constitutes reproductive violence that meets genocide convention criteria. UN agencies cite over 6,000 maternal deaths and 150,000 displaced pregnant or nursing women.

articles.title: UN charter reminder for the attorney general | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Richard Hermer’s comments on Trump and Venezuela show that he seems to have forgotten what it says, writes Mark Seddon
articles.summary: In a letter, Mark Seddon praises María Fernanda Espinosa’s habit of sending the UN charter to every member state as a reminder of binding commitments and urges her to revive this if elected UN secretary-general. He suggests leaders who flout international law—Donald Trump after his Venezuela actions, Vladimir Putin, Benjamin Netanyahu evading arrest warrants, and notably UK attorney general Richard Hermer, who proposes a dubious “UK right” to weigh diplomacy over calling out allies—all need the charter. Seddon notes the 80th anniversary of the first UNGA in London and quips that Hermer should receive his copy at the January 17 commemoration.

articles.title: Italian influencer Chiara Ferragni cleared of fraud over charity Christmas cake scandal
articles.trailText: Social media star says ‘justice has been done’ in cases involving cakes and Easter eggs being promoted as charitable initiatives
articles.summary: Influencer Chiara Ferragni, 38, was acquitted on January 14 in Milan of aggravated fraud charges tied to her 2022 pandoro Christmas cake campaign and 2021–22 Easter egg fundraisers, after prosecutors sought a 20-month sentence. Italy’s antitrust authority had fined her €1 million and Balocco €420k over misleading claims that cake and egg sales funded a Turin children’s hospital—receipt limited to a €50k donation—while Ferragni later paid €1.2 m to settle the egg case. The scandal cost her 200k followers, major clients like Coca-Cola, spurred AGCOM influencer registration rules and ignited debate on ad transparency.

articles.title: Quebec premier François Legault resigns from post in surprise move
articles.trailText: Legault’s abrupt resignation follows months of chaos that has rocked the governing Coalition Avenir Québec party
articles.summary: Quebec Premier François Legault abruptly resigned as leader of the Coalition Avenir Québec, citing pride in forming back-to-back majority governments since 2018. He’ll stay on until a new CAQ leader is chosen, leaving little time ahead of fall elections. His administration was battered by ministerial departures, backlash over physician pay reform, a costly online licensing scandal, controversial secularism (Bill 21) and French language laws, plus immigration disputes. Polls show the CAQ at risk of losing all seats as the Parti Québécois surges, promising a third referendum. It follows the Quebec Liberal leader’s recent resignation amid vote-buying allegations, leaving both major parties leaderless.

articles.title: How far will Europe go to defend Greenland from Trump?
articles.trailText: The president’s disregard for international law exposes the continent’s reliance on the US. Leaders have hardened their language in support of Denmark, but the price of confronting him is high
articles.summary: Trump’s threat to seize Greenland — after his US raid on Venezuela and Stephen Miller’s boast that "nobody will fight" for it — has exposed Europe’s reliance on US security and prompted a rare joint statement by six European powers reaffirming Danish sovereignty. Denmark seeks de-escalation under NATO treaties, while the UK under Starmer aims for a "modus vivendi" addressing Arctic security via existing agreements. Analysts propose EU offers of billions in reinvestment for Greenland, trade and regulatory measures targeting Trump’s political base, or even expulsion of US bases in Europe to pressure Washington. Europe must balance diplomatic, economic and strategic options short of combat to defend Greenland’s autonomy.

articles.title: ‘They were just shooting everyone’: Iranian Australians left distraught with no confirmation their family is safe
articles.trailText: While some Iranian Australians have received calls from loved ones in Iran, others remain in limbo amid communications blackout
articles.summary: Over a week into Iran’s communication blackout amid ‘Woman, Life, Freedom’ protests, more than 85,000 Iranian-Australians, including activist Mohammad Hashemi and artist Dr Moj Habibi, have agonised over family safety. Partial easing of call bans allowed brief contacts: Hashemi’s brother recounted mass street shootings; unofficial death tolls reach 12,000. Hashemi’s cousin was executed in 2023. Some receive scant updates; others remain cut off under the internet shutdown. Community leaders report acute stress, cling to hope, call for accountability and debate potential US intervention.

articles.title: Yulia Tymoshenko reportedly accused of scheming to bribe Ukrainian MPs
articles.trailText: Opposition figure says she denies any accusations against her and suggests office raid is linked to election speculation
articles.summary: Ukraine opposition leader Yulia Tymoshenko is accused by anti-corruption prosecutors of running a cash-for-votes scheme to sway MPs—including some from President Zelenskyy’s party—to erode his parliamentary majority. Sapo and Nabu agents raided her Fatherland party offices, seizing dollars, phones and documents. Prosecutors point to intercepted Signal chats directing bribes for votes on firing security and defence chiefs. Tymoshenko, who rose to fame in the Orange Revolution and was jailed in 2011, denies the charges as politically driven ahead of possible elections and will challenge them in court.

articles.title: France records more deaths than births for first time since end of second world war
articles.trailText: Country joins EU neighbours in demographic crunch of ageing population and falling birthrate
articles.summary: France recorded 651,000 deaths versus 645,000 births in 2025—the first time since WWII—while its fertility rate fell to 1.56 (lowest since WWI), down 24% since 2010. A public survey cited child-rearing costs (28%), societal anxieties (18%) and work–life balance (15%) as barriers to having children. Life expectancy hit records (85.9 years for women, 80.3 for men) and 22% of the population is 65+, equaling those under 20. Population edged up to 69.1 million thanks to 176,000 net migrants. With ageing trends mirroring other EU states and rising far-right anti-immigration sentiment, forecasts warn France could fall to 59 million by 2100 without immigration.

articles.title: ‘Are they going to bring their violence here?’: Fear – but little preparation – as threat of invasion looms over Greenland
articles.trailText: Ahead of high-stakes talks, people tell of alarm, thoughts of fleeing and lack of information on what to do if US invades
articles.summary: Greenland’s 57,000 residents are gripped by anxiety after Trump’s repeated threats to “acquire” the Danish territory, prompting fears of US military invasion, impromptu evacuation planning and sleepless nights. Locals track US flights, debate relocating families and demand guidance from authorities. Ahead of crucial talks in Washington between Greenlandic, Danish and US officials, communities confront colonial trauma, rising Inuit identity politics and divisions over US ties versus Danish protection, urging clear security protocols and solidarity amid geopolitical uncertainty.

articles.title: Ukraine able to buy weapons from non-European suppliers with €90bn EU loan
articles.trailText: Loan will be repaid only if Moscow pays reparations and plan to use Russia’s frozen assets still on table
articles.summary: EU executive proposed a €90bn loan to Ukraine, comprising €60bn for military and €30bn budget support, repayable only if Russia pays reparations. An alternative financing via €210bn of frozen Russian assets remains possible. Funds expected in April pending EU member states and Parliament approval, tied to anti-corruption and rule-of-law benchmarks. To ensure European industry benefits, Ukraine must prioritize EEA/EFTA/EU suppliers but may source weapons from non‐European providers if essential systems (e.g., US air defences) aren’t available. 24 member states back the plan; Hungary, Czech Republic and Slovakia abstain.

articles.title: Julio Iglesias faces claims female staff were told to have sexual health tests, say reports
articles.trailText: Spanish singer, 82, had already been accused of sexually assaulting two female former employees
articles.summary: Spanish singer Julio Iglesias, 82, faces sexual assault and human trafficking accusations from two former employees—Rebeca and Laura—at his 2021 Caribbean villas. Amid a joint three-year probe by elDiario.es and Univision, testimonies reveal he ordered 10–12 female staff to undergo gynaecological screenings for STDs, supported by medical records for five workers. Rebeca alleges repeated non-consensual anal and vaginal penetration; Laura cites unwanted kisses and breast touches. Spain’s Audiencia Nacional is investigating, while calls mount to strip Iglesias of Madrid honours amid debate over ethics versus presumption of innocence.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: Over-budget and under-regulated – the NHS’s ADHD crisis
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With NHS England set to double its budgeted spending on ADHD services this year, the system is at breaking point – patients are being failed and private providers are cleaning up
articles.summary: NHS England’s ADHD services are forecast to spend £314 m by April 2026—more than double the £150 m budget, creating a £164 m overspend. A Guardian investigation led by Sarah Marsh, using data from 32 integrated care boards and Freedom of Information requests, reveals soaring demand has spawned a fragmented, under-regulated private market. Private equity-backed clinics now receive £58 m annually, but rushed assessments, GP refusals and lack of national care standards leave many patients unsupported amid a heated ‘overdiagnosis’ debate.

articles.title: ‘The settlers brought the violence’: the ethnic cleansing of a West Bank village
articles.trailText: Ras ‘Ein al ‘Auja is a community of about 135 families – and the only one remaining in this part of the Jordan valley
articles.summary: Ras ‘Ein al ‘Auja, home to 135 Bedouin families in the West Bank’s Jordan valley, was ethnically cleansed in January 2026: settlers, including state-backed “hilltop youth,” used arson, theft, beatings, utility cuts and night raids to force residents out. Masked shepherds celebrated on donkeys while security forces ignored or abetted them. Over 250 sq km have been seized; Palestinians face near-total impunity despite international warnings.

articles.title: Cymbal of unity? South Korea and Japan leaders bash out K-pop hits after summit talks
articles.trailText: South Korean president Lee Jae Myung had his work cut out, picking up his drumsticks alongside Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi, a former heavy metal drummer
articles.summary: At the Nara summit, South Korea’s President Lee Jae Myung and Japan’s PM Sanae Takaichi capped talks by drumming K-Pop Demon Hunters’ Golden and BTS’s Dynamite in matching blue kits—she a former metal-band drummer, he a novice who mastered basic beats in minutes. The surprise session, complete with exchanged drumsticks, underscored Takaichi’s use of K-culture as soft diplomacy while Lee navigates Beijing’s overtures. Beyond theatrics they signed deals on 1942 Chosei mine DNA testing, scam-crime cooperation, economic security and North Korea, and toured Horyu-ji temple, sidestepping comfort-women and territorial disputes.

articles.title: Iran protests: what we know so far about the spiralling anti-government demonstrations
articles.trailText: Protests began over the fall in value of the currency have grown into wider demonstrations and calls for the fall of Iran’s clerical establishment
articles.summary: Since early January protests over a plunge in the rial have spun into nationwide anti-clerical demonstrations. Amid a government-imposed internet blackout, human rights groups report over 2,000 killed—90% civilians—and 16,700 arrested; hospitals document hundreds of gunshot eye injuries. US President Trump has threatened “strong action,” urged continued unrest and floated military options, while SpaceX’s Starlink seeks to restore connectivity. Iran schedules executions for protestors, prompting global condemnation from EU states, Russia and the UN.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Estonia leads with entry ban on Russians who fought in Ukraine
articles.trailText: ‘We call on other countries to do the same’ says foreign minister; major fires after Ukraine targets Russian drone plant at Taganrog. What we know on day 1,421
articles.summary: Estonia has banned 261 Russians who fought in Ukraine from entry, urging an EU-wide visa ban; its interior ministry counts 1.5 million participants, half frontline, as security threats. Ukraine’s foreign minister praised the measure. Kyiv forces struck the Atlant Aero drone plant in Taganrog, causing major fires, while two tankers (Matilda, Delta Harmony) were hit in the Black Sea without casualties. Russia launched one of its largest raids—nearly 300 drones, 18 ballistic and 7 cruise missiles—killing at least four and disrupting heat and power across eight Ukrainian regions.

articles.title: South Korean prosecutors demand death penalty for former president Yoon Suk Yeol
articles.trailText: Yoon is on trial for insurrection charges, after trying to declare martial law in late 2024
articles.summary: South Korean prosecutors have sought the death penalty for former president Yoon Suk Yeol in an unprecedented insurrection trial—the first for a Korean head of state since 1996’s coup-era prosecutions—over his December 2024 martial law declaration. They argue he deployed troops to block a parliamentary vote, planned the operation since October 2023 via detailed memos, and plotted to torture officials and cut media power. Under the criminal code, insurrection carries only death, life with labour, or life without labour. Prosecutors also demand life with labour for ex-defence minister Kim Yong-hyun. Yoon was impeached in December, removed in April 2025, and faces eight more trials; the verdict is due February 19.

articles.title: Keir Starmer offered place on Trump’s Gaza ‘peace board’
articles.trailText: Prime minister is yet to receive a formal invitation, but the Guardian has been told that Starmer is expected to accept
articles.summary: Donald Trump has invited UK PM Keir Starmer to join a “peace board” overseeing Gaza’s administration and reconstruction under the recent Israel-Hamas ceasefire plan. While formal invite is pending, Starmer is expected to accept amid ongoing talks about the board’s composition. Chaired by Trump, it will include top global leaders; Tony Blair was dropped after Middle Eastern objections and shifted to an executive board with Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff. Foreign sec. Yvette Cooper affirmed UK support for the fragile ceasefire and humanitarian efforts. Starmer argues international engagement on trade and defence is vital to tackling UK cost-of-living challenges.

articles.title: ‘They want to break us’: Russian energy grid strikes give freezing Kyiv some of its darkest days
articles.trailText: Impact of raid on infrastructure rivals early weeks of war when tanks tried to force their way into Ukrainian capital
articles.summary: On the night of Jan 9, after presidential warnings of imminent Russian airstrikes, missiles and drones targeted Kyiv’s energy grid—hitting substations and leaving 70% of the city without power as temperatures fell to –19 °C. Residents like Tetiana Shkred cooked through the night by candlelight, then sheltered in unheated corridors, while others relied on battery banks, generators and municipal warming tents. Ukrenergo warns Moscow aims to ‘disconnect the city’ and force evacuations. Despite power cuts, community volunteering and emergency services are critical to survival.

articles.title: Trump promises ‘help is on its way’ and tells Iranians to ‘keep protesting’
articles.trailText: US president gives clearest signal yet that he might take military action against Tehran over killing of demonstrators
articles.summary: Donald Trump urged Iranians to “keep protesting” and promised “help is on the way,” signaling possible military action over Tehran’s deadly crackdown on demonstrations. He cancelled talks with Iran, warned of “very strong action” if protesters are executed, and threatened 25% tariffs on any country trading with Iran. The State Department ordered US citizens to leave. European diplomats doubt Iran will bend without a sustained bombing campaign. Trump’s stance, supported by allies like Senator Lindsey Graham, rejects nuclear talks and escalates economic and military pressure on the regime.

articles.title: Louisiana officials seek to extradite abortion provider from California
articles.trailText: Louisiana law enforcement officials allege California doctor mailed abortion pills to a woman in the southern state
articles.summary: Louisiana AG Liz Murrill has filed an extradition request for California obstetrician Remy Coeytaux, accusing him of violating Louisiana’s criminal abortion statute by mailing abortion pills via Aid Access to a Louisiana resident in October 2023. Coeytaux faces fines and up to 50 years of hard labor under state law. The move intensifies the legal showdown between abortion-ban states and blue-state "shield laws," echoing Texas’s failed suit against a New York doctor. The extradition surfaced amid Louisiana’s bid to join a federal challenge to mifepristone access; more indictments may follow.

articles.title: A long, dire history of US interference in Iran | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Raza Griffiths says the US should give up its act as the world’s policeman; plus letters from Bryn Hughes and Maged Karim
articles.summary: Letters to The Guardian criticize longstanding US meddling in Iran—from the 1953 Mossadegh coup and support for the Shah’s repression, through arming Saddam Hussein in the Iran–Iraq war and fueling Israeli attacks on Iranian civilians—to Donald Trump’s recent calls for insurrection as a domestic distraction. Writers question America’s credibility and urge focus on addressing US policing and ICE abuses at home. Meanwhile, survivors of Iranian dictatorships stress that protests reject all tyranny, not monarchy, and back the NCRI’s 10-point plan led by Maryam Rajavi for a secular, democratic, non-nuclear republic that guarantees human rights and global peace.

articles.title: Gerry Gable obituary
articles.trailText: Founder of Searchlight magazine who was a formidable figure in the fight against fascism and the extreme right
articles.summary: Gerry Gable, who died aged 88, was a pioneering anti-fascist campaigner and founder of Searchlight magazine. From 1960s 62 Group collaborations and Communist trade-union organising to clandestine infiltration of the National Front, BNP and neo-Nazi cells, he exposed extremist funding, leadership and bomb plots such as the Notting Hill Carnival attack. Relaunched in 1975 with Maurice Ludmer, Searchlight became the Anti-Nazi League’s research arm, crippled far-right electoral fortunes and inspired Sweden’s Expo. After a 2011 split with HOPE Not Hate, he reconciled in 2023, led Searchlight’s digital transformation and withstood threats and legal battles over five decades.

articles.title: Why Trump’s options are limited when it comes to using force against Iran
articles.trailText: As US president tells protesters ‘help is on the way’, any military action would be unlikely to succeed
articles.summary: Though President Trump vows support to Iran’s protesters, US military options are scant: recent carrier drawdowns leave no continuous strike group, forcing reliance on regional airbases whose hosts and US assets could face Iranian missile retaliation. Urban strikes risk civilian casualties and may rally regime support. Assassinating Khamenei would trigger major escalation without guaranteeing collapse. Cyberattacks or limited demo strikes lack decisive impact. Overall, any force option is legally fraught, operationally constrained and unlikely to aid on-ground dissent.

articles.title: Greenland and Denmark unite against US advances before White House talks
articles.trailText: Island’s PM tells media event with Danish counterpart ‘we choose Denmark’ and will not be owned or governed by US
articles.summary: Greenland’s PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen, joined by Danish PM Mette Frederiksen, declared “we choose Denmark” ahead of White House talks as US VP JD Vance and Secretary Marco Rubio meet their Danish and Greenlandic counterparts. Their statement rejects Donald Trump’s renewed threat to seize the largely self-governing island, emphasizing allegiance to Denmark, NATO and the EU. Residents in Nuuk fear for their identity and security as Trump argues for Arctic control against China and Russia. Allies including Germany and other NATO members vow to defend Greenland’s sovereignty and consider boosting Arctic deployments.
