Greenland’s government insists any US takeover is unacceptable while pursuing dialogue within NATO’s framework.

articles.title: Julio Iglesias accused of sexual assault by two female former employees
articles.trailText: Spanish singer allegedly subjected women to ‘inappropriate touching, insults and humiliation’
articles.summary: Spanish singer Julio Iglesias, 82, is accused by two former employees—a domestic worker (“Rebecca”) and a physical therapist (“Laura”)—of sexual assault at his Dominican Republic and Bahamas estates in 2021, including non-consensual touching, digital penetration, insults and humiliation in a climate of control. A joint elDiario.es–Univision investigation, citing 15 testimonies and documents (photos, call logs, medical reports), led the women to file complaints in Spain’s Audiencia Nacional for sexual assault, human trafficking and labour abuses. Iglesias’s camp denies the claims, while Madrid’s regional president defends him and Spain’s deputy PM calls the allegations “chilling.”

articles.title: German church’s televised ‘slime Jesus’ provokes fury on right
articles.trailText: Christmas Eve live broadcast showed holy child portrayed by female performance artist writhing in sticky rice paper
articles.summary: During an ARD televised Christmas Eve mass at St Mary’s in Stuttgart, performance artist Eleni Sismanidou portrayed the infant Jesus swaddled in sticky rice paper to mimic vernix. Officiant Fr Thomas Steiger argued the visceral scene showed “how radically God becomes human”. Rightwing outlets like Bild ran “slime Jesus” headlines, viewers called it a “breathing alien” and “sick and twisted”, and CDU councilor Klaus Nopper condemned it as “disgusting” wokeness. After 1,400+ complaints, Bishop Klaus Krämer apologized, acknowledged hurt faith, admitted TV-driven liturgy cuts, and vowed tighter review of future broadcasts.

articles.title: Marine Le Pen’s appeal against embezzlement conviction begins
articles.trailText: Trial’s outcome will determine whether leader of far-right National Rally can run for French presidency in 2027
articles.summary: Marine Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Rally, is appealing a 2025 conviction for embezzling €4.8m in EU parliamentary funds via fake MEP assistant jobs, which led to a five-year ban from public office. The appeal hearing runs until 12 February, with a verdict due before summer to determine her eligibility for the 2027 presidential race. If her ban is cut to under two years she could stand; otherwise her protege Jordan Bardella, who currently leads polls, will become RN’s candidate. Le Pen maintains her innocence and warns of judicial overreach.

articles.title: Spanish author lambasts linguistic academy over social media influence
articles.trailText: Arturo Pérez-Reverte says ‘an illiterate pundit, YouTuber or influencer’ has more impact than a literary prize winner
articles.summary: Novelist Arturo Pérez-Reverte, a member of the Spanish Royal Academy (RAE), accused the institution in El Mundo of prioritising social media influencers over professional writers. He derided the RAE’s “anything goes Taliban” faction that cedes to media, political and social usage, lamenting that “an illiterate pundit, YouTuber or influencer” wields more impact on language than literary prize winners. Pérez-Reverte warned this erosion of standards and unity across the Hispanic world threatens the academy’s mission. The RAE’s plenary will review his critiques and propose operational reforms.

articles.title: Workers at Chinese factory that produces Labubu toys are being exploited, says NGO
articles.trailText: Exclusive: China Labor Watch says people aged 16-18 employed without required special protections
articles.summary: China Labor Watch found that Shunjia Toys in Jiangxi employed over 4,500 workers making Pop Mart’s Labubus, including 16-17-year-olds assigned full assembly-line duties without required legal protections. Investigators documented forced signing of blank labor contracts, inadequate safety training, unrealistic daily quotas (4,000 toys per 25–30 workers), and monthly overtime exceeding 100 hours, far above China’s 36-hour limit. Production estimates exceeded planned annual capacity of 12m units. Pop Mart says it audits suppliers and is investigating the NGO’s findings, pledging to strengthen oversight and require corrective actions if breaches are confirmed.

articles.title: Israel poised to start construction of bypass through heart of West Bank
articles.trailText: Road project, part of blueprint for new illegal settlement in E1 area east of Jerusalem, is considered a tool of annexation
articles.summary: Israel will next month begin building a sealed bypass road through the E1 area east of Jerusalem, a core element of a new illegal settlement plan that fragments the West Bank and solidifies de facto annexation. The corridor will channel Palestinian vehicles separately, bar them from existing roads and isolate communities like As Saraiya, Elazariya and Abu Dis while enabling home demolitions. Critics call it an “apartheid road” and warn it will destroy prospects for a Palestinian state. Palestinians have 45 days to object; over 20 countries and the ICJ deem it illegal.

articles.title: Search for single-tusked elephant after 22 killed in India rampage
articles.trailText: Eastern region on high alert as authorities try to track animal tearing through villages in Jharkhand after apparently becoming separated from herd
articles.summary: A rogue young single-tusked elephant, believed separated from its herd, has killed 22 people since 1 January across West Singhbhum district in Jharkhand. Attacks—mostly nocturnal—have struck villages like Bandijhari and Chaibasa, trampling families and a forest official. Over 100 forest personnel and wildlife specialists from three states are scouring 30km-a-day search zones; three tranquilisation attempts have failed. Officials have imposed night-time forest bans and high alert warnings. The spree underscores escalating human–elephant conflict in India, driven by deforestation, water scarcity and the loss of 10% of historic elephant corridors, with over 2,800 fatalities recorded in five years.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What has sparked Iran’s latest wave of protests – and what might happen next
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: A researcher with a focus on the region explains what’s behind deadly nationwide demonstrations and what a hardening of public opinion against the state might bring
articles.summary: Nationwide protests in Iran since 28 December, sparked by electronics vendors in Tehran’s bazaars, have left at least 648 dead and over 10,600 arrested amid soaring inflation (40%+), bread prices up 110%, water shortages, air pollution and political repression. After initial concessions, security forces stormed hospitals, imposed internet blackouts, threatened death sentences and blamed foreign enemies. Middle East politics expert Eskandar Sadeghi-Boroujerdi says anger stems from economic collapse, mismanaged infrastructure and a corrupt oligarchy, weakening the Islamic Republic. Potential next steps include further crackdowns, US military pressure under Trump’s threats, internal elite defections or limited reforms if moderates prevail.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Oreshnik missile sparks anger at UN security council
articles.trailText: Strike on Lviv that used nuclear-capable ballistic missile a ‘dangerous, inexplicable escalation’. What we know on day 1,420
articles.summary: At an emergency UN Security Council meeting US and UK envoys condemned Russia’s firing of a nuclear-capable Oreshnik missile at Lviv as a “dangerous, inexplicable escalation”. Russia said it hit an aviation repair factory; Ukraine said the strike, part of wider drone and rocket attacks, struck an unknown site. The rare multiwarhead missile, used twice likely with dummy warheads, is viewed as symbolic and may lack accuracy for conventional bombs. Concurrent Russian assaults on Kyiv, Kharkiv and Odesa caused civilian casualties and infrastructure damage, and two civilian food ships in the Black Sea were attacked. The UN recorded a record 2,514 civilian deaths in Ukraine in 2025. Kyiv also granted US-linked Dobra Lithium rights to mine the Dobra deposit.

articles.title: An ecosystem of smuggled tech holds Iran’s last link to the outside world
articles.trailText: Despite internet blackout, a small number of Iranians are risking their lives to share messages as protests continue
articles.summary: After the harshest internet blackout in years amid nationwide protests, a small network of Iranians uses smuggled tools—Telegram proxies, the Ceno browser and 50,000–100,000 covertly imported Starlink terminals—to send videos, photos and calls abroad. They face military-grade jamming, drone hunts and a 2025 law branding Starlink use as espionage—punishable by up to 10 years in prison. Meanwhile, Tehran races to replace the open web with a closed “national internet” of government-approved domestic apps and sites.

articles.title: Russia working to circumvent sanctions to ensure India oil imports continue
articles.trailText: Delhi is world’s second largest purchaser of Russian crude, which is now cheaper than oil from Middle East
articles.summary: As the world’s second-largest buyer since the Ukraine war, India imports heavily discounted Russian crude via Russia restructuring its export chain—using new non-Rosneft/Lukoil intermediaries—to sidestep US sanctions and keep flows high. Despite US threats of up to 500% tariffs and November sanctions targeting Rosneft/Lukoil buyers, four of India’s top seven refineries still rely on Russian barrels. Imports dipped from 1.7m to 1.2m bpd in December but are set to rebound as $9–$10 per barrel savings outweigh compliance risks. Only Reliance halted purchases, eyeing Venezuelan oil for EU markets.

articles.title: ‘The real ringleader’: the Venezuelan security chief with a $25m bounty on his head
articles.trailText: Security chief Diosdado Cabello is nicknamed the Octopus for good reason, with the regime’s fate said to rest with him
articles.summary: Diosdado Cabello, nicknamed “the Octopus,” commands Venezuela’s security apparatus as interior minister, overseeing police, prisons and state enterprises after three decades in Chavismo. Rivaling Nicolás Maduro and aligned with interim president Delcy Rodríguez, he wields media influence via his TV show Con el Mazo Dando. A US indictment and $25 m reward for his capture, plus Maduro’s recent abduction, have weakened his position, forcing a delicate balance between intimidation and appeasement of Washington. Yet many Venezuelans view him as the regime’s true power.

articles.title: Berry nice to meet you: bumper fruit crop could lead to huge mating season for NZ’s endangered kākāpō
articles.trailText: After a four-year wait, the abundant fruiting of the rimu tree could inspire the world’s heaviest parrots to boost their population
articles.summary: After a four-year gap, a ‘mega-mast’ of native rimu trees has triggered breeding in New Zealand’s critically endangered kākāpō, the world’s heaviest and only flightless nocturnal parrot. The species recovered from 51 individuals in 1995 to 236 today under a DOC programme, including 83 breeding-age females. When rimu fruit is abundant every two to four years, females can raise two to three chicks on the nutrient-rich berries. Males perform night-time lek booms audible up to 5 km to attract mates. This season sees many younger females but variable success; populations on three predator-free islands are nearing habitat capacity, posing a relocation challenge as numbers grow.

articles.title: China pressing European countries to bar Taiwan politicians or face crossing a ‘red line’
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Chinese officials are using a ‘highly specific’ interpretation of EU rules to suggest Taiwanese figures should not be granted visas, officials say
articles.summary: Chinese officials urged EU countries to use a strict interpretation of Schengen and diplomatic law to bar Taiwanese politicians' visas, warning they'd cross Beijing's 'red line.' They issued note verbales in November and December to multiple capitals and embassies, citing the Schengen Borders Code and Vienna Convention, arguing Taiwan visits threaten China-EU relations. They targeted trips by Taiwan's vice-president and foreign minister, condemning Hsiao Bi-khim's speech at the European Parliament. Norway, Finland and the UK rejected interference, while analysts see the move as part of Beijing's strategy to isolate Taiwan internationally.

articles.title: Greenland says it cannot accept US takeover ‘under any circumstances’
articles.trailText: Self-governing island stresses it is member of Nato, which is looking at improving Arctic defences, through Denmark
articles.summary: Greenland’s self-governing government has rejected President Trump’s threat to seize the island “under any circumstances,” affirming its status as a member of NATO via Denmark and pledging to strengthen Arctic defences within that framework. The refusal comes as NATO chief Mark Rutte and alliance members explore options—from new missions to exercises—to counter perceived Russian and Chinese activity. Denmark invokes a 1951 treaty on US bases, while EU, US senators, and China weigh in on Arctic security and Greenland’s strategic importance.

articles.title: Iran holds pro-government rally as regime seeks to downplay protests
articles.trailText: Speaker of parliament says country fighting four-front war after minister claims unrest has ‘come under total control’
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of pro-government supporters rallied in Tehran’s Enqelab Square as parliament speaker Mohammad Bagher Ghalibaf decried a “four-front war” against economic, psychological, military and terrorist threats, vowing retaliation against the US. Ayatollah Khamenei called the demonstration a warning to Washington, while the foreign minister claimed protests were “under total control.” Independent reports cite at least 648 dead amid a 16-day uprising over economic hardship, internet blackouts, forced confessions and looming executions. Opposition figure Reza Pahlavi urged security defections, and Germany and Canada condemned the crackdown.

articles.title: Dozens of artists call for end to Israel’s ‘systematic attacks’ on Gaza hospitals
articles.trailText: Actors, doctors and human rights leaders sign letter calling for restoration of medical care to ‘collapsed’ system
articles.summary: Dozens of artists including Cynthia Nixon, Mark Ruffalo and Ilana Glazer, alongside doctors and rights groups such as B’Tselem and Physicians for Human Rights, have signed a letter urging Israel and world leaders to end systematic attacks and blockade collapsing Gaza’s healthcare. Highlighting the death of five-year-old Hind Rajab when her ambulance was shelled, signatories demand immediate humanitarian and medical access, noting 94% of hospitals damaged, 1,722 healthcare workers killed and 18,500 patients awaiting evacuation. They cite a UN panel’s finding of “medicide” and condemn Israel’s ban on aid groups like MSF, which supply one-in-five hospital beds. Israel denies these claims.

articles.title: Iran says it is open to talks with US amid protest crackdown
articles.trailText: Foreign minister says talks possible only on basis of respect after Trump threatened ‘very strong’ military response
articles.summary: Iran’s FM Abbas Araghchi said Tehran is open to nuclear negotiations with Washington on a basis of mutual respect, even as supreme leader Khamenei and hardliners remain opposed. President Trump claimed Iran had requested talks and warned of “very strong” military action if nationwide protests—violently suppressed with estimates of 300–3,000 dead—persist. The US is reviewing options, including intervention and using Elon Musk’s Starlink to breach Iran’s internet blackout. Meanwhile, reformist calls for dialogue are sidelined by hardline rallies and denunciations of US interference.

articles.title: Eva Schloss obituary
articles.trailText: Holocaust survivor, educator and bestselling author who was a co-founder of the Anne Frank Trust UK
articles.summary: Eva Geiringer Schloss (1929–2026), Holocaust survivor who in childhood befriended Anne Frank and later became her posthumous stepsister when Otto Frank married her mother in 1953. Deported in 1944 to Auschwitz-Birkenau, she survived thanks to a nurse cousin’s intervention, while her father and brother perished. After the war she married Zvi Schloss, ran an antiques business, and from 1986 devoted herself to Holocaust education. Co-founder of the Anne Frank Trust UK, co-author of Eva’s Story, The Promise and After Auschwitz, and appointed MBE in 2012, she lectured widely, urging tolerance and remembrance.

articles.title: How Iran’s protest movement has gained increasing momentum – a visual guide
articles.trailText: Demonstrations initially focused on economic issues but as they have grown and become political the regime has responded with deadly force
articles.summary: Iran’s protests began in late December as shopkeepers in Tehran rallied against a 50% rial collapse and surging inflation. They have morphed into the largest nationwide anti‐regime uprising in years, with chants of “death to the dictator” targeting Supreme Leader Khamenei. Security forces and the Basij militia have killed hundreds, arrested thousands and severed internet and phone access. Satellite links relay images of burning cars and casualties. Echoing the 2009 election and 2022–23 Woman, Life, Freedom protests, some demonstrators even call for exiled Pahlavi’s return. President Pezeshkian blames “rioters” and foreign enemies; Trump threatens military, cyber-attacks and tougher sanctions as the US and Israel press for regime change after last summer’s bombing of Iranian military and nuclear sites.

articles.title: People in Iran: share your views on the current situation
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from Iranians living in Iran or abroad about how the crisis has affected your life and those of your friends and family
articles.summary: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, has warned that while Tehran “is not seeking war, it is fully prepared” and cautioned adversaries against any “miscalculation.” His remarks follow Donald Trump’s claim that Iran has sought negotiations, even as the US president weighs “very strong” military options over a crackdown on protesters that has reportedly left hundreds dead. The Guardian invites Iranians at home and abroad to share firsthand accounts of daily life amid the unrest, views on possible US intervention and the impact on friends and family, with strict guidance on maintaining security and anonymity.

articles.title: Spanish police seize 10 tonnes of cocaine hidden in ship off Canary Islands
articles.trailText: Haul represents country’s largest seizure at sea, with officers digging bales out from vast amount of salt
articles.summary: Spain’s Policía Nacional carried out its largest maritime cocaine interception, seizing 9,994 kg of the drug concealed in salt aboard a merchant vessel 332 miles off the Canary Islands. Operation White Tide—coordinated with Brazilian federal police, the US DEA, the UK’s NCA, plus French and Portuguese authorities—uncovered 294 bundles and a firearm, arresting 13 suspects. The ship, en route from Brazil, was towed to Santa Cruz de Tenerife after running out of fuel. This haul surpasses the 1999 record of 7.5 tonnes and contributes to Spain’s record 123 tonnes seized in 2024.

articles.title: Hungary grants asylum to former Polish minister amid abuse of power investigation
articles.trailText: Former justice minister Zbigniew Ziobro faces allegations he ran a criminal group while in government
articles.summary: Former Polish justice minister Zbigniew Ziobro—key figure in PiS judiciary reforms that alarmed the EU—has been granted political asylum in Hungary amid a Polish investigation into alleged abuse of power. Prosecutors have filed 26 charges accusing him of running a criminal group, misusing victims’ aid funds for political patronage and acquiring Pegasus spyware against rivals. Ziobro denies wrongdoing, calling the probe a Tusk-led “vendetta” and vowing to stay abroad until Poland’s rule of law is restored. Budapest’s government, led by Viktor Orbán, says it has sheltered multiple Poles facing political persecution. Poland’s new pro-EU coalition has waived his immunity and seeks his arrest this week.

articles.title: Trump’s other Latin American feud: why Colombia’s Petro is not Maduro
articles.trailText: Leftwing leader rallies his supporters as US president accuses him of drug trafficking and threatens military action
articles.summary: After a year of tit-for-tat insults and echoes of the Maduro case, US president Donald Trump publicly accused Colombia’s leftwing leader Gustavo Petro of personally flooding the United States with cocaine, slapped sanctions on him and his family, revoked visas and even threatened military action. Petro—Colombia’s first democratically elected leftist president (2022), with no personal indictments—rallied supporters, touting record 836.8 t cocaine seizures in 2025. A conciliatory phone call this week, hailed as “good” by both sides, eased tensions, but deep policy rifts and looming March legislative elections remain.

articles.title: Carney heads to Beijing as Trump’s America First agenda forces Canada into trade rethink
articles.trailText: Canada’s PM seeks to smooth over past ructions in relationship with China as trade war takes its toll
articles.summary: In January 2026 PM Mark Carney visits Beijing—the first Canadian leader in nearly a decade—to mend ties strained by U.S. “America First” trade policies and Chinese canola tariffs. Carney aims to diversify exports from their dependency on the U.S. (76% share) and limited 4% to China by expanding energy and agriculture sales, while urging Beijing to lift punitive duties and address political detainees. Yet risks linger over Chinese election meddling, Arctic territorial encroachments, human rights abuses, and past hostage detentions of Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor. Analysts caution Carney to secure safe trade deals without compromising critical sectors or Canada’s liberal values.

articles.title: ‘Big step forward’: Myanmar military faces Rohingya genocide case at UN court
articles.trailText: Survivors of violence hope proceedings will bring justice a step closer and set a precedent for future genocide allegations
articles.summary: On January 12 at the ICJ in The Hague, The Gambia opened its case against Myanmar’s military, alleging genocide during 2016–17 clearance operations that killed, raped and burned Rohingya villages, forcing 700,000 to flee to Bangladesh. Survivors, many from Cox’s Bazar camps, will testify through January 29, marking the court’s first full genocide trial since 2013 and shaping how intent may be inferred from patterns of violence. Myanmar, now ruled by the junta that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi, denies the charges and presents its defense from January 16. A ruling within 6–12 months could enforce provisional measures and set a precedent for future cases like South Africa’s against Israel.

articles.title: Monday briefing: How Elon Musk’s Grok is being used as a tool for digital sexual abuse
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The chatbot is being used to digitally undress photos of women and children. What can politicians actually do to stop it, and what does it say about our control of the internet?
articles.summary: Elon Musk’s Grok AI is being exploited to digitally undress women and children, creating non-consensual deepfake sexual images that child protection groups classify as CSAM. UK tech secretary Liz Kendall and deputy PM David Lammy condemned the tool’s misuse, and ministers have threatened X bans under the Online Safety Act, granting Ofcom powers to fine or block services. Musk countered that restrictions curb free speech even as X limited Grok’s image features to paying users. Experts warn rapid rollout outpaced safeguards, exposing gaps in AI regulation and online safety.

articles.title: ‘Act of family vengeance’: French defamation case highlights perils of writing autofiction
articles.trailText: Complaint against Cécile Desprairies over Nazi collusion novel alleges that ‘resentment permeates the entire work’
articles.summary: French historian Cécile Desprairies is being sued by her brother and cousin for defamation over her autofiction novel La Propagandiste (2024), which depicts her morphine-addicted mother and a great-uncle as a pro-Nazi propaganda designer. Plaintiffs call it a “family vengeance” lacking evidence and demand its pulping. Longlisted for the Prix Goncourt, the book typifies Europe’s autofiction boom that has spawned disputes from Knausgård’s threatened suits to Christine Angot’s privacy damages. Under France’s 1881 defamation law, only the living are protected; a verdict is due March 17.

articles.title: What can the EU and Nato do to stop Trump from trying to claim Greenland?
articles.trailText: The territory and the European bloc are trying to see off the US president, who has said control of Greenland is essential to national security
articles.summary: Facing Trump’s threats to seize Greenland for US national security, the EU and NATO are exploring: intensified diplomacy via US-Danish defence treaty updates and high-level lobbying; boosting Arctic military presence and joint exercises under NATO; leveraging the EU’s anti-coercion trade instrument; doubling EU economic support to match Danish grants; and deploying up to 5,000 European rapid-reaction troops as a deterrent. Each measure aims to uphold Greenland’s self-determination and Denmark’s sovereignty without direct confrontation.

articles.title: Civil society groups condemn ‘dangerous’ plans for more anti-protest powers
articles.trailText: Dozens including TUC join force to oppose ‘wide-ranging’ move to increase police powers in England and Wales
articles.summary: Over 40 civil society groups—including TUC, Amnesty UK, Greenpeace and the Palestine Solidarity Campaign—have denounced an amendment to England and Wales’s crime and policing bill that empowers police to ban or restrict protests by assessing the 'cumulative impact' of repeated demonstrations in a vaguely defined area. They warn this draconian move, targeting Palestinian solidarity marches, threatens freedom of assembly and could block anti-racist, climate or Pride events due to unrelated prior protests. The coalition urges the government to drop the proposal and review existing protest laws; the Home Office maintains it balances community protection with peaceful protest rights.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Nightfall – Britain races to develop ballistic missile for Kyiv
articles.trailText: UK government starts contest to have deep-strike prototypes delivered within 12 months; heat-starved Kyiv under Russian attack again. What we know on day 1,419
articles.summary: Britain has launched Project Nightfall, a £27m competition to design and deliver three deep-strike, ground-launched ballistic missile prototypes within 12 months. Each will carry 200kg warheads beyond 500km and be fired from vehicles in rapid salvo before withdrawal. Ukraine currently relies on US Atacms and self-developed Sapsan missiles as it withstands renewed Russian bombardment of Kyiv, leaving over 1,000 buildings without heat. Kyiv’s forces struck three Lukoil Caspian oil platforms to disrupt Russian revenue. President Zelenskiy warns of worsening winter hardship while Pope Francis and international leaders call for peace amidst reports of Russian drone strikes in Voronezh.

articles.title: Iranian student killed during protests was shot in head ‘from close range’
articles.trailText: Rubina Aminian, 23, struck by bullet from behind after joining Tehran protest from college, says human rights group
articles.summary: Rubina Aminian, a 23-year-old Kurdish textile and fashion design student at Tehran’s Shariati College, was shot in the head from close range after leaving campus to join anti-government protests, Iran Human Rights reports. Her family traveled from Kermanshah to identify her among hundreds of victims and, barred by intelligence forces, were forced to bury her roadside between Kermanshah and Kamyaran. Described by her uncle as a fearless advocate for freedom and women’s rights, Aminian is one of the few named fatalities in a crackdown that the Human Rights Activists News Agency estimates has killed 538 protesters and led to over 10,600 arrests.

articles.title: ‘The streets are full of blood’: Iranian protests gather momentum as regime cracks down
articles.trailText: Demonstrators recount experiences on the frontlines as protest movement rapidly moves beyond government’s control
articles.summary: Triggered by a sudden currency crash and soaring prices, protests erupted nationwide on Dec 28, drawing families, students and elderly chanting “death to Khamenei” and calls for Pahlavi’s return. Authorities imposed an internet blackout, deployed rifle-toting security forces and stormed a hospital in Ilam. Human Rights Activists News Agency reports at least 538 killed, over 10,600 arrested. President Pezeshkian urged dialogue but repression intensified; foreign minister dismissed unrest as routine. Diaspora and Reza Pahlavi amplified videos via Starlink glimpses. US President Trump threatened military aid. Despite live fire, nightly rallies persist under blackout, protesters plead for international support.

articles.title: Avalanche kills British skier in La Plagne in the French Alps
articles.trailText: Man, thought to be in his 50s, was found under 2.5 metres of snow and had been skiing off-piste
articles.summary: On Sunday afternoon, a British skier in his 50s was killed by an off-piste avalanche at La Plagne resort in France’s Savoie region. A 50-strong rescue team of medics, ski-school instructors and dogs excavated 2.5 m of snow over 50 minutes to recover him. He was skiing with a group but lacked an avalanche transceiver and professional guide. La Plagne extended condolences to his family.

articles.title: Unpredictable Trump weighs up Iranian pleas for help against calls for restraint
articles.trailText: Observers say if US gets response wrong to Tehran’s repression it could end up entrenching regime’s ​position
articles.summary: Trump faces conflicting advice over his pledge to support Iranian protesters under violent crackdown. While opposition figures—including Nobel laureate Shirin Ebadi and exiled Shah son Reza Pahlavi—urge swift US action to prevent crimes against humanity, partners like Qatar and analysts from Chatham House warn that strikes risk reinforcing Tehran’s regime narrative and unifying elites. Military options targeting IRGC bases are weighed against civilian casualty risks in densely populated Tehran. Critics highlight the administration’s lack of strategy after bold promises in Ukraine and Gaza, urging focus on achievable political transition rather than hasty intervention.

articles.title: Iran warns US against attack as protest death toll reportedly soars
articles.trailText: Tehran issues warning after Donald Trump says US stands ready to help amid crackdown on demonstrations
articles.summary: Iran has warned the US against military or cyber intervention after President Trump signaled readiness to “rescue” protesters facing a brutal crackdown. Rights groups report between 192 and 538 confirmed deaths (likely undercounts) and over 10,600 arrests amid a nationwide internet shutdown. Hardliners threaten US and Israeli targets if Iran is attacked, while President Masoud Pezeshkian blames foreign-backed “terrorists” and calls a “national resistance march.” Protest leader arrests have begun under martial law, as exiled prince Reza Pahlavi urges continued mass demonstrations for regime change.

articles.title: Trump tells Cuba to ‘make a deal’ or face the consequences
articles.trailText: No more Venezuelan oil or money will flow to the communist-run island after Maduro’s fall, says US president
articles.summary: Donald Trump warned Cuba via Truth Social that no Venezuelan oil or money will flow after US forces captured Maduro, urging Havana to “make a deal” or face undefined consequences. Shipping data show zero Venezuelan cargoes since the raid that killed dozens of Venezuelan and Cuban security personnel. Cuba’s president Miguel Díaz-Canel vowed to defend sovereignty. Some GOP lawmakers praised Trump’s stance. Separately, Washington and Caracas are negotiating a $2 bn Venezuelan oil-for-revenue deal, while the US State Department urged citizens to leave Venezuela amid militia checkpoints.

articles.title: Gaza’s garden is a rare story of hope | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Act of resistance | Amended signs | Curt waiters | Disgusted in Tunbridge Wells | Crossword clues | Smug travellers
articles.summary: Series of six brief letters: Taqwa Ahmed al-Wawi praises planting a garden in Gaza amid Israeli bombardment as an act of resistance and hope; Maggie Rylance quips that someone scrawled “This train takes ages” on a railway advert; Harry D Watson points out Russian waiters say “Slushayu” (“I’m listening”); Hilary Clarkson complains Tunbridge Wells residents face water cuts blamed on freezing weather; Anne Unseld spots a unicorn startup clue in the Quick Crossword; and John Quigley mockingly tallies the paper’s “50 places to go in 2026.” Readers are invited to submit letters.

articles.title: ‘Fateful moment’ for Denmark amid Trump threats to take over Greenland
articles.trailText: Danish prime minister says country is at a crossroads and accuses US of turning its back on Nato
articles.summary: Danish PM Mette Frederiksen warned Denmark faces a ‘fateful moment’ amid Donald Trump’s threats to seize Greenland, accusing the US of risking a break with NATO by menacing an ally. She spoke at a political rally ahead of talks between Danish, Greenlandic FMs and US Secretary of State Marco Rubio. Trump said America would act on Greenland ‘whether they like it or not,’ refusing to rule out force. Greenland’s leaders insisted only Greenlanders should decide their future. NATO partners, including Sweden, rallied to Denmark and condemned threatening rhetoric.

articles.title: EU wants ‘Farage clause’ in Brexit ‘reset’ talks with UK
articles.trailText: Move would mean Brussels would receive compensation if future government reneged on deal Starmer is negotiating
articles.summary: The EU’s draft Brexit reset agreement on agricultural trade, nicknamed the “Farage clause,” would require any party that withdraws to cover costs – echoing its €5.4bn Brexit adjustment reserve – to re-establish SPS border controls, infrastructure, recruitment and training. Brussels fears a future Reform-led government under Nigel Farage may cancel Keir Starmer’s deal and leave it out of pocket. UK officials insist exit clauses are standard, bilateral and symmetrical. Formal SPS talks, alongside carbon border adjustment and Erasmus reinstatement, begin this month and could take months.

articles.title: Underground church says leaders detained as China steps up crackdown
articles.trailText: Early Rain pastor said to be among those held in sweep that followed arrests of members of other unregistered churches
articles.summary: Leaders of the Early Rain Covenant Church in Deyang, Sichuan—pastor Li Yingqiang, his wife Zhang Xinyue, pastor Dai Zhichao and lay member Ye Fenghua—were detained in January amid an intensifying nationwide crackdown on unregistered “house” churches. At least four other members were briefly jailed; some remain off the grid. Authorities have also targeted Zion Church and a Zhejiang congregation since October, invoking charges such as “picking quarrels.” Under Xi Jinping’s sinicisation drive and new rules banning online sermons by unlicensed groups, Beijing is tightening ideological control over religious activity.

articles.title: Nobel Institute rejects María Corina Machado’s offer to share peace prize with Trump
articles.trailText: Organisers clarify award ‘cannot be revoked, shared or transferred’ after Venezuelan opposition leader’s comments
articles.summary: After Venezuela opposition leader María Corina Machado offered to share her Nobel Peace Prize with Donald Trump, the Norwegian Nobel Institute clarified that once awarded, Nobel prizes “cannot be revoked, shared or transferred.” Machado had dedicated her prize to Trump for his support of a democratic transition following US actions against Nicolás Maduro. Trump said accepting the prize would be a “great honour” and plans to meet Machado in Washington. The Nobel Committee emphasized its decisions are final and noted it never withdraws or comments on laureates’ later statements.

articles.title: Syrian forces expel Kurdish fighters as US strikes Islamic State targets
articles.trailText: Three hundred Kurds detained and further 400 evacuated following clashes in Aleppo
articles.summary: Syrian government forces detained about 300 Kurdish fighters and evacuated over 400 from Sheikh Maqsoud and Ashrafiyeh in Aleppo under a ceasefire after stalled talks on Kurdish integration into President al-Sharaa's government. At least 21 civilians died and 155,000 were displaced. Separately, US-led coalition, including Jordan, launched 'Operation Hawkeye Strike', conducting large-scale air raids on Islamic State positions across Syria in retaliation for December's Palmyra attack that killed US personnel.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv struggles to stabilise ruined power grid after major Russian attack
articles.trailText: Residents battle bitter winter cold inside unheated apartments; Ukraine confirms UN to hold emergency meeting Monday on Russian ballistic missile attack. What we know on day 1,418
articles.summary: Kyiv engineers raced to stabilise a power grid crippled by recent Russian strikes, leaving residents huddling in freezing apartments as heating, electricity and water remain unreliable. PM Svyrydenko warned load and damage persist amid rising heater use. Ukraine secured a UN Security Council emergency meeting Monday over Russia’s Oreshnik missile attack that UN spox Dujarric said caused significant civilian casualties. Zelenskiy’s negotiator conferred with US officials on a war-end framework. Cross-border strikes hit Belgorod, Volgograd, Voronezh regions and facilities in Zaporizhzhia and Pokrovsk.

articles.title: Protester pulls down national flag from Iranian embassy in London
articles.trailText: Demonstrator seen putting up pre-Islamic revolution lion and sun flag in support of rallies challenging Tehran regime
articles.summary: A protester climbed onto the balcony of the Iranian embassy in London, removed Iran’s flag and raised the pre-1979 lion and sun standard used by opposition groups, during a rally of 500–1,000 participants. Police made two arrests for aggravated trespass (one also for assault on an emergency worker) and continue to seek another suspect. Globally, demonstrators in Berlin rallied with the imperial flag and photos of exiled crown prince Reza Pahlavi. UK ministers, including foreign secretary Yvette Cooper and PM Keir Starmer, condemned violence against protesters inside Iran—where over 60 have died, 2,300 detained and internet access is restricted—and urged Tehran to respect peaceful assembly.

articles.title: ‘It’s younger people seeking some sort of spirituality’: UK Bible sales reach record high
articles.trailText: Surge in 2025 sales correlates with the growth in church attendances in England and Wales, research shows
articles.summary: UK Bible sales hit a record £6.3m in 2025, up 134% since 2019, coinciding with a 50% rise in church attendance in England and Wales. Industry research by SPCK Group and Nielsen BookScan shows younger, non-Christian backgrounds—especially 18–24s—are driving growth, drawn by social media influencers (e.g. Jordan Peterson) and a search for meaning amid post-pandemic uncertainty. Religion now outpaces other nonfiction genres. Critics warn against political appropriation of faith, but publishers see a genuine countercultural revival of Christianity among young men.

articles.title: Trinidad and Tobago went all in with the US – it will prove a costly misjudgment | Kenneth Mohammed
articles.trailText: Aligning itself with Washington and casually dismissing regional diplomacy has left the dual island nation isolated amid the Venezuela crisis, says Caribbean analyst Kenneth Mohammed
articles.summary: Kenneth Mohammed argues Trinidad and Tobago’s overt alignment with the US under PM Kamla Persad-Bissessar has collapsed its strategic ambiguity and isolated it amid the US attack on Venezuela and Maduro’s kidnapping. By dismissing Caricom solidarity and hosting US military assets, T&T risks over $1.2bn in oil and gas trade, regional boycotts and refugee influx. Both US and Venezuelan regimes use coercion, so smaller states have leverage only through diplomatic agility. This misjudgment exposes T&T to economic, diplomatic and security fallout.

articles.title: Greenlanders ‘don’t want to be Americans’, say political leaders amid Trump threats
articles.trailText: Five parties issue joint statement after US president warns he would acquire the island ‘the nice way or the more difficult way’
articles.summary: In response to Donald Trump’s renewed threats to acquire Greenland—“the nice way or the more difficult way”—the leaders of five Greenlandic parties, including PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen, issued a joint statement asserting “We don’t want to be Americans, we don’t want to be Danish, we want to be Greenlanders,” and demanding self-determination free from foreign interference. A 2025 poll shows 85% opposition to US takeover. Danish PM Frederiksen warned any attempt to annex would fracture NATO. The US operates a WWII-era base on the island and is eyeing its vast mineral and energy reserves.

articles.title: Iran’s internet shutdown is chillingly precise and may last some time
articles.trailText: Experts note the blackout is unprecedented in its extent but also selective, allowing some government communications
articles.summary: During escalating anti-government protests, Iran’s authorities imposed a 36-hour selective blackout, cutting 90% of traffic, blocking mobile calls and jamming Starlink, while whitelisting regime channels on Telegram, X and select university sites. Digital rights expert Amir Rashidi and infrastructure analyst Doug Madory say this shutdown is more refined and severe than 2019’s or Egypt’s 2011 outage, enabling only “bare necessities” communications for propaganda and governance. The whitelist-based approach suggests Tehran plans a long-term, China-style national intranet to sustain degraded connectivity.

articles.title: Indonesia blocks Musk’s Grok chatbot due to risk of pornographic content
articles.trailText: Move comes after governments and regulators from Europe to Asia have condemned the AI tool and some have opened inquiries into sexualised content
articles.summary: Indonesia has become the first country to temporarily block Elon Musk’s AI chatbot Grok over risks of pornographic and non-consensual sexual deepfake content, including depictions of minors. Communications Minister Meutya Hafid called such outputs a serious human rights violation and has summoned X officials for discussions. In response, xAI has restricted image generation and editing to paying subscribers while it strengthens safeguards. The move echoes growing inquiries from Europe to Australia—where PM Anthony Albanese and the eSafety Office warned of exploitative imagery—and UK regulators concerned about illegal sexual content on Grok.

articles.title: Quebec’s Lake Rouge vanished – but was it a freak natural event or caused by human actions?
articles.trailText: Experts and community trying to untangle mystery of outburst that saw water travel almost 10km overland into a bigger lake
articles.summary: Lake Rouge, a 3 sq km lake in northern Quebec, drained overnight last May in an unprecedented non-glacial outburst flood, its water traveling 10 km overland into a larger lake with no injuries reported. Cree community leaders and international scientists debate whether unusually high snowfall and rapid melt triggered the sudden bank collapse or if decades of logging and two severe wildfires—stripping forest cover, boosting runoff and saturating soils—accelerated the event. Hydrologists warn this unique case of bank failure could foreshadow similar mass water movements elsewhere.

articles.title: New protests erupt in Iran as supreme leader signals upcoming crackdown
articles.trailText: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei calls protesters ‘vandals’ and ‘saboteurs’ and blames US for instigating the unrest
articles.summary: Mass protests have erupted across Iran since 28 Dec, triggered by currency collapse but fuelled by demands for reform. Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei branded demonstrators “vandals” serving foreign agendas and vowed a harsher crackdown amid nationwide internet blackouts. Security forces have killed over 50 people and detained more than 2,270, according to rights groups. Protesters in Tehran, Mashhad, Tabriz and Qom chanted “death to Khamenei” and waved pre-1979 flags, as calls from exiled crown prince Reza Pahlavi encouraged further rallies. Western governments condemned the violence and urged restraint, while Iran accused the US and Israel of instigating unrest.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: UK earmarks £200m to prepare for possible Ukraine troop deployment
articles.trailText: British defence minister says money will be spent on vehicle upgrades, communication systems and counter-drone protection, ensuring troops are ready to deploy. What we know on day 1,417
articles.summary: Britain has earmarked £200 million ($270 million) to upgrade vehicles, communications and counter-drone systems as it prepares troops for a possible deployment to Ukraine, following a UK–France–Germany declaration to form a multinational force in the event of a ceasefire. The move coincided with Russia’s overnight strike of 242 drones and 36 missiles, including its new Oreshnik hypersonic weapon, on Kyiv and western regions. Ukraine has called an urgent UN Security Council meeting. The assault killed four, wounded 25, damaged 20 residential buildings (including the Qatari embassy), disrupted heating and water, and struck two cargo ships in the Black Sea, killing one Syrian crew member.

articles.title: Trump claims he has cancelled second wave of attacks on Venezuela
articles.trailText: US president does not elaborate on alleged plan for fresh strikes but says large naval presence in region will remain
articles.summary: Donald Trump said he cancelled a planned second wave of strikes on Venezuela after Caracas cooperated on oil-infrastructure rebuilding and released political prisoners, but kept a US naval armada in the Caribbean on standby. US forces seized a fifth tanker near Trinidad, and Trump plans to sell up to 50 million barrels of Venezuelan oil directly to approved US firms. Both sides will dispatch delegations to assess reopening embassies. Human rights groups dispute Caracas’ prisoner tallies. Trump will meet opposition leader María Corina Machado and agreed joint US-Colombian operations against the ELN, hinting at future land strikes on drug cartels.

articles.title: Growing protests in Iran do not necessarily herald a return to monarchy
articles.trailText: Despite significant support for the shah, Iranian society may be looking for any ‘escape from a dead end’
articles.summary: Protests that include calls for the exiled heir Reza Pahlavi and slogans for the shah reflect Iranians’ frustration with 47 years of clerical rule rather than genuine monarchist revival. Lacking a unified leadership or clear political program beyond ending corruption, repression and inflation, opposition rallies around any escape from a “dead end.��� Pahlavi’s supporters claim a referendum on his leadership, but Trump remains noncommittal, fearing entanglement. Activists and unions caution against externally imposed solutions or old authoritarian models, as Iran confronts a historic choice over religion, state power and its future governance.

articles.title: EU states back controversial Mercosur deal with Latin American countries
articles.trailText: Agreement after 25 years of negotiations prompts farmers to block roads in Paris, Brussels and Warsaw
articles.summary: EU member states approved a landmark Mercosur free-trade pact with Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay after 25 years of talks, clearing a qualified-majority hurdle despite France, Poland, Austria, Ireland and Hungary voting against and Belgium abstaining. Italy’s support under Giorgia Meloni averted a collapse. The European Parliament must still ratify it, with Ursula von der Leyen set to sign in Paraguay. The deal promises €50bn in extra EU exports by 2040, strategic access to critical minerals (lithium, niobium, nickel) and diversification from China, but has prompted farmer roadblocks and warnings of deforestation and food-security risks.

articles.title: Syrian army says it will renew Aleppo attacks after Kurds reject ceasefire terms
articles.trailText: Military opens window for civilians to leave as Kurdish groups turn down demand their fighters withdraw from city
articles.summary: The Syrian army vowed to renew strikes on Kurdish-majority Sheikh Maqsoud, Ashrafieh and Bani Zaid in Aleppo after Kurdish councils rejected a ceasefire that demanded fighter withdrawals by 3am. Damascus opened a civilian corridor from 1300–1500 GMT as tens of thousands fled and at least 21 were killed since Tuesday’s outbreak. The collapse of a March deal to integrate the US-backed SDF stalled merger talks; both sides accuse each other of war crimes. SDF leader Mazloum Abdi decried state shelling, while Turkey’s FM Hakan Fidan warned SDF obstinacy hampers peace.

articles.title: ‘An incomprehensible nightmare’: grief turns to anger over Swiss bar fire as Le Constellation owner arrested
articles.trailText: Jacques Moretti arrested on Friday as lawyers representing families of victims say investigators are not moving fast enough
articles.summary: Swiss authorities arrested bar owner Jacques Moretti on charges of negligent manslaughter after a New Year’s Eve sparkler-triggered fire at Le Constellation in Crans-Montana killed 40 mainly teens and twenty-somethings, injured 116, and exposed safety lapses including no inspections since 2019 and questionable renovations. Victims’ families’ lawyers accuse prosecutors of slow evidence gathering and the Morettis of deleting social media content. A national day of mourning was held, top EU leaders attended a memorial, and new safety checks are under way across Swiss venues.

articles.title: ‘A more convenient dictatorship’: fear and uncertainty in Venezuela after fall of Maduro
articles.trailText: US capture of president gave many Venezuelans hope, but a week on, an even more draconian atmosphere pervades
articles.summary: Following US special forces’ secret night raid that captured Nicolás Maduro from a military base, optimism among Venezuelans for mass releases quickly faded. While Trump touted closure of El Helicoide and freed some high-profile detainees, vice-president Delcy Rodríguez has consolidated power, dispatching Kalashnikov-armed civilians and security checkpoints that scan phones for anti-regime content. Paramilitaries enforce street curfews, journalists are barred, and fear grips Caracas and border regions. Analysts warn Washington’s takeover serves US oil interests, calling it “regime capture” rather than democratization. For many Venezuelans, the new order is “a more convenient dictatorship” shrouded in uncertainty.

articles.title: Germany braces for more heavy snowfall as Storm Goretti hits northern Europe
articles.trailText: France and Germany battered by strong winds and plunging temperatures, as schools closed and travel disrupted
articles.summary: Storm Goretti—dubbed Elli in Germany—has struck north-west Europe with record gusts exceeding 210 kph in Normandy and Brittany, cutting power to ~380,000 French homes, suspending regional trains and shutting schools. One man was seriously injured replacing roof tiles and 27 others suffered minor injuries. Météo-France issued severe weather warnings as winds peaked at 148 kph atop the Eiffel Tower. In Germany, up to 20 cm of snow and temperatures down to –20 °C are expected, prompting Deutsche Bahn to halt long-distance services in the north, 700 sanitation workers in Hamburg, and school closures. Isolated incidents include youths throwing ice blocks near Bremerhaven and a bus skidding in Baden-Württemberg (minor injuries), while Berlin largely escaped the worst.

articles.title: Russia fires hypersonic Oreshnik missile at Ukraine in massive attack
articles.trailText: Kyiv dismisses as ‘absurd’ Moscow’s attempt to portray missile launch as retaliation for supposed attempted drone strike on Putin residence
articles.summary: Russia’s military launched a new hypersonic Oreshnik missile at western Ukraine near the EU/NATO border, alleging it was retaliation for an aborted Ukrainian drone strike on President Putin—a claim Kyiv and Washington dismiss as false. Ukraine’s foreign minister warned the launch, apparently with inert warheads, poses a “grave threat” to European security and released fragments from Lviv. The strike damaged critical infrastructure, hit Kyiv districts killing one and injuring rescue workers, and damaged the Qatar embassy. Occurring amid EU security guarantee talks, it prompts calls to bolster air defenses and deepen sanctions.

articles.title: ‘We are not for sale’: chair of Greenland’s top labor union rebukes Trump’s call for annexation
articles.trailText: Exclusive: SIK leader Jess Berthelsen rejects Trump claim that the US needs Greenland for ‘national security’
articles.summary: SIK chair Jess Berthelsen categorically rejects Donald Trump’s renewed threats to annex Greenland, calling claims of Russian and Chinese naval activity in its waters “unrecognizable.” Representing thousands of government and private-sector workers, Berthelsen stressed Greenland’s semi-autonomous status under Denmark, its right to self-determination and 84% support for independence. He argued that US military threats strain Greenland-US cooperation, traditionally allies, and noted that European leaders from the UK, France and Germany have affirmed that decisions on Greenland rest with Denmark. The White House says “all options” remain on the table but favors diplomacy.

articles.title: Friday briefing: Trump tactics could leave office with him – or the US could descend into a rogue state
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: In just one year, this administration has lurched from one bewildering decision to another. Will things go back to normal after Trump’s term, or are we seeing a broader erosion of western democratic norms?
articles.summary: Historic paramilitary deployments, lethal force on civilians, ship seizures, capture of a foreign leader, dismantling of cultural bodies, a pliant judiciary and talk of extended presidencies have led experts like LSE’s Peter Trubowitz to warn that the Trump administration’s erratic mix of hemispheric dominance (notably in Venezuela), tariff-driven Wall Street agendas and tech-led deregulation may signal a deeper erosion of US democratic norms. With overt “power-for-power’s-sake” tactics and a push for a unitary executive, these measures risk leaving lasting institutional damage, suggesting a potential post-Trump landscape that won’t simply “snap back” to the status quo.

articles.title: Venezuela begins releasing political detainees to ‘consolidate peace’
articles.trailText: Opposition leader María Corina Machado hails move to tackle ‘injustice’ as Spain’s foreign ministry confirms release of five Spanish nationals
articles.summary: Venezuela's National Assembly president Jorge Rodríguez announced the imminent release of an 'important number' of political detainees as a gesture to 'consolidate peace'. Among those freed were former opposition candidate Enrique Márquez, activist Biagio Pilieri and five Spanish nationals including dual Spanish-Venezuelan lawyer Rocío San Miguel. Spain's foreign ministry confirmed embassy assistance for their repatriation. Opposition leader María Corina Machado hailed the move as a triumph over injustice. NGOs report only eight to ten releases so far, estimate 800–1,000 detentions remain, many at the El Helicoide torture complex. The government offered no official tally, sparking caution among activists.

articles.title: Whistle, crackle, banned: Dutch set to outlaw fireworks after more new year chaos
articles.trailText: Netherlands expected to join Ireland in prohibiting most consumer fireworks as other EU countries debate crackdown
articles.summary: After New Year’s Eve chaos in the Netherlands left more than 1,200 injured (one-third hospitalized), two dead and firefighters attacked, parliament approved a ban on most consumer fireworks to take effect by late 2026. The second European nation after Ireland to outlaw private displays, it follows 15 years of campaigning by animal welfare and medical groups alarmed by trauma cases and urban pollution. Industry losses (€129m in 2025) and cross-border imports trigger compensation talks. The debate mirrors Germany’s and Finland’s pushes for stricter pyrotechnics laws and highlights EU safety, environmental and enforcement gaps. Defenders cite a cultural 17th-century legacy, while critics stress toxic fumes, pet terror and emergency-service strain.

articles.title: ‘We can’t take it any more’: thousands flee guerrilla clashes on Colombia-Venezuela border
articles.trailText: Caracas shake-up could intensify violence in Catatumbo in Colombia, an area rich with coca crops, cocaine laboratories and a porous border with Venezuela
articles.summary: Since late December, over 2,000 residents from Catatumbo—an area rich in coca fields and cocaine labs on the porous Colombia–Venezuela border—have been displaced by clashes between the National Liberation Army (ELN) and a Farc dissident faction. The spike in violence follows the US January 3 raid in Venezuela to capture President Maduro, who faces narco-terrorism charges. Both guerrilla groups now deploy armed drones, terrorizing farmers and prompting humanitarian appeals in Cúcuta.

articles.title: ‘Damage is piling up’: has the Netherlands forgotten how to cope with snow?
articles.trailText: Cyclists and others voice frustration as transport infrastructure descends into chaos amid increasingly rare cold snap
articles.summary: During a rare week-long cold snap depositing up to 15cm of snow and temperatures down to –10 °C, the Netherlands, unaccustomed to winter extremes due to climate change, faced unprecedented disruption: over 2,000 flight cancellations, gridlock on roads and rail, partial building collapses and angry cyclists lamenting uncleared bike lanes. KNMI data show annual snow-cover days dropped from 23 in 1961 to three today. Authorities ran out of de-icing fluid, drivers lacked winter tyres and ProRail blamed delays. Experts warn infrastructure must adapt to unpredictable extreme weather to maintain resilient mobility.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kremlin denounces European troops plan as Kyiv warns of ‘massive Russian attack’
articles.trailText: Moscow says any Nato peacekeepers would be considered legitimate targets; US embassy and Kyiv flag ‘potentially significant air attack’. What we know on day 1,416
articles.summary: Moscow brands a US-led monitoring mechanism and proposed European stabilisation force in Ukraine “dangerous” and warns any NATO peacekeepers would be legitimate targets. German chancellor Merz insists a ceasefire must come first, while Kyiv and the US embassy alert citizens to a possible massive Russian air assault overnight. Recent Russian drone and missile strikes killed and injured civilians, damaged infrastructure and caused blackouts in Kyiv, Lviv and Dnipropetrovsk; Ukraine’s counterstrikes hit Belgorod’s energy grid. Despite pledges to end Russian LNG imports by 2027, EU buys rose to €7.2 bn last year. In London, Nigel Farage opposes any troop deployment, triggering a Commons debate on postwar security guarantees.

articles.title: As climate crisis threatened her home, Alolita was offered a chance at a new life in Australia
articles.trailText: Alolita Tekapu and her family among the first arrivals under a world-first agreement that allows people from Tuvalu to move to Australia
articles.summary: Alolita Tekapu and her family, among the first beneficiaries of the Australia–Tuvalu Falepili Union, settled in Melbourne last September under a landmark deal granting up to 280 Tuvaluans permanent residency annually to escape rising seas. Facing knee-deep king tides, flooded airstrips and eroding atolls at home, Tekapu fast-tracked her application while pregnant, reuniting with her husband, a Pacific labour scheme worker. Despite struggles securing housing and employment and longing for Tuvalu, the family receives support from AMES Australia. Experts hail the agreement as a model for climate-driven migration, though Tuvalu resists framing it as a refuge for “climate refugees.”

articles.title: Senate advances war powers resolution to stop Trump from taking further military action in Venezuela
articles.trailText: Democratic-led resolution would require US president to seek Congress’s approval to use military against Venezuela
articles.summary: The Senate approved a bipartisan war powers resolution 52–47 to prevent President Trump from launching further military operations against Venezuela without congressional authorization, following his unannounced special forces raid that captured President Maduro on U.S. soil. All Senate Democrats plus Republicans Rand Paul, Todd Young, Lisa Murkowski, Josh Hawley and Susan Collins backed the Kaine-led measure, invoking the 1973 War Powers Resolution. It now heads to the House and Trump’s desk. Trump decried it as “unconstitutional” and threatened to oppose supporters, marking a sharp rebuke to his Venezuela campaign.

articles.title: Iran plunged into internet blackout as protests over economy spread nationwide
articles.trailText: Security forces reported to have killed at least 45 people since protests began 12 days ago, as protesters gather in Tehran
articles.summary: Iran was cut off from the internet as anti-government protests over a collapsing currency and soaring prices erupted across all 31 provinces. Security forces have killed at least 45 protesters, including eight children, and wounded hundreds in a crackdown marked by shop closures in Kurdish regions, the toppling of Qassem Suleimani’s statue and reported attacks on demonstrators in Kermanshah and Abadan. Over 2,000 arrests followed strikes called by Kurdish groups. President Pezeshkian urged restraint while exiled crown prince Reza Pahlavi mobilises support. Washington warned Iran would face “severe action” if protesters are killed.

articles.title: Two oil tankers under US sanctions sailing through Channel towards Russia
articles.trailText: Aria and Tia both south of Britain after US-UK seizure of Marinera, deemed to be part of Moscow’s ‘shadow fleet’
articles.summary: Two US-sanctioned tankers, the Aria and the Tia (now Tiavan), are sailing east through the English Channel towards Russia days after US-UK forces seized the Marinera shadow-fleet tanker. Defence Secretary John Healey told MPs disrupting Russia’s illicit oil shipments is a government priority. The Tia, renamed repeatedly since 2024 sanctions for carrying Venezuelan crude, is heading from Turkey to the Gulf of Finland, arriving January 13. The Barbados-flagged Aria, linked to Russia’s largest maritime firm, is bound for Ust-Luga. The MoD declined to comment on potential new seizures.

articles.title: Harvey Weinstein weighing guilty plea to resolve third-degree rape charge
articles.trailText: Disgraced former movie mogul would avoid a third trial in New York on charges that came to define the #MeToo era
articles.summary: Disgraced former movie mogul Harvey Weinstein is considering a guilty plea to resolve a third-degree rape charge in New York and avoid a third trial tied to a 2013 Jessica Mann allegation. At a Jan 8 hearing, Judge Curtis Farber denied Weinstein’s motion to dismiss a prior conviction for forcing oral sex on Miriam Haley, rejecting claims of juror intimidation. Weinstein, 73, wheelchair-bound and held at Rikers since his arrest, said jail conditions are “soul-crushing.” Prosecutors maintain repeated trials reflect justice for sexual-assault survivors. Weinstein has two weeks to decide plea talks.

articles.title: French farmers stage protest in Paris to oppose EU-Mercosur trade deal
articles.trailText: Tractor protest in city centre comes as Emmanuel Macron confirms he will vote against accord on Friday
articles.summary: French farmers in tractors blocked roads around the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe in a pre-dawn protest by Coordination Rurale against an EU-Mercosur trade deal with Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay. They fear being undercut by cheaper agricultural imports. Despite President Macron’s vow to vote against the accord and recent French tariff concessions, the deal—backed by Germany, Spain and now Italy after €45 bn in extra farm funding—looks set to secure an EU qualified-majority vote on Friday.

articles.title: Venezuela cooperating fully and US will control its oil for years, Trump claims
articles.trailText: US president says Delcy Rodríguez’s interim administration is doing ‘everything that we feel is necessary’
articles.summary: Donald Trump says Venezuela’s interim president Delcy Rodríguez is fully cooperating, granting Washington indefinite political and commercial control over its vast oil reserves. US forces have seized sanctioned tankers, and the administration will oversee all crude exports, demanding they serve American interests—VP Vance warns no sales outside US strategy. Rodríguez praised energy ties and announced some political-prisoner releases amid NGO skepticism. The White House unveiled up to $3bn of crude access and will host oil companies, though elections remain unscheduled.

articles.title: Visas leave migrants anything but settled | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Rev Dr Rebekah E Sims urges Britons to respond to the government consultation on ‘earned settlement’ in support of workers like her, while another reader describes prolonged years of uncertainty and cost
articles.summary: Two letters slam Labour’s ‘fairer pathway to settlement’ consultation. Rev Dr Rebekah E Sims, on a skilled worker visa, denounces the earned settlement proposals as performative, costly and delaying indefinite leave to remain, while a British citizen with a spouse visa details thousands in fees, NHS surcharges, extended five-year waits and unachievable earnings tests. Both stress migrants’ roles in healthcare, research and childcare, warn that shifting definitions of Britishness fuel insecurity, and urge UK residents to respond by 12 February to defend migrant rights and cohesion.

articles.title: Why 'go home' is a meaningless chant to many of us | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to Hugh Muir’s article about the simplistic way in which the far right looks at identity and belonging
articles.summary: Hugh Muir’s DNA journey tracing ancestry across 15 regions reveals the absurdity of single‐origin identity, undermining ethno‐nationalist and racialist definitions of belonging. Writers—including those with Irish, Roma, African, Dutch and wider European roots, British-born honorary citizens, and global nomads holding multiple passports—share mixed-heritage narratives. They say taunts to ‘go home’ ignore transnational realities, echoing rising hate crime and right-wing populism. The letters urge a constructive dialogue on identity to counter xenophobic hostility.

articles.title: Iran’s overtures of peace are at odds with its actions | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: One reader responds to an article by Abbas Araghchi, Iran’s foreign minister, appealing to President Trump to come to the negotiating table
articles.summary: Iran’s 1979 revolution solidified anti-Western ideology, from chanting "Death to America" and seizing 52 US diplomats, to backing 1983 Beirut bombings (241 US marines killed) and the 1996 Khobar Towers attack. US courts and agencies link the IRGC to those strikes and to arming Iraqi militias whose explosively formed weapons killed hundreds of US soldiers post-2003. Continued support for Hezbollah, Hamas, and other proxies undercuts Iran’s peace rhetoric; genuine diplomacy demands cutting ties to terror and proxy warfare.

articles.title: On the lamb: 50 sheep break away from flock and storm German supermarket
articles.trailText: Ewes and lambs coaxed out of store in Burgsinn after about 20 minutes, leaving trail of destruction in drinks section
articles.summary: During a seasonal migration in Burgsinn, Bavaria, about 50 sheep broke from a 500-strong flock and stormed a Penny supermarket, spending 20 minutes wandering aisles before being coaxed out. They left minor destruction in the drinks section but spared produce, amusing roughly 20 shoppers. Shepherd Dieter Michler, who blamed acorn distractions and sheep following a bag into the store, retrieved them in the car park. Penny dismissed billing for damages, instead pledging a year’s feed for the runaways. The incident went viral, prompting a punning post from Germany’s London embassy.

articles.title: Aldrich Ames obituary
articles.trailText: CIA officer who betrayed western intelligence assets and espionage operations to the Soviet Union and Russia
articles.summary: Aldrich Ames, who died in prison aged 84, was the most senior CIA officer exposed as a Soviet spy. Recruited in 1967, he betrayed more than 30 allied agents—among them GRU general Dmitri Polyakov and MI6’s Oleg Gordievsky—and over 100 US and British operations. Plunged into debt, he began selling secrets to the KGB in 1985, culminating in a massive leak of CIA assets that led to at least ten executions. Uncovered by CIA investigator Sandra Grimes, Ames pleaded guilty in 1994 and received life without parole; his wife served four years.

articles.title: Saudi Arabia says UAE helped Yemeni separatist leader flee as crisis deepens
articles.trailText: Riyadh says Aidarous al-Zubaidi, leader of the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council, was helped to flee Yemen
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia has accused the UAE of orchestrating the secret evacuation of Aidarous al-Zubaidi, head of the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC), after he skipped crisis talks in Riyadh. Riyadh says al-Zubaidi fled Aden by boat to Berbera in Somaliland, then flew via Mogadishu to Abu Dhabi under Emirati supervision. Saudi authorities expelled and charged him with treason, demanding international sanctions and blaming Abu Dhabi for stoking separatist ambitions. The episode deepens a rift between Saudi Arabia and the UAE following last month’s STC push to secede southern Yemen—a drive that collapsed amid internal splits, a Saudi-backed counteroffensive across Hadramaut, Shabwa and Aden, and the UAE’s withdrawal of military support.

articles.title: Syrian army orders Aleppo evacuations amid fighting with Kurdish forces
articles.trailText: People told to leave three areas as fears grow of wider conflict between government and Kurdish authorities
articles.summary: The Syrian army has ordered residents to evacuate the contested Aleppo districts of Sheikh Maqsoud, Ashrafieh and Bani Zeid by early afternoon, opening corridors and shelters as clashes with the US-backed Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces enter a third day. Shelling began after a 1:30pm deadline, displacing roughly 140,000 people and killing at least 16 civilians. This is the fiercest violence since Assad’s fall in late 2024 and stems from stalled talks over SDF integration under a March 2025 agreement. Both sides accuse each other of rights abuses as the US urges restraint and Turkey signals support for Damascus.

articles.title: Berlin mayor faces calls to resign after playing tennis during city blackout
articles.trailText: Kai Wegner acknowledged he had not been entirely forthcoming to public about his actions when outage began
articles.summary: Berlin mayor Kai Wegner faces calls to resign after playing tennis with his partner during a militant-triggered blackout that cut power to 45,000 households and 2,000 businesses. He initially claimed to have worked around the clock but later admitted taking a short sporting break and apologized for misleading the public. Parties from the far-right AfD to the SPD denounced his lapse ahead of regional elections. Dubbed “tennis-gate,” the affair highlights concerns about crisis management and political accountability in Berlin.

articles.title: Indian police raid home of environmental activists over anti-fossil fuel campaign
articles.trailText: Satat Sampada founders Harjeet Singh and Jyoti Awasthi say allegations are ‘baseless, biased and misleading’
articles.summary: India's Enforcement Directorate raided environmental NGO Satat Sampada co-founders Harjeet Singh and Jyoti Awasthi citing suspicions they received nearly £500,000 in foreign funds disguised as consultancy fees to promote a fossil fuel non-proliferation treaty (FFNPT), allegedly undermining national energy security. Searches at Singh’s Delhi home and NGO offices, uncovering excess whisky stores, preceded his arrest and bail. The probe targets misdeclaration of funds and alleged threats to India’s economic interests, amid broader scrutiny of climate activists and serial suspension of foreign funding licenses. Singh and Awasthi deny wrongdoing, calling the charges baseless.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Why skinny jabs’ short-term fix comes with long-term concerns
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: A new study shows that people don’t just regain weight after stopping GLP-1 drugs, they see other positive health markers reverse – leading to questions about long-term impacts and solutions
articles.summary: GLP-1 drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy yield consistent weight loss and improved metabolic and heart-health markers, but a new Oxford-led study finds that within two years of stopping, patients regain weight at 0.4kg/month and see cholesterol, blood pressure and diabetes risk markers revert. NICE caps treatment at two years, yet long-term data suggest ongoing use may be needed. Side effects (nausea, hair loss, contraceptive failure) and high costs drive many to discontinue. Experts warn these jabs require integrated programmes—nutrition, therapy, exercise—to sustain benefits and avoid a cosmetic-only shortcut that fuels unhealthy beauty norms.

articles.title: Right to protest is under attack in England and Wales, reports warn
articles.trailText: Human Rights Watch and Justice say recent legislative changes have had a chilling effect and should be repealed
articles.summary: Human Rights Watch and Justice warn England and Wales’s 2022 Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Act and 2023 Public Order Act have produced a chilling effect on peaceful dissent, granting police broad, vague powers to curb noise, pre-emptively contain assemblies and criminalise items like cable ties. Reports cite arrests of anti-monarchy, pro-Palestinian, climate and juror-rights protesters, and harsh sentences for Just Stop Oil activists. They urge repeal of recent laws, cancellation of further restrictions on face coverings, repeat protests and places of worship, and independent review to restore protest rights.

articles.title: Coalition of the willing must be ‘robust’ to deal with Russia, warns ex-US general
articles.trailText: Ben Hodges says multinational force to aid Ukraine would need thousands of troops to stop Russia breaking ceasefire
articles.summary: Ex-US Army Europe commander Ben Hodges warns that an Anglo-French stabilisation force in Ukraine must deploy 10,000–15,000 combat troops with robust rules of engagement to counter Kremlin-orchestrated provocations like drone attacks and ceasefire breaches. PM Keir Starmer and President Macron signed a declaration with Zelenskiy pledging ground, air and naval assets but left troop numbers and combat roles undefined pending a ceasefire vote. Few allies have committed forces; Germany and Turkey offer conditional support while the US, Poland and Italy oppose ground deployments. The force, operating alongside Ukraine’s army, aims to serve as a trip-wire deterrent less extensive than Bosnia’s NATO mission.

articles.title: Two weeks on, questions linger over targeting and impact of US airstrikes in Nigeria
articles.trailText: Very little information has been shared about strikes in Sokoto state
articles.summary: Two weeks after Christmas Day US airstrikes in Sokoto state targeting the Islamist Lakurawa group, both US and Nigerian authorities have shared scant details on casualties or impact. Trump hailed “numerous perfect strikes” on “ISIS scum,” while local sources report up to 100 fighters killed, 200 missing and fleeing into Niger, and missile debris damaging civilian areas hundreds of miles away. Analysts argue the one-off operation served Trump’s evangelical base, exposing murky links between Lakurawa, Islamic State or al-Qaida in a bandit-plagued, governance-vacant region.

articles.title: EU accused of fuelling Putin’s war by importing Russian liquefied natural gas
articles.trailText: Despite Brussels’ pledge to ban Russian LNG by 2027, shipments to European ports increased in the last year
articles.summary: Despite the EU’s 2027 ban pledge, imports of Russian LNG rose in 2025 to 15m tonnes via the Yamal peninsula, earning Moscow €7.2bn. EU share of Yamal exports climbed to 76.1%. Seapeak (37.3%) and Dynagas (34.3%) dominate Arc7 tanker logistics. Major EU terminals—Zeebrugge, Dunkirk, Montoir—facilitate rapid returns, sustaining Russia’s war chest. Rights group Urgewald urges Brussels to shutter this ‘Yamal loophole’ immediately to cut Kremlin gas profits.

articles.title: ‘Out with the Yanks!’: Thousands protest in Colombia as anger builds over Trump’s intervention in Venezuela
articles.trailText: President Gustavo Petro called for demonstrations after Trump said he was interested in military action in Colombia
articles.summary: Thousands rallied in Colombian cities after US president Donald Trump threatened to expand military operations into Colombia following a controversial US special forces raid that captured Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro. President Gustavo Petro called protests denouncing 'Yankee imperialism' and an alleged US oil grab, as demonstrators chanted 'Fuera los yanquis!' Demonstrations spread to Mexico City, São Paulo and Buenos Aires, highlighting regional alarm. The US embassy warned of potential violence, while Latin American leaders and diplomats condemned Trump’s actions as destabilizing and symptomatic of US disregard for regional sovereignty and alliances.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Allies yet to provide details of security guarantee, Zelenskyy says
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president says he has received no ‘unequivocal answer’ from European allies about how they would defend Ukraine if Russia attacked again. What we know on day 1,415
