articles.summary: On day 1,415 of the war, Zelenskiy said he’s received no unequivocal legal security guarantee from European allies—including on deployment of the proposed multinational force—if Russia invades again. Political will exists but awaits parliamentary and congressional backing. In London, PM Keir Starmer pledged an MPs vote on troop numbers and defence hubs in Ukraine, though parliamentary limits remain uncertain. Meanwhile Russian strikes cut power almost entirely in Dnipropetrovsk and Zaporizhzhia amid sub-20°C weather, and hit Odesa’s Chornomorsk and Pivdennyi ports, killing one and injuring eight. Ukraine’s FX reserves hit $57.3bn as defence spending surged to $70bn.

articles.title: ‘Hard to say who’s winning’: China and Australia battle for influence in Solomon Islands policing
articles.trailText: Beijing and Canberra have adopted different strategies to support policing in the Pacific nation and observers are split on which is proving more effective
articles.summary: In Honiara, Beijing and Canberra vie to shape Solomon Islands policing: China focuses on community‐level support—training local leaders in urban policing, solar lights, sewing machines and soccer balls—through roughly a dozen trainers, while Australia invests over $170 million (with an additional $190 million pledge now stalled) to equip 1,100 officers via formal partnerships, ~36 advisers, patrol boats and weapons. Observers highlight China’s grassroots appeal versus Australia’s capacity building, fueling a “battle for hearts and minds” and internal rifts over pro‐Beijing versus pro‐Canberra factions.

articles.title: ‘They are killing us’: authorities use force against protesters in Kurdish regions of Iran
articles.trailText: People face teargas, pellet guns and violence as protests continue and opposition parties call for general strike
articles.summary: Demonstrators in Kurdish cities across western Iran staged continued protests against economic hardship and government corruption, shutting shops and demanding reforms. Security forces responded with teargas, pellet guns and live fire—Hengaw and witnesses report Kalashnikov use—killing at least 36 people and arresting over 2,100. Seven Kurdish opposition parties and exiled royal Reza Pahlavi called a general strike and nationwide protests. President Pezeshkian announced bread subsidies and investigations into hospital raids, while the army warned of pre-emptive action against foreign intervention. The rial’s plunge and looming subsidy cuts underscore widespread grievances fueling this intensifying movement.

articles.title: María Corina Machado to publish book on political vision for Venezuela amid upheaval
articles.trailText: Venezuelan opposition leader and Nobel peace prize winner will lay out vision for the country in book publishing in US
articles.summary: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, Nobel peace laureate, will release The Freedom Manifesto, a 120-page US title from Regnery/Skyhorse, outlining her roadmap for Venezuela’s political reconstruction after the US capture of Nicolás Maduro. The book expands on her November manifesto, championing human dignity, security, free speech, assembly, home-based education and transparent elections as pillars of a liberal democracy. Originally set for February, it’s being updated with post-ousting developments; 50,000 English and 5,000 Spanish copies are planned. Despite her Nobel win, Trump withheld support, favoring acting president Delcy Rodríguez conditionally.

articles.title: Marco Rubio says he will meet Danish officials to discuss Greenland next week
articles.trailText: Remarks by US secretary of state come after Greenland and Denmark request urgent meeting over Trump threats
articles.summary: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio will meet Danish officials next week after Greenlandic and Danish FMs demanded urgent talks over President Trump’s threats to buy or militarily seize Greenland, which allies warn would shatter NATO post–WWII security. French FM Barrot says Paris and EU partners are preparing a joint response if the US invades. The White House insists diplomacy is preferred but keeps “all options on the table.” UK PM Starmer upholds that Greenland’s future belongs to Greenlanders and Denmark, amid Danish claims that US warnings about Chinese and Russian presence are exaggerated.

articles.title: What are Trump’s real options for gaining control of Greenland?
articles.trailText: The White House has said using the US military is always an option, but few analysts believe it a likely one
articles.summary: The Trump administration’s push to control Greenland spans proposals to buy the territory (echoing past US offers), despite Danish and Greenlandic rejections and the islanders’ right to self-determination (85% oppose US rule). Strategic hearts-and-minds campaigns involve investment, a reopened consulate and envoy, plus alleged influence operations. Officials are also exploring a “compact of free association” securing independence with US military access. Existing treaties already grant Washington wide Arctic base rights. While analysts note a small-scale invasion is logistically feasible, weather, legal, NATO fallout and diplomatic costs render it virtually impossible.

articles.title: US reportedly warns Maduro ally Diosdado Cabello he could be next
articles.trailText: Interior minister told he must back acting president, while Marco Rubio lays out three-point plan for Venezuela
articles.summary: The Trump administration has quietly warned hardline Interior Minister Diosdado Cabello that he risks sanctions or arrest if he fails to back acting president Delcy Rodríguez after Maduro’s capture. Washington strives to stabilize post-capture Venezuela, divert $2bn of crude from China, ensure Western market access, and pursue reconciliation and a political transition. Marco Rubio outlined this three-phase plan. Meanwhile, US forces seized two oil tankers, Cabello’s colectivos patrol Caracas amid a declared state of emergency, and opposition leader María Corina Machado demands swift elections.

articles.title: Cod conflict between two Nato members | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Allies at war | Shakespeare on tyranny | Leicester greetings | Winter style | Road sign supplements
articles.summary: Five letters cover topics from 1970s cod wars to local customs and humor. Sarah Palmer recalls how US pressure forced the UK to cede fishing rights to Iceland, ending a NATO fracas. Josephine Billingham quotes Shakespeare on the tyranny of undue strength. Tracy Twell outlines Leicester’s ‘Hiya’ and hybrid ‘Y’alright cho?’ greeting. Margaret Harris mocks winter layering style tips, while Pat Begg shares a playful ‘CATS EYES REMOVED—MICE VERY HAPPY’ road sign pun.

articles.title: Reflagged by Russia, spied on by UK, seized by US: why so much interest in a rusty tanker in the Atlantic?
articles.trailText: The ship is alleged to be part of a shadow fleet dodging western sanctions. It had no oil onboard – but was it carrying Russian weapons?
articles.summary: Russia-flagged 300m tanker Marinera, formerly Bella 1, part of the shadow fleet evading western sanctions, was trailed by a UK RC-135W and monitored by US surveillance before US forces seized it in the Atlantic. Empty of oil but US-sanctioned for illicit cargo for Hezbollah, it diverted from Venezuela’s blockade to northern waters. An earlier US Coast Guard boarding attempt in December was rebuffed by the crew. Reflagging prompted Kremlin protests, while theories suggest hidden Russian arms or symbolic power play in the US-Russia standoff. Moscow dispatched naval escorts including a submarine ahead of the high-seas boarding.

articles.title: ‘How is it possible?’: Berliners demand answers after sabotage causes blackout
articles.trailText: Arson attack that left parts of German capital in darkness for days stirs outrage over infrastructure insecurity
articles.summary: An arson attack by leftwing militants Vulkangruppe on a high-voltage cable bridge in south-west Berlin caused Germany’s longest blackout since WWII, cutting power to 45,000 homes, 2,000 businesses, four hospitals, 74 care homes, 20 schools and major transport lines. With only footprints at the scene, federal prosecutors are under pressure to explain the grid’s vulnerability and outline prevention measures. Reconnection of the final 20,000 properties coincided with calls from the Red Cross and infrastructure experts for urgent investments in resilience. Public outrage mounted as Mayor Kai Wegner and Energy Senator Franziska Giffey faced criticism, while the far-right AfD seized on security lapses.

articles.title: Amsterdam airport cancels at least 800 flights because of snow and wind
articles.trailText: Camp beds set up as more than 1,000 travellers spend night at key flight hub during freezing European weather
articles.summary: At least 800 flights were cancelled on Jan 7 at Amsterdam’s Schiphol airport due to heavy snow and wind, forcing over 1,000 travellers to camp overnight on beds with blankets. The cold snap, driven by Storm Goretti, also led Paris airports to cancel around 140 flights, suspend bus services and put 38 of France’s 96 departments on snow and black-ice alert. Five people died in French road accidents. Spain halted a Madrid commuter rail line and closed over 40 roads; travel chaos spread to the Balkans (Croatia train stuck 12 hours, Bosnian and Serbian towns under emergencies), while Poland and Hungary closed schools and delayed trains.

articles.title: People living in the US: what do you think about Donald Trump’s threat to take control of Greenland?
articles.trailText: What is your reaction to Trump’s territorial ambitions?
articles.summary: In a Reuters survey piece, Americans are asked for their opinions – particularly those who voted for Donald Trump or supported him – on his revived proposal for the US to take control of Greenland from Denmark, a plan he floated in 2019, reportedly valuing the island at over $1.4tn. The call coincides with his interventionist rhetoric following the removal of Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro. Respondents can share their reaction via an online form, offering insights into public sentiment on Trump’s territorial ambitions and broader US expansionism. It aims to capture US citizens’ perspectives on sovereignty disputes and America’s global role.

articles.title: ‘The pressure is too much’: Lesotho’s garment workers on the frontline of Trump tariffs
articles.trailText: Women gather outside factories hoping for work as the economy struggles under US export taxes
articles.summary: Since Trump’s reciprocal tariffs took effect in April 2025, Lesotho’s garment sector—once employing 50,000 under AGOA—has shed jobs and cut hours. Workers in Maseru now queue daily for sporadic contracts, earning as little as 50 maloti weekly. Exports to the US face 15% duties (instead of the potential 50%), chilling growth and prompting a 1-point GDP revision to 0.9% for 2026. Surveys report 400 layoffs, factories at 5–30% capacity and wages of ≈2,582 maloti/month. The government seeks a three-year AGOA renewal and a tariff reduction to 10% to restore competitiveness. Families struggle with fees, food and basic needs.

articles.title: MPs would get vote on troop deployment to Ukraine, says Keir Starmer
articles.trailText: UK and France ready to send peacekeeping troops, PM tells House of Commons
articles.summary: At PMQs on Jan 7, 2026, Labour leader Keir Starmer announced MPs would debate and vote before any UK troops deploy on peacekeeping duties in Ukraine, conditional on a ceasefire and peace deal agreed at a “coalition of the willing” meeting in Paris with Presidents Macron and Zelenskyy. He said full details—including troop numbers, legal instruments, and plans for deterrent operations and military hubs—would be tabled in the Commons. Tory leader Kemi Badenoch pressed for an immediate statement; Speaker Lindsay Hoyle sought an early update.

articles.title: Australia’s cost of living ‘getting crazier’ as nearly half of lower-income families worry about affording school shoes
articles.trailText: Nine in 10 families are worried about price of back-to-school essentials as inflation continues to bite, research has found
articles.summary: Research by The Smith Family of 1,100+ low-income Australian families shows nine in ten are anxious about affording back-to-school essentials, with over 80% unable to cover uniforms, shoes or digital devices for three consecutive years. Child poverty rose from 15% in 2023 to 15.6% in 2025, risking over one million children in poverty. Disadvantaged students risk falling 4–5 years behind by Year 9. More than half fear missing laptops, 40% miss out on extracurriculars. Single mother Laura highlights choices between food, power bills and school costs, despite charity laptop support.

articles.title: Yemen separatist leader to make last stand after rejecting Saudi ultimatum, supporters say
articles.trailText: Saudi airstrikes hit Aidarous al-Zubaidi’s military camps after he defies a demand to travel to Riyadh for talks
articles.summary: STC leader Aidarous al-Zubaidi has rejected a Saudi ultimatum to engage in Riyadh talks, choosing instead to fortify his remaining forces in Aden for a defiant last stand. Saudi airstrikes on his Dhale camps killed two civilians and injured 14 after he ignored Prince Khalid bin Salman’s summons, facing UN-government treason charges over his unilateral southern-flag-raising and independence drive. With UAE arms deliveries halted and a 50-member STC delegation in Riyadh reportedly detained and uncontactable, Saudi-backed troops have since reclaimed Hadramaut and al-Mahrah. Al-Zubaidi’s stance highlights widening Saudi-UAE rifts and deepening risks of Yemen’s fragmentation.

articles.title: Trump claims Venezuela is set for an oil boom after US attack – history points to a bumpy road ahead
articles.trailText: From Venezuela to Libya to Iraq, removal of dictators has not always guaranteed a surge in oil production, data shows
articles.summary: After US special forces captured Nicolás Maduro and indicted him, President Trump declared Venezuela’s vast reserves would fuel an “oil boom” as US majors rebuild nationalized fields. Industry and analysts doubt rapid gains within 18 months: historical parallels show regime change in petrostates seldom yields instant output growth. Venezuela’s output fell after Chávez nationalized assets and US sanctions until 2022 when Chevron alone resumed. Post-2003 Iraq rebounded only after six years, while Libya remains volatile a decade after Gaddafi. Political instability and infrastructure challenges cloud Trump’s vision.

articles.title: Can Cuba’s bond with Venezuela survive Trump’s ousting of Maduro?
articles.trailText: Havana’s long, fractious history with the US leaves it vulnerable if Caracas is forced to withdraw its support
articles.summary: After a US-led push to topple Nicolás Maduro, Cuba’s vital lifeline—Venezuelan oil trades in exchange for Cuban security and intelligence backing—is imperiled. Already reeling from chronic blackouts, economic collapse and 32 Cuban deaths in the assault, Havana faces intensified US sanctions under Trump, who expects the regime to fall without direct action. High-profile corruption and espionage trials, Raúl Castro’s intervention delaying a key party congress, and mounting leadership uncertainty expose cracks, yet historical resistance to US invasion and calls for gradual economic opening suggest survival over sudden change.

articles.title: People from Venezuela and neighbouring countries: share your reaction to US raid
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people in Venezuela, as well as from neighbouring countries mentioned by the Trump administration, about how they are responding to recent US actions
articles.summary: Following a shock US military raid in Venezuela, which the UN human rights office says violated a core principle of international law, and the recent US court appearance of ex-president Nicolás Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores on charges they pleaded not guilty to, the Guardian is calling for responses from Venezuelans, both domestically and in diaspora, as well as inhabitants of neighboring Colombia and Cuba highlighted by the Trump administration. We welcome personal testimonies on emotional reactions, family and community impacts, political concerns or aspirations, and anticipated consequences of US actions and Trump’s rhetoric for Venezuela’s future.

articles.title: A brief history of US military bases in Greenland
articles.trailText: How the Guardian reported the US military presence and establishment of airbases in the former Danish colony and county
articles.summary: Details key milestones of US military installations in Greenland: the 1941 Coast Guard occupancy and airfield agreements under Roosevelt’s channel-hopping strategy to defend Britain; a 1947 US denial of any Greenland purchase proposal; the 1951 US-Denmark joint defense treaty handing Groennedal station to Denmark, defining defense areas with dual command, tax exemptions for US troops, and NATO access; the 1952 plan to construct four major arctic air bases nearer the USSR; the 1956 mechanized Thule base at 47°C below zero, built for $500m despite seasonal ice blockade; and the 1968 B-52 H-bomb crash and radioactive cleanup that reaffirmed Danish prohibition of nuclear weapons in Greenland.

articles.title: Gambling platform Polymarket not paying bets on US invasion of Venezuela
articles.trailText: Gamblers who placed wagers totalling $10.5m angered after capture of Nicolás Maduro deemed not to qualify
articles.summary: Prediction market Polymarket has refused to settle $10.5m of wagers on a US invasion of Venezuela after Donald Trump’s forces seized President Nicolás Maduro on Jan 7, 2026, ruling the operation didn’t meet its definition of “invasion” – which requires US military operations intended to establish control. An anonymous trader’s $30,000 bet, which briefly showed $436,760 in gains, was voided. Users criticized the decision as arbitrary. Polymarket, US-regulated since 2025 and linked to adviser Donald Trump Jr, lacks a UK licence.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: What Europe’s silence over Venezuela says about its fear of Trump
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Leaders’ refusal to condemn the US’s intervention in Caracas shows a desperation to keep the White House on side – but a red line might not be far away
articles.summary: Europe’s measured response to the US-led capture of Maduro reflects its dilemma: welcome authoritarian’s removal while avoiding endorsing a likely breach of international law. Brussels, London and Paris stress a peaceful democratic transition, invoking legal norms but stopping short of criticism to preserve US backing—vital for Ukraine’s security. France voices unease, Italy deems it legitimate, the UK stays abstract. Officials fear public rebuke could undermine private influence on Trump. True red lines may emerge over Greenland, where US threats would directly challenge NATO sovereignty and force unified European action.

articles.title: EU reveals weak hand as Trump raids Venezuela and threatens Greenland
articles.trailText: European acquiescence risks undermining legal principles behind opposition to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine as they struggle to keep US president onboard
articles.summary: After US forces raided Venezuela’s government and Donald Trump threatened to annex Greenland, the EU struggled to issue a firm stance. Brussels greeted Trump’s Caracas operation with muted social-media posts on free movement, while member states issued split, cautious reactions. Experts warned that acquiescence undermines legal norms underpinning EU opposition to Russia’s war in Ukraine, yet criticism risks alienating America. Denmark led a firmer rebuff of Greenland annexation, backed by major EU capitals, but concrete measures remain undecided amid fears of jeopardising transatlantic security ties.

articles.title: ‘Yamagata is ramen’: Japan’s city of noodle fiends revels in ‘capital’ status
articles.trailText: Noodle dish is nation’s favourite comfort food and source of civic pride – but it has health risks
articles.summary: Yamagata, a 240,000-strong city 340 km north of Tokyo, boasts some 230 ramen shops and has reclaimed its title as Japan’s “ramen capital,” outspending rivals like Niigata with average household ramen bills of ¥22,389 in 2024. Ramen here evolved from post-1923 Great Kantō Earthquake chefs’ influence into a local culinary staple fueling civic pride and the regional economy—from farmers and soy-sauce makers to hot-towel suppliers. A Yamagata University study links eating ramen three or more times weekly to a 1.52× higher mortality risk due to high salt, yet devotion to slurping remains strong.

articles.title: Venezuela ‘turning over’ $2bn in oil to US, Trump says, in move that could cut supply to China
articles.trailText: Deal would indicate Venezuelan government is responding to Trump’s demand that it open up to US oil firms or risk more military intervention
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced Venezuela will transfer $2bn of crude to the US, diverting supplies from China to American ports via Chevron-run PDVSA terminals, with proceeds he claims to control to benefit both nations. The deal follows a US raid that toppled Nicolas Maduro, prompting interim president Delcy Rodriguez's sharp reversal: initial invitation to cooperate then condemnation of a "kidnapping" and illegal intervention. US Energy Secretary Chris Wright will execute the transfer. Oil markets slid over 1.5% on expectations of increased Venezuelan flow. Under US sanctions PDVSA's assets are frozen, blocking Venezuela's direct access to proceeds.

articles.title: Teen killed by bus during ultra-Orthodox protest against conscription in Jerusalem
articles.trailText: Mass demonstrations against compulsory service law have been taking place as Israel’s military tries to solve its manpower shortages
articles.summary: In Jerusalem on Jan 7, 2026, a 14-year-old ultra-Orthodox boy was crushed and killed when a bus, its driver detained and alleging assault, ploughed into a crowd protesting a new conscription law. Thousands had rallied against mandatory service amid Israel’s manpower shortages after two years of war. Police say rioters blocked buses, set fires and assaulted officers. The incident escalates disputes over Haredi army exemptions established in 1948, threatening Netanyahu’s fragile coalition as draft legislation stalls.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: US backs European ceasefire security guarantees for first time
articles.trailText: Pledge came at Paris summit of mainly European nations to firm up guarantees to reassure Kyiv in the event of a ceasefire with Russia. What we know on day 1,414
articles.summary: At a Paris summit on day 1,414 of the Ukraine war, the US for the first time joined European allies in pledging binding security guarantees to defend Kyiv if Russia attacks post-ceasefire. US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner affirmed Trump’s backing, while France, Britain and Ukraine agreed trilateral declarations and a US-led monitoring mechanism using drones, sensors and satellites. Macron and Sunak signaled readiness to deploy peacekeeping troops. Moscow has shown no willingness to accept such terms. Zelenskiy welcomed concrete backstops; territorial disputes remain unresolved. A Ukrainian drone strike ignited fires at Russia’s Belgorod depot, with no casualties reported.

articles.title: Government signals tougher motoring rules to reduce casualties on Britain’s roads
articles.trailText: Eye-tests for older drivers, automatic emergency braking in new cars and crackdown on drink-driving among new proposals
articles.summary: Britain’s government has unveiled its first road safety strategy in over a decade, targeting a 65% cut in fatalities and serious injuries by 2035. Proposals include lowering drink-drive limits (from 35μg to 22μg breath alcohol), mandatory alcolocks for offenders, licence suspension pending drug or drink-drive tests, tougher uninsured driver fines, seatbelt penalty points, extended learning for new drivers, triennial eyesight (and potential cognitive) tests for over-70s, mandatory autonomous emergency braking under ‘Dev’s law’, and revised crash-test standards to protect diverse occupants.

articles.title: UK and France ‘ready to deploy troops’ to Ukraine after ceasefire
articles.trailText: Trilateral declaration of intent signed after ‘coalition of the willing’ summit in Paris with plan to establish military hubs
articles.summary: Following a Paris “coalition of the willing” summit, UK PM Starmer, French President Macron and Ukrainian President Zelensky signed a trilateral declaration to deploy British and French troops to Ukraine after a ceasefire, establishing military hubs well behind the contact line to reassure Ukrainians without directly engaging Russian forces. US envoy Steve Witkoff pledged “strongest ever” security guarantees under US leadership for ceasefire monitoring and long-term support. Moscow vows to block any NATO presence. Size and scope remain unspecified as bilateral US-Ukraine peace talks continue amid territory disputes.

articles.title: European leaders rally behind Greenland as US ramps up threats
articles.trailText: Support comes after presidential aide Stephen Miller says ‘no one will fight US militarily over future of Greenland’
articles.summary: European leaders including UK PM Keir Starmer, French president Emmanuel Macron and German chancellor Friedrich Merz—joined by Italy, Poland, Spain and Denmark—issued a rare rebuke to Washington after Stephen Miller said ‘no one will fight’ over Greenland, implying US seizure by force. They affirmed Greenland’s right to self-determination under Denmark, urging NATO-based Arctic security rather than unilateral US action. The White House confirmed military intervention ‘is always an option’ as Trump pursues acquisition to counter Arctic rivals. Denmark’s PM Mette Frederiksen warned annexation would shatter NATO trust. Greenland officials and Inuit leaders condemned the threats, insisting only Greenlanders decide their future amid surging independence sentiment.

articles.title: Wyoming supreme court strikes down near-total abortion bans
articles.trailText: Justices rule 4-1 that laws, including a ban on abortion pills, violate a state amendment protecting healthcare choices
articles.summary: Wyoming’s Supreme Court has struck down two near-total abortion bans—including the nation’s first exclusive ban on abortion pills—in a 4–1 decision, ruling they violate a 2012 state constitutional amendment guaranteeing competent adults’ right to make healthcare decisions. The laws would have outlawed abortion except to save a woman’s life or in cases of rape or incest. Wellspring Health Access and advocates sued to block the bans. Governor Mark Gordon called the ruling “profoundly unfortunate” and plans to push a voter-approved constitutional amendment in November. Similar measures are pending in other conservative states.

articles.title: Nicolás Maduro ‘tries to imitate my dance’, says Trump in latest accusation
articles.trailText: More seriously, US president claims ousted Venezuelan leader has ‘killed millions of people’ in remarks to congressional Republicans
articles.summary: At a GOP gathering in Washington, Trump accused ousted Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro—recently seized in a US raid that left dozens dead—of mimicking his trademark hip-swaying and arm-waving while dancing to a techno remix of “No War, Yes Peace.” He also leveled unsubstantiated claims that Maduro “killed millions” and ran a Caracas torture chamber. Trump contrasted his own controversial rally dances—criticized by his wife, Melania—with supporters’ enthusiasm as he mocks Maduro’s conduct amid terrorism and drug trafficking charges.

articles.title: Trump touts ‘brilliant’ Venezuela attack in remarks at House Republicans retreat
articles.trailText: President calls deposed leader Maduro a ‘violent guy’ in speech that receives warm reception from Republicans
articles.summary: At a House Republicans retreat at the JFK Center, President Trump hailed the weekend’s “brilliant” multi-aircraft assault that captured Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, noting no US special-forces fatalities despite opposition troops’ deaths. Amid applause, he derided Democrats for failing to thank him, mocked Maduro’s dancing and torture chamber, and alleged paid “Free Maduro” protesters. He urged unity on gender, healthcare, election reform and voter ID ahead of crucial 2026 midterms, warning of a third impeachment if Republicans lose. Trump repeated false 2020 election-rigging claims, mused on a third term and performed mock dances to rally support.

articles.title: Armed militias deployed in Venezuela as regime attempts to impose authority
articles.trailText: Paramilitary groups known as colectivos rove streets with assault rifles, stop and search cars and people’s phones
articles.summary: Venezuela’s interim regime deployed colectivos paramilitaries armed with assault rifles across Caracas to patrol streets, set up checkpoints and search vehicles and phones for signs of dissent after a US raid and President Maduro’s abduction. Interim president Delcy Rodríguez projected control, rebuffed US claims of running the country and hardened rhetoric. Authorities detained journalists, banned celebrations of Maduro’s ouster and warned of arrests for supporting the US attack amid fears of further strikes. Citizens describe a tense climate of fear; opposition figure María Corina Machado vows to return and contest power. Trump remains skeptical and ties support to oil concessions.

articles.title: Why is Donald Trump renewing calls for takeover of Greenland?
articles.trailText: US refuses to rule out military force to take control. This is why an attack on Nato ally would end alliance. And what do Greenlanders think?
articles.summary: After ousting Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, Trump revived his pursuit of Greenland, a Danish territory, declaring he “needs” it for national security and to bar Chinese access to its oil, gas, rare earths and strategic Arctic shipping routes opened by melting ice. Denmark’s PM Mette Frederiksen warned any US assault on a NATO ally would shatter the alliance, while Greenland’s PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen denounced “annexation fantasies.” White House aides insist a peaceful transfer suffices despite the US base at Thule. Nuuk has pressed Copenhagen over colonial-era forced IUD insertions and parenting tests, fueling pro-independence sentiment. European leaders affirm Greenland’s right to self-determination.

articles.title: Artists decry dismantling of Belgium’s oldest contemporary art museum
articles.trailText: Cost-saving plan to transfer Antwerp museum’s entire collection to another city described as ‘simply insane’
articles.summary: Flanders’ culture minister Caroline Gennez has abruptly canceled an €80m purpose-built home for Antwerp’s M HKA (founded 1985) and plans to dissolve the museum by moving its 8,000-strong contemporary art collection—including Luc Tuymans, Kerry James Marshall, Anish Kapoor and Marina Abramović—to Ghent’s Smak. M HKA directors decry “flagrant illegalities” and warn no equivalent ecosystem exists in Ghent. Belgium’s financial inspectorate disputes any meaningful savings, noting Smak lacks storage space. The shake-up to create three regional “beacon” museums faces parliamentary debate Friday amid a 5.4% GDP deficit and wider arts-sector cuts.

articles.title: Cops of the World by Phil Ochs captures the zeitgeist again | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: US imperialism | Trump’s actions in Venezuela | Roosevelt’s big stick | Tony Blair Institute | Citizen’s arrest | Fifa peace prize | Triumph of evil
articles.summary: Letters to the editor across the Guardian reflect on Phil Ochs’ 1966 protest song 'Cops of the World'—released 50 years ago—mocking US imperialism and its repeated flouting of international law. Writers propose shrinking the beleaguered G7 to G6 in light of Trump’s Venezuela threats and Greenland tensions; liken his loudspeaker diplomacy to Roosevelt’s 'big stick'; jest about Tony Blair Institute ground boots; wonder if British courts could okay citizen’s arrests of rogue leaders; tease Gianni Infantino over FIFA’s peace prize; and caution that evil thrives when good people stand idle.

articles.title: ‘Stock up’: Ontario premier promises to banish Crown Royal whisky from province
articles.trailText: Doug Ford’s move comes after Diageo announced plan to shutter Ontario whisky plant and move operations to US
articles.summary: Ontario Premier Doug Ford has vowed to force Crown Royal off province liquor shelves after Diageo announced it will close its Ontario distillery and shift production to the US, costing about 200 jobs. Locked in a tariff-fueled feud with the spirits giant, Ford says Ontario’s liquor board will banish the iconic Canadian whisky, introduced in 1939 and known for its purple velvet bag, to punish Diageo. Despite company assurances of continued Canadian distilling for non-US markets, Ford insists all operations will move to Alabama and warns he may target other Diageo labels, including Guinness and Smirnoff.

articles.title: Iranian security forces clash with protesters at Tehran’s grand bazaar
articles.trailText: Nationwide protests continue to grow as rights groups accuse authorities of cracking down on demonstrators
articles.summary: In Tehran’s historic grand bazaar, security forces dispersed a sit-in with teargas and expulsions on the 10th day of nationwide protests against inflation and economic decay. Rights groups report 35 dead and over 1,200 arrested amid demonstrations in 257 locations across 88 cities. The rial plummeted to 1.46m per dollar, stoking price surges and shortages as the central bank curbs preferential dollar rates. President Pezeshkian blamed sanctions for limited fiscal options, vowed probes into Illam province violence after a hospital raid condemned by the US as a crime against humanity.

articles.title: Why won’t Yvette Cooper criticise Trump over Venezuela? Look no further than Ukraine
articles.trailText: The foreign secretary faces a tight balancing act between keeping the US involved in peace talks, and trying to maintain international order
articles.summary: Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper has dodged condemning Donald Trump’s forcible removal of Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro to avoid jeopardising fragile US commitments to Ukraine security guarantees. British officials fear that public criticism could prompt Trump to abandon the painstakingly negotiated US role in binding protections serving as an alternative to Ukrainian NATO membership. Cooper signalled support for international law in private, while pressing to shape US plans for Venezuela’s democratic transition. The episode highlights the UK’s tightrope between upholding a rules-based order and preserving vital US backing under a transactional Trump-Rubio administration.

articles.title: Six people die as snow, ice and freezing temperatures wreak havoc in Europe
articles.trailText: Deaths in France and Bosnia as icy conditions disrupt travel in countries including UK and the Netherlands
articles.summary: Six people have died across Europe as snow, ice and sub-zero temperatures ground travel and trigger accidents. In south-west France three fatalities and 15 injuries occurred in road crashes; two more died near Paris after a river plunge and HGV collision. A Bosnian woman was killed by a falling branch in Sarajevo. Paris and Amsterdam airports cancelled up to 40% of flights to clear runways. Rail services in the Netherlands and Eurostar to Paris faced suspensions. Temperatures plunged below −10°C in Germany and −12.5°C in Britain, disrupting roads and schools. Snow, rain, floods affected Italy and the Balkans, prompting emergency measures.

articles.title: How a US takeover of Greenland would undermine Nato from within
articles.trailText: The alliance has no provision for the previously unthinkable: one of its members turning on another
articles.summary: The article explores a hypothetical US invasion of Greenland and its implications for NATO’s cohesion. Article 5 offers no precedent for intra‐alliance aggression, so a US attack on fellow member Denmark’s Arctic territory would paralyze mutual defense, erode treaty credibility and benefit Russia. Recent disputes over US defense commitments under Donald Trump, rising European NATO spending targets, and America’s overwhelming military advantage highlight deep transatlantic rifts. Experts warn Greenland’s seizure would expose vulnerabilities despite allies’ agreement to lift defence spending to 3.5% of GDP by 2035, and shift European security doubts toward greater self-reliance.

articles.title: Israel pushes ahead with vast illegal settlement in heart of West Bank
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Tender posted for construction of 3,401 homes in settlement designed to ‘bury idea of a Palestinian state’
articles.summary: Israel’s Land Authority quietly issued a tender in December for 3,401 homes in the E1 settlement east of Jerusalem, aiming to sever north-south West Bank and preclude a viable Palestinian state. Peace Now’s Yonatan Mizrachi warns accelerated planning could see construction start within a year. UK, France, Canada and other allies condemned it as illegal. Finance minister Bezalel Smotrich and PM Netanyahu back the plan to “bury” Palestinian statehood. Infrastructure funding was approved with Ma’ale Adumim in September; fast-tracked bids, permits and contracts could see bulldozers moving in before October elections.

articles.title: People in Greenland: share your views on Trump’s recent comments
articles.trailText: We’d like to hear from people in Greenland on their thoughts about the US president’s renewed call to take over the territory
articles.summary: Speaking aboard Air Force One on Sunday, President Trump doubled down to reporters on his claim that Greenland—an autonomous Danish territory—should be transferred to US sovereignty, insisting it is vital for US national security and that Denmark lacks the capacity to defend the island. The article solicits direct feedback from Greenland residents on Trump’s renewed takeover proposal via an online form below, with troubleshooting links and access to terms of service and privacy policy. Readers are encouraged to share their perspectives on his recent comments and the strategic implications for the Arctic region.

articles.title: María Corina Machado vows to return to Venezuela and rejects rule of Maduro’s deputy
articles.trailText: Opposition leader says her movement is ready to win a fair election and praises Trump for toppling the president
articles.summary: María Corina Machado, Venezuelan opposition leader, vows immediate return and rejects interim president Delcy Rodríguez—US-backed after Trump ousted Maduro. Speaking from hiding, she says her movement won a 2024 election landslide under fraudulent conditions and would capture over 90% in a free vote. She praises Trump’s intervention and offers him her Nobel Peace Prize, while denouncing Rodríguez for torture, corruption and narco-trafficking amid rising repression. Reports cite US security concerns and personal tensions behind Trump’s support shift. Maduro’s decree now declares a state of emergency, mobilizes forces, suspends protests and briefly detains dozens of journalists amid drone and gunfire reports near the presidential palace.

articles.title: Warning over TikTok scam using AI-generated videos of Spain’s Princess Leonor
articles.trailText: Princess of Asturias Foundation says fraudsters are using fake profiles and videos purporting to show heir to Spanish throne
articles.summary: The Princess of Asturias Foundation has warned that fraudsters are using AI-generated TikTok videos and fake profiles to impersonate 20-year-old Princess Leonor, offering thousands of dollars in return for small upfront fees. An El País investigation traced all scam phone numbers to the Dominican Republic and found some videos have over one million views. The foundation stresses it offers no financial schemes, and despite repeated complaints, TikTok has refused to remove the fraudulent content.

articles.title: From elation to frustration: Trump snub wrongfoots Venezuela’s opposition
articles.trailText: Some supporters of María Corina Machado still see path to power after US president refused to back her
articles.summary: Venezuelan opposition figures initially hailed Operation Absolute Resolve and Maduro’s capture but were blindsided when President Trump ruled out supporting conservative leader María Corina Machado, citing her lack of “respect,” and signaled recognition of interim president Delcy Rodríguez. Opposition stalwarts—including Ricardo Hausmann, Pedro Burelli and Machado coordinator Pedro Antonio de Mendonça—expressed astonishment and warned of a “legal and political vacuum,” deep regime divisions and continued US pressure. Analysts doubt Rodríguez’s legitimacy and foresee a future electoral contest Machado is poised to win. Despite frustration, exile leaders cling to optimism that free elections and democratic transition remain possible.

articles.title: No safety inspections at site of Swiss bar fire for past five years, mayor says
articles.trailText: Nicolas Féraud says he does not know why bar in Crans-Montana had not been inspected annually, as required by law
articles.summary: Authorities in Crans-Montana revealed that Le Constellation bar, where a New Year’s Eve fire killed 40 (average age 19, 20 minors) and injured 116, went without legally required safety inspections from 2020 to 2025. Mayor Nicolas Féraud apologized but blamed understaffing of five officers for 10,000 buildings and refused to resign. Investigators probe whether sparkler-lit champagne bottles ignited foam-clad ceilings and hold bar owners Jacques and Jessica Moretti, now under homicide-by-negligence suspicion, responsible. Legal representatives of victims demand full accountability; the municipality joined civil proceedings. Memorials and a French government tribute, with President Macron attending, are planned.

articles.title: Wes Streeting warns of ‘disintegration’ of rules-based world order after Venezuela attack
articles.trailText: UK health secretary declines to criticise Donald Trump directly but suggests he is disturbed by events of recent days
articles.summary: Streeting warned US capture of Maduro shows the rules-based order is disintegrating, threatening UK security. He avoided direct Trump criticism, saying Starmer must tread carefully as the system “creaks.” He urged Europe to boost defence and intelligence, insisting “a world without rules” is unsafe. He argued Europe must assume robust control of its own defence. Streeting backed Starmer’s cautious stance to protect UK interests and Venezuelan democracy. Maduro pleaded not guilty in New York amid uncertainty, while Trump praised the raid as a regional blueprint.

articles.title: Iran to try risky economic concessions as it attempts to quell protesters’ anger
articles.trailText: President wants to placate demonstrators calling for political change, action on corruption and help with cost of living
articles.summary: Iran’s president Masoud Pezeshkian is abolishing the preferential foreign exchange subsidy system—blamed for corruption and rial collapse—in favor of direct consumer payments, while parliament considers 43% wage hikes, VAT cut to 10%, $8.8 bn in subsidized forex and pension adjustments. The reforms aim to defuse unrest that’s spread to 27 provinces over nine days, leaving 35+ dead and 1,200+ arrested. Hardliners warn no more concessions; judiciary chief Gholamhossein Mohseni Ejei accuses the US/Israel of fueling chaos. Protesters demand political reform and accountability for security forces’ shootings; UN chief Guterres and Trump have publicly weighed in.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: Will a ban on advertising junk food help to tackle obesity in the UK?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As new rules ban TV and online ads for high-fat, salt and sugar products​, the curbing of junk food marketing has found cross-party support
articles.summary: From 5 January 2026, the UK enforces a cross-party ban on TV advertising of HFSS (high fat, salt, sugar) foods before the 9 pm watershed and paid online ads at all times. Using nutrient profiling (A vs C nutrients), the measure targets products from cereal bars to pastries, snacks and sugary drinks to reduce children’s exposure amid 27% of UK children overweight/obese. William Roberts (RSPH) cites Transport for London’s 2019 junk-food ad ban, which cut calorie, fat and sugar intake in 10 months, as evidence. Industry reaction is mixed: some will reformulate; others seek clarity on implementation and scope online.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian strikes kill two and trigger hospital fire ahead of Paris peace talks
articles.trailText: Overnight attacks trigger evacuations ‘under fire’ at Kyiv medical facility while European leaders gather to seek peace plan breakthrough. What we know on day 1,413
articles.summary: Overnight Russian strikes launched 165 drones and nine missiles, killing two – one in a private Kyiv hospital fire (three wounded) and a man in Fastiv – and causing power outages amid –8°C. Kharkiv’s energy grid and a Bunge facility in Dnipro were struck. Ukraine’s drone downed in Russia’s Tver region killed one and injured two. European leaders, including envoys Kushner and Witkoff, meet in Paris to finalise a “90% ready” peace plan. President Zelenskiy appointed Chrystia Freeland as economic adviser, reshuffled his cabinet, and reassigned SBU chief Vasyl Malyuk. Russia claims seizing Grabovske in Sumy.

articles.title: What does the US raid in Venezuela mean for China’s designs on Taiwan?
articles.trailText: Perception that Chinese-made weapons could not stop a ‘decapitation strike’ may give Beijing pause for thought
articles.summary: Details of the US operation to seize Nicolás Maduro in Venezuela have sparked debate in Beijing and Taipei over Taiwan’s security. Chinese analysts dismiss parallels, calling cross-strait ties a domestic issue, but Taiwan sees the raid as proof that Chinese weapons may not deter a US ‘decapitation strike.’ Despite the PLA’s growing firepower—hypersonics, AI and biotech—the failure of Chinese arms in Venezuela could give Beijing pause. Washington’s swift action underlines US resolve and complicates Beijing’s calculations, even as allies shy away from condemning breaches of international law. In Taiwan, commentators urge unity and vigilance to avoid Venezuelan-style vulnerability, while still banking on US support.

articles.title: Venezuela detains journalists and seizes communication devices after Maduro’s removal
articles.trailText: Thirteen of those detained were released according to the country’s National Union of Press Workers
articles.summary: In Caracas, Venezuelan authorities detained 14 journalists and media staff, including 13 foreigners, after US troops captured Nicolás Maduro. SNTP reports 13 later freed (one deported), one remains in intelligence custody. Detainees—covering the National Assembly opening, barred from recording—had phones seized, searched for contacts and files. Daniel Álvarez of Televen was freed. At the Venezuela–Colombia border, Univision’s Juan Carlos Vélez and crew were briefly detained; others lost footage. A Guardian reporter was expelled. The National Association logged 21 journalist arrests in 2025 on charges like terrorism. Reporters Without Borders warns forced disappearances have become routine in repressing Venezuela’s free press.

articles.title: US attack on Greenland would mean end of Nato, says Danish PM
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen criticises Donald Trump’s ‘unacceptable pressure’ as Greenland counterpart condemns ‘fantasies’
articles.summary: Denmark’s PM Mette Frederiksen warned that US President Trump’s renewed threats to annex Greenland would shatter NATO and post-WWII security if the US attacked its ally. Greenland’s PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen condemned “fantasies about annexation” and “unacceptable pressure,” stressing the island’s democratic autonomy. The EU, Sweden, Norway and other NATO members reaffirmed support for Danish sovereignty. Analysts highlight strategic Arctic competition over minerals and US missile defenses, spurring calls for concrete defense plans as Greenland weighs its future.

articles.title: MPs across UK parties criticise ministers over cautious stance on Venezuela attack
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer and Yvette Cooper challenged over cautious response to Nicolás Maduro’s capture despite widespread doubts about legality
articles.summary: MPs from Labour, Conservative and Liberal Democrat benches have attacked Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper and PM Keir Starmer for refusing to condemn Donald Trump’s raid and capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro as a breach of international law, warning that Britain’s cautious stance undermines Western unity and risks emboldening China, Russia and even US threats like Greenland annexation. Cross-party figures—from Emily Thornberry and Richard Burgon to Ed Davey and former foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt—demand an explicit defence of the UN charter and concrete plans to safeguard NATO allies. Cooper spoke to her US counterpart and opposition leader María Machado but declined to label the abduction illegal, insisting Washington must set out its justification—a stance critics say reveals UK diplomatic timidity.

articles.title: Starmer delivers masterclass in hedging his bets after Venezuela raid
articles.trailText: Prime minister assures colleagues he may one day stand up to Donald Trump – but not yet
articles.summary: After Trump’s CIA-backed raid seizing Nicolás Maduro, Starmer waited 16 hours before calling Maduro “illegitimate” but stopped short of condemning the US, stressing respect for international law. Under pressure from Lib Dems, Greens and anxious Foreign Office officials, Downing Street adopted a realpolitik line—saying as little as possible to offend Washington and leaving legal justification to the US. Starmer, who backed Denmark on Greenland’s autonomy, is due a tactful call with Trump after a Paris summit, warning a tougher stance may wait until UK interests allow.

articles.title: US foes and allies denounce Trump’s ‘crime of aggression’ in Venezuela at UN meeting
articles.trailText: US ambassador defends attack as ‘law enforcement’ action against an ‘illegitimate’ leader, not an act of war
articles.summary: At a UN Security Council emergency meeting convened hours before Nicolás Maduro’s Manhattan trial on narco-terrorism charges, members including Brazil, China, Russia, Colombia, South Africa and Spain denounced President Trump’s cross-border raid in Venezuela as a “crime of aggression” aimed at seizing Maduro and his wife. US envoy Mike Waltz defended the strikes as a law-enforcement operation executing criminal indictments, not acts of war. Secretary-General Guterres warned it risked regional destabilisation and violated international law. Russia, China and Latin American states demanded the pair’s release, while deep divisions and the US veto blocked censure.

articles.title: Palestine’s ambassador to UK hails embassy as ‘proof our identity cannot be denied’
articles.trailText: Husam Zomlot says inauguration of mission in London marks change of direction for Palestinian state
articles.summary: Palestine’s ambassador to the UK, Husam Zomlot, inaugurated the state’s embassy in Hammersmith, branding the upgrade from mission to embassy a “monumental” proof of Palestinians’ inalienable identity and sovereign statehood. He described it as a “change of direction” reflecting UK recognition in September aimed at preserving a two-state solution. The ceremony, attended by MPs, diplomats and public, came after pro-Israel vandalism targeted the building. Zomlot cited 422 Gaza deaths since October’s ceasefire and Gaza’s devastation, while 14-year-old refugee Obaidah, evacuated for medical care, spoke of hope for justice and dignity.

articles.title: Zelenskyy names Canada’s ex-finance minister as economic adviser in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Chrystia Freeland takes on new role amid government shakeup in Kyiv as Ukrainian president replaces key figures
articles.summary: President Zelenskiy appointed Canada’s former finance minister and deputy prime minister Chrystia Freeland as adviser on Ukraine’s economic development amid a major Kyiv government shake-up, replacing top intelligence chiefs and Yermak’s exit. Freeland, who speaks Ukrainian and has ancestral ties, will leverage her experience attracting investment and driving reforms to bolster resilience for recovery and defense. A former journalist, she served under Trudeau, chaired the Pinchuk forum, and was Canada’s special envoy for Ukraine reconstruction. She remains a Toronto MP and will become CEO of the Rhodes Trust in July.

articles.title: Colombian president says ‘I will take up arms again’ if US invades
articles.trailText: Gustavo Petro makes remark after Trump threatens military action similar to Venezuela
articles.summary: Following US forces’ attack on Venezuela to oust Nicolás Maduro, Trump threatened similar intervention in Colombia, labeling President Gustavo Petro a 'cocaine-making sick man'. Petro—former M-19 guerrilla turned president—denounced the slander via X, warned that US bombs would drive campesinos into guerrilla ranks, and vowed 'for the homeland I will take up arms again'. Relations have soured over drug allegations, visa revocation and sanctions, while Colombia fortifies Petro’s security amid broad political backlash.

articles.title: Zelenskyy forces out Ukrainian spy chief who led daring raids against Russia
articles.trailText: Vasyl Malyuk reportedly unwilling to leave post as head of the Security Service but will now lead special operations
articles.summary: President Zelenskyy has forced the resignation of SBU chief Vasyl Malyuk, a Hero of Ukraine famed for last year’s Operation Spiderweb drone raid that destroyed Russian strategic bombers and inflicted an estimated $7 bn in damage. Malyuk initially resisted leaving but agreed to step down and instead oversee asymmetric special operations within the SBU, rejecting posts in foreign intelligence and the national security council. His replacement, Maj Gen Yevhen Khmara, formerly headed the elite Alpha unit. Analysts speculate the shake-up reflects Zelenskyy’s push for fresh faces and political motives ahead of upcoming elections.

articles.title: Trump’s lawless actions in Venezuela demand a resolute response | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: International law cannot be selective, writes Hannah Walker , while Celia Cashman calls for an alliance to challenge to US actions in Venezuela, and Charlie Owen for clarity of language
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s vow to occupy Venezuela, install US oil firms and dictate its political transition breaches the UN charter’s ban on force, constituting occupation and pillage under Hague and Geneva rules, warn Guardian letter writers. They cite the UN secretary-general’s warning that international law has been flouted. Hannah Walker says selective enforcement would collapse norms protecting Ukraine and criticizes Keir Starmer’s refusal to condemn force as treating legality as conditional; Celia Cashman calls for a European-Canada-South Africa-Australia alliance to oppose US supremacy; Charlie Owen urges ‘abduction’ over ‘capture’ for clarity.

articles.title: What’s in the US criminal indictment against Nicolás Maduro?
articles.trailText: US alleges the Venezuelan president has spent past two decades working with international drug trafficking groups
articles.summary: On Jan. 5, 2026, the US superseding indictment alleged that Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro and five co-defendants — including his wife, Cilia Flores, son Nicolás Ernesto “Nicolasito” Maduro Guerra and Tren de Aragua leader Héctor Guerrero — spent two decades collaborating with FARC, ELN, Sinaloa, the Zetas and other narco-trafficking groups to ship cocaine and conceal weapons shipments into the US. New charges expand the 2020 complaint to include narco-terrorism, cocaine importation, machine-gun and destructive-device offenses and conspiracy, and adds Cilia Flores for accepting bribes. Prosecutors cite meetings arranged via “Nicolasito” trading weapons for cocaine; potential cooperation from ex-spy chief Hugo Carvajal; and face a court challenge over Maduro’s head-of-state immunity.

articles.title: Delcy Rodríguez strikes conciliatory tone with US after Trump warning
articles.trailText: Venezuela’s interim leader offers to work with US after Trump threatened she could pay ‘very big price’
articles.summary: Venezuela’s acting president Delcy Rodríguez, sworn in by the supreme court and swiftly recognized by the military after US forces seized Nicolás Maduro and his wife on drug and weapons charges, has offered to "work jointly on an agenda of cooperation" with Washington. The move from initial defiance follows Donald Trump’s warning she could "pay a very big price" and his threat of further strikes if she resists. His endorsement sidelines the opposition led by María Corina Machado, while Venezuelans celebrate cautiously under fear of repression.

articles.title: Trump’s attack leaves China worried about its interests in Venezuela | Amy Hawkins
articles.trailText: Maduro had just affirmed ‘strong bonds of brotherhood’ with Beijing when US made its shocking intervention
articles.summary: After Maduro’s handshake with China’s envoy, Trump’s US forces ousted him, alarming Beijing, which condemned the action as imperialist, backed Maduro’s release, and urged a UN debate. China’s financial regulators are probing $10bn in outstanding Venezuelan debt from $106bn in loans since 2000, fearing US-led debt prioritization could trigger losses for Chinese lenders tied to loan-for-oil deals. Beijing, Venezuela’s biggest oil buyer (4% of China’s imports), may leverage rare earths exports or restructure future oil proceeds to protect creditors. Analysts warn legal action could follow if a US-backed regime repudiates Maduro-era agreements, forcing China to litigate Caracas rather than negotiate with Washington.

articles.title: All 116 people injured in Swiss resort fire identified, say police
articles.trailText: Bodies of first foreign victims repatriated after 40 people died in bar fire during New Year’s Eve party in Crans-Montana
articles.summary: Valais police have identified all 116 people injured in the New Year’s Eve fire at Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, revising the toll down from 119. Among the wounded – 68 Swiss, 21 French, 10 Italian, four Serb, four dual nationals, two Polish and one each from seven other countries – 83 remain hospitalized with severe burns. The last of 40 fatalities, predominantly youths averaging 19 years, were confirmed Sunday; five of six Italian victims were repatriated Monday. Investigators suspect sparklers ignited foam-clad ceilings; owners Jacques and Jessica Moretti face negligent homicide probes. A memorial is planned Friday, with President Macron attending.

articles.title: US aircraft monitor tanker off Ireland that tried to evade Venezuela blockade
articles.trailText: Ship changed its name and registered in Russia in apparent attempt to prevent possible US seizure near British Isles
articles.summary: US surveillance aircraft (P-8s) are monitoring the tanker formerly known as Bella 1—now Marinera, reflagged in Russia—250 miles off Ireland after it evaded a US naval blockade of sanctioned Venezuelan oil. US C-17s and AC-130s at RAF bases suggest a possible special-forces seizure mission. Sanctioned since July 2024 over alleged Hezbollah-linked illicit cargo, the tanker joins a dozen vessels spoofing identities to dodge a Trump-ordered “complete blockade.” Venezuela denounces US “piracy” amid Maduro’s recent capture.

articles.title: Nicolás Maduro to appear in New York court on drugs and weapons charges
articles.trailText: Venezuelan president captured by US in shocking raid is seen being led in handcuffs on his way to court
articles.summary: In a pre-dawn US special forces raid in Caracas, deposed Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores were captured, reportedly after an assault that killed at least 40. On Monday, they appeared in Manhattan federal court on charges of narco-terrorism, cocaine importation and illegal arms possession. President Trump hailed the operation as a “brilliant blueprint” for Latin America and threatened further interventions, including seizing Venezuela’s oil industry. He asserted US control of Venezuela until a “judicious transition” and hinted at possible actions in Colombia. Meanwhile, acting Venezuelan president Delcy Rodríguez, sworn in amid constitutional questions, offered pragmatic cooperation with Washington. Democrats condemned the raid as unconstitutional.

articles.title: Starmer backs Danish PM after she demands US stop threats to take over Greenland
articles.trailText: British prime minister says Donald Trump should stop raising idea of US annexation he claims necessary for security
articles.summary: British PM Keir Starmer publicly backed Denmark’s PM Mette Frederiksen after she demanded the US end threats to annex Greenland. Starmer told BBC and Sky News that Greenland’s future rests solely with Greenland and the Danish kingdom, calling Denmark “a close ally.” Frederiksen labelled US takeover talk “absolute nonsense,” while Greenland’s PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen decried threats as disrespectful and against international law. The controversy follows Donald Trump’s reiterated security-driven claim he “needs” Greenland and a pro-Trump podcaster’s X post depicting Greenland under US stars and stripes. Danish migration minister Mike Tapp declined to publicly challenge the US rhetoric, citing diplomatic delicacy.

articles.title: From grudging respect to unease: Russia weighs up fall of Maduro
articles.trailText: Reaction to effectiveness of US operation contrasts with loss of key ally for Putin, whose priority remains Ukraine
articles.summary: In a swift US raid, Donald Trump–authorized forces captured Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, sparking Russian anger and grudging admiration at its “decisive” execution, as pro-Kremlin outlets lament Moscow’s failed blitzkrieg in Ukraine. Voices from Dva Mayora to Margarita Simonyn express envy and shame over Russia’s protracted war, while Putin, prioritizing Ukraine and ties with Trump, shuns intervention. Moscow risks losing billions in loans, advanced arms (S-300, Pantsir, Buk-M2) and crucial oil leverage. Hawks like Medvedev hail a return to power politics over international law.

articles.title: Paris court finds 10 guilty of harassing Brigitte Macron online
articles.trailText: Teacher and publicist among those convicted of maliciously posting or sharing false claims French first lady is a man
articles.summary: A Paris court convicted ten individuals—eight men and two women, aged 41 to 60, including a teacher, gallery owner and publicist—for online harassment of First Lady Brigitte Macron by spreading malicious claims she was a man named Jean-Michel Trogneux. Sentences ranged from compulsory anti-harassment courses to suspended prison terms, with one absentee developer handed six months behind bars. Several were barred from the offending platforms. The ruling, part of transatlantic defamation battles including a US lawsuit against Candace Owens, underscores Macron’s fight against false gender attacks and online bullying.

articles.title: From tourism to wine, Syrian businesses flounder in post-Assad cultural flux
articles.trailText: Shop owners report fewer travellers while bars and wineries hope for legal clarity on alcohol sale
articles.summary: In post-Assad Syria’s coastal city of Tartous, souvenir sellers report a collapse in tourism since the year-old Islamist-led government replaced the regime: they’ve swapped Assad memorabilia for revolutionary flags, handicrafts and rebel portraits, yet footfall remains low amid security concerns. At the Jarjour winery, decades of harassment by former officials have ended but a lack of clear alcohol laws bars sales, forcing two years of losses. In Damascus, bars face arbitrary raids and licensing limbo even as rooftop raves and house parties flourish. Syrians navigate new cultural boundaries—defacing Assad portraits, cautious of Islamist rulers—while entrepreneurs await legal clarity to revive their businesses and wines.

articles.title: Protests in US cities over Trump’s military intervention in Venezuela
articles.trailText: Hundreds gathered coast to coast, even as many in the diaspora celebrated ousting of Maduro
articles.summary: Hundreds gathered in Chicago, Dallas, New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, San Francisco and Seattle to protest Trump’s unilateral operation that captured Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro—an action some diaspora members celebrated—and flew him to New York on drug-trafficking charges. Organized by ANSWER and Code Pink, protesters condemned potential war, constitutional overreach, UN charter breaches and Venezuelan deportations, waving “No Blood for Oil” signs and urging Maduro’s release. Senior Democrats decried bypassing Congress, while most Republican lawmakers praised Trump’s intervention.

articles.title: Donald Trump warns of ‘big price to pay’ if Caracas fails to toe line
articles.trailText: Washington keeping 15,000-strong military presence in Caribbean in case interim president hinders US objectives
articles.summary: After Nicolás Maduro’s ouster, US plans to seize direct control of Venezuela receded, but Trump warned interim president Delcy Rodríguez to comply with US oil and security demands or face a second military intervention. Washington maintains 15,000 troops in the Caribbean and a maritime “quarantine” on Venezuelan oil under sanctions. Trump also threatened operations in Colombia and Mexico over drug flows. Rodríguez pledged cooperation after talks with Secretary of State Rubio. Cuba confirmed 32 casualties from the US raid. Maduro, indicted for narco-terrorism, faces arraignment in New York. EU and Latin American governments urged restraint as Venezuelans queued for supplies amid uncertainty.

articles.title: ‘Women have to fight for what they want’: UK campaigner’s 60-year unfinished battle for abortion rights
articles.trailText: Diane Munday helped secure legal terminations in 1967 and, aged 94, is still calling for wider reproductive rights
articles.summary: Diane Munday, now 94, co-founded the British Pregnancy Advice Service and helped secure the 1967 UK Abortion Act but says “the job is only half done”. Driven by a friend’s death and her own 1961 abortion, she spent decades lobbying, gathering women’s hidden testimonies to shift public opinion. This summer, parliament passed an amendment ending criminal probes into women’s terminations, yet Munday still urges full decriminalisation and removal of two-doctor rules. She warns of US rollbacks post-Roe v Wade, welcomes free morning-after pills, but doubts a modern UK Abortion Act will arrive soon.

articles.title: Monday briefing: Why the US moved to oust Venezuela’s president
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Saturday’s capture of Nicolás Maduro by the US was as unexpected as it was swift – but what led Trump to topple the South American regime?
articles.summary: Over the weekend, US forces launched airstrikes and seized Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores, transporting them to New York. President Trump declared the operation aimed to hand Venezuela’s vast oil infrastructure to US companies and fight alleged narco-trafficking charges against Maduro, who was indicted in 2020. He warned of further strikes if interim leader Delcy Rodríguez refused US demands. The swift action—echoes of Baghdad 2003—followed years of “maximum pressure” sanctions and military threats, deploying 15,000 troops in the Caribbean. The assault, which left over 40 dead, drew mixed regional and global reactions and fresh debates on US interventionism.

articles.title: The weightlifting champion jailed by Russia for ‘plotting sabotage and assassinations’
articles.trailText: Yulia Lemeshchenko was defiant and did not deny the accusations, saying she had decided to fight against Russian military aggression
articles.summary: Yulia Lemeshchenko, 42, a Voronezh-born weightlifter who became Ukraine’s 2021 champion after moving to Kharkiv, was sentenced to 19 years in a Russian prison for allegedly plotting sabotage of power lines near St Petersburg and an assassination attempt on an air force commander. She admitted participating, professed a clear conscience and patriotism driven by Kharkiv’s war devastation. The FSB says she volunteered via a Telegram bot for Ukrainian services; authorities displayed video of her confession and seized alleged explosives and burner phones from her apartment, though experts caution confessions under duress.

articles.title: Woman wearing ‘globalise the intifada’ jacket among three arrested at Sydney protest against US action in Venezuela
articles.trailText: About 300 people turned out in Sydney despite NSW police prohibition on public demonstrations, as protests across Australia condemn US actions
articles.summary: About 300 people defied an NSW ban to protest in Sydney against US military action in Venezuela after reports that US forces removed President Nicolás Maduro. Police arrested three—including a woman wearing a “globalise the intifada” jacket—for alleged breach of peace and displaying offensive messaging under post-Bondi anti-protest laws. A parliamentary inquiry is examining hate speech bans including that slogan. Similar rallies occurred in Melbourne. Opposition supporters counter-protested. The Venezuelan diaspora in Australia expressed mixed emotions. Prime Minister Albanese urged dialogue and diplomacy.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv escalating drone attacks on Russia, Moscow claims
articles.trailText: Russia’s defence ministry said Ukraine had targeted Moscow with drones every day of 2026 so far. What we know on day 1,412
articles.summary: Russia’s defence ministry reports that Ukraine has carried out daily drone strikes on Moscow throughout early 2026, downing 57 drones over the capital and 437 nationwide by Jan 5. Kyiv’s long-range drones target energy and logistics hubs to raise Moscow’s war costs and retaliate for Russian attacks. Three of four Moscow airports closed, causing widespread flight disruptions during New Year. Ukrainian strikes killed two in Belgorod and Kursk; Russia’s overnight raids on Kyiv province and Fastiv killed two. Kharkiv saw five fatalities from a missile strike and three wounded in drone hits. A Ukrainian drone sparked a fire at the Energiya battery plant in Yelets, Lipetsk, with no casualties.

articles.title: Few in Caracas are celebrating as they face an uncertain post-Maduro future
articles.trailText: Stockpiling not partying is the priority for Venezuelans who say they fear crackdowns by the regime the US left in place
articles.summary: After the first-ever large-scale US airstrike on South American soil struck Caracas and nabbed President Nicolás Maduro, residents of the 3 million-strong city queued to stockpile essentials amid power and water cuts, expressing fear and uncertainty rather than celebration. While some quietly welcomed Maduro’s removal, most feared regime reprisals and doubted lasting change; the military endorsed Vice-President Delcy Rodríguez as acting president and Trump signaled willingness to work with her, prompting regional governments to brace for instability at the border.

articles.title: US ‘has no right’ to take over Greenland, Danish PM says after renewed Trump threats
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen responds to president amid febrile atmosphere after US actions in Venezuela
articles.summary: Denmark PM Mette Frederiksen rebuked Trump’s renewed threats to annex Greenland after US actions in Venezuela stoked takeover fears. Trump doubled down on claims that Greenland is vital for national security, echoed by rightwing voices like Katie Miller and special envoy Jeff Landry. Greenland PM Jens-Frederik Nielsen condemned the symbolism as a breach of sovereignty and international law, while Denmark’s US ambassador underscored NATO ties and a $13.7bn Arctic defense budget. Amid US, China and Russia competition in the Arctic, Denmark’s intelligence service labeled the US a security risk; Greenlanders largely favor independence but reject US rule.

articles.title: ‘Things are complicated’: tense calm holds at Venezuela’s border with Colombia after Maduro capture
articles.trailText: Many shops closed after rush to buy essentials, as exiles held muted celebrations amid uncertainty about future
articles.summary: Following the US capture and rendition of Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro, a tense calm prevails at the Simón Bolívar bridge border crossing with Colombia. National guard troops report unchanged orders amid uncertainty, while Trump claims the US will govern Venezuela temporarily. Colombian president Gustavo Petro denounces this as an assault on Latin American sovereignty, prompting heightened security around him. Organized crime and ELN guerrillas straddle the 2,200 km frontier. Colombian Red Cross teams and contingency plans stand ready for up to 120,000 fleeing Venezuelans. Locals clear shop shelves, and exiled Venezuelans in Cúcuta hold muted freedom rallies but await clearer signals before returning.

articles.title: Last 16 victims of Crans-Montana fire identified, police say
articles.trailText: Hundreds of people join silent procession in Swiss town, with youngest known victim just 14
articles.summary: Swiss police have identified the final 16 victims of the New Year’s Eve blaze at Crans-Montana, completing the ID of 40 bodies. Severe burns slowed forensic work. The newly named include teens and young adults—two Swiss girls aged 15, a 15-year-old British-Israeli, Italian youths aged 15 and 16, plus victims from France, Portugal and Belgium. Hundreds joined a silent procession past Le Constellation bar, laying bouquets and applauding emergency workers. Switzerland will hold a national day of mourning Friday. Prosecutors suspect sparklers touching acoustic panels caused the fire; two bar managers face involuntary homicide and safety-breach investigations.

articles.title: Anne Frank stepsister and Auschwitz survivor Eva Schloss dies aged 96
articles.trailText: The king, who danced with Anne Frank’s stepsister in 2022, said he and Queen Camilla ‘admired her deeply’
articles.summary: Eva Schloss, Anne Frank’s stepsister and Auschwitz survivor, has died aged 96. Born Eva Geiringer in Vienna, she evaded capture in Amsterdam before deportation to Auschwitz in May 1944. Co-founder and honorary president of the Anne Frank Trust UK, she spent over 70 years in London promoting Holocaust education. King Charles III and Queen Camilla paid tribute, praising her courage and lifelong dedication to combating hatred. Married in 1952 with three daughters, Schloss regained Austrian citizenship in 2021. Her family and the Trust celebrate her legacy of resilience, tolerance and learning.

articles.title: Months in planning, over in two and a half hours: how the US snatched Maduro
articles.trailText: The operation to capture the Venezuelan president and his wife involved at least 150 aircraft, months of surveillance – and reportedly a spy in the government
articles.summary: In a pre-dawn raid lasting two hours and 28 minutes, US forces captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, after months of CIA surveillance—including a human source—and a Caribbean military buildup. Over 150 aircraft, from Tomahawk missiles and F-35 jets to modified Black Hawk and Chinook helicopters, achieved air dominance by suppressing S-300 and Buk defenses. Delta Force, trained on a replica of Maduro’s Caracas compound, breached steel doors with blow torches amid gunfire, killed dozens of guards, and exfiltrated the couple to the USS Iwo Jima. No US fatalities; around 40 Venezuelans died. The operation’s long-term political impact remains unclear.

articles.title: Top Republicans backpedal from Trump claim that US will run Venezuela
articles.trailText: Secretary of Stat Marco Rubio defends US capture of Maduro and says US has ‘leverage’ over country
articles.summary: After US forces captured Venezuela’s president Nicolás Maduro and flew him to face federal charges, Donald Trump claimed the US would “run” Venezuela in transition with figures like Marco Rubio, Pete Hegseth and Gen. Dan Caine. In rapid backpedaling, Rubio, Sen. Tom Cotton and Rep. Jim Jordan said the operation was aimed at applying US “leverage” to curb narco-trafficking, control oil exports and protect American interests, not to assume direct governance. They stressed no US ground troops are deployed, cited unspecified legal bases and said Venezuela’s response will determine next steps.

articles.title: UK ‘not entirely clear’ what it means for US to ‘run’ Venezuela
articles.trailText: UK waiting to determine if US breached international law by capturing Nicolás Maduro, PM’s chief secretary says
articles.summary: Chief secretary Darren Jones says the UK is “not entirely clear” what President Trump meant by the US ‘running’ Venezuela after US forces attacked Caracas and captured President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, and will await legal analysis of any breach of international law. The UK urges a swift, peaceful transition reflecting Venezuelan will. Labour leader Keir Starmer insists on full facts before judging the strike; Lib Dem Ed Davey warns deference invites further aggression. Human rights KC Philippe Sands decries the raid as “manifestly illegal,” Reform UK’s Richard Tice defends it under US self-defence, and ex-Home Secretary Priti Patel calls for a clear democratic pathway.

articles.title: Leftwing militants claim responsibility for arson attack on Berlin power grid
articles.trailText: Protest over climate crisis and AI has cut power to tens of thousands of homes which may take days to fully restore
articles.summary: German leftwing militant group Vulkangruppe claimed a pre-New Year arson on a bridge over Berlin’s Teltow canal, cutting power to up to 35,000 homes and 1,900 businesses, including elderly care homes and hospitals, amid subzero temperatures. In a 2,500-word pamphlet they said they targeted wealthy districts to protest fossil-fuel energy for AI datacentres, framing the attack as “self-defence” for the planet. State security has launched an investigation; Stromnetz Berlin warns full restoration may take until 8 January. Mayor Kai Wegner condemned the politically motivated blackout, noting past far-left grid sabotage.

articles.title: European leaders appear torn in face of new world order after Venezuela attack
articles.trailText: Leaders try to focus on what comes next, as backing for ejection of Maduro mingles uncomfortably with voicing of support for international law
articles.summary: European leaders are deeply divided over the US’s forcible removal of Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, praising the end of his repressive regime but warning that Trump’s invasion flouts international law.
