While Italy’s Giorgia Meloni deems the operation a “defensive intervention,” others—Greece’s Kyriakos Mitsotakis, Germany’s Friedrich Merz, EU’s Kaja Kallas and Ursula von der Leyen—stress respect for the UN charter and call for a peaceful, democratic transition under opposition figures like María Corina Machado or Edmundo González Urrutia.

articles.title: Trump’s focus on Venezuelan oil reinforces claim action was never about ‘war on drugs’
articles.trailText: US president claims US will take back ‘stolen’ oil, but experts say no legal claim to natural reserves exists
articles.summary: At a Jan 4 press conference, Trump recast the operation in Venezuela as reclaiming 'stolen' oil, downplaying the 'war on drugs'. He claimed US-built reserves were taken by Maduro’s socialist regime, echoing adviser Stephen Miller, despite experts noting US firms held only exploration concessions and lack legal claim under international and UN sovereignty law. Venezuela’s PDVSA controls 50% of output; Chevron 25%; Russia, China and European JVs 25%. Past nationalisations (1976, 2007) led ExxonMobil and ConocoPhillips to win >$10bn in arbitration. Revived sanctions and partial Chevron licence complicate future investment, which experts say would need $100bn and a decade to restore output.

articles.title: Delcy Rodríguez strikes defiant tone but must walk tightrope as Venezuela’s interim leader
articles.trailText: Technocrat must accommodate US demands while shoring up a regime that is hated by many Venezuelans
articles.summary: In her first address as interim leader, Delcy Rodríguez, Maduro’s ex-vice-president and oil minister, condemned the US abduction of Maduro, pledging loyalty while performing defiance to loyalist forces. Washington, led by Trump, endorses her as a pliable technocrat to 'run' Venezuela, balancing US demands - energy investments and drug interdiction - with appeasing the regime's military. Her selection over opposition Nobel laureate María Corina Machado reflects US preference for a market-friendly yet autocratic partner. Rodríguez must navigate potential internal coups, uprisings or US force, walking a precarious tightrope between oil deals and Bolivarian ideology. Threats of US ground troops loom.

articles.title: ‘Venezuela helped us a lot’: US’s capture of Nicolás Maduro stirs anxiety in Cuba
articles.trailText: Trump government issues warning to Havana, which has lost key ally in its struggle with blackouts and fuel shortages
articles.summary: After US forces captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro, Cubans—long dependent on subsidized oil and political backing from Caracas—fear worsening blackouts and fuel shortages. President Díaz-Canel branded the action state terrorism akin to Gaza assaults, invoking memories of US invasions and the Bay of Pigs. In Mar-a-Lago, Trump warned of Cuba’s collapse, later saying it would crumble without intervention, while Rubio issued a direct threat. With daily nationwide outages and gasoline lines, public opinion is split: many denounce American aggression, others quietly hope for change despite no clear opposition leader.

articles.title: Why has the US captured Venezuela’s president and what happens next?
articles.trailText: Donald Trump’s capture of Nicolás Maduro follows months of military campaign and years of strained relationship
articles.summary: US forces launched pre-dawn airstrikes across Venezuela, seizing President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, and flying them to the US to face narco-terrorism charges in New York. The raid caps months of “maximum pressure”: naval deployments, strikes on alleged drug-smuggling vessels, and oil-tanker seizures that killed over 110 people. Trump touted US dominance and plans to “run” Venezuela and open its oil sector. Caracas’s Supreme Court named Vice-President Delcy Rodríguez acting head, but the military remains in place. Observers warn of prolonged chaos, refugee flows and potential further US operations.

articles.title: ‘It’s an opportunity’: joy and wariness among US Venezuelans after Maduro toppled
articles.trailText: Hundreds of people danced, sang and waved the flag of Venezuela in the suburban Miami city of Doral on Saturday
articles.summary: In Doral, Miami’s suburb where up to 40% of residents are Venezuelan, hundreds danced and chanted “libertad” after US troops captured Nicolás Maduro and his wife. Joy turned to unease when President Trump declared a US-run interim government, sidelining opposition leaders and seizing Venezuela’s oil assets—stoking fears of accelerated deportations among the diaspora. Florida Republicans hailed history in the making, while Democrats like Rep. Maxwell Frost condemned the move as illegal and dangerous. Exiled entrepreneurs see an opportunity to help rebuild Venezuela, but many remain wary of Washington’s uncertain plans.

articles.title: Canadian officials say US health institutions no longer dependable for accurate information
articles.trailText: Misinformation from the Trump administration is cited as fuelling Canadians’ concerns over childhood vaccinations
articles.summary: Canadian health minister Marjorie Michel and immunologists warn US agencies—driven by health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr’s anti-vaccine panel that dropped the CDC’s newborn hepatitis B recommendation and falsely hinted at a vaccine-autism link—can no longer be trusted for accurate guidance. After losing measles-elimination status and reporting over 5,000 cases amid pandemic-era doctor shortages and rising social-media misinformation, experts urge Canada to build its own surveillance system, strengthen domestic trust and collaborate globally rather than rely on faltering US institutions.

articles.title: Maduro indictment attempts to link Venezuelan leader to Tren de Aragua
articles.trailText: Co-defendants include alleged gang founder Héctor Rusthenford Guerrero Flores, indicted two weeks ago
articles.summary: Federal prosecutors superseded 2020 charges against Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro immediately after his US capture, adding allegations that he ‘partnered with narco-terrorists’ including Tren de Aragua. One of five co-defendants is alleged gang founder Héctor Rusthenford Guerrero Flores. Critics say the indictment amplifies Donald Trump’s contested claims—framing the Colombian street gang as a Venezuelan-backed invasion force—to justify mass deportations under the Alien Enemies Act. National intelligence contradicted US government assertions of state direction of TdA. Democrats on Capitol Hill decried the US-led raid as illegal and overly provocative.

articles.title: Venezuelan leaders’ fever dream of a US invasion finally becomes reality
articles.trailText: Maduro and Chávez used fears of American aggression to tighten their grip on power – but now an even greater fantasist has imposed his will on their country
articles.summary: Chávez and Maduro long invoked an imminent US invasion to shore up authoritarian rule; in a surreal twist, US forces under Trump bombed Caracas and arrested Nicolás Maduro and Cilia Flores without UN or congressional approval. The operation—topped by power-grid sabotage—mirrors Chávez’s own theatrics while Trump, labeled a fellow populist strongman, heralds a "Donroe doctrine" to govern Venezuela indefinitely, exploit oil fields via US oil majors, and cooperate with Chavista holdovers. The raid completes a historic circle from Bush-era coups to modern narco-terrorist falsehoods, leaving Venezuelans in hope and dread.

articles.title: Leading UK far-right activist spoke at Russian extreme nationalist event
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Patriotic Alternative’s Mark Collett addressed forum along with ideologue described as ‘Putin’s brain’
articles.summary: Mark Collett, founder of UK far-right group Patriotic Alternative, addressed the inaugural Forum of the International Anti-Globalist League in St Petersburg, convened by Kremlin-linked oligarch Konstantin Malofeyev. The summit featured ultranationalist Alexander Dugin and European far-right ideologues including Alain de Benoist, Alain Soral and Alexander von Bismarck. MPs warn Russia seeks to subvert UK democracy by aligning with and funding extremist groups, amplifying societal divisions through influence operations. Collett, who spoke online on birthrates and immigration, denies Russian state ties. Critics call for Patriotic Alternative’s ban amid concerns over hybrid warfare, digital recruitment and attacks on democratic values.

articles.title: ‘It has hit us very hard’: grief grips Crans-Montana as police identify more victims
articles.trailText: The community spirit of the close-knit Swiss resort where at least 40 people died in a fire is strong even as inhabitants say they feel crushed by the tragedy
articles.summary: In Crans-Montana, Switzerland, a New Year’s blaze at Le Constellation bar killed at least 40, including 11 minors and six foreign nationals, and injured 119. Police have identified 24 victims so far amid painstaking efforts due to severe burns. Bar owners face homicide, bodily harm and negligent arson probes over possible safety lapses after sparkling candles ignited renovations. The tight-knit resort community of 6,000 has held masses, closed shops, offered blood donations and shelter, and filled a makeshift memorial with candles and messages. Residents say the tragedy has crushed their spirit, eclipsing tourism concerns as grief and solidarity dominate daily life.

articles.title: ‘It has become difficult to live’: Hungarian writers bemoan country’s hostile environment
articles.trailText: Nobel prize for László Krasznahorkai provides a rare glimpse of unity in a nation divided on party lines
articles.summary: In Gyula, home to Nobel winner László Krasznahorkai, billboards honor his visionary oeuvre amid a fractious political backdrop. Hungarian authors say Viktor Orbán’s far-right Fidesz has tightened its grip on culture—seizing publishers, diverting arts funding to pro-government outlets, nationalizing Libri, enforcing anti-LGBTQ book bans and reshaping curricula to favor conservative writers. Independent periodicals struggle, young writers face emigration or precarity, and homophobic legislation chills content. Yet Krasznahorkai’s prize elicited rare cross-party celebration, as his hometown plans commemorative plaques and tours, underscoring literature’s enduring resonance in a polarized nation.

articles.title: ‘This is business as usual’: boss of bombed Ukrainian vodka maker seeks to expand exports
articles.trailText: Nemiroff says products still reaching UK chains such as Sainsbury’s and Tesco despite production difficulties
articles.summary: This is business as usual, says Yuriy Sorochynskyi, CEO of Nemiroff, Ukraine’s largest vodka exporter, whose products continue flowing to UK chains (Tesco, Sainsbury’s, Waitrose, Co-op) and duty free despite a 17,000-bottle container destroyed by a missile at Odesa amid the four-year war. After cutting Russian and Belarus sales, UK revenues rose 24% to £6.25m and global volumes recovered to 4.4m cases. Battling power cuts and a blockaded Black Sea, Nemiroff installed generators, rerouted by road, leverages EU-backed rail to western markets, and supports peers with bottling while boosting brand via Oleksandr Usyk and Premier League partnerships.

articles.title: Venezuela attack: what we know so far as US captures President Maduro
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says US will ‘run’ Venezuela as Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores are flown to New York
articles.summary: US forces conducted a pre-dawn large-scale assault on Caracas, La Guaira, Miranda and Aragua, killing at least 40. President Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores were captured in handcuffs, flown to New York and indicted by the DOJ on drug-trafficking charges. President Trump vowed to ‘run’ Venezuela and control its oil industry until a ‘safe, proper’ transition, posted photos on Truth Social, and appointed VP Delcy Rodríguez as acting head. VP Vance and Secretary Rubio praised the operation; UN Secretary-General Guterres warned of a dangerous precedent. Venezuela, Russia, Cuba, Iran and several Latin American governments condemned the intervention.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukraine will fight on if peace talks fail, Zelenskyy vows
articles.trailText: Ukraine’s top allies hold security talks in Kyiv; Russia condemns US attack on Venezuela. What we know on day 1,411
articles.summary: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Ukraine will fight on if peace talks fail, while hoping to convene a leaders’ summit in the US by end-January to finalise a US-brokered ceasefire plan. Security advisers from 15 countries – including the UK, France, Germany, NATO and the EU – met in Kyiv on Saturday, with US envoy Steve Witkoff joining virtually; follow-up talks are set for Paris and Washington. Russia and Ukraine remain deadlocked over territory: Moscow demands full Donbas, Kyiv refuses to cede land. Meanwhile, Russia condemned a US strike on Venezuela, calling for President Maduro’s release. On the ground, Russian strikes killed a woman and a three-year-old child in Kharkiv, and two in southern Kherson.

articles.title: Trump says US will ‘run’ Venezuela after Nicolás Maduro captured and taken to New York
articles.trailText: Audacious US military operation plucked Venezuelan leader from power and removed him from the country
articles.summary: US Special Forces raided Caracas, captured President Nicolás Maduro and flew him to New York. At Mar-a-Lago, Trump vowed to ‘run’ Venezuela temporarily, installing pro-US figures like Rubio, Hegseth and Gen. Caine, and to overhaul broken oil infrastructure with US firms. The operation, which knocked out power in parts of Caracas and killed at least 40 people, drew accusations of imperialism from Democrats and foreign leaders. Vice-president Delcy Rodríguez was named interim leader by Venezuela’s supreme court. Trump plans to recoup occupation costs from Venezuela’s vast oil revenues.

articles.title: Albanese calls for ‘peaceful, democratic transition’ of power in Venezuela after US capture of Nicolás Maduro
articles.trailText: Australian prime minister says government has ‘long held concerns about the situation’ in South American country
articles.summary: Australian PM Anthony Albanese endorsed a peaceful, democratic transition in Venezuela after the US military’s capture and extradition of President Nicolás Maduro. He stressed respect for international law, dialogue and regional stability, and reaffirmed Australia’s long-standing concerns over human rights, democratic freedoms and security. Travel advisory warns Australians to avoid Venezuela due to instability. Domestic reactions range from opposition praise of Maduro’s removal to Greens criticism of US overreach, with Labor internal dissent. Global leaders split: US and Brazil back the move, Russia, Cuba, Iran and Mexico condemn it, while the UN Security Council convenes.

articles.title: US oil giants silent on Trump claim they will spend billions on Venezuelan oil industry
articles.trailText: US president says oil majors primed to invest in rebuilding infrastructure following Maduro ouster
articles.summary: After claiming US oil giants would spend “billions” rebuilding Venezuela’s vast but dilapidated oil sector post-Maduro, President Trump has drawn silence from Chevron—focused on legal compliance—and muted responses from ExxonMobil and ConocoPhillips. Despite a US embargo and outstanding ICSID awards for seized assets, Trump promises reimbursement and private investment to restore up to 2m bpd by the 2030s—an $110bn project. Analysts warn companies will demand political stability amid oversupply, non-linear transitions and legal uncertainties, though competition for Venezuelan reserves rises.

articles.title: The ‘Putinization’ of US foreign policy has arrived in Venezuela
articles.trailText: Trump is no longer bending the rules – he is demolishing them, with consequences far beyond Caracas
articles.summary: Within days of 2026’s start, US forces struck Venezuela, abducted President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, and Trump vowed to “run” the country and sell its oil, shattering international law and norms. Preceded by offshore airstrikes on fishing craft and tanker seizures, the operation reveals Trump’s growing appetite for military intervention under dubious drug-trafficking charges. Drawing parallels to Panama ’89 and Iraq 2003, he dismisses a rules-based order, keeping an “American armada” poised while eyeing Venezuelan oil. Critics dub it the “Putinization” of US foreign policy, heralding armed spheres of influence from Latin America to Iran and Greenland.

articles.title: ‘It’s impossible not to feel relief’: UK Venezuelans on Maduro’s capture
articles.trailText: Hope, fear and unease ripple through Britain’s Venezuelan community after US forces seized Nicolás Maduro
articles.summary: UK’s 21,000-strong Venezuelan diaspora reacts with relief and unease after US troops captured Nicolás Maduro in a pre-dawn raid and flew him to New York on criminal charges. Charity founder Cinzia de Santis welcomes the collapse of a regime built on fear but laments foreign boots on Venezuelan soil and mistrusts US motives under Trump. Doctor Alejandro Arenas-Pinto fears post-coup instability and civilian harm despite desperation, while manager Domingo Lapadula praises the end of Maduro’s status quo amid low military resistance.

articles.title: ‘It sends a horrible signal’: US politicians react to capture of Nicolás Maduro
articles.trailText: Republicans cheer capture of Venezuelan leader, but Democrats say it ‘risks pulling our nation into another war’
articles.summary: Republicans, including AG Pam Bondi, Sec. of State Marco Rubio and VP JD Vance, applauded US forces’ capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on narco-terrorism, drug trafficking and weapons charges, celebrating enforcement of a 2020 indictment. Venezuelan expatriates in Miami cheered. Democrats—from senators Mark Warner, Jeanne Shaheen and Andy Kim to Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, Gov. Kathy Hochul and NYC Mayor Zohran Mamdani—condemned the unilateral operation as illegal regime-change without congressional approval, warning of international backlash, constitutional breaches and regional instability. Analysts note it’s the largest US military action in Latin America since 1989, with uncertain fallout depending on Venezuela’s armed forces’ response.

articles.title: Is there any legal justification for the US attack on Venezuela?
articles.trailText: International law experts expect Washington to claim self-defence and face little serious pushback
articles.summary: After Trump’s large-scale strike on Venezuela capturing President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, experts say the operation breaches UN Charter article 2(4) and constitutes a crime of aggression. Without UN Security Council authorization or a credible self-defence claim, the US violates international law. With Washington’s veto power, sanctions are unlikely, weakening the UN’s authority. Observers warn the precedent may embolden states like China to invade Taiwan. UK and NATO allies, including Prime Minister Starmer, face pressure to uphold Nuremberg principles and condemn the attack. Maduro and Flores face New York indictments on terrorism and drug trafficking, underpinning the US’s self-defence claim.

articles.title: Britain not involved in US Venezuela attack, says Keir Starmer
articles.trailText: UK prime minister describes situation as fast-moving and is waiting for more details to emerge
articles.summary: UK PM Sir Keir Starmer said Britain had no role in the US operation, during which President Nicolás Maduro and his wife were captured and Caracas hit by airstrikes, stressing it’s a fast-moving situation and London is working with its Caracas embassy to support some 500 Britons while awaiting full details from a forthcoming Trump press conference. Starmer has yet to speak to the US president. Opposition figures – Lib Dem Ed Davey, Green Zack Polanski and Reform leader Nigel Farage – urged condemnation over alleged international law breaches, and Conservative shadow foreign secretary Priti Patel welcomed Maduro’s removal but called for clarity on the facts.

articles.title: Swiss prosecutors place bar managers under investigation after deadly fire
articles.trailText: Suspected offences include homicide by negligence, causing bodily harm by negligence and arson by negligence
articles.summary: Swiss prosecutors in Valais have opened a criminal probe into Jacques and Jessica Moretti, owners of Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, after a sparkler fountain on champagne bottles ignited foam-lined ceiling panels during a New Year’s party, killing 40 revellers and injuring over 100. The couple faces charges of homicide, bodily harm and arson by negligence. Investigations will examine whether the soundproofing material, fire extinguishers, escape routes and use of sparklers complied with regulations. Authorities emphasized the presumption of innocence and continue identifying victims and relatives, while regional officials warn further prosecutions may follow if liability is confirmed.

articles.title: Airstrikes, helicopters and a snatch squad with a blowtorch: how the US raid on Caracas unfolded
articles.trailText: Some suspected the attacks on Venezuela were coming, but the shock was still real and no one knows what will happen next
articles.summary: Pre-dawn on Jan. 3 US forces launched Operation Absolute Resolve with airstrikes and helicopter insertions against Caracas targets including La Carlota and Fuerte Tiuna. Delta Force commandos used blowtorches to breach President Maduro’s residence, allegedly capturing Nicolás Maduro and wife Cilia Flores and flying them to a US warship. Trump hailed the “tyrant’s” removal while Venezuela’s government, backed by military and colectivos, denounced the “imperialist attack.” Analysts warn the regime’s structure endures and civil unrest looms.

articles.title: Nicolás Maduro: from bus driver to Chávez successor to US detainee
articles.trailText: As Maduro faces trial in New York on alleged involvement in narco-terrorism, how will Venezuelans judge their president?
articles.summary: Nicolás Maduro, 63, rose from Caracas bus driver and union leader to succeed Hugo Chávez in 2013. Over 13 years he oversaw economic collapse—hyperinflation, oil output plummeting—and mass exodus of millions. He crushed opposition protests in 2014, 2017 and 2024, neutralized the legislature via a pro-government assembly and rigged elections, prompting ICC probes for crimes against humanity. US sanctions failed to unseat his military-backed regime until a 2026 special forces operation seized him on narco-terrorism charges. Now detained in New York, Maduro faces indictment and possible long imprisonment, as Venezuelans reassess his legacy alongside wife and power broker Cilia Flores.

articles.title: US has captured Venezuela’s President Maduro and wife, says Trump
articles.trailText: US president lauds ‘brilliant operation’ on social media as attorney general says couple will face criminal charges
articles.summary: In a pre-dawn assault in western Caracas and surrounding regions, US forces led by Delta Force reportedly captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, Cilia Flores, whom Attorney General Pam Bondi said will face US criminal charges based on a 2020 indictment. Donald Trump hailed the operation as “brilliant”; legal authority and congressional notification remain unclear. The attack, which included strikes on La Carlota, Fuerte Tiuna and other sites, drew global condemnation—especially from Colombia, the UN, human rights experts and allied states—while civilian casualties remain unconfirmed as Maduro’s vice-president demands proof of life and calls for mass mobilization.

articles.title: Global outcry after US launches strikes on Venezuela and captures president
articles.trailText: France, Russia, China and EU say Washington broke international law after US troops carried out the operation
articles.summary: After US forces launched airstrikes on Caracas and abducted President Nicolás Maduro and his wife, global leaders from France, Spain, Brazil, Russia, China and the EU condemned Washington for breaching international law and urged a UN Security Council session. Trump said Maduro and Cilia Flores will face drug-trade charges in New York. South American reactions split: Lula, Petro and Boric decried “imperialism,” while Milei and Ecuador’s Noboa cheered. China and Russia demand their release; the UN warns of a dangerous precedent. Colombia has mobilized troops on its border, fearing a mass refugee influx.

articles.title: New year, new deal? Why peace still feels elusive for Ukraine
articles.trailText: The US may be making positive noises, but exhausted Ukrainians remain wary after nearly four years of war
articles.summary: Ukraine enters 2026 with peace talks “90% ready” yet stalled by 10% of core issues: Russia’s insistence on addressing “root causes”, US diplomatic pressure, and leaked demands for Donbas concessions. Nearly four years of war, winter power cuts and air raids have sapped public morale. Zelenskyy shuffles his team, promoting intelligence chief Kyrylo Budanov to chief of staff, hinting at a tougher security-negotiation line. Martial law delays elections, fueling debate over Zelenskyy’s mandate even as fatigue drives many to accept a “bad deal”. Success depends on steady Western aid, a frozen front and Russian internal crises.

articles.title: ‘No future for us’: disaffected Iranians say it’s now or never to topple regime
articles.trailText: Ailing economy sparks biggest uprising in years, with protesters saying it’s time to hit regime when it’s at its weakest
articles.summary: In early January 2026, Iran’s worst protests in years erupted after the rial plunged over 50%, sparking merchant strikes and mass demonstrations in at least 32 cities. Students and young professionals, invoking “woman, life, freedom” and “death to the dictator,” demand economic relief and the end of Ali Khamenei’s rule. Security forces have killed at least ten protesters and arrested over 100, prompting online classes and tighter campus control. Reformist president Masoud Pezeshkian called for dialogue while Donald Trump renewed threats on Iran’s missile program. Despite fear of reprisals, activists vow sustained resistance.

articles.title: Tents supplied to displaced Palestinians ‘inadequate for Gaza winter’
articles.trailText: Thousands have blown down in storms and tents from China, Egypt and Saudi Arabia found to be not waterproof
articles.summary: Assessment by the Palestine Shelter Cluster finds thousands of tents donated by China, Egypt and Saudi Arabia to Gaza’s displaced inadequate for winter storms: poor sewing, non-waterproof fabric, weak frames and no flooring led to thousands damaged or blown down, affecting 235,000 people. Only Qatar, UAE and UN-supplied tents met UN specifications. Stark disparities in aid—just 20,000 of 90,000 tents from UN/NGOs—reflect Israeli restrictions favoring direct bilateral deliveries and commercial contractors. Winterisation efforts are stymied by limits on tarpaulins, construction materials and equipment, leaving families in leaky tents or ruins months into the ceasefire amid scarce basic services.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia makes biggest battleground gains since first year of war, analysis shows
articles.trailText: Russian army captured more Ukrainian territory in 2025 than previous two years combined; Zelenskyy names new top aide. What we know on day 1,410
articles.summary: AFP analysis of ISW data shows Russia captured over 5,600 sq km in 2025—nearly 1% of Ukraine—its biggest gain since 2022 and exceeding the previous two years combined. President Zelenskyy will host security advisers from 15 countries—including the EU, NATO and a US delegation via videolink—as he appoints Kyrylo Budanov his new top aide, replacing Andriy Yermak, and plans to swap defence minister Denys Shymhal for digital minister Mykhailo Fedorov. A Russian strike on Kharkiv killed two, including a toddler, and injured 25, while over 3,000 children and parents were evacuated from 44 frontline settlements in Zaporizhzhia and Dnipropetrovsk.

articles.title: ‘Magical place’: tourists see another side of Papua New Guinea’s most troubled region
articles.trailText: Tourism operators in PNG’s highlands offer access to lush scenery, adventure and culture – in contrast with the region’s dangerous image
articles.summary: In PNG’s Highlands, tourism operators like Ambua Lodge in Hela province are reframing the region’s reputation by offering guided tours of lush valleys, Huli Wigmen, birdwatching and cultural immersion despite historical tribal conflict. Prime Minister James Marape lauded its four decades of “safe investment,” and Trans Niugini Tours runs both Ambua and Rondon Ridge lodges in partnership with local tribes. Visitor numbers rose 9.3% in early 2025, led by Australians and Asians. On Mount Wilhelm, Betty’s Place provides rustic accommodation and authentic Melanesian experiences, though owners still rely on generators and call for infrastructure support.

articles.title: Crans-Montana fire: families face agonising wait for victims’ identification
articles.trailText: Collective grief hangs over Swiss resort as relatives desperately seek information about missing loved ones
articles.summary: On New Year’s Eve at Crans-Montana’s Le Constellation bar, a sparkler atop a champagne bottle ignited acoustic foam, triggering a blaze that killed about 40 and critically injured 80. A Milan group of 15 friends saw eight escape, three hospitalized and four still missing—including 16-year-olds Achille Barosi and Chiara Costanzo. Identification of the deceased and injured (119 total) is delayed by severe burns and DNA checks; publicly confirmed victims include Italian golfer Emanuele Galeppini and British-educated teenager Charlotte Niddam. Swiss prosecutors are probing foam compliance, videos and interviews as families endure collective grief and pray for news of the unaccounted.

articles.title: Teenage girl educated in Britain among the missing after Crans-Montana fire
articles.trailText: Charlotte Niddam, 15, had attended a school in Hertfordshire and her family have not heard from her since the blaze
articles.summary: Fifteen-year-old Charlotte Niddam, a former Immanuel College pupil from Bushey, Hertfordshire, is among the missing after a New Year’s Day fire ripped through Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana. Swiss officials say 40 people died and over 100 were injured when fountain sparklers on champagne bottles ignited the ceiling at around 1:30 am. Niddam’s family, now back in France, have received no word since the blaze. Immanuel College and victims’ families are appealing for information and support.

articles.title: Sparklers held near ceiling started Swiss ski resort fire, investigators believe
articles.trailText: Footage and witness statements show blaze that killed about 40 was ‘very rapid’, prosecutor says
articles.summary: Investigators believe fountain sparklers ('Bengal lights') mounted on champagne bottles ignited foam soundproofing panels on the ceiling of Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana at 1.30 am on New Year’s Eve, triggering a rapid fire that killed about 40 and injured over 100, many critically burned. Authorities are probing safety compliance, materials, exits, fire extinguishers and occupancy, while identifying victims via DNA and dental records. Victims include Swiss, French, Italians and others; EU and neighboring countries have offered medical aid. A communal memorial is set for January 9.

articles.title: What happened in the Crans-Montana bar fire in Switzerland – visual guide
articles.trailText: While the cause of the disaster is still under investigation, videos and photos suggest the blaze spread quickly
articles.summary: In Crans-Montana on New Year’s Eve 2025-26, a sparkler-ignited blaze erupted at Le Constellation bar at 1:30 am, killing over 40 people and seriously burning dozens more, many teenagers. Videos show flares touching insulated ceilings, igniting combustible gases and causing rapid fire spread. With around 300 inside and narrow exits, patrons panicked up a single staircase; some broke windows to escape. Forensics cite ceiling insulation and close-range sparklers as likely causes. Regional ICUs were overwhelmed; about 50 critical burn victims were flown to specialized European units. Switzerland mourned with flags at half-mast; injured included citizens from France and Italy.

articles.title: Crans-Montana fire survivors treated in burns units across Europe
articles.trailText: Some of the injured taken to Belgium, France and Germany while Swiss officials try to identify the dead
articles.summary: After a New Year’s Eve blaze at Le Constellation bar in the upmarket Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana killed about 40 and injured 119, survivors are being treated in specialist burns units in Zurich, Lausanne and Geneva, as well as in Belgium, France, Germany, Poland, Sweden and North Macedonia. Investigators believe sparklers on champagne bottles ignited the fire; many victims are so badly burned that ID via dental records and DNA could take weeks. Swiss and foreign embassies coordinate repatriation, with authorities confirming 113 injured—mostly Swiss, French and Italians—while six remain unidentified. Families use Instagram to trace missing loved ones amid ongoing forensic work.

articles.title: Maduro urges Trump to abandon ‘illegal warmongering’ and start ‘serious talks’
articles.trailText: Venezuelan president warns of a ‘forever war’ similar to Iraq after US counterpart claims first land strike on dock
articles.summary: Venezuelan president Nicolás Maduro, responding to Donald Trump’s five-month US military pressure campaign—including a purported CIA dock strike in December and 35 maritime drug raids killing 115—accused Washington of “illegal warmongering” and resource-grabbing of Venezuela’s oil, gold and rare earths. In a New Year’s Eve “pod car” TV interview, he rejected narco-terrorism claims, declined to confirm the drone attack, and offered to start “serious talks” on drug-trafficking cooperation and US oil investment, warning against an Iraq-style “forever war.” He noted the US blockade, naval fleet deployment, airstrikes on suspected traffickers and the seizure of two oil tankers while pursuing a third.

articles.title: Real estate agents under the microscope in Australian-first privacy ‘compliance sweep’
articles.trailText: Businesses including pubs and car rental companies targeted to check if they use ‘power asymmetry’ to gather personal data and keep it too long
articles.summary: In its first national privacy “compliance sweep” in January, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner will audit 60 businesses across six high-risk sectors—rental inspections and real estate open homes, car dealers and rental companies, licensed venues, pawnshops and chemists—to curb “power asymmetry” in real-time data collection. Firms must explain why, how long and where they store personal details and face up to A$66,000 fines for non-compliance. Regulators flagged agents’ practice of hoarding bank statements, IDs and social media profiles; past breaches in major franchises spurred the crackdown.

articles.title: Iran officials warn Trump of red line after his threat to ‘rescue’ protesters
articles.trailText: Foreign minister says Iranian military is on standby after US president said he would act if demonstrators were killed
articles.summary: After President Donald Trump threatened to "rescue" Iranian protesters if they were killed and warned the US was "locked and loaded," Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi condemned the remarks as "reckless and dangerous," placing the military on standby. Adviser Ali Shamkhani and NSC secretary Ali Larijani warned any US interference would cross a "red line" and provoke retaliation. The protests, driven by a sharp rial collapse and economic grievances, have spread nationwide, resulting in at least seven deaths. Amidst unrest, President Masoud Pezeshkian opened dialogue with demonstrators even as hardliners vow a harsh response to foreign meddling.

articles.title: China threatened to cancel key trade talks after UK minister’s Taiwan visit in June
articles.trailText: Exclusive: diplomats had to scramble to contain fallout with Beijing after Douglas Alexander’s trip to Taipei
articles.summary: After Trade Minister Douglas Alexander’s June visit to Taiwan—where he met President Lai Ching-te—Beijing threatened to cancel the UK-China trade and economic commission (Jetco), its first dialogue since 2018, jeopardizing talks set for September. Diplomats swiftly contained the fallout, sending new Business Secretary Peter Kyle to Beijing. Ministers maintain the visit was within long-standing UK policy and vow ongoing engagement amid £9.3 bn bilateral trade and pursuit of £1 bn in market access deals, even as security concerns grow over plans for a Chinese super-embassy in London and Keir Starmer’s planned Beijing trip.

articles.title: Sewage in drinking water blamed for at least 10 deaths in India’s ‘cleanest city’
articles.trailText: Hundreds hospitalised in Indore after public toilet built above water pipeline appears to have let sewage into supply
articles.summary: Sewage-contaminated drinking water in Indore’s Bhagirathpura neighbourhood has killed at least ten people, including an infant, and hospitalized over 270 with vomiting, diarrhoea and fever after sewage seeped from a public toilet (built without a septic tank) into a main pipeline. Despite eight years as India’s “cleanest city,” residents’ warnings were ignored. Water tests confirmed sewer bacteria; local media report up to 15 deaths. State health teams have identified 2,456 suspected cases. Officials have been suspended and investigations launched. Critics demand stricter enforcement of water safety and environmental laws.

articles.title: ‘A place of darkness and light’: the uninhabited Japanese island that became a rabbit paradise
articles.trailText: Once host to a poisonous gas research facility, Okunoshima is now an Instagram-friendly tourist destination
articles.summary: Okunoshima, an uninhabited island in Japan’s Seto Inland Sea, hosted secret imperial gas‐weapon research from 1929 to 1945, using rabbits to test mustard gas. Abandoned after the war, it was reseeded with rabbits in the 1970s and now supports some 400–500 tame grey rabbits, entirely dependent on volunteers and 200,000 annual tourists for food amid scarce natural forage. DNA studies suggest multiple introductions over time. Visitors flock for Instagram shots, but the population faces predators, abuse and fading public memory of the island’s dark chemical-warfare legacy.

articles.title: Friday briefing: How the Home Office denied ​a British-born ​m​an his citizenship for 15 years
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Born in London but he spent years fearing detention and deportation. Olu Sowemimo’s story reveals the hidden consequences of Britain’s nationality system
articles.summary: Olu Sowemimo, born in London in 1991 to a Nigerian mother without settled status, spent 15 years fearing detention and deportation under Britain’s restrictive nationality laws after his passport application was rejected at 20. The UK ties citizenship to parents’ status and enforces a “good character” test that had initially barred him over a teenage offence. With PRCBC’s legal support, he secured citizenship at 32 in 2024. He warns Labour’s plan to extend residence requirements will leave more UK-born children stateless.

articles.title: Switzerland to hold five days of mourning after 40 killed in resort fire, as investigators rush to identify victims
articles.trailText: Blaze that swept through crowded New Year’s Eve bar in Crans-Montana also injured 115 people
articles.summary: Swiss authorities declared five days of national mourning after a New Year’s Eve blaze at Crans-Montana’s Le Constellation bar killed about 40 people and injured 115. The fire, which erupted around 1:30 am in the packed basement nightclub—allegedly sparked by sparklers or a candle igniting wooden beams—rapidly collapsed the ceiling, trapping patrons, many of them teenagers. President Guy Parmelin called it one of Switzerland’s worst traumas and vowed to improve safety standards. Prosecutors and investigators are racing to identify victims and determine causes, while dozens remain missing.

articles.title: ‘Truly humbling’: inside the centre where UK medics are helping Ukrainian amputees
articles.trailText: British military doctors and therapists provide support at base where innovative treatments aid recovery of those who have lost limbs
articles.summary: At a specialist Ukrainian centre near Lyman, UK military doctors, physiotherapists and occupational therapists from Project Renovator support dozens of amputees each month with advanced prosthetics, nerve-stimulation surgery and peer-group rehab. Former arbitration lawyer Vladislav, who lost a leg to a Russian drone strike, and fitness teacher Oleksandr, who lost both legs to artillery fire, undergo innovative treatments and psychological support alongside family visits and group physiotherapy. British consultants share expertise from Afghanistan and learn faster nerve-repair techniques from Ukrainian surgeons. Defence Secretary Healey applauds the UK’s low-profile but ongoing commitment to wounded soldiers’ long-term recovery.

articles.title: Strike a pose: vogue balls go mainstream in New Zealand
articles.trailText: Led by Māori and Pasifika queer communities, the counterculture has gone from performing in lounges and clubs to Wellington’s national museum
articles.summary: At Wellington’s national museum, Te Papa Tongarewa, a 600-strong crowd cheered as predominantly Māori and Pasifika queer performers from local vogue houses showcased dance, drag and high-fashion routines in a ballroom competition. Vogue balls—born in 1960s Harlem’s Black and Latinx subculture—evolved in Auckland over a decade into a platform for indigenous queer expression, community building and political resistance. Wellington’s Kiki House of Marama and Auckland’s Coven-Aucoin now lead mainstream collaborations with institutions, blending Pasifika and Māori aesthetics, activism—like ripping up a treaty bill—and queer excellence.

articles.title: Kim Jong-un’s daughter visits state mausoleum, fuelling speculation she will be next North Korean ruler
articles.trailText: Kim Ju-ae has been making increasingly prominent appearances in state media over the past three years
articles.summary: Kim Ju-ae, around 13, made her first public visit to the Kumsusan Palace of the Sun on Jan 1 alongside her parents, paying respects to Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il. Her prominent state-media appearances over three years and a recent Beijing trip have fueled analyst and intelligence speculation that she is being groomed as Kim Jong-un’s successor. Observers note this display of a "stable family" ahead of the party congress, but her youth and possible roles for Kim’s other children leave succession uncertain.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv’s GUR ‘faked Russian-ordered killing and bagged $500k Kremlin reward’
articles.trailText: ‘I congratulate you on returning to life’ says spy chief Budanov to Denis Kapustin, commander of a Russian unit fighting on the Ukrainian side. What we know on day 1,409
articles.summary: Ukraine’s GUR military intelligence staged the death of Denis Kapustin (aka Nikitin), leader of the Russian Volunteer Corps’ Timur Special Unit, to thwart a Kremlin‐ordered $500,000 assassination, lure the plotters and identify Russian special services operatives, then recovered the bounty for use in Ukraine’s fight, as announced by chief Kyrylo Budanov at a briefing. Simultaneously, Ukrainian drones struck energy and industrial sites in Krasnodar, Tatarstan and Kaluga regions; both sides accused each other of New Year civilian attacks; Kherson city saw one fatality and injuries, while rail targets in three regions were hit.

articles.title: ‘We are always living in fear’: inside Myanmar’s ‘sham’ election
articles.trailText: Myanmar’s military rulers are holding the first elections since the 2021 coup, and life in the country’s biggest city is fraught with anxiety
articles.summary: In Yangon’s bustling streets, residents live in constant fear as Myanmar’s military, in power since the Feb 2021 coup, stages its first election—a process dismissed by the UN and Western governments as a sham. Public dissent is stifled under arrests, forced conscription and rampant disappearances. Daily power cuts and the kyat’s 80% collapse deepen economic hardship; GDP has contracted 9% since 2020. Aung San Suu Kyi remains imprisoned and her NLD party banned. Bars offer drug-fueled escapes, but most keep heads down. With 52% turnout and conflict zones excluded, the vote offers no real return to democracy.

articles.title: New year drone strike kills 24 in Russian-occupied Ukraine, Moscow says
articles.trailText: Ukraine rejects claim, saying its forces exclusively targeted Russian military or energy sites
articles.summary: In Russian-occupied Khorly, Kherson region, Moscow-installed governor Vladimir Saldo said a Ukrainian drone strike on New Year’s Eve hit a café and hotel, killing 24 and wounding 50, one drone carrying an incendiary payload. Kyiv’s general staff denied civilian targeting, stating strikes are confined to Russian military, fuel and energy sites. Top Russian officials condemned the attack, linking it to demands to prevail in the four-year invasion. These claims follow Moscow’s contested allegation of a Kyiv drone attack on a Putin residence, which US agencies and Ukraine call fabrications amid intensifying peace talks.

articles.title: ‘It happened in seconds’: sudden inferno brings horror to Swiss ski resort
articles.trailText: New year party at Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana turned into tragedy as flames shot across the ceiling
articles.summary: On 1 January at 1:30 am, a sparkler on a champagne magnum in the wooden-ceilinged Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana ignited a flashover fire that engulfed the packed basement within seconds. Young revelers, some under 18, were trapped in the inferno as panicked crowds smashed windows and fled up narrow staircases. Firefighters, police and hundreds of bystanders rescued patrons; about 40 died and 115 were injured, many seriously. Swiss authorities say arson is unlikely and investigations continue. President Parmelin declared five days of mourning as devastated families await news and forensics teams search the wreckage.

articles.title: Abortion may no longer be a top priority for Democratic voters ahead of 2026 midterms, polls show
articles.trailText: Abortion was seen as one of Democrats’ strongest issues in the 2024 election – new polls indicate that may be shifting
articles.summary: Recent polls from PRRI show only 36% of Democrats now rate abortion as a key voting issue for the 2026 midterms, down from 55% in 2024, while Republican concern remains steady. Affordability, the economy and democracy top Democratic priorities instead. Abortion ballot measures will appear in up to seven states (Idaho, Montana, Nebraska, Oregon, Virginia, plus confirmed Nevada and Missouri), with mixed pro- and anti-abortion proposals. Fundraising for rights groups like DC Abortion Fund is declining, raising concerns about support for travel and clinic-based procedures.

articles.title: Le Constellation bar fire in Switzerland: what we know so far
articles.trailText: Investigators say no indication of terrorism or arson after 40 people die and 115 are injured in blaze Switzerland ski resort fire – latest updates
articles.summary: On January 1, a flash fire ripped through Le Constellation bar during a New Year’s Eve party in Crans-Montana, killing around 40 people and injuring 115, many seriously. Victims—mostly teens and twenty-somethings from several countries—are still being identified as authorities confirm no sign of terrorism or deliberate arson. Eyewitnesses report sparklers in champagne bottles ignited the wooden ceiling, triggering a rapid flashover. Valais canton hospitals declared emergencies and overflowed, with some patients set for transfer abroad. Investigators are probing fire-safety compliance and cause while families await news.

articles.title: About 40 killed and 115 injured in fire at bar in Swiss ski resort of Crans-Montana
articles.trailText: Police say blaze tore through crowded bar where people were seeing in the new year
articles.summary: Swiss police say about 40 people were killed and 115 injured when a fire tore through Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana during a packed New Year’s Eve party. The blaze, deemed accidental after a lit candle or shisha embers ignited a wooden ceiling, broke out at 1.30 am, trapping revelers on two floors with narrow exits. Severe burns made identification difficult; forensics teams are working to return remains to families. Victims, many tourists aged 16–26, were flown to hospitals across Switzerland. Authorities have opened a full investigation but ruled out foul play and set up a helpline and reception centre for relatives.

articles.title: More women reporting abuse in Norway as member of royal family to go on trial for rape
articles.trailText: Country’s largest women’s health organisation says case of Marius Borg Høiby encouraging people to seek help
articles.summary: Norway’s largest women’s health NGO, Sanitetskvinnene, reports a notable rise in women seeking support for domestic violence and sexual assault linked to media coverage of Marius Borg Høiby’s high-profile rape trial in February. The 28-year-old son of Crown Princess Mette-Marit faces 32 counts—including four rapes, domestic abuse and illegal filming—and denies all charges. If convicted, he could serve up to 10 years. New allegations of street-level drug dealing have further fueled republican sentiment, while NKVTS statistics show one in ten Norwegian women experience serious partner violence.

articles.title: Israel allowing traders to bring into Gaza ‘dual-use’ items barred from aid organisations
articles.trailText: Sources say generators and tent poles restricted from humanitarian organisations but commercial shipments allowed in
articles.summary: Israel maintains parallel controls on Gaza imports: humanitarian agencies remain barred from 'dual-use' essentials like generators and tent poles under security pretexts, yet commercial traders have imported and sold them legally at Israeli checkpoints. This two-tier system enriches private interests, undermines aid operations, and fuels an informal economy, per military, diplomatic and NGO sources including Gisha. The Civil-Military Coordination Center and US commanders have challenged the policy; COGAT insists on uniform restrictions. Meanwhile Gaza’s civilian population faces shelter shortages, winter cold, and escalating hunger amid broader blockade dynamics.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Thirty years of the Women’s prize for fiction – have male novelists been edged out?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As the literary award marks its 30th anniversary, the debate about whether it is relevant when women dominate bestsellers list has resurfaced
articles.summary: On its 30th anniversary, the Women’s Prize for Fiction highlights a shift from the male-dominated early 1990s to a female-led bestseller era. Despite Booker shortlist gender balance improving and women like Atwood, Rooney and Ferrante dominating, critics question whether male novelists are marginalised. Catherine Taylor recalls the prize’s role in redressing bias and challenges labels of women’s fiction as “interior.” Industry data show women buy 63% of fiction but men still favour male authors, underlining that gender gaps in recognition and readership endure.

articles.title: ‘It’s a matter of time before a farmer is seriously injured’: on the trail of hare coursers in Wiltshire
articles.trailText: Police show the Guardian around hotspots for a rural crime that has links to international gangs – and is on the rise
articles.summary: Wiltshire’s fields have become hotspots for hare coursing, a violent rural crime where gangs set greyhounds or lurchers on hares for high-stakes betting, often livestreamed globally. Police report a 20% rise in offences and a 500% increase in arrests since January 2025, yet many culprits evade capture. Farmers face property damage, farmworker injuries and threats, building barriers and investing in CCTV. Authorities link coursers to international organised crime, equipment theft and dog abandonment. New Hunting Act powers, RSPCA and NFU collaboration, plus armed patrols and drones, aim to stem this growing crisis.

articles.title: Australian man reportedly killed fighting with Ukrainian forces against Russia
articles.trailText: Australia’s foreign affairs department seeking to verify reported death of Russell Allan Wilson on 12 December
articles.summary: Australia’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is seeking confirmation that Russell Allan Wilson, reportedly killed on 12 December in the Donetsk region while fighting with Ukrainian forces, has died. Sources including an ABC report and social media tributes by a US army veteran describe Wilson—formerly from Gosford and Brisbane—serving in Ukraine since 2023 and due to wed days after his death. DFAT warns against travel to Ukraine and is assisting his family. At least eight Australians have died in the conflict since 2022; the only known prisoner is ex‐teacher Oscar Jenkins. Advocacy groups urge Canberra to press for Jenkins’ inclusion in prisoner exchanges to prevent him being “forgotten.”

articles.title: Grief, fear and fury: the Israeli and Palestinian mothers still standing united against bloodshed
articles.trailText: Israeli movement Women Wage Peace and Palestinian group Women of the Sun held a mass rally in October 2023. Three days later a Hamas attack triggered war – leaving the women more determined than ever
articles.summary: Israeli Yael Admi and Palestinian Reem al-Hajajreh, mothers of six and four, co-founded a grassroots peace partnership after gathering 1,500 women at a Dead Sea rally in October 2023. Three days later Hamas’s attack killed 1,200 Israelis, triggering a devastating war that claimed over 70,000 lives in Gaza, shattering their fragile hope. Despite fierce backlash, travel hurdles and the loss of activists, they persisted in The Hague on Human Rights Day, urging women’s inclusion in negotiations. Last December they launched 'Mothers’ Call' and plan a barefoot Rome-Jerusalem march in March 2026, demanding leaders heed women’s voices for a peaceful future.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: 10% away from peace, Zelenskyy tells Ukrainians
articles.trailText: US intelligence officials persuade Donald Trump that Ukrainians did not target Putin with drones – reports. What we know on day 1,408
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy declared peace terms 90% complete but insisted on robust security guarantees and rejected a “weak” deal, as Macron vowed firm commitments at a Jan 6 Paris summit. Kyiv’s drones struck Russia’s Rybinsk oil depot; Russia’s drones hit Odesa, wounding six. US and European intelligence convinced Trump Ukrainians didn’t target Putin, countering Moscow’s video claims of a downed Chaklun-V drone. North Korea’s Kim Jong-un praised overseas troops in Ukraine, and the US delayed sanctions on Serbia’s Russian-owned NIS until Jan 23.

articles.title: ‘We want the mullahs gone’: economic crisis sparks biggest protests in Iran since 2022
articles.trailText: Demonstrations against deteriorating living conditions have widened to include criticism of how Iran is governed
articles.summary: In late Dec. 2025, Iran's worst currency crash (rial at 1.42m/USD, 56% six-month drop) and 72% food inflation triggered four-day protests from Tehran to Isfahan. Merchants closed shops, students occupied campuses, chanting “death to the dictator” and “woman, life, freedom”. Demonstrators demand the mullahs’ ouster and democracy, rejecting President Pezeshkian’s dialogue offer as a ploy. Security forces used teargas, metal pellets, arrests. IRGC warns of “cognitive warfare” by enemies. Amid US threats of renewed strikes, trade unions consider joining strikes.

articles.title: Who should pay for slavery reparations? And to whom? | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Graham Hadibi-Williams says current debate on reparations is one of theory rather than justice. Plus Abhishek Kalyankar on India’s colonial experience
articles.summary: In two letters readers critique the reparations debate’s focus on moral theory over practical justice and urge a broader historical scope. Graham Hadibi-Williams, whose English kin labored in mills built on slave-picked cotton alongside North African colonial descendants, warns that funding via general taxation unfairly burdens today’s working class and insists reparations must target actual beneficiaries—landed elites and offshore assets. Abhishek Kalyankar adds India’s colonial subjugation—systematic wealth extraction, Bengal famines, looted cultural treasures—and current visa hurdles to the reparations agenda.

articles.title: Finnish police seize vessel suspected of damaging underwater cable
articles.trailText: Border guards say they found ship with anchor lowered into sea after detection of fault in Helsinki-Tallinn telecoms link
articles.summary: Finnish coastguard boarded and seized the cargo vessel Fitburg, en route from St Petersburg to Haifa, after faults were detected in two undersea telecom cables between Helsinki and Tallinn. Fourteen multinational crew members were detained, and a helicopter crew observed its anchor dragging on the seabed. Authorities opened a preliminary probe for aggravated damage and interference with telecommunications in Finland’s exclusive economic zone. The case, linked by some to a Russian “shadow fleet” and hybrid-war tactics, coincided with a large‐scale Russian drone attack on Odesa.

articles.title: France targets Australia-style social media ban for children next year
articles.trailText: Draft bill to be submitted for legal checks as France aims to follow Australia’s world-first ban on platforms including Facebook, Snapchat and YouTube
articles.summary: France will ban social media platforms (Facebook, Snapchat, TikTok, YouTube) for under-15s from September 2026 under a draft bill sent to the Conseil d’État. Proposed by President Macron to mirror Australia’s world-first under-16 ban, it also bans mobile phones in high schools. Citing risks to mental health, sleep, bullying and academic performance, the short bill—aligned with the EU’s Digital Services Act—awaits parliamentary debate early 2026. Similar measures are under consideration in Denmark, Norway, Malaysia and the UK, while a French inquiry decried TikTok as a “slow poison.”

articles.title: Israeli ban on aid agencies in Gaza will have ‘catastrophic’ consequences, experts say
articles.trailText: Thirty-seven NGOs told they have to cease operations, putting Palestinian lives ‘at imminent risk’
articles.summary: Israel’s new ministry directive forces 37 NGOs in Gaza to halt operations within 60 days or submit extensive staff data, a move it says prevents extremist infiltration and aid diversion. Diplomats, UN and aid officials warn of a catastrophic collapse in health, nutrition, shelter and hygiene services—mostly delivered via UN contracts—putting Palestinian lives at ‘imminent risk’ and breaching October’s ceasefire aid guarantees. EU, UN rights chief, MSF and NRC reject Israel’s unfounded claims, cite robust vetting, and warn that amid recent storms, destroyed shelter, scarce water and soaring food costs, no workaround can avert disaster.

articles.title: ‘We live with war over our heads’: the Romanian villagers threatened by Russian drones
articles.trailText: Intensifying attacks on Ukraine’s Danube ports bring blasts, evacuations and fear of escalation to border communities
articles.summary: At Romania’s Danube delta edge in the Ceatalchioi commune, villagers endure nightly Russian drone attacks on nearby Ukrainian ports. Explosions rattle homes, drone debris lands on Romanian soil, prompting repeated evacuations via a single rutted dirt road. With no casualties so far, 500 residents live in constant fear, subsisting on livestock while schools and children suffer panic attacks. Locals decry neglected infrastructure—unpaved roads, lack of clean water—and resent that more aid goes to Ukrainian refugees. Though Romania amended laws to down unauthorised drones, authorities avoid firing to prevent escalation.

articles.title: Xi Jinping vows to reunify China and Taiwan in New Year’s Eve speech
articles.trailText: Reunification ‘is unstoppable’, says Chinese president, a day after the conclusion of intense military drills
articles.summary: In his New Year’s Eve address, Xi Jinping declared Taiwan’s reunification with China “unstoppable,” a day after PLA’s “Justice Mission 2025” drills encircled Taiwan with record 200 warplanes, naval ships and 27 missiles. US intelligence flags growing PLA strike capabilities amid Washington’s $11 bn arms sale. Xi highlighted China’s multilateral role, WWII legacy events, “One China” doctrine and tech advances. Taiwan’s president Lai Ching-te warned of Chinese expansionism, urged parliamentary support for higher defense spending. The exercises drew criticism from the US, UK, EU, Japan, Australia and the Philippines.

articles.title: Trump’s approach to Africa: more trade deals, less democracy and human rights
articles.trailText: From Christmas strikes in Nigeria to peace deals and talks of trade, the US president’s diplomatic approach to the continent has been all over the place
articles.summary: Trump’s second term Africa policy de-emphasizes democracy and human rights in favor of “trade not aid” and conflict resolution. He brokered a Rwanda–DRC peace deal promising business opportunities, yet ordered Christmas Day strikes on IS in Nigeria. He dismantled USAID, let AGOA lapse, imposed visa bans, insulted African leaders and feuded with South Africa over “white genocide” claims. Africa ranks last in his priorities, with diplomacy driven by transactional commercial and security interests, engaging only when U.S. strategic or extractive benefits are at stake.

articles.title: ‘It’s not a hen party hellscape’: Dublin’s Temple Bar strives to shake off its bad reputation
articles.trailText: Despite reviews of the district as a raucous tourist trap, improved policing has restored safety and an eclectic vibe
articles.summary: Temple Bar, redeveloped in the 1990s as Dublin’s cultural quarter, gained a raucous reputation amid pub crawls, stag and hen parties and headline-making assaults. Critics dubbed it a ‘pub theme park’, but local stakeholders report a renaissance: late-night licences have fallen from 25 to 7, policing has improved, and annual footfall tops 24m. Galleries, outdoor markets, fine dining and family-friendly events now share cobbled lanes with historic pubs. Visitors praise its eclectic vibe and safety. Business leaders plan street art, seating and cinema screenings to cement Temple Bar’s front-room-of-Dublin status.

articles.title: Cyprus pledges ‘different mindset’ as it assumes EU presidency
articles.trailText: Country’s six-month stint at helm begins with defence, migration and Ukraine still at top of agenda
articles.summary: Small-state Cyprus begins its six-month EU presidency with a promise of a "different mindset," focusing on defence, migration and support for Ukraine amid conflict. Foreign Minister Constantinos Kombos emphasizes Cyprus’s occupation history to bolster EU strategic autonomy, while integrating Middle East outreach—from Syria and Gaza to Lebanon and the Red Sea—into the agenda. Nicosia aims to sidestep national disputes over Turkish troops in its north while maintaining defence cooperation with Ankara. The motto "an autonomous union, open to the world" underpins initiatives on security readiness, trade diversification—including a proposed EU-India free trade zone—and regional engagement.

articles.title: France fears ‘era of Trumpism’ as public broadcaster comes under fire from right
articles.trailText: Investigation established by UDR party to look at ‘neutrality, workings and financing’ of state TV and radio
articles.summary: Rightwing UDR party, allied with Le Pen’s RN, launched a parliamentary inquiry running until March into the neutrality, workings and financing of France’s public TV and radio ahead of the 2027 election. Citing alleged anti-far-right bias, MPs spotlighted secret footage of broadcasters Patrick Cohen and Thomas Legrand meeting Socialist officials, amplified on Bolloré’s CNews. The journalists filed privacy suits, warning France has entered an era of “Trumpism.” Hearings have been heated—RN MPs decry “enemy” treatment—while Macron, post-licence-fee abolition, distances himself from CNews amid warnings that Bolloré’s empire seeks to weaken public broadcasting as a democratic counterpower.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: What St Albans ​tells ​us ​about Britain’s ​changing ​pub ​culture
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With young people drinking less, and landlords wrestling with unpredictable trade, one city’s pub history offers clues to the future of Britain’s boozers
articles.summary: Facing over 400 pub closures in England and Wales in 2024, Britain’s boozers are grappling with cost-of-living pressures, soaring beer duties and a generation of lighter drinkers. St Albans, once home to 92 pubs within a kilometre (thanks to the 1830 Beerhouse Act), bucks the trend: locals and tourists alike defend surviving inns via a “Save St Albans Pubs” campaign, WhatsApp support network and reinvented offerings, from non-alcoholic beers to social events. Curator David Thorold’s new museum exhibition and landlords’ community ethos suggest pubs must evolve as communal hubs to endure in 2026.

articles.title: Ten English fire services tackled record number of grass, forest and crop fires in 2025
articles.trailText: Fire chief says summer, UK’s hottest on record, was ‘one of the most challenging for wildfires we’ve ever faced’
articles.summary: Ten English fire services tackled nearly 27,000 wildfires during the UK’s hottest spring and summer on record in 2025. From March–May, 12,454 grassland, woodland and crop fires were logged—over four times the 2024 spring total—with Dorset & Wiltshire reporting 298 incidents, West Yorkshire 1,094 and Tyne & Wear 1,240. June–August saw 14,448 blazes. Services warned the frequency and intensity strained equipment, finances and crews. A major deliberate heath fire near Bournemouth burned 72 ha and took a week to extinguish. Fire chiefs urged prevention to reduce avoidable deaths and landscape damage.

articles.title: Burkina Faso and Mali ban US nationals in retaliation to Trump’s visa decision
articles.trailText: Announcements mark latest twist in the frosty relationship between west African military governments and the US
articles.summary: On Dec 31, 2025, Mali and Burkina Faso announced immediate travel bans on US citizens in retaliation for President Trump’s Dec 16 order adding their junta-led states to a US visa restriction list of 20 countries, citing armed-group threats and insufficient entrant data. Mali’s foreign ministry invoked reciprocity, applying identical visa conditions to Americans; Burkina Faso’s FM Karamoko Jean-Marie Traoré echoed this stance. Washington justified the expansion by invoking a Nov 26 shooting of two National Guard members in DC. The measures mark a new low in ties between West African military regimes battling insurgencies and Washington’s security-driven immigration crackdown.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: ‘Attack on global food security’ as Russia hits wheat ships and ports
articles.trailText: US has verified as fake the claimed attack on Putin residence, says Zelenskyy; leaders of Ukraine’s allies to meet in France next week. What we know on day 1,407
articles.summary: Russia launched drone strikes on Black Sea ports Pivdennyi and Chornomorsk, hitting Panama-flagged vessels Emmakris III and Captain Karam and oil tanks, threatening global food security. Kyiv condemned them as war crimes; ports remain operational. A French source said Moscow’s strikes defy US peace efforts. Zelenskyy dismissed claims of a Ukrainian drone hit on Putin’s Valdai residence as fake. Ukraine also hit Russia’s Tuapse port and pipeline, plus sites in Moscow and Crimea. Zelenskyy will host allied leaders in France on 6 Jan. Germany and the US lifted sanctions on oligarch Alisher Usmanov and ex-Sberbank CFO Alexandra Buriko after settlements.

articles.title: ‘Tonga is not a threat’: anger as small Pacific nation falls under Trump visa restrictions
articles.trailText: Community leaders raise alarm over study links and Polynesian ties, with Tonga to face restrictions from January as US says too many overstay
articles.summary: From 1 January the Trump administration will impose “partial” visa and entry restrictions on 15 countries, including Tonga, citing high overstay rates—over 14 percent for some categories. Despite its modest 100,000 population, Tonga joins African and Caribbean nations, with visas now limited to exceptional cases such as US government work. Community leaders, Tongan scholars and Hawaiian senator Jarrett Keohokalole denounce the move as discriminatory, arguing Tongans pose no security threat, have supported US missions abroad, and risk family separations and declining student exchanges. Critics warn the ban strains longstanding Polynesian and US–Tonga ties.

articles.title: Israel to ban dozens of aid agencies from Gaza as 10 nations warn about suffering
articles.trailText: Failure of groups including MSF and ActionAid to hand over staff details means they will not be able to operate in Gaza, say Israeli officials
articles.summary: Israel’s Ministry of Diaspora Affairs gave 36 hours’ notice to dozens of aid groups, including ActionAid, the IRC and MSF, accusing them of failing to submit staff lists and revoking licences from Jan. 1. The move coincides with 10 nations warning of Gaza’s 'catastrophic' winter humanitarian crisis—1.3 million needing urgent shelter, half of health facilities only partly functional, 740,000 at risk of toxic flooding—and calling for lifted import curbs and open crossings to reach the 4,200-trucks-per-week ceasefire aid target. Israel says noncompliant NGOs provided just 1% of post-ceasefire aid, while agencies warn data demands breach EU privacy laws and endanger staff.

articles.title: Trump’s shadow war in Venezuela grows, but country’s strongman leader still clings to power
articles.trailText: Report of a drone attack on a port facility signals new phase in US military campaign against Nicolás Maduro
articles.summary: CNN and NYT reported the CIA used a drone to target a port facility linked to the Tren de Aragua gang, though date, location and casualties remain unknown. If confirmed, this would mark a new phase in Trump’s four-month shadow war on Venezuela, which has deployed a massive naval fleet, conducted airstrikes killing 107, blockaded oil tankers and seized vessels. Analysts call it a psy-ops campaign to pressure Nicolás Maduro into defections without formal war. Experts doubt any major impact on drug networks or Maduro’s grip, noting Venezuela’s minor role in cocaine trafficking and the gang’s weakened state.

articles.title: Russia claims to have moved nuclear-capable missile system into Belarus
articles.trailText: Assertion comes after the Kremlin accused Ukraine of attacking Vladimir Putin’s palace in Novgorod
articles.summary: Russia said it deployed Oreshnik nuclear-capable missiles in eastern Belarus, releasing footage of camouflaged launchers and an airbase flag-raising. The Kremlin also alleged a 91-drone attack by Ukraine on Putin’s Novgorod residence—claims unsubstantiated and rejected by Kyiv. Belarus’s Lukashenko confirmed 10 systems hosted on his territory; Putin vowed more Ukrainian territorial gains as Lavrov threatened reprisals. Ukraine’s foreign minister urged world powers to dismiss Russia’s narrative amid Zelenskiy’s US talks with Trump and planned EU peacekeeping discussions in France.

articles.title: Iran to listen to protesters’ ‘legitimate demands’ after widespread dissent
articles.trailText: President calls for talks with leaders of demonstrations caused by decline in currency and living standards
articles.summary: Iran’s government has opened talks with protest leaders following the largest anti-government demonstrations in three years over a plunging rial and worsening living standards. Tens of thousands marched in Tehran, Isfahan, Shiraz and Mashhad chanting “Azadi” as prices soared—food up 72%, medical goods 50% year-on-year. President Pezeshkian pledged a dialogue mechanism to address “legitimate demands” and reform monetary policy after central bank chief Farzin resigned. Eased social repression and US threats of renewed strikes over Iran’s nuclear programme compound pressure.

articles.title: If you really care about animals, stop eating them | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dean Weston says we are still killing animals by the billion, but praising ourselves for marginally reducing panic and pain, while Jo Barlow calls for transparency and truth about where our food comes from. Plus a letter from Scott Miller
articles.summary: Three Guardian letters contend that incremental animal welfare reforms merely tweak a cruel system without confronting its moral core: the mass breeding, confinement and killing of sentient beings for food. Dean Weston likens improved regulations to adding valves to a cholera-ridden sewer while ignoring the sewage itself, urging veganism as the arithmetic outcome of genuine compassion, climate concern and wildlife preservation. Jo Barlow demands transparency about how battery hens and dairy cows live and die, and Scott Miller highlights crustaceans’ capacity to suffer, arguing that refusing animal products is the only ethical response.

articles.title: Tensions between Saudis and Emiratis over future of Yemen reach boiling point
articles.trailText: Dispute has potential to create civil war in south of Yemen and spill over into neighbouring countries
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia and the UAE are locked in a high-stakes clash over Yemen’s future as the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) seizes Hadramaut and al-Mahra, rekindling southern independence ambitions. Riyadh bombed UAE-supplied vehicles at Mukalla, accusing Abu Dhabi of threatening its national security. Saudi diplomats now push for STC withdrawal, warning that an unrecognised micro-state will remain isolated. Analysts warn this Gulf rivalry—fuelled by control of oilfields, shipping lanes and commercial access—risks proxy escalation, recalls the 2017 Gulf crisis and could strengthen the Iran-backed Houthis amid stalled UN peace efforts.

articles.title: UAE promises to withdraw forces from Yemen after bombing by Saudi Arabia
articles.trailText: Attack was aimed at what Riyadh called a shipment of weapons for separatists backed by UAE
articles.summary: After Saudi Arabia bombed an alleged shipment of UAE-provided weapons for the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council in Mukalla, the UAE announced it would withdraw its remaining forces from Yemen. Riyadh said it struck arms bound for separatists seeking South Yemen’s independence; Abu Dhabi denied the cargo contained weapons. STC refuses to cede territory in Hadhramaut and Mahra. Yemen’s Presidential Leadership Council ordered a 24-hour UAE pullout, emergency measures and a 72-hour blockade. US and UN call for de-escalation.

articles.title: Campaigner turned down MBE over ‘scapegoating’ of people with disabilities
articles.trailText: Exclusive: In letter declining proposed award, Tressa Burke, CEO of Glasgow Disability Alliance, accused government of ‘fuelling hatred’
articles.summary: Tressa Burke, CEO of Glasgow Disability Alliance, rejected an MBE awarded for two decades of service, asserting in a letter to the Cabinet Office that the UK government is “fueling hatred, blame and scapegoating” of disabled people. She cited the recent budget’s tougher PIP assessments, cuts to universal credit health top-ups and Motability, condemning negative framing of disability and far-right misinformation. Burke praised GDA’s member-driven community support and said that while Scotland’s new disability equality plan offers hope, disabled people will scrutinise manifesto commitments ahead of May’s Holyrood elections.

articles.title: Russia still importing Michelin aviation tyres despite sanctions, records suggest
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Sales via intermediary companies appear to continue despite Michelin’s attempts to cut off trade
articles.summary: Customs records and an Economic Security Council of Ukraine analysis reveal that Russia imported 2,687 Michelin aviation tyres (valued at over $7m) between October 2024 and March 2025 via intermediaries in Turkey, Spain, Saudi Arabia, India and a purported UK firm, despite EU and UK sanctions and Michelin halting all exports in March 2022. In 2023, Russia also received $28m worth of tyres. None of these intermediaries are Michelin clients, and Melaris LLC—linked to Russia’s military-industrial complex—was the largest importer. Michelin denies wrongdoing, cites enhanced diversion controls and data uncertainties, while Ukrainian experts urge stronger due-diligence under France’s vigilance law.

articles.title: Cecilia Giménez, famed for ‘Monkey Christ’ mural mishap, dies at 94
articles.trailText: Spanish woman’s attempted restoration of church artwork was widely mocked but became lucrative tourist attraction
articles.summary: Cecilia Giménez, aged 94, the Spanish amateur restorer whose 2012 botched Ecce Homo mural in Borja (‘Monkey Christ’) became an internet sensation, has died. Initially mocked, her failed restoration transformed into a major tourist draw, generating €600,000 for local care homes and funding sanctuary jobs. She sold her own art online to support Catholic charities and inspired the 2023 Opera Las Vegas premiere ‘Behold the Man.’ A widowed mother of disabled children, Giménez overcame anxiety after the backlash. Borja will honor her with a dedicated center, street and square.

articles.title: Israeli president’s office denies Trump’s claim Netanyahu pardon is ‘on its way’
articles.trailText: Isaac Herzog’s spokesperson says he has not spoken to Trump since US president wrote to urge him to stop trial
articles.summary: Israel president Isaac Herzog's office refutes Donald Trump's claim that Benjamin Netanyahu would soon be pardoned, saying no conversation has occurred since Trump’s November letter. Trump, before meeting Netanyahu in Florida, called the trial “political” and urged clemency. Netanyahu—Israel's first sitting PM on trial for bribery, fraud and breach of trust—filed his own pardon bid citing national interest. Herzog stressed pardons follow formal procedures, while experts note no precedent for halting an ongoing trial; critics decry U.S. interference.

articles.title: ‘Data is control’: what we learned from a year investigating the Israeli military’s ties to big tech
