articles.trailText: Our reporting revealed a symbiotic relationship between the IDF and Silicon Valley – with implications for the future of warfare
articles.summary: In 2025, Guardian reports revealed a deep symbiosis between Israel’s military and Silicon Valley: Microsoft, Google and Amazon provide ‘blob storage’ and AI analytics—powering mass surveillance of Palestinian calls and images on Azure and enabling ChatGPT-style tools for target selection in Gaza. AI algorithms like ‘Lavender’ scored civilians as militants, facilitating data-driven airstrikes with high civilian death tolls. Microsoft’s partial service suspension and employee protests highlight tech’s ethical and legal risks. These ties signal how future wars hinge on cloud AI, raising genocide liability and shaping global military AI arms races.

articles.title: Trump should defy Netanyahu over nuclear talks with Iran, says its foreign minister
articles.trailText: Abbas Araghchi claims US president’s Arab allies now view Israel’s recklessness as ‘a threat to us all’
articles.summary: Abbas Araghchi urges President Trump to defy Benjamin Netanyahu’s calls for fresh attacks and revive nuclear negotiations with Iran, leveraging stronger regional and Republican backing for diplomacy over further conflict. He warns that U.S. “blank cheques” for Israel jeopardize Middle East stability, points to Gulf states’ unprecedented readiness to guarantee any agreement and highlights a brief post-June window for a “full and verifiable” accord. Defending Iran’s right to domestic uranium enrichment, he insists Tehran is stronger despite sanctions and warns against unnecessary crises, citing rising U.S. doubts about Israeli brinkmanship.

articles.title: Iceland has hottest Christmas Eve ever with temperature of 19.8C recorded
articles.trailText: Meteorological office reports high temperatures across country and record measured at Seyðisfjörður in east
articles.summary: On Christmas Eve, 24 December 2025, Iceland recorded its highest ever temperature for the date when Seyðisfjörður in the east hit 19.8 °C, just above Bakkagerði’s 19.7 °C. Average December highs are –1 °C to 4 °C. The Icelandic Met Office attributes the spike to a strong high‐pressure system funneling tropical air over the country. This event follows record May heatwaves (up to 26.6 °C at Egilsstaðir), the first mosquitoes sighted in Iceland, collapsing glaciers and new warm‐water fish arrivals, underscoring rapid Arctic warming.

articles.title: ‘He will not be accepted, dead or alive’: the fate of Palestinians suspected of helping Israel
articles.trailText: Khalil Dawas was thought to have been recruited from Israeli jail but large parts of his story remain shrouded in mystery
articles.summary: Khalil Dawas, a Jericho refugee, spent over six years in Israeli jails, where he was allegedly recruited by Unit 8200 through coercion. After his 2020 release, camp residents noticed cheap ammunition sales and probing questions, branding him a collaborator. A 2023 IDF raid and PA arrest—followed by his release for lack of evidence—led locals to exile and torture him. In May 2024 Hamas displayed his body in Israeli uniform, claiming he was a captive soldier. His family disowned him; his remains remain unburied amid deep stigma against alleged collaborators.

articles.title: Did Ukraine target Putin’s residence or is Russian claim a ploy to sway Trump?
articles.trailText: Ukraine has denied the claim and accused Russia of trying to undermine diplomatic progress – so who believes what?
articles.summary: Russia claimed Ukraine launched a mass drone strike on Putin’s residence, downing 91 drones and accusing Kyiv of “state terrorism.” Ukraine and Zelenskyy denied the attack as Russian disinformation aimed at derailing peace talks after his Mar-a-Lago meeting with Trump, who initially echoed Putin’s version. Moscow provided no evidence and independent witnesses reported no explosions. Analysts view the allegation as a tactic to sway Trump from backing Kyiv amid a purportedly “95% done” peace deal, prompting scepticism in Europe but concern in India and others.

articles.title: ‘A little light in the dark’: the former Chinese police officer bringing bubble tea to wartorn Ukraine
articles.trailText: Brother Dong is one of a growing band of Chinese volunteers who are lending their support to Ukraine
articles.summary: Brother Dong, a 52-year-old Chinese-German ex-People’s Armed Police officer, ships tapioca pearls from Berlin to Ukraine monthly, running four crowdfunded “Maomi” bubble-tea cafes in Odesa and beyond. His “Odesa Fighting Cats” volunteer network also delivers winter supplies and snacks. Motivated by a post-pandemic disillusionment with China’s authoritarianism and solidarity with Ukrainian democracy, he uses his German passport to bypass Beijing’s scrutiny. Alongside artist Du Yinghong, these Chinese volunteers honor fallen East Asian fighters and face harassment from Chinese authorities for publicly backing Kyiv against Russia.

articles.title: ‘I don’t like winning’: Toronto man outruns streetcars to show up sluggish transit network
articles.trailText: Mac Bauer’s racing activism has made ‘signal priority’ and traffic congestion a big talking point for the Canadian city
articles.summary: Toronto runner Mac Bauer uses head-to-head races against streetcars to expose the city’s slow transit. On the notorious 511 route, he remains undefeated, often beating the 100,000lb trams due to frequent stops, traffic delays and lack of signal priority. His Instagram videos and high-profile races—even outrunning the new C$3.5 billion Line 6 LRT by 18 minutes—have spurred councillors to adopt more aggressive traffic signal priority and dedicated lanes. As new red-painted lanes narrow the gap in his latest race, Bauer sees fresh hope for faster, more reliable streetcars before the 2026 FIFA World Cup.

articles.title: Trump ‘not worried’ as China’s live-fire Taiwan wargame enters second day
articles.trailText: US president says Chinese leader did not notify him of drills that have involved live missile launches into Taiwan strait
articles.summary: In surprise two-day PLA exercise 'Justice Mission 2025', China fired 27 missiles, deployed 70 warplanes, 11 navy vessels and 14 coast guard ships into the Taiwan Strait, some breaching its contiguous zone. President Trump, citing a 'great relationship' with Xi Jinping, said he was 'not worried' and hadn't been notified, despite US intelligence Beijing aims to annex Taiwan by 2027. Taiwan's Lai Ching-te condemned the drills and vowed defence; Koo called them cognitive warfare. Exercises simulated port blockades, anti-submarine strikes and sea-air coordination. China tied the drills to a record $11bn US arms sale and cautioned Japan over potential intervention.

articles.title: Australian cruise ship refloated after becoming stuck on reef off coast of Papua New Guinea
articles.trailText: Coral Adventurer, being investigated for allegedly leaving behind passenger who died, ran aground with 124 people on board on Saturday
articles.summary: The Coral Adventurer, carrying 80 passengers and 44 crew, ran aground on a reef 30 km from Lae, PNG, on Saturday. A tug helped refloat the vessel on Tuesday; initial inspections show no hull damage. Coral Expeditions cancelled the voyage and will fly everyone back to Cairns by charter as early as Tuesday. No injuries were reported. The ship, on its first voyage since an unrelated probe into the October death of passenger Suzanne Rees—allegedly left behind on Lizard Island—awaits comprehensive hull and environmental inspections.

articles.title: Trump shows customary disdain for protocol as poker-faced Netanyahu looks on
articles.trailText: President’s impromptu news conference in company of Benjamin Netanyahu touched on Gaza, the possibility of further strikes on Iran’s nuclear program and Israel’s tensions with Syria
articles.summary: At Mar-a-Lago, Trump hosted Netanyahu for a 15-minute impromptu press conference, flouting diplomatic protocol by mocking journalists ("Do you recognize this guy?"), pledging immediate US support for further Israeli strikes on Iran’s nuclear and missile sites, and confirming he sought a pardon for Netanyahu in Israel’s corruption case. He upended alliance norms by repeating Russia’s unverified claim that Ukraine attacked Putin, praised Erdogan and hinted at regime change in Iran while balking at discussing it openly. Netanyahu returned lavish praise, but underlying frictions over Trump’s Gaza plan, Hamas disarmament and Syria’s border security remain unresolved.

articles.title: Foreign Office cautioned against UK military action to overthrow Robert Mugabe
articles.trailText: Archives reveal options considered by Tony Blair’s government for dealing with Zimbabwean dictator in 2004
articles.summary: In July 2004 the UK Foreign Office advised Tony Blair’s government that military intervention to depose Zimbabwean president Robert Mugabe was not a viable option, citing heavy casualties, legal barriers and lack of African or Western support. Policy papers reviewed forceful removal alongside tougher sanctions or re-engagement, the latter backed by ambassador Brian Donnelly. Officials warned that, as seen in Iraq and Yugoslavia, external regime change seldom succeeds. With no UN mandate or partner, Blair adopted a strategy of exposing electoral malpractice and re-engaging on conditional terms. Mugabe ultimately fell in a 2017 coup.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: A surreal year in news gives our cartoonists endless material
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Covering everything from Donald Trump to AI, and Gaza to Ukraine, award-winning cartoonist and illustrator Ben Jennings shares his favourite caricatures of 2025, and we share ours too.
articles.summary: In this Dec 30 newsletter, Guardian cartoonist Ben Jennings reviews 2025’s most surreal headlines—from Jeff Bezos’s lavish Venice wedding and Donald Trump’s farcical second term to the Gaza humanitarian crisis, the entrenched Russia-Ukraine war, AI’s threat to creativity, and the resurgence of the far right. Tracing political satire back to James Gillray, Jennings selects seven personal favourite caricatures alongside five standout works by peers, forming a monthly gallery of 12 powerful cartoons that captured the absurdity and brutality of the year.

articles.title: Khaleda Zia, first female Bangladesh prime minister, dies aged 80
articles.trailText: Zia’s archrivalry with Sheikh Hasina defined the country’s politics for a generation
articles.summary: Khaleda Zia, Bangladesh’s first female prime minister, has died aged 80, the BNP announced. Widow of ex-president Ziaur Rahman, she led the Bangladesh Nationalist Party from 1991–96 and briefly again, forging a fierce three-decade rivalry with Sheikh Hasina. Accused of corruption, sentenced in 2018 and under house arrest, she was freed after Hasina’s 2024 ouster and granted medical travel in January. Despite ill health, Zia vowed to campaign in the February 2026 elections. Her son, Tarique Rahman, returned from UK exile to lead the party. She will be buried in Dhaka alongside her husband.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy says Kyiv cannot win without US support as Putin orders advance in Zaporizhzhia
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president calls latest talks with Trump productive; Zelenskyy says attack on Putin’s residence is ‘lies’. What we know on day 1,406
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned on day 1,406 of Russia’s invasion that Kyiv “cannot win without American support,” after a productive two-hour meeting with Donald Trump in Florida. He dismissed Moscow’s claim of foiled drone attack on Putin’s residence as “fabrication” aimed at derailing diplomacy. Putin ordered forces to intensify operations to seize full control of Zaporizhzhia province, where Russia holds roughly 75%. Sergei Lavrov insisted Russia retains the strategic initiative as settlement talks proceed. Separately, the IAEA reported completed power-line repairs at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, and a rebuilt Mariupol theatre reopened under Russian occupation, prompting Ukrainian council condemnation.

articles.title: Hamas will have ‘hell to pay’ if it fails to disarm, Trump warns after Netanyahu meeting
articles.trailText: Israeli prime minister said he will award Trump with Israel prize, highest civilian honor, while visiting Mar-a-Lago
articles.summary: In a Mar-a-Lago meeting, Donald Trump warned Hamas will have “hell to pay” if it fails to disarm under the Gaza ceasefire, backing Benjamin Netanyahu’s push for full implementation. Netanyahu, who plans to award Trump Israel’s highest civilian honor, insists Hamas must return the remains of the last Israeli captive, Ran Gvili, before the deal’s second phase—troop withdrawals, a technocratic Palestinian authority and international stabilisation force—can proceed. Trump, unperturbed by Israeli operations, blamed Hamas for delays, echoed Netanyahu’s stance on Iran’s nuclear ambitions and repeated unfounded claims about his role in past hostage releases.

articles.title: Jair Bolsonaro undergoes second procedure to treat persistent hiccups
articles.trailText: Former Brazilian president underwent a phrenic nerve block while temporarily released from prison for surgery
articles.summary: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro underwent a second minimally invasive right-side phrenic nerve block on Dec. 29 to treat nine months of persistent hiccups, following hernia repair surgery he was granted leave from prison to receive. His condition is stable; doctors postponed the left-side block to minimize risk. Michelle Bolsonaro said he may be discharged Jan. 1 and will return to serving his 27-year sentence in Brasilia. While hospitalized, Bolsonaro endorsed his son Flavio’s 2026 presidential bid.

articles.title: Zelenskyy accuses Russia of trying to sabotage peace talks with ‘typical Russian lies’
articles.trailText: Russia’s claim it foiled drone attack on Putin residence shows ‘they do not want to finish this war’, Ukrainian president says
articles.summary: Meeting at Mar-a-Lago, Zelenskyy accused Russia of spreading “typical lies” after Moscow claimed it thwarted a Ukrainian drone attack on Putin’s residence, calling the allegation a fabrication to justify new strikes on Kyiv. Russian FM Lavrov threatened retaliatory strikes and warned of reviewing negotiations, while Kremlin aides alleged UK involvement and briefed a “shocked” Trump. Zelenskyy won 15-year US security guarantees under a 20-point peace plan but left Donbas unresolved, pushing for 30-50 year guarantees, international monitors, and a referendum on a demilitarised zone to secure Ukraine’s future.

articles.title: Netanyahu meets Trump in US amid fears of Israeli regional offensives
articles.trailText: Israel’s PM travels to Mar-a-Lago as US administration reported to be running out of patience over Gaza ceasefire
articles.summary: PM Benjamin Netanyahu met Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago to press for swift progress to phase two of Trump’s 20-point Gaza ceasefire plan, including Hamas disarmament, amid US frustration over stalled implementation. With fears Israel may strike Hezbollah in Lebanon or Iran, they discussed preventing Tehran’s missile buildup and reinforcing Israel’s military edge. Trump falsely claimed full credit for hostage releases. The visit, Netanyahu’s fifth this year, aims to shore up US support ahead of Israeli elections and amid growing Middle East instability.

articles.title: At least 13 people killed and 98 injured in train derailment in Mexico
articles.trailText: Train accident in Oaxaca is likely to raise criticisms about public works projects from the previous administration
articles.summary: At least 13 people died and 98 of the 250 aboard were injured when the Interoceanic Train derailed in Oaxaca on December 29. Built under Andrés Manuel López Obrador to link the Atlantic and Pacific across the Isthmus of Tehuantepec, the military-managed project and its sister Mayan Train faced safety concerns after multiple non-fatal incidents earlier in 2025. President Claudia Sheinbaum pledged a rigorous investigation into the crash, while opposition PRI leader Alejandro Moreno demanded a full audit and suspension of similar infrastructure works pending safety reviews.

articles.title: Key factors in the unstoppable rise of fascists in Germany | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Dr Jens Holst on why voters are drifting towards the right, Ahmed Dirie on arming ourselves against Fascism 2.0 movement, and Paul Gander on the role of the state and the media
articles.summary: Letters responding to Tania Roettger argue Germany’s coalition of conservatives, reactionaries and SPD fuels AfD growth by neglecting rising living costs, rents and social inequality, reinforcing fear of global finance and ecological transition. Contributors warn modern fascism (2.0) uses civilisational exclusion, Islamophobia and administrative tools—militarised borders, bureaucratic “remigration���—rather than uniformed paramilitaries, weaponising the security state and media complicity. They stress converging interests of state and press, not just an extremist party, erode legal safeguards and universal rights.

articles.title: More than 3,000 migrants died trying to reach Spain in 2025
articles.trailText: Tighter border controls caused arrivals to decline sharply but forced people on to more dangerous routes, activists say
articles.summary: Caminando Fronteras reports 3,090 migrants—192 women and 437 children—drowned en route to Spain by sea between January and 15 December 2025, down from 10,457 the prior year. Activists say tighter border controls, notably in Mauritania under a €210m EU deal, cut arrivals (35,935 vs. 60,311) but forced migrants onto riskier routes. The Atlantic Canary Islands route caused 1,906 deaths, the new Algeria–Balearic Islands route 1,037; 303 shipwrecks and 70 missing vessels were recorded. Rights groups accuse authorities of abuses, “necropolitics” and inadequate rescue response.

articles.title: Germany’s far-right AfD invited to join Munich Security Conference 2026
articles.trailText: Move comes after party’s exclusion for last two years was lambasted by JD Vance at this year’s event
articles.summary: The Munich Security Conference has reversed its two-year ban on far-right AfD MPs and will invite all Bundestag parties, including 19 AfD members on defence and foreign affairs committees, to its February 2026 meeting. Organisers say invitations follow long-standing policy and cited their status as a private foundation for silence. They declined to confirm if US vice-president JD Vance’s critique—calling the exclusion a free-speech violation—triggered the shift. Critics warn of Kremlin ties, security risks and normalisation ahead of regional elections where AfD leads polls. Germany’s intelligence service calls it a confirmed right-wing extremist force.

articles.title: ‘A gift that cannot be sold’: the Palestinian family fighting to save their West Bank farm
articles.trailText: For more than three decades, the Nassars have battled Israeli efforts to reclassify their property as ‘state land’
articles.summary: In 1916 Daher Nassar bought and repeatedly re-registered 42ha of farmland near Nahalin south of Bethlehem under Ottoman, British, Jordanian and Israeli rule. Since 1991 Israel has sought to reclassify it as state land, sparking a 34-year military and supreme court battle. Cut off from water and electricity and hemmed in by settler outposts, the Christian Palestinian family lives partly in caves and hand-waters olives with rainwater. Relying on solar panels and global volunteers via the Tent of Nations, they resist nonviolently to safeguard their inherited land amid accelerating West Bank seizures.

articles.title: China launches live-fire drills around Taiwan simulating blockade of major ports
articles.trailText: Taipei condemns exercise that Chinese army calls ‘a stern warning’ against separatist and external forces
articles.summary: China’s People’s Liberation Army launched surprise “Justice Mission 2025” live-fire drills around Taiwan, deploying navy destroyers, frigates, coastguard ships, fighters, bombers, drones and long-range missiles to simulate a blockade of key ports, anti-submarine attacks and deterrence of external forces. Taipei reported 28 vessels entering its contiguous zone and at least 89 warplanes—its largest incursion in over a year—and condemned the exercises as escalation. Beijing framed the drills as a warning to “separatist” Taiwan and foreign backers—particularly the US, after an $11bn arms sale—and urged abandonment of “illusions” of containment. Taiwan vowed counter-readiness and defense of its democracy.

articles.title: Is claim Ukraine deal is ‘95% done’ just another empty assertion from Trump?
articles.trailText: A sober observer assessing the US president’s claim may react the same way as Zelenskyy – with shock and disbelief
articles.summary: After meeting Zelenskyy at Mar-a-Lago, Trump claimed a Ukraine–Russia peace deal was “95% done,” but analysts point out the remaining 5% requires Vladimir Putin’s sign-off amid fresh Russian drone strikes and Moscow’s maximalist demands. Zelenskyy’s shocked disbelief echoes past missed deadlines from leaked plans. Despite US intelligence support and Trump’s vague security guarantees, neither Washington nor its European allies are willing to pressure or militarily confront Russia. With no mechanism to enforce a ceasefire, Ukraine faces either prolonged war until Russia’s calculus shifts or eventual capitulation under Moscow’s terms.

articles.title: Japanese town reeling from year of record bear encounters
articles.trailText: Bears are becoming a growing problem in some of Japan’s urban areas as they are forced to venture further in search of food
articles.summary: In late 2025, Osaki (pop. 128,000) and northern Japan witnessed a record 400 bear sightings (vs. fewer than 100 in 2024), prompting a state of emergency and multi-language safety advisories. Hungry Asian black and Ussuri brown bears—driven by failed acorn/beechnut crops, delayed hibernation, and booming populations (44,000 black bears in Honshu; 12,000 brown in Hokkaido)—have ventured into towns, injuring dozens and causing 13 nationwide deaths in 197 attacks. Tourism and local businesses suffered cancellations. Limits on hunters, disappearing satoyama borders, and habituated bears compound the crisis. Akita prefecture enlisted Self-Defense Forces to trap over 2,000 bears, igniting debate on culling versus habitat management. Experts urge a national wildlife policy reform.

articles.title: Trump says ‘tough’ issues remain for Ukraine peace deal after meeting Zelenskyy in Florida
articles.trailText: US president said ‘thorny’ questions over territory have yet to be resolved and expressed sympathy with Russia not wanting a ceasefire
articles.summary: After a two-hour Mar-a-Lago meeting, Trump claimed a Ukraine peace deal was nearly 95% complete but admitted 'thorny' issues remain over eastern Donbas territory, security guarantees and ceasefire terms. He expressed sympathy for Russia's reluctance to agree a ceasefire, gave confused details on the occupied Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant and touted a “productive” call with Putin. Zelenskyy thanked Trump’s team, noted negotiators have 90% of a 20-point draft agreed, including demilitarized zones and a referendum after a 60–90 day ceasefire. Meanwhile, Russia’s heavy airstrikes killed civilians, seized settlements and hit Kyiv. With no Russian signoff or US defense commitment, major doubts remain.

articles.title: British-Egyptian rights activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah apologises for ‘hurtful’ tweets
articles.trailText: Campaigner recently released from prison makes statement after PM’s support is questioned by Tory MPs
articles.summary: Alaa Abd el-Fattah, released after more than a decade in Egyptian prison, has issued an unreserved apology for tweets from 2010–12 praising violence against “Zionists” and insulting British people, which resurfaced amid Tory demands to revoke his UK citizenship and deport him. He blamed youthful anger amid regional wars, denied antisemitism and homophobia, and pointed to his record defending LGBTQ+ rights, religious minorities and free speech. Conservatives including Kemi Badenoch and Nigel Farage have called for his expulsion, while Labour acknowledges vetting oversights.

articles.title: Boy, 5, died after arm trapped in ski resort travelator in Japan
articles.trailText: Hinata Goto reportedly fell as he was trying to get off the 30-metre-long walkway
articles.summary: Hinata Goto, a five-year-old on a family ski trip in Otaru, Hokkaido, died after his right arm became lodged in the winding mechanism of a 30 m-long, 60 cm-wide “snow escalator” linking the car park to the slope. Firefighters freed him about 40 minutes after his mother’s emergency call, but he was pronounced dead on arrival at hospital. Installed six years ago without handrails, the travelator’s safety stop reportedly failed, and no staff were on duty nearby. Hokkaido police have opened a negligence investigation and critics are demanding design and oversight reforms at the Asari resort.

articles.title: Peace, power and profit – the logic behind Donald Trump’s dealmaking diplomacy
articles.trailText: As Trump’s business and diplomacy fuse, critics warn that his approach risks trading stability – and US democracy – for leverage
articles.summary: Donald Trump's fusion of business and diplomacy: as a candidate he promised peace—ending the wars in Gaza and Ukraine—but as president he authorized US bombings in Yemen and Iran, threatened Venezuela and pressed Ukraine for concessions. He has brokered Gaza ceasefires and regional truces while his family business raked in real-estate and crypto licensing fees from Gulf states. Jared Kushner’s private equity deals overlap with his diplomatic role. Critics warn this conflict of interest risks US democracy and international law.

articles.title: ‘They want to destroy my career’: Kiwi Chow on life as a dissenting director in Hong Kong
articles.trailText: With his new film rejected by official censors, the award-winning film-maker says he is being punished for his outspoken views
articles.summary: Kiwi Chow, 46, Hong Kong–based director of Ten Years and Revolution of Our Times, sees his career under siege after the city’s censors rejected his new film, Deadline, citing national security. Deadline, a Taiwanese‐shot drama on student suicide amid oppressive academic and security curricula, premiered in Taiwan but was effectively banned in Hong Kong. Chow, who refused to appeal, views the move as punishment for his outspoken criticisms of the CCP, especially after the Wang Fuk Court fire and “patriots only” elections depressed turnout to 31.9%. Undeterred, he vows to keep speaking out despite living with fear.

articles.title: ‘Too important not to fight for’: Spain’s wine industry seeks infusion of new blood
articles.trailText: Rural depopulation compounding challenges of climate emergency and changing technologies in drawing young people to sector
articles.summary: Spain’s €22.4bn wine sector faces a generational crisis: OIVE data show 74% of growers over 51, under-40s just 9.3%, and 22,600 recruits needed as vintners retire. Climate extremes, new technologies and la España vaciada rural exodus deter young talent. Leaders urge vineyard modernization, sustainability training and digital skills, reframing winemaking as an entrepreneurial career. At Cuatro Rayas, 36-year-old engineer-turned-vigneron Óscar de Íscar embodies this shift. Stakeholders warn that without fresh blood, carbon-storing vineyards, rural economies and cultural heritage could vanish.

articles.title: More than 300 earthquakes recorded in UK this year, study finds
articles.trailText: Western Highlands and southern Wales among most active regions, according to British Geological Survey
articles.summary: British Geological Survey data show 309 earthquakes in the UK in 2025, with 1,320 public felt reports, and hotspots in Perthshire/western Highlands, southern Wales, Yorkshire and Lancashire. The strongest onshore tremors hit near Loch Lyon on 20 October—magnitudes 3.7 and 3.6—eliciting 198 reports up to 37 miles away. A 3.2 quake rattled Silverdale, Lancashire, on 3 December (700 reports). Dr Brian Baptie notes small quakes occurred virtually daily and stresses studying them to assess risks to energy and infrastructure. The BGS’s 80-station network tracks fault-driven seismicity across Britain.

articles.title: Search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 expected to resume on Tuesday
articles.trailText: Marine robotics firm to renew its search more than decade after plane disappeared with 239 people onboard
articles.summary: From 30 December, UK–US robotics firm Ocean Infinity will resume its 55-day seabed search for Malaysia Airlines MH370 under a “no find, no fee” deal, covering 5,800 sq miles with a $70 million payout only if wreckage is located. Earlier multinational efforts (2014–17) scoured 46,330 sq miles after the Boeing 777 vanished en route Kuala Lumpur–Beijing with 239 onboard. Debris found on African shores aided drift modelling. Families hope this targeted phase finally delivers closure.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: thorny questions remain after Trump-Zelenskyy talks
articles.trailText: US and Ukraine presidents meet in Florida to discuss deal to end war; Trump says it will be clear in ‘a few weeks’ if negotiations can succeed. What we know on day 1,405
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met in Florida, saying they are 95% toward a peace framework with security guarantees for Ukraine and European partners to assume key roles. Donbas’ final status remains unresolved. US and Ukrainian teams will reconvene next week to iron out remaining issues. EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen, UK PM Keir Starmer and France’s Emmanuel Macron backed the effort, with Macron convening allies in Paris in January. Overnight, Russian bombs struck Sloviansk homes, killing one and injuring three.

articles.title: Polls close in first phase of Myanmar elections widely condemned as a sham
articles.trailText: Turnout appears low for vote in which most candidates seen as allies of junta and large areas excluded by war
articles.summary: First-phase polls in Myanmar's conflict zones closed under the military junta, widely condemned as a sham to legitimize Min Aung Hlaing's rule. Aung San Suu Kyi and the NLD are banned, most candidates are junta allies, the USDP. Areas under anti-junta control were excluded. Turnout in Yangon was low amid fear and repression. The UN labels the vote violent and unfair; China, Russia, India and Vietnam sent observers. A new electoral law criminalises dissent with harsh penalties. Critics decry a 'theatre of the absurd' as airstrikes and fighting rage in Sagaing and Mandalay. Further phases are set for January.

articles.title: Saving Kyiv’s heritage: a city rebuilding itself in the shadow of war
articles.trailText: Volunteers and neighbours are restoring the century-old homes as an act of defiance against Russia’s assault
articles.summary: Volunteers in Kyiv’s Shevchenkivskyi district are restoring early 20th-century art nouveau houses—adorned with horse-chestnut leaves, camomile flowers and turrets—as symbolic defiance against Russia’s intensified air raids. Projects like Lesia Danylenko’s “croissant” transom window embody residents’ commitment to normal life and homeland. Heritage Kyiv activists warn that corrupt developers, apathetic officials and harsh winters threaten these rare mansions, with just 80 of 3,500 original doors surviving. They lament political inertia under Mayor Klitschko and frontline losses of defenders like blogger Serhiy Mironov. True Kyiv volunteers, led by Nelli Chudna, operate a 1910 creeper-clad house as museum. Advocates insist urgent preservation is vital to safeguard Kyiv’s architectural identity.

articles.title: Zelenskyy heads to Florida for talks with Trump amid fresh strikes on Kyiv
articles.trailText: Russia’s “barbaric” attack on capital draws condemnation as Ukrainian leader readies for Florida meeting
articles.summary: After Russia’s overnight drone and missile assault on Kyiv—nearly 500 drones, 40 missiles—power remains unstable, with 750,000 households restored but the left bank still under outages amid sub-zero temperatures. One killed, two dozen injured. Zelenskyy paused in Canada to secure $2.5bn more aid, condemned the strikes as “barbaric,” then heads to Florida to refine his 20-point peace plan with Trump. He’s also in talks with Macron, von der Leyen and Costa, warning that only stronger international pressure can deter Moscow’s Christmas attacks. Russia claims to have downed 111 drones and seized more towns. Peace hinges on addressing conflict roots and security guarantees.

articles.title: ‘Almost collapsed’: behind the Korean film crisis and why K-pop isn’t immune
articles.trailText: Both industries dominate the world but now face fundamental transformation and uncertainty at home
articles.summary: Once a cultural superpower, South Korea’s film industry has seen admissions plunge 45% since 2019 to 123m and box office fall from $1.3bn to $812m. Production budgets and mid-tier titles have dwindled, prompting consolidation of cinema chains and a shift to streaming with shorter holdback windows. Meanwhile, K-pop album sales dropped 19.5% in 2024, driving agencies to rely on global tours and core superfans. Smaller labels are squeezed, and international creators now adapt Korean aesthetics abroad. Seoul’s government unveiled a five-year ₩51.4tn cultural investment plan to bolster exports, but risks overlooking domestic infrastructure vital for creative renewal.

articles.title: Tommy Robinson says he found Jesus in prison. Churches disagree about how to respond
articles.trailText: C of E faces dilemma as far right claims Christianity to push agenda that often clashes with gospel message
articles.summary: Tommy Robinson, leader of the far-right ‘Unite the Kingdom’ movement, claims he ‘found Jesus’ in prison after visits from Spirit Embassy minister Rikki Doolan. His December carol service in Whitehall drew only 1,500 attendees versus 150,000 in September, prompting Anglican, Baptist, Methodist and URC leaders to debate responding to Christian nationalism. Within the Church of England, figures like Bishop Arun Arora urge a firm rebuttal of Robinson’s Islamophobia and xenophobia, while others, including Archbishops Stephen Cottrell and Sarah Mullally, worry that overt opposition may backfire. At January’s bishops’ meeting and a forthcoming Theos study, church leaders will decide whether to confront or risk normalizing Robinson’s political use of faith.

articles.title: ‘Times have changed’: Germany’s military seeks recruits as it confronts new era
articles.trailText: As young men face new rules forcing them to indicate their readiness to serve, the Bundeswehr drums up support at a trade show
articles.summary: At the Essen Motor Show, Germany’s Bundeswehr stages a major recruitment campaign—showcasing armoured vehicles, VR simulators and a khaki Porsche—to help expand its professional force by 80,000 and reservists by 140,000 over the next decade. From January, 18-year-old men must complete questionnaires and health tests indicating service readiness. To win volunteers, the army is boosting pay, offering language courses, subsidised licenses, free train travel in uniform and new qualifications. After conscription ended in 2011, public outreach—from career lounges to “girls’ days”—seeks to shift pacifist attitudes amid the war in Ukraine.

articles.title: Australian cruise ship investigated after leaving passenger behind runs aground off PNG with 120 people on board
articles.trailText: Coral Adventurer says passengers and crew are safe while team tries to refloat ship and inspects the hull
articles.summary: Coral Adventurer, under investigation after passenger Suzanne Rees died alone during a Lizard Island excursion, ran aground early Saturday about 30 km off Lae, PNG, with 120 crew and passengers aboard. The operator reports no injuries or hull damage in initial checks, and authorities will conduct formal inspections while refloating efforts proceed. Rees, 80, from Sydney, went missing on 26 October; her body was found after the ship turned back 100 km and later canceled the 60-day voyage, refunding guests. Balcony cabins list at $86,400 per person.

articles.title: Central African Republic goes to polls as president seeks third term
articles.trailText: Opposition hopes to tap into frustrations of people living in country where conflict remains a daily reality
articles.summary: On Dec 28, 2025, 2.3m registered voters in the Central African Republic cast ballots in a quad election—presidential, parliamentary, local and municipal—as incumbent Faustin-Archange Touadéra seeks a third term after a 2023 referendum scrapped term limits and extended mandates to seven years. Seven candidates, including former PMs Anicet Dologuélé and Henri-Marie Dondra, vie amid ongoing sectarian violence that has displaced over half a million internally and across borders. Despite a 2022 peace accord and UN MINUSCA security support, Wagner mercenaries and Rwandan forces wield influence. Critics warn online-only voter lists and boycotts risk disenfranchisement.

articles.title: ‘Ferryman of the souls’: the man who helps Taiwan’s dead return home to China
articles.trailText: Liu De-wen operates at a sensitive space in Taiwan’s history, as Beijing demands reunification with the island
articles.summary: Liu De-wen, a 58-year-old Taiwanese volunteer and former borough chief, has devoted 23 years to repatriating the ashes of hundreds of “waishengren” — mainland Chinese soldiers, forced conscripts and migrants brought to Taiwan by the KMT after 1949 — to ancestral villages in Fujian. Working without government funding, he locates neglected graves, handles legal permits and personally transports urns across the Taiwan Strait, earning praise in PRC media as a “ferryman of souls.” Beijing leverages his story to underscore cross-strait family ties amid reunification rhetoric that most Taiwanese reject.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Nabu and Sapo raid Kyiv parliament in new corruption inquiry
articles.trailText: Russia not strong enough to take Donetsk and then keep fighting, says ISW; Zelenskyy heads to Florida for talks with Trump. What we know on day 1,404
articles.summary: Ukraine’s anti-corruption bureaus Nabu and Sapo raided MPs’ offices in Kyiv’s parliament over alleged bribery-for-votes, following previous investigations that forced Zelenskyy’s chief of staff to resign. President Zelenskyy, after meeting Canada’s PM who pledged $2.5bn, heads to Florida for talks with Trump to coordinate European support. The ISW warns Russia, lacking manpower for Donetsk, is pressuring Ukraine to cede unoccupied territory. Ukrainian forces claim tactical gains around Kupiansk amid contested fighting in Myrnohrad and Huliaipole. A 10-hour Russian barrage on Kyiv killed one, wounded two dozen and left a third without heating.

articles.title: Myanmar is going to the polls. But it’s not the people who hold the power – it’s China
articles.trailText: As the military pushes ahead with a widely condemned election, Beijing’s priorities are proving decisive
articles.summary: The Myanmar military, buoyed by Chinese support, has regained territory and is pushing ahead with a widely condemned December 2025 election. Beijing has used border closures, drone technology, weapons transfers and diplomatic backing—sending observers and integrating the junta into SCO platforms—to pressure ethnic armed groups into ceasefires and return land. Balancing its infrastructure and anti-crime interests, China hedges its bet despite ties to various factions. The sham vote, dominated by the military-backed USDP, cements junta chief Min Aung Hlaing’s grip while Beijing monitors project progress.

articles.title: Bayeux tapestry to be insured for £800m for British Museum exhibition
articles.trailText: The 70-metre-long cloth about the Norman invasion has not been seen in England since it was created in 11th century
articles.summary: Returning to the UK in 2026 for the first time in over 900 years, the 70m Bayeux Tapestry — depicting 58 scenes of the 1066 Norman conquest and commissioned in the 11th century — will be insured under the Government Indemnity Scheme at an £800m valuation, saving UK museums £81m in premiums. On display at the British Museum’s Sainsbury Gallery from autumn 2026 to July 2027 while Normandy’s Bayeux Museum is renovated, it’s part of a major loan swap under a UK-French agreement in which London will lend the Sutton Hoo treasure and Lewis Chessmen. Some French conservators warn the delicate embroidery risks transport damage.

articles.title: Poland preparing ��2bn anti-drone fortifications along its eastern border amid Russian threat
articles.trailText: Deputy defence minister says new air defence systems will be completed in 24 months
articles.summary: Polish deputy defence minister Cezary Tomczyk announced a €2bn programme to install layered anti-drone fortifications along eastern borders with Belarus, Ukraine and Kaliningrad. The system—integrating machine guns, cannons, missiles and drone jammers with a decade-old defence line—will see initial capabilities in six months and full deployment in 24. Funded mainly by EU SAFE loans and state budgets, it responds to September’s Russian drone incursions. Part of the wider Eastern Shield, it includes local logistics hubs and accompanies a rise in Poland’s defence spending to 4.7% of GDP amid hybrid threats.

articles.title: Child abuse victim of Jackanory presenter tells how climbing saved him
articles.trailText: Iain Peters waited more than 50 years before going to the police but hopes he can be a beacon for other survivors
articles.summary: Iain Peters, 77, has revealed how weekly sexual abuse by John Earle—former Devon boarding-school deputy head, John Tom Tom and Jackanory presenter—left him with PTSD for over 50 years. He finally reported Earle in 2015; Earle was jailed in 2017. Peters turned to extreme climbing—from the Alps to Tierra del Fuego—as a survival tool and detailed his journey in memoir The Corridor, winner of the 2024 Boardman Tasker award. He now uses his story to support fellow survivors and challenge the stigma around reporting abuse.

articles.title: ‘It’s frightening’: How far right is infiltrating everyday culture
articles.trailText: Extremist messaging now woven into music and YouTube videos, with one expert saying: ‘You can be radicalised sitting on your couch’
articles.summary: Researchers warn far-right extremists are embedding propaganda in everyday culture—from Germany’s Balaclava Kitchen vegan cooking show with Nazi imagery to mainstream top-40 bands, ‘tradwife’ influencers and wine-tasting groups. A C-REX six-country study shows memes, fitness pages, stickers and AI-generated content rapidly normalise radical views online. Social-media incentives and bots blur who’s ideologically driven, even offering food delivery covertly linked to extremists. Researchers Katherine Kondor and Greta Jasser caution that subculture pathways can radicalise people on their couch and urge new tools to help audiences spot far-right aesthetics before they escalate.

articles.title: Opposition anger as Guinea’s junta leader is frontrunner to be elected president
articles.trailText: Mamady Doumbouya accused of betraying his promise to be the restorer of democracy after leading 2021 coup
articles.summary: Colonel-turned-junta leader Mamady Doumbouya, who toppled Alpha Condé in the 2021 coup promising a 36-month transition to civilian rule, is now Guinea’s clear frontrunner in the Dec 27 presidential vote after a controversial referendum rewrote the constitution to extend terms to seven years and allow his candidacy. Opposition parties remain suspended, top rivals detained or exiled, and critics warn of a climate of fear amid West Africa’s “coup belt.” Doumbouya’s government touts the new Simandou iron-ore mine as an economic boon, but doubts over democratic integrity persist.

articles.title: No gels, no foams: Catalonia turns to grannies to teach traditional cooking
articles.trailText: Region famed for molecular gastronomy begins video project to collect and share rustic recipes
articles.summary: Under the Catalan government’s Gastrosàvies initiative, over 100 elder home cooks share more than 300 rustic Catalan recipes via video, preserving heritage techniques such as sofregit, picada and herb-infused dishes, eschewing modernist spherification or liquid nitrogen. Twelve recorded tutorials—from rice with cabbage and peas to Penedès cockerel with dried fruit and cognac—celebrate seasonal, local produce and traditional equipment. Catalonia’s avant-garde chefs acknowledge these flavors as their roots, yet urban eateries lean toward global fast foods. Gastrosàvies aims to inspire future generations to cook simple, regional classics instead of pizzas, ramen or burgers, reinforcing cultural identity.

articles.title: Thailand and Cambodia agree ‘immediate’ ceasefire after weeks of deadly border clashes
articles.trailText: Two countries pledge in joint statement to halt all forms of attacks and further troop deployments in long-running dispute over contested territory
articles.summary: Thailand and Cambodia agreed an immediate ceasefire from noon on Saturday to halt a 20-day border conflict over contested territory that killed over 100 people, displaced more than 500,000, and saw fighter-jet strikes and artillery duels. The defence ministers pledged no new weapon use or troop movements, maintaining current deployments. Both sides will cooperate on demining and cybercrime. Despite the accord—brokered with Malaysian PM Anwar Ibrahim’s mediation and US pressure—Cambodia reported a Thai F-16 airstrike on Banteay Meanchey province Saturday morning. Thailand conceded previous strikes, while each side reported dozens of civilian and military casualties.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kim Jong-un celebrates sharing ‘blood, life and death’ with Russia
articles.trailText: North Korea leader speaks of ‘really meaningful year’ for alliance with Moscow; Zelenskyy accuses Russia of using Belarus apartments to attack Ukraine. What we know on day 1,403
articles.summary: Kim Jong-un hailed 2025 as a “meaningful year” of shared “blood, life and death” alongside Russia in a New Year message to Putin, after confirming Pyongyang sent troops to Ukraine—including mine-clearing in Kursk—and suffered casualties. Kyiv faced missile and drone strikes overnight, prompting nationwide air alerts and explosions in the capital. Zelenskyy accused Russia of guiding Shahed drones from Belarusian apartment roofs. US analysts say satellite imagery shows Russian Oreshnik hypersonic launchers at a former Belarus airbase. Moscow also claims to have seized Kosivtseve near Huliaipole.

articles.title: Israel becomes first country to recognise Somaliland as sovereign state
articles.trailText: Diplomatic breakthrough criticised by African Union, which said it could have ‘far-reaching implications for peace and stability across the continent’
articles.summary: Israel has become the first country to recognise Somaliland’s 1991-declared independence from Somalia, signing a full diplomatic agreement including embassies and ambassadors. Prime Minister Netanyahu hailed the move as part of the Abraham accords; President Abdirahman Mohamed Abdullahi of Somaliland welcomed the historic step and invited to visit Jerusalem. The African Union, Somalia’s government, Egypt, and Turkey condemned the recognition as a threat to Somalia’s sovereignty and continental stability. Analysts note strategic benefits for Israel in countering Yemen’s Houthi rebels via Somaliland’s port at Berbera, already hosting a UAE military base.

articles.title: Zelenskyy to travel to US for Trump meeting amid push for Ukraine  deal
articles.trailText: Meeting on Sunday will follow flurry of US, Russian and Ukrainian talks, but Putin has shown little sign of softening
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy will travel to Florida—likely Trump’s Mar-a-Lago—for a Sunday meeting with Donald Trump to refine a US-backed “20-point” peace plan aimed at ending Russia’s full-scale invasion. Following a November 28-point draft negotiated by US and Russian envoys, talks will address Ukrainian security guarantees, reconstruction funding, Donbas territorial status and Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant control. Early Saturday missile and drone alerts threatened Kyiv. Trump has withheld endorsement pending review. Moscow insists on full Donbas annexation and shows no sign of compromising despite Ukraine’s recent counteroffensive retaking Kupiansk.

articles.title: Cyclones, floods and wildfires among 2025’s costliest climate-related disasters
articles.trailText: Christian Aid annual report’s top 10 disasters amounted to more than $120bn in insured losses
articles.summary: Christian Aid’s annual report identifies 2025’s top 10 climate disasters—southeast Asian cyclones and floods ($25 bn damage, 1,750+ fatalities), California wildfires ($60 bn, 400+ dead) and China floods ($12 bn, 30+ dead)—totaling over $120 bn in insured losses. Emeritus professor Joanna Haigh warns these events stem from fossil-fuel-driven warming, not “natural” variability. The study highlights disproportionate human tolls in developing nations and calls on rich countries to exceed COP30’s pledge to triple adaptation finance to $120 bn by 2035. A voluntary global fossil-fuel phase-out roadmap, led by Brazil, launches this year.

articles.title: British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah arrives in UK after travel ban lifted
articles.trailText: Family say campaigner, who has a son in Brighton, will be able to travel freely between UK and Cairo months after his release from Egyptian jail
articles.summary: British-Egyptian dissident Alaa Abd el-Fattah has reached London after Egypt lifted a travel ban imposed on him post-release in September, ending nearly a decade of detention over dissent. His initial attempt to leave in November was blocked by security forces, reflecting Egypt’s refusal to credit pretrial detention. Freed two years beyond his 2019 sentence for “spreading false news,” he can now travel freely between the UK and Cairo under a negotiated agreement. Reuniting with his special-needs son in Brighton, his family and human rights groups hailed a victory after PM Starmer’s diplomatic pressure and his mother’s hunger strike.

articles.title: Labour’s animal welfare strategy does not go far enough | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to the government’s plans to improve the lot of animals
articles.summary: The government’s animal welfare strategy improves kept animal conditions—outlawing hen cages and pig farrowing crates—but critics say it neglects free-living wildlife by relying on outdated laws, offering patchy mustelid protection and a hare close season that endangers predators. Experts call for a full review of wildlife legislation under the Animal Welfare (Sentience) Act and urge a shift away from expanding factory farming toward nature-friendly systems. Pet owners warn that banning electric containment collars could increase cat road deaths, while others debate bans on boiling lobsters. The 2026 national food strategy is seen as the next reform opportunity.

articles.title: Report on Israeli settlements plan is all too brief | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Letters: West Bank occupation | You Must Believe in Spring | A gift of time and attention | Tanks for the reference | Amended signs
articles.summary: Letters respond to the Guardian’s brief notice that Israel approved 19 new West Bank settlements, condemning the move as a flagrant breach of international law and likening Palestinian Christians’ lives to "small prisons", urging sanctions. Other correspondents celebrate Shelley’s lyric in "You Must Believe in Spring" (notably Bennett/Evans’ recording), advocate gifts of time and listening over material presents, note the 100-tonne London "fatberg" exceeds tank weight, and recall a Crook of Devon sign "Twinned with The Thief of Bagdad".

articles.title: Former Malaysian PM Najib Razak jailed for 15 more years in 1MDB graft scandal
articles.trailText: New conviction over plunder of state fund substantially increases six-year term in separate case
articles.summary: Former Malaysian PM Najib Razak was convicted on four counts of abuse of power in the biggest 1MDB trial, receiving an additional 15-year prison term on top of his ongoing six-year sentence. Prosecutors say he diverted 2.2 billion ringgit ($544 m) from the state fund into personal accounts, part of a $4.5 billion fraud that financed luxury property, a yacht and artworks. Najib denies wrongdoing, calling the case a political witch-hunt. The verdict heightens tensions in PM Anwar Ibrahim’s coalition, where Najib’s UMNO retains influence; money laundering verdicts loom.

articles.title: China imposes sanctions on US defence firms over Taiwan arms deal
articles.trailText: $10bn Trump-approved sale to Taipei triggers Beijing sanctions against firms such as Boeing and Northrop Grumman
articles.summary: Beijing’s foreign ministry slapped sanctions on 20 US defence firms and 10 executives, including Boeing’s St. Louis hub, Northrop Grumman and L3Harris, freezing any assets in China, banning business ties and barring individuals such as Anduril’s founder from entry. The measures retaliate against the $10bn Trump-approved arms package—420 ATACMS missiles, drones and other systems—the largest US sale to Taiwan yet. Beijing calls Taiwan its “core interest” and warns any US provocation will prompt strong countermeasures, urging Washington to halt “dangerous” arms deals despite US legal obligations to bolster Taipei’s defense.

articles.title: US warns of more Nigeria strikes as Abuja talks of ‘joint ongoing operations’
articles.trailText: Pete Hegseth says ‘more to come’ as Nigerian minister confirms his country provided intelligence for first wave
articles.summary: US defence secretary Pete Hegseth warned of more air strikes on Islamic State camps in north-west Nigeria after a Christmas Day operation coordinated with Nigerian government intelligence in Sokoto. President Trump delayed the attack to Christmas, touting it as a decisive blow. Nigeria’s foreign minister Yusuf Tuggar described the campaign as joint ongoing operations, approved by President Tinubu. Civilians in Jabo reported panic but no casualties. The strikes reflect broader US Africa Command efforts amid sectarian and resource-driven violence by IS, bandits and Boko Haram.

articles.title: Why has Trump ordered strikes in Nigeria and what has it got to do with the persecution of Christians?
articles.trailText: Parts of the US right have for years been amplifying claims that Christians face violence in Nigeria, a notion the US president has helped to encourage
articles.summary: On Christmas Day 2025, President Trump ordered US strikes on Islamic State militants in northern Nigeria, citing rampant killings of Christians. Approved by Nigeria’s government, the joint operation involved intelligence-sharing and targeted ISWAP in Sokoto. The strikes reflect Trump’s alignment with US right claims of widespread Christian persecution and his evangelical base, following Nigeria’s 2024 designation as a “country of particular concern” under the International Religious Freedom Act. Nigerian officials welcomed the counter-terror cooperation but reject framing violence as solely anti-Christian, noting extremists also target Muslims and that conflicts often arise from resource competition and ransom-driven kidnappings. Boko Haram, ISWAP and criminal “bandits” continue insurgencies and mass abductions amid Nigeria’s ongoing security crisis.

articles.title: Venezuela says it released 99 people detained for 2024 election protests
articles.trailText: Government said the move was due to its ‘unrestricted respect for human rights’ in the face of US aggression
articles.summary: Venezuela announced on Christmas Day the release of 99 individuals detained for participating in post-July 2024 election protests widely considered against Nicolás Maduro’s disputed re-election. The government framed the move as evidence of its commitment to human rights amid escalating US “imperialist” military pressure—including deployment of 15,000 troops, naval blockades, oil tanker seizures and airstrikes. Civil society groups called the gesture “selective,” noting at least 900 political detainees remain, most under conditional release terms. Notable opposition figures and the first juvenile terrorism convict, 17-year-old Gabriel Rodríguez Méndez, were not among those freed.

articles.title: Southern separatists in Yemen report Saudi airstrikes near positions
articles.trailText: Alleged strikes close to UAE-backed forces follow Riyadh’s call for STC to withdraw from newly seized provinces
articles.summary: UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) forces seized the oil-rich Hadramaut and al-Mahra provinces in southern Yemen with minimal resistance. After Riyadh urged the STC to withdraw, the STC reported Saudi warning airstrikes near its Wadi Nahab positions following ambushes that killed two. The UN-recognized Yemeni government, backed by Saudi Arabia and Arab and European states, decries STC "unilateralism" and pleads for Yemeni unity, while the STC argues an independent south is key to countering Iran-aligned Houthis. Aden protests called for secession. Riyadh’s firm calls for talks risk a Saudi–UAE rift over future support.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Deep freeze grips Canada as US records warmest Christmas
articles.trailText: Temperatures plunge below -50C in the Yukon, while swaths of US experience springlike weather
articles.summary: Northern Canada has endured a deep freeze with temperatures from -20C to -40C for weeks. Braeburn, Yukon plunged to -55.7C (coldest December since 1975), Mayo to -50.4C after 16 nights below -40C, and Whitehorse saw repeated nights under -30C. Southern regions like Edmonton fell below -28C on Christmas and face Boxing Day lows near -20C amid grid-strain warnings. The entrenched polar vortex is expected to retreat, letting Pacific air in. In contrast, a heat-dome ridge drove record-breaking Christmas highs (25C in Oklahoma City; 25C+ in Austin, Dallas, Charlotte) across the US.

articles.title: A child is born: Italians celebrate village’s first baby in 30 years
articles.trailText: Feted birth of bambina Lara in Pagliara dei Marsi highlights sticky national debate over country’s ‘demographic winter’
articles.summary: In Pagliara dei Marsi, Abruzzo, nine-month-old Lara Bussi Trabucco became the first baby born in almost 30 years, raising the hamlet’s 20-strong population and drawing tourists. Her arrival spotlights Italy’s demographic winter: 2024 saw a record low 369,944 births, a 1.18 fertility rate and a 10.2% birth decline in Abruzzo. Parents received a €1,000 baby bonus and €370 monthly, but face childcare shortages and school closures. Nearby Sulmona’s maternity unit struggles to meet the 500-birth threshold for funding. Locals urge systemic reform beyond financial incentives to sustain rural communities.

articles.title: ‘All brakes are off’: Russia’s attempt to rein in illicit market for leaked data backfires
articles.trailText: Russian state has tolerated parallel probiv market for its convenience but now Ukrainian spies are exploiting it
articles.summary: Russia’s decade-old probiv market—a black-market network of corrupt officials, traffic police and insiders selling personal data for as little as $10—has long served journalists, police and criminals. As the Ukraine war raged, Ukrainian intelligence and phone scam syndicates exploited leaked passports, call metadata and travel logs. In response, Putin enacted stiffer penalties (up to 10 years in prison) and security services arrested key brokers. But probes have backfired: major services relocated abroad, axed security ties and unleashed massive leaks like the FSB’s Kordon-2023 and the Alfa Bank trove, while pro-Ukrainian hackers dump data openly.

articles.title: Friday briefing: The answers to our quiz are in – how much of 2025 did you remember?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: From the right number of French prime ministers to the pasttimes of Archie Bland’s dog – here are answers to our inaugural Christmas Day quiz.
articles.summary: Guardian’s Friday briefing presents answers to its Christmas Day First Edition quiz, recapping 2025 milestones across global politics, tech, culture and science. It confirms DeepSeek as January’s viral Chinese AI app, Donald Trump as the most featured avatar, Friedrich Merz’s CDU chancellorship in Germany and Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment in South Korea. Topics include France’s record seven prime ministers under Macron, a 43-day US shutdown, Trump-Musk spat, Angela Rayner’s stamp duty exit, Zack Polanski’s Green leadership, NASA’s Artemis moon programme, a 26% Antarctic ice deficit, Black History Month in October, Taylor Swift’s The Life of a Showgirl album and Archie Bland’s dog Quincy getting stoned.

articles.title: Japan’s cabinet approves record defence budget amid escalating China tensions
articles.trailText: Japanese strike-back capabilities and coastal defences to be boosted while Beijing accuses Tokyo of fuelling a ‘space arms race’
articles.summary: Japan’s cabinet approved a record ¥9tn defence budget, up 9.4%, part of a five-year plan to reach 2% of GDP. Funds target strike-back capability, coastal defences via surface-to-ship missiles; allocates ¥100bn for unmanned air, sea & underwater drones under “Shield” system by 2028. Budget rise follows PM Takaichi’s vow to defend Taiwan if attacked, triggering Beijing’s diplomatic and economic reprisals. China condemned Japan’s US-backed space launches as fuelling a space arms race. Tokyo cites constitutional updates and US cooperation as deterrent to Chinese military pressure.

articles.title: ‘Keeps your mind alert’: older Swedes reap the benefits of learning for pleasure
articles.trailText: Retirees with ‘fantastic hunger for education’ taking part in university organised events in record numbers
articles.summary: Swedish retirees are joining Senioruniversitet—an adult-education network run by and for pensioners—with record membership and turnout: 2,099 events hosting 161,932 participants in 2023, rising to a projected 2,391 events and 177,024 attendees in 2025. Its 30 branches deliver study circles, lectures and courses across languages, politics, medicine and culture; Stockholm’s Tuesday lectures draw 1,000 weekly. Volunteers organize talks on topics from Nobel prizes to AI disinformation. Participants cite reduced loneliness, cognitive stimulation and civic engagement. Funding has fallen even as appetite for learning-for-pleasure surges. Organizers aim to diversify an increasingly homogenous membership.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv hits Russian oil refinery with British Storm Shadow missiles
articles.trailText: Ukrainian military says ‘numerous explosions’ at Novoshakhtinsk refinery; Zelenskyy says ‘very good’ talks held with Trump envoys. What we know on day 1,402
articles.summary: Ukraine struck the Novoshakhtinsk oil refinery in southern Russia with UK Storm Shadow missiles, causing “numerous explosions” at a key fuel supplier to Russian forces. President Zelenskyy said he’d had “very good” talks with Trump envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner on new peace‐plan formats, timelines and limited US-led concessions. In Russia, opposition figure Sergei Udaltsov received six years for “justifying terrorism”, French scholar Laurent Vinatier faces fresh espionage charges amid a Moscow-Paris exchange offer, and Russia-installed authorities ready to reopen Mariupol’s drama theatre amid mass exiles and property seizures.

articles.title: ‘Not for the people’: Myanmar junta prepares for elections designed to legitimise grip on power
articles.trailText: Elections will be first since military seized power in 2021, but analysts say vote is far from a step toward democracy
articles.summary: Myanmar’s military junta is staging its first polls since seizing power in 2021 to validate its rule, despite Aung San Suu Kyi’s imprisonment, the dissolution of the NLD and dozens of ethnic parties, and the exclusion of about a third of townships and wards under rebel control. With six nationwide parties—mostly junta-backed—on a ballot of 57, critics label the vote a sham enforced by new laws criminalizing dissent. Conflict has intensified: air and drone strikes rose 30% and abductions 26% year-on-year; many young people have fled conscription. China backs the election while Western governments and the UN reject it.

articles.title: Handwritten letters are still a powerful force for good | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Frankie Meehan on the decline of letter writing and Amnesty International’s annual Write for Rights campaign
articles.summary: In a letter to The Guardian, Frankie Meehan argues that handwritten letters remain a potent tool, pointing to Amnesty International’s annual Write for Rights campaign, which produced 4.7 million handwritten appeals to human rights defenders and oppressors last year. Meehan emphasizes that the time, effort and physicality of a real letter carry more weight with decision-makers than digital clicks, while recipients feel uplifted by personalised messages of solidarity, making letter-writing an enduring force for good.

articles.title: Letter: Ros Howells obituary
articles.trailText: Richard Bourne writes: Ros helped us negotiate the trickier moments with calm diplomacy and Caribbean understanding.
articles.summary: Ros Howells (later Lady Howells of St Davids) chaired the British Caribbean representatives’ committee at Kensington’s Commonwealth Institute in 1986 for the year-long Caribbean Focus programme. She coordinated 50 Caribbean communities nationwide to mount a touring art and education exhibit across 21 railway stations, established a Caribbean Music Village in Holland Park, launched a pan-Caribbean Theatre Company and a literary conference. Throughout the initiative she navigated complex logistical and cultural challenges with calm diplomacy and deep Caribbean insight, earning lasting admiration and friendship.

articles.title: British campaigner launches legal challenge against Trump administration after deportation threat
articles.trailText: Imran Ahmed, an anti-disinformation advocate, claims he is being targeted for scrutinising social media companies
articles.summary: British anti-disinformation campaigner Imran Ahmed, CEO of the Centre for Countering Digital Hate, has sued Secretary of State Marco Rubio and AG Pam Bondi in the Southern District of New York after the US state department threatened to deport him. Ahmed, who lives in Washington, DC with his American wife and daughter, argues this targeting of his scrutiny of platforms like Elon Musk’s X violates his First Amendment rights and lacks any credible basis. A judge has granted a temporary restraining order against his detention pending further court proceedings.

articles.title: Divine messengers: Italian nuns’ social media posts go viral
articles.trailText: Revelation of Instagram spurs retired Catholic devotees in Abruzzo to gain millions of views with upbeat videos
articles.summary: In Raiano, Abruzzo, 22 retired nuns from the Ravasco congregation—led by spirited 98-year-old Sister Maria Chiara and driven by 45-year-old Sister Nayiby Jimenez—have amassed over 145,000 followers on Facebook, Instagram and Threads since July. Their upbeat 5am videos blend daily routines, humor and spiritual guidance—from tossing boxes labeled “anxiety” to light exercise before prayer—spark thousands of comments and personal prayer requests, each recorded in books, giving the sisters renewed purpose and digital outreach.

articles.title: Israeli police arrest Palestinian man dressed as Santa Claus at Christmas party
articles.trailText: Officers closed Christmas event in Haifa, confiscating equipment and also arresting a DJ and a street vendor
articles.summary: Israeli police raided a Christmas party in Haifa on Dec. 25, confiscating equipment and arresting a Palestinian Santa Claus performer, a DJ and a street vendor. Video shows officers forcefully pushing and handcuffing the trio; police say the Santa resisted and assaulted an officer, while the Mossawa Center alleges excessive force and an illegal raid. The arrests coincided with Christmas celebrations in the occupied West Bank and Gaza—Bethlehem’s first since the Gaza war began, and a small Christian service amid ruins in Gaza under a shaky ceasefire. Pope Leo’s Christmas address condemned Gaza’s humanitarian crisis and rising attacks on Christians.

articles.title: ‘It’s the wildest place I have walked’: new national park will join up Chile’s 2,800km wildlife corridor
articles.trailText: Government poised to officially protect 200,000 hectares of remote Patagonian coastline and forest
articles.summary: Chile's government is set to establish its 47th national park at Cape Froward, safeguarding nearly 200,000 hectares of remote Patagonian coastline and forest and completing a 2,800 km wildlife corridor to Tierra del Fuego. The park hosts endangered huemul deer, pumas, huillin otters and 10,000 hectares of carbon-rich sphagnum bogs. Assembled over a decade by Tompkins Conservation and Rewilding Chile, it intertwines biodiversity protection with Kawesqar Indigenous heritage, from archaeological shoreline fish traps to the restored San Isidro lighthouse museum. After a stalled Indigenous consultation, Chile's environment ministry targets formal designation by March to secure this ecological mosaic against reversion.

articles.title: Immigration debate ‘dividing us’, incoming archbishop of Canterbury warns in Christmas sermon
articles.trailText: Sarah Mullally says ‘national conversations … continue to divide us, when our common humanity should unite us’
articles.summary: Incoming archbishop of Canterbury Dame Sarah Mullally used her Christmas Day sermon at St Paul’s Cathedral to warn that national immigration debates fracture society and urged Christians to practice joy as resistance by making room in homes, churches and conversations. She highlighted economic pressures, inequality and societal fear of strangers. Archbishop of York Stephen Cottrell echoed calls for unity, recalling walls and checkpoints in the Holy Land and warning against building barriers in hearts. Mullally’s confirmation is set for January ahead of her March enthronement.

articles.title: ‘Dancing on bones’: Mariupol theatre to reopen with staging of Russian fairytale
articles.trailText: Restoration presented as rebuilding, but many see it as part of a broader Russification effort in occupied Ukrainian city
articles.summary: Mariupol Drama Theatre, destroyed by a 2022 Russian airstrike that killed civilians sheltering inside, is due to reopen under occupation authorities with a Russian fairytale, The Scarlet Flower. Moscow touts the rebuild as cultural renewal and Russification, while exiled former actors call it 'dancing on bones' and stage their own memorial play, Mariupol Drama, in Europe. At least a dozen deaths are confirmed—independent probes and Amnesty International deem the strike a likely war crime. Thousands of Ukrainians have had homes seized under a decree labeling unclaimed properties 'ownerless' and requiring Russian citizenship for compensation.

articles.title: Dordogne murder mystery: British woman’s death confounds detectives
articles.trailText: Brutal stabbing of Karen Carter, 65, in France has been followed by talk of affairs and speculation over the culprit
articles.summary: Karen Carter, a 65-year-old British-South African who ran two gîtes at Les Chouettes in Trémolat, was found fatally stabbed eight times outside her farmhouse on April 29. Discovered by companion Jean-François Guerrier after a village wine-tasting at Café Village Trémolat, an autopsy cited severe blood loss. A 69-year-old attendee was briefly detained and released without charge. Husband Alan Carter, in South Africa, has expressed shock over reports of his wife’s alleged affair. Eight months on, detectives have excluded local DNA samples, are probing robbery or personal-grudge motives, and have renewed appeals for witnesses.

articles.title: Falling price of cocaine forces drug traffickers to reuse narco-submarines, say Spanish police
articles.trailText: Previously vessels would be sunk once they had completed their cargo runs from South America to Europe
articles.summary: Spanish police report that plunging wholesale cocaine prices—now about €15,000 per kilo, half the price of a few years ago—have made the €600,000 semi-submersible “narco-subs” economically worth reusing instead of sinking after one-way South America–Europe runs. Authorities logged 10 narco-subs since 2006 and seized 123 tonnes of cocaine in 2024. Meanwhile, Spain’s synthetic drugs unit dismantled 11 large amphetamine, methamphetamine and MDMA labs in 2023–24, reflecting a shift from the Netherlands to rural Spain, France and Germany as gangs scale production with local labor, waste disposal and drone surveillance.

articles.title: Ukrainian refugee leaves UK sixth-form college that urged her ‘to study Russian’
articles.trailText: Kateryna Endeberia says teachers made the ‘hurtful’ request when she had difficulty with other subjects
articles.summary: Kateryna Endeberia, a 19-year-old Ukrainian refugee in Stoke-on-Trent, withdrew from City of Stoke-on-Trent Sixth Form College after teachers, finding her struggling in A-level economics, politics and statistics, urged her to study Russian—a language she rejects due to her father’s role as a soldier and the war’s trauma. She now studies at home, plans private A-level exams in 2026 at her own expense, and is pursuing a complaint through the Potteries Educational Trust with plans to escalate to Ofsted. The college cites confidentiality; meanwhile Ukraine’s education ministry and exam board AQA discuss introducing a GCSE in Ukrainian.

articles.title: Hundreds of thousands newly displaced as Islamic State insurgency expands in Mozambique
articles.trailText: Rising numbers of people flee jihadists, as violence against civilians increases and foreign aid dwindles
articles.summary: Since July 2025, over 300,000 people—part of more than one million displaced since 2017—have fled an expanding Islamic State affiliate in northern Mozambique, now pushing into Nampula. Despite a 1,000-strong Rwandan deployment now totaling 4,000–5,000 troops alongside Mozambican forces, violence persists: Acled records 302 attacks and 549 deaths this year, 56% more civilian fatalities than 2024. Militants abduct children for forced labour, marriage or combat. The government’s priority appears to be securing Total’s $20bn LNG project, while humanitarian funding meets only 55% of needs, leaving families in dire conditions and dialogue efforts stalled.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: A short quiz on a very long year – how many questions can you answer about 2025?
articles.trailText: Welcome to the newsletter’s first end-of-year quiz. Test yourself on culture, technology and assorted political chaos – and check back on 26 December to see how you fared
articles.summary: The Guardian’s First Edition Christmas newsletter launches a 28-question end-of-year quiz covering key 2025 moments: the US popularity of a Chinese AI app; leadership shifts from Germany’s Friedrich Merz to France’s rapid PM turnover; UK upheavals from Nigel Farage spats to HS2 debates and tight by-elections; global events like the US government shutdown, South Korea’s impeached president, the resurgent space race via NASA’s Artemis; environmental stats on Antarctic ice; culture rounds on Taylor Swift’s album; plus figures from Zelenskiy, Trump, Musk, Liz Truss and even Archie Bland’s dog. Answers follow on 26 December.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy open to creating demilitarised zone in country’s east
articles.trailText: The proposal pushes Washington and Kyiv closer to a jointly agreed formula to end the war. What we know on day 1,401
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy has proposed withdrawing Ukrainian troops from parts of the eastern Donbas to establish an international demilitarised zone if Russia similarly retreats, marking a compromise that aligns US and Kyiv peace filings and revises a US draft seen as Kremlin-friendly. US negotiators are expected to engage the Kremlin imminently. A Russian poll found 70% of citizens anticipate the war ending in 2026, signalling public openness to settlement. Russian air strikes on Odesa caused a sunflower oil spill and wildlife fatalities, prompting a port closure, while Russian defenses shot down 25 drones near Moscow.

articles.title: No pain, no game: how South Korea turned itself into a gaming powerhouse
articles.trailText: Gaming was once compared to drugs, gambling and alcohol in South Korea. Now its gaming academies offer a chance to earn a six-figure salary – if you make the grade
articles.summary: Son Si-woo (Lehends) went from banned gamer to League of Legends champion as South Korea rebranded gaming from addiction to strategic industry. After broadband-led PC bangs and early StarCraft leagues, the domestic market swelled 47% (2019–23) to ₩23tn, exports hit ₩11tn and esports grew to ₩257bn. Academies like Nongshim train hopefuls (500k₩/20h) but yield 1–2% pros who earn six-figure salaries. Government now caps youth training hours and funds healing centres for balance.

articles.title: Trump-backed candidate Asfura declared new president of Honduras
articles.trailText: Winning margin of 28,000 votes announced a month late but before review of all ‘inconsistent’ ballots was completed
articles.summary: Donald Trump-backed Nasry “Tito” Asfura was declared winner of Honduras’s contested presidential vote with 40.27% vs 39.53% for rival Salvador Nasralla, a 28,000-vote margin announced before completing a special scrutiny of inconsistent ballots. The electoral council’s split 2-1 decision—mirroring party alignments including a boycott by the leftist president’s councillor—triggered fraud allegations from Nasralla and criticism from the OAS and ruling Libre party. US interference debates flared after Trump’s pre-election endorsement and pardon of former president Juan Orlando Hernández. A legal challenge looms.

articles.title: UK, Canada and Germany condemn Israel for 19 new West Bank settlements
articles.trailText: Fourteen countries, also including France, Italy, Ireland and Spain, say actions ‘violate international law and risk fuelling instability’
articles.summary: Fourteen countries—including the UK, Canada, Germany, France, Italy, Ireland, Spain, Japan, Norway and others—condemned Israel’s security cabinet approval of 19 new West Bank settlements, including two sites evacuated under the 2005 disengagement, raising this government’s tally to 69 and national total to 210.
