The joint statement warned that unilateral expansion breaches international law (UNSCR 2334), undermines Gaza reconstruction, risks fuelling instability and harms prospects for a negotiated two-state solution within secure borders. Israel’s FM Gideon Sa’ar defended the decision as vital for national security and denounced external limits on Jewish settlement as discriminatory.

articles.title: Three killed in Moscow car explosion, say Russian authorities
articles.trailText: Anonymous official from Ukraine’s GUR military intelligence says the agency carried out the attack
articles.summary: An explosive device detonated on Yeletskaya Street in Moscow at about 1:30 am, killing two traffic police officers—Lt Ilya Klimanov, 24, and Lt Maxim Gorbunov, 25—and a suspected bomber. Investigators have cordoned off the scene and are reviewing CCTV footage. Russian Telegram channels reported the third victim was planting the device, while an anonymous Ukrainian GUR source told AP the attack was a Ukrainian intelligence operation. The blast occurred under half a mile from where Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov was killed by a car bomb days earlier, an incident also blamed on Kyiv and prompting calls for retribution.

articles.title: Israel strikes southern Lebanon as deadline to disarm Hezbollah nears
articles.trailText: Strikes were latest violation of year-long ceasefire and targeted what Israel said were Hezbollah sites
articles.summary: Israel carried out airstrikes on Hezbollah infrastructure in southern Lebanon’s Nabatieh valleys (Houmin, Wadi Azza, Nimeiriya), breaching a year-old ceasefire. According to ACLED, Israel averages one bombing every four hours since December 2024. With a US-backed plan, Lebanon’s army must clear Hezbollah south of the Litani River by year’s end; Beirut says it’s nearly done, but Jerusalem accuses Hezbollah of rearming. A recent drone strike killed three men—Israel claims one was a Hezbollah-affiliated officer. Negotiations in Naqoura resume over the ceasefire, with civilian reps. Defence Minister Israel Katz has vowed to disarm Hezbollah to guarantee Israel’s security.

articles.title: US and Ukraine edge closer to joint plan to end war – with Moscow’s response uncertain
articles.trailText: Ukraine accepts principle of demilitarised zone in east, while insisting Russia make similar concessions in pulling back forces
articles.summary: Washington and Kyiv have drafted a streamlined peace formula requiring mutual troop withdrawals and creation of a demilitarised zone along the eastern contact line, with Ukraine relinquishing its NATO membership bid in exchange for US-European security guarantees akin to Article 5. Zelenskyy secured revisions to an earlier US proposal, sent the plan to Putin via envoy Dmitriev and awaits Moscow’s response. It calls for Russian pullbacks from Dnipropetrovsk, Mykolaiv, Sumy and Kharkiv, international monitors, and a referendum in Ukraine on free-trade economic zones. Russia’s acceptance, especially on buffer zones and nuclear plant control, is uncertain.

articles.title: Ukraine’s best hope may lie elsewhere as Russia inches forward on the battlefield
articles.trailText: While it struggles to hold up land advance, Kyiv eyes economic and political fronts to turn around fortunes
articles.summary: Ukraine’s €90 billion EU loan secures its defence until 2027 but won’t reverse a grinding land war in which Russia advances 176 sq miles monthly at a cost of 382,000 casualties. Repeated Russian penetrations east of Dobropillia, Kupiansk and Huliaipole underscore Kyiv’s infantry shortfall despite potent drone defences. Critics urge a shift to ‘dynamic defence’ and rebuilding reserves rather than counterattacks like last year’s Kursk incursion. Economically, Ukraine targets Russian oil infrastructure and shadow tankers to hobble Kremlin finances. Politically, US donor support hinges on Washington’s stance—especially under Trump—and midterm election outcomes. Kyiv’s best hope: hold a near stalemate and wait for diplomatic or domestic shifts in Moscow or Washington.

articles.title: British boy stabbed to death in Portugal allegedly by ex-partner of his mother
articles.trailText: Tributes paid to Alfie Hallett, 13, as police say suspect also died in incident believed to be domestic violence related
articles.summary: Thirteen-year-old Alfie Hallett, a British boy living in Casais near Tomar, Portugal, was fatally stabbed in his home by his mother's ex-partner, who then stabbed himself and triggered a gas explosion. GNR officers found Alfie, the assailant and Alfie’s mother—who showed signs of restraint—injured; a blast later wounded one officer. The perpetrator had been jailed for aggravated homicide and faced 2022–23 domestic violence complaints. Alfie’s local basketball club paid tribute online. The Foreign Office is liaising with Portuguese authorities to provide consular support.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: What your Christmas cranberries reveal about the climate crisis
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Extreme weather and fragile supply chains are pushing up food costs – and raising fears of instability
articles.summary: Rising costs of Christmas staples—from turkeys to cranberries—reflect a climate-driven squeeze on supply. Guardian scientist Sarah Bridle traces cranberry’s path: 25% price jumps follow supermarket pricing wars and global supply fragility, while heatwaves and water stress threaten yields. UK wheat output fell 20% in 2023–24 after record rainfall, driving up bread prices and stoking inflation. A survey of 58 experts warns 80% foresee civil unrest over future food crises. Bridle calls for policy reforms: resilient distribution, climate-impact labelling and waste reduction to secure Britain’s food supply.

articles.title: In Berlin, I took an evening class on fascism – and found out how to stop the AfD | Tania Roettger
articles.trailText: With the far-right party ahead in the polls, I discovered that a novel set during the rise of the Nazis provides a timely warning, says journalist Tania Roettger
articles.summary: Tania Roettger attends a Berlin seminar on fascism—defining it by ethnic purity, paramilitary violence, anti-democratic aims and elite backers—to assess the AfD, now polling 26% and labelled “right-wing extremist.” She warns Germany’s political “firewall” is crumbling as CDU leader Friedrich Merz secures AfD support on migration policy. Reading Gabriele Tergit’s rediscovered 1930s novel The Effingers reveals eerie parallels of affluent citizens insulated from looming terror. Roettger argues that solidarity protests and legal bans alone won’t suffice; historical vigilance and multi-front resistance are vital.

articles.title: ‘Warning to others’: murky death of militia leader as Kremlin reasserts control
articles.trailText: Reports that Stanislav Orlov was killed by Moscow security services highlights careful managing of non-state power
articles.summary: Stanislav Orlov, ‘Spaniard’, the far-right founder of the Española neo-Nazi volunteer unit in Ukraine, was ambushed and shot at his Crimea home by presumed Moscow security agents—CCTV released by exiled outlet Astra shows armed servicemen arriving before gunshots. His funeral at Moscow’s Cathedral of Christ the Saviour, with no official cause cited, underscores the Kremlin’s post-Wagner mutiny campaign to rein in autonomous ultranationalist formations and send a warning to unruly paramilitaries.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Pope Leo expresses ‘great sadness’ at Russian rejection of truce calls
articles.trailText: Pontiff calls for ‘day of peace’ on Christmas Day; two Moscow police injured in suspected explosion near site of general’s killing. What we know on day 1,400
articles.summary: On day 1,400 of the Ukraine war, Pope Leo XIV renewed his plea for a Christmas Day truce, lamenting Russia’s apparent refusal, and called for 24 hours of global peace. In Moscow, two traffic officers were injured in an explosion near the site of Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov’s car bombing. Ukraine faced a massive Russian drone and missile strike that killed at least three, while Poland scrambled jets. Kyiv withdrew forces from Siversk after heavy fighting. Talks in Miami produced draft peace outlines, and Ukraine warned of collapse risks at Chernobyl’s radiation shelter if struck.

articles.title: Rare footage from trial of Chinese general who defied Tiananmen crackdown order leaked online
articles.trailText: Video shows Gen Xu Qinxian explaining why he refused to deploy troops to crush 1989 student-led demonstrations
articles.summary: Leaked online for the first time, a six-hour court martial recording reveals PLA General Xu Qinxian’s defiance of orders to deploy the 38th Group Army into Beijing during the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown. Xu, later expelled and jailed for five years, argues martial law is a ��mass political incident” requiring political resolution, warning that violent force would render commanders “sinners in history.” Provided anonymously to historian Wu Renhua, the footage—viewed over 1.2m times—offers an unprecedented first-person military perspective on internal dissent at China’s most sensitive political moment and underscores ongoing CCP concerns about PLA loyalty.

articles.title: After more than a decade of tragedy, Christchurch emerges as New Zealand’s most ‘vibrant city’
articles.trailText: Christchurch now at the centre of the country’s fastest-growing region as lower house prices, job prospects and thriving cultural scene entice people to the city
articles.summary: After a decade of earthquakes, wildfires and the 2019 mosque shootings, Christchurch has transformed into New Zealand’s fastest-growing and “most vibrant” city. With a top ranking on the 2024 Happy City Index, affordability (average house NZ$751k vs NZ$1.2m in Auckland), a net migration gain of 5,300 and 2.4% business growth, it’s attracting newcomers to booming sectors from health tech to the arts. Revitalized CBD features street art, new public buildings and a NZ$683m stadium due in 2026. Residents and leaders credit resilience and community spirit for this cultural, commercial and urban renewal.

articles.title: Myanmar’s first election since the 2021 coup: everything you need to know
articles.trailText: The ruling junta says the heavily restricted polls are a return to democracy but critics are wary
articles.summary: Myanmar’s junta is staging its first national election since the 2021 coup, with voting across 100 townships from 28 December, a second phase on 11 January and a third phase pending. The NLD and dozens of ethnic parties were banned, leaving 57 largely military-allied parties and uncontested seats for the junta-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party. Polls exclude conflict zones, and draconian laws have jailed over 200 dissenters. China backs the vote, while Western governments and the UN label it a sham amid civil war. Aung San Suu Kyi remains detained under a 27-year sentence, her party absent.

articles.title: Gibraltar’s chief minister made ‘sinister’ interventions to protect friend from police
articles.trailText: Inquiry finds Fabian Picardo was ‘grossly improper’ to protect James Levy from a search warrant
articles.summary: Sir Peter Openshaw’s inquiry concluded that Gibraltar chief minister Fabian Picardo made grossly improper and sinister interventions to shield friend and business partner James Levy KC—a senior Hassans partner—during a police raid under a warrant for alleged hacking and security contract fraud. Picardo summoned and berated police commissioner Ian McGrail, shared confidential DPP advice and disciplinary rules to aid Levy. Although Levy was never charged and effectively exonerated, Openshaw found Picardo put personal ties above official duties. McGrail’s subsequent retirement stemmed from undue political pressure rather than performance failings.

articles.title: Russian attacks kill three and cut power to freezing Ukrainian regions
articles.trailText: Four-year-old child among those killed in drone and missile assault targeting energy infrastructure
articles.summary: On 23 December, Russia launched a large-scale drone and missile barrage—over 650 drones and 30 missiles—killing three, including a four-year-old, and cutting power to three western Ukrainian regions as freezing winter weather sets in. President Zelenskyy denounced the Christmas-timed strike, which comes amid Miami-based peace talks led by US envoys. Kyiv meanwhile hit a petrochemical plant in Russia’s Stavropol region. Negotiations have produced draft documents on security guarantees and reconstruction but stall over territorial concessions. Energy operator Ukrenergo called this the ninth mass energy attack of the season. Temperatures in Kyiv drop to –5 °C, exacerbating outages.

articles.title: Bolsonaro supporters ‘cancel’ Havaianas flip-flop brand over television ad
articles.trailText: Son of jailed former Brazilian president says spokesperson for ‘national symbol’ sandals is ‘openly left wing’
articles.summary: Brazil’s jailed former president Jair Bolsonaro’s supporters, led by his son Eduardo, launched a boycott of flip-flop maker Havaianas after an ad featuring Oscar-winning actor Fernanda Torres joked about starting “with both feet” instead of “on the right foot.” Eduardo Bolsonaro filmed himself discarding the sandals as “betrayal” of a national symbol and warned Havaianas to heed marketing lessons from the Bud Light backlash. The first day of the boycott reportedly wiped £20 million from the brand’s market value. Havaianas and Torres have yet to comment. Left-wing critics offered sandal donations and ankle-tag swaps in mockery.

articles.title: Sydney’s queer bookstore ‘haven’ to close after 43 years: ‘This has never been about just selling books’
articles.trailText: The Bookshop Darlinghurst has stood firm through the decades as laws and attitudes towards LGBTQI people have changed dramatically. Today it shuts its doors for good
articles.summary: The Bookshop Darlinghurst, Australia’s oldest queer bookstore founded in 1982, closes after 43 years on Christmas Eve amid financial pressures and delayed redevelopment. Owner Charles Gregory and long-time bookseller Noel Lee have welcomed generations—from closeted teens to elder patrons—offering literature, community support and intergenerational connections through eras of decriminalisation, the AIDS crisis and same-sex marriage. Customers like 78-year-old Reino Okkonen and writer Marc Linke recall life-saving solace and serendipitous encounters. Its final days mark the loss of a vital cultural haven that transcended mere book sales to nurture LGBTQI identity and solidarity.

articles.title: Canada bill targeting refugees feared to signal new era of US-style border policy
articles.trailText: Bill C-12 includes many changes around border security along with new ineligibility rules for refugee claimants
articles.summary: Bill C-12, Strengthening Canada’s Immigration System and Borders Act, passed the House introducing US-style restrictions on refugee claims: asylum applications filed more than one year after arrival or at the US land border beyond 14 days are diverted from the Immigration and Refugee Board to single-officer pre-removal risk assessments with high rejection rates. It expands executive power over document control and inter-agency data sharing, enacted as deportations hit 18,000 in 2024 at a cost of $78m. Critics warn it fuels xenophobia, scapegoats migrants, undermines safe third country obligations, and erodes Canada’s refugee protections.

articles.title: Biography aims to fill gaps in story of ultra-libertarian Telegram founder Pavel Durov
articles.trailText: Like many of his US counterparts, the Russian science prodigy turned hugely successful ‘digital populist’ has a deep suspicion of government constraint
articles.summary: The Populist, by Nikolay Kononov, traces 41-year-old Pavel Durov’s journey from St Petersburg science prodigy and VKontakte founder to the ultra-libertarian ‘digital populist’ behind Telegram’s billion-plus users. Based on 14 years of interviews, it exposes his tactic of direct in-app broadcasts to bypass institutions, near-absolute free-speech ethos alongside centralized, single-man control, Kremlin clashes leading to his 2014 Dubai exile, a startling 2024 French detention that deepened his anti-Western conspiracy leanings, an obsession with longevity and pronatalism, and pragmatic compromises—yet no evidence of FSB collusion.

articles.title: The second China shock is coming – and the UK’s response is too timid | George Magnus
articles.trailText: Beijing’s push to dominate technology through state-backed industrial policy is reshaping global trade and could devastate European industry
articles.summary: Beijing’s new 15th five-year plan intensifies state-directed industrial policy to dominate advanced tech—EVs, batteries, semiconductors, biotech, robotics and AI—risking overproduction, deflationary pressures and a $1 trillion goods surplus that threatens European and UK manufacturing. Despite weak domestic demand, China prioritises industrial output over consumption, underpinned by an undervalued yuan. The EU has imposed EV tariffs and a surveillance mechanism; the UK’s measures remain limited to joint steel policy with the EU and empowering its Trade Remedies Authority. Starmer’s planned China visit must confront the realities of this “second China shock,” not downplay its threat.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What would a Reform-led country look like?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Local government may offer some answers – after winning 677 council seats, Reform’s triumph quickly gave way to reports of chaos, infighting, and scandal
articles.summary: Reform UK has surged to 677 council seats and 10 councils since 2021, reshaping British politics and positioning Nigel Farage for No 10. Yet local administrations—from Cornwall’s resignations to Kent’s defections—have been marred by infighting, funding shortfalls and broken promises. In Warwickshire, 19-year-old leader George Finch faces underfunded budgets, backlash over school transport cuts and a Pride-flag row. Green councillor Sam Jones warns of symbolic victories over real reform, arguing that national power would encounter the same chaos and bureaucracy Reform pledges to dismantle. Reform’s leadership has admitted it cannot fund its £90 bn tax cuts, while its disciplined national machine contrasts with inexperienced grassroots councillors. Jones urges the left to offer positive alternatives before Reform’s chaos scales up to Westminster.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian forces attack Odesa twice in one day
articles.trailText: Emergency crews at work after port facilities and ship damaged, governor says, while Donald Trump says peace talks going ‘OK’. What we know on day 1,399
articles.summary: Russian forces struck Odesa twice in 24 hours, damaging port facilities and a ship and cutting electricity for tens of thousands; no casualties reported, regional governor says. Kyiv calls the attacks efforts to disrupt maritime logistics amid widespread power outages. In Moscow, Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov died in a car-bomb explosion blamed on Ukrainian services. Donald Trump described US-led Ukraine peace talks in Florida as “OK”; Zelenskiy welcomed draft proposals, warning neither side will get everything. The Kremlin dismissed Miami talks as routine. Separately, 52 residents of Hrabovske were taken prisoner; Kyiv battles Russian advances in the Sumy border area.

articles.title: Russia and China pledge support for Venezuela as Trump ratchets up pressure on Maduro
articles.trailText: Trump again called for Venezuela’s president to leave power and said the US would keep or sell the oil it had seized
articles.summary: China and Russia backed Venezuela against a US blockade on sanctioned oil tankers as President Trump ramped up calls for Nicolás Maduro’s ouster and threatened to keep or sell seized oil. Port loadings have slowed, stranding millions of barrels amid discount demands. China condemned US interceptions as illegal and defended Venezuela’s trading rights; Russia decried Washington’s Caribbean actions as “escalatory” and reaffirmed solidarity with Maduro. Caracas branded the US “piratical” while Trump justified strikes on alleged drug-trafficking vessels, prompting Venezuelan retaliation.

articles.title: ‘Is this real?’: wife of detained pastor describes anguish as China cracks down on unofficial churches
articles.trailText: Church leaders and members detained as government tightens controls on underground Christian gatherings
articles.summary: In October, plain-clothed officers detained Gao Yingjia of Beijing’s Zion Church, founder Jin Mingri and over a dozen other underground pastors, charging them with “illegal use of information networks” in China’s largest Christian crackdown since 2018. Human Rights in China reports more than 100 worshippers swept up in Wenzhou raids after disputes over national flags. New regulations bar unlicensed gatherings and online sermons under Xi Jinping’s Sinicization campaign. The US condemned the detentions, but analysts warn unofficial house churches face existential threat.

articles.title: Fiji wrestles with plans to restore Indigenous rights over world-famous surf breaks
articles.trailText: Move to bring back customary marine rights is celebrated, but concerns remain about potential effect on tourism and lack of clarity about how it might work
articles.summary: Fiji’s government has introduced a marine areas bill to restore customary marine rights (qoliqoli) to its Indigenous iTaukei people, enabling them to govern and profit from surf breaks like Cloudbreak and fishing grounds long dominated by foreign resorts. While hailed as a landmark move to address rural poverty and historical exclusion—ended by a 2010 decree—tourism operators warn of unclear lease processes, enforcement and potential higher costs for visitors. Experts say if well-structured, the law could empower iTaukei participation in Fiji’s vital tourism sector.

articles.title: Russian general killed by car bomb in Moscow, say investigators
articles.trailText: Russia’s Investigative Committee says it is looking into whether Ukraine intelligence services were behind attack
articles.summary: Russian investigators say Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov, head of combat training at Russia’s general staff, died after a bomb under his car exploded in Moscow, and are probing whether Ukrainian intelligence orchestrated the assassination. Sarvarov, a veteran of both Chechen wars and Syria intervention, is the third senior officer killed in Moscow this year. Kremlin figures have demanded swift retaliation, while Ukraine has neither confirmed nor denied involvement. The attack highlights apparent lapses in Russian security and comes amid US-Ukraine peace talks in Florida.

articles.title: Boiling lobsters alive to be banned in England amid animal cruelty crackdown
articles.trailText: Move is part of a long-awaited Labour strategy including outlawing hen cages and ending puppy farming
articles.summary: England will ban boiling lobsters alive under a new Labour animal welfare package that builds on a 2022 law recognising invertebrate sentience. Charities back pre-stunning with electric guns or chilling before slaughter. The wider strategy also outlaws hen cages, pig farrowing crates, puppy farming, electric shock collars, and mandates humane fish slaughter. Hunting reforms include banning hare shooting in the breeding season and ending trail hunting. Reform UK’s Nigel Farage condemned the measures as authoritarian, while polls show strong public support. The Green Party urges further action on greyhound racing. The ban applies to England only.

articles.title: Ecuador court sentences 11 air force troops over disappearance of four boys
articles.trailText: Long sentences in case of Afro-Ecuadorian ‘Guayaquil Four’ focuses attention on president’s crackdown on crime
articles.summary: Court in Ecuador sentenced 11 air force personnel to 34 years 8 months for the forced disappearance of four Afro-Ecuadorian boys (aged 11–15) known as the “Guayaquil Four” during patrols under President Daniel Noboa’s security crackdown. Five collaborators received 2½-year sentences; one was acquitted. Judges cited torture, racist insults, abandonment in a dangerous area, and execution by close-range gunshots before burning and dismemberment. Prosecutors pursue separate kidnapping-death charges. Defendants argue lack of rights-training for unprepared troops.

articles.title: France’s national post office hit by suspected cyber-attack
articles.trailText: La Poste’s websites, apps and banking service affected by a DDoS incident, which is also delaying postal deliveries
articles.summary: Three days before Christmas, La Poste – France’s national post office – and its banking arm La Banque Postale were struck by a suspected DDoS attack that rendered websites, mobile apps and online payment services inaccessible, delaying the sorting and delivery of over 2 million items ahead of the holidays. While customer data remains secure and in-store card payments, ATMs and authenticated online transfers via SMS function, users report last-minute parcel drop-offs blocked. No claim of responsibility has emerged, but the incident follows recent hacks on the interior ministry and private firms as France accuses Russia of hybrid cyber-warfare. Teams are working to restore full service swiftly.

articles.title: Collecting memories and stories of feminists | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Sue O’Sullivan and Miriam David on being part of the women’s liberation movement, in response to a long read by Susanna Rustin on the Sex Discrimination Act. Plus a letter from Paul F Faupel
articles.summary: Letters by Sue O’Sullivan and Miriam David, WLM veterans since the late 1960s, respond to Susanna Rustin’s long read on the Sex Discrimination Act, clarifying that the women’s liberation movement was an informal network of consciousness-raising conferences and grassroots activism, not a formal organisation. They warn that these struggles are fading from living memory and introduce Howl (History of Women’s Liberation), an online archive soliciting personal stories, photos and documents. Paul F Faupel adds a letter on WWII’s Air Transport Auxiliary under Pauline Gower, who pioneered equal pay and opportunities for women pilots but was sidelined postwar.

articles.title: You cannot annex other countries, Danish and Greenlandic leaders tell Trump
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen and Jens-Frederik Nielsen demand respect for borders after US appoints Greenland envoy
articles.summary: Denmark PM Mette Frederiksen and Greenland Premier Jens-Frederik Nielsen condemned President Trump’s appointment of Louisiana Governor Jeff Landry as US special envoy to Greenland as a thinly veiled bid to annex the territory. They and Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen, who summoned the US ambassador, insisted international law upholds sovereignty: “Greenland belongs to the Greenlanders.” EU chiefs Ursula von der Leyen and António Costa, along with Nordic allies Sweden and Norway, expressed solidarity. Polls show most Greenlanders seek independence, not US control, amid strategic Arctic rivalries.

articles.title: What is the status of Islamic State, the group linked to the Bondi attacks?
articles.trailText: Al-Qaida offshoot has lost 95% of the territory it gained in 2014 but remains a force to be reckoned with online
articles.summary: Police suspect Bondi attackers Naveed and Sajid Akram were inspired by IS, echoing its ideology via videos and visits to a Philippine IS affiliate. Islamic State (IS/Daesh) split from al-Qaida in Iraq, seized territory in 2014 to form a caliphate before losing 95% by 2017 and Baghdadi’s death in 2019. Only a few thousand fighters remain in Iraq/Syria, but IS wields global reach through online propaganda that spurs lone-wolf attacks. Its Salafi-jihadist doctrine targets Shia, security forces and minorities, espousing extreme antisemitism tied to apocalyptic narratives. IS rejects nation-states in favor of a global caliphate. The impact of Gaza protests on the Bondi plot’s radicalization remains unclear.

articles.title: Spanish villagers devastated by forest fire win €468m in lottery prizes
articles.trailText: Mayor of La Bañeza says winning El Gordo Christmas lottery ‘is something that has fallen from the heavens’
articles.summary: After August’s wildfires killed three, ravaged 55,000 ha of woodland and displaced 8,000 around La Bañeza in Castilla y León, its 10,000 residents scored €468 m in Spain’s El Gordo Christmas lottery by selling 117 series locally. Each €20 décimo wins €400,000, and nearby Villablino survivors of a mining accident that killed five in March await multimillion-euro payouts. Mayor Javier Carrera called the win “a cascade of emotions…fallen from the heavens” after tragedy. The televised San Ildefonso draw, steeped in superstition, often favours towns struck by misfortune.

articles.title: Revealed: how big businesses are rolling back public support for Pride
articles.trailText: Guardian analysis of 20 major companies in UK and US shows mentions of Pride on social media have fallen substantially in past two years
articles.summary: Guardian analysis of social media posts by the 10 largest UK and 10 largest US companies shows Pride mentions fell 92% (52→4) in the UK from 2023–25 and 54% (39→18) in the US. HSBC led UK mentions but still dropped 94%; AstraZeneca, Shell and Unilever were least active. In the US, Apple bucked the trend with a 22% rise, while Berkshire Hathaway, Broadcom and Tesla posted least. Experts link rollbacks to Trump’s 2025 DEI reversals and warn that visibility matters amid global LGBTQ+ hostility. Firms cite ongoing sponsorship and internal networks but face calls to ‘walk the walk.’

articles.title: Freed Nigerian schoolchildren to be reunited with families
articles.trailText: Month-long ordeal ends but no details released on how they regained their freedom or who was behind abduction
articles.summary: 130 pupils abducted from St Mary’s Catholic school in Papiri, Niger state, were freed by the government on Dec 22 after a month-long captivity and will reunite with families Dec 23. Earlier, 50 escapees and 100 released on Dec 7 underscored the opaque role of kidnappers and negotiators. Kidnap-for-ransom gangs and Sahel-linked jihadists exploit Nigeria’s stretched security forces: SBM Intelligence reports 4,722 abductions, 762 deaths and $1.66 m paid (July 2024–June 2025). Papiri marks Niger state’s second mass school raid since 2021 and echoes Chibok 2014. The US (Trump) has branded Nigeria a “country of particular concern” over alleged “Christian genocide,” which Nigeria disputes.

articles.title: Academic ‘prepared to take legal action’ after gender lecture disrupted at Bristol University
articles.trailText: Prof Alice Sullivan claims university failed to protect her right to freedom of expression after protest at event
articles.summary: Prof Alice Sullivan, a UCL academic, plans legal action against the University of Bristol and regulator OfS over failure to protect her freedom of expression after protesters disrupted her October lecture on sex and gender at the Clifton campus. She alleges some attendees stayed away, protesters climbed walls, used megaphones, banged windows, set off fire alarms, and undergrads were barred. In a pre-action letter she demands accountability and a safer venue. Bristol insists it upheld free speech and safety; the OfS declined to comment.

articles.title: Spain’s socialists shed voters in regional election as far right makes gains
articles.trailText: Vox doubles its seats in Extremadura as Socialist Workers’ party, mired in corruption scandals, loses 10 of its 28 seats
articles.summary: PSOE lost 10 of 28 seats in Extremadura’s regional vote, shedding 108,000 ballots amid corruption and harassment probes. Vox doubled to 11 seats, UxE rose from four to seven, while the PP fell four short of an outright 33-seat majority, forcing leader María Guardiola back into coalition with Vox. After Guardiola’s PP ousted PSOE in 2023 via a shaky Vox tie, a snap vote backfired. Vox’s core base skews men aged 35-54. PSOE candidate Miguel Ángel Gallardo and PM Sánchez’s brother face influence-peddling trials, and all main parties plus Vox youth face scandal allegations.

articles.title: ‘Teach your daughter to speak Polish’: Ukrainians in Poland face growing resentment
articles.trailText: Change in attitudes has been stoked by disinformation, viral videos and the election of rightwing populist president
articles.summary: Since Russia’s full-scale invasion, initial Polish generosity toward Ukrainian refugees has sharply declined, fueled by disinformation, a rightwing populist shift under President Nawrocki and resurfacing historical grievances. Incidents like the assault on Valeriia Kholkina for speaking Ukrainian have become common, prompting surveys showing support for refugees plummeting from 94% to 48% and EU accession backing sliding from 85% to 35%. Hardship, online hate and proposed welfare cuts contrast with more positive experiences in major cities. Despite net-positive economic contributions, many Ukrainians now fear public hostility while weighing whether to stay in Poland.

articles.title: Monday briefing: A route out of Gaza’s shattered universities – and the student who made it to the UK
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With Gaza’s education system in ruins, a small number of students have found a way to study abroad. Aseel Mousa reflects on escape, guilt and how the war followed her to the UK
articles.summary: 27-year-old Gazan student Aseel Mousa recounts fleeing Gaza’s shattered higher-education system—undermined by a two-decade blockade and two-year war Israel prosecuted and UN-called genocide—to pursue a master’s in international relations at the University of Leicester. One of fewer than 100 Gazans to reach the UK since October 2023, she reflects on escape, survivor’s guilt and the conflict’s shadow over her life: celebrating academic achievements and simple freedoms (internet access, travel) while mourning family, friends and her destroyed home. Her journey highlights Gaza’s educational collapse, humanitarian crisis and the personal toll of occupation and war.

articles.title: Jeju Air crash: South Korea sets up independent inquiry into disaster that killed 179 amid delays and acrimony
articles.trailText: MPs vote to investigate crash amid accusations from victims’ relatives of cover-ups and delays
articles.summary: South Korea’s parliament approved (245–1) an 18-member independent inquiry into the Dec 29, 2024 Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 bird-strike crash at Muan airport that killed 179 of 181 aboard. Families accuse the Araib—answerable to the transport ministry—of cover-ups, delays and a structural conflict of interest. Over a 40-day (extendable) mandate, MPs can summon transport, Jeju Air and airport officials, probe bird-strike handling, aircraft defects, the concrete embankment and any government attempts to downplay evidence. An interim report is due by Dec 29 under international aviation regulations.

articles.title: ‘It’s upset us all’: New Forest residents unnerved by man leaving animal carcasses by churches
articles.trailText: Case of man who apparently targeted Christians is latest in series of incidents in Hampshire of animal remains being dumped
articles.summary: Residents of England’s New Forest are alarmed after Totton man Benjamin Lewis admitted stealing livestock and dumping carcasses—black lambs and deer—near local churches in an apparent anti-Christian campaign. Arrested in May after increased police patrols in villages such as Bramshaw and Burley, he pled guilty at Southampton Crown Court to religiously aggravated harassment and theft, and remains in custody pending sentencing next year. Linked to Lewis’s interest in the supernatural, the case highlights a broader rise in animal cruelty flagged by the RSPCA. Local farmers, faith groups and animal-welfare advocates condemn the “horrific” acts and urge greater kindness to animals.

articles.title: Hen cages and pig farrowing crates to be outlawed in England
articles.trailText: Humane slaughter requirements for farmed fish and end to puppy farming also in new package of animal welfare laws
articles.summary: England’s government unveils its most ambitious animal welfare strategy in a generation, proposing to ban enriched 'colony' cages for laying hens and pig farrowing crates by phasing in non-cage systems, affecting 7 million hens and 150,000 sows annually. Additional measures include ending puppy farming, consulting on bans of electric shock dog collars, snares, and trail hunting, imposing humane slaughter standards for farmed fish, and restricting hare shooting during breeding season. Environment Secretary Emma Reynolds emphasizes raising welfare standards on farms, in the wild, and at home.

articles.title: ‘Slightly haunted but manageable’: new signs cause confusion – and delight – in Christchurch
articles.trailText: Six absurdist signs resembling official city council information boards have popped up across New Zealand’s second-largest city
articles.summary: Artist Cameron Hunt installed six spoof signs resembling official city boards across Christchurch during the Little Street art festival, emblazoned with absurd directives like “slightly haunted but manageable,” a 2.83km/h walking speed limit and simply “don’t.” Designed to subvert the authority of urban signage, the guerrilla artworks sparked public confusion and delight, prompting photo-sharing, online debates over authenticity on Reddit and a city-wide treasure hunt. Christchurch City Council praised the playful interruptions, while Hunt says the site-specific pieces aim to spark curiosity, conversation and a renewed awareness of the urban environment.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv’s forces battle Russian push to break through in Sumy region
articles.trailText: Moscow reported to have forcibly moved dozens of people from border village; Florida peace talks described as ‘productive’. What we know on day 1,398
articles.summary: Ukraine’s military is battling a renewed Russian push in Sumy region, with fierce fighting in Grabovske and reports of 50 civilians forcibly moved into Russia after Moscow claimed Vysoke. US–Ukraine talks in Miami were deemed “productive and constructive” but yielded no ceasefire breakthrough; a proposed trilateral format involving Russia was firmly rejected by the Kremlin. A Ukrainian drone strike on Russia’s Krasnodar coast damaged vessels and sparked fires. Meanwhile, UK PM Starmer and US envoys discuss coalition backing, amid Russian criticism of Western amendments to Washington’s peace plan and US intelligence warning Putin still seeks territorial gains.

articles.title: Kimchi, made in China: how South Korea’s national dish is being priced out at home
articles.trailText: In the first 10 months of this year, South Korea imported $159m worth of kimchi, almost entirely from China, while exporting $137m
articles.summary: In 2025, South Korea became a net importer of kimchi, buying $159 m worth from China in 10 months against $137 m exported. Chinese kimchi at 1,700 won/kg undercuts domestic producers charging 3,600 won, forcing factories in Incheon and Hwaseong to struggle. Rising single-person households shift consumption to free, ready-made kimchi in restaurants, making price king. Climate-driven cabbage shortages spike costs. Industry groups propose vouchers, advance tariff checks, voluntary Korean-kimchi labeling, agricultural support and shelf-life R&D, while championing local quality and unique taste as the best defence.

articles.title: Letter: Sir Geoffrey Bindman obituary
articles.trailText: Edie Friedman writes: We disussed our shared experiences of being minority communities in Britain
articles.summary: Edie Friedman remembers Sir Geoffrey Bindman’s long-standing role in a Black, Asian and Jewish breakfast group in Chalk Farm, north-west London, where members convened over the kitchen table to debate refugee support and advocate stronger race relations legislation. Through decades of shared minority experiences, Bindman championed intercommunal dialogue and legislative reform. Friedman warns that, amid today’s tensions and fraying social cohesion, his collaborative initiatives remain urgently needed to bridge divisions and protect vulnerable communities.

articles.title: Rejoining Erasmus+ is brilliant news for Britain | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Guardian readers celebrate the European exchange programme and the fact that Britain will be rejoining it in 2027
articles.summary: Three Guardian letters applaud the UK’s decision to rejoin Erasmus+ from 2027, highlighting renewed student mobility and cultural exchange. Graham Walters recalls a 12-year Erasmus-funded environmental field course, rotating across six EU universities and fostering lasting friendships and staff collaborations. Maddalaine Ansell of the British Council underlines Erasmus+’s wider impact 2014–20, funding 4,846 projects, engaging 128,000 UK participants and awarding €679 million to British organisations across education, vocational training and sport. Ray Kirtley points to the “Plus” elements—schools, youth groups, vocational and adult learning, eTwinning and teacher exchanges—welcoming its reinstatement as vital for building a globally skilled UK workforce.

articles.title: Kremlin renews criticism of Europe’s efforts to amend US plan to end Ukraine war
articles.trailText: Putin’s top foreign policy aid says proposals could prolong conflict as talks with US negotiators are held in Miami
articles.summary: Russia’s Kremlin, via Putin aide Yuri Ushakov, lashed out at European and Ukrainian amendments to Washington’s peace plan, warning tweaks could prolong conflict. Meanwhile, US envoys Jared Kushner and Steve Witkoff are in Miami with Russian envoy Kirill Dmitriev for talks deemed “productive,” as Zelenskiy touts fast-moving diplomacy. French President Macron’s outreach to Putin is welcomed. US intelligence flags Putin’s broader territorial ambitions. EU leaders pledged €90 bn to Ukraine. On the front, Kyiv repelled a Russian push in Sumy, disputed reports of a village’s fall, and struck Russia’s Caspian oilfield with drones.

articles.title: Élysée Palace staff member accused of stealing tableware worth up to €40,000
articles.trailText: Silver steward is one of three people arrested in connection with alleged theft from presidential residence
articles.summary: An Élysée Palace silver steward and two alleged accomplices were arrested after investigators uncovered the theft of silverware and Sèvres porcelain valued at up to €40,000 from the French president’s residence, sold via online platforms like Vinted. Palace staff flagged missing national-heritage items; recovered around 100 pieces— including René Lalique statuette, Baccarat champagne coupes and copper saucepans— from his home and locker. Prosecutors say inventory records indicated further planned heists. The trio, barred from auction venues and under judicial supervision, will stand trial in February. Their arrest follows recent high-profile museum raids across France.

articles.title: Troubling memories resurface in Davao as authorities trace Bondi shooting suspects’ movements
articles.trailText: Many residents believe alleged gunmen were in Mindanao for ‘tourism, not terrorism’ and say extremist groups in area have been significantly weakened
articles.summary: In Davao City, residents still recall the 2016 IS bombing at the Roxas night market that killed 15 as authorities probe the four-week stay of alleged Bondi shooters Sajid and Naveed Akram. Locals like therapists Gerry Pendon and Emelyn Lorenzo insist the pair came for tourism, not terrorism, and note that IS-linked groups in Mindanao have been weakened. Officials stress the men never left Davao or received combat training, while police review CCTV and taxi records. Analysts warn socioeconomic and political grievances must be addressed to prevent mislabeling and renewed bias against Muslim communities.

articles.title: Do prawns feel pain? Why scientists are urging a rethink of Australia’s favoured festive food
articles.trailText: Studies show crustaceans can learn, remember, solve problems and form relationships
articles.summary: Australia devours 18.5 million kg of prawns and 150 000 lobsters over Christmas, but researchers argue decapod crustaceans—from shrimp to crabs—are sentient, experiencing pain, fear and complex behaviours such as learning, memory and symbiotic relationships (e.g., pistol shrimp and goby fish). Despite evidence, common practices—boiling alive, cable-tying, eyestalk ablation—inflict distress. While the UK and New Zealand legally protect crustaceans, Australia’s regulations are patchy. Scientists and advocates call for bans on live sales and exports, mandatory stunning and stronger welfare laws, urging consumers to seek humanely handled seafood.

articles.title: Alarm over ‘exploding’ rise in use of sanctions-busting shadow fleet
articles.trailText: Fear that confrontation is on the cards as policing of ships becomes more aggressive and Russia challenges Europe
articles.summary: Russia, Iran and Venezuela’s sanctions-busting “shadow fleet” of ageing tankers, now 900–1,200 vessels under opaque ownership and fake flags, has surged since 2022. Western responses—US helicopter raids on the Skipper off Venezuela, a second vessel seizure, France and Estonia interdicting ships, and Ukrainian drone strikes on Russian tankers in the Black Sea and Mediterranean—have escalated tensions and risk military clashes. Moscow has re-flagged ships under the Russian ensign and deployed fighter jets to protect them. Europe, led by Macron, considers tougher boarding policies. Despite fresh EU sanctions on brokers and registries, discounted oil profits and complex evasion networks suggest the shadow fleet will endure.

articles.title: Friedrich Merz wants Berlin to be a geopolitical hub. Will German voters reward him?
articles.trailText: The chancellor is pursuing a risky quest for European leadership, and last week’s setback over Russian reparations is unlikely to knock him off course
articles.summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s bid to make Berlin a European geopolitical hub suffered a setback when his proposal to channel €201bn of frozen Russian assets as a reparations loan to Ukraine was rejected by EU peers, resulting instead in a €90bn interest-free loan. Undeterred, Merz insists on European sovereignty over frozen assets, thwarted a US carve-up to preserve leverage against Russia, hosted US envoys in Berlin, and pushed for doubling defence spending to €378bn by 2029 with limited conscription. He faces domestic risk from the AfD and a public divided on Ukraine support ahead of elections.

articles.title: Danish postal service to stop delivering letters after 400 years
articles.trailText: PostNord’s decision to end service on 30 December comes after fear over ‘increasing digitalisation’ of Danish society
articles.summary: PostNord will cease letter delivery in Denmark on 30 December, ending a 400-year tradition. The move cuts 1,500 jobs and removes 1,500 red postboxes amid drastic falls in letter demand as Denmark digitizes. Stamps will be refunded; parcels remain PostNord’s focus. Dao expands from 30 m to 80 m letters in 2026, charging for app/online postage or pick-up. Despite a 90% drop in 25 years, 18-34 year-olds are reviving handwritten mail. Danish law mandates a letter service, so customers still send via Dao. With 97% registered to digital MitID post, physical letters have become niche yet valued.

articles.title: Spain’s ruling party faces crunch regional poll amid corruption and harassment claims
articles.trailText: Results of Sunday’s snap election in Extremadura are seen as key test of Pedro Sánchez and his PSOE party
articles.summary: Sunday’s snap election in Extremadura, called by regional president María Guardiola after her coalition with Vox collapsed over next year’s budget, represents a critical test for Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez and his PSOE amid a barrage of corruption and sexual harassment allegations against his inner circle. Socialist candidate Miguel Ángel Gallardo faces trial for influence-peddling linked to a job for Sánchez’s brother, while investigations dog Sánchez’s wife and top aides. Polls predict the PP and Vox could secure 55–57% of votes, likely forcing another right-wing pact and signaling a broader nationwide swing ahead of upcoming regional contests.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian oil rig hit in Caspian Sea over 700km from Ukraine
articles.trailText: Kyiv continues campaign of attacks on Russia-linked maritime targets; latest US idea is three-way peace talks. What we know on day 1,397
articles.summary: Ukrainian drones struck Russia’s Filanovsky oil platform 700 km from Ukraine, damaging the rig and patrol ship Okhotnik, and hit a radar site in Crimea; SBU says two Russian jets destroyed. Russia’s forces repeatedly bombed the Dniester River bridge near Mayaky in Odesa, halting 40% of fuel supplies and killing eight at Pivdennyi port—where sunflower-oil tanks exploded. Russian air raids (42 strikes, 101 guided bombs, 1,684 kamikaze drones) killed two in Izium; Ukraine repelled 60+ attacks at Pokrovsk. Russia reported strikes on Belgorod and Kursk. The White House proposed US-Russia-Ukraine talks; Kyiv insists on preserving current frontlines and retaining Donbas territory.

articles.title: Israeli troops kill six Palestinians sheltering in Gaza school, say hospital chiefs
articles.trailText: Attack brings total number of Palestinians killed by Israel to 401 since October ceasefire took effect
articles.summary: Hospital officials report Israeli forces killed six Palestinians, including an infant, sheltering in a Gaza City school on Friday, firing across the ceasefire line and raising Israel’s toll to 401 since October’s truce. Bodies were recovered under UN coordination. Witnesses decry a "bloodbath" amid unannounced shelling. Negotiations on phase two—which would see Hamas disarm, full Israeli withdrawal, and deployment of an international stabilization force—stall over mandate and funding, as US Secretary of State Marco Rubio urges clarity. Qatar warns further delays risk collapsing the deal. Since Hamas’s October 2023 attack, the Gaza war has killed over 70,000 Palestinians amid famine and allegations of genocide.

articles.title: The bleakest winter: Ukrainians face exhaustion and uncertainty as Trump demands concessions
articles.trailText: People torn between craving for peace as conditions worsen and desire to hold strong against Russian military and US
articles.summary: At Kharkiv’s puppet theatre a nativity play staged on ammo crates epitomises how four years of conflict have seeped into daily life as Ukrainians face their bleakest winter. With Trump’s first-year push for concessions, grinding Donbas offensives, missile-induced blackouts, budget holes and conscription strains, civilians oscillate between exhaustion and resilience. Frontline towns like Vovchansk lie devastated, repeated evacuations test morale, yet urban innovation in drones, underground schools and sold-out Kyiv events reveal determination. Amid uncertainty over peace terms and territory, Ukrainians cling to unity and hope.

articles.title: Brussels bike ban plan for pedestrian zone ‘dangerous and absurd’
articles.trailText: Cyclist and road safety groups argue proposed alternative route away from traffic-free Le Piétonnier is unsafe
articles.summary: Brussels plans to ban bikes and e-scooters from its 650 m Le Piétonnier pedestrian zone (18 000 m²) outside 4 am–11 am, forcing riders to dismount or face fines. Councillor Anaïs Maes cites pedestrian complaints and poor compliance with the 6 km/h speed limit. Cyclist and road-safety groups condemn the proposed parallel alternative route—three busy streets with blind spots—as “dangerous and absurd.” Officials reject a dedicated bike lane, warning it would increase speeds and conflicts, while council debates continue amid cyclist and courier protests.

articles.title: The volunteers putting their bodies between Israel settlers and a Palestinian village
articles.trailText: In the Jordan valley, teenage settlers drive herds of goats into a Palestinian community in a bid to force families out – volunteers are trying to hold the line
articles.summary: Teenage Israeli settlers repeatedly drive herds of goats and camels down from outposts in the Jordan Valley into Ras Ein al-Auja to harass its 700 Palestinian residents and force them off their land. Each morning a small group of Israeli Jewish, Hungarian and American volunteers—including ex-IDF officers from Looking the Occupation in the Eye and internationals with Unarmed Civilian Protection in Palestine—shields villagers, films incursions with body-cams and shoo away livestock. They confront sticks, pepper spray, ATV raids and the support of government-paid security coordinator Gabriel Kalish. Since October settlers have closed grazing lands, seized the spring and tightened a de facto siege. Volunteers say their protective presence is the only barrier to expulsion and ethnic cleansing.

articles.title: India’s doctors sound alarm over boom in availability of weight loss jabs
articles.trailText: Country is facing epidemic of diabetes and obesity, but experts say widespread and unregulated use of weight loss drugs could put patients at risk
articles.summary: Indian doctors warn of health risks from the rapid, unregulated rise of GLP-1 weight-loss jabs—Mounjaro, Wegovy, Ozempic���now top sellers in a nation battling 212 million diabetics and 180 million overweight adults. With patents ending next year and local generics poised to flood the market, experts caution against misuse in pharmacies, gyms and beauty clinics. Specialists like Mohit Bhandari and Anoop Misra emphasize the need for strict government control, specialist prescription, patient screening and long-term monitoring to avoid side effects—muscle loss, pancreatitis, gallstones, even blindness—and stress that lifestyle changes remain vital.

articles.title: ‘From her pen sprang unforgettable females’: 16th-century Spanish author’s knight’s tale given reboot
articles.trailText: Beatriz Bernal’s pioneering novel features brave, chivalrous women who ride dragons and her adapter wants his illustrated version to reach young readers
articles.summary: Beatriz Bernal’s 1545 novel Cristalián de España—the earliest known chivalric romance by a female Spanish author, bristling with dragons and sorcery—is relaunched for young readers in a richly illustrated adaptation by Diego Arboleda and Eugenia Ábalos. Bernal, largely forgotten after being eclipsed by Cervantes, originally published under anonymity; a posthumous edition in 1587 revealed her name. The retelling highlights her trailblazing female characters—Membrina, a self-determined sorceress, and Minerva, a knight who rescues others—reviving a genre that once legitimized women’s voices in 16th-century literature.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian missiles strike port near Odesa, killing seven, officials say
articles.trailText: Another 15 people injured in attack on one of three ports important for Ukrainian grain and other exports. What we know on day 1,396
articles.summary: On day 1,396 of Russia’s full-scale invasion, a late Friday missile strike on infrastructure around Pivdennyi port in Odesa region killed seven and wounded 15, imperiling Ukraine’s grain exports. Kyiv retaliated by attacking a Russian “shadow fleet” tanker off Libya. Ukrainian authorities are negotiating alternative routes via Moldova, where temporary camps have been set up for travelers. President Zelenskiy hailed a €90 billion EU loan—repayable only from Russian reparations—as crucial support. US intelligence reports Putin aims to conquer all Ukraine and reclaim former Soviet territories, contradicting Trump envoys’ peace plan as Miami talks led by Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, with Marco Rubio’s assurance that no deal will be forced on Kyiv, enter their second day.

articles.title: Gaza no longer in famine but hunger levels remain critical, UN says
articles.trailText: Monitor says almost one in eight people face food shortages as flooding and cold exacerbate humanitarian emergency
articles.summary: Gaza’s famine classification has lifted due to increased aid since the October ceasefire, but the entire strip remains at “emergency” levels of food insecurity, with almost 1 in 8 facing shortages exacerbated by winter flooding and cold. Despite eased Israeli aid restrictions, deliveries are inconsistent. The IPC warns 1.6m could face “crisis” hunger in coming months and Gaza could relapse into famine if the ceasefire collapses. Israel denies impeding aid. Oxfam says $2.5m of relief sits blocked. Disease risk in flooded tent camps is high, and a 29-day-old infant recently died of hypothermia.

articles.title: Disabled people in England ‘betrayed’ by cuts to new-build accessibility targets
articles.trailText: Campaigners decry plan to reduce requirement for improved standards from 100% down to 40% of new homes
articles.summary: Proposed planning reforms reduce mandatory accessible new homes in England—M4(2) step-free, widened-door properties—from 100% to 40%, and eliminate any minimum for fully wheelchair-accessible M4(3) units. Disability Rights UK dubbed it a “monumental reversal,” saying disabled people feel “betrayed and excluded,” while the Centre for Ageing Better called 40% a “step back.” Councils may opt for higher local requirements. Currently just 13% of homes meet M4(3), with the East Midlands and North East six times less likely than London—where 90% M4(2)/10% M4(3) has applied since 2015—to be wheelchair-friendly. Housing secretary Steve Reed argues reforms will boost building; Sense urges reinstating stronger targets.

articles.title: Europe mustn’t build its own house of dynamite | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: A compelling model for sustainable security without nuclear deterrence or offensive military capabilities could be developed, writes Dr Ian Davis . Plus letters from Prof Michael Rustin and Jon Duke
articles.summary: Europe must prepare for a post-Nato security architecture that diverges from nuclear deterrence and offensive capabilities. Dr Ian Davis warns against an EU “house of dynamite”—shared nuclear arms and chronic military spending—and instead urges a human-security framework modeled on neutral states, emphasizing deterrence-by-denial and societal resilience. Prof Michael Rustin advocates EU-Russia rapprochement via a neutral Ukraine, while Jon Duke calls for an independent European defence alliance, immediate defence investment and reintroduced military service.

articles.title: We abhor racism in Britain, but refuse to recognise where it comes from | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Paul McGilchrist says we will remain complicit in the rise of racism until we can accept that it emerges from problematic behaviours and attitudes. Plus letters from Dr Peter Purton and Michael Bulley
articles.summary: Three Guardian letters from Paul McGilchrist, Dr Peter Purton and Michael Bulley dissect Britain’s struggle to confront racism and the dangers of passive complicity. McGilchrist critiques a cultural paradox that abhors overt racists like Nigel Farage yet excuses racist tropes in anti-immigration rhetoric, highlighting how everyday behaviours and ‘face-saving’ focus on intent and benefit of the doubt mask systemic prejudice. Purton recalls latent racism kept secret by white Britons reclaiming respectability, while Bulley warns that unfiltered democracy may empower the ‘stupid and evil’ alongside virtuous voters, undermining democratic ideals.

articles.title: Santas and elves rob Montreal grocery store to ‘give food to the needy’
articles.trailText: Group called Robins des Ruelles later said in statement stunt was intended to highlight cost of living crisis
articles.summary: Masked Santas and elves from activist group Robins des Ruelles stormed a Montreal supermarket, seized thousands of dollars of groceries then vanished, announcing they’d redistribute the haul to the hungry. They dropped some under a public Christmas tree and said the rest would go to community food banks. Dubbed a Robin Hood–style raid “When hunger justifies the means,” the stunt targeted spiralling living costs and record grocer profits. Metro condemned the theft, citing supply-chain pressures, rising retail crime and its $1.15 million in 2025 food-bank donations. Police are investigating with no arrests made.

articles.title: Circle back in February? If only we could | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: David Parker responds to the news that some New Zealanders are taking an extremely long summer break
articles.summary: In a Guardian letter, David Parker questions reports of New Zealand workers taking a break from Christmas to March, asking which sectors truly enjoy this downtime. He notes retail, supermarket, hospital, fast-food and hospitality staff return after Boxing Day, implying only "professionals"—company directors, academics, politicians—benefit from extended leave. Meanwhile essential lower-paid workers like bin collectors and bar staff continue labouring under poor wages. Parker condemns the oblivious "circle back in February" mindset, urging recognition of socioeconomic disparities in work entitlements.

articles.title: At least four people killed in mass stabbing in Taipei
articles.trailText: Man, 27, from northern Taiwan reported to have fallen to his death in police chase after rampage through capital
articles.summary: In a rare mass stabbing in central Taipei on Friday evening, a 27-year-old ex-air force volunteer used replica US smoke grenades and knives at rush hour, killing four people and wounding several more as he struck first in Taipei Main Station then in the nearby Zhongshan shopping district. The suspect fell to his death during a police chase. One victim died trying to intervene in the station. Charged previously with obstructing military service and discharged in 2022, he had outstanding warrants. President Lai Ching-te ordered heightened security and vowed “no leniency” as authorities probe his motive.

articles.title: ‘Radiator rattling’ earthquake hits Lancashire village for second time in two weeks
articles.trailText: People of Silverdale report rattling and shaking as 2.5 magnitude earthquake strikes in probable aftershock
articles.summary: Silverdale on Lancashire’s coast experienced a 2.5-magnitude quake at 5.03am, the second tremor in under two weeks following a 3.3-magnitude shock on 3 December. With its epicentre 1.6 miles offshore, the aftershock rattled radiators, windows and pictures but caused no injuries or damage. The British Geological Survey classifies it as a routine aftershock. Locals described jolts, bangs and booms, noting such quakes are among the 10% of annual UK tremors felt without instruments.

articles.title: Ukraine attacks Russian ‘shadow’ tanker off Libyan coast
articles.trailText: Reportedly critical drone strike is first in Mediterranean since full-scale invasion began as maritime conflict grows
articles.summary: Ukraine’s SBU used aerial drones to strike the Russian “shadow fleet” tanker Qendil off Libya – its first Mediterranean attack since full-scale invasion, 2,000 km from Kyiv. The empty vessel, part of a 1,000-strong network evading sanctions to fund Moscow’s war, was critically damaged with no environmental harm. Friday’s strike coincided with Putin’s year-end press conference, where he vowed retaliation but downplayed impact. Kyiv says the multi-stage operation underscores its reach to disrupt sanctioned oil exports. Western navies and US forces have also stepped up actions against shadow tankers in global waters.

articles.title: ‘She was like a deer in headlights’: how unskilled radical birthkeepers took hold in Canada
articles.trailText: In holistic communities and midwifery deserts, women are turning to the Free Birth Society for information and unlicensed providers
articles.summary: Holistic communities in Canada’s midwifery deserts are turning to the Free Birth Society (FBS), whose podcast and courses promote unassisted “free births” without prenatal care or licensed professionals. Since 2018 FBS has made over $13m; its Instagram has 132k followers. A Guardian investigation linked FBS to at least 48 stillbirths or neonatal deaths. In BC, Emma Cardinal lost her son Floyd and nearly died of sepsis after following FBS’s radical advice; on Vancouver Island, an FBS-trained attendant failed to recognise placental abruption, leaving baby Aksel brain-damaged. Amid legal cases, Canadian authorities warn against unlicensed “radical birthkeepers” trained via FBS’s Zoom school.

articles.title: EU’s Ukraine loan may have been Plan B, but don’t underestimate its significance to the bloc
articles.trailText: This €90bn agreement won out over a plan to use frozen Russian assets, but has been hailed a ‘huge deal for the EU’
articles.summary: After 16-hour summit talks, EU leaders agreed a €90bn loan for Ukraine under Plan B—abandoning Plan A to leverage €210bn of frozen Russian assets, blocked by Belgium’s legal retaliation concerns. Using unallocated EU budget funds as collateral, they secured support without full unanimity by exempting Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic. This historic first EU debt decision sans unanimity, hailed by Macron and backed despite von der Leyen’s and Merz’s Plan A loss, boosts Kyiv and signals new EU fiscal integration.

articles.title: Richard Moth appointed Roman Catholic archbishop of Westminster
articles.trailText: Moth, 67, bishop of Arundel and Brighton, becomes leader of 6m Catholics in England and Wales
articles.summary: Richard Moth, 67, bishop of Arundel and Brighton since 2015, has been appointed by Pope Leo as Archbishop of Westminster, replacing Cardinal Vincent Nichols and becoming head of about 6m Catholics in England and Wales. Moth, born in Zambia and raised in Kent, pledges to acquaint himself with local clergy, build on Nichols’s legacy and continue the church’s mission. A former bishop of the forces, prison liaison and St Mary’s University governor, he has campaigned on assisted-dying legislation, refugee empathy and social justice, including opposing the two-child benefit cap. His formal installation is set for 14 February.

articles.title: ‘Matter of survival’: South Korean president urges public health cover for hair loss
articles.trailText: Medical professionals and some in conservative circles feel argument of Lee Jae Myung may be a bit thin
articles.summary: South Korean president Lee Jae Myung has asked his government to explore expanding the country’s universal health insurance to cover hair-loss treatments—beyond alopecia areata—arguing male pattern baldness is a “matter of survival” for young adults. The proposal, previously criticized as populist, has drawn scepticism from the Korean Medical Association and conservative media citing insurance finances under strain and priority for life-threatening illnesses. Critics including a former lawmaker and the health minister warn of deficits, while ruling party MP Park Joo-min endorses it. Lee also ordered a probe into high menstrual pad prices.

articles.title: Chile’s far-right president taps into support for Pinochet that never went away
articles.trailText: Experts say José Antonio Kast able to ‘reactivate a dormant Pinochetism’ and warn more education needed on ‘horrors of dictatorship’
articles.summary: José Antonio Kast, elected Chile’s president, has long openly championed Augusto Pinochet, campaigning aged 22 in the 1988 plebiscite and breaking from the UDI to restore authoritarian ideals. His victory, supported by a third of voters who view Pinochet positively, revives a dormant Pinochetism rooted in memories of 40,000 tortured, 3,000 killed under the dictatorship. Experts warn that many Chileans lack awareness of these brutalities. Historian Katia Chornik, a former exile’s daughter, documents 168 survivor testimonies in her new book Music and Political Imprisonment in Pinochet’s Chile and calls for UNESCO-backed educational initiatives to prevent forgetting.

articles.title: Ukraine deal: EU leaders agree €90bn loan, but without use of frozen Russian assets
articles.trailText: Two-year deal will cover most of Ukraine’s needs, but will be secured against EU borrowing rather than Russian assets
articles.summary: EU leaders approved a €90bn two-year loan for Ukraine, to be raised on capital markets and backed by the EU budget instead of immediate use of the bloc’s €210bn frozen Russian assets. Kyiv will repay once Russia pays reparations; the EU retains rights to immobilised assets as security. The package cleared unanimity by exempting Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic from guarantees, enabling mid-January disbursements. Zelenskiy hailed it as resilience-boosting, while Belgium resisted open-ended budget exposure. Champions like Germany see assets eventually repurposed; Brussels now calls on non-EU allies for €45bn to fill 2026-27 funding gaps.

articles.title: ‘I can’t think of a place more pristine’: 133,000 hectares of Chilean Patagonia preserved after local fundraising
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Ancient forests and turquoise rivers of the Cochamó Valley protected from logging, damming and development
articles.summary: Local NGOs led by Puelo Patagonia mobilized a grassroots campaign to stymie hydroelectric and development plans, raising $63m to buy 133,000ha of Cochamó Valley. Now managed by Fundación Conserva Puchegüín, the pristine region hosts ancient alerce groves (11% of global total), turquoise rivers, waterfalls and rare species. The initiative, backed by Cox, Patagonia and Freyja foundations, links to 1.6mha of protected lands, caps visitors at 15,000/year, funds endowment-backed conservation and blends national park–level reserves with community tourism and traditional ranching.

articles.title: ‘Better off with Taiwan’: Honduras joins other Latin American countries rethinking ties with China
articles.trailText: US pressure, broken promises by China and corruption scandals have halted Taiwan’s slide to diplomatic irrelevance in the region
articles.summary: After Honduras’s 30 Nov election, both leading candidates vowed to reverse Xiomara Castro’s March 2023 switch to Beijing, restoring ties with Taiwan. They cite zero benefits from China—shrimp exports collapsed, promised infrastructure delayed—and praise US pressure, agriculture and debt relief from Taipei. Honduras joins Panama, the Dominican Republic and others rethinking China embassies amid broken promises, corruption allegations and US-led pushback. With only 12 diplomatic allies left, Taiwan gains momentum: Panamanian MPs visit Taipei, St Vincent’s drops plans to recognise China and US support deters further switches.

articles.title: Friday briefing: Why the search for Britain’s missing TV is running out of time
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: From Quatermass to Doctor Who, so much early television has vanished – and as film degrades and collectors age, the chances of recovering what remains are shrinking
articles.summary: Despite streaming ubiquity today, much early British television—from Quatermass to Doctor Who—was wiped or junked, leaving gaps in cultural memory. Archivists and volunteers, notably the Film Is Fabulous network spearheaded by experts like Toby Hadoke, race to salvage deteriorating film cans from aging private collectors before tapes degrade or vanish. Technical faults, wiping practices and rights issues have left hundreds of episodes missing. With no central archive and analog formats at risk, the search for these “sacred relics” is a dwindling, time-critical endeavour.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Hungary agrees to allow EU loan to Kyiv but will not contribute
articles.trailText: Viktor Orbán appeared to have agreed not to block the borrowing as long as his country, Slovakia and the Czech Republic were excluded from the guarantees. What we know on day 1,395
articles.summary: Hungary’s Viktor Orbán agreed not to block an EU-backed interest-free loan to Ukraine for two years if Hungary, Slovakia and the Czech Republic are excluded from the guarantees. EU states dropped plans to use frozen Russian assets after legal risks in Belgium. German chancellor Friedrich Merz said repayment depends on Russian reparations or immobilised assets. US president Donald Trump urged swift Ukraine-Russia talks. Denmark blamed Russia for hybrid cyber-attacks on utilities and elections. Russian strikes near Odesa killed a civilian. The UK and EU imposed new sanctions on Russian oil firms and shadow-fleet ships.

articles.title: Dashed dreams and land grabs: The rise of rural protests in China
articles.trailText: Exclusive : Clashes over rural plots are increasing, as people whose big-city plans have evaporated return home to face local governments groaning under huge debt
articles.summary: Reports show a surge in rural protests across China—661 incidents by November, a 70% rise over 2024—driven by debt-strapped local governments seizing collective farmland and demolishing community sites like temples. High-profile clashes in Hainan and Hunan reflect villagers’ anger over unfair compensation. Returning young migrants, disillusioned by sluggish urban job markets, bring heightened expectations and fuel volatile outbursts. Authorities are rolling out legal and social service centers to stave off further unrest.

articles.title: Denmark says Russia was behind two ‘destructive and disruptive’ cyber-attacks
articles.trailText: Intelligence service says attacks were work of groups connected to Russian state in ‘clear evidence’ of hybrid war
articles.summary: Denmark’s Defence Intelligence Service (DDIS) attributes two 2024 cyberattacks—a December hack on a Køge water utility by pro-Russian Z-Pentest that burst pipes and pre-election DDoS assaults on municipal websites by NoName057(16)—to the Russian state’s hybrid war aimed at punishing Ukraine supporters, sowing insecurity and as part of a broader influence campaign to erode Western support for Kyiv. DDIS director Thomas Ahrenkiel and defence minister Troels Lund Poulsen condemned the “unacceptable” operations, summoning Russia’s ambassador. Resilience minister Torsten Schack Pedersen warned these incidents and earlier drone incursions expose critical security gaps and bolster calls for a European drone defence network.

articles.title: ‘Money today or blood tomorrow’: EU leaders race to secure deal for Ukraine
articles.trailText: Summit divided on idea of loan secured against Russian assets, as Belgium seeks guarantees if scheme goes wrong
articles.summary: EU leaders at a critical summit debated tapping €210 bn of frozen Russian sovereign assets to extend Kyiv a €90 bn “reparations loan” versus joint EU borrowing to cover an estimated €136 bn gap in 2026–27. Poland, Germany and frugal states favour Russian-asset security; Belgium, which hosts most assets via Euroclear, demands unlimited guarantees against Russian legal retaliation; Italy, Malta and Bulgaria push EU-budget borrowing; Hungary threatens a veto. Zelenskyy pressed for a decision by year-end to avert spring bankruptcy, amid Macron’s, von der Leyen’s and the UK’s calls for swift solidarity. The summit unfolds alongside US-sponsored peace talks involving Trump envoys and Russian officials.

articles.title: Copenhagen’s ‘ghetto law’ may be unlawful, EU court rules
articles.trailText: ECJ ruling gives hope to residents in Copenhagen neighbourhood targeted due to its high percentage of residents with ‘non-western’ backgrounds
articles.summary: In a preliminary ruling, the European Court of Justice found Denmark’s 2018 “parallel societies” or “ghetto law”—which mandates a 40% cut in social housing by 2030, drives demolitions and lease terminations in areas with over half non-western residents and unfavourable socioeconomic conditions—may breach the EU’s race equality directive. The ECJ said Danish courts must now determine whether the law’s neutral wording masks less favourable treatment based on ethnic origin. More than 1,000 tenants in Copenhagen’s Mjølnerparken have already been displaced. Residents, NGOs and human rights bodies hailed the verdict as a pivotal legal victory ahead of a high-court appeal.

articles.title: Thousands to avoid Christmas on streets as Home Office ordered to delay refugee evictions
articles.trailText: Move-on period extended from 28 days to 56 days if person recently granted refugee status is at risk of sleeping rough
articles.summary: UK high court orders the Home Office to extend the move-on period for newly recognized refugees from 28 to 56 days if they face imminent street homelessness, halting around 3,000 planned evictions over Christmas until 16 January. The 2024 pilot had halved rough sleeping, but an August reversion sparked protests by 60 NGOs and a legal challenge. The ruling excludes those already evicted (eg, a 19-year-old Eritrean rough sleeping in London). Campaigners, including the British Red Cross, urge a permanent 56-day rule; the government promises further housing measures like military bases.

articles.title: Brazilian president vows to veto bill cutting Jair Bolsonaro’s prison term
articles.trailText: Lula acknowledges his decision to uphold 27-year sentence could be overridden by conservative lawmakers
articles.summary: Brazil’s leftist president Lula da Silva has pledged to veto a newly passed congressional bill that would slash Jair Bolsonaro’s 27-year sentence—currently requiring a minimum of six years in a closed regime—to just over two years via sentence-combining and early-release mechanisms. Although Bolsonaro’s family, including son Flávio, hailed the partial gains, Lula warned that coup plotters “must pay for their acts,” even as conservative lawmakers may override his veto. The measure also benefits top military officers and hundreds involved in the January 8, 2023, Brasília riots, raising fears of a renewed era of impunity amid widespread public opposition.

articles.title: US announces more than $10bn of arms sales to Taiwan
articles.trailText: Package includes medium-range missiles, howitzers and drones, and has drawn an angry response from China
articles.summary: The Trump administration announced over $10 billion in arms sales to Taiwan, covering 82 HIMARS, 420 ATACMS, 60 self-propelled howitzers, drones, military software, Javelin and TOW missiles, helicopter spares and Harpoon refurbishment kits. China angrily denounced the package as a breach of diplomatic agreements that undermines regional stability and threatens its sovereignty. The State Department says the sale supports Taiwan’s defense modernization and credible deterrence. Taipei’s government welcomed the move, pledging to raise defense spending to 3.3% of GDP next year and to 5% by 2030, although opposition lawmakers have blocked parts of its military budget.

articles.title: Bavarian pensioner lays trap to catch phone fraudster who was out for his gold
articles.trailText: Second ‘exemplary’ success for 85-year-old who had already rumbled bogus police officer demanding €60,000
