articles.summary: An 85-year-old Bavarian in Ingolstadt twice outwitted phone scammers posing as police officers demanding bail money—first ca €60,000 in Sept., then €10,000 in cash plus gold coins in Dec.—by feigning compliance while his daughter alerted local police, who arrested a 20-year-old pickup courier. In both scams, fraudsters claimed a relative was in a fatal accident. Authorities highlighted other recent regional scams: an octogenarian Munich woman who lost €600,000 in cash and gold to a fake doctor and an earlier Ingolstadt case involving €100,000 in stolen gold bars, urging seniors to verify unsolicited calls and protect personal data.

articles.title: Canada’s population drop reflects souring of attitudes to immigration
articles.trailText: A country known for welcoming newcomers has reversed policy as immigration becomes increasingly a partisan issue
articles.summary: Canada’s population fell 0.2% in Q3 2025 to 41.6 million—the first quarterly drop outside the COVID lockdown—after successive governments under Trudeau and Carney cut study permits, migrant work visas and boosted deportations to “get immigration under control.” This reversal follows a policy shift from record intake in 2022 to discipline in 2024, as polling shows immigration support at 30-year lows and growing partisan divides. Economists warn that while per-capita GDP may rise, weaker population growth will drag on broader economic expansion amid affordability and infrastructure strains.

articles.title: UN distances itself from International Women’s Day website winning corporate partnerships
articles.trailText: Sainsbury’s, Barclays and University College London have all drawn on themes created by IWD site run by London business with no link to UN
articles.summary: London marketing firm IWD Support Ltd (formerly Aurora Ventures) operates internationalwomensday.com, presenting itself as the central hub for IWD with minimal reference to its private ownership. Since 2001 it has sold merchandise packs (£184), hosted a £160 “inner goddess” lunch, and forged corporate partnerships with Sainsbury’s, Barclays, UCL, London Eye, BP and EY. It sets annual themes (e.g., Make it Happen 2015; Accelerate Action 2025; Give to Gain 2026) and promotes purple, green and white branding. Organisations and media, including the BBC and Evening Standard, have mistaken its themes and colours for UN guidance. UN Women disavows any link, announcing its own 2025 theme “For ALL women and girls: Rights. Equality. Empowerment.” Universities removed posts after the Guardian probe.

articles.title: Guggenheim scraps Basque Country expansion plan after local protests
articles.trailText: Campaigners celebrate defeat of proposal to extend Bilbao institution into areas including nature reserve
articles.summary: Guggenheim Foundation, Basque government and regional authorities have abandoned plans for a satellite museum at Guernica and within the Urdaibai UNESCO biosphere reserve (designated 1984) after local residents and NGOs—Greenpeace, WWF, SEO/BirdLife, Ecologists in Action—mobilised against the scheme, decrying inadequate consultation and risks to the 22,068-hectare site’s cliffs, marshes and migratory birds. Citing territorial, urban planning and environmental constraints, the foundation scrapped the project and pledged to explore alternative expansion proposals to preserve its international cultural standing —echoing the 1997 flagship Bilbao museum’s post-industrial revival successes—and boost regional economic development.

articles.title: Saudi-backed forces gather on Yemen border as separatists face pressure to pull back
articles.trailText: Southern Transitional Council, backed by UAE, told it could face airstrikes after its recent huge territorial gains
articles.summary: 20,000 Saudi-funded National Shield militia troops gather on Yemen’s eastern border to force the UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council (STC) to pull back from its rapid takeover of Hadramaut, al-Mahra and Abyan. Riyadh warns of possible airstrikes as the STC presses for a return to separate north-south states, controlling key oil fields and ports. UN chief António Guterres cautions that unilateral actions threaten Red Sea and Horn of Africa stability and urges respect for Yemen’s sovereignty. The STC rebuffs Saudi demands, raising the risk of Saudi–UAE proxy clashes. Islah party leaders decry STC forces for undermining state structures and warn of Houthi gains.

articles.title: French court finds ‘twisted’ anaesthetist guilty of killing 12 patients
articles.trailText: Former top medic described as ‘Dr Death’ by prosecutors poisoned 30 people ranging in age from four to 89
articles.summary: French anaesthetist Frédéric Péchier, 53, dubbed ‘Dr Death’, was sentenced to life imprisonment for intentionally poisoning 30 patients and killing 12 between 2008 and 2017 in private clinics in Besançon. Prosecutors revealed he tampered with paracetamol bags and anesthesia pouches to induce cardiac arrests—sometimes resuscitating victims to conceal his crimes and other times targeting patients of rival doctors to undermine them. Victims aged 4–89 endured lasting harm. Péchier denies all charges and has ten days to appeal.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: How pay erosion and job shortages pushed doctors to strike again amid winter flu surge
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: ​The government’s clash with resident doctors has hardened into one of the most bitter public-sector disputes since austerity began
articles.summary: Amid an early flu surge that has pushed the NHS into crisis, 55,000 resident doctors in England launched a five-day strike—their 14th since 2023—after last-ditch talks with ministers collapsed over real-terms pay erosion and a severe shortage of specialty training posts. Despite a 28.9% nominal pay rise over three years, inflation has left doctors worse off than in 2008/09, and just 10,000 training places exist for 40,000 applicants. Health secretary Wes Streeting’s offer to boost posts but defer raises was rejected by 83% of members. With ballots underway for a new mandate and independent mediation urged, the stalemate could extend into 2026, heightening risks for patients and the already overstretched service.

articles.title: ‘Pretty birds and silly moos’: the women behind the Sex Discrimination Act
articles.trailText: In the 50 years since equal rights for women were enshrined in UK law, the campaigners have been reduced to caricatures, or forgotten. But their struggle is worth remembering
articles.summary: In the late 1960s and early ’70s, women journalists like Celia Brayfield and Shirley Conran faced daily sexism at Fleet Street and formed Women in Media to lobby for legal change. They mobilized petition drives, staged a ‘Women’s Parliament’ in Westminster, and even ran a feminist candidate in 1974. Building on wins like the 1968 Ford Dagenham strike and cross-party bills championed by MPs including Joyce Butler, their sustained pressure secured the 1975 Sex Discrimination and Equal Pay Acts and the Equal Opportunities Commission, reshaping UK gender-equality law.

articles.title: EU leaders urged to use frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine’s defence
articles.trailText: Pressure is growing on member states to back a €90bn loan for Kyiv ahead of a Brussels summit
articles.summary: At a Dec 18 EU summit in Brussels, leaders are debating a €90bn funding package for Ukraine’s defense using Russia’s €210bn frozen assets. German Chancellor Merz and European Commission chief von der Leyen back a “reparations loan” from Euroclear-backed borrowing; Belgium’s PM De Wever and Italy’s PM Meloni oppose it without solid legal guarantees, preferring joint EU borrowing—vetoed by Hungary. Polish PM Tusk warned Europe must choose “money today or blood tomorrow.” Belgium fears legal reprisals by Moscow, while EU officials argue only the loan needs a qualified majority and that emergency powers could secure funds. The decision will signal Europe’s stance on collective security and risk of Russian retaliation.

articles.title: Ten years of fortress Europe has served only cruelty, profiteers and racists. The next decade is up to us | Maurice Stierl
articles.trailText: The hard right and far right are the political winners from the migration ‘crisis’, but only because centrist parties keep legitimising them, says migration and border researcher Maurice Stierl
articles.summary: Since 2015 Europe’s endless “migration crisis” has been weaponized by profiteers—Frontex’s budget ballooned from €90m to over €1bn—and the EU’s booming border-industrial complex—while migratory flows remain manageable. Centrist parties in Germany and the UK have adopted hard-line asylum laws to outbid the far right (AfD surging to 26%, Reform UK’s influence), emboldening racist “great replacement” narratives. The 2026 EU pact on migration and asylum will entrench emergency detention and accelerate deportations under vaguely defined “mass influx” rules. Militarized borders, deportations and cruelty erode democracy without solving displacement. The next decade hinges on grassroots resistance: Mediterranean rescues, protests against raids and reclaiming cities for solidarity to counter the authoritarian trajectory.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Drones strike tanker in Russian port, local officials say
articles.trailText: Deaths and damage to ship reported in attack in Rostov-on-Don; Zelenskyy to reportedly push EU plan to use frozen Russian assets. What we know on day 1,394
articles.summary: Ukrainian drones struck a tanker docked in Rostov-on-Don, killing crew members and sparking a fire that damaged a nearby high-rise under construction and two homes. In Zaporizhzhia, Russian air raids wounded at least 32 people, including five children, and a drone strike hit a civilian car. President Zelenskyy travels to Brussels to push an EU plan tapping €90 billion in frozen Russian assets for Ukraine, despite US objections and Kremlin intimidation of Belgian officials over €185 billion at Euroclear. Putin vowed to press on in 2026, while the UK gave sanctioned oligarch Abramovich 90 days to release £2.5 billion for Ukraine or face court action.

articles.title: China to hike tax on condoms in attempt to boost falling birth rate
articles.trailText: From 1 January, contraceptives will be subject to a 13% VAT rate – part of a carrot-and-stick approach by the government to increase births
articles.summary: From Jan 1, China will impose a 13% VAT on condoms and contraceptives, reversing a tax exemption since 1993, as part of a broader strategy to reverse its declining birthrate. The VAT change, buried in a 2024 law to modernize the tax system, coincides with continued incentives—higher child quotas, IVF discounts, childcare subsidies, extended parental leave and an expansion of birth-related health coverage. Critics on social media mock the move as a "stick" offsetting carrots. Experts say the measure is largely symbolic and unlikely to significantly boost fertility, though it signals state expectations for family behavior.

articles.title: Islamic extremism in the Philippines: is it a terrorism hotspot, and which groups are active there?
articles.trailText: Alleged gunmen behind Bondi beach terror attack travelled to the Philippines last month, raising questions for investigators about why they went
articles.summary: Reuters reports that the Bondi beach attack suspects Sajid and Naveed Akram visited Manila and conflict-ridden Mindanao in November, raising inquiries into possible links with local Islamist militants. Southern Philippines has long hosted jihadist factions—Abu Sayyaf, the Maute Group, Bangsamoro Islamic Freedom Fighters and ISIS-East Asia—exploiting dense terrain and porous maritime borders. Although the 2017 Marawi siege and subsequent military offensives plus a 2020 anti-terror law have weakened these groups, sporadic bombings—Jolo church blasts in 2019–20 and a 2023 mass attack—and killings persist around Marawi. The Bangsamoro Autonomous Region stems from a peace deal with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, which renounced violence in 2019.

articles.title: Canada sees large drop in population amid international students crackdown
articles.trailText: Population fell by 0.2% in third quarter – and the only other quarterly decline on record was attributed to Covid limits
articles.summary: Statistics Canada reports a 0.2% population decline in Q3 2025 to 41.6 million — the second on record after 2020 COVID restrictions — driven by Ottawa’s halving of international student permits. Non-permanent residents fell from 7.3% to 6.8% of the population as PM Mark Carney aims to reduce their share to 5% by 2027. The government will admit 395,000 permanent residents in 2025 and slightly fewer thereafter. Economists warn of a major population adjustment affecting rentals, inflation and GDP per capita, while only Alberta and Nunavut saw growth.

articles.title: Population growth is as concerning as overconsumption | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Robin Maynard reponds to an article by George Monbiot
articles.summary: Population advocate Robin Maynard rebukes George Monbiot’s dismissal of population concern as hypocritical or racist, arguing he deflects from affluent overconsumption. She cites IPCC data identifying economic and population growth as leading CO2 drivers, and defenders of family planning as guardians of women’s rights, not proponents of “mass murder.” Maynard warns Monbiot’s rhetoric mirrors xenophobic, extractive nationalist agendas by ignoring gender justice and ecological evidence. Enabling safe family planning and migrant inclusion, she asserts, is essential to stabilise population growth ethically and curb climate change.

articles.title: Belgian politicians and finance bosses targeted by Russian intelligence over seized assets
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Key figures at frozen assets depository among targets of intimidation campaign, say European intelligence agencies
articles.summary: European intelligence agencies warn that Russia’s GRU has orchestrated intimidation of Belgian politicians and senior Euroclear executives—notably CEO Valérie Urbain, now protected by private bodyguards—to dissuade Belgium from approving use of €185bn of the €210bn frozen Russian central bank assets for a €90bn loan to Ukraine. At an EU summit in Brussels, leaders debate legal guarantees for Euroclear reimbursement amid Russian threats of $230bn lawsuits and countermeasures. The UK supports the plan; Ukraine requires $50bn in external finance for 2026 to sustain its defense sector. Belgium has voiced legal concerns and insists on full reimbursement guarantees before committing, while Russia publicly labels asset use as ‘theft’.

articles.title: Scientists log rare case of female polar bear adopting cub: ‘They’re really good moms’
articles.trailText: Canadian researchers tracking bear known as X33991 noticed she had gained a second cub who likely needed help
articles.summary: In Canada's Western Hudson Bay, researchers tracking female polar bear X33991 via GPS discovered a rare adoption: she's now raising two 10-11-month-old cubs, the 13th adoption among 4,600 studied over 45 years. Scientists attribute such 'curious behaviour' to strong maternal instincts prompting females to rescue orphaned cubs. The adoptive family has ventured onto sea ice, where the cubs will learn seal-hunting skills over 1.5 years. Though only three previous adoptees reached adulthood, experts say having a mother boosts survival. Genetic tests on the stray cub may clarify if a litter swap occurred, illuminating polar bear social dynamics.

articles.title: Brigitte Macron faces lawsuit after being filmed using sexist slur at Paris theatre
articles.trailText: More than 300 women file complaint after video shows French first lady calling feminist protesters ‘sales connes’
articles.summary: French first lady Brigitte Macron is facing a public insult lawsuit after being filmed at the Folies Bergère theatre in Paris referring to feminist protesters as “sales connes” (stupid bitches) during a backstage discussion with actor Ary Abittan. 343 women, echoing the symbolic 1971 abortion petition, filed the complaint through groups including Les Tricoteuses Hystériques, accusing Macron of contradicting her pro-women public image. The protesters, organised by Nous Toutes, had disrupted Abittan’s show to denounce a dropped 2021 rape inquiry. Macron apologised for the private nature of her remarks but refused to retract them. Several celebrities have adopted #salesconnes in solidarity with the activists.

articles.title: Sheinbaum urges UN to ‘prevent bloodshed’ after Trump orders Venezuela blockade
articles.trailText: Mexican leader warns of conflict as US president targets sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela
articles.summary: Mexico president Claudia Sheinbaum urged the UN to prevent bloodshed in Venezuela after the US, under Donald Trump, imposed a blockade on sanctioned oil tankers. Washington’s Caribbean deployment, ostensibly against drug trafficking, is seen by Caracas as a move to oust Nicolás Maduro and seize oil. Sheinbaum condemned foreign interference, called for peaceful dialogue, and offered Mexico as host for negotiations. China backed Venezuela’s sovereignty; Chile���s president-elect vowed to end Maduro’s “dictatorship,” and US forces seized a tanker bound for Cuba and China and stationed in Ecuador.

articles.title: Why young people are the big losers in Europe’s dysfunctional housing system
articles.trailText: The EU has unveiled its first-ever housing strategy, but can it rescue a generation shut out of affordable living?
articles.summary: Weak market-based policies have driven EU house prices up 60% since 2010 and rents by 30%, with spikes over 100% in Estonia, Lithuania, Ireland and Hungary. Eurofound reports 30% of 25–34-year-olds still live with parents and spend nearly a third of income on housing; in five countries they spend over 80% on rent. Experts blame financialisation and the rollback of social housing since the 1980s. Rising costs hamper labour mobility and fuel political extremism. The European Commission’s new affordable housing strategy eases state-aid rules, allows rental caps and targets the “missing middle,” though no €300bn investment or anti-speculation measures are yet approved.

articles.title: What action is Trump taking against Venezuela’s oil industry?
articles.trailText: The US president wants a blockade of oil tankers under sanctions to stop them entering and leaving Venezuela
articles.summary: Trump orders a “total and complete blockade” of all Venezuelan oil tankers under US sanctions entering or leaving the country, escalating pressure on Maduro’s main revenue source. Enforcement could involve Coast Guard seizures. This follows recent oil tanker seizures and marks the largest US military buildup in the region since 1989. The administration accuses Maduro of financing crime and terrorism with “stolen” oil; Maduro denies claims. Venezuela exports ~900,000 bpd amid economic collapse. Analysts warn of short-term price spikes, long-term supply shifts as Western firms eye the market.

articles.title: What is the row about the EU using frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine?
articles.trailText: Complex plan would involve EU lending €90bn to Ukraine, which some fear could destabilise Eurozone. Putin says move is akin to ‘theft’
articles.summary: EU leaders on Thursday will vote on using €210 billion of frozen Russian central bank assets—held at Euroclear—to fund a €90 billion loan for Ukraine in 2026–27, repayable only if Russia pays war reparations. The scheme keeps legal Russian ownership to avoid outright confiscation but raises concerns over eurozone stability and investor confidence. Belgium demands full EU guarantees against Russian lawsuits; Hungary threatens to veto budget‐backed alternatives. Chancellor Merz backs the plan amid US aid delays. Russia calls it theft and has launched claims against Euroclear, warning of retaliatory asset seizures.

articles.title: UK gives Abramovich final warning to transfer £2.5bn to Ukraine fund
articles.trailText: Keir Starmer says oligarch must commit funds from sale of Chelsea football club or face court action
articles.summary: UK gives Roman Abramovich 90 days to transfer £2.5bn from his 2022 Chelsea FC sale into a new Ukraine humanitarian foundation or face court, Keir Starmer warned in the Commons. Under a special licence, the frozen proceeds in a UK bank must aid Ukrainian war victims exclusively. Dispute over whether funds can also support Russians has stalled the transfer. Chancellor Rachel Reeves called it “unacceptable” that the cash remains frozen. Legal action is imminent if Abramovich fails to comply. The ultimatum comes ahead of an EU summit on using €90bn of frozen Russian assets to aid Ukraine.

articles.title: Parliamentary Friends of Aukus group sponsored by lobbying firm with high-profile defence clients
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Greens condemn sponsorship of group’s launch by Precision Public Affairs, which represents clients with lucrative contracts with the Australian government
articles.summary: Canberra-based lobbying firm Precision Public Affairs, whose defence clients including Rafael Australia and L3Harris Technologies have secured over $200m in federal contracts since 2022, will foot the bill for the February launch of the Parliamentary Friends of Aukus at Parliament House, featuring Defence Minister Richard Marles. Greens senator David Shoebridge and the Centre for Public Integrity warn this may breach House and Senate rules that ban external sponsorship of friendship groups. Co-convenors MPs Matt Burnell and Aaron Violi were approached for comment. Critics demand transparent funding, disclosure or disbanding to prevent undue industry access.

articles.title: British baker outrages Mexicans with attack on their ‘ugly’ bread
articles.trailText: Food bloggers liken Richard Hart to Christopher Columbus for ‘stomping’ on a country that has welcomed him
articles.summary: British baker Richard Hart, who opened Mexico City’s Green Rhino bakery in June, sparked backlash after calling Mexico’s wheat “highly processed,” torta rolls “white ugly industrial” breads and dismissing the country’s “bread culture” during an April PopFoodie Radio podcast. Food bloggers and chefs such as Tania Medina and influencer Rodrigo Sierra criticized his remarks—likening him to Columbus trampling local traditions—and highlighted the bolillo’s everyday role among diverse Mexican classes and the 600+ native breads including pan de muerto. Amid tensions over gentrification and rising rents, Hart issued an Instagram apology, acknowledging his disrespect as a guest.

articles.title: ‘Trojan horse moment’: anti-rights groups seize chance to fill void left by US aid cuts
articles.trailText: Ultra-conservative Christian organisations look to reshape global health landscape as new aid agreements open door to demands restricting family planning services
articles.summary: January 2025’s abrupt USAID shutdown—83% of programmes eliminated—serves a deliberate “destruction” phase in a far-right plan to reconfigure global health aid. New US bilateral agreements and an expanded global gag rule channel funding to ultra-conservative Christian groups, enforcing the 2020 Geneva Consensus Declaration via the IWH’s Protego project. Through abstinence-only education, natural family planning curricula and faith-based clinics in Guatemala, Uganda and beyond, these initiatives restrict abortion, marginalize modern contraception and CSE, heightening the risk of unsafe abortions and maternal deaths.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: What’s at stake for the BBC as it faces further funding questions
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The BBC is bracing for a high-stakes legal fight after the US president sues over an edited Panorama clip, and questions mount about the broadcaster’s future funding and political vulnerability
articles.summary: The BBC faces a high-stakes legal battle after Donald Trump filed a $10 bn defamation suit in Florida over an edited Panorama clip that spliced two Jan 6 speeches, accusing it of maliciously misleading viewers. The claim threatens licence-fee funding as ministers launch a review of subscription and ad-supported models amid declining fee payers. The BBC has apologized for the “error of judgment” but denies legal liability. Resignations of DG Tim Davie and news chief Deborah Turness highlight political and financial pressures on the broadcaster.

articles.title: East of Zaporizhzhia Ukraine’s drone crews face endless battle to hold the line
articles.trailText: On a frontline where Russia has made the most gains in recent weeks, drone pilots wonder how long they can keep up the fight
articles.summary: On the flat farmland east of Zaporizhzhia (Pokrovske–Huliaipole), Ukraine’s 423rd drone battalion (formed 2024) coordinates FPV and Mavic UAVs via the Delta system to spot and strike Russian infantry, reporting 418 kills in November. Russia counterattacks exploiting autumn fog with 250 kg glide bombs launched by 300 jets—Ukrainian ECM delays 70% of strikes but gives only four minutes’ warning. Despite 10,000 daily missions and drones inflicting 60% of Russian casualties, Ukraine lost six miles in a sudden assault after reserves were depleted. Crews swap 20-minute batteries, hone skills on video games like Stalker 2, and fear pilot attrition will curb this high-tempo defense within months without fresh recruits.

articles.title: A visual guide to the historical maps and temples at the heart of the Thailand-Cambodia conflict
articles.trailText: Border conflict has roots in colonial maps and long-standing ‘sibling rivalry’
articles.summary: Thailand and Cambodia’s century-old border dispute, reignited in summer 2025, stems from colonial-era Franco-Siamese treaties (1904, 1907) and conflicting maps over the Dangrek escarpment. A 1907 French “Annex I” map deviated from watershed-based boundaries to enclose three Khmer temples—Ta Moan Thom, Ta Khwai and especially 11th-century Preah Vihear—within Cambodia. Thailand cites treaty language and the natural watershed to claim the site. A 1962 ICJ ruling awarded the temple core to Cambodia but left adjacent territory undefined. Fuelled by nationalism and “sibling rivalry,” both sides exploit historic documents and strategic tourism routes.

articles.title: The rural towns fighting for survival as New Zealand grapples with a growing exodus
articles.trailText: Ruapehu is emblematic of question facing New Zealand: how to prevent rural regions – and the country at large - from hollowing out
articles.summary: In New Zealand’s Ruapehu region, disrupted snow seasons shrank ski tourism, the century-old Chateau Tongariro closed in 2023 and Winstone Pulp shut two mills in October 2024, laying off over 230 workers in Ohakune and Raetihi. Dozens of shops stand empty and houses are for sale as families leave, mirroring 1,000+ rural job losses since 2023. Local iwi, small businesses and cycle-way investments aim to retrain residents, but experts warn of a hollowing-out without bigger infrastructure and investment.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Peacekeepers could repel Russian forces under ceasefire plan, says Merz
articles.trailText: German Chancellor says this remains a far-off prospect; Zelenskyy says negotiations on peace deal could soon be finalised. What we know on day 1,393
articles.summary: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz told ZDF that under US and European post-ceasefire guarantees, peacekeepers could in certain scenarios repel Russian incursions to secure a demilitarized zone, though implementation remains distant. President Zelenskyy said US-negotiated peace deal terms could be finalized soon, following US officials’ claim of resolving 90% of contested issues in Berlin talks—despite Russia’s absence and Kremlin objections to European participation. Separately, UN rights chief Volker Türk warned of shrinking freedoms in Russian-occupied Ukrainian regions; Russia labelled Deutsche Welle “undesirable”; Zaporizhzhia plant runs on one line amid military disruptions; South Africa seeks repatriation of fighters allegedly tricked to Ukraine.

articles.title: Marshall Islands launches world’s first universal basic income scheme offering cryptocurrency
articles.trailText: Quarterly payments of $200 to be offered via stablecoin or traditional currency in a scheme designed to ease cost of living pressures in the Pacific nation
articles.summary: Marshall Islands has launched world’s first national UBI scheme offering quarterly US$200 to each of its 42,000 citizens via stablecoin or traditional channels, funded from a $1.3bn trust (plus $500m US through 2027) set up after US nuclear tests. Recipients choose bank deposit, cheque or government-backed blockchain wallet; about 60% opted for banks while only a handful use crypto so far. Officials hope the digital option eases delivery across remote atolls, though experts warn of connectivity, governance and financial risks.

articles.title: Pentagon won’t release full video of Caribbean strike that killed two people, Hegseth says
articles.trailText: Legal experts have raised concerns US forces may have committed a war crime by killing survivors of initial strike
articles.summary: Pentagon secretary Pete Hegseth refused to release the unedited, top-secret video of a September strike in the Caribbean that killed two people clinging to their burning boat, citing longstanding DoD classification policy. Democrats led by Chuck Schumer, Chris Coons and Gregory Meeks pressed for full footage in closed briefings but left empty-handed. The attack, part of Trump’s campaign against Venezuela, has sunk over 20 suspected narcotics vessels and killed at least 90, drawing war-crime concerns from legal experts and spurring competing war-powers resolutions in Congress.

articles.title: Serbian president threatens reprisals after plans for Belgrade Trump Tower thwarted
articles.trailText: Development abandoned after Serbian minister indicted over $500m project, in setback for Trump family empire
articles.summary: Serbia’s President Aleksandar Vučić vowed reprisals after prosecutors and protesters halted a planned $500m Trump Tower in Belgrade. The project, backed by the Trump Organization and Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners, was abandoned following the indictment of Culture Minister Nikola Selaković for falsifying paperwork to remove the site’s protected status – the besieged ruins of Milošević’s bombed military HQ. Vučić decried ‘corrupt gangs’ and vowed accountability, while heritage officials hailed a victory for rule of law and public interest. This rare setback underscores tensions between business, politics and cultural preservation.

articles.title: EU to regulate short-term rentals in plan to tackle affordable homes shortage
articles.trailText: Soaring rents and housing costs have priced out young people, key workers and families from many European cities
articles.summary: The European Commission unveiled its first EU-wide plan to ease the affordable housing crisis by drafting legislation by end-2026 to regulate short-term rentals on platforms like Airbnb. It proposes a “white list” of measures—caps on nights, zoning powers—granting local authorities legal certainty without banning holiday lets. Brussels will also allow member states more scope for housing subsidies and study speculation patterns to curb market excesses. The plan, backed by S&D but criticized as vague by Greens, complements a €375bn public/private investment pledge for social and affordable homes.

articles.title: US designates Colombia’s biggest drug cartel Gulf Clan as terrorist organization
articles.trailText: Marco Rubio calls drug-trafficking militia, present in at least 20 of Colombia’s departments, ‘violent and powerful’
articles.summary: The US has designated Colombia’s Gulf Clan (AGC) as a foreign terrorist organisation—its largest drug‐trafficking militia active in over 20 departments, controlling Darién Gap routes. Rooted in far-right paramilitaries, the group’s cocaine revenue funds violent assaults on rivals and communities. Secretary of State Marco Rubio called it “violent and powerful” with thousands of members. The move, first under Trump against Colombian cartels, risks straining ties with President Gustavo Petro amid mutual threats and US lethal strikes on suspected drug vessels. Gulf Clan peace talks stall, hindering Petro’s total peace plan.

articles.title: Peace plans ready to be presented to Russia in days, says Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: US says talks with Ukraine in Berlin have resolved 90% of difficult issues – but no sign Putin willing to compromise
articles.summary: Volodymyr Zelenskyy said after two days of US–Ukraine talks in Berlin that 90% of issues on a proposed peace deal to end Russia’s war have been resolved and that American envoys will soon present five key documents to the Kremlin, including legally binding security guarantees akin to NATO’s Article 5. With Russia absent and still demanding full control of Donbas, the US has floated a compromise of a “free economic zone,” while ruling out ground troops. Zelenskyy warned that if Putin rejects the package, Kyiv will seek further weapons and sanctions.

articles.title: Relief and reward for passengers as Rome’s ‘museum stations’ finally open
articles.trailText: Archaeological treasures revealed during construction at two metro stops led to years of delays
articles.summary: Rome’s Metro C has finally opened two ‘museum stations’—Colosseo-Fori Imperiali beside the Colosseum and Porta Metronia near San Giovanni—after multi-year delays caused by rich archaeological finds. Commuters can now explore a four-level Republican townhouse, an early imperial thermal bath, 28 pre-aqueduct wells filled with jugs, bowls and votive offerings, plus a 2nd-century AD military barracks complete with frescoed commander’s house and mosaic floors. The 3 km extension by Webuild links suburbs to central Rome and promises to unite modern transit with heritage conservation once Porta Metronia’s museum spaces open early next year.

articles.title: Victims of Iran’s 2022 crackdown file criminal complaint against 40 officials
articles.trailText: Claim filed in Argentina alleges crimes against humanity were carried out on Women, Life, Freedom protesters
articles.summary: Survivors and relatives of Iran’s 2022 Women, Life, Freedom protests have filed the first criminal complaint in Argentina against 40 Iranian security officials, alleging crimes against humanity—targeted blinding, arbitrary detention, torture and murder. Coordinated by the Iran Human Rights Documentation Center, the claim invokes Argentina’s liberal universal jurisdiction to investigate live ammunition, paintball and metal-pellet assaults. Key complainants include UK-based Mahsa Piraei, whose mother Minoo Majidi was shot at point-blank range, and blinding victims Kowsar Eftekhari and Mersedeh Shahinkar. They seek criminal accountability and preservation of evidence, not damages.

articles.title: At least three authors withdraw from Hay festival in protest at Machado invite
articles.trailText: Writers cited Machado’s support for Trump’s pressure campaign against Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro
articles.summary: Three authors—Laura Restrepo, Giuseppe Caputo and Mikaelah Drullard—withdrew from January’s Hay festival in Cartagena to protest the invitation of Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado. They cite her support for Donald Trump’s pressure campaign and potential US military intervention in Venezuela, her ties to Latin America’s far right, and her praise for Chile’s incoming ultra-conservative president José Antonio Kast. The festival defended its commitment to open dialogue; Machado, who escaped Venezuela under clandestine and dangerous circumstances, will participate remotely on January 30, and her team declined to comment on the boycott.

articles.title: Court backs ruling that UK unlawfully detained Tamils on Diego Garcia
articles.trailText: British Indian Ocean Territory commissioner’s appeal against decision last year rejected by judges in London
articles.summary: In December 2024 a judge found that over 60 Tamil asylum seekers stranded by a shipwreck en route to Canada were unlawfully detained for three years on Diego Garcia in rat-infested tents, fenced and guarded like a prison. On 16 December 2025, London appeal judges rejected all four grounds of the BIOT commissioner’s challenge, calling his evidence “highly selective.” Solicitors from Leigh Day and Duncan Lewis hailed the ruling as full vindication, noting UK taxpayers paid £108,000 per day and now face multimillion-pound damages. The Foreign Office says it will study the judgment and decide next steps.

articles.title: Arctic endured year of record heat as climate scientists warn of ‘winter being redefined’
articles.trailText: Region known as ‘world’s refrigerator’ is heating up as much as four times as quickly as global average, Noaa experts say
articles.summary: From October 2024 to September 2025, NOAA data shows the Arctic experienced its warmest year in 125 years, with the past decade the hottest on record. Warming at up to four times the global average, the region saw its smallest sea-ice maximum in 47 years and a 95% loss of its oldest, thickest ice since the 1980s. Record precipitation fell mostly as rain, shrinking June snow cover by half and redefining winter by limiting ice growth. Greenland lost 129 bn t of ice, raising sea-level risks and disrupting ecosystems, fisheries and communities. Rain-on-snow layers hinder wildlife foraging and create hazardous travel, while glacier retreats triggered floods in Juneau, Alaska, and dark ocean waters absorb extra heat, amplifying global climate impacts.

articles.title: Mark Carney criticised for using British spellings in Canadian documents
articles.trailText: Linguists say the prime minister’s use of ‘s’ instead of ‘z’ breaks national English conventions
articles.summary: Mark Carney, leveraging his seven years as Bank of England governor, has sparked criticism for using British spellings (e.g. utilisation, colour) in key Canadian documents, including the recent federal budget and a Trump press release. In an open letter, six linguists—university professors and editors—urge the government to adhere to established Canadian English norms, warning that adopting British variants could confuse national spelling conventions. They highlight Canada’s distinct orthography—shaped by Loyalist settlers, British, French, Indigenous influences (e.g. toque, muskeg)—as a source of identity and pride. The PMO declined to comment.

articles.title: Green groups decry EU ‘betrayal’ after vote to reduce oversight of firms
articles.trailText: Social and environmental reporting to be required of fewer companies after EPP aligns with far right to achieve goals
articles.summary: After MEPs voted 428–218 to gut EU sustainability reporting and due diligence rules, social and environmental disclosures now apply only to firms with >1,000 employees and €450m turnover, and due diligence only to those with >5,000 employees and €1.5bn turnover (from 2029). The changes, brokered by the EPP alongside far-right parties and amid US and Qatari pressure, remove harmonised justice access and transition plan obligations. Green groups condemned it as a betrayal, citing corporate abuse victims. Critics accuse Commissioner Warborn of conflicts of interest amid wider Commission-led deregulation under competitiveness and procedural concerns flagged by the ombudsman.

articles.title: Norway’s national oil company facing £53m penalty for oil spills and gas leaks
articles.trailText: Equinor accused of ‘extensive and long-term pollution’ caused by years of inadequate maintenance
articles.summary: Norway's state-owned oil firm Equinor faces a 220m-kroner (£16m) fine and record 500m-kroner (£37m) confiscation order after Økokrim probed extensive and long-term pollution from oil spills and gas leaks at its Mongstad refinery. The probe, launched in 2020 following NGO Bellona's reports, uncovered leaks between 2016–21, including a 40-ton hydrogen sulfide release that could have been fatal. Equinor disputes negligence claims and will contest the penalty in court.

articles.title: Five key moments in the assault on the rights of women and girls in 2025
articles.trailText: Since Trump’s second term began in January, global healthcare, especially for sexual and reproductive health, has been under constant attack
articles.summary: Since President Trump’s second term began in January, rapid executive orders and USAID’s freeze (cutting 83% of programmes) have triggered humanitarian and reproductive crises, with other major donors also slashing aid. Christian-right groups convened alongside the UN Women summit to strategize anti-rights campaigns, while US and European activists led “family values” conferences in Africa promoting conservative “sovereignty.” In July Washington threatened to destroy $10m of contraceptives in Belgium, imperiling 1.4m women’s supplies. In October the US announced plans to expand its global gag rule to governments and multilaterals, risking further erosion of sexual and reproductive health services worldwide.

articles.title: Many Europeans mistakenly think most immigrants are illegal, poll shows
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Seven-country survey finds strong opposition to increasing migration and support for deportations
articles.summary: YouGov’s seven-country poll (Britain, Denmark, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Poland) shows 44–60% of respondents erroneously believe most migrants are in their country illegally, though studies put undocumented rates far lower (e.g. 21% in France). Majorities (49–60%) favor large cuts in migrant numbers; 46–53% support a freeze on new arrivals plus mass departures. Between 64% and 82% oppose any increase. Strong backing exists for deporting rule-breakers, benefit claimants (78–91%), irregular asylum seekers (73–85%) and unskilled visa-holders (66–85%), but little appetite for removing doctors or skilled workers. Concerns span identity, integration and economic trade-offs.

articles.title: How a Brazilian meat tycoon accused of bribery and deforestation became a key player in regional diplomacy
articles.trailText: Joesley Batista is credited as a major force behind the reconciliation between Trump and Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva
articles.summary: Brazilian meat magnate Joesley Batista, twice jailed for corruption and linked to illegal deforestation through his JBS empire, has emerged as an unofficial diplomatic broker. In late November he flew to Caracas on a private jet to lobby Nicolás Maduro amid US intervention threats, though the dictator remains in power. Earlier, Batista spearheaded the rapprochement between Donald Trump and President Lula da Silva, personally meeting Trump to argue for lifting 50% US tariffs on Brazilian imports (especially beef). Backed by JBS’s US arm Pilgrim’s Pride donations, he now wields outsized influence in Brazil’s foreign policy.

articles.title: South Africa in talks with Russia over men ‘tricked’ into fighting in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Government says it received distress calls, as daughter of ex-president Jacob Zuma accused of luring men to frontline
articles.summary: South Africa’s government is negotiating with Russia to repatriate 17 South African and two Botswanan men who were allegedly deceived into joining Russian forces in Ukraine by Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, ex-president Jacob Zuma’s daughter, after being enticed with promises of bodyguard training for uMkhonto weSizwe or personal development courses. Authorities received distress calls in November. Vincent Magwenya says the retrieval process is sensitive and ongoing. Another daughter, Nkosazana Zuma-Mncube, filed a police report accusing Zuma-Sambudla of deceptive recruitment; Zuma-Sambudla counters that she was misled by recruiter Blessing Khoza. On December 5, families protested in Durban, highlighting reports of ill-treatment and forced Russian contracts.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What polar bear DNA tells us about a warming Arctic
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As species across the world struggle to keep pace with global warming, ​how ​do we report the rare glimmers of hope without downplaying the accelerating ecological ​crisis?
articles.summary: The Guardian’s environment reporter Helena Horton explains new research providing the first statistical evidence that polar bears are undergoing DNA changes in response to fossil fuel-driven Arctic warming—a rare example of wildlife adaptation under extreme stress. While this suggests cautious hope, Horton cautions it’s a forced response to habitat destruction, not a solution. She underscores mixed biodiversity trends, the limits of rapid adaptation and the urgent need to slash emissions before further extinctions follow.

articles.title: Libya looks to its past to build a new future as national museum reopens
articles.trailText: It is hoped the institution can help foster new bonds in a fractured nation, but such optimism will be a stretch for some
articles.summary: Tripoli’s National Museum of Libya reopened after 14 years, marked by a spectacular ceremony of fireworks, an Italian orchestra and acrobats. Its four floors showcase cave paintings, 5,000-year-old mummies, Punic tablets and Roman mosaics from Leptis Magna and Sabratha. PM Abdul Hamid Dbeibah ceremonially hammered open the doors, symbolising hope for unity between rival eastern and western administrations. Former antiquities chief Dr Mustafa Turjman stressed the museum’s role in rebuilding national identity, educating youth post-Gaddafi, and bridging regional divides. Despite ongoing security, corruption and oil-dependency challenges, the reopening stands as a cultural catalyst for Libya’s fractured future.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: US offers Nato-style security guarantees to Kyiv
articles.trailText: Trump envoys warn deal will not be on table forever but European leaders say it’s still unclear ‘whether Russia wants peace at all’. What we know on day 1,392
articles.summary: US envoys meeting in Berlin offered Kyiv unprecedented Nato-style security guarantees amid stalled talks on territorial concessions with Russia. Zelenskyy said he will push for new sanctions and long-range weapons if Moscow rejects peace proposals and seeks a Christmas ceasefire on energy strikes. European leaders hailed progress but noted Russia’s silence. A suspected cyberattack hit Germany’s parliament emails. Ukraine’s SBU submarines disabled a Russian Kilo-class sub at Novorossiysk. MI6 warns Putin is stalling. Russia sued Euroclear over frozen assets as the EU readies €210bn to aid Ukraine and convenes a Hague claims conference, plus new oil sanctions.

articles.title: India’s electoral roll revision threatens democracy and Muslims, say critics
articles.trailText: Opposition claims SIR process being used to disenfranchise minority groups to benefit Narendra Modi’s government
articles.summary: India’s ruling BJP is carrying out a Special Intensive Revision (SIR) of voter rolls across nine states and three territories, purportedly to remove deceased or duplicate entries. Critics, led by Congress’s Rahul Gandhi, allege SIR mimics Assam’s NRC to disenfranchise poor and Muslim voters, citing 6.5m removals in Bihar with many alive and legal challenges ongoing. BJP leaders, including Amit Shah, claim SIR protects democracy by expelling 'infiltrators'. In West Bengal, Mamata Banerjee linked the exercise to fear-driven suicides, while southern opposition-led states have also rejected it. Final lists now due February 2026.

articles.title: What did Ukraine peace talks in Berlin achieve – and what happens next?
articles.trailText: US meeting with Ukrainian and European leaders positive on security guarantees, but hardest questions unresolved
articles.summary: In Berlin, US, Ukrainian and European leaders outlined security guarantees for Ukraine’s future peace deal with Russia: a European-led multinational force to protect its air and maritime space, legally binding commitments from the UK and EU to restore peace after attacks, EU accession support, sustained arms-building aid to maintain a peacetime 800,000-strong army, US-led ceasefire monitoring, and reconstruction funding. Next, US envoys Witkoff and Kushner will present these proposals to Moscow. Key obstacles remain: Russia’s rejection of NATO troops on Ukrainian soil and unresolved status of occupied territories that Kyiv refuses to cede long-term.

articles.title: Europe ready to lead ‘multinational force’ in Ukraine as part of US peace plan
articles.trailText: Proposal is part of new package of security guarantees, backed by the White House, that could mark breakthrough in reaching agreement
articles.summary: European leaders from the UK, France, Germany and eight more back a US-proposed peace package that would see a Europe-led “multinational force” in Ukraine to rebuild Kyiv’s army, secure its skies and seas, and support a US-led ceasefire monitoring mechanism. The plan offers ‘article five-like’ legal guarantees, an 800,000-strong Ukrainian force and EU accession support. Zelenskyy praised progress but disputes over the status of Russian-occupied Donbas territories and the Zaporizhzhia plant remain unresolved.

articles.title: Venezuela accuses Trinidad and Tobago of taking part in US seizure of oil tanker
articles.trailText: Maduro regime accuses Caribbean nation of participating in ‘theft of Venezuelan oil’ as tensions mount in region
articles.summary: Caracas has accused Trinidad and Tobago of collaborating with US forces in the Dec 10 interception of the Skipper oil tanker—carrying roughly 2m barrels of heavy crude—labeling it piracy and a violation of international law. T&T’s recent agreement to host US military flights and install a long-range radar spurred the Maduro government to scrap pending gas-supply and Dragon field negotiations, denouncing PM Kamla Persad-Bissessar as an American vassal. T&T defends the radar as anti-crime and military access as logistical rotations, while domestic opposition warns of entanglement in Trump’s campaign against Maduro.

articles.title: Chile’s new far-right head is latest Latin American leader to ride hardline wave to power
articles.trailText: From the US to Hungary to Argentina, rightwing leaders are praising José Antonio Kast’s win in Chile’s presidential race
articles.summary: José Antonio Kast, a far-right Catholic and son of a Nazi party member, won 58.2% of Chile’s presidential runoff, outpolling leftist Jeannette Jara by over two million votes. Lauded by global hard-liners—US senator Marco Rubio, Viktor Orbán, Giorgia Meloni, Javier Milei and Elon Musk—he campaigned on Trump-style pledges: expelling 330,000 undocumented migrants, building walls, trenches and boosting border militarisation. An open admirer of Pinochet, Kast is Chile’s most extreme leader since 1990. Analysts warn his victory heralds democratic backsliding and fuels a regional right-wing, security-first surge modeled on El Salvador’s Bukele and backed by US pressure for tougher measures.

articles.title: Governments and rights groups condemn conviction of Hong Kong activist Jimmy Lai
articles.trailText: UK, EU and Australia say guilty verdict against 78-year-old is further blow to democracy and press freedom in territory
articles.summary: Hong Kong court convicted 78-year-old British citizen and Apple Daily founder Jimmy Lai on one count of conspiracy to publish seditious publications and two of foreign collusion under the 2020 national security law and colonial-era sedition law, risking life in prison. The UK, EU, Australia, US and rights groups decry the politically motivated verdict as an attack on democracy and press freedom, calling for Lai’s immediate release amid concerns over his deteriorating health after five years in detention.

articles.title: Spain to launch €60 monthly nationwide public transport pass
articles.trailText: Bus and train initiative comes as government struggles to survive corruption and sexual harassment allegations
articles.summary: Spain’s socialist-led government will launch a nationwide public transport pass at €60 per month (€30 for under-26s) from mid-January, covering all national bus services and middle-distance and suburban trains. Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez presents it as a tool to transform travel habits and slash commuting costs by up to 60% for about 2 million users. The uncosted initiative echoes Germany’s €49 ticket. Announced amid corruption and sexual-harassment probes targeting his PSOE-led coalition, Sánchez rejects calls for early elections, vows to serve until 2027, and defends his administration’s anti-corruption and feminist credentials.

articles.title: Any Russia-Ukraine deal is doomed without security guarantees, says Starmer
articles.trailText: Prime minister reiterates support for Kyiv as it comes under mounting US pressure to sign up to Trump-backed plan
articles.summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer warned that any Russia-Ukraine peace accord will collapse absent robust Western military guarantees, citing historical failures. He and French President Macron have formed a “coalition of the willing” to back Ukraine alongside the US, while MI6 chief Blaise Metreweli accused Putin of dragging negotiations and distorting history. Starmer reiterated UK readiness to commit troops under a multinational force if logistical support from Washington is secured. Ahead of Berlin talks with EU and NATO leaders, he backed Zelenskiy’s offer to drop NATO membership for “article-5-like” assurances and urged European states to boost defence spending and coordination.

articles.title: Infighting breaks out over departure of Oxfam chief executive Halima Begum
articles.trailText: Split emerges among members of board of trustees over circumstances of charity boss’s exit from organisation
articles.summary: Oxfam GB’s chief executive Halima Begum left amid contested claims of misconduct and bullying after an external review of 32 current and former staff accounts flagged serious leadership breaches. Trustees reportedly voted unanimously to remove her over process violations and interference in safeguarding probes, but Dr Balwant Singh, a trustee, denied being briefed and condemned the media leak as a smear. Staff letters cited restructuring-driven fear of retribution. Oxfam acknowledged unresolved issues around inclusion and pledged cultural reforms. Begum’s lawyers allege a retaliatory “witch-hunt” and say she has filed whistleblower complaints with the Charity Commission.

articles.title: Biden bowl or Milei statuette, anyone? Meloni to put world leaders’ gifts up for auction
articles.trailText: Italian prime minister’s charity sale may also feature presents from Narendra Modi, Viktor Orbán and Volodymyr Zelenskyy
articles.summary: Italian PM Giorgia Meloni will auction 270 diplomatic gifts—valued at around €800,000—through Bertolami Fine Art before Christmas, with proceeds to charity. Stored at Palazzo Chigi, highlights include Javier Milei’s chainsaw-wielding statuette; blue python-skin, gold-heeled shoes from Saudi Italian Business Council’s Kamel Al-Munajjed; Joe Biden’s ceramic bowl; Narendra Modi’s traditional Kerala dress; Viktor Orbán’s porcelain tea set and wine; Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s tablet; Peter Pellegrini’s jewelry box; and Edi Rama’s birthday scarf. Additional items range from Moldovan watercolors and carpets to a skateboard and makeup. By law, gifts over €300 must be declared; Meloni may also list predecessors’ items still in storage.

articles.title: ‘The last bastion before collapse’ – Louvre museum closed as workers begin strike
articles.trailText: Crisis-hit Paris institution still reeling from jewel heist is in dispute over staffing, renovations and ticket price rises
articles.summary: The crisis-hit Louvre closed on 15 December as 2,100 staff began a rolling strike demanding urgent renovations, increased staffing and a reversal of a 45% ticket-price hike for non-EU visitors. Unions say recent failures—a €88m crown-jewels heist, a damaging water leak in the Egyptian department and ceiling safety fears—exposed years of underinvestment and 200 job cuts. They criticize Macron’s plan for a new entrance over building restoration, and accuse management of discrimination by charging higher fees to US, British and Chinese tourists. France’s state auditor and security adviser have flagged “woefully inadequate” upgrades, and workers warn the museum risks collapse at peak season if conditions don’t improve.

articles.title: Women who say they were tricked into servitude for Opus Dei to meet in Argentina
articles.trailText: Pope urged organisers to hold conference after 43 women alleged they were exploited as minors by Catholic group
articles.summary: An inaugural conference in Buenos Aires will gather 43 former minors who allege they were lured into Opus Dei schools with education promises but forced into unpaid domestic labor from 1972 to 2015. Under allegations of trafficking and coercive control—censored mail, restricted visits, intense labor—the women have prompted an Argentine federal probe and a Vatican review of Opus Dei’s statutes. Pope Leo XIV privately urged the event, and survivors hope it spurs a formal statement, institutional reforms, and progress in the trafficking case stalled by delayed testimonies.

articles.title: Russia seeks $230bn in damages from Euroclear over seized assets
articles.trailText: Kremlin aims to fire warning shot against EU’s plan to use €90bn of frozen funds to give loan to Ukraine
articles.summary: Russia’s central bank launched an 18 trn rouble ($230 bn) lawsuit against Euroclear, warning against the EU’s plan to lend €90 bn to Ukraine using €185 bn of frozen Russian assets held in Brussels. EU leaders debate a larger €210 bn loan option, which Moscow calls theft, threatening to retaliate by seizing European investors’ Russian holdings. Russia may enforce judgments in friendly jurisdictions like China or the UAE. Brussels is crafting legal safeguards and exploring alternative EU borrowing amid Hungary’s opposition. EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas calls the reparations loan the “most credible” taxpayer-free solution.

articles.title: Hong Kong: Jimmy Lai facing life in prison after conviction on security charges
articles.trailText: Rights groups dismiss ‘sham conviction’ of media tycoon on national security offences in city’s most closely watched rulings in decades
articles.summary: Media tycoon Jimmy Lai, 78, was convicted under Hong Kong’s 2020 national security law and colonial-era sedition law—one count of seditious publications conspiracy and two foreign collusion charges—and faces life imprisonment. Government-picked judges branded him the “mastermind” of plots to destabilize Beijing; his Apple Daily entities were also found guilty. Britain condemned the conviction as politically motivated, rights groups decried it as a sham crackdown on press freedom, and Lai, jailed since 2020, is due to appeal on 12 January. The verdict precedes a planned visit by the UK prime minister.

articles.title: Monday briefing: The latest on the deadly attack on Bondi beach’s Jewish community
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: On Sunday evening local time, two gunmen opened fire on a gathering at Sydney’s famous beach – here’s what we know so far
articles.summary: On Dec 14 2025 in Sydney, father-son duo Sajid (50) and Naveed Akram (24) targeted a Hanukkah event at Bondi Beach’s Archer Park, killing 16 people (including a child and Rabbi Eli Schlanger) and injuring 42 others before police fatally shot Sajid and hospitalized Naveed. Witnesses described chaos as hundreds fled; a bystander’s tackle disarmed one gunman. NSW police declared an antisemitic terrorist incident, uncovering IEDs in a vehicle. PM Anthony Albanese condemned it as “evil antisemitism,” pledged stricter gun controls and license audits; state leaders to meet on reforms.

articles.title: Assad family live in Russian luxury as Bashar ‘brushes up on ophthalmology’
articles.trailText: Family friend, sources in Russia and Syria, and leaked data help give rare insight into life of dictator’s reclusive household
articles.summary: Deposed in December 2024, Bashar al-Assad and his family now live in sequestered luxury in Moscow’s Rublyovka (with occasional UAE visits), their wealth shielded from Western sanctions. Barred by the Kremlin from politics or media, Assad studies Russian and refreshes his ophthalmology skills, eyeing wealthy Moscow clients. His wife Asma recovered from leukemia under Russian security-service care, while children like Zein (MGIMO graduate) and Hafez adapt to elite exile life. Cut off from former cronies and Putin’s inner circle, the Assads lead a quiet, controlled existence as they plan a calibrated media return.

articles.title: The rise and fall of Jimmy Lai, whose trajectory mirrored that of Hong Kong itself
articles.trailText: Progressing from child labourer to billionaire, Lai used his power and wealth to promote democracy, which ultimately pitted him against authorities in Beijing
articles.summary: On Monday a Hong Kong court convicted 78-year-old media tycoon Jimmy Lai of national security offences, ending a landmark trial that mirrored the city’s democratic rise and fall. From garment-factory child labourer to billionaire behind Giordano and Apple Daily — dubbed the “Rupert Murdoch of Asia” — Lai was politicised after Tiananmen in 1989 and funded 2003 security law protests, 2014 Occupy Central and 2019 anti-extradition movement. Attacked, arrested since 2020 and forced to close his outlets, he was convicted of sedition and foreign collusion, risking a life term and symbolising Hong Kong’s lost freedoms.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Britain’s spy chief to warn of Russia’s ‘expansionist threat’ as Berlin talks enter second day
articles.trailText: MI6 chief to deliver remarks on Monday warning ‘chaos is a feature not a bug in the Russian approach’; European leaders to join day two of talks in Berlin. What we know on day 1,391
articles.summary: MI6 chief Blaise Metreweli, in her first address, brands Russia an “aggressive, expansionist, revisionist” threat and vows sustained UK support, warning its “export of chaos” will persist. Gen. Richard Knighton urges a “whole society” defence approach and cautions a possible Russian invasion of NATO territory. In Berlin, President Zelensky calls for a “dignified” peace with reliable security guarantees and debate over a front-line ceasefire, while US envoy Steve Witkoff reports “a lot of progress”. Ukraine’s NATO forgo is deemed inconsequential. The Kremlin blasts NATO’s Rutte, a drone-related fire hits Afipsky refinery, and Russia claims Varvarivka.

articles.title: Ultra-conservative José Antonio Kast elected Chile’s next president
articles.trailText: The son of a Nazi party member and an admirer of Pinochet, Kast built his campaign on a promise to expel tens of thousands of undocumented migrants
articles.summary: Ultra-conservative ex-MP José Antonio Kast won Chile’s presidency with 58.16% against leftist Jeannette Jara’s 41.84%. The son of a Nazi party member and Pinochet admirer, Kast built his campaign on expelling some 330,000 undocumented migrants, erecting Trump-style walls, trenches and detention centers, and beefing up military border patrols to curb rising violence. A staunch Catholic who opposes abortion and same-sex marriage, he vows “firmness” on crime and illegal immigration but will face a fragmented Congress. Allies include Trump-aligned Marco Rubio and Argentina’s Javier Milei; Kast also promises $6bn in budget cuts, though details remain unclear.

articles.title: Far-right José Antonio Kast favored to win as Chile votes in presidential runoff
articles.trailText: Trump-inspired former congressman expected to succeed Gabriel Boric but compulsory voting could create volatility
articles.summary: In Chile’s presidential runoff ultra-conservative José Antonio Kast, a Trump-inspired former congressman and Pinochet admirer who vows to expel undocumented migrants, build border walls, and curb abortion and same-sex marriage, is favored over centre-left ex-labour minister Jeannette Jara. Despite Jara’s first-round plurality and her own iron-fist proposals—new prisons and biometric migrant registration—Kast leads in polls mobilised by compulsory voting. Analysts warn votes of outsider Franco Parisi’s 20% share are unpredictable amid heightened migration and crime anxieties.

articles.title: US wargames played out scenarios for Maduro’s fall. None of them ended well for Venezuela
articles.trailText: Venezuelan politicians battling to end Maduro’s rule reject claims his downfall would thrust their country into maelstrom of bloodshed and retribution
articles.summary: Declassified US war games in 2019 foreshadowed three end-of-Maduro scenarios—mass revolt, palace coup or US decapitation strike—all leading to protracted violence: military repression, rival power struggles, guerrilla attacks and deepening refugee flows. Latin America experts warn of fragmented insurgencies, ELN involvement, infrastructure sabotage and mercenary deployment if intervention occurs. Venezuelan opposition leaders, including María Corina Machado and Miguel Pizarro, dispute the inevitability of bloodshed, urging negotiated transition and limited purges, though analysts caution any post-Maduro path risks years of chaos.

articles.title: ‘Like a mini Louvre’: two generations of Rothschilds fight over treasure trove of artworks
articles.trailText: Baronesses Nadine and Ariane de Rothschild at odds over the future of Swiss chateau’s priceless contents
articles.summary: Rothschild feud over Chateau de Pregny art trove: Nadine, 93, claims her late husband Edmond bequeathed her Louis XVI furniture and paintings by Goya, Rembrandt, El Greco, Boucher within the \"mini Louvre\" to endow her Geneva museum via Edmond & Nadine de Rothschild Foundation. Daughter-in-law Ariane (60) insists the intact collection stay at the family estate. Ariane alleges Nadine is unduly influenced, invoking parallels with Liliane Bettencourt's inheritance saga. Two lawsuits: Ariane failed to bar Nadine using Edmond’s name; Nadine barred from château. Third suit battles ownership. Dispute split generations and complexities of inheritance, influence claims and museum vs private trust.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: US envoy to meet Zelenskyy, Europe leaders in Berlin
articles.trailText: White House official confirms Trump’s envoy Steve Witkoff will meet with Zelenskyy and European leaders this weekend.
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff will meet President Zelenskyy and European leaders in Berlin this weekend to press for a ceasefire plan, following Germany-hosted talks. Kyiv seeks a political peace agreement as Moscow demands Ukrainian withdrawal from parts of Donetsk. Overnight Russian strikes—450 drones, 30 missiles—hit energy and ports, causing outages, a silo blaze in Odesa and wounding two. Germany will send engineers to fortify Poland’s eastern border. Polish police evacuated a threatened Kyiv-bound train. Ukraine’s navy blamed Russia for a drone attack on Turkish vessel VIVA. Belarus released 114 Ukrainian POWs.

articles.title: Special delivery: how a Royal Mail postbox ended up in Antarctica
articles.trailText: A letter to the king has added a royal flourish to life at Rothera Research Station, where mail remains a vital link to the world
articles.summary: Kirsten Shaw, station support assistant at the UK’s Rothera Research Station in Antarctica, successfully petitioned King Charles III for a genuine red ‘lamp’ Royal Mail postbox to replace a makeshift model. Fitted with the new royal cipher, it will collect postcards and letters—crucial morale-boosters for staff facing infrequent mail runs (three or four per year via ship or BAS flights through the Falklands). Stamps cost just 87p to the UK, and mail remains a festive lifeline amid Christmas movie nights, quidditch matches and isolated field operations.

articles.title: Belarus releases 123 prisoners including opposition leaders after US lifts sanctions
articles.trailText: Nobel prize winner Ales Bialiatski and opposition figure Maria Kalesnikava among those freed after US talks with Alexander Lukashenko
articles.summary: Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko released 123 prisoners – including Nobel laureate Ales Bialiatski, opposition leader Maria Kalesnikava and ex-candidate Viktar Babaryka – after the US lifted potash sanctions following two days of talks by President Trump’s envoy John Coale. The largest release since 2021 marks a Western rapprochement aimed at weakening Russia’s grip. Many freed detainees suffered health decline amid alleged mistreatment; relatives gathered at the US embassy in Vilnius, and Ukraine received 114 civilians. Opposition figures hailed US pressure but urged EU sanctions to remain. Minsk denies holding political prisoners even as 1,227 remain jailed, per rights group Viasna.

articles.title: Thailand denies Trump ceasefire claim as clashes with Cambodia continue at border
articles.trailText: Thai PM says military will keep fighting and Cambodia suspends border crossings as casualties rise
articles.summary: Thailand’s caretaker PM Anutin Charnvirakul denied any ceasefire agreement with Cambodia, countering Donald Trump’s announcement of a US-brokered halt following calls with Thai and Cambodian leaders and Malaysia’s mediation. Heavy border clashes resumed after a Dec 7 firefight, with Thailand deploying fighter jets and Cambodia firing BM-21 rockets. At least 15 Thai soldiers and an estimated 165 Cambodian troops killed, 11 civilians dead and two injured; over 500,000 displaced. Cambodia suspended border crossings; both sides dispute who fired first as diplomatic efforts continue. Thai warships shelled Koh Kong province, and the Thai army said it destroyed a crane near the contested Preah Vihear temple, citing its use for military command.

articles.title: Wes Streeting calls for ‘cross-party consensus’ on gender identity ahead of puberty blocker trial
articles.trailText: Health secretary wrote to Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch, urging her to ‘take heat and ideology’ out of debate
articles.summary: Health Secretary Wes Streeting has urged Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch to preserve the cross-party consensus of the April 2024 Cass review on under-18 gender identity services and to remove ideological heat from debate over a new puberty blocker trial. The £10.7m King’s College London study will follow more than 200 young people with gender dysphoria alongside a non-treatment control group. While Badenoch and shadow minister Stuart Andrew question the drugs’ efficacy and warn of risks like infertility, Streeting—though “deeply uncomfortable” pausing natural puberty—insists ethical approval and robust evidence are essential for children’s care.

articles.title: ‘Chalk Revolution’ strikes nerve as Slovakia fears return to authoritarian past
articles.trailText: Teenager who first scrawled messages on pavement in protest at rightwing government did not expect so many others to follow suit
articles.summary: Teenager Michal ‘Muro’ sparked Slovakia’s “Chalk Revolution” in early November by scrawling “Enough Fico” and a joke about sexual favours for Putin on Poprad pavements ahead of PM Robert Fico’s lecture. Police briefly questioned him, but social media propelled hundreds of similar messages nationwide—peaking around the 1989 Velvet Revolution anniversary—fueling rallies against corruption, democratic backsliding and Fico’s pro-Russian stance in his fourth term. Although cold weather slowed chalking, activists plan renewed protests before the 2027 elections, warning of an authoritarian relapse.

articles.title: C of E responds to Tommy Robinson’s carols event with ‘Christmas is for all’ message
articles.trailText: Release of 43-second video comes as senior church figures speak out against dangers of Christian nationalism
articles.summary: The Church of England released a 43-second “Christmas Isn’t Cancelled” video featuring over 20 voices—from the archbishop of York to schoolchildren—affirming joy, love and hope and that Christmas “belongs to all,” in direct response to far-right activist Tommy Robinson’s Westminster carols event. Senior bishops including Rowan Williams, Arun Arora, Anderson Jeremiah and Southwark leaders warn against Christian nationalism, anti-migrant rhetoric and the weaponisation of faith. They urge Christians to uphold hospitality, kindness and diversity, as counter-protests and inclusive worship services are organised to resist exclusionary agendas.

articles.title: New Israeli barrier will slice through precious West Bank farmland
articles.trailText: Palestinians who have worked the ‘breadbasket’ area for generations face being replaced by Israeli settlers
articles.summary: On Dec 4, Palestinians in Atouf received eviction orders giving them seven days to vacate 85% privately owned farmland for a new military road and barrier, part of Israel’s 5.5 bn-shekel, 500 km “Crimson Thread” project from the Golan to Eilat. The 22 km first section severs irrigation pipes and will enclose communities in 50 m roads plus 200 m no-go zones. Israel claims security, but human rights groups and locals see land grab and ethnic cleansing. Appeals lodged in Israeli courts are pending as settlers plan to occupy fertile plots once farmed for generations.

articles.title: EU to freeze €210bn in Russian assets indefinitely
articles.trailText: The decision is a significant step towards using the cash to aid Ukraine’s defence – but Moscow is threatening to retaliate
articles.summary: The EU has used emergency powers to indefinitely freeze €210 billion of Russia’s central bank assets, ending the need for six-month renewals vulnerable to veto. Russia’s central bank has sued Euroclear over the immobilisation. Brussels is split: Belgium, Bulgaria, Malta and Italy demand legal guarantees before approving a proposed €90 billion loan to Ukraine secured by these assets, while Germany and the UK back the scheme and offer guarantees. EU leaders will decide at next week’s summit as Kyiv faces looming funding shortfalls.

articles.title: US treasury lifts sanctions on Brazilian judge who presided over Bolsonaro case
articles.trailText: Justice Alexandre de Moraes and his wife had been under Global Magnitsky sanctions after conviction of ex-president
articles.summary: The US Treasury has lifted Global Magnitsky sanctions on Brazilian Supreme Court Justice Alexandre de Moraes and his wife Viviane Barci de Moraes, imposed since July and September for de Moraes’s role in convicting ex-president Jair Bolsonaro to 27 years. The delisting follows President Lula’s push in negotiations with Donald Trump to roll back 50% tariffs on Brazilian imports. The decision undermines Bolsonaro and his son Eduardo’s lobbying in Washington. Eduardo lamented the removal but vowed on social media to keep fighting. Bolsonaro is incarcerated in Brasília, and a lower-house bill that could cut his closed-cell term now awaits senate approval.

articles.title: Danish intelligence accuses US of using economic power to ‘assert its will’ over allies
articles.trailText: The US is also listed as a threat due to its interest in Greenland, which the Trump administration has claimed is vital to America’s national security
articles.summary: In its 2025 annual assessment, the Danish Defence Intelligence Service for the first time names the US a security threat, accusing Washington of leveraging economic and technological power—including high‐tariff threats—and even military coercion against allies. It warns that intensifying great‐power competition in the Arctic, especially US interest in Greenland, heightens espionage and cyber risks across the Danish realm. The report notes concern over the US’s role as Europe’s security guarantor and potential Russian hybrid attacks, yet DDIS chief Thomas Ahrenkiel still calls America Denmark’s closest ally under its nuclear umbrella.

articles.title: The importance of Europe in curbing Russia’s might | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Europe must realise its superior economic and military potential has to be mobilised, writes Bill Jones, while Robin Wilson addresses Belgium’s resistance to seizing Russian assets
articles.summary: Bill Jones warns that with the US under Trump deprioritising European defense and sowing doubt in NATO’s nuclear deterrent, Russia under Putin may be tempted to expand its sphere of influence—from Ukraine to the Baltic states. He urges Europe to mobilise its superior economic and military resources to secure Ukraine and broader stability, invoking the 1930s lesson that ignoring existential threats leads to catastrophe. Robin Wilson adds that Belgium’s refusal to seize frozen Russian assets stems from the fear of crippling legal liabilities, and he criticises other EU members for not sharing the potential financial burden.

articles.title: Nobel peace prize laureate Narges Mohammadi arrested in Iran
articles.trailText: Mohammadi ‘violently’ detained along with other activists at memorial event in Mashhad, her foundation says
articles.summary: At a memorial in Mashhad for human rights lawyer Khosro Alikordi, suspiciously found dead, 2023 Nobel peace laureate Narges Mohammadi, 53, was violently detained alongside activists by Iranian security using teargas and force. Released on medical leave in December 2024 after heart attacks and surgery, her health risks worsening. She had been jailed since 2021 for opposing capital punishment and the hijab mandate, with her suspended sentence extended amid Western pressure. Her husband, Taghi Rahmani, supporters and over 80 lawyers demand her immediate release and a probe into Alikordi’s death.

articles.title: Canada’s Liberals edge closer to majority after Conservative lawmaker crosses floor
articles.trailText: Rookie Michael Ma leaves Conservative party for ‘steady, practical approach’ of Mark Carney’s government
articles.summary: Rookie MP Michael Ma has left the Conservative caucus to join PM Mark Carney’s Liberals, citing the government’s ‘steady, practical approach’ and focus on affordability and the economy. His defection lifts Liberal seat count to 171—one short of a majority. Tory leader Pierre Poilievre accused Ma of betraying his voters, while government house leader Stephen MacKinnon hinted at further Conservative defections amid frustration with party leadership. The move follows three recent Tory departures and comes as Carney faces internal dissent over an Alberta-Pacific oil pipeline after Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault resigned in protest.

articles.title: ‘What is going on here?’ Meloni celebrated at Italy’s far-right Atreju Christmas festival
articles.trailText: Week-long event organised by Brothers of Italy looks like winter wonderland but is chance for PM to flaunt power
articles.summary: At Atreju, the Brothers of Italy’s week-long Christmas festival in Rome’s Castel Sant’Angelo gardens, rooted in neo-fascist National Alliance youth debates, PM Giorgia Meloni blends festive attractions—ice rinks, mulled wine, Santa’s elves—with political propaganda: a “bullyometer” mocking leftist critics, celebratory tributes to far-right allies like Charlie Kirk and historical fascist imagery.
