The event, featuring Steve Bannon, Elon Musk, Marion Maréchal and oppositional figures such as Matteo Renzi and Giuseppe Conte, doubles as Meloni’s power showcase—highlighting meetings with Macron, Starmer, von der Leyen and Trump, touting tough migrant and crime policies amid Civicus’s civic-freedoms downgrade and managing dissent with security crackdowns.

articles.title: Machado escape planner feared US strike on her vessel as it fled Venezuela
articles.trailText: Special forces veteran Bryan Stern says he told US defence officials some of his planned route to reduce airstrike risk
articles.summary: Venezuelan opposition leader and Nobel laureate María Corina Machado, forced into hiding after Maduro’s disputed 2024 re-election, escaped Venezuela on a clandestine 5,500-mile sea and air route masterminded by US special forces veteran Bryan Stern. Facing 10ft waves, a disabled GPS, and the threat of a US anti-narco airstrike, her fishing skiff eluded radar until rendezvousing with a larger vessel to Curaçao, before flying via the US to Oslo for the Nobel ceremony. Financed by private donors, the operation required deconfliction with US defense at risk of symbolic arrest on return.

articles.title: ‘Transition is irreversible’: María Corina Machado says not too late for Maduro’s peaceful handover
articles.trailText: Nobel peace laureate says Maduro’s political downfall is inevitable after her fraught journey to freedom by boat
articles.summary: María Corina Machado, Nobel Peace Prize winner, insists Nicolás Maduro’s exit is irreversible and urges a negotiated, peaceful transition. Speaking in Oslo after fleeing Venezuela by boat, she dismissed comparisons to Syria or Libya, citing Venezuela’s social cohesion. She highlighted intensifying US pressure – a $50m bounty on Maduro, Caribbean military build-up, sanctions on his in-laws and oil tankers – and the recent US seizure of a Venezuelan oil shipment. Despite Maduro’s 2024 election crackdown, secret talks with Trump and Lula’s mediation bid signal shifting regional dynamics. Machado’s camp plans González as president and invites her as vice-president, confident security forces will comply.

articles.title: Indonesia floods were ‘extinction level’ disturbance for world’s rarest ape
articles.trailText: Conservationists fear up to 11% of Tapanuli orangutan population perished in disaster that also killed 1,000 people
articles.summary: Late-November floods in North Sumatra dumped over 1,000 mm of rain in four days, killing an estimated 33–54 of the fewer than 800 wild Tapanuli orangutans (6–11% of the population). The disaster carved gashes across nearly 4,000 ha of intact forest—already threatened by mining, palm oil and hydropower—and delivers an unprecedented “extinction‐level disturbance.” Scientists warn the species’ path to extinction has steepened and call for an immediate halt to habitat-damaging projects, rapid surveys, expanded protections and forest restoration.

articles.title: UK imposes sanctions on four RSF officers for ‘heinous’ mass killings in Sudan
articles.trailText: Senior commanders accused of atrocities against civilians face asset freezes – but no action against key backer UAE
articles.summary: UK imposes asset freezes and travel bans on four senior RSF commanders—Abdul Rahim Hamdan Dagalo, Gedo Hamdan Ahmed, Al-Fateh Abdullah Idris and Tijani Ibrahim Moussa Mohamed—accused of mass executions, sexual violence and attacks on El Fasher civilians during an 18-month siege. The measures follow evidence including social-media videos and mirror recent EU sanctions, though the UAE and RSF leader Mohamed Hamdan 'Hemedti' Dagalo escape censure amid UK preference for private pressure. Britain warns of conflict spill-over, cites up to 60,000 killed, and pledges an extra £20 million to aid 150,000 people. A UK-led UN resolution now mandates an inquiry into atrocities.

articles.title: Friday briefing: How the Free Birth Society’s ​philosophy ​contributed to a ​preventable ​death
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The Guardian’s new podcast, The Birth Keepers, explores how a global network promoting unassisted childbirth has shaped women’s decisions​ around childbirth. One mother’s story stands as a stark warning
articles.summary: The Guardian’s new podcast series ‘The Birth Keepers’ examines how the US-based Free Birth Society’s anti-medical ethos—promoted via podcasts, social media and online schools—led Lorren Holliday to attempt an unassisted home birth despite warning signs. Advised to avoid doctors, ultrasounds and midwives, she endured six days of intense labor, ignored meconium distress indicators and had pleas for help deleted. When she finally sought hospital care, her baby was stillborn. Medical experts call it a preventable death fueled by FBS’s extreme messaging.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: ‘Terrorist’ attack kills serviceman in Kyiv and injures four
articles.trailText: Explosion of improvised bomb was followed by a second as police and medics arrived, say prosecutors; drones hit major Russian military chemical maker. What we know on day 1,388
articles.summary: Two improvised bombs exploded in Kyiv, killing a National Guard serviceman and wounding four, including two police officers, in a “terrorist” attack that detonated a second device as first responders arrived. Ukrainian drones struck chemical plants in Novgorod and Smolensk producing explosive components. Ukraine denied Russian claims to control Siversk amid ongoing Donbas fighting; ISW reported recent advances near Pokrovsk and in Kharkiv. Nato’s Rutte warned Europe is Russia’s “next target.” The EU approved freezing €210 bn of Russian assets to fund Ukraine. Kim Jong-un praised North Korean troops’ role in Ukraine, Zelenskiy rejected a U.S. plan for unilateral Ukrainian withdrawal in Donbas, and Trump signalled U.S. participation in upcoming ceasefire talks if progress seems possible.

articles.title: Dozens killed in hospital strike in Myanmar’s western Rakhine state
articles.trailText: Conflict monitors say the junta has increased airstrikes year-on-year since the start of Myanmar’s civil war
articles.summary: On Dec. 11, Myanmar junta aircraft struck Mrauk U General Hospital in western Rakhine’s Mrauk U township, killing at least 31 and wounding 68 as the 300-bed facility overflowed amid suspended services, aid workers and Arakan Army spokespeople report. UN rights chief Volker Türk warned such hospital bombings may constitute war crimes; the US State Department condemned the "disturbing" violence against civilians. The attack – part of a year-on-year surge in airstrikes since the 2021 coup – underscores a pre-election offensive ahead of polls starting Dec. 28, which the AA, controlling most of Rakhine, vows to contest.

articles.title: Trump expands Venezuela sanctions as Maduro decries new ‘era of piracy’
articles.trailText: Six more oil supertankers added to sanctions list, as well as members of Maduro’s extended family, amid rising tensions following tanker seizure
articles.summary: Donald Trump on Dec 11, 2025 expanded sanctions on Venezuela, blacklisting six oil supertankers—including four Panama-flagged vessels—and three nephews of first lady Cilia Flores after the US Coast Guard seized the ‘dark fleet’ tanker Skipper off Venezuela’s coast. The Treasury accused the ships of deceptive practices funding Maduro’s narco-terrorist regime. Trump warned of future strikes on overland drug routes. Maduro denounced the seizure as “criminal naval piracy,” secured Russian backing, and regional leaders from Colombia to Brazil explored asylum and transitional solutions amid fears of escalation.

articles.title: Papua New Guinea grapples with HIV epidemic as it battles stigma and US aid cuts
articles.trailText: Papua New Guinea has one of the fastest growing HIV epidemics in the Asia-Pacific region, with many unaware they have the virus
articles.summary: Papua New Guinea faces one of Asia-Pacific’s fastest HIV epidemics, with new infections doubling since 2010 and only 59% aware of their status. Maternal-child transmission rates rank among the world’s highest, leading PNG to declare HIV a national crisis in June and launch an emergency response for increased testing, treatment and outreach. Sharp cuts in US foreign aid and global UNAids funding have forced over 200 clinics to scale down or close, disrupting antiretroviral supply and community programmes. Australia’s extra A$10m and partial USAID funding restoration offer relief, but advocates urge PNG to secure K45-50m (US$10m) annually for sustainable domestic HIV control.

articles.title: ‘It’s not going to end’: Thai evacuees fear for future after fresh clashes with Cambodia
articles.trailText: Displaced people in Thailand voice doubts that Donald Trump can stop the fighting as violence flares on the border
articles.summary: After Trump-brokered ceasefire collapsed again, over 500,000 people in Thailand and Cambodia have been forced to flee homes into crowded temples and schools. Locals like Rangsan Angda and Patcharee Kotmakti doubt lasting peace despite Trump’s promise to pressure leaders, highlighting economic hardship and skepticism of third-party mediation. Analysts warn Thailand’s 2026 election could drive PM Anutin Charnvirakul toward nationalist rhetoric to maintain support. With families reliant on daily wages and wary of negotiations, many fear the border clashes will persist, straining livelihoods and regional stability.

articles.title: US wants Ukraine to withdraw from Donbas and create ‘free economic zone’, says Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president says plan would not be fair without guarantees that Russia would not simply take over zone
articles.summary: President Zelenskyy revealed that the US has proposed Ukraine withdraw its troops from Donbas in exchange for establishing a ‘free economic zone’ under frozen frontline conditions, barring further Russian advance. He warned such a compromise demands firm guarantees and a Ukrainian referendum to prevent Russian takeover. Under the plan, Kherson and Zaporizhzhia lines stay fixed, Russia relinquishes minor enclaves, and security and Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant control remain key sticking points. Trump is pressing Kyiv to sign, while EU leaders and Nato’s Rutte call for fair Ukrainian-led decisions. Concurrently, Lviv talks reiterated Ukraine’s EU accession despite Orbán’s blockade.

articles.title: UK MPs face rise in phishing attacks on messaging apps
articles.trailText: Hackers include Russia-based actors targeting WhatsApp and Signal accounts, parliamentary authorities warn
articles.summary: UK parliamentary authorities warn that MPs, peers and officials face a surge in phishing attempts on WhatsApp and Signal from Russia-based actors. Attackers pose as app support, asking for access codes, links or QR scans to harvest messages, download contact lists and monitor activity undetected. Despite October NCSC guidance, incidents persist. MPs are urged to stop using commercial messaging for official work, switch to Microsoft Teams, enable two-factor authentication, audit linked devices and register with the NCSC for compromise alerts. The warning follows past Star Blizzard operations and a recent “Abigail” WhatsApp spear-phishing probe.

articles.title: Dushan Chimbur obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Supporter of the Lifeline Humanitarian Organisation who arrived in the UK soon after the second world war as a displaced person
articles.summary: Dushan Chimbur (1928–2025) arrived in the UK as a displaced person via the British European Voluntary Workers programme after fleeing war and persecution in Yugoslavia in 1944. He worked on a Welsh farm before a 34-year career at Stewarts & Lloyds in Corby. He married fellow émigré Milica in 1955 and raised two children, helping establish the Serbian Orthodox church locally. During the 1990s Balkan wars he oversaw shipment of sterilising equipment for Lifeline Humanitarian Organisation. He survived cancer at 87, praised the NHS, and was lauded by Crown Prince Alexander of Yugoslavia. He leaves his wife, two children, grandchildren and a great-granddaughter.

articles.title: Fate of 11 Nigerian troops unclear after ‘unauthorised’ plane landing in Burkina Faso
articles.trailText: Confusion over diplomatic standoff deepens after conflicting reports about the soldiers’ whereabouts
articles.summary: Eleven Nigerian military personnel remain in Burkina Faso days after their C-130 cargo plane was forced to land without authorisation in Bobo Dioulasso en route from Lagos to Portugal. Burkinabé authorities initially branded the diversion an “unfriendly act” yet later said the troops were freed, but Abuja denies their release. Nigeria’s foreign ministry says its embassy in Ouagadougou is negotiating their return amid speculation over links to recent coup-foiling in Benin and AES’s break from ECOWAS.

articles.title: Half a million flee as deadly Cambodia-Thailand border clashes escalate
articles.trailText: At least 20 killed and almost 200 injured, as Trump claims he can settle hostilities ‘pretty quickly’
articles.summary: Clashes flared Dec 11 along the disputed Cambodia–Thailand border, marking the fiercest fighting since July’s five-day conflict. Cambodia and Thailand traded artillery and airstrikes, each accusing the other of territorial violations. At least 20 combatants and civilians were killed, nearly 200 injured, and over 500,000 people evacuated (400,000 in Thailand, 101,000 in Cambodia). Political turbulence in Thailand—PM Anutin may dissolve parliament—and US ex-president Trump’s vow to negotiate a “quick” ceasefire underscore international concern, as Cambodia even withdrew from the Southeast Asian Games.

articles.title: Germany drops promise to resettle hundreds of Afghans
articles.trailText: Interior ministry will tell 640 people awaiting sanctuary ‘there is no longer any political interest in their being admitted’
articles.summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s conservative government has abruptly revoked resettlement for 640 Afghan staff and family awaiting entry in Pakistan, ending two humanitarian programs inherited from the centre-left. Interior Minister Alexander Dobrindt will notify them “there is no longer any political interest” in their admission, a move rights groups decry as a betrayal exposing returnees to Taliban persecution. Since the Taliban takeover, Berlin had evacuated 4,000 local employees and 15,000 relatives, but Merz, facing far-right pressure, plans to phase out the scheme, offering cash buy-outs—only 62 accepted—and leaving 1,800 approved candidates stranded.

articles.title: Bulgarian government resigns after mass anti-corruption protests
articles.trailText: Prime minister makes announcement before parliament vote on no-confidence motion filed by opposition
articles.summary: An estimated 100,000 Bulgarians rallied in Sofia and other cities in rolling protests against perceived corruption and planned tax hikes. On Dec 11, PM Rosen Zhelyazkov resigned before a no-confidence vote and Bulgaria’s Jan 1 eurozone entry. Demonstrators condemned a draft budget dubbed graft cover and oligarch influence—especially by sanctioned media mogul Delyan Peevski. President Rumen Radev backed the ouster; parliament must now form a government or trigger an interim cabinet and fresh elections—Bulgaria’s eighth in four years—amid EU rule-of-law warnings.

articles.title: Amsterdam’s Rijksmuseum announces southern outpost in Eindhoven
articles.trailText: Museum, which includes rich collection of Vermeers and Rembrandts, currently shows only fraction of its 1m objects
articles.summary: Amsterdam’s Rijksmuseum, home to over one million objects including Vermeers and Rembrandt’s Night Watch, plans a 3,500 sq m outpost in Eindhoven. Built in parkland by the River Dommel near the central station, the centre—backed by Eindhoven city council and ASML—will open in six to eight years to relieve Amsterdam overtourism and extend access to the collection in the south. Eindhoven, the Netherlands’ fifth-largest city and a major tech hub with Philips roots, joins a European trend of museum satellites following Louvre Lens and Abu Dhabi.

articles.title: Austria votes to ban headscarves in schools for girls under 14
articles.trailText: Law passes despite fears it will ‘normalise Islamophobia’ and fact it could be struck down by constitutional court
articles.summary: Austria’s conservative-led parliament approved a ban on headscarves for schoolgirls under 14 by a large majority, despite warnings it could face constitutional challenge and deepen Islamophobia. Fining families up to €800 for repeat breaches, the law takes effect in September with a soft launch in February. Proponents say it shields girls from sexualisation, while critics—including Austria’s Islamic Community, Amnesty International and the Greens—warn it marginalises Muslim children and stigmatises their faith. This follows a 2019 ban for under-10s later overturned; opponents argue the measure distracts from economic woes and entrenches exclusion.

articles.title: Greenlandic women claim victory in legal fight with Denmark over forced IUD scandal
articles.trailText: Compensation due to thousands of women and girls fitted with coils without their knowledge or consent
articles.summary: Greenlandic victims of Denmark’s IUD scandal, in which about 4,500 women and girls were forcibly fitted with contraceptive coils without consent between 1960-1991, have secured the right to 300,000 DKK each from a newly established reconciliation fund. The Danish parliament’s June 2026 law, following a three-year lawsuit by 143 women, opens applications from April 2026 on proof of forced fitting, residence in Greenland, and sworn lack of consent. Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen apologized for systemic discrimination; former PM Múte B. Egede called the practice ‘genocide’. Claimants, including Bula Larsen and Aviaja Fontain, hailed recognition of their trauma alongside monetary redress.

articles.title: Spain’s ruling socialist party accused of failing to act on sexual misconduct by senior men
articles.trailText: Slew of allegations of sexual harassment hits party already battered by corruption claims and political setbacks
articles.summary: Spain’s ruling PSOE under Pedro Sánchez has been rocked by accusations of mishandling sexual misconduct by senior men. Former Moncloa coordinator Francisco Salazar resigned amid ignored harassment complaints—later blamed on a system error—while his deputy Antonio Hernández was sacked for allegedly covering it up. In Lugo, senior politician José Tomé also quit after multiple allegations. Recordings of ex-minister José Luis Ábalos discussing sex workers compounded the scandal. Senior female party members have called for deep equality reforms and legal oversight. Opposition parties decry hypocrisy, but Sánchez has admitted failures, pledged support for victims, and framed PSOE as accountable versus reactionary rivals.

articles.title: Former Bolivian president Luis Arce detained on corruption charges
articles.trailText: Allegations he allowed state funds for Indigenous projects to be transferred to government officials’ accounts
articles.summary: Former Bolivian president Luis Arce was detained on Dec 10 over alleged illicit enrichment in his 2013–15 tenure as economy minister and head of a hydrocarbon tax–funded Indigenous development program. Authorities accuse him of authorising transfers totalling 360 m bolivianos (£39.2 m) into officials’ personal accounts for “ghost projects,” reviving probes under incoming president Rodrigo Paz Pereira’s centre-right administration. The interior minister labelled Arce the main culprit; a precautionary hearing is set, while Morales remains unnamed. Vice-president Edmand Lara lauded the arrest; ex-minister María Prada decried it as political persecution.

articles.title: Venezuelan Nobel laureate backs US seizure of oil tanker
articles.trailText: María Corina Machado says action was ‘very necessary step’ to confront Nicolás Maduro’s ‘criminal’ regime
articles.summary: Maria Corina Machado, Venezuela’s exiled opposition leader and 2025 Nobel Peace laureate, praised the US navy’s seizure of an oil tanker off Venezuela as “a very necessary step” to cut Nicolás Maduro’s “criminal” regime off from oil revenues used for weapons. In Oslo to collect her award, she recounted slipping out of Venezuela by boat and reuniting with her family after nearly two years apart, calling it a “historic turning point” for democratic change. She vowed to return in hiding, decried Iranian and Hezbollah presence in Venezuela, and warned that Maduro’s crackdown persists even amid international pressure.

articles.title: ‘Follow the path of exiles’: María Corina Machado’s US-aided escape from Venezuela
articles.trailText: Nobel peace laureate’s decision to flee on people-smuggling route is highly symbolic, but will her influence wane if unable to return?
articles.summary: Opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize–winner María Corina Machado fled Venezuela via a dangerous people-smuggling yola route to Curaçao, aboard a 5,500-mile secret escape aided by US and rogue Maduro insiders. After dodging military checkpoints in disguise, she flew via the US to Oslo to collect her prize. Her choice to follow exile routes underscores her crusade to end the mass migration Exodus triggered by Maduro’s authoritarian, hyperinflationary rule. Analysts debate whether exile will erode her grassroots support—remembered by millions of displaced Venezuelans—or bolster her campaign from abroad as she vows to reunite families and return to lead democratic change.

articles.title: Rwanda-backed M23 rebels say they have captured key city in eastern DRC
articles.trailText: Rebel spokesperson claims Uvira ‘fully liberated’ as offensive continues despite Trump-brokered peace deal
articles.summary: M23 rebels claim to have captured Uvira, a strategic city in eastern DRC near Burundi, as part of their offensive following Bukavu’s fall in February. Rebel spokesman Lawrence Kanyuka said Uvira is “fully liberated”, urging opposing forces to surrender, while Burundi’s FM and Kinshasa deny its fall. Control of Uvira could open routes for further advances and access to mineral-rich areas. The offensive, blamed on Rwandan backing, has displaced over 6m people in North and South Kivu since 2021, killed at least 74 around Uvira, and triggered alleged war crimes. Fighting persists despite a Doha accord and a Trump-brokered truce this year.

articles.title: ‘She was very, very thin’: witness tells of Ukrainian journalist’s final days in Russian prison
articles.trailText: Soldier’s account corroborates reports Viktoriia Roshchyna was taken to prison deep inside Russia, where it is believed she died
articles.summary: The Guardian’s Viktoriia Project published Azov soldier Mykyta Semenov’s eyewitness account of Ukrainian journalist Viktoriia Roshchyna’s last days in Russian captivity. Seized summer 2022, she endured nine months in Taganrog’s Sizo-2, then on 9 September 2024 was transferred by train and truck to Sizo-3 in Kizel, Ural region. Semenov describes her emaciation, yellowed skin, difficulty walking and speaking, brutal beatings by FSIN officers and harsh standing-only rules. Russia informed her family she died on 19 September 2024; autopsy noted torture signs, including hyoid bone fracture, though Moscow never confirmed place or cause.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Will Labour’s human rights overhaul curb or fuel the far right?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As the UK joins a group of European governments pushing for stricter asylum rules, critics warn of the risks of weakening safeguards
articles.summary: On Human Rights Day, at a Council of Europe summit, the UK joined Hungary, Italy and 25 other states in an unofficial call to constrain the ECHR—narrowing Article 3’s “inhuman or degrading treatment” and Article 8’s family-life rights—to enable Rwanda-style migration deals and more deportations. Starmer and Home Secretary Mahmood argue the asylum system, built for another era, needs updating to stem far-right votes by proving mainstream politics can deliver. Opponents, including Michael Palin, Stephen Fry and legal experts, warn that weakening core protections risks empowering extremists and undermining the absolute ban on torture.

articles.title: ‘It’s not going to be some miraculous recovery’: film charts healing of Ukrainian children rescued from Russia
articles.trailText: Director of After the Rain says she aimed to portray ‘children as children, not as a statistic’ while filming at Estonian animal therapy retreat
articles.summary: A new documentary by British-Ukrainian director Sarah McCarthy follows seven-year-old Sasha and fourteen-year-old Veronika—Ukrainian children forcibly deported to Russia and later rescued—to an animal therapy retreat in Estonia. Sasha, seized from besieged Mariupol after her father’s 45-day detention and reunited via a volunteer aid network, spends days interviewing potential adoptive mothers, tending golden retrievers and riding ponies. Veronika, freed after her veteran mother’s UN appeal, uses humour to mask trauma from propaganda and isolation. Ukraine’s government cites 19,546 children deported, 1,898 returned. McCarthy eschews politics, capturing emotional recovery amid Baltic forests.

articles.title: I used to report from the West Bank. Twenty years after my last visit, I was shocked by how much worse it is today
articles.trailText: The long read: Among the many people I met, there was a pervasive feeling of hopelessness and a sense that resistance is slowly becoming a memory
articles.summary: In a first return in 20 years, the writer finds the West Bank more oppressive: 1,000 Israeli flags line highways near Nablus, nearly 850 checkpoints hinder movement, and settler numbers have grown from 400k to 700k, encroaching on Palestinian villages. Ramallah’s apparent normality masks farm exclusion and economic collapse – per capita income down 20%, 33% unemployment – amid PA corruption accusations. Political fragmentation, rising fatigue and absence of unified leadership leave resistance a fading memory. Palestinians express despair over stalled statehood, fear settler extremism, and pin hope on figures like Barghouti or international BDS pressure.

articles.title: Sexually explicit letters about exiled Hong Kong activists sent to UK and Australian addresses
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Letters with deepfake images of Carmen Lau in UK and targeting of Ted Hui in Australia part of growing harassment
articles.summary: Carmen Lau, an exiled pro-democracy activist and former district councillor, and ex-legislator Ted Hui and his wife in Australia have been targeted with sexually explicit deepfake letters and posters. In the UK, neighbours of Lau received letters posted from Macau containing deepfaked images of her in sexualised poses, including a pixelated sex act, and personal details. In Australia, Hui’s wife was depicted on a “Hong Kong lonely housewife” poster advertising sex services at a fake address. Victims reported terror, police investigations in the UK and South Australia, and calls for sanctions over escalating transnational repression.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv’s SBU cripples shadow fleet tanker in Black Sea
articles.trailText: Third sea drone strike in two weeks on Russian vessels; ‘coalition of the willing’ convenes as US continues chaotic peace efforts. What we know on day 1,387
articles.summary: Ukrainian sea drones disabled the Dashan tanker, part of Russia’s sanctioned ‘shadow fleet’, by striking its stern in Ukraine’s EEZ en route to Novorossiysk, marking the third strike this month. Kyiv’s SBU aims to choke Moscow’s oil revenues. Meanwhile, leaders of a “coalition of the willing” held talks amid US-led, messy peace negotiations, as Ukraine submits its own counterproposal. Zelenskyy warns against foreign pressure on elections under martial law. NGOs report minimal diversion of Western arms. UNFPA flags a 37% rise in maternal deaths. US House passes $900bn defense bill including sustained support for Ukraine and troop levels in Europe.

articles.title: Texas and Florida sue FDA in latest effort to restrict abortion pill access
articles.trailText: States’ attorneys general argue agency has failed to properly evaluate mifepristone’s safety since initial 2000 approval
articles.summary: Texas and Florida’s attorneys general filed a lawsuit in federal court challenging FDA’s 2000 mifepristone approval and its recent generic authorization, arguing the agency neglected safety reviews and unlawfully expanded access under Obama and Biden policies. They seek to block Evita Solutions’ generic and regulations allowing mail and telemedicine prescriptions, claiming agency actions violate the Administrative Procedure Act. This case mirrors similar suits by Missouri, Kansas and Idaho and feeds a broader conservative effort to restrict medication abortion post-Roe.

articles.title: Ukraine war: Trump criticises European leaders on eve of crunch coalition meeting
articles.trailText: President says there were ‘strong words’ in latest call, as Volodymyr Zelenskyy to join other European leaders to discuss peace plan on Thursday
articles.summary: On Thursday Zelenskyy, Starmer, Macron, Merz and over 30 allied heads will hold a video call on Ukraine after President Trump publicly scolded European partners, warning fresh talks risk “wasting time” and casting doubt on US participation. Zelenskyy will submit a revised peace plan as EU states draft security guarantees. Domestically he dismissed his chief of staff over a corruption probe and, under US pressure, says he is ready to hold wartime elections. On the front, Russia’s forces press assaults on Pokrovsk and Myrnohrad with armoured attacks amid fierce street fighting.

articles.title: Venezuelan Nobel peace prize winner misses ceremony but vows to continue struggle
articles.trailText: Daughter delivers speech, with Nobel Institute saying María Corina Machado still expected in Oslo after journey of ‘extreme danger’
articles.summary: Venezuela’s opposition leader María Corina Machado, awarded the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize for her fight against Nicolás Maduro’s “brutal dictatorship” and systemic corruption, missed Wednesday’s Oslo ceremony, instead sending her daughter Ana Corina Sosa Machado to deliver a lecture. In an audio message she thanked those who helped her flee secretly—allegedly by boat to Curaçao—and vowed to continue Venezuela’s “long march to freedom.” Latin American presidents Milei, Noboa, Mulino and Peña attended in solidarity as Machado awaits arrival. The award, praised by US hardliners but criticized for her past support of Trump-backed interventions, has sparked protests in Oslo.

articles.title: Ethiopia is committed to peace and dialogue in the Amhara region | Letter
articles.trailText: Letters: Ambassador Biruk Mekonnen Demissie responds to a photo essay about the Fano insurgency in the Horn of Africa
articles.summary: Ethiopian Ambassador Biruk Mekonnen Demissie disputes a photo essay’s claim that Fano militias control over 80% of Amhara, affirming government oversight of security and development throughout the region. He outlines post-conflict measures: former Fano fighters offered integration into national or regional forces or civilian reintegration under the state’s exclusive right to bear arms. He rejects Fano’s democratic legitimacy and narrow ethnic rhetoric, defends the Pretoria peace deal as an inclusive federal–Amhara accord, and urges balanced reporting, continued dialogue, disarmament and accountability.

articles.title: ‘It’s a breach of trust’: fear and frustration over countries’ push to return Syrians home
articles.trailText: Syrians who have rebuilt their lives abroad face uncertainty over their futures amid hardening of attitudes
articles.summary: After Assad’s fall, Austria, Germany and over a dozen EU states suspended Syrian asylum claims, reviewed existing protections and prepared repatriation plans. Austria halted family reunification and resumed deportations; Germany’s chancellor Friedrich Merz called for voluntary returns despite Syrians filling critical labor shortages. In the US, the administration moved to revoke temporary protections for 6,100 Syrians, only to be blocked by a federal judge. Activists and researchers warn that forced returns risk retraumatizing refugees and straining Syria’s war-torn infrastructure—estimated to need $200 bn for reconstruction—while integration successes spotlight deepening mistrust and anxiety among the diaspora.

articles.title: Trump has confirmed Europeans’ worst fears. Are their leaders ready to stand up to him now?
articles.trailText: The White House has formalised its contempt for ‘decaying’ Europe with an ominous plan to undermine the EU and boost the far right
articles.summary: New survey: half of EU citizens view Donald Trump as Europe’s foe. His 2025 National Security Strategy brands the EU an ideological battleground, pledges to ‘cultivate resistance’ by empowering far-right parties and promoting nativist conspiracy theories under the guise of restoring national sovereignty. The doctrine threatens liberal democracy with “civilisational erasure” from immigration, aligns with the Kremlin, sidelines Europe in Ukraine peace talks to secure “strategic stability” with Russia, and pressures leaders into mute compliance to protect defense funding. Analysts warn Europeans must forge an independent security roadmap, safeguard Ukraine, and counter MAGA-style interference to future-proof their democracies.

articles.title: AfD responds to Trump ‘erasure’ claims with call for nationalist revival in Europe
articles.trailText: Continent’s other nationalist parties wary of echoing sentiments of US president due to his unpopularity
articles.summary: Germany’s far-right AfD, led by co-spokesperson Markus Frohnmaier, embraced the Trump administration’s claim of European civilisational erasure and vowed a conservative renaissance, forging ties with MAGA Republicans in Washington and attending Young Republican events amid allegations of extremist praise. Praised in Trump’s 2025 US national security strategy as bolstering patriotic European parties, the AfD’s approach contrasts with caution from other EU nationalists—France’s RN leader Jordan Bardella rejects US subservience; Italy’s Giorgia Meloni stresses transatlantic unity; Hungary’s Viktor Orbán defers comment—highlighting divisions between America First and Europe First agendas.

articles.title: EU proposes loosening rules on AI gigafactories in green rollback
articles.trailText: Latest package in dismantling of environmental rules also suggests repealing hazardous chemicals database
articles.summary: The EU commission proposed exempting datacentres, AI gigafactories and affordable housing from mandatory environmental impact assessments, letting member states opt-in. It would expand strategic sectors, repeal the EU hazardous chemicals database, drop authorised-representative rules for polluters and shift environmental management requirements from plants to companies. Brussels claims €1bn annual savings. Greens warn this rollback undermines policy, risking human health and biodiversity, with non-implementation costs of €180bn/year. Simultaneously, it proposes expanding and modernizing the EU electricity grid, sets a 90% emissions-by-2050 target (5% via carbon credits) and scales back corporate sustainability rules, delaying and narrowing due-diligence obligations.

articles.title: Daily killings in Mexico drop 37% under Claudia Sheinbaum, but experts say data is problematic
articles.trailText: Government claims national security strategy is working, but analysts say figures don’t show rise in forced disappearances
articles.summary: Government data shows Mexico’s daily homicides fell from almost 87 in September 2024 to 55 in November 2025, a 37% decline that President Claudia Sheinbaum credits to her reinforced national guard, improved intelligence and interagency coordination. Yet experts like Cecilia Farfán-Méndez and Mexico Evalúa warn these figures mask spikes in forced disappearances (up 15% nationally, 200% in some states), classification gaps and peak violence days. Arrests of nearly 40,000 suspects, 20,000 firearms and 311 t of drugs seized underscore operational gains, but cartel bloodshed, mayoral killings and mass protests highlight enduring insecurity and contested narratives.

articles.title: Burkina Faso releases 11 Nigerian troops after ‘unauthorised’ plane landing
articles.trailText: Military personnel told they can return to Nigeria after actions described as ‘unfriendly act’
articles.summary: Burkina Faso freed 11 Nigerian military personnel held after a Lagos-to-Portugal C-130 made an unauthorised emergency landing in Bobo-Dioulasso amid a technical fault. The AES labelled the unscheduled incursion an “unfriendly act,” granting repatriation for two crew and nine passengers, though the plane’s fate remains unclear. Nigeria maintains the stop obeyed safety protocols and is investigating clearance procedures. The incident, following Nigerian airstrikes in Benin against coup fugitives and a recent domestic crash, underscores mounting regional friction between the breakaway AES and ECOWAS, whose leaders warn of a Sahel security and democratic crisis.

articles.title: Italy first country to win Unesco recognition for national cuisine
articles.trailText: Italian cooking added to ‘intangible cultural heritage’ list after campaign by Giorgia Meloni’s far-right government
articles.summary: UNESCO has added Italian cuisine – from pasta and mozzarella to wine and tiramisu – to its intangible cultural heritage list, making Italy the first country honoured for its national cuisine rather than a single dish. The recognition followed a bid launched by PM Giorgia Meloni’s government, which staged promotional events including a Roman Forum lunch. UNESCO praised Italian food as a communal ritual emphasising ingredient respect, intergenerational recipe exchange and cultural identity. Agriculture minister Francesco Lollobrigida celebrated the listing, and a Sapienza University report forecasts increased tourism.

articles.title: Santa at war: ‘home’ town in Finland hosts Nato soldiers as Russian threat looms
articles.trailText: Christmas tourists are noticing a growing military presence in Lapland, where Santa Park doubles as a bomb shelter
articles.summary: Rovaniemi, Finland’s self-styled Santa Claus home, has become a hub for NATO exercises near the Russian border as thousands of troops train at Lapland’s vast Rovajärvi area. Visitors now encounter military aircraft and Santa Park’s shelter doubling as a bunker. Finland’s new Forward Land Forces battlegroup and Arctic command centre bolster deterrence against Russia’s Kola Peninsula buildup. Joint drills like Lapland Steel and Northern Strike involve Finnish conscripts alongside Swedish, British and Polish troops preparing for potential Russian advances.

articles.title: ‘A generation lost at sea’: the desperate Rohingya falling prey to traffickers as they flee Bangladesh
articles.trailText: Barred from work and school in Bangladesh, thousands of refugees are making the perilous voyage to Malaysia by boat – with some beaten en route to extort even more money
articles.summary: Barred from work, education and movement in overcrowded Bangladesh camps, more than 1.1 million Rohingya are risking perilous sea voyages to Malaysia. Since September, the Arakan Project has tracked 22 boats carrying around 4,000 people; UNHCR reports 600 have died or gone missing. Traffickers charge migrants roughly 500,000 taka each, then detain hostages in makeshift camps, beat them on camera to extort further ransom, and force transfers by small boat to larger ships. Testimonies from families describe capsizes killing women, children and men. Observers warn this exodus could match the 2015 trafficking peak without urgent humanitarian or repatriation measures.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: Why is AI becoming the go-to support for our children’s mental health?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Chatbots are becoming confidants for young people in distress​ – raising urgent questions about safeguarding, regulation and the limits of synthetic empathy
articles.summary: New Youth Endowment Fund survey of 11,000 UK teens (13–17) finds 25% use AI chatbots for mental health support, rising to 40% among those affected by serious violence, as NHS waiting times average 392 days. Chatbots deliver 24/7 synthetic empathy, memory of prior conversations and perceived anonymity but lack professional challenge, safeguarding and consistent clinical oversight. Lawsuits over youth suicides linked to long chatbot engagements and reports of harmful advice have prompted calls to extend the UK Online Safety Act to AI. The debate centers on balancing rapid access, privacy, safety and effectiveness for vulnerable children.

articles.title: Teacher in Hungary facing criminal charges for organising Pride event
articles.trailText: As Viktor Orbán tightens his grip in the country, rights organisations have called for the EU to intervene
articles.summary: A Romani LGBTQ+ activist and teacher, Géza Buzás-Hábel, is the first person in the EU to face criminal prosecution for organizing a Pride march after defying Hungary’s ban on such events. In October 2025, he led Pécs Pride despite a law imposing fines via facial-recognition and a court-confirmed ban, drawing 8,000 participants including MEPs. Prosecutors seek charges of organizing and calling for participation in a prohibited assembly, risking up to three years' suspended sentence and a permanent teaching ban. Rights groups warn this unprecedented move under Orbán threatens EU values and civil liberties.

articles.title: Trump says he will make a call to end hostilities as Thailand and Cambodia ‘at it again’
articles.trailText: After a ceasefire deal he brokered collapsed, Trump told a rally in Pennsylvania that he would ‘make a call’ to ‘stop a war’ between Thailand and Cambodia
articles.summary: At a Pennsylvania rally, US President Donald Trump vowed to ‘make a call’ to halt renewed border fighting between Thailand and Cambodia after the July ceasefire he brokered collapsed. Citing his record of ending eight wars, Trump said he’d intervene diplomatically to stop clashes over disputed territory that have displaced over 500,000 civilians and left at least nine Cambodian civilians and four Thai soldiers dead, plus dozens injured. Thailand’s PM Anutin Charnvirakul backed continued military operations, accusing Cambodia of newly laid landmines, while Cambodia’s Hun Sen insists his forces only responded in self-defense.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Pope defends Europe – and its role in peace talks – from Trump
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy addresses Trump gripe with offer to hold elections if allies help; Syrski outlines territorial losses and gains around Pokrovsk. What we know on day 1,386
articles.summary: Pope Leo XIV after meeting Zelenskyy insisted Europe be included in Ukraine peace talks, criticizing Trump’s US-European alliance strategy. Zelenskyy, reacting to Trump’s democracy critique, offered to hold wartime elections within 60–90 days if parliament approves and allies ensure security; opponents warn it would aid Russia. Zelenskyy plans to deliver an updated peace plan to Washington. A British soldier died in Ukraine testing defenses. Gen Syrskyi reported gains around Pokrovsk amid 156,000 Russian troops. Facing winter energy cuts, Kyiv imposed blackouts. Meanwhile, a German court tried suspects in a Russian-linked assassination plot, and Spain closed its probe into a defector’s murder.

articles.title: What’s behind the Thailand-Cambodia clashes – explained in 30 seconds
articles.trailText: Hostilities have flared in the contested border area after a Trump-brokered ceasefire deal has broken down
articles.summary: Thailand and Cambodia’s 817km border has been disputed since France mapped it in 1907. In May 2025, clashes after a Cambodian soldier’s death sparked reprisals: Thai border restrictions, Cambodian bans on Thai media and imports. July saw the worst fighting in a decade—five days of clashes after a Thai soldier hit a landmine—killing 48, displacing 300,000. A Trump-brokered ceasefire in October collapsed in November following another mine blast. Renewed Thai airstrikes have killed at least 7 Cambodian civilians and 3 Thai soldiers; both blame each other for violations.

articles.title: Zelenskyy ‘ready for elections’ after Trump questions Ukrainian democracy
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says he would hold wartime elections within months given help from allies and Ukraine’s parliament
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, after Trump accused him of clinging to power, declared he is ready to hold wartime elections in 60–90 days if Ukraine’s parliament and allies secure polling logistics and amend martial-law rules. Constitutional and security constraints currently bar ballots amid conflict—an opposition MP warns it would aid Russia—but Zelenskyy is soliciting partner proposals to ensure votes for troops, displaced citizens and those under occupation. Back from a European tour, he is also planning US peace talks and proposed an energy ceasefire if Russia agrees. Trump Jr. claimed Zelenskyy may prolong the war to retain power; the White House is pushing Kyiv toward a peace deal that could cede Donbas.

articles.title: Honduras president alleges ‘electoral coup’ under way amid Trump ‘interference’
articles.trailText: Xiomara Castro alleges US manipulation and blackmail as preliminary count shows two rightwing candidates closely tied
articles.summary: President Xiomara Castro accused an ‘electoral coup’ aided by US interference, alleging Donald Trump’s backing for rightwing candidate Nasry “Tito” Asfura—who leads the preliminary count with 40.52% versus Salvador Nasralla’s 39.48%—and Trump’s pardon of ex-president Juan Orlando Hernández. Third-place Liberal candidate Rixi Moncada drew Trump’s warnings of “narco-terrorists.” Castro vowed to appeal to the UN, EU, OAS and CELAC, while Honduras’s attorney-general reactivated an international arrest warrant for Hernández. The electoral council must resolve 14.5% of disputed tally sheets by 30 December.

articles.title: Brigitte Macron criticised after using sexist slur against feminist protesters
articles.trailText: French first lady was filmed calling women who had disrupted Paris theatre show by Ary Abittan ‘sales connes’
articles.summary: French first lady Brigitte Macron was filmed backstage at the Folies Bergère calling feminist protesters who had disrupted Ary Abittan’s show “sales connes” (“dirty/stupid bitches”) and threatening to eject them. Macron’s office said she was merely calming the actor, whose 2021 rape allegations were dropped for lack of evidence. Left-wing figures from François Hollande to Green leader Marine Tondelier condemned her sexist language and demanded an apology, while feminist group Nous Toutes defended the disruptions as protest against sexual violence impunity. Celebrities adopted the insult via #salesconnes; a National Rally MP labeled the outcry media hypocrisy.

articles.title: Member of UK armed forces killed in ‘tragic accident’ in Ukraine, says MoD
articles.trailText: Ministry says Briton, who has not publicly been named, was injured while observing a test, away from the frontline
articles.summary: On 9 December 2025 the MoD announced a serving UK soldier died in a tragic accident while observing Ukrainian forces test a new defensive weapon off the frontline in Ukraine – the first combatant‐death among British military personnel since Russia’s full‐scale invasion. No hostile fire was involved, and the family has been notified. PM and opposition leaders offered condolences. Britain’s small training and embassy security contingent in Ukraine now faces renewed debate over potential ‘boots on the ground’ peacekeeping deployments. Separately, a Kyiv war museum memorial notes 40 volunteer Britons killed in Ukraine, none serving in UK forces.

articles.title: US puts sanctions on network said to funnel Colombian mercenaries to Sudan
articles.trailText: US treasury accuses Colombian nationals and companies of aiding the RSF, which has committed horrific war crimes
articles.summary: US Treasury sanctions four individuals and four firms linked to a network recruiting Colombian ex-soldiers to fight for Sudan’s Rapid Support Forces accused of genocide and war crimes. Key targets include recruiter Álvaro Andrés Quijano Becerra and his wife, plus fund managers Mateo Duque Botero and Mónica Muñoz Ucros. US-based firms linked to Duque moved millions in wire transfers, prompting calls to halt external military and financial support to the RSF. Hundreds of battle-hardened Colombians have trained child soldiers, piloted drones and joined frontline assaults. Analysts praise the measures, but experts warn sanctions alone can’t curb a Dubai-based mercenary economy. Colombia has ratified an anti-mercenary convention to strengthen security policy.

articles.title: Martin Collins obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Political activist and organiser with a focus on Ireland who worked to help secure the Good Friday agreement
articles.summary: Martin Collins, 75, died of dementia complications. A lifelong human rights activist and organiser focused on Ireland, he worked in parliament for MP Kevin McNamara from 1994, organising the All-Party Agreed Ireland Forum behind the Good Friday Agreement. Earlier he co-founded the Labour Committee on Ireland (1982), edited the magazine Labour and Ireland and the book Ireland After Britain (1985), led the Time to Go! campaign (1987) and campaigned on miscarriages of justice including the Guildford Four. As director of the Britain and Ireland Human Rights Project he launched the journal Rapporteur. In the 2000s he championed the Irish Traveller Movement, advised Chris Ruane MP and supported bereaved families in army barracks death inquiries. Born in Bristol and educated at UEA, he is survived by partner Ginnie Lawlor and brother Simon.

articles.title: More than 9,000 children in Gaza hospitalised for acute malnutrition in October, UN says
articles.trailText: Aid agencies say Israel is still restricting their aid shipments despite ceasefire announced two months ago
articles.summary: In October, 9,300 Gaza children were hospitalised for severe acute malnutrition—down from August’s peak of 14,000 but far above rates during the February–March ceasefire—while 8,300 pregnant or breastfeeding women were also treated, the UN reports. Despite a ceasefire declared on 10 October, Israeli authorities have facilitated only four of eight scheduled aid convoys and allow roughly 140 of the required 600 UN-coordinated trucks daily, worsening food insecurity among 2.2 million Palestinians. UNICEF warns this deficit risks low-birthweight babies and lasting generational impacts.

articles.title: Oslo appearance by Nobel peace prize winner María Corina Machado cancelled
articles.trailText: Press conference was expected to have been Venezuelan opposition leader’s first public appearance in 11 months
articles.summary: María Corina Machado’s Oslo press conference ahead of her Nobel Peace Prize ceremony was cancelled shortly before start; the Norwegian Nobel Institute says it remains unaware of her whereabouts. The Venezuelan opposition leader last appeared publicly in January 2025 protesting Nicolás Maduro’s third term. Now in hiding amid government accusations of conspiracy and terrorism, she has not confirmed travel plans. Her family, including her 84-year-old mother and children, are in Oslo awaiting her. The institute states logistics are unclear and rescheduling seems unlikely. Machado won the prize for her fight against authoritarianism in Venezuela, dedicating it to the Venezuelan people and to President Trump for his support.

articles.title: Why has ceasefire collapsed between Thailand and Cambodia?
articles.trailText: The long-simmering border conflict has erupted again with each side accusing the other of breaching Trump-brokered deal
articles.summary: A revived century-old territorial dispute over the Preah Vihear temple and surrounding lands has reignited violent clashes between Thai and Cambodian forces despite a US-brokered ceasefire, killing seven Cambodian civilians, three Thai soldiers, wounding 20 more, and displacing 300,000 residents. Nationalist backlash to energy exploration talks, political fallout from leaked calls between Hun Sen and Thaksin’s daughter, and referrals to the ICJ have heightened tensions. Trump’s 36% US tariff leverage led to an immediate ceasefire and detailed de-escalation pact, but landmine incidents and mutual ceasefire violations in May and July triggered its collapse, prompting border restrictions, trade bans, and fresh fighting.

articles.title: ‘We’re living in terror’: fears in southern Syria over Israel’s growing occupation
articles.trailText: Residents say incursions and raids have increased since forces first entered country a year ago after fall of Assad
articles.summary: A year after Assad’s fall, Israel’s forces remain entrenched across Quneitra, southern Syria, transforming the UN buffer zone into military bases. Residents like falafel-seller Abu Ibrahim report night raids, checkpoints, weapon seizures, the demolition of 14 homes for bases and 13 killed in a recent incursion at Beit Jinn. Syrians need permits for farms or weddings, endure drone surveillance and arbitrary detentions of suspected militants. Damascus’ appeals at the UN and US-mediated talks on an Israeli withdrawal under the 1974 agreement have stalled. Locals fear they’ve only traded one tyranny for another, living in constant terror.

articles.title: Nigerian troops held in Burkina Faso after ‘unfriendly’ emergency landing
articles.trailText: Unauthorised touchdown comes less than 24 hours after Nigerian forces intervened in attempted coup in Benin
articles.summary: Eleven Nigerian military personnel are detained in Bobo Dioulasso, Burkina Faso, after a C-130 transport on a Portugal-bound ferry mission made an unauthorized emergency landing. The Alliance of Sahel States (AES)—Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger—led by Mali’s Assimi Goïta, denounced the incident as an “unfriendly act” violating confederal airspace and vowed to neutralize future intrusions. Nigeria says the crew is safe, citing a technical issue. The episode follows Nigeria’s ECOWAS-mandated airstrikes to foil a coup in Benin and highlights the deepening rift between ECOWAS and the Russia-aligned AES.

articles.title: Fatal Thailand-Cambodia clashes spread along contested border area
articles.trailText: Each side has blamed the other for renewed clashes, which have derailed a ceasefire brokered by Donald Trump
articles.summary: Bilateral clashes along the disputed 500-mile Thailand–Cambodia border have reignited after both sides accused each other of breaching a US-brokered ceasefire inked six weeks earlier under Donald Trump’s mediation. Fiercest since July, fighting has killed seven Cambodian civilians, wounded 20, and killed three Thai soldiers. Cambodia’s senate president Hun Sen announced a counterattack after evacuations stalled; Thailand’s navy and defence ministry report expelling Cambodian troops in Trat using artillery, drones and rocket launchers while accusing Phnom Penh of shelling civilian areas. Over 125,000 Thais and 21,000 Cambodians are in evacuation shelters. The century-old boundary dispute has repeatedly flared despite earlier truces.

articles.title: Australia deporting refugee to Nauru may cause his ‘imminent’ and ‘preventable’ death, court hears
articles.trailText: Legal team of man who was part of cohort of non-citizens freed after high court decision argues Nauru’s medical facilities are ‘insufficient’ to treat his severe asthma
articles.summary: Lawyers for Iranian refugee TCXM warn his deportation to Nauru could cause his “imminent” death from severe asthma, given the island’s inadequate medical facilities. TCXM was freed under the 2023 High Court NZYQ ruling but re-detained after Nauru issued him a 30-year visa under a new $2.5 billion bilateral deal. The High Court is now hearing his appeal against procedural unfairness, the government’s duty to deport non-citizens and recent Migration Act amendments stripping natural justice from removal-pathway detainees. TCXM seeks an injunction to block his removal.

articles.title: UK campaigners condemn ‘creepy’ digital billboards that can track viewers’ responses
articles.trailText: Tech company has installed the advertising screens in hundreds of apartment blocks across 20 British cities
articles.summary: 30Seconds Group has fitted digital noticeboards with built-in cameras into communal areas of hundreds of UK apartment blocks across 20 cities, claiming they measure “occupant engagement” during an average 30-second wait. Civil liberties groups and residents, led by Big Brother Watch and tenant Conor Nocher, denounce the installations as “creepy” surveillance, object to service-charge funding (£800 installation plus £2.60 annual running cost per resident) and lack of opt-out. RMG—one of nearly 50 property firms—says cameras remain inactive and the screens aid resident communication, but previous displays at Sheffield’s Park Hill were removed after backlash.

articles.title: China’s record trade surplus reveals its biggest strength – and hidden weakness
articles.trailText: Booming Chinese exports have driven trade surplus past $1tn but also reveal the extent of country’s reliance on foreign markets
articles.summary: China’s goods trade surplus hit a record $1.076 trn in Jan–Nov, underscoring its export dependence and complicating US efforts to rebalance trade. US imports from China plunged nearly a third in November amid tariffs, prompting rerouting via south-east Asia—Indonesia’s US shipments rose 30%—and EU exports jumped 14.8%. Despite the bilateral trade war, global shipment volumes barely budged. China’s share of world exports in hi-tech goods and semiconductors rose sharply. Xi’s politburo vows to boost domestic demand, but consumption remains just 50% of GDP versus 80% in the US.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: Is next year’s XXL World Cup an expansion too far?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As the 2026 tournament expands, questions are being asked about its new format, its environmental impact and whether Fifa is bending too many of its own rules
articles.summary: In a glitzy Washington draw – capped by Donald Trump receiving FIFA’s inaugural peace prize – the 2026 World Cup expands to 48 teams, 12 groups and 104 matches across the US, Mexico and Canada. Newcomers like Curaçao add excitement, but critics warn the bloated format risks predictable group games, diluted quality and logistical headaches: long travel, steep tickets and carbon emissions. Politics loom: strained US���Iran visa talks, Trump’s influence and FIFA’s rule-bending on seeding and disciplinary measures. Despite concerns over competitiveness, costs and environmental impact, FIFA forecasts record viewership, yet purists fear the tournament may sacrifice drama for scale.

articles.title: France and UK ‘failing to tackle anti-migrant activists’
articles.trailText: Migrant support groups in France say lack of action over British activists is ‘encouraging violent and xenophobic practices’
articles.summary: Nine French associations—including L’Auberge des Migrants, Utopia 56 and Médecins du Monde—accuse UK and French authorities of “seriously inadequate” response to anti-migrant British activists from Raise the Colours’ Operation Overlord. Members have flown Union and St George’s flags, harassed migrants, unearthed and destroyed dinghies, livestreamed coast patrols and recruited over 5,500 volunteers with calls for stab-proof vests, drones and encrypted radios. Despite brief detentions, NGOs say no entry bans or prosecutions followed, normalising violent, xenophobic tactics. The UK Home Office warns against vigilantism; France plans tougher maritime interceptions and a Dunkirk enforcement unit.

articles.title: Full steam ahead with Aukus – but where to?
articles.trailText: Defence agreement kept afloat through sheer political will, despite Pentagon doubts over its ability to ever deliver what it promises
articles.summary: Australia has committed a third US$1bn payment under the AUKUS pact to help build nuclear submarines in the US, yet Pentagon skepticism and chronic shipyard delays threaten delivery. Between 2019 and 2023 the US Navy delivered four of 11 planned Virginia-class boats and now builds only 1.13 a year versus a 2.33-per-year rate needed to meet its own force levels and supply Australia. US law bars transfers unless vessels are surplus to American needs. Meanwhile, the UK’s nuclear program faces major reactor-core and scheduling flaws, spurring doubts over any sovereign SSN-Aukus fleet.

articles.title: Walking into disaster: the narcotrafficking scandal that blew up the BVI
articles.trailText: The long read: When the new premier of the British Virgin Islands said he needed an armed security detail, his chief of police knew trouble was on its way
articles.summary: After Hurricane Irma in 2017 exposed endemic corruption in the British Virgin Islands, Governor Augustus 'Gus' Jaspert clashed with pro-independence Premier Andrew Fahie, whose unorthodox power grabs - arbitrary firings, demands for armed guards and opaque political donations - raised alarms. Behind the scenes, US Drug Enforcement agents baited Fahie's security chief and port regulator into a plot with a fake trafficker, Roberto Quintero. Fahie accepted bribes and logistical promises for cocaine shipments, was arrested in a DEA sting in 2022, convicted of drug and money-laundering conspiracies and sentenced to 11 years, triggering a judge-led inquiry that laid bare governance failures.

articles.title: What is LegCo in Hong Kong – explained in 30 seconds
articles.trailText: LegCo elections have become increasingly meaningless as Hong Kong has faced significant political repression and undergone major governance system overhauls in recent years
articles.summary: Hong Kong’s Legislative Council (LegCo) functions as a local parliament, but its elections have been hollowed out by Beijing’s tightening control since the 2019 protests and 2020 national security law. Once a symbol of the “one country, two systems” promise, LegCo saw democratic parties disband under repression and electoral reforms. A 2021 “patriots only” rule ensures only pro-Beijing candidates can run; only 20 of 90 seats are directly elected. Voter turnout has plunged, making abstention one of the few peaceful means for residents to signal dissent.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: ‘Donbas Cowboy’ – Russians jailed for killing US volunteer on their side
articles.trailText: Russell Bentley, 63, was grabbed and tortured by soldiers who thought he was spying for Ukraine; $800m US arms shortfall, says Zelenskyy. What we know on day 1,385
articles.summary: Russian military court in Donetsk sentenced two soldiers to 12 years and a third to 11 for torturing and killing Russell 'Donbas Cowboy' Bentley, a 63-year-old US volunteer with Russian citizenship, before blowing up his body—an embarrassment for Moscow’s foreign fighter recruitment. President Zelenskyy cited an $800m US arms shortfall and a $15bn need for Purl-funded US weapons, ruling out ceding territory. EU leaders eye a £78bn frozen-assets loan for Kyiv. Zelenskyy met UK’s Starmer, France’s Macron and Germany’s Merz in London, then NATO/EU chiefs in Brussels, before visiting Italy, as Russian drones attacked Sumy.

articles.title: ‘Yellow line’ that divides Gaza under Trump plan is ‘new border’ for Israel, says military chief
articles.trailText: Eyal Zamir said Israel would hold on to current positions, giving it control of more than half of the territory
articles.summary: Israel’s chief of general staff, Eyal Zamir, has declared the “yellow line” in Donald Trump’s ceasefire plan a “new border,” committing to maintain military positions that secure over half of Gaza—key agricultural areas and the Egypt crossing—despite a clause forbidding occupation. Palestinians have been pushed into a narrow coastal enclave. Israel has built fortified outposts and declared the line lethal, shooting those who cross it. Zamir’s stance appears to contradict the ceasefire’s terms for phased Israeli withdrawal to an international force. Meanwhile, US documents envision splitting Gaza into an Israeli-controlled “green zone” for reconstruction and a devastated “red zone,” with true reunification deemed merely aspirational.

articles.title: European leaders rally behind Ukraine in Downing Street talks
articles.trailText: Hopes rise of a breakthrough in using £78bn of frozen Russian assets to bankroll Kyiv
articles.summary: European leaders—UK, France and Germany joined by seven peers, a Turkish envoy and NATO/EU chiefs—met Zelensky at Downing Street to seek a breakthrough on channeling £78 billion of frozen Russian assets into a ‘reparations loan’ for Kyiv. While Brussels’ mid-December summit aims to approve the plan, Belgium resists over liability fears at Euroclear. Participants pledged robust security guarantees, increased support and tighter pressure on Moscow. Zelensky, under Trump’s push for concessions, refused to cede territory. Further talks among national security advisers and foreign ministers will continue this week.

articles.title: Far-right National Rally ‘not a danger’ to France, Sarkozy claims
articles.trailText: Nicolas Sarkozy’s new book, The Diary of a Prisoner, is being released this week – and also details the time he spent in jail
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, reflecting on his 20-day jail stretch for his Gaddafi funding conviction in The Diary of a Prisoner, argues Marine Le Pen’s far-right National Rally is “not a danger” to France and declines to back a united anti-Le Pen front in 2027. He urges rebuilding a broad French right that includes RN voters, thanks Le Pen for her solidarity after his sentence, decries her ban from office post-embezzlement conviction and notes her pending appeal. He also recounts personal letters of support from RN MP Sébastien Chenu and a prison visit request from US envoy Charles Kushner.

articles.title: England health officials identify newly evolved variant of mpox
articles.trailText: Virus caught by person who travelled to Asia combines more severe form of mpox with less virulent type
articles.summary: UKHSA identified a recombinant mpox variant in England from a traveler returning from Asia, merging genetic elements of the more severe clade 1 and the less virulent clade 2. Genome sequencing confirms natural recombination; officials are evaluating its transmissibility and clinical severity. Although most mpox cases remain mild, authorities urge vaccination for eligible groups. This finding highlights ongoing viral evolution and underlines the importance of sustained genomic surveillance after global public health emergencies in 2022 and 2024 and nearly 48,000 cases reported to WHO in 2025.

articles.title: False claims Afrikaners are persecuted threaten South Africa’s sovereignty, says president
articles.trailText: Cyril Ramaphosa says theories, promoted by Donald Trump, ‘conveniently align with wider notions of white supremacy’
articles.summary: Cyril Ramaphosa warns that false claims of white Afrikaner persecution, amplified by figures like Donald Trump and Elon Musk, threaten South Africa’s sovereignty and security by aligning with white supremacist ideology. He urges a global campaign to counter the “white genocide” narrative as transformation and redress policies face fierce opposition. Tensions rose after the US boycott of the Johannesburg G20 summit, visa freezes, and refugee caps on white South Africans. Despite high-profile farm murders, there is no evidence of systemic, race-based targeting of the 4% Afrikaner minority.

articles.title: Zelenskyy meets European leaders in London for talks on ending Ukraine war
articles.trailText: Ukraine president’s UK visit comes amid heavy pressure from Washington for Kyiv to cede territory to Russia
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy met UK PM Keir Starmer, France’s Emmanuel Macron and Germany’s Friedrich Merz in London as US officials, led by the Trump administration, press Kyiv to cede territory to Russia under a proposed peace framework. European leaders pledged robust security guarantees, with Starmer refusing to pressure Zelenskyy and Merz sceptical of US terms. Polls show Ukrainians largely oppose concessions. Zelenskyy will brief Nato and EU chiefs in Brussels. Meanwhile, the new US national security strategy’s pro-Russia tone and anti-expansion NATO stance alarm Europe, even as Biden envoys seek a diplomatic breakthrough.

articles.title: European Council president warns US not to interfere in Europe’s affairs
articles.trailText: The new US national security strategy codifies a seismic shift in transatlantic relations, say experts
articles.summary: António Costa, president of the European Council, warned Donald Trump’s administration against meddling in European politics after its new US national security strategy cast Europe as vulnerable to “civilisational erasure” and pledged to “cultivate resistance” in the EU, effectively backing far-right nationalists. Welcomed by the Kremlin, the policy represents a seismic shift, analysts say, codifying open US support for regime change and aiming to influence elections—starting with Hungary’s in April. Experts urge EU leaders to stop appeasing Trump and craft a robust strategy to defend sovereignty and transatlantic ties.

articles.title: Can Syria’s president turn wave of global goodwill into tangible results at home?
articles.trailText: Sanctions, instability and external meddling are still problems for Ahmed al-Sharaa, one year after Assad’s fall
articles.summary: Since taking office in January 2025, former HTS leader Ahmed al-Sharaa has embarked on 21 overseas trips and hosted UN Security Council envoys, securing Gulf pledges including $6bn from Saudi Arabia and Qatari help to revive oil and gas. Yet Syria still grapples with chaos, opaque GDP, lingering US sanctions, Israeli airstrikes and ground incursions, and Turkish-Islamist tensions. Sharaa’s push for internal reconciliation, Kurdish integration and demilitarised buffers faces stalling over SDF autonomy and external meddling, testing whether global goodwill can translate into stability and genuine sovereignty.

articles.title: Thailand launches airstrikes along disputed border with Cambodia as tensions flare
articles.trailText: Escalation follows killing of Thai soldier and four Cambodian civilians weeks after Trump-brokered ceasefire
articles.summary: Thailand launched airstrikes along its disputed border with Cambodia after a Thai soldier was killed, killing at least one Thai soldier and four Cambodian civilians in Oddar Meanchey and Preah Vihear provinces. The strikes, targeting Cambodian military positions in response to alleged ceasefire breaches and weapons mobilization, have forced over 385,000 evacuations. The flare-up overturns a Trump-brokered ceasefire signed six weeks earlier. Cambodian officials blame Thailand; Hun Sen and ASEAN chair Anwar Ibrahim urge restraint, while Thailand’s PM denies launching aggression.

articles.title: US attack on Venezuela risks ‘Vietnam-style’ regional conflict, warns Lula adviser
articles.trailText: Brazil aide says Trump’s closure of Venezuelan airspace amounts to an ‘act of war’ that could escalate
articles.summary: Brazil’s foreign policy adviser Celso Amorim warns that any US invasion or attack on Venezuela—exemplified by President Trump’s closure of Venezuelan airspace, $50m bounty on Nicolás Maduro, the largest Caribbean naval deployment since 1962 and deadly airstrikes—amounts to an ‘act of war’ likely to spark a Vietnam-style conflict, galvanising regional resistance and rekindling anti-US sentiment. While Brazil doesn’t recognize Maduro’s disputed 2024 re-election, Amorim opposes forced regime change, preferring negotiated solutions like recall referenda and gradual political openings. He cautions that intervention risks plunging all of South America into prolonged guerrilla war and proposes diplomatic and democratic mechanisms for a peaceful transition.

articles.title: Silenced by China, Hong Kong struggles to voice its grief over the Tai Po fire disaster | Antony Dapiran
articles.trailText: The pain is visceral, but civil society, media and the creative community have been in retreat since the 2019 pro-democracy protests, says author Antony Dapiran
articles.summary: Under Beijing’s post-2019 security crackdown, Hong Kong’s grassroots activism has been gutted: at least 159 died and 31 remain missing in the Tai Po fire, yet pro-democracy legislators were jailed in 2021, independent outlets like Apple Daily and Stand News closed, civil society groups disbanded, and artists censored. Authorities swiftly detained activists demanding an inquiry, even under moral policing laws. A dispute over bamboo scaffolding as cultural heritage underscores identity politics. Unlike in mainland China, local officials face no real accountability, measured only by crushing dissent.

articles.title: A year after fall of Assad, a divided Syria struggles to escape cycle of violence
articles.trailText: While country’s return to global stage has filled many Syrians with pride, domestically old grievances threaten efforts to rebuild the state
articles.summary: As Syria marks one year since Assad’s 53-year reign ended after a rebel offensive, president Ahmad al-Sharaa has reinserted Damascus into global politics—easing U.S. sanctions, meeting Trump, curbing Iranian influence—and pledged reconstruction. But domestically, stalled transitional justice and daily targeted killings of former regime and Alawite figures, recent Druze and coastal massacres, and underfunded accountability bodies have reignited sectarian divides. Victims like wounded activist Ayman Ali and slain teacher Riham Hamouyeh wait for evidence to file complaints, while local re-enactment trials offer limited solace. With new security bureaus and a powerful presidency, activists warn Syria’s fragile peace may unravel without swift justice.

articles.title: Ancient Egyptian pleasure boat found by archaeologists off Alexandria coast
articles.trailText: First-century luxury vessel matches description by the Greek historian Strabo, who visited city around 29-25BC
articles.summary: Archaeologists from the European Institute for Underwater Archaeology, led by Franck Goddio, have uncovered a 35-metre, first-century AD Egyptian pleasure boat off the submerged island of Antirhodos near Alexandria’s Portus Magnus. Matched to Strabo’s account of royal excursion vessels, the craft features a central pavilion cabin, a 7-metre beam, flat bow and rounded stern for shallow-water navigation, and space for over 20 rowers. Lying just 7 m underwater and 1.5 m under sediment near the Temple of Isis, it may date to the temple’s AD 50 collapse or have served in the Navigium Isidis festival. Greek graffiti inscribed on its carling and preserved timbers promise fresh insights into luxury, religion and daily life in early Roman Egypt waterways.

articles.title: Israeli surveillance targets US and allies at joint base planning Gaza aid and security, say sources
articles.trailText: Concerns over recording of meetings at coordination centre excluding Palestinians that was set up to provide support for Trump’s Gaza plan
articles.summary: Sources say Israeli operatives have conducted covert audio recordings of US and allied staff at the Civil-Military Coordination Center (CMCC) in southern Israel, prompting US commander Lt Gen Patrick Frank to demand the practice cease. The CMCC, established in October to monitor the Gaza ceasefire, coordinate aid under Trump’s 20-point plan and plan Gaza’s reconstruction, excludes Palestinian representatives. Allies say Israel retains control over Gaza’s perimeter and restricts “dual-use” supplies, forcing US logisticians and diplomats to negotiate access. Observers warn the centre lacks a clear mandate, blurs military and humanitarian roles and may erode Palestinian agency over their territory’s future.

articles.title: Seizure of South Yemen by UAE-backed forces could lead to independence claim
articles.trailText: STC troops now control all eight governorates, a major setback for Emirates’ regional rival Saudi Arabia
articles.summary: UAE-backed Southern Transitional Council forces have seized control of all eight southern governorates of Yemen, including Hadramaut and Marib, prompting fears of a formal independence bid and a reversion to two Yemens. Saudi troops withdrew from Aden, marking a reversal for Riyadh, while Oman reopened its border. STC leader Aidarous al-Zubaidi, bolstered by UAE support, may push for a referendum as president Rashad al-Alimi appeals from Riyadh. Western envoys monitor talks on potential ties with Russia and Houthi conflict, with Taiz and Marib eyed as STC protectorates. Saudi and UAE relations face strain as regional alignments shift.

articles.title: Monday briefing: How this year’s Guardian charity appeal​ champions the best of British values
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The 2025 appeal​ supports grassroots organisations proving that compassion, connection and local action still have the power to transform lives
articles.summary: On Friday the Guardian launched its 2025 charity appeal to fund five grassroots organisations—Linking Network, Locality, Citizens UK, Who Is Your Neighbour? and Hope Unlimited—working in the UK’s most deprived areas to restore community spaces, run food banks, skills schemes and interfaith youth days. Editor-in-chief Katharine Viner and social policy editor Patrick Butler frame the campaign as a tribute to hope, compassion and social justice, even repurposing far-right slogans (“Bring back good old-fashioned British values”) to highlight unity. Readers can donate online, dial into a telethon on 13 December or give via the Guardian Bookshop until 31 December.

articles.title: Near-record low election turnout in Hong Kong amid discontent over apartment fire
articles.trailText: Sunday’s ‘patriots only’ Legislative Council elections took place in the shadow of the Tai Po fire that killed at least 159 people
articles.summary: Turnout for Hong Kong’s ‘patriots only’ Legislative Council election dipped to 31.9%, near 2021’s record low, as voters, disillusioned by restrictive vetting of candidates and discontent over the Tai Po fire that killed at least 159 people, abstained. Authorities extended polling hours, ran campaigns and offered incentives, yet boycotts remain one of the few safe dissent tools. Four people were arrested for incitement to spoil ballots; three face prosecutions. In parallel, mourning gatherings and calls for accountability over alleged building safety failures triggered a sweeping national security crackdown, with arrests of petitioners, activists and closure of memorial sites, raising fresh concerns about civil liberties under Beijing’s tightened control.

articles.title: Four members of same family killed in Goa nightclub fire that left 25 dead
