articles.trailText: Officials say the venue had contravened multiple safety regulations and that the basement had no fire safety exit
articles.summary: At just before midnight on Saturday, a fire at Birch by Romeo Lane nightclub in Goa’s Aporna district killed 25 people—including 20 staff who suffocated in a basement lacking fire exits—and five tourists from Delhi and Karnataka, among them three sisters and a brother-in-law on their first Goa holiday. One sister survived. Officials arrested the venue’s general manager, owners and event organisers after finding multiple safety violations: flammable wood and bamboo interiors, no basement exit, unauthorized pyrotechnics during a live show and potential electrical short circuit. Narrow lanes hindered emergency access. The Goa government has formed a high-level committee to submit its report within a week.

articles.title: Japan PM vows ‘resolute’ response after Chinese aircraft accused of locking radar on to Japanese fighter jets
articles.trailText: China’s ambassador summoned over alleged weekend incident that saw Chinese J-15 fighter aircraft twice train their radar on Japanese F-15s
articles.summary: Japan PM Sanae Takaichi vowed a calm but resolute response after Chinese J-15 fighters allegedly locked fire-control radar twice onto Japanese F-15s southeast of Okinawa. Tokyo summoned China’s ambassador, protesting the dangerous act—first such admission by Japan’s defence ministry, which recorded about 100 take-offs from China’s Liaoning carrier and radar illuminations at 16:32 and two hours later. No damage occurred, but the lock indicates a potential threat. Beijing denied the claims, accusing Japanese jets of harassing its carrier during far-sea drills and branding Tokyo’s accusations false. The incident adds to escalating tensions following Takaichi’s remarks on potential PLA action around Taiwan, prompting Chinese economic and maritime reprisals near Senkaku and Ryukyu islands.

articles.title: UN report sounds alarm over Māori rights in New Zealand
articles.trailText: UN committee raised concerns over government policies including scrapping the Māori Health Authority and funding cuts for Indigenous services
articles.summary: UN’s CERD report (5 Dec) delivers its strongest critique of NZ’s racial discrimination record, warning that scrapping the Māori Health Authority, budget cuts to Māori services, downgrading the Treaty of Waitangi in education and governance, and proposed land-rights changes risk entrenching systemic discrimination. It flags persistent Māori disparities in health, education, housing and justice and condemns framing affirmative action as "racial privilege." Māori leader Lady Tureiti Moxon hailed it unprecedented, while the coalition government defends reforms and promises to review recommendations. The committee calls on NZ to bolster Māori language revitalisation, environmental protection, redress over-representation in the justice system and strengthen land rights, demanding concrete implementation plans.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Peace talks with US constructive but ‘not easy’, says Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president’s comments after Florida negotiations come ahead of talks with European allies including Keir Starmer and Emmanuel Macron. What we know on day 1,384
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy said talks with US envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner were constructive but challenging, ahead of EU meetings in London with UK’s Keir Starmer, France’s Emmanuel Macron and Germany’s Friedrich Merz. Italy’s Giorgia Meloni pledged emergency energy aid after fresh Russian strikes, while the UK and US will reaffirm commitment to a peace deal. The Kremlin praised Donald Trump’s new security strategy, even as US officials say a final framework is near without sign-off by Kyiv or Moscow. Donald Trump Jr. criticized Ukraine’s leadership, and recent Russian missile, drone and shelling attacks killed at least four civilians.

articles.title: Murder inquiry under way after woman and child die in house fire in Co Offaly
articles.trailText: Police say the Edenderry home was deliberately set alight, leaving two dead and a third person seriously injured
articles.summary: After a deliberate blaze at a family home in Edenderry, County Offaly, on Saturday evening, 60-year-old Mary Holt and four-year-old Tadhg Farrell died; a woman in her 50s remains hospitalized with serious injuries. Gardaí have launched a murder investigation into the “reckless, callous and murderous” attack by an unidentified assailant. Postmortems are scheduled, and police urge anyone near Castleview Park estate to come forward. Justice Minister Jim O’Callaghan called it “heinous violence,” and local councillor Fergus McDonnell said the community is “absolutely distraught.”

articles.title: Troops and warplanes deployed in Benin after ‘failed coup attempt’
articles.trailText: West African Ecowas forces sent to country after group of soldiers announced dissolution of government on state TV
articles.summary: After a group of soldiers calling itself the Military Committee for Refoundation seized state TV and announced government dissolution in Cotonou, West African and Nigerian forces including Ghanaian, Ivorian, Nigerian and Sierra Leonean troops plus Nigerian air force jets were deployed to support President Patrice Talon and Benin’s army. Talon declared the failed coup under control, vowed punishment, and arrested 14 suspects. The attempt, ahead of April’s election, underscores regional threats from military unrest and jihadist insecurity in northern Benin.

articles.title: Being a nun offers me the best of both worlds: prayer and service to the poor | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Sister Sophia Rose responds to Emma Beddington’s article on how nuns are having a moment
articles.summary: Sister Sophia Rose, a Franciscan sister for two years, replies to Emma Beddington’s column on the resurgence of interest in religious life. She highlights active orders that marry communal prayer with practical service—running soup kitchens, homeless shelters, emergency food and housing programs, and street healthcare in central London. Emphasizing diverse forms of religious life—from cloistered contemplation to fully active apostolic work—she challenges cinematic stereotypes and underscores a vocation that combines spiritual community with real-world outreach.

articles.title: Kremlin hails Trump’s national security strategy as aligned with Russia’s vision
articles.trailText: Moscow welcomes White House document critical of the EU as talks to end the Ukraine war enter a key phase
articles.summary: The Kremlin praised Trump’s new national security strategy—criticizing the EU as risking “civilisational erasure”—as largely in line with Russian thinking, hailing signals of dialogue despite warning of a US “deep state” sabotage. As Trump envoys negotiate a Ukraine peace framework, Ukraine resists territory concessions without firm security guarantees. Zelenskyy’s Downing Street summit with Starmer, Macron and Merz follows difficult US-Ukraine talks in Florida and a Moscow envoy visit. Key sticking points: territory, Zaporizhzhia plant, Western troop presence. Meanwhile, winter strikes on Ukrainian energy grids escalate amid political turmoil in Kyiv.

articles.title: Disarming Hamas should not be first task of Gaza stabilisation force, Turkey says
articles.trailText: Ankara’s foreign minister suggests international partners should start by separating Israeli troops from Hamas
articles.summary: Turkey’s FM Hakan Fidan urged the UN-backed Gaza stabilization force to first separate Israeli troops and Hamas, delaying any forced disarmament. He noted Indonesia and Azerbaijan back Turkey’s troop contribution despite Israel’s veto attempts. Egypt’s FM called for monitors along Gaza’s “yellow line” to enforce the ceasefire, while Norway warned delays risk renewed war. Gulf and Turkish proposals would have Hamas hand weapons to a Palestinian Authority, a plan Israel rejects. Hamas says it will disarm only to a sovereign Palestinian state. Qatari and Saudi officials stress full Israeli withdrawal must precede lasting security.

articles.title: The Right Rev Thomas McMahon obituary
articles.trailText: Roman Catholic bishop noted for opposing nuclear arms and abortion, and for remodelling Brentwood Cathedral in Essex
articles.summary: Thomas McMahon (1936–2025), RC bishop of Brentwood (1980–2014), was a liturgical traditionalist who funded Quinlan Terry’s neoclassical rebuild of Brentwood Cathedral, drawing criticism over expenditure. As Pax Christi vice-president from 1989, he led full-vestment anti-nuclear vigils at arms fairs and the US embassy, opposed Trident renewal and exposed UK arms sales to Indonesia. He also joined anti-abortion protests at Marie Stopes. Trained in Paris and a former Essex University chaplain, he championed ecumenical and multifaith initiatives before retiring as Stock parish priest until his death aged 89.

articles.title: First phase of Gaza ceasefire plan nearly complete, says Netanyahu
articles.trailText: Israeli PM to discuss next steps with Donald Trump this month but timetable for lasting peace remains unclear
articles.summary: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu said the first phase of the UN-backed Gaza ceasefire plan—codified in UNSC resolution 2803—was nearly complete after Hamas freed 20 hostages and Israeli forces withdrew to a ceasefire line. Speaking with German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, Netanyahu said phase two must disarm Hamas and demilitarize Gaza. He will meet Donald Trump in Washington this month to outline next steps, though no timeline or sequence for lasting peace, troop withdrawals and an international stabilization force has been set. He also floated alternatives to the ISF, refused to rule out West Bank annexation and dismissed ICC arrest warrants against him as politically motivated.

articles.title: Two marathon organisers arrested in Iran over women running without hijabs
articles.trailText: Judiciary says a criminal case has been opened after online images showed a number of unveiled female competitors
articles.summary: Iranian judiciary arrested two organisers of a Kish Island marathon after online photos showed unveiled female runners. The event, with 5,000 participants, breached mandatory hijab and public decency laws, prompting a criminal case. One organiser is a Kish free zone official, the other from the private promoter. Ultraconservative outlets condemned the race; lawmakers and the chief justice demanded stricter hijab enforcement. This incident follows sporadic veil observance since Mahsa Amini protests. President Masoud Pezeshkian’s administration has resisted harsher dress code penalties, while past sports events also saw officials ousted for hijab breaches.

articles.title: African swine fever outbreak in Spain may have leaked from research lab, officials say
articles.trailText: Authorities say strain of virus that has killed wild boars in Catalonia is one often used for experiments in secure facilities
articles.summary: Spain’s agriculture ministry is probing a possible lab leak after 13 African swine fever cases in wild boar near Barcelona tested positive for a ‘Georgia 2007’ strain used in research, not matching EU outbreaks. Catalonia’s president has ordered audits of five high-security labs within 20 km. Authorities tested 37 additional wild boars (all negative) and inspected 39 pig farms with no infections; over 100 military emergency personnel have been deployed. As the EU’s top pork exporter (€8.8 bn annually), Spain races to contain threats to its key pig sector.

articles.title: Canada may approve a new oil pipeline. First Nations fear another ‘worst-case scenario’
articles.trailText: Mark Carney is considering lifting a tanker ban that has protected coastal communities for 53 years
articles.summary: After the 2016 grounding and 110,000-litre diesel spill from the Nathan E Stewart tug near Heiltsuk territory devastated clam-garden harvests and remains uncompensated, the federal gov’t under PM Carney is weighing an Alberta-BC bitumen pipeline plus lifting a 53-year tanker ban. Coastal First Nations unanimously oppose any reversal, citing tempestuous Hecate Strait risks, ecological and cultural losses, and years-long spill impacts. BC’s premier also deems scrapping the ban a non-starter without consent, warning of severe economic harm.

articles.title: C of E to challenge Tommy Robinson’s ‘put Christ back into Christmas’ message
articles.trailText: Church leaders respond to far-right appropriation of Christian symbols with ‘Outsiders welcome’ message
articles.summary: The Church of England is launching a national poster campaign—’Christ has always been in Christmas’ and ’Outsiders welcome’—to challenge Tommy Robinson’s far-right ‘put the Christ back into Christmas’ carol event. Displayed at bus stops and offered as downloadable resources, the initiative counters Christian nationalism’s appropriation of faith. Backed by the Joint Public Issues Team (Baptist, Methodist and URC), and echoing an open letter by senior Christian leaders, Bishop Arun Arora says it reaffirms a commitment to justice for migrants, inspired by the Holy Family’s refugee flight.

articles.title: Hostile powers sending spies to west’s universities, says former security chief
articles.trailText: Canadian expert David Vigneault warns of China’s ‘industrial-strength’ attempts to steal new technologies
articles.summary: Former CSIS chief David Vigneault warns that hostile spy agencies, notably China’s, have shifted from targeting government secrets to infiltrating Western universities and private-sector R&D through cyber-attacks, agent infiltration and staff recruitment. Beijing allegedly runs industrial-scale programmes to strip military applications from stolen innovations for the PLA. Vigneault urges national security screenings for sensitive academic programmes while cautioning against racial profiling of Chinese scholars. Now at security adviser Strider, he calls for broad societal vigilance and sovereign data platforms amid big-power competition.

articles.title: Tourists among at least 25 killed in Goa nightclub fire
articles.trailText: Fire broke out at midnight in Arpora with victims mostly kitchen workers, according to state’s chief minister
articles.summary: At least 25 people, including several tourists, were killed in a fire that broke out around midnight on 6 December at Birch by Romeo Lane, a popular restaurant–bar–club in Arpora, Goa. A live music show was underway when flames erupted on the first floor and spread rapidly, trapping many basement workers who suffocated due to lack of an alternate exit. Around 100 patrons were present; most guests escaped, but staff and some visitors were entrapped. Goa CM Pramod Sawant ordered a probe, warning of strict action for negligence. Initial reports cite proper licensing but absent emergency exits. The blaze, extinguished overnight, left the building a charred shell and prompted calls for comprehensive safety audits amid recurring fatal fires in India.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: With no Miami breakthrough, Zelenskyy turns to European allies
articles.trailText: Positive tone after Florida talks with Ukrainian president heading to London Street to see Starmer, Macron and Merz. What we know on day 1,383
articles.summary: Three days of Ukraine–US talks in Miami ended without a breakthrough. Zelenskyy called them “substantive and constructive,” agreed next steps for peace, and is now heading to London to meet Keir Starmer, Emmanuel Macron and Friedrich Merz to “take stock” of negotiations and discuss a potential European peacekeeping force. Meanwhile, Russian air strikes on Kremenchuk, plus over 700 drone and missile attacks, knocked out power, water and heating. The IAEA warned damage to Chornobyl’s new safe confinement compromises its radiation shield. Hungary’s Viktor Orbán plans a business mission to Russia, while Bulgaria protested a crippled tanker towed into its waters after a Black Sea drone strike.

articles.title: Gunmen kill at least 12 people including three-year-old in hostel in South Africa
articles.trailText: Police launch ‘manhunt’ after 25 people are shot in early morning in township attack west of Pretoria
articles.summary: In early morning raid on a hostel in Saulsville township, west of Pretoria, gunmen opened fire indiscriminately, killing 12 people—among them a three-year-old child, a 12-year-old boy and a 16-year-old girl—and wounding at least 13 others, with a total of 25 shot. Police have launched a manhunt for three suspects and are probing links to an illegal shebeen on site. Forensic teams are investigating amid concerns over alcohol-fuelled violence at unlicensed bars in South Africa, which reports over 60 daily murders between April and September.

articles.title: Zelenskyy to meet Starmer at Downing Street to discuss US draft peace deal
articles.trailText: Emmanuel Macron and Friedrich Merz will also be present for talks on guaranteeing Ukraine’s postwar security
articles.summary: Volodymyr Zelenskyy will visit Downing Street on Monday to meet UK Labour leader Keir Starmer alongside Emmanuel Macron and Friedrich Merz to discuss a US-brokered draft peace deal and postwar security guarantees for Ukraine. The four, part of a “coalition of the willing,” back using current front lines as a negotiation base and exploring a European peacekeeping force. Kyiv last month amended an earlier US-Russia draft criticized for ceding too much to Moscow. Overnight Russia launched a major drone and missile assault on Ukrainian infrastructure. US-Ukraine talks continue in Florida, even as Washington balances Ukraine’s survival with strategic stability with Russia.

articles.title: Syria interim president accuses Israel of fighting ‘ghosts’ and exporting crises
articles.trailText: Ahmed al-Sharaa says Israel justifies aggression in the name of security amid airstrikes on southern Syria
articles.summary: At a Doha conference on Dec 6, interim Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa accused Israel of using Gaza’s war to justify over 1,000 airstrikes and 400 incursions into southern Syria, dubbing its security rationale ‘fighting ghosts’ and exporting crises. He defended Syria’s adherence to the 1974 Golan disengagement agreement, warned against a demilitarised zone without Syrian army protection, and said he’s negotiating—with US backing—for Israel’s withdrawal to pre-8 December borders while overseeing transitional elections.

articles.title: Russia launches attacks across Ukraine as Miami peace talks continue
articles.trailText: More than 650 drones target locations across Ukraine including western regions with sirens sounding in eastern Poland
articles.summary: Ukraine was hit overnight by a massive Russian drone and missile assault—650+ drones and 51 missiles—targeting power stations, energy infrastructure and sites deep in western regions, triggering sirens in eastern Poland and injuring three near Kyiv. Russia said it shot down 116 Ukrainian drones and reported debris at a Ryazan oil refinery. Meanwhile, US and Ukrainian negotiators in Miami pressed on with peace talks exploring Ukrainian land concessions for security guarantees after a Putin–Witkoff–Kushner meeting in Moscow. With Russia unwilling to endorse US terms, EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas affirmed the US-European alliance despite Washington��s controversial security strategy.

articles.title: Maduro says the real reason for Trump’s Venezuela fixation is oil – is he right?
articles.trailText: The South American country facing a huge US military buildup has almost a fifth of known global reserves
articles.summary: President Nicolás Maduro claims Donald Trump’s Caribbean military buildup targets Venezuela’s vast oil reserves—the largest globally—while the US insists its operations, including boat airstrikes that killed over 80 people, combat drug trafficking. Critics counter that these strikes barely stem cocaine flows, suggesting oil is the hidden agenda. Analysts note Venezuela holds almost 20% of global reserves but produces under 1% of oil output due to heavy sour crude, corruption, mismanagement and sanctions. Reviving production to 4–5 million barrels a day would require over $100 billion and years of investment, with companies prioritizing political stability and risk assessments.

articles.title: Harbadus attacks Andvaria: cyber war game tests Nato defences against Russia
articles.trailText: Power blackouts, public chaos and loss of communication with space were all thrown at troops in seven days
articles.summary: At NATO’s largest cyber war game held near the Russian border in Tallinn (CyberRange14), 29 member states, seven allies and 1,000+ participants tested readiness against a seven-day rolling assault by fictitious Harbadus on ally Andvaria’s digital infrastructure around Icebergen. Scenarios featured power-grid blackouts, satellite jamming, GPS disruption, fuel-system malware, fake news and data dumps. Troops practiced cross-border threat sharing, legal response frameworks and piloted an OpenAI-based AI chatbot for situational awareness. The exercise reflects rising real-world Russian and Chinese cyber operations—up 25% against NATO states—and a shift toward proactive hybrid defence strategies.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Progress depends on Russia taking peace talks seriously, say Washington and Kyiv
articles.trailText: US and Ukraine to hold third day of discussions in Florida as Emmanuel Macron says there is ‘no mistrust’ between Europe and White House
articles.summary: US and Ukrainian envoys convened a third day of peace talks in Miami, agreeing that progress hinges on Russia’s genuine commitment to de-escalation, cessation of killings and robust security arrangements. Their discussions follow special envoys’ Kremlin meeting with Vladimir Putin, who rejected parts of the US plan and warned of war if Europe acts. Meanwhile, Emmanuel Macron reaffirmed transatlantic unity in Beijing as EU leaders debate using frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine. Overnight, Russia launched drone and missile attacks on Fastiv and Chernihiv regions, while Ukraine struck Russian territory, including Ryazan and Grozny, with no reported casualties except one boy killed in Dnipropetrovsk.

articles.title: Swedish navy encountering Russian submarines ‘almost weekly’ – and more could be on the way
articles.trailText: Moscow ‘continuously reinforcing’ its presence in the region, says Swedish chief of operations Capt Marko Petkovic
articles.summary: Swedish navy chief Capt Marko Petkovic says his forces encounter Russian submarines in the Baltic almost weekly as Moscow steadily reinforces regional presence. Hybrid threats—from drone attacks to underwater infrastructure sabotage and shadow oil tankers—test surveillance in Baltic’s complex waters. Sweden hosted NATO’s anti-submarine exercise Playbook Merlin 25 with nine countries, boosting detection skills. Russia’s one-a-year Kilo-class sub production and fleet modernization underscore potential post-ceasefire buildup, prompting Sweden to expand naval capacity. Operation Baltic Sentry’s cohesion has halted cable incidents, raising merchant-vessel caution in Baltic transit. He warns that Baltic littoral states—Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia and Lithuania—rely on secure sea lines for energy and trade, making underwater assets vulnerable.

articles.title: Bombed Chornobyl shelter no longer blocks radiation and needs major repair – IAEA
articles.trailText: Drone attack that Ukraine blamed on Russia blew hole in painstakingly erected €1.5bn shield meant to allow for final clean-up of 1986 meltdown site
articles.summary: The IAEA has reported that February’s drone strike, blamed by Ukraine on Russia, created a hole in the €1.5bn New Safe Confinement at Chornobyl, rendering it incapable of blocking radiation despite no permanent harm to its load-bearing structure or monitoring systems. Erected in 2019 by a Europe-led initiative to replace the expiring Soviet-era sarcophagus, temporary repairs have begun, but comprehensive restoration is vital to preserve long-term nuclear safety. Radiation remains stable. The inspection occurred during Ukraine war damage surveys; Russia denies involvement.

articles.title: ‘We have to end the melancholy’: the French leftwing MP intent on resisting the far right
articles.trailText: Clémentine Autain believes only a leftwing alliance united behind one leader can stave off the threat of a far-right president
articles.summary: Clémentine Autain, MP for Seine-Saint-Denis, is launching a bid to become the unified left’s 2027 presidential candidate to block the rising far-right National Rally. Polls show Le Pen or Bardella could win amid voter anger over inequality and public service cuts. Autain, a staunch radical advocating billionaire taxes (Zucman levy) and expanded social funding, co-founded L’Après after splitting from La France Insoumise. Primary rivals include Greens leader Marine Tondelier, MP François Ruffin and the Socialists; Mélenchon and Raphaël Glucksmann have declined. Her personal feminist activism and memoir-based film underscore her fight against reactionary forces.

articles.title: Zootopia 2 bucks trend for Hollywood releases in China as it breaks records for foreign animation
articles.trailText: Surprise success of film, known as Zootropolis in some countries, bucks trend for Chinese to spurn Hollywood in favour of domestic productions
articles.summary: Zootopia 2 (aka Zootropolis 2) grossed about 2 bn yuan (£213 m) in its first week in China, breaking the single-day import record on day 4 (surpassing Avengers: Endgame) and becoming the highest-grossing foreign animated film there, outpacing the original’s 1.5 bn yuan. Extended six-week screening, strong marketing since 2016, and the new snake character Gary De’Snake—timely in the Year of the Snake—fueled its feel-good appeal amid waning Hollywood imports, capturing 40% of US film revenue in China this year.

articles.title: ‘No mistrust’ between Europe and US over Ukraine, Macron says
articles.trailText: French president’s remarks come a day after a report claimed he had warned Washington could betray Kyiv
articles.summary: During a visit to China, French President Emmanuel Macron refuted reports by Der Spiegel claiming he warned President Zelensky of a US ‘betrayal’ of Ukraine, stressing ‘no mistrust’ and underscoring essential Europe-US unity on peace efforts. The alleged leak of a confidential call, in which Macron and German Chancellor Merz voiced doubts over Washington’s negotiations, sparked tensions as EU leaders debate a €90 bn funding plan for Kyiv—opposing proposals to seize frozen Russian assets—and US and Ukrainian envoys hold third-day talks on postwar security.

articles.title: From ‘terrorist’ to national treasure, renowned Māori activist finally tells his own story
articles.trailText: Tāme Iti’s colourful memoir covers his decades-long fight for Indigenous rights in New Zealand and takes aim at ‘saboteurs’ in the government
articles.summary: Tāme Iti’s memoir Mana traces his journey from a schoolboy punished for speaking Māori to a national treasure leading the Māori renaissance. He recounts founding the “Māori embassy” on parliament lawns, the 1975 Land March that birthed the Waitangi Tribunal, and his 2007 Te Urewera arrest. Blending art, direct action and whakapapa, he unveils run-ins with police, protests that burned cars and flags, and the sprawling 2024 hīkoi and Waitangi Day rallies. Ending with a call to dismantle colonial infrastructure and forge new, Indigenous-led relationships, Mana is both personal history and rallying cry for land and language.

articles.title: German MPs rubberstamp military service plan amid school pupil protests
articles.trailText: All 18-year-old men to be screened for suitability for armed forces, but proposal falls short of conscription
articles.summary: German parliament on Dec 5 approved a new military service model obliging all 18-year-old men to complete a suitability screening from Jan 1 without reinstating full conscription. If volunteers fail to boost troop strength to 460,000 (260,000 active, 200,000 reservists), MPs must debate reintroducing conscription, Defence Minister Boris Pistorius warned. The bill passed 323–272 with one abstention amid climate-style “school strike” protests in 90 cities. SPD MP Siemtje Möller dismissed conscription fears as “populism,” while AfD and Die Linke led opposition. Incentives include higher pay, funded driving licences and language courses to attract recruits.

articles.title: Putin vows oil shipments to India will be ‘uninterrupted’ in defiance of US
articles.trailText: Narendra Modi says energy security is ‘pillar of the India-Russia partnership’ as two leaders meet in Delhi
articles.summary: In Delhi, Vladimir Putin pledged to maintain uninterrupted oil shipments to India, defying recent US-imposed 25% tariffs on New Delhi’s purchase of discounted Russian crude. Framing energy security as a pillar of their decades-long strategic partnership, he rebuffed Western pressure alongside Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The joint statement underscored ties “resilient to external pressure” and accompanied new defence and economic agreements aimed at doubling bilateral trade to $100 bn by 2030, including plans for joint production of advanced military platforms. This marked Putin’s first visit since the Ukraine invasion.

articles.title: Edinburgh airport resumes flights after services suspended due to IT problem
articles.trailText: EasyJet, British Airways and Ryanair passengers among those caught up in cancellations caused by air traffic control problems
articles.summary: Edinburgh airport suspended departures Friday morning after Air Navigation Solutions (ANS) suffered an IT fault in its air traffic control system. Operations resumed at 10:40 GMT, though delays and cancellations persisted: EasyJet, British Airways, Ryanair, Delta and United flights were disrupted, including a diverted New York–Edinburgh service. Passengers waited up to two hours; some transatlantic and domestic connections were rerouted. A mother, “Felicity,” said she would miss her youngest child’s final nativity play. ANS engineers restored the system, blaming an unrelated technical glitch. Scotland’s busiest airport handles 43,000 passengers daily across 155 destinations.

articles.title: Friday briefing: After ​constant leak​s and ​a resignation​, is the OBR ​still ​fit for ​purpose?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: ​Critics say the OBR’s growing influence has outpaced its accountability​, raising questions about whether it serves the public, the Treasury, or the markets
articles.summary: The OBR, designed as an independent budget watchdog, has been thrust into the political spotlight by multiple leaks—including an early release of Rachel Reeves’s budget—and the subsequent resignation of chair Richard Hughes. Critics from MPs to think-tanks accuse it of lacking accountability, producing volatile forecasts and prioritising markets over the public. Debates now focus on its political independence, forecasting accuracy amid economic shocks and whether to reform or abolish it without undermining fiscal credibility.

articles.title: EU leaders race to save Ukraine funding deal as Kyiv’s cash runs low
articles.trailText: ‘Future of Europe’ at stake with Von der Leyen and Merz desperate to persuade Belgian PM to allow use of frozen Russian assets
articles.summary: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen will hold emergency talks with Belgian PM Bart De Wever in Brussels, aiming to unlock a €90bn package to fund Ukraine’s military and services. Von der Leyen proposes borrowing on markets or issuing a loan secured by €290bn of frozen Russian assets, repaid via postwar reparations. Belgium rejects the asset plan over legal risks, demanding joint EU borrowing. Splits ahead of the 18 December summit threaten EU credibility and strategic independence, Merz warns.

articles.title: Bring forth your crafts, customs and traditions: UK to recognise UN cultural heritage list
articles.trailText: Call for submissions from across UK could include cheese rolling, Burns Night suppers and Notting Hill carnival
articles.summary: Eighteen months after ratifying UNESCO’s 2003 convention on intangible cultural heritage, the UK has launched a public call––open until February––to nominate domestic traditions for four national lists (England, Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland) plus a UK-wide inventory due next summer. Culture minister Fiona Twycross urged proposals spanning seven categories, from sports and games (Cheese Rolling on Cooper’s Hill) and performing arts (Highland dancing, steel drumming) to crafts (Welsh love spoons, dry-stone walling), culinary practices (Burns Night suppers) and immigrant-heritage events such as Notting Hill Carnival.

articles.title: US considers wider sanctions on Sudanese army and RSF as ceasefire efforts falter
articles.trailText: Trump envoy fails to secure deal as Norway prepares to host talks on how to restore civilian government in Sudan
articles.summary: The US, frustrated by envoy Massad Boulos’s failure to secure a ceasefire between General Burhan’s army and the Rapid Support Forces, is weighing far broader sanctions on both sides. Donald Trump, urged on by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, will likely target groups blocking peace and enforce the Darfur arms embargo. Norway is convening Oslo talks with Sudanese civilian groups to plan a post-conflict transition. The two-year war has killed some 40,000 people, displaced over 14 million and prompted warnings of looming atrocities.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: drones reportedly spotted near Zelenskyy flight path on Dublin trip
articles.trailText: Irish navy ship spotted suspicious drones near the flight path of Zelenskyy’s aircraft as he landed on Monday in Ireland, local media reported. What we know on day 1,3811
articles.summary: An Irish navy ship detected up to five drones near President Zelenskyy’s flight path 20 km northeast of Dublin airport on Dec 5, triggering a security alert though no threat materialised. Russia’s Putin warned Ukraine to withdraw from Donbas or face force, calling recent India talks with US envoys “useful but difficult.” Macron and Germany’s Merz cautioned Zelenskyy on unclear US guarantees. The EU debates a reparations loan using frozen Russian assets. Ukraine struck a major chemical plant in Stavropol. Turkey summoned envoys over Black Sea drone attacks, and 130+ UK MPs urged safeguards for deported Ukrainian children in any US-led peace plan.

articles.title: Yasser abu Shabab, leader of Israel-backed militia, killed in Gaza
articles.trailText: Death of commander of Popular Forces is blow to Israel’s efforts to confront Hamas through proxy groups
articles.summary: Yasser abu Shabab, Bedouin leader and commander of the Israeli-backed Popular Forces militia in Gaza, was killed in a clash with powerful local families over a hostage dispute, dealing a major blow to Israel’s proxy strategy against Hamas. Sources say he died of a gunshot wound while intervening in clan infighting. Hamas denies responsibility. Abu Shabab, in his 30s and expelled by his own tribe, led the largest proxy group since Israel began arming anti-Hamas factions post-2023 invasion. His death highlights limits of Netanyahu’s reliance on local militias and casts doubt on their ability to contain Hamas.

articles.title: Putin and Modi to meet amid politically treacherous times for Russia and India
articles.trailText: Delhi visit gives Russian leader a chance to reduce Moscow’s isolation but both countries need each other to negotiate Trump’s US and a powerful China
articles.summary: Putin’s Dec 2025 Delhi visit marks his first in four years, signalling Russia’s return from Ukraine-induced isolation. Meeting Modi against US pressure and China’s rise, they’ll discuss defence cooperation—balancing India’s cut in Russian arms from 70% to under 40%—and energy ties amid US/EU sanctions on Russian oil. For Russia it’s proof of normalizing relations; for India, a hedging strategy amid Trump’s punitive tariffs and a turbulent geopolitical climate. India values Russia as a continental balancer against China but seeks to diversify suppliers and avoid overdependence under Beijing’s sway.

articles.title: Federica Mogherini resigns from College of Europe amid corruption inquiry
articles.trailText: Former EU foreign policy chief to also stand down as head of diplomatic academy at centre of investigation
articles.summary: Federica Mogherini, the EU’s former foreign policy chief (2014–19), has resigned as rector of the College of Europe and director of its €1m Diplomatic Academy amid a European Public Prosecutor’s Office inquiry. EPPO has formally charged her and ex-EEAS civil servant Stefano Sannino with procurement fraud, corruption, conflict of interest and breach of professional secrecy, stemming from alleged sharing of inside information to win the 2023 tender. Investigations, including raids on EEAS HQ and Mogherini’s home, proceed as both deny wrongdoing under Belgian due process.

articles.title: Wheelchair worry for young disabled people | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Chris Burgess says her daughter has had to reapply for a wheelchair seven times, in response to an article by Paul Sagar. Plus a letter from Charlie Hislop
articles.summary: In letters responding to Paul Sagar’s Guardian piece on the NHS wheelchair service, Chris Burgess highlights her 38-year-old daughter’s struggle: daily-use chairs break down every five years, forcing seven reapplications and hampering younger users still in education. She argues standard satisfaction surveys skew toward elderly, part-time wheelchair users, masking the repeated delays and barriers faced by those fully dependent on chairs. Charlie Hislop adds a critique of Sagar’s support for privatising hospital cleaning, citing decades of contractor failures and superbug outbreaks, and urging accountable public services for the vulnerable.

articles.title: Here’s why we can’t get rid of ‘mansplaining’ | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Dr Amanda Nimon Peters responds to an article by Zoe Williams in which she said we should stop using the term
articles.summary: Dr Amanda Nimon Peters rebuts Zoe Williams’s proposal to retire “mansplaining,” warning it risks gaslighting women about systemic bias. She cites a Conversation study by Ashley and Doldor linking the term to male—and specifically white, middle/upper-class—authority coding, and her own research demonstrating pervasive implicit authority bias. Occasional fair usage doesn’t negate its validity; ‘mansplaining’ remains essential to describe real, gendered power dynamics until authority is seen as gender-neutral.

articles.title: Macron reportedly warned Zelenskyy US may ‘betray Ukraine on territory’
articles.trailText: Der Spiegel quotes leaked call in which European leaders voice doubts about Washington’s approach to peace talks
articles.summary: Macron warned Zelensky of a risk the US could ‘betray Ukraine on territory’ due to murky security guarantees, according to a Der Spiegel‐leaked summary of a call with EU leaders. Germany’s chancellor Merz urged caution, alluding to Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner’s Kremlin mission. Finland’s Alexander Stubb and NATO’s Mark Rutte echoed concerns. Participants confirmed authenticity, though Paris disputes Macron’s quotes. This unfolds amid US’s contested 28-point peace plan and renewed diplomacy in Geneva, Florida and Moscow. German ministers Pistorius and Merz call on Europe to independently back Ukraine, even using frozen Russian assets.

articles.title: US and EU critical minerals project could displace thousands in DRC – report
articles.trailText: Global Witness says plan to upgrade railway line to Angola puts up to 1,200 buildings at risk of demolition
articles.summary: Campaign group Global Witness warns that the US- and EU-backed Lobito Corridor rail upgrade across the DRC – part of a $4.5bn Angola stretch plus a $553m USDFC loan and €50m EU pledge – could demolish up to 1,200 buildings and displace 6,500 residents, mainly in Kolwezi’s Bel Air neighbourhood. Lobito Atlantic Railway (Mota-Engil, Trafigura, Vecturis) holds a 30-year Angola concession while DRC’s SNCC operates its segment. Expanding the buffer zone from 10m to 25m threatens informal settlements with forced evictions amid contested land titles and pending social and environmental impact assessments.

articles.title: Outcry in Italy over sex education bill to crack down on ‘gender ideology’
articles.trailText: Legislation is needed to stop leftwing politicians ‘bringing drag queens and porn actors into schools’, minister says
articles.summary: Italy’s far-right government under Giorgia Meloni has approved a sex education bill for 11–14-year-olds that requires written parental consent and bans lessons in primary schools. Presented as a clampdown on “gender ideology” and “woke” activism, it aligns middle schools with high-school procedures. Opposition parties, campaigners and victims’ families denounce it as regressive, warning it undermines violence-prevention and femicide-prevention efforts. The bill now moves to the Senate, while polls show up to 90% of students and 80% of parents favor compulsory sex education.

articles.title: ‘Day by day I lose weight’: asylum seekers on Nauru get $115 a week, but a bag of grapes costs $20
articles.trailText: Forbidden from working, people sent to the island by Australia say they are struggling to survive because food is so expensive
articles.summary: Asylum seekers sent by Australia to Nauru—over 160 since 2023—face dire conditions: barred from work while awaiting processing, they receive A$230 fortnightly (A$115/week) yet imported staples cost A$20 for grapes or A$24 for watermelon. With monthly mobile data at A$99 and accommodation funded under Australia’s A$750 million MTC contract, many skip meals, lose weight and risk unlawful work. Only eight have gained legal work rights, while some remain detained over four months past the 60-day target. Fearful of deportation to persecution, advocates urge Australia to uphold non-refoulement duties and ensure basic survival rights.

articles.title: US envoy Steve Witkoff to meet Ukraine national security chief in Miami
articles.trailText: Meeting comes two days after Witkoff and Jared Kushner held five hours of talks with Vladimir Putin in Moscow
articles.summary: US special envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, fresh from five hours of talks with Putin in Moscow, will meet Ukraine national security chief Rustem Umerov in Miami as Washington intensifies efforts to broker peace. Kremlin insists talks made no progress; Putin demands full Donbas control, which Kyiv and Zelensky reject outright. A leaked European leaders' transcript reveals fears the US may abandon Ukraine and questions Washington’s reliability. Meanwhile, Brussels debates loans from frozen Russian assets and the UN General Assembly calls for the return of abducted Ukrainian children.

articles.title: Earthquake of 3.3 magnitude rattles Lancashire and Lake District
articles.trailText: Residents report homes shaking from quake with epicentre near the village of Silverdale in Lancashire
articles.summary: Shortly after 11.23pm on Wednesday a 3.3-magnitude earthquake struck near Silverdale in Lancashire, the strongest in England since a 3.3-magnitude event in Staffordshire in 2023. Tremors were felt up to 30 miles away, including Blackpool and parts of Cumbria, prompting over 1,100 reports of shaking, rattling shop alarms and panicked pets. Emergency services confirmed no injuries or structural damage. The British Geological Survey notes such quakes (3.0+) are rare—only two or three occur annually in the UK—and this was north-west England’s largest since a 3.7 tremor in Morecambe Bay in 2009.

articles.title: Children’s rights must be protected in any Ukraine peace plan, 130 MPs tell Foreign Office
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Letter by cross-party group to Stephen Doughty warns of omission in US proposals involving Russia
articles.summary: A cross-party group of 132 UK MPs, led by Labour’s Johanna Baxter, has urged Foreign Office minister Stephen Doughty to ensure any US-brokered Ukraine peace plan explicitly protects forcibly deported Ukrainian children under the Geneva conventions. They warn the current 28-point framework omits special child safeguards and risks granting amnesty to alleged war criminals, including Vladimir Putin and Russia’s children’s commissioner, Maria Lvova-Belova. MPs also caution that recognizing Russian sovereignty over Crimea, Donetsk and Luhansk would imperil 1.6 million Ukrainian children, erode their rights and hollow out the fourth Geneva convention, and call on the UK to insist on accountability and uphold international humanitarian law.

articles.title: Hardline migration policies are fuelling people smuggling, report finds
articles.trailText: As leaders try to break smugglers’ business model, research suggests strategy so far has had opposite effect
articles.summary: A Mixed Migration Centre report by the Danish Refugee Council, based on 80,000+ interviews with migrants (2019���2025) and 458 smugglers across Africa, finds that tougher enforcement and slogans like “break the business model” have instead boosted demand for people smuggling and driven up fees. Even as arrivals to Italy fell in 2024, 44% of central Mediterranean smugglers saw demand rise, 57% raised prices over heightened risks, and nearly half colluded with state officials. Just 6% of migrants said smugglers influenced their journeys, highlighting that shrinking legal pathways, not smuggler deception, fuel irregular migration.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: ​Will the ramped up rhetoric of Reform bring about the demise of the Conservatives?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Claims of the Tories’ ‘death’ are becoming a political tactic that risks galvanising supporters just as Westminster enters uncharted territory
articles.summary: After the Tories’ poor local election showing, Nigel Farage and ex-minister Justine Greening have proclaimed the Conservative Party ‘dead’, arguing Reform’s rise signals their end. Farage has intensified anti-Tory messaging, forecasting an inevitable deal or merger despite denials. Guardian’s Peter Walker and ConservativeHome’s Giles Dilnot counter that while Tory support sits at historic lows (around 18%), the party isn’t extinct and may even be galvanised by these claims. They note Kemi Badenoch’s improving standing, the UK’s unprecedented multi-party fragmentation and the prominence of potential confidence-and-supply or coalition scenarios ahead of the next general election.

articles.title: ‘Embodying the zeitgeist more than ever’: German sitcom character Stromberg revived for Merz era
articles.trailText: New film is based on TV series inspired by The Office, whose lead character is said to resemble the chancellor
articles.summary: German satire character Bernd Stromberg returns in Stromberg – Wieder Alles Wie Immer, a feature film sequel to the 2004–12 sitcom inspired by The Office. With Christoph Maria Herbst reprising his opportunistic, cringe-inducing insurance manager, the movie riffs on workplace mockumentary tropes and includes real CDU figures endorsing Stromberg’s outdated sexism. Since Friedrich Merz’s chancellorship this year, memes dubbing the slender, boomer-era politician “Stromberg” went viral (#Strommerz) after his bread-in-Angola and women-quips sparked fremdschämen. Critics say the film and Merz-era parallels underscore Germany’s zeitgeist: dark comedy, political cringe, and generational tone-deafness.

articles.title: ‘I’m rapt!’: meatball chants but no mania as New Zealand assembles for first Ikea store
articles.trailText: Overnight camping was banned and motorists were told to plan their journey as New Zealand finally joined the flatpack family
articles.summary: After 80 years and 400+ stores, Swedish retailer Ikea opened its first New Zealand outlet in Auckland on Dec 4, drawing hundreds of shoppers who queued (camping banned) for early entry. Emigrant customers celebrated familiar Swedish staples—chiefly meatballs—while planners warned motorists of potential delays that never materialised. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon’s ribbon-cutting marked a push for affordable homeware amid a cost-of-living squeeze, with competitive pricing (Billy bookcase NZ$99) and 29 pickup points nationwide signalling Ikea’s long-awaited Kiwi debut.

articles.title: Half of Europeans see Trump as enemy of Europe, survey finds
articles.trailText: Nine-country poll finds half of people believe risk of war with Russia is high and three-quarters want to stay in EU
articles.summary: Nine-country poll by Le Grand Continent finds 48% of Europeans view Donald Trump as an “enemy of Europe” (62% in Belgium, 57% in France, 37% in Croatia, 19% in Poland). A majority (51%) judge the risk of open war with Russia high—77% in Poland—while 69% doubt their country could defend against Russian aggression (France most confident at 44%). Tech and military insecurity top threats. Three-quarters (74%) back EU membership (90% Portugal, 61% France) and 63% view Brexit’s impact on the UK negatively.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Stop wasting the world’s time, Putin told
articles.trailText: Ukrainian, British and Estonian officials chastise the Kremlin for apparently fruitless peace talks in Moscow. What we know on day 1,380
articles.summary: Ukraine’s FM Andrii Sybiha, UK foreign secretary Yvette Cooper and Estonia’s Margus Tsahkna condemned Vladimir Putin for “wasting the world’s time” after unproductive US-Moscow peace talks, urging genuine negotiations. King Charles and Germany’s president Frank-Walter Steinmeier reaffirmed support for Ukraine’s defense. Trump envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner reported “reasonably good” but inconclusive talks. On the battlefield, Ukraine struck Russian oil depots and drones in Crimea, pushed forces back near Kupyansk, and contested Russia’s claim on Pokrovsk. UK and Norway will hunt Russian subs; the EU debates loans from frozen assets; the UN demands return of abducted Ukrainian children; Australia and New Zealand ramp up arms funding and sanctions.

articles.title: King Charles decries ‘Russian aggression’ in pledge on defending Europe
articles.trailText: Monarch welcomed German president, Frank-Walter Steinmeier, and promised both nations’ support for Ukraine
articles.summary: During German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier’s three-day state visit, King Charles hosted a Windsor Castle banquet, complete with a 41-gun royal salute and oversized Royal Standard flag display, to reaffirm the 2025 Kensington Treaty’s commitments on migration, defence, trade and education. Both leaders pledged to strengthen UK-Germany ties, bolster Europe against further Russian aggression and stand with Ukraine. Steinmeier and PM Starmer highlighted post-Brexit cooperation gains. The visit, featuring a Coventry cathedral homage, festive décor, a royal carriage ride, cultural exchanges and diplomatic gift swaps, drew a small Republic protest.

articles.title: European Commission plans ‘reparations loan’ to Ukraine using frozen Russian assets
articles.trailText: Leaders focus on bolstering Ukraine’s finances as US-Russia talks to end war make little progress
articles.summary: The European Commission will propose a €90bn, two-year funding plan for Ukraine, financed either by a loan secured on €290bn of Russia’s frozen sovereign assets or through common EU borrowing. Commission president Ursula von der Leyen argues both options ensure Kyiv can defend itself and negotiate from strength, but Belgium—home to €183bn of the assets at Euroclear—warns of legal and financial risks. EU leaders are set to decide on the mechanism at a December summit.

articles.title: The Ukraine peace deal has stumbled yet again over an inevitable obstacle: Putin
articles.trailText: Russian leader’s rejection of latest peace proposal was predictable and shows the Kremlin continues to hold the trump card
articles.summary: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner led Trump’s latest peace gambit in Moscow, but Putin rebuffed US-drafted terms on territorial control and Ukraine’s political future. Despite US pressure on Kyiv and Kremlin claims via Yuri Ushakov and Kirill Dmitriev that talks were ‘productive,’ Russia refuses key concessions. Secretary of State Marco Rubio conceded both sides remain distant. Analysts note Putin prefers formal working groups over backroom deals and will extend the war until his sovereignty and territorial demands are met.

articles.title: Motability cuts are a deeply cynical policy | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Disabled customers and their carers will lose out as suitable vehicles and tax reliefs are removed, says Colin Hughes
articles.summary: Colin Hughes argues that recent Motability changes—scrapping ‘luxury’ makes (just 5% of leases) and axing £300m in tax relief—will hike advance payments, shrink vehicle choice and erode disabled people’s independence. Framed as industrial policy to boost UK car manufacturing, this shift is cynical given the sector’s weak, foreign-owned state. Hughes, from a family of four siblings with muscular dystrophy who relied on adapted Chrysler Voyagers, warns these cuts undermine a quiet social-policy success and echo dangerous right-wing rhetoric even under a Labour government.

articles.title: Letter: Rhoda Kalema obituary
articles.trailText: Sarah Hutton writes: One of her achievements was the direct election of women to Uganda’s parliament
articles.summary: Obituary for Rhoda Kalema, Ugandan women’s rights pioneer and post-war recovery advocate, written by Sarah Hutton. A founding member of Uganda’s feminist cohort that met at the 2002 World Women’s Congress in Kampala, Kalema successfully lobbied President Yoweri Museveni’s government to enshrine universal primary education and secure direct parliamentary elections for women. Her pioneering activism helped set the foundation for female political representation and education equity that shapes Uganda’s development trajectory today. Her legacy highlights gender equity and education reform in sub-Saharan Africa yet remains underappreciated in global media.

articles.title: Amid missiles and diplomacy, Russia is exploiting western divisions over Ukraine
articles.trailText: As Russia intensifies its military pressure and diplomatic manoeuvring, European leaders find themselves increasingly at odds with Washington over how to pursue peace
articles.summary: Russia’s stepped-up missile strikes and diplomatic overtures expose deep rifts between European capitals and Washington over Ukraine. EU leaders warn Putin’s imperial ambitions threaten NATO and the bloc, insisting any peace plan guard against future aggression. By contrast, US figures aligned with Trump treat Russia as a conventional actor, downplaying expansionist aims. This transatlantic split plays into Moscow’s hands: accept a “peace” deal on Russia’s maximalist terms or face renewed offensives. As nightly drone and missile attacks continue, Putin underscores that war remains his primary tool for extracting concessions, rendering frantic diplomacy largely futile.

articles.title: EU has a plan to use frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine – how will it work?
articles.trailText: What are the legal implications, and why does Belgium fear being left alone with the bill?
articles.summary: The European Commission proposes €90bn funding for Ukraine over 2026–27 by issuing a “reparations loan” secured on ~€290bn of Russian central bank assets frozen in the EU (two-thirds in Euroclear, Brussels). Ukraine would repay from future Russian war reparations, then sanctions lift and assets return to Moscow. Belgium, hosting most assets, fears unilateral liability and legal risk; it favours joint EU borrowing instead. Plan needs 65% of member states, EU parliament and Council sign-off. Key hurdles: Belgian objections, Hungary’s sanction-renewal veto and aligning G7 support. Funds earmarked for European/Ukraine-made defence.

articles.title: Trial of aid workers accused of facilitating illegal entry of migrants into Greece set to begin
articles.trailText: The accused, including Syrian refugee Sarah Mardini and Irishman Sean Binder, were among those providing humanitarian assistance in Europe’s migration crisis
articles.summary: Twenty-four former ERCI search-and-rescue volunteers, including Syrian refugee Sarah Mardini and Irishman Sean Binder, face felony charges in a long-delayed Lesbos appeals trial starting Thursday. Accused of facilitating illegal entry, membership of a criminal organisation and money laundering punishable by up to 20 years, they deny wrongdoing, saying they offered humanitarian assistance during the 2015 migrant crisis. Rights groups like Amnesty denounce the prosecutions as intimidation of civil society. Defendants hope a verdict will vindicate rescue work and lift years of legal limbo.

articles.title: Colombia’s president warns Trump: ‘Do not wake the jaguar’ with threats of military strikes
articles.trailText: Gustavo Petro responded to intimations by US president of military strikes on Colombian soil to fight drug trafficking
articles.summary: Colombian president Gustavo Petro warned US president Donald Trump that threats of military strikes on land targets, including cocaine labs in Colombia, risk "waking the jaguar" and violate two centuries of diplomatic ties. Responding to Trump’s declaration of imminent land attacks in Venezuela and on any narcotics-producing state, Petro invited him to witness lab destructions—"one every 40 minutes"—as evidence of Colombia’s anti-drug efforts. The warning follows US naval deployments near Venezuela, over 80 boat-strike deaths, the revocation of Petro’s visa and Trump’s pardon of ex-Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, convicted of trafficking and corruption.

articles.title: India revokes order to preload smartphones with state-owned security app
articles.trailText: Tech companies including Apple and Google made it clear they would not comply due to privacy concerns
articles.summary: India’s telecom department rescinded an order requiring all smartphones sold domestically to ship with the government’s Sanchar Saathi security app, after privacy outcry from tech giants Apple and Google, opposition MPs and internet freedom groups. Critics warned the preinstall mandate could enable mass surveillance or remote kill switches, citing concerns over data access and internal OS policies. Communications minister Jyotiraditya Scindia affirmed the app is voluntary, deleteable and aimed at blocking fraudulent calls and tracking lost devices. Rights advocates hailed the revocation as a win but urged vigilance until formal legal withdrawal is published.

articles.title: NIH funds new cat experiments despite pledge to phase them out, watchdog reports
articles.trailText: White Coat Waste finds $1.7m in NIH grants for cat research months after officials said they were working to end studies
articles.summary: Despite pledging to phase out feline research, the NIH has awarded over $1.7m in new grants since July for invasive cat experiments, watchdog White Coat Waste (WCW) reveals. Projects include $486,000 to induce strokes in kittens via skull removal and viral brain injections, and $439,000 for glaucoma gene‐therapy trials in mutant kittens. NIH extended seven existing cat studies totaling $572,000, part of a $38m program. WCW and Congress members call for cancellation, arguing legal constraints are false. NIH says it's reviewing its portfolio and promoting non‐animal alternatives as part of a shift toward human-based models.

articles.title: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 search to resume 11 years after jet went missing
articles.trailText: Malaysian transport ministry says robotics company Ocean Infinity will restart search operation on 30 December
articles.summary: On December 30, marine robotics firm Ocean Infinity will resume a 55-day seabed search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, missing since March 8, 2014, when it vanished en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing with 239 aboard. Under a “no-find, no-fee” contract offering $70 million upon discovery, the UK-US company will scan a new 15,000 sq km area of the southern Indian Ocean. Malaysian, Australian and Chinese authorities have endorsed the effort, and families of victims expressed relief and hope for long-awaited closure after previous hunts recovered only scattered debris.

articles.title: Italy could act as mediator between Russia and Ukraine, says Pope Leo
articles.trailText: Pontiff says Italy has capacity, ‘culturally and historically’, as he stresses importance of Europe’s involvement
articles.summary: Pope Leo urged stronger European involvement in US-led Ukraine peace talks, noting that a US proposal was revised after European input. He proposed Italy, owing to its cultural and historical ties, as an intermediary among Ukraine, Russia and the US, and suggested the Holy See could facilitate or host talks. His comments followed stalled Russian-US negotiations and threats from Vladimir Putin preparing for conflict with Europe. Although the Vatican is not a formal party to negotiations, Leo reaffirmed its readiness to call for ceasefire, dialogue and support a just peace amid escalating military, cyber and energy crises this winter.

articles.title: Top ex-EU diplomat Federica Mogherini accused of corruption and fraud
articles.trailText: Prosecutors say two others also indicted in investigation into funding for school training young diplomats
articles.summary: The European Public Prosecutor’s Office has indicted former EU high representative Federica Mogherini—now rector of the College of Europe in Bruges—for alleged procurement fraud, corruption, conflict of interest and breach of professional secrecy. Two co-accused, a senior College official and a European Commission veteran (reportedly Stefano Sannino), face similar charges linked to a contract for the EU Diplomatic Academy. Belgian police raided EEAS and College premises and Mogherini’s home. All three have been released pending trial and deny wrongdoing. The College and EU’s current foreign policy chief, Kaja Kallas, vow full cooperation and uphold integrity safeguards.

articles.title: ‘There’s no monitoring of earthquakes’: new British Columbia pipeline could spell catastrophe, experts warn
articles.trailText: Project on ‘very poorly understood’ terrain and likely to pass through Rocky Mountain trench, which researchers say poses immense geological hazard
articles.summary: Experts warn Canada’s proposed Alberta–BC heavy oil pipeline faces poorly understood seismic risks as no detailed fault mapping or monitoring exists in the Rocky Mountain trench or coastal fjords. Seismologist Edwin Nissen warns active but unmapped faults beneath the Rocky Mountain trench and Douglas Channel could trigger earthquakes, massive landslides and tsunamis that devastate infrastructure and ecosystems. Funding limits prevent deploying seismic and GPS stations to assess these hazards. Premier David Eby decries BC and First Nations bearing risk while profits flow to Alberta, urging comprehensive geology studies pre-approval.

articles.title: A year after South Korea’s martial law crisis, the president urges unity, but the wounds are still raw
articles.trailText: President Lee praised South Koreans for overcoming ‘an unprecedented democratic crisis in world history’ but some fears its society is becoming increasingly polarised
articles.summary: One year after ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol’s failed 3 Dec 2024 martial-law ‘self-coup’, President Lee Jae Myung urged ‘righteous unity’ and full accountability. Yoon—impeached for insurrection and alleged collusion with North Korea—faces trial alongside ex-PM Han Duck-soo and former defence minister Kim Yong-hyun. The mass ‘revolution of light’ rallies with K-pop lightsticks overturned the decree, but deep polarization endures: Yoon loyalists and rising radical-right, anti-China movements remain active, while Lee’s probes into 700,000+ civil servants spark privacy and democracy concerns.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: ​​Does the new ​U​S plan put ​Ukraine and ​Russia on the path to peace​?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With US pressure mounting and Ukraine signalling cautious openness, Moscow continues to project military momentum
articles.summary: In early December, Trump envoy Steve Witkoff met Putin in Moscow to push a revised 28-point US plan, following US-Ukraine talks in Geneva and Florida. Ukrainian president Zelenskiy called the update “better” but cautioned it’s unresolved; the White House remains optimistic. Russia reported no progress, with Putin demanding deep cuts to Ukraine’s military, a ban on Western support, territorial handovers and no NATO membership—terms unacceptable to Kyiv and Europe. Analysts warn the Kremlin will accept only a Russia-centric deal, using diplomatic theatrics to pressure Ukraine or else press on militarily.

articles.title: Russia ‘ready’ for war if Europe starts it, Putin says, as US peace talks end without progress
articles.trailText: Kremlin aide says Ukraine crisis is no closer to resolution after Witkoff talks, as Russian president accuses European powers of sabotaging peace
articles.summary: After a five-hour Kremlin meeting in Moscow, Russian aide Yuri Ushakov said talks between Trump envoy Steve Witkoff, Jared Kushner and Moscow yielded no progress on Ukraine peace terms, despite “constructive” dialogue on US proposals. Putin accused European powers of sabotaging a deal and warned Russia was “ready” to fight if Europe initiates conflict. US Secretary of State Marco Rubio claimed some advances on security guarantees for Ukraine. Putin also asserted Russia had seized Pokrovsk and threatened further strikes on Ukrainian ports. President Zelenskiy awaits US signals amid skepticism over Russia’s willingness to concede.

articles.title: UK government delays decision on China’s super-embassy until January
articles.trailText: New date to approve site near Tower Bridge in London aligns with Keir Starmer’s planned visit to Beijing
articles.summary: The UK government has postponed final planning permission for China’s new “super-embassy” at Royal Mint Court near Tower Bridge to January 20, aligning with PM Keir Starmer’s anticipated Beijing trip. Security services cleared the build, and Home and Foreign Office reviews confirm all security considerations are resolved. Ministers say consolidating China’s seven London missions into a 20,000 sqm site boosts security. It marks the third deferral amid local protests over Beijing’s human-rights record. Labour intervened after Tower Hamlets refused permission in 2022; China warns delays undermine mutual trust.

articles.title: ‘A king above all’: The rise and rise of Asim Munir, Pakistan’s increasingly powerful army chief
articles.trailText: Known as Trump’s ‘favourite field marshal’, Munir’s power now extends over all the armed forces, along with lifelong immunity from prosecution, thanks to a constitutional amendment
articles.summary: Asim Munir, Pakistan's army chief, has solidified unprecedented power via the 27th constitutional amendment: extended five-year term with possible renewals, control over army, navy and air force, and lifelong immunity. Parliament rushed the bill through, replacing the Supreme Court with a government-picked constitutional court. Opponents label it a "constitutional coup," warning of unchecked military rule, sole nuclear command under Munir, and eviscerated civilian oversight. Riding May’s India clashes, Trump meetings and a Saudi defense pact, Munir’s influence eclipses the fragile civilian government in a country beset by economic crisis and insurgencies.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Peace push fizzles as Witkoff leaves Moscow with no sign of deal
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says ready to meet Trump and that Russia is hoping US loses interest; Briton held in Ukraine on Russian spy allegations. What we know on day 1,379
articles.summary: US envoy Steve Witkoff left Moscow after five-hour talks yielded no breakthrough on Russia’s 28-point peace wishlist. Kremlin aide Ushakov said both sides are “neither further nor closer” to ending the war. Zelenskyy warned America might lose interest and said he’s ready to meet Trump, while Putin threatened war with Europe if its “demands” continue. Kyiv arrested Briton Ross Cutmore for alleged FSB plotting of targeted killings. Black Sea tanker attacks amid naval drone strikes add maritime tensions. Meanwhile the EU will propose using €140bn in frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine’s needs.

articles.title: More than 200 leading cultural figures call for release of jailed Palestinian leader
articles.trailText: Group including Margaret Atwood, Ian McKellen and Richard Branson sign open letter to free Marwan Barghouti
articles.summary: Over 200 cultural figures including Margaret Atwood, Ian McKellen, Benedict Cumberbatch, Brian Eno and Richard Branson have signed an open letter urging Israel to free Marwan Barghouti, the 66-year-old Palestinian leader imprisoned 23 years following a trial deemed flawed. Advocates argue Barghouti’s release could unite Palestinian factions and revive two-state talks. The campaign, likened to the struggle that freed Nelson Mandela, warns of potential Israeli death-penalty legislation and calls on the UN and global governments to press Prime Minister Netanyahu, likely to resist without U.S. pressure.

articles.title: Handling of China spying case was ‘shambolic’, security committee concludes
articles.trailText: Report says ‘systemic failures’ led to collapse of trial, but found no evidence of UK government interference
articles.summary: JCNSS report criticizes CPS and government for ‘shambolic’ handling of espionage case against ex-parliamentary researcher Christopher Cash and teacher Christopher Berry. Charges under the 1911 Official Secrets Act were unexpectedly dropped 15 Sept, after CPS cited insufficient evidence that Beijing posed a direct UK security threat. MPs identified systemic failures—confusion, misaligned expectations and poor communication between CPS, Cabinet Office and security advisers—that eroded confidence but found no proof of high-level political interference. The committee urges formalised evidence-review processes, a case conference within 30 days of charge and clearer escalation protocols, warning outdated secrecy laws alone cannot explain the breakdown.

articles.title: Family of victim in alleged Trump ‘drug boat’ killings files first formal complaint
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Petition says Colombia citizen Alejandro Carranza Medina was illegally killed in US airstrike on 15 September
articles.summary: A Colombian family has lodged the first formal petition with the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, alleging US forces illegally killed fisherman Alejandro Carranza Medina in a 15 September airstrike on a suspected ‘drug boat’. Filed by human rights lawyer Dan Kovalik, the complaint accuses Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth—whose orders President Trump publicly endorsed—of ordering strikes without verifying targets. It challenges the administration’s novel legal rationale for Caribbean boat attacks and seeks redress and an injunction to halt future kinetic operations against alleged narcotraffickers.

articles.title: British military instructor arrested in Ukraine on suspicion of spying for Russia
articles.trailText: Ross David Cutmore, from Dunfermline, was allegedly recruited to assist in assassinations on Ukrainian soil
articles.summary: Ross David Cutmore, a 40-year-old British military instructor from Dunfermline, was arrested by Ukrainian authorities in late 2025 on suspicion of spying for Russia’s FSB and plotting assassinations of Ukrainian personnel. Between 2024–25 he allegedly passed unit coordinates, base photos and personnel data, received $6,000 per intel packet, and undertook bomb-making tasks. Recruited in Odesa via pro-Russian online ads, he is also suspected of supplying weapons for high-profile killings including MP Andriy Parubiy. He faces up to 12 years in prison. The UK Foreign Office confirms consular support and ongoing talks with Kyiv.

articles.title: Families on rooftops, homes buried by mud: Asia floods show water is overtaking wind as main threat
articles.trailText: Much improved response systems are struggling to cope with ever more powerful and destructive storms
articles.summary: Series of cyclones and monsoon storms across south and southeast Asia triggered torrential rains that killed over 1,200 people and displaced a million within a week. Scientists link intensified rainfall—carrying ~7% more moisture per °C warming—to human-induced climate change, making water, not wind, the main threat. Natural patterns (La Niña, Indian Ocean dipole) amplified impacts, while deforestation and illegal logging worsened landslides in Indonesia. Experts call for upgraded early-warning systems, nature-based defences (trees, mangroves), improved shelters and social protection to reduce future losses.

articles.title: Trump frees ex-Honduran president from prison as country awaits knife-edge election result
articles.trailText: Release of convicted cocaine trafficker Juan Orlando Hernández is latest US interference in election and comes despite Trump’s apparent ‘war on drugs’
articles.summary: Trump pardoned ex-Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernández, convicted in a US prison for cocaine trafficking, releasing him as Honduras’s presidential vote count remains stalled with US-backed Nasry Asfura leading Salvador Nasralla by just 0.02%. Trump publicly threatened electoral officials, tied Washington aid to an Asfura victory and intervened despite his own ‘war on drugs.’ Rival leftist Rixi Moncada trails on 19.16%. Technical issues halted the count, reviving 2017 fraud fears. Observers decry overt US interference while analysts warn delayed results risk a legitimacy crisis.

articles.title: Pope Leo urges Trump not to try to overthrow Venezuelan president with military force
articles.trailText: Pontiff calls on US president to ‘seek dialogue’ as White House steps up campaign against Nicolás Maduro
articles.summary: Pope Leo, returning from his first overseas trip to Turkey and Lebanon, urged President Trump not to invade Venezuela to overthrow Nicolás Maduro but to pursue dialogue and economic pressure. He made the appeal amid the US’s largest Caribbean military deployment since 1989 and recent strikes on drug-trafficking vessels that killed at least 83 people. Maduro denies illicit trade links and rejected Trump’s reported ultimatum. Leo warned civilians suffer most in conflict, criticized anti-migrant Islamophobia, advocated Christian-Muslim cooperation, and outlined plans for future peace-focused foreign visits, including Africa.

articles.title: British women stranded by landslides in Sri Lankan mountains running out of food and water, daughter says
articles.trailText: Friends Melanie Watters and Janine Reid have been trapped in Pussellawa since Thursday
articles.summary: Melanie Watters (54) and Janine Reid (55), both British tourists, have been trapped since Thursday in Pussellawa’s tea plantation region after Cyclone Ditwah triggered landslides that left their car stranded and local roads impassable. They are running low on food, water and fuel. Watters’ daughter, Katie Beeching—nine months pregnant—says the UK Foreign Office has declined to organise an evacuation despite her urgent appeals. Sri Lanka���s cyclone death toll has reached 465, while India has airlifted more than 330 stranded nationals with military helicopters.

articles.title: Former EU top diplomat among three held in fraud investigation
articles.trailText: Belgian police raid EU foreign service HQ and College of Europe and arrest Federica Mogherini and two others
articles.summary: Belgian police have arrested Federica Mogherini, former EU high representative and current College of Europe rector, along with Stefano Sannino and a third diplomatic insider, in a European public prosecutor’s fraud probe. Raids targeted the European External Action Service HQ and College campuses in Bruges, focusing on alleged procurement fraud, corruption and conflicts of interest in an EU-funded diplomatic training tender. The EPPO, investigating cross-border misuse of EU funds since 2021, lifted suspects’ immunity and suspects the College had prior access to confidential bidding information. All are presumed innocent until convicted in Belgian courts.

articles.title: Indian order to preload state-owned app on smartphones sparks political outcry
articles.trailText: Apple among big tech companies reportedly refusing to install Sanchar Saathi cybersecurity app on their devices
articles.summary: India’s government quietly ordered Apple, Samsung, Xiaomi and other smartphone makers to preload its state-owned Sanchar Saathi cybersecurity app on all devices sold in India within 90 days or via updates on existing handsets. Billed as a tool to block and track lost or stolen phones, disconnect fraudulent numbers and verify secondhand devices, the mandate met fierce pushback from opposition MPs and digital rights groups, who warn it enables mass surveillance across 730 million phones. Apple is reportedly refusing to comply on security and privacy grounds, while the telecom ministry insists the app is privacy-neutral and removable.

articles.title: The slow death of Pokrovsk
articles.trailText: An 18-month battle, now in its endgame, has left the strategically important Ukrainian city in ruins
articles.summary: In an 18-month attritional struggle, Russia’s gradual advance since summer 2024 has reduced Pokrovsk—a once-bustling 60,000-resident mining and rail hub 48 km from Ukraine’s front—to ruins. Sustained FPV drone strikes, artillery barrages and semi-encirclement inflicted massive civilian evacuations; coal mine tunnels were collapsed and flooded, utilities cut, shops shuttered, leaving some 1,200 elderly residents. Ukraine’s defenders, hampered by artillery shortages, held out amid growing casualties. With Russia suffering over 40,000 losses near Pokrovsk and Kyiv’s lines buckling near Huliaipole, the city’s fate underscores the war’s enormous human cost and shapes ongoing peace talks.

articles.title: ‘An unprecedented void’: Brussels goes record-breaking 542 days without a government
articles.trailText: No sign of an end to rancour among 14 parties elected to the Belgian capital’s 89-seat parliament after 542 days
articles.summary: Brussels Capital Region has gone 542 days without a government since June 2024 elections, surpassing Belgium’s 2010-11 record but falling outside Guinness recognition. Deep rifts among 14 parties—complicated by linguistic quotas protecting Dutch-speakers—have stalled Brussels’ budget and responses to drug violence, homelessness and rising migrant arrivals. A €1.6 bn deficit looms, subsidies are frozen and major projects like the Kanal museum face halts. Nearly 200 academics and business figures have petitioned leaders to form a coalition, while protests of 500 residents condemned political inaction. With Socialists, N-VA and Open VLD unwilling to compromise, no breakthrough is in sight.
