articles.title: Trump’s full-throttle threats suggest no backing down from aims to topple Maduro’s regime
articles.trailText: As US-Venezuela tensions have long simmered, Trump’s alleged ultimatum may tip relations to boiling point
articles.summary: President Trump escalated pressure on Venezuela’s Nicolás Maduro, ordering him in a 21 November call to “leave the country now” amid the largest US military buildup in Latin America since 1962. Despite recent overtures by envoy Richard Grenell—migrants’ repatriation flights and prisoner releases—national security adviser Marco Rubio’s hawkish influence prevailed. Trump, who views Maduro as a “narco-terrorist,” considers a decapitation strike plausible and aims to resolve “unfinished business” before year-end, offering the Venezuelan leader safe exile in Qatar, Cuba or Turkey. Analysts warn military action could precede Christmas if negotiations fail.

articles.title: Death toll from Indonesia floods passes 700 as 1 million evacuated
articles.trailText: About 3.2 million people on Sumatra island have been affected, 2,600 have been injured and 504 are missing
articles.summary: Floods and landslides on Sumatra have killed 708 people, with 504 missing, up from 604 the day before, as record monsoon rains and a rare Malacca Strait tropical storm displaced over 1 million and affected 3.2 million across Aceh and North and West Sumatra. Aid access is hindered by broken roads and bridges, and markets in Aceh face rice and vegetable shortages with prices tripling. Indonesia’s government is sending 34,000 tonnes of rice and 6.8 million litres of cooking oil, while WHO teams bolster disease surveillance. Survivors describe flooding. WHO chief Tedros said climate change is driving more extreme weather.

articles.title: Nine boars found dead in Spanish swine fever outbreak
articles.trailText: Hundreds of police, rangers and military personnel deployed to tackle virus threatening pork export industry
articles.summary: Spain has deployed hundreds of police, wildlife rangers and 117 military emergency personnel to contain an African swine fever outbreak near Bellaterra, outside Barcelona, after nine wild boars tested positive. A 6 km exclusion zone was imposed, pig farms within 20 miles tested negative, while sanitation, drone surveillance and biosecurity measures are underway. Officials suspect contaminated meat from haulage routes introduced the virus. Authorities urge against feeding wild boar and reporting carcasses. The outbreak threatens Spain’s €8.8 bn pork export industry—China has suspended imports from Barcelona province, though products from unaffected regions still flow—and ministers are coordinating to lift remaining trade restrictions.

articles.title: ‘We have to rebuild from scratch’: Sri Lankans relive the devastation of Cyclone Ditwah
articles.trailText: Many uncertain about the future after losing everything in the country’s deadliest natural disaster for years
articles.summary: Early December Cyclone Ditwah inundated Sri Lanka’s hill and lowland regions with unrelenting rains and landslides. President Dissanayake called it the “largest and most challenging natural disaster” in history. Official toll: 410 dead, 360+ missing, 1.1 million affected, hundreds of thousands of homes destroyed. In Badulla, Layani Niroshani and neighbours dug through mud after a landslide buried their house; others shelter in overcrowded schools on scant rations and shared toilets. Overwhelmed rescue teams and military helicopters airlift food and aid, but further rains and Sri Lanka’s 2022 economic collapse threaten long-term recovery, hitting tourism and agriculture hard.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What’s next for the resurgent space race?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As suppliers get ready to meet policy makers and space agencies at the industry’s largest gathering, a look at the exploration and exploitation of space
articles.summary: Glasgow’s Space-Comm summit brings 2,000 industry and policy leaders together as the ISS nears retirement in 2030, marking a shift from decades-long US-Russia cooperation to competing lunar alliances. Russia and China plan joint lunar missions and infrastructure, while the US, Europe, Canada and Japan push Artemis-led orbiting platforms and surface programmes. Commercial incentives—rare earths, Helium-3 and logistics—remain “vague,” critics warn, even as space-technology spin-off benefits are touted. Scientists fear fragile lunar sites could be ruined amid this geopolitically driven moon rush and governance race.

articles.title: Man charged with theft after allegedly swallowing Fabergé pendant in jewellery store
articles.trailText: New Zealand police allege 32-year-old ingested the 18-karat gold egg – a James Bond Octopussy locket – and say the object has ‘not yet been recovered’
articles.summary: A 32-year-old man in central Auckland was charged with theft on 29 November after allegedly swallowing a Fabergé x 007 Special Edition Octopussy egg locket—an 18-karat yellow gold pendant set with 60 white diamonds and 15 blue sapphires and housing a miniature gold octopus—valued at NZ$33,585 (US$19,200) in Partridge Jewellers. Arrested inside the store minutes after the incident, the pendant remains unrecovered. He also faces charges for stealing an iPad from the same shop on 12 November and cat litter and flea treatment from a private address on 13 November. Remanded in custody, he will reappear in court on 8 December.

articles.title: Japan PM’s pledge to ‘work, work, work, work, and work’ wins catchphrase of year
articles.trailText: Sanae Takaichi’s not-so-catchy remarks about everyone working like a horse did not go down well in a country notorious for its demanding work culture
articles.summary: Japan PM Sanae Takaichi’s pledge to “work, work, work, work, and work” was named Japan’s 2025 catchphrase of the year, beating 25 candidates. Critics, citing the country’s notorious karoshi problem, slammed her exhortation to have MPs “work like a horse” and abandon work-life balance; reports noted she slept just 2–4 hours nightly and held 3am meetings. Accepting the award, Takaichi insisted her words were misinterpreted and aimed only to signal her leadership resolve. Other top phrases included “First female prime minister” and “Trump’s tariffs”. At a Saudi forum, she later quoted Attack on Titan, urging: “Just shut your mouths. And invest everything in me!”

articles.title: What are scam centres – explained in 30 seconds
articles.trailText: Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos have become havens for the multibillion dollar scam industry, which has proliferated in the region in recent years
articles.summary: Scam centres in Myanmar, Cambodia and Laos are fortified compounds run by transnational criminal networks as part of a multibillion-dollar online fraud industry in south-east Asia. Operating in lawless border zones—especially along the Thai-Myanmar frontier where facilities more than doubled after the 2021 junta takeover—these hubs traffic, enslave and coerce an estimated 120,000 people in Myanmar and 100,000 in Cambodia to conduct scams via social media and messaging apps. Detainees face torture, beatings and electric shocks. Thailand has cut electricity, fuel and internet access, while Myanmar’s military raided a major centre, detaining 2,100 people and seizing Starlink terminals.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Witkoff shuttles into Moscow to hear Putin’s demands
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says redrafted peace plan ‘looks better’ but Kaja Kallas fears Moscow meeting will wrongfully put pressure on Kyiv rather than Kremlin. What we know on day 1,378
articles.summary: US special envoy Steve Witkoff shuttles into Moscow to meet Putin as Zelenskyy visits Paris after US talks. Zelenskyy says a redrafted peace plan “looks better” but demands security guarantees, full sovereignty and no concessions for Russian aggression. EU foreign policy head Kaja Kallas warns Moscow meeting risks pressuring Ukraine to concede. White House expresses optimism after Florida talks, though envoy’s past coaching of Putin staff draws scrutiny. Ukraine reports 4 killed, 40 wounded in Russian missile strike on Dnipro.

articles.title: Trump reportedly gave Maduro ultimatum to relinquish power in Venezuela
articles.trailText: US president sent a ‘blunt message’ to his South American counterpart, sources say
articles.summary: According to the Miami Herald, on 21 November President Trump delivered a blunt ultimatum to Nicolás Maduro by phone: immediately resign to secure safe passage for himself and his family or face potential U.S. military action amid a massive naval deployment off Venezuela’s coast. Maduro refused, demanding global immunity and retention of armed forces control even if he ceded political power. No further calls followed after the U.S. closed Venezuelan airspace. At a Caracas rally he decried “a slave’s peace,” accusing Washington of coveting Venezuela’s oil. Skeptics view U.S. threats as a bluff. Colombia’s Gustavo Petro offered Cartagena for talks.

articles.title: ‘The current could kill an elephant’: Asia flood survivors describe escaping with their lives
articles.trailText: From Thailand to Indonesia, torrential flooding has carried away people’s possessions, homes and lives
articles.summary: In late November monsoon rains and tropical cyclones unleashed record floods across Indonesia’s Sumatra, Sri Lanka, southern Thailand, Malaysia and Vietnam, killing over 1,100 people (more than 600 in Sumatra alone, 176 in southern Thailand). Survivors like Indonesia’s Aminah Ali clung to rooftops amid 3m waves, while Busra Ishak swam hours to safety as currents strong enough to kill an elephant swept away homes. In Hat Yai, Thai residents waited 48 hours for rescue amid rising chest-high waters and even venomous snakebite. With bridges cut, communications down and tens of thousands displaced, communities face immense cleanup and aid shortages.

articles.title: Mexican authorities kill one of country’s top fentanyl traffickers
articles.trailText: Pedro Inzunza Coronel, alias ‘El Pichón’, was killed during an anti-drug operation by the Mexican navy in Sinaloa
articles.summary: Pedro Inzunza Coronel, alias El Pichón, one of Mexico’s top fentanyl traffickers accused by US authorities of narco-terrorism for importing tens of thousands of kilos of the drug, was killed on 1 December 2025 during a Mexican navy operation in Sinaloa. Two accomplices were detained after opening fire. Coronel, co-leader with his father Pedro Inzunza Noriega of a major network linked to the defunct Beltrán Leyva Organization and its Guasave cartel splinter, faced US charges including money laundering. Authorities seized labs, weapons, vehicles and chemical precursors.

articles.title: Enver Solomon restores our faith in Britain | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers reflect on an interview with the outgoing chief executive of the Refugee Council
articles.summary: Readers across Britain praise Enver Solomon’s compassionate leadership at the Refugee Council in response to Zoe Williams’s interview. They lament five years of punitive asylum policies—from the Rwanda scheme to “islands of strangers” rhetoric—and express despair at successive governments and the current Labour party. A 75-year-old retiree cites her Punjabi grandchildren to question the country’s hostility; a former South African exile likens western pass laws to apartheid and cites Spain’s humane migrant work model; a Brighton reader mourns lost faith in Labour but finds renewed hope and restored faith in Britain through Solomon’s example.

articles.title: A ‘feminised workplace’ doesn’t mean what you think it means | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: The point is not to reiterate gender stereotypes, write Emily J Hogg, Dr Charlotte J Fabricius and Dr Ida Aaskov Dolmer, but to make visible the ways that contemporary capitalism exploits our ideas about gender
articles.summary: Researchers Emily Hogg, Charlotte Fabricius and Ida Dolmer challenge conservative accounts that portray a ‘feminised workplace’ as women’s emotional excess or declining masculinity. Instead, they redefine feminisation as the gendered reshaping of work: from heavy industry’s decline to service-sector growth and the assumption that women’s labour equals equality. This critical lens reveals how capitalism exploits gender norms, linking pay, hours and conditions to ideas of femininity and masculinity, and calls for nuanced descriptions as a step toward true workplace equity.

articles.title: US-Russia talks may pile pressure on Kyiv to make concessions, says EU foreign policy chief
articles.trailText: Kaja Kallas says negotiators should not ‘lose focus that it’s actually Russia who has started this war’
articles.summary: Kaja Kallas warns that US envoy Steve Witkoff’s planned meeting with Putin risks shifting pressure onto Ukraine to make concessions, recalling Russia initiated and sustains the war. European leaders, alarmed by a US proposal granting Russia eastern territories and capping Ukraine’s army, insist any peace "no dictated deal" include Ukrainian and European input. Zelenskyy, amid adviser Yermak’s resignation, lobbied Macron, Starmer, Merz and Tusk for durable peace and security guarantees. Meanwhile Russia gained 701 sq km in November; the Netherlands pledged €250m to Ukraine’s air defence.

articles.title: Israeli settlers attack and rob Italian and Canadian volunteers in West Bank
articles.trailText: Group beaten in early hours of morning in village where they volunteered to help protect Palestinians from settler violence
articles.summary: On 30 Nov in Ein al-Duyuk, West Bank, 10 masked Israeli settlers—two with army rifles—broke into a volunteer post where three Italians and a Canadian were guarding Palestinians from settler violence. They beat and robbed them for 15 minutes, shattering solar batteries; all four were hospitalized, one Italian remains in care in Ramallah. The attack follows an uptick in raids since a nearby illegal outpost was set up. Italy and Canada condemned the assaults; villagers say Israeli police have done little to curb daily settler mobs that UN data ties to a broader campaign of violence.

articles.title: Frozen-in tenor: Italian mayor apologises over Pavarotti statue stuck in ice rink
articles.trailText: Late singer’s widow says building ‘ugly’ ice rink around statue in Pesaro is disrespectful and ridicules his memory
articles.summary: In Pesaro’s central square, an ice rink was built around Luciano Pavarotti’s lifesize bronze—depicting him in a tailcoat with outstretched arms and handkerchief—burying it up to its knees. Widow Nicoletta Mantovani branded the “very ugly” installation disrespectful, accusing the council of ridiculing the late tenor, who held honorary citizenship and lived locally. Mayor Andrea Biancini apologised after urging skaters to “give Pavarotti a high five,” admitting the mistake but citing prohibitive costs and risk of damage in any removal.

articles.title: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100
articles.trailText: Millions of people affected by torrential rainfall in Sri Lanka and large parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, southern Thailand and northern Malaysia
articles.summary: Flooding from Cyclone Ditwah and heavy monsoon rains across Sri Lanka, Indonesia’s Sumatra, southern Thailand and Malaysia has killed over 1,100 people and displaced millions. Indonesia reports 604 dead, 464 missing; Sri Lanka 366 dead, 366 missing; Thailand 176 dead; Malaysia three. Sri Lanka declared a state of emergency, evacuated 148,000, and deployed military helicopters, warships and hospital ships. President Dissanayake vows to rebuild after the worst disaster since the 2004 tsunami. Indonesia’s President Subianto sent navy vessels and aircraft to cut-off areas. Thailand restores utilities, offers cash and loans; over 1,000 schools in Sumatra remain closed. Experts link intensifying cyclones to climate change.

articles.title: Bangladesh court sentences UK MP Tulip Siddiq to two years in prison in absentia
articles.trailText: MP for Hampstead and Highgate in London denies allegations and condemns ‘flawed and farcical’ trial
articles.summary: Bangladeshi court sentenced UK Labour MP Tulip Siddiq to two years in prison in absentia, accusing her of using her “special influence” to coerce former PM Sheikh Hasina into corrupt land transfers to Siddiq’s immediate family; trial deemed “flawed and farcical” by Siddiq and criticised by British lawyers, with no fair legal process and no extradition treaty making the sentence unlikely to be served. Mother Sheikh Rehana received seven years, part of an interim government’s anti-corruption drive against Hasina’s circle following her 2024 ousting.

articles.title: How cyclones and monsoon rains converged to devastate parts of Asia – visual guide
articles.trailText: Extreme weather kills more than 1,100 people across south and south-east Asia as cyclones turbocharge rain systems
articles.summary: Over 1,100 people have died across South and Southeast Asia as cyclones Senyar, Koto and Ditwah converged with monsoon rains, triggering floods and landslides in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam and Sri Lanka. Indonesia bore the brunt – 604 dead, 464 missing, 300,000 displaced – after a rare equatorial cyclone formed in the Malacca Strait. Sri Lanka’s record rains killed 366 and left 367 missing, affecting 1.3m. Thailand reported 170 fatalities amid its worst floods in a decade; Vietnam and Malaysia also saw deaths and mass evacuations. Scientists warn warming oceans are fueling more intense storms.

articles.title: ‘We’re true guardians of the forest’: quilombola community near Belém demand land rights and recognition
articles.trailText: Short boat ride from Cop30 host, Afro-descendant residents of Menino Jesus say their voices are not being heard
articles.summary: The Menino Jesus quilombola community near Belém, descendants of enslaved Africans living in the forest for six generations, is fighting to block a proposed 200-ha landfill just 0.5 km from their settlement. Their agroforestry and traditional practices sustain them and contribute to 29–55 % lower deforestation rates, yet only 4.3 % of Brazil’s 1.3 million quilombolas hold legal title. Pará’s environmental agency revoked the waste plant licence, but a court has reopened the process and dumping has already begun. At COP30, Afro-descendant voices appeared only perfunctorily in texts despite Brazil’s pledge to create 10 new indigenous territories. Leaders demand specific land rights and political recognition to protect their forest guardianship and livelihoods.

articles.title: Five South Africans in court over alleged recruitment for Russia’s war in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Suspects arrested after tipoff over accusation that 17 South Africans were tricked on to frontlines of the conflict
articles.summary: Five South Africans appeared in court, accused of recruiting compatriots to fight for Russia in Ukraine after a tip led police to intercept three men bound for Russia and arrest a female facilitator at OR Tambo airport. The suspects—radio host Nonkululeko Mantula and four others—are linked to allegations that 17 South Africans were lured into frontline combat via a purported MK bodyguard training scheme, prompting competing affidavits by Jacob Zuma’s daughters. Proceedings resume 8 December. Mantula, co-chair of the EU-sanctioned Brics Journalists Association, posted from Moscow; the presidency investigates the stranded fighters.

articles.title: Suspected members of neo-Nazi terror group arrested in Spain
articles.trailText: Three people are accused of belonging to the Base, an ‘accelerationist’ white power organisation founded in the US
articles.summary: On Nov 25 in Castellón, Spain, Policía Nacional dismantled the country’s first accelerationist neo-Nazi cell, arresting three individuals linked to the Base—an organisation designated terrorist by the EU, UK, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Officers seized firearms, replica guns, ammunition, knives, tactical military gear and extremist propaganda. The suspects face charges of belonging to a terrorist organisation, recruitment, indoctrination, paramilitary training and illegal weapons possession. The cell’s leader, in direct contact with US founder Rinaldo Nazzaro, has been remanded in custody by the Audiencia Nacional.

articles.title: What led to Bangladesh trial of former UK minister Tulip Siddiq in her absence?
articles.trailText: Labour MP for Hampstead and Highgate says she has not been informed of charges against her
articles.summary: Tulip Siddiq, Labour MP for Hampstead and Highgate, was sentenced in absentia by a Bangladeshi court to two years’ jail for alleged corruption tied to her aunt, ex-PM Sheikh Hasina. She denies all charges, says she was not informed of allegations or granted legal representation, and claims documents are forged. Prosecutors seek up to life imprisonment. UK lawyers – including Robert Buckland KC – argue her trial violated due process. This follows Hasina’s recent death sentence for crimes against humanity over last year’s student protest crackdown. Siddiq resigned as UK minister in January over a separate finances row. No extradition treaty exists.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Trump says ‘good chance’ of deal to end conflict after latest talks with Kyiv
articles.trailText: Marco Rubio also expresses optimism while saying ‘more work’ needed as Trump envoy set to meet Vladimir Putin. What we know on day 1,377
articles.summary: Donald Trump said after productive Florida talks with Ukrainian delegates that there's a 'good chance' of brokering a deal to end the war, amid ongoing corruption probes that forced President Zelenskiy's chief of staff to resign. Secretary Marco Rubio called discussions realistic but optimistic, stressing more work to secure long-term prosperity as envoy Steve Witkoff heads to Moscow to meet Putin. Meanwhile Ukraine faces weekend drone attacks, political turbulence and seeks fresh European backing from Macron and von der Leyen, while Turkey condemns Ukrainian naval strikes on Russian tankers.

articles.title: Monday briefing: What did we learn at Your Party’s first conference?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: No new name, but a decision to embark on collective leadership means that the factionalism in Your Party is here to stay
articles.summary: In Liverpool, the new left-wing ‘Your Party’ led by Jeremy Corbyn and Zarah Sultana held its inaugural conference amid public infighting and MPs quitting. Retaining the placeholder name, delegates narrowly backed a collective leadership model to avoid a Corbyn–Sultana contest, and approved dual membership of other groups – a concession after Sultana’s boycott over expelled delegates. The launch’s tech mishaps, financial limbo and six initial factions underscored persistent splits. With policy scant and Zack Polanski’s energized Greens drawing progressive supporters, Your Party must clarify its platform ahead of 2026 elections.

articles.title: ‘I have been defeated’: hundreds of Palestinians face eviction from East Jerusalem
articles.trailText: Residents in Batn al-Hawa have all but given up hope and blame the Gaza war which, they say, has created ‘an atmosphere of hate’ towards them
articles.summary: In Jerusalem’s Batn al-Hawa, 34 Palestinian families (some 175 people) face imminent eviction after right-wing settler group Ateret Cohanim and a revived Ottoman-era trust won court claims to historic land titles. Longtime resident Zohair Rajabi, who fears losing his four-storey home built by his grandfather in 1965, says recent Gaza war tensions fuel an “atmosphere of hate” accelerating evictions under Israel’s most hardline government. Activists warn this could be the largest coordinated Palestinian displacement in East Jerusalem since 1967 as settlers move in under a 1970 law allowing Jews to reclaim pre-1948 properties.

articles.title: Old tensions simmer just below surface as Tusk and Merz to meet in Berlin
articles.trailText: Ukraine will top agenda, but meeting comes as positive sentiment towards Germany in Poland hits near record lows
articles.summary: Polish PM Donald Tusk meets German Chancellor Friedrich Merz in Berlin for annual talks dominated by Ukraine but overshadowed by lingering bilateral strains. A German Institute of Polish Affairs study reports near-record Polish aversion to Germany despite Germany’s record-low negativity towards Poles. Poland’s growing self-confidence, fueled by economic success and anti-German rhetoric under the PiS era, clashes with Berlin over migration, border controls and perceived sidelining in Ukraine peace talks. Historic grievances – Nazi occupation reparations, looted artefacts and a stalled memorial – intensify calls for compensation and deeper reconciliation amid domestic far-right pressures and asymmetric historical narratives.

articles.title: Rising levels of hate forcing women out of Swedish public life, says equality agency
articles.trailText: Country seen as champion of equal rights faces reckoning after senior politician says she felt compelled to quit
articles.summary: In Sweden, growing hate, threats and harassment against female politicians, exemplified by Anna-Karin Hatt’s resignation, are deterring women, especially younger and minority politicians, from public office and self-censoring debate. A government equality agency warns this poses a ‘big threat to democracy.’ A 2025 security survey shows over 26% of women reps faced threats, with 32.7% feeling vulnerable, vs 23.6% and 24% of men. Women limit social media, avoid high-risk issues like immigration, and resign from local councils at higher rates. Experts call for stronger legal protection, culture change, and social media accountability to uphold gender equality and free debate.

articles.title: Death toll passes 900 in Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka floods
articles.trailText: Officials in Indonesia say more than 442 people have died, while Sri Lanka suffers worst natural disaster since 2004 tsunami
articles.summary: Monsoon rains and a tropical storm triggered floods and landslides in Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Thailand, killing over 900. Cyclone Ditwah flooded Colombo and central regions, killing 334, prompting a state of emergency and displacing 148,000 in Sri Lanka. In Indonesia’s Sumatra, 442 died, 402 missing, with communities cut off and reports of opportunistic looting as aid lagged. Thailand reported 162 deaths, widespread damage and suspensions of officials over relief delays. Governments deployed ships, helicopters and promised compensation amid criticism of slow response, highlighting climate-driven intensification of monsoon extremes.

articles.title: Ukrainian and US officials meet in Florida to discuss proposals to end Russia’s war
articles.trailText: Marco Rubio, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner meet Kyiv delegation amid more deadly Russian attacks in Ukraine
articles.summary: Ukrainian negotiators met US officials in Florida—Sen. Marco Rubio, envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner—with Ukraine’s security council chief Rustem Umerov to refine Washington’s 28-point framework aimed at ending Russia’s war. Discussions focused on securing Ukraine’s sovereignty and long-term prosperity by revising terms seen as too favorable to Russia. Witkoff heads to Moscow next week. The talks unfold amid intensified Russian attacks, Ukraine’s political turbulence after Andriy Yermak’s resignation, and US pressure. Kyiv insists any deal start from current front lines, reject forced demilitarization or NATO veto, as Macron readies a meeting with Zelenskiy on security guarantees.

articles.title: Tommy Gee obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Colonial service administrator who helped to promote better schooling in newly independent Uganda
articles.summary: Tommy Gee (1925–2025) was a progressive British colonial administrator in 1950s–60s Uganda whose advocacy for Africanisation won him respect from locals and led Prime Minister Milton Obote to retain him after independence (1962) as education permanent secretary. He doubled secondary schools from 21 to 42 by 1965, earning an OBE. Educated at High Pavement, Oxford (mathematics) and a WWII Royal Navy navigator, he later directed IDS at Sussex University, helped found the University of the South Pacific, served as registrar in Fiji and Papua New Guinea, became a Quaker convert and Liberal Democrat councillor, voyaged the Amazon at 98, and is survived by three children and descendants.

articles.title: Thousands rally in Madrid to demand snap election over corruption allegations
articles.trailText: Pressure grows on Pedro Sánchez amid series of claims involving his family, party and administration
articles.summary: Tens of thousands of protesters gathered at Madrid’s Temple of Debod under the slogan “This is it: mafia or democracy?” to demand Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez call a snap election amid a widening corruption scandal. Organized by the conservative PP, the rally followed the pretrial detention of ex-transport minister José Luis Ábalos on alleged kickbacks. PP leader Alberto Núñez Feijóo lambasted “sanchismo” as systemic graft, while Madrid’s PP president, Isabel Díaz Ayuso, accused Sánchez of aiding ETA. The government dismissed the protest as politically motivated, pointing to recent resignations and ongoing judicial probes into Sánchez’s allies and family.

articles.title: Benjamin Netanyahu asks Israel’s president for pardon in corruption case
articles.trailText: Request is submitted weeks after Donald Trump called on Isaac Herzog to pardon Israeli prime minister
articles.summary: Israel’s prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu has formally requested President Isaac Herzog to grant a pre-conviction pardon for bribery, fraud and breach of trust charges, lodging a 111-page petition claiming that ending his five-year corruption trial is vital for national unity. The bid, coming weeks after a letter from Donald Trump, would break with Israeli precedent. Opponents and legal experts argue that without admission of guilt or resignation, a pardon would provoke a constitutional crisis and note the only similar 1986 Shin Bet case involved guilty pleas. Critics further accuse Netanyahu of exploiting the Gaza war to cling to power.

articles.title: Bridge to the past: JR to wrap Pont Neuf again, 40 years after artistic forebears
articles.trailText: Exclusive: French artist planning to cover bridge over Seine in tribute to Christo and Jeanne-Claude
articles.summary: French street artist JR will wrap Paris’s 232 m Pont Neuf for three weeks next June in Pont Neuf Cavern, echoing Christo and Jeanne-Claude’s 1985 installation. Calling it his biggest challenge, he plans a fabric ‘rock cave’ amid the city. Invited by Christo’s nephew Vladimir Yavachev with full artistic freedom and swiftly approved by Mayor Hidalgo and President Macron, the privately funded project (6–28 June) keeps the bridge open. JR, who began as a banlieue graffiti tagger and gained fame for large-scale public photography and murals, says this tribute fulfills a lifelong inspiration.

articles.title: Can you have a community without craic? Scholars of Ireland’s pubs warn of declining numbers
articles.trailText: Two new books analyse what makes the ‘perfect pub’ and both come to a sobering conclusion: Irish pubs are in trouble
articles.summary: Two new studies by Donal Fallon and Perry Share examine the history, design, sociology and cultural role of Irish pubs, concluding that these community hubs are in decline: Ireland has lost over 2,100 pubs (25%) since 2005, driven by taxes, drink‐driving laws, property prices and falling consumption. Rural towns and Dublin see closures threatening social cohesion, cross‐class interaction and national identity, despite pubs’ global appeal in literature, film and themed export venues. Coffee shops rise but lack authentic ‘craic’. Scholars urge planners to safeguard pub infrastructure to preserve communal warmth and Ireland’s living heritage.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukrainians fly to US for peace talks with Rubio, Witkoff and Kushner
articles.trailText: Marco Rubio, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner will meet Ukrainian negotiators on Sunday, after a weekend of drone strikes on two Russian oil tankers and more deadly attacks on Kyiv..
articles.summary: US Sec. of State Marco Rubio and special envoy Steve Witkoff will meet Ukrainian negotiators led by Rustem Umerov in Florida alongside Jared Kushner to discuss Washington’s plan to end the war; top aide Andriy Yermak is absent after resigning amid corruption probes. Witkoff plans a follow-up trip to Moscow to present a fine-tuned peace proposal to Putin. In Europe, Macron will host Zelensky in Paris to consider tougher sanctions for a just, lasting peace. Separately, Ukrainian naval drones struck two empty oil tankers (Kairos, Virat) bound for Novorossiysk. Russia’s overnight drone and missile barrage killed six and wounded dozens in Kyiv, cutting power for 500,000 residents before partial restoration. Moldova briefly closed its airspace after two unidentified drones overflew its territory.

articles.title: Six dead and dozens wounded in Russian attack on Ukraine
articles.trailText: Strike on Kyiv cuts power to half of city amid Moscow’s campaign to break civil resistance by attacking energy grid
articles.summary: Russian forces launched nearly 600 drones and 36 rockets in two waves on Nov. 29, killing six and wounding dozens across Kyiv and nearby regions. The attack cut power to half of the capital, leaving 500,000 residents in darkness before crews restored electricity to 400,000. Zelensky urged urgent Western air-defense support, while Ukrainian forces struck Russia’s Afipsky oil refinery. The bombardment forms part of Moscow’s winter strategy to break civil resistance by crippling Ukraine’s energy infrastructure. It coincides with a corruption scandal that toppled presidential chief of staff Andriy Yermak, fueling debate over successors, peace talks and a €140 bn EU loan plan.

articles.title: Working the land but rarely owning it: life for New Zealand’s young farmers
articles.trailText: A country built on agriculture is seeing the sector change as the number of farms shrinks and it becomes harder for young people to buy land
articles.summary: New Zealand’s farm count has plunged 33% since 2002 (70,336 to 47,250) and farmland fallen 15%, even as dairy, meat, kiwifruit and apple exports boom and Fonterra sold its consumer arm to Lactalis for NZ$4 billion. Young Farmers clubs report rising land costs and consolidation make buying or share-farming entry blocks nearly impossible. Thirty-year-old Cam Clayton now leases and manages multiple Waikato properties—milking, breeding and mustering—while 27-year-old Cam Lowery runs 2,700 sheep on a family lease and commutes for extra income.

articles.title: At least 500 killed in south-east Asia floods and landslides
articles.trailText: More than 300 people killed on Indonesia’s Sumatra island with 162 reported dead across Thailand
articles.summary: Monsoon rains and a tropical storm have caused floods and landslides in south-east Asia, killing over 500 people. In Indonesia’s Sumatra, 350 were confirmed dead and 279 remain missing—166 in North Sumatra, 90 in West Sumatra, 47 in Aceh—while over 80,000 were evacuated, 28,400 sheltered and 3,500 police deployed. Thailand’s floods affected 3.8m people across eight provinces, with 162 fatalities (145 in Songkhla); morgues in Hat Yai were overwhelmed. The Thai PM apologized, set a two-week clean-up plan and pledged up to 2m baht compensation. Malaysia reported two deaths in Perlis. Authorities cite climate change for worsening monsoon intensity.

articles.title: Venezuela denounces ‘colonialist threat’ as Trump orders airspace closed
articles.trailText: President made declaration in a social media post, after FAA last week warned airlines of ‘worsening security situation’
articles.summary: After the FAA warned of a “worsening security situation” over Venezuela, former US President Donald Trump declared on Truth Social that Venezuelan airspace is “closed in its entirety” to airlines, pilots, drug traffickers and human smugglers. Caracas denounced the order as a “colonialist threat” and breach of international law, suspended US migrant deportation flights and revoked rights of six international carriers. The measure caps months of US naval strikes on alleged drug boats, military buildup, covert CIA actions and Trump’s vow of possible land operations to stop illicit networks, which President Maduro vows to resist.

articles.title: Sri Lanka death toll from floods and landslides reaches 153
articles.trailText: Another 191 missing after heavy rains from Cyclone Ditwah while almost 78,000 evacuated to temporary shelters amid rescue operations
articles.summary: Cyclone Ditwah’s torrential rains and floods have killed 153 people in Sri Lanka, left 191 missing and forced 78,000 into nearly 800 temporary shelters, the Disaster Management Centre says. Over 500,000 islanders have been affected by landslides and flash floods, including 11 residents of a flooded care home. Military and police are distributing food, clearing roads and rescuing stranded bus passengers, tourists and families as the Kelani River bursts its banks near Colombo and authorities warn of worsening monsoon flooding linked to climate change.

articles.title: Zelenskyy faces ‘mini-revolution’ as Yermak’s fall reshapes Ukraine’s wartime power system
articles.trailText: Exit of Zelenskyy’s most powerful aide could also have impact on Kyiv’s negotiating position in talks over ending war
articles.summary: The resignation of Andriy Yermak, Zelenskyy’s chief enforcer and de facto powerbroker, follows a search of his apartment in an anti-corruption probe. As head of the peace delegation and gatekeeper to the president, Yermak’s exit triggers what analysts call a "mini-revolution" in Ukraine’s wartime governance. His departure risks undermining Kyiv’s negotiating heft, disrupts a highly centralized decision-making system, and opens competition for influence in the president’s inner circle. Observers warn a fraught transition could either weaken Zelenskyy or usher in fresh, consensual policymaking amid demands for reforms.

articles.title: Israel has ‘de facto state policy’ of organised torture, says UN report
articles.trailText: Committee highlights allegations including dog attacks and sexual violence, raising concern about impunity for war crimes
articles.summary: A UN committee’s report covering two years since October 2023 accuses Israeli security forces of a de facto state policy of organized torture—severe beatings, dog attacks, electrocution, waterboarding, prolonged stress positions, sexual violence and humiliation—and systematic denial of medical care. It highlights mass administrative detention under the Unlawful Combatants Law, including children (some under 12) held in solitary confinement, and an abnormally high custody death toll of 75 Palestinians with no officials held accountable. The committee urges Israel to amend legislation to end impunity and protect detainee rights.

articles.title: Impasse over EHRC single-sex spaces guidance ‘distracting from other issues’
articles.trailText: Staff at human rights body said to be ‘desperate for regime change’ over inertia after court’s legal definition of a woman
articles.summary: Insiders warn ongoing deadlock over the Equality and Human Rights Commission’s guidance on single-sex spaces, following the UK supreme court’s biological definition of a woman, is overshadowing other priorities like rising far-right threats. Staff cite ‘stall, stall, stall’ inertia as ministers delay approving rules limiting trans people’s access to their lived-gender toilets. With chair Lady Falkner stepping down and Mary-Ann Stephenson due in December, up to four new commissioners—potentially including the EHRC’s first trans member—are being sought. Advocates urge a broader, nuanced approach to trans inclusion, while critics call on ministers to end prevarication and publish the code.

articles.title: Convincing evidence Israel backed aid convoy looters in Gaza, historian says
articles.trailText: Account of visit to Gaza by French professor describes Israeli military attacks on security personnel protecting convoys
articles.summary: Jean-Pierre Filiu, a Sciences Po Middle East historian, spent six weeks in Gaza and documents in A Historian in Gaza 'utterly convincing' evidence that Israeli forces attacked Gaza police protecting aid convoys, facilitating armed looters amid famine fears. He recounts Israeli drones supporting gangs, killing two protectors and looting 20 of 66 trucks. An internal UN memo cited Israel’s 'passive, if not active benevolence.' Israel rejects the allegations, claiming it struck terrorists. Filiu also accuses Israel of bombing an alternative aid route and warns of broader humanitarian-law implications.

articles.title: UK immigration plans may betray Hong Kong refugees, says exiled politician
articles.trailText: Nathan Law says ‘moral obligation’ to Hongkongers should extend to anyone fleeing from political persecution
articles.summary: Exiled Hong Kong politician Nathan Law warns that the UK’s proposed immigration overhaul, which would extend the standard qualifying period for permanent residence from five to ten years, risks reneging on Britain’s moral obligation to Hongkongers and non-BNO-status refugees fleeing political persecution. Law, who arrived in 2020 after leading pro-democracy protests, says new asylum rules—heralded by Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood as Europe’s most controlled—are causing anxiety over uncertainty and settlement. A government debate continues over applying restrictions to existing residents or only future arrivals. Law, targeted by Chinese surveillance and a HK$1m bounty, stresses permanent residency is vital for safety.

articles.title: UK MPs push for extra aid and visas as Jamaica reels from Hurricane Melissa
articles.trailText: Dawn Butler leads calls for humanitarian visas and fee waivers for vulnerable relatives of UK nationals affected by storm
articles.summary: Following Hurricane Melissa’s devastation of Jamaica—nearly 1m people affected, 150k homes destroyed, US$8bn losses—Labour MP Dawn Butler and others, including Diane Abbott and the Green party, are urging the UK government to supplement its £7.5m aid pledge with temporary humanitarian visas and fee waivers for vulnerable Jamaican relatives of UK nationals, mirroring the Homes for Ukraine scheme. Windrush activist Euen Herbert-Small and NGOs stress Britain’s moral and Commonwealth ties demand greater support amid rebuilding, disease outbreaks and climate justice obligations linked to the slavery legacy.

articles.title: Global ‘Free Marwan��� campaign calls for Palestinian political leader’s release
articles.trailText: Locked away in prison for decades, Marwan Barghouti is a longstanding advocate for a two-state solution
articles.summary: Family-led and UK-backed “Free Marwan” campaign seeks release of 66-year-old Marwan Barghouti, jailed by Israel for over 20 years on contested charges, as a focal point in Gaza ceasefire talks. Widely recognised as the West Bank and Gaza’s most popular politician and a two-state advocate, Barghouti’s plight—heightened by prolonged solitary confinement, reported beatings and denied Red Cross access—is spotlighted through murals in London and Ramallah and an upcoming letter from political and cultural figures. Supporters view him as a unifying leader for Fatah, the PLO and all Palestinian prisoners.

articles.title: How Motability cuts went from a rightwing online campaign to Rachel Reeves’s budget
articles.trailText: Car lease scheme for people with mobility problems portrayed as ‘free’ but is funded by benefits and their own contributions
articles.summary: Once praised by Rachel Reeves as the “keys to freedom”, the Motability car-lease scheme—funded by disability benefits and user top-ups—has been hit in her first budget, ending £300m/year of tax breaks, removing premium-brand options and adding VAT and insurance levies. A rightwing campaign on X (Max Tempers, Motability Check) and tabloids framed it as unjust “free” BMWs for claimants, prompting Treasury-led reforms. Officials tout a £1bn five-year saving and restored fairness, but disability groups decry lack of consultation and warn cuts will block access for those needing larger, more robust vehicles.

articles.title: The week Europe realised it stands alone against Russian expansionism
articles.trailText: Washington’s Putin-appeasing plan for peace in Ukraine has failed, but many heard death knell sounded for European reliance on US protection
articles.summary: In late November 2025 EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas highlighted Russia’s 33 invasions of 19 states, warning that rewarding aggression fuels more war. European leaders from Macron to Starmer condemned a 28-point US-Russian peace plan backed by Trump and adviser Steve Witkoff as capitulation, threatening Ukraine’s sovereignty and Europe’s security. They excised pro-Russian clauses, secured Nato-style guarantees and rallied a “coalition of the willing.” The episode exposed US isolationism and Senate splits over Ukraine, underscoring that Europe can no longer depend on Washington and must bolster its own defenses against Russian expansionism.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: two killed and dozens wounded as Russia launches another overnight attack on Kyiv
articles.trailText: Blasts heard in capital from midnight and residential buildings hit as Zelenskyy’s closest ally resigns amid anti-corruption probe. What we know on day 1,375
articles.summary: Russia launched dozens of cruise and ballistic missiles and over 500 drones at Kyiv overnight, killing two civilians, wounding about two dozen, damaging homes, energy infrastructure and sparking fires amid a nine-hour air alert. President Zelenskyy accepted the resignation of chief of staff Andriy Yermak following an anti-corruption probe, reshaping Ukraine’s US peace negotiation team. Ukrainian forces continued defensive and strike operations around Kupiansk in Kharkiv region. Separately, Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla resigned as an MP over alleged recruitment of South Africans to fight for Russia; Human Rights Watch affirmed ongoing Russia investigations despite its domestic ban; and two sanctioned Russian tankers in the Black Sea suffered fires after explosions.

articles.title: After landmark climate win, lawyer hopes for a ‘new legal order’ to protect Indigenous rights
articles.trailText: Pacific lawyer Julian Aguon to be honoured with Right Livelihood award for his work that led to ICJ ruling on climate harm
articles.summary: Julian Aguon, a Chamorro lawyer from Guam, led a transformative ICJ case, commissioned by Vanuatu in 2019, that in 2025 affirmed nations’ legal duty to prevent climate harm after Pacific testimonies from Vanuatu, Papua New Guinea and beyond. On Dec 2, he and the Pacific Islands Students Fighting Climate Change receive the Right Livelihood Award for pioneering rights-based climate litigation and reparations claims. His Blue Ocean Law—founded in 2014 to establish an Indigenous-rooted “new legal order”—now tackles deep-sea mining and land and water contamination. He envisions treating the ocean as kin rather than a commodity, invoking Indigenous guardianship to defend marine ecosystems and cultural survival.

articles.title: Zelenskyy’s top aide quits after anti-corruption searches of his home
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president announces departure of Andriy Yermak, who was leading peace talks with US
articles.summary: Andriy Yermak, President Zelenskyy’s chief of staff and key US peace talks negotiator, resigned after Ukraine’s anti-corruption bureau (NABU) and prosecutor (SAPO) searched his Kyiv apartment in a probe into a nuclear energy kickback scandal at state generator Energoatom. An associate of Zelenskyy’s, Timur Mindich, fled abroad amid allegations of 10–15% kickbacks, and former deputy PM Oleksiy Chernyshov faces charges. Zelenskyy praised Yermak’s patriotism, vowed to reorganise the presidential office and find a successor, and underscored the need to focus on national defence. The European Commission affirmed Ukraine’s anti-corruption bodies are functioning.

articles.title: Quebec to ban public prayer in sweeping new secularism law
articles.trailText: Bill 9 would outlaw prayer and face coverings in public institutions, sparking fears it targets Muslims in Canada
articles.summary: Quebec’s CAQ government has introduced Bill 9, a sweeping secularism law banning public prayer, communal worship in parks and roads, full-face coverings and kosher/halal meal offerings in public institutions—colleges, universities, daycares and private schools—under threat of C$1,125 fines, with exemptions for short approved events. Building on 2019’s Bill 21, it extends religious-symbol prohibitions. Secularism minister Jean-François Roberge argues neutral public spaces free all, while Muslim students, the National Council of Canadian Muslims and Catholic bishops condemn it as discriminatory. The law invokes the notwithstanding clause to pre-empt Charter challenges; the Supreme Court will soon review its use.

articles.title: Rebel nuns who busted out of Austrian care home win reprieve – if they stay off social media
articles.trailText: Trio given leave to stay in their abandoned convent near Salzburg until further notice, church officials say
articles.summary: Three octogenarian nuns—Bernadette (88), Regina (86) and Rita (82)—were granted provisional leave to remain in their abandoned Goldenstein Castle convent near Salzburg after defying church orders to enter a care home. Conditioned on staying off social media, banning visitors, settling legal claims and accepting provided medical and pastoral support, the deal follows months of supporters smuggling priests and supplies into the nunnery. The sisters say the agreement lacks binding legal force, demands dialogue with the archdiocese and calls proposed terms oppressive and one-sided.

articles.title: Talks for UK to join EU defence fund collapse in blow to Starmer’s bid to reset relations
articles.trailText: UK had been pushing to join €150bn Safe fund, a loan scheme that is part of bloc’s drive to rearm Europe
articles.summary: Negotiations for the UK’s participation in the EU’s €150bn Security Action for Europe (Safe) defence fund fell apart days before the 30 November deadline, marking a setback for Keir Starmer’s bid to reset UK-EU ties. London insisted it would only sign on terms offering value for money, balking at EU demands for up to €6bn in entry fees and component caps proposed by France. Ministers stress British firms can still join projects under third-country terms, while wider security cooperation under the May partnership remains on track.

articles.title: Jacob Zuma’s daughter resigns amid claims South Africans tricked to fight for Russia
articles.trailText: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla quits as MP after being accused of recruiting 17 men who are trapped in war-torn Ukraine
articles.summary: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, daughter of ex-president Jacob Zuma, has resigned as an MP after her sister filed a police report accusing her of recruiting 17 South African men into Russia’s military effort in Ukraine under the guise of bodyguard training for the Zumas’ MK party. She denies wrongdoing, claiming she was deceived by associates, and filed an affidavit as a victim while cooperating with a probe to repatriate the trapped volunteers. The MK party denies involvement. South African authorities, citing mercenary laws and official neutrality on the Russia-Ukraine war, are investigating amid her public pro-Russia activism.

articles.title: German president honours victims of Nazi bombing atrocity on Guernica visit
articles.trailText: Frank-Walter Steinmeier travels to Basque town for remembrance ceremony marking ‘terrible crimes’ of 1937
articles.summary: German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier, on a state visit to Spain, became the first German head of state to travel to Guernica on 28 November to honor the 1937 Nazi bombing by the Condor Legion that killed hundreds of civilians. Joining King Felipe VI, he laid a wreath, met survivors and in Madrid publicly acknowledged Germany’s “terrible crimes,” invoking Picasso’s Guernica as a universal warning. Guernica’s mayor and the Basque president urged bringing Picasso’s masterpiece home and called on Spain to similarly confront its past.

articles.title: ‘We can’t get any answers’: grief and anger in Hong Kong after deadly high-rise fire
articles.trailText: With the blaze extinguished but hundreds still unaccounted for, the city is grieving – with questions being raised of authorities
articles.summary: Deadly blaze ripped through seven of eight towers at Hong Kong’s Wang Fuk Court high-rise, killing at least 128 and leaving 200 unaccounted as distraught families like Mei Lan’s await news. Questions swirl over flammable styrofoam netting and bamboo scaffolding despite 16 safety inspections, and a controversial HK$330m renovation contract awarded to Prestige Construction. Volunteers at Tai Po echo 2019 protest demands for victim care and official accountability. Authorities have arrested multiple construction employees and launched an independent anti-corruption probe, but chief executive John Lee faces criticism for vague crisis management.

articles.title: ‘Not going to happen’: First Nations threaten to end Carney’s pipe dream
articles.trailText: The Canadian PM’s breakthrough oil deal with Alberta cost him a cabinet minister and will still face stiff opposition
articles.summary: When the Haida nation secured Aboriginal title to Xhaaidlagha Gwaayaai, Canada agreed to respect its rights. On Nov 28, PM Mark Carney and Alberta premier Danielle Smith unveiled an oil pipeline deal—over 1m barrels/day, faster approvals, higher Alberta carbon pricing and a multibillion-dollar carbon capture project—in exchange for lifting coastal tanker and emissions moratoriums. Haida president Gaagwiis and Coastal First Nations categorically refuse consent, citing oil-spill risks to ecosystems and culture. BC premier David Eby warned there’s no proponent, route or financing; a cabinet minister resigned in protest. The pact highlights tensions between economic cooperation, Indigenous consent and Canada’s climate commitments.

articles.title: Fatos Nano obituary
articles.trailText: Politician who helped steer Albania’s chaotic transition in the early 1990s from communist rule to fledgling market economy
articles.summary: Fatos Nano, who died aged 73 of COPD, was Albania’s Socialist leader and four-time prime minister during the transition from Stalinist rule to a market democracy. Emerging from an economist background, he rebranded the communist Party of Labour into the Socialist Party, steered the 1991 peaceful reforms, survived imprisonment for alleged corruption, and returned in 1997 to stabilize the economy, shift power to parliament and calm social unrest. Defeated in 2005 amid corruption allegations, he oversaw a smooth handover and retired to private life.

articles.title: Video shows Israeli forces shooting Palestinians dead moments after surrender
articles.trailText: Far-right minister defends killing of two men who appeared to have given themselves up, saying ‘terrorists must die’
articles.summary: Video footage from a Jenin raid shows Israeli border police unit Yamas summarily executing two unarmed Palestinians—Youssef Asasa, 37, and Mahmoud Abdallah, 26—moments after they surrendered; journalists nearby recorded the incident. The IDF says the shooting during the joint operation is under review, while far-right minister Itamar Ben-Gvir publicly lauds the killings. Palestinian Islamic Jihad says the men were al-Quds Brigades fighters. UN and B’Tselem condemn the act as a war crime, with B’Tselem branding military reviews a whitewash.

articles.title: Belgium hits back at EU plan to use frozen Russian assets to aid Ukraine
articles.trailText: Prime minister says proposal violates international law and would destabilise financial markets
articles.summary: Belgium’s PM Bart De Wever criticized the EU’s draft law to use €183 bn in frozen Russian assets in Euroclear to back a €140 bn loan for Ukraine, calling it “fundamentally wrong”, violative of international law and a risk to markets and the euro. In a letter to Ursula von der Leyen he demands full guarantees from member states and warns of lawsuits and systemic risks. He also cautioned it could hamper peace talks and invite Russia to reclaim assets. EU leaders under pressure face a unanimous vote at the 18–19 December summit amid US proposals.

articles.title: Search under way after British man falls from cruise ship off Tenerife
articles.trailText: Coastguard says 76-year-old passenger was reported missing from Tui-operated vessel on Thursday morning
articles.summary: Marella Cruises, operated by TUI UK, is working with Spanish authorities in the search for a 76-year-old British man who fell overboard from the Marella Explorer 2 on Thursday morning. The coastguard received an alert at 09:48 local time when the ship was 16.5 nautical miles northwest of Punta de Teno off Tenerife en route to La Gomera. A dedicated care team is supporting the passenger’s family, and the operator remains committed to assisting rescue efforts.

articles.title: St Vincent opposition party celebrates historic election win
articles.trailText: New Democratic party victory is crushing defeat for Unity Labour, which has held power since 2001
articles.summary: The New Democratic Party (NDP) secured a landslide, winning 14 of 15 seats in St Vincent and the Grenadines, toppling the long-ruling Unity Labour Party (ULP) in power since 2001. Only outgoing prime minister Ralph Gonsalves—a climate-justice and reparations advocate—retained his seat. Lawyer Godwin Friday, NDP leader since 2016, will take office amid voter backlash over a Covid-19 vaccine mandate, anti-incumbent sentiment and demands for jobs, crime reduction, health and infrastructure. Friday’s manifesto promises citizenship-by-investment but remains vague on shifting ties from Taiwan to China. Regional leaders from Jamaica to Taiwan have congratulated him on a historic mandate.

articles.title: Ukraine corruption scandal threatens Zelenskyy’s special relationship with top aide
articles.trailText: Police raid at the home of Kyiv’s main peace negotiator is causing shock waves across Ukraine’s political scene
articles.summary: Anticorruption police raided Andriy Yermak's Kyiv residence, threatening President Zelenskyy's right-hand man and key peace negotiator. Yermak, Zelenskyy's chief of staff, controls access to the president, enforces domestic politics, liaises with foreign leaders, and orchestrates negotiations. His concentration of power has generated both admiration and resentment within Ukraine’s elite and abroad; some U.S. officials preferred dealing with security council head Rustem Umerov. Despite mounting calls to oust Yermak amid corruption allegations, Zelenskyy's symbiotic bond with him makes dismissal unlikely, even though removing him may be politically expedient to defuse the scandal.

articles.title: ‘Foam that’s washed away’: support dissolves as Bolsonaro starts 27-year jail term
articles.trailText: Brazil shows little sign of feared rightwing rebellion, with only a few die-hards protesting outside prison
articles.summary: Jair Bolsonaro began serving a 27-year coup sentence in a confined cell at a federal police base; outside, only two dozen loyalists protested in Brasília despite calls for a rightwing uprising. With son Eduardo facing arrest in the US and his movement devoid of mass mobilization, analysts debate if 'Bolsonarismo' has lost momentum. Followers cling to hopes of amnesty or a conservative victory in 2026; comparisons to Lula's and Vargas's political comebacks underscore uncertainties over Brazil's far-right future.

articles.title: St Vincent prime minister seeks record sixth term in tight election
articles.trailText: Ralph Gonsalves campaigns on economic record in bid to retain office he has held since 2001
articles.summary: In the Nov 27 election in St Vincent and the Grenadines, incumbent PM Ralph Gonsalves (ULP) seeks a record sixth term against Godwin Friday’s New Democratic Party. Gonsalves highlights robust 4% 2025 growth, tourism-led recovery after the pandemic, La Soufrière volcano and storm setbacks, plus a new international airport, scholarships, climate justice and slavery reparations leadership. The NDP attacks rising living costs, youth unemployment, crime, pledges jobs, better healthcare, infrastructure and citizenship-by-investment. Observers note Gonsalves’ 79-year age and the NDP’s ambiguous stance on Taiwan–China ties.

articles.title: Friday briefing: How will Ukraine fare this winter as Trump pushes for a controversial peace deal? ​
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: After nearly four years of war, Ukraine is confronting deep fatigue, dwindling strategic options and fresh US pressure to accept terms that many see as a surrender in all but name
articles.summary: With Ukraine entering its fourth winter of war, Kyiv faces troop fatigue, stalled fronts and mounting US pressure from the Trump administration to accept a 28-point peace plan effectively meeting all of Putin’s demands—ceding Donbas, shrinking its army, banning long-range weapons and abandoning NATO ambitions. European leaders warn it amounts to capitulation. Neither side can force a decisive breakthrough. Kyiv’s negotiating options hinge on uncertain NATO-style security guarantees. Domestically Zelenskiy navigates political scandals amid intensified diplomatic deadlines, while Putin juggles economic strain against his regime’s commitment to the conflict. A grinding stalemate looms.

articles.title: Bear attacks man in public toilet in Japan
articles.trailText: Incident north of Tokyo comes after a record 13 deaths from bear attacks in Japan since the start of April
articles.summary: In Gunma prefecture north of Tokyo, a 69-year-old security guard was lightly injured after fighting off a 1–1.5 m bear that entered a closed railway-station toilet at dawn on Nov. 28. This incident is part of a record wave: 13 fatalities and 197 attacks since April nationwide amid poor acorn and beechnut yields driving bears into towns. The government deployed Self-Defense Forces to trap bears and authorized armed police to shoot them. Separately, Onagawa municipality apologised for posting an AI-generated bear image online.

articles.title: ‘Is this doable?’: why political paralysis threatens an ambitious Brussels arts complex
articles.trailText: Kanal is 95% complete and on schedule but plans to slash its budget mean conversation around its opening have moved from ‘when’ to ‘if’
articles.summary: Brussels’s Kanal, 95% complete in a former Citroën garage, plans to open Nov 2026 with 12,500 m² of exhibition, architecture and performance spaces—surpassing the original Tate Modern—and a five-year, €2 m/yr Centre Pompidou partnership. But 537 days of political paralysis in the Brussels-Capital region and a looming €1 bn austerity drive, with proposals to cut Kanal’s budget by over 50%, threaten to halt construction. Supporters highlight 780 new jobs and a €144 m annual economic boost; critics call to ditch the Pompidou tie and scale back to avoid cultural “suicide.”

articles.title: ‘A constant fear’: Myanmar nationals face imprisonment back home as US ends protected status
articles.trailText: Thousands of Myanmar diaspora are at risk of deportation, after the US said they no longer required Temporary Protective Status
articles.summary: US DHS announced termination of Temporary Protected Status for Myanmar nationals effective Jan 26, 2025, affecting about 4,000 diaspora including students like Aung, Su Htet and Lungpi. Citing perceived improvements after the junta’s planned December elections and ceasefire deals, the decision risks legitimising Myanmar’s military regime and leaves vulnerable activists, students and ethnic or religious minorities facing real threats of arrest, torture or conscription. Concerned rights groups warn conditions remain “deeply unsafe” and many have sought asylum to avoid forced returns.

articles.title: Millions in China cram for civil service exam and the hope of a job for life
articles.trailText: Amid troubled economic times, many in China are shifting back towards the certainty of a career in the public sector
articles.summary: A record 3.7 million applicants will sit China’s national civil service exam this weekend, vying for 38 100 posts (an average of 97 candidates per vacancy) after age limits rose from 35 to 38 (general) and 40 to 43 (postgraduates). The change mirrors recent retirement‐age hikes (women: 50→55/55→58; men: 60→63) as workers seek the “iron rice bowl” amid 17.3 percent youth unemployment and economic uncertainty. Competition peaks for an immigration officer role in Ruili (6 470 applicants per slot). The notoriously tough exam now adds political‐theory questions on Party ideology, forcing aspirants to juggle intense study with family commitments.

articles.title: Palestinian Australian assaulted and abused on Sydney train ‘shocked’ police charged assailant with assault but not hate speech
articles.trailText: Exclusive : Assault on Shamikh Badra captured on video and incident labelled ‘unacceptable’ by attorney general, but sole charge highlights issues with hate speech laws
articles.summary: Palestinian-Australian filmmaker Shamikh Badra was filmed being racially abused and struck by 46-year-old Nicholas Haskal on a Sydney train in August, seconds after leaving a pro-Palestine rally. Despite video and CCTV evidence of Haskal’s taunts—“Get the fuck out of here…we don’t want you in our country”—he was charged only with common assault, pleaded guilty and received a 12-month conditional release order with no conviction. Police say hate speech provisions under NSW’s 93Z/93ZAA couldn’t be proven; legal experts warn intent to incite hatred is hard to establish. Critics and the Badra brothers say this exposes flaws in NSW’s hate speech laws and lack of transparency.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy will not give up land in exchange for peace, president’s chief of staff says
articles.trailText: Andriy Yermak’s comments come as Putin says Russia will fight on unless Kyiv withdraws from territory. What we know on day 1,374
articles.summary: Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelenskyy refuses to cede land for peace, his chief of staff Andriy Yermak tells the Atlantic, ruling out territorial concessions under his tenure. Russian President Vladimir Putin, while acknowledging a US-drafted 28-point peace plan, insists Ukraine withdraw from contested regions and calls Zelenskyy "illegitimate." US and Ukrainian delegations plan follow-up talks in Geneva. Concurrently, Hungary's Viktor Orbán travels to Moscow for energy discussions; Belgian PM Bart De Wever cautions that using frozen Russian assets for Ukrainian reparations could jeopardize peace prospects; Nobel laureate Oleksandra Matviichuk opposes war-crimes amnesty; Moldova votes to close a Russian cultural centre over security concerns.

articles.title: Canada minister resigns from cabinet over Carney’s controversial oil pipeline deal
articles.trailText: Minister Steven Guilbeault says Indigenous nations were not consulted and the pipeline would have ‘major environmental impacts’
articles.summary: Mark Carney and Alberta premier Danielle Smith agreed on an energy package to build a new heavy-oil pipeline from the oil sands to BC’s coast, plus nuclear power and datacentres, in return for exempting the project from tanker and emissions moratoria while boosting provincial carbon pricing and funding multibillion-dollar carbon capture. Culture minister Steven Guilbeault resigned, faulting the plan’s lack of Indigenous or BC consultation, its threat to the Great Bear rainforest and Canada’s climate goals. BC premier David Eby and Coastal First Nations have vowed to block any proposal, and no private investors have yet emerged.

articles.title: Venezuela bans six international airlines as tensions with US escalate
articles.trailText: Carriers accused of joining ‘actions of state terrorism promoted by US’ after they suspended flights to Venezuela
articles.summary: Venezuela’s civil aviation authority revoked operating permits for six carriers—Iberia, Tap, Avianca, Latam, Gol and Turkish Airlines—accusing them of 'state terrorism' after suspending flights following a US FAA warning over military activity and security risks in Venezuelan airspace. Caracas rejected FAA authority, while Portugal called the ban disproportionate and sought reinstatement for Tap. The US has bolstered its Caribbean military presence amid drug-trafficking accusations against President Maduro, who denies them. IATA gave airlines 48 hours to resume flights or lose rights; some have canceled, though Iberia and Avianca plan gradual resumption.

articles.title: Putin insists Ukraine has to surrender territory for any deal to be possible
articles.trailText: Russian president says latest draft peace plan ‘can be basis for future agreements’ if Kyiv gives up unspecified areas
articles.summary: During a visit to Kyrgyzstan, Vladimir Putin said a US-Ukraine draft peace plan could serve as a negotiating basis—but only if Ukraine cedes unspecified territory. He insisted Russia would halt its offensive only once Ukrainian forces withdraw, and repeated his claim that President Zelenskyy is “illegitimate,” making any binding agreement impossible without broader recognition. Putin confirmed US envoy Steve Witkoff’s upcoming trip, dismissing bias allegations. Kremlin tactics mix peace overtures with maximalist demands, while analysts and Ukraine’s chief of staff stress Kyiv will not surrender land under Zelenskyy’s leadership.

articles.title: Pope Leo warns of risk from ‘piecemeal’ world war in first overseas trip
articles.trailText: Leo welcomed by Recep Tayyip Erdoğan as he begins six-day itinerary that will also include visit to Lebanon
articles.summary: Pope Leo’s warning against a “piecemeal” third world war sets the tone for his six-day first overseas trip to Turkey and Lebanon. Welcomed by Erdoğan in Ankara, he urged Turkey to champion stability and mediate conflicts from Gaza to Ukraine. He will meet Orthodox Patriarch Bartholomew at the 1,700th Nicaea anniversary, visit Istanbul’s Blue Mosque and celebrate mass in a stadium. In Lebanon, he’ll pray at the 2020 port blast site, address Israel–Hezbollah tensions and seek Christian unity amid economic turmoil, promoting the Vatican’s peacemaking role.

articles.title: Anger swelling in Hong Kong over deadliest fire in more than 70 years
articles.trailText: Some think leader John Lee’s focus on blaming bamboo scaffolding deflects from actual cause
articles.summary: The deadliest Hong Kong fire in 70 years tore through seven high-rise blocks at Wang Fuk Court, killing dozens and leaving hundreds missing. Survivors blame government and contractors for shoddy maintenance rather than bamboo scaffolding, now under fire as potential accelerant. Authorities promised a HK$300m relief fund, scaffold material checks, and face arrests and a corruption probe into the renovation firm. Public distrust runs high amid soaring housing costs and fears of a cover-up without an independent inquiry. Beijing has mobilised PLA support and corporate aid, while election postponement looms.

articles.title: France to introduce voluntary military service amid threat from Russia
articles.trailText: Macron says plan to introduce 10 months’ service among 18- and 19-year-olds will help France respond to ‘accelerating threats’
articles.summary: French president Macron will launch a voluntary 10-month military service by mid-2026 for 18- and 19-year-olds (up to 25 for specialist roles) paying €800 monthly plus benefits, deploying only on national soil. A €2 bn hybrid-army plan aims for 3,000 recruits in 2026 ramping to 10,000 by 2030 and 50,000 by 2036, bolstering reservists and active forces amid perceived Russian threats and shifting US security priorities. Macron ruled out reinstating conscription, framing the scheme as aligned with European partners. The move follows debate over armed forces chief Gen. Mandon’s remarks on readiness for potential losses.

articles.title: Palestinian-American teenager held in Israeli prison freed after nine months
articles.trailText: Israeli soldiers had taken Mohammed Ibrahim from his home in a night raid when he was only 15 years old
articles.summary: Palestinian-American teenager Mohammed Ibrahim, 16, was freed after nine months in Israeli military detention following a February night raid on his West Bank home when he was 15. Charged with throwing objects at moving vehicles, he entered a guilty plea in exchange for a suspended sentence. His family says he lost 25% of his body weight, contracted scabies and suffers severe malnutrition. The US embassy, faith and civil rights groups, plus 27 Democratic lawmakers, pressed for his release. Upon freedom he was hospitalized for IV therapy and blood tests as advocates highlight hundreds of other Palestinian minors still detained.

articles.title: Arrest warrants issued for Miss Universe co-owners in latest twist in pageant saga
articles.trailText: Raúl Rocha Cantú is under investigation for drug, gun and fuel trafficking while Jakkaphong Jakrajutatip is accused of fraud
articles.summary: Just days after Fátima Bosch’s win in Thailand, arrest warrants were issued for both Miss Universe co-owners. Mexican businessman Raúl Rocha Cantú faces a Mexican attorney general investigation into drug, gun and fuel trafficking between Guatemala and Mexico—he denies the charges. Thai media mogul Jakkaphong Jakrajutatip was accused of defrauding a plastic surgeon over investments in her JKN Global Group, failed to appear at her fraud trial and is now deemed a flight risk. These legal battles follow a pageant marred by onstage injuries, a judge walkout over alleged vote-rigging, a viral protest by Bosch and disputed ties between Rocha and Bosch’s family.

articles.title: Italy’s rape law stalls as Matteo Salvini claims it could be used for ‘vendettas’
articles.trailText: Parliament delays debate over law defining sex without consent as rape, after comments by far-right deputy PM
articles.summary: Italy’s ruling coalition has postponed the senate debate on a landmark bill—brokered by PM Giorgia Meloni and opposition leader Elly Schlein—that would define any sexual act without explicit consent as rape (punishable by six to 12 years’ imprisonment). Deputy PM Matteo Salvini’s League bloc blocked the debate, warning it could clog courts and be used for personal vendettas, despite nominally supporting the principle. The lower house passed the measure and a separate femicide law this week, but critics link the stall to recent regional election losses. Senate consideration is now scheduled for January amid pressure from Schlein and women’s rights groups.

articles.title: Denmark sets up ‘night watch’ to monitor Trump after Greenland row
articles.trailText: US president’s threat to seize territory prompts intelligence briefings reminiscent of Game of Thrones patrol
articles.summary: Denmark’s foreign ministry has created a permanent “night watch,” staffed from 17:00–07:00 CET, to track and report daily on US President Donald Trump’s pronouncements and moves. Launched after Trump’s spring threat to seize Greenland, the watch issues a morning briefing for all relevant departments, streamlining updates across the time zone gap. Politiken notes it reflects wider civil-service adaptations to Trump’s second term. Ex-defence intelligence analyst Jacob Kaarsbo says the measure highlights a breakdown in shared values and trust underpinning the traditional US–Denmark alliance.

articles.title: US deal must punish Russia war crimes, says Ukraine’s Nobel peace prize winner
articles.trailText: Oleksandra Matviichuk warns any amnesty could encourage authoritarian leaders to attack their neighbours
articles.summary: Ukrainian Nobel laureate Oleksandra Matviichuk warns any US-mediated peace must punish Russian war crimes and reject full amnesties, cautioning that clause 26 of a leaked 28-point US-Russia draft would set a dangerous precedent. She backs President Zelenskiy’s 19-point counter-proposal, calls for NATO-style security guarantees, protection for 6 million citizens in occupied areas, and rejects territorial concessions in Donetsk. Matviichuk argues a durable settlement needs enforceable safeguards to deter future aggression, echoing Ukrainian officials’ resistance to ceding land without victory. Negotiations continue this week as US envoy Steve Witkoff heads to Moscow amid Kremlin insistence on no changes. Her Ukrainian Center for Civil Liberties has documented over 92 000 probable war crimes since 2014.

articles.title: South Africa hits back at ��punitive’ Trump move to bar it from G20 meeting in Florida
articles.trailText: Diplomatic row worsens after US president says member state will not be invited to 2026 summit
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced South Africa would be excluded from the 2026 Miami G20 summit and US aid and subsidies would be halted, accusing Pretoria of failing to hand over the rotating presidency and of “killing white people” ��� claims SA calls misinformation. Johannesburg summit host Ramaphosa refused to cede protocol to a US envoy, dubbing Trump’s measures “punitive” insults to its sovereign G20 status. South Africa hailed the summit as a win for multilateralism on climate and gender, while Trump presses on with refugee offers to Afrikaners amid contested farm-murder statistics.

articles.title: West is ‘missing obscure sanctions that could set back Russia’s war machine’
articles.trailText: US group Dekleptocracy identifies additives for military vehicles’ lubricants and tyres as potential vulnerabilities
articles.summary: US NGO DeKleptocracy flags obscure chemicals—lubricant additives and tyre vulcanisation accelerants—as strategic vulnerabilities in Russia’s war effort after sanctions hit oil majors. Only a few global suppliers, notably China’s Xinxiang Richful (supplying 8 m kg/month), backfill Russian demand; cutting them off could cripple tank and vehicle readiness. Moscow lacks domestic production capacity and has launched an import-substitution drive. G7 officials, like US Secretary of State Rubio, claim few sanction targets remain, but experts urge imposing new measures on these niche suppliers and enforcing existing bans. Civil society researchers continue mining trade data to expose further weak points in Russia’s war economy.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: ​What could the government’s proposals to scrap jury trials mean for democracy?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As pressure mounts to tackle ​the backlog​ of almost 80,000​ cases, the government is considering sweeping reforms that senior lawyers warn may reshape justice in England and Wales
