articles.summary: In response to an 80,000-case Crown Court backlog—some suspects facing trials only by 2029—the government under Justice Secretary David Lammy proposes a new court tier for England and Wales, restricting jury trials to the gravest offences (murder, rape, manslaughter and other public-interest cases) and vesting judges alone with jurisdiction over offences meriting sentences up to five years. Leaked plans exceed Sir Brian Leveson’s three-year threshold, triggering a backlash from senior lawyers and campaigners who warn that removing juries risks more miscarriages of justice, worsens minority under-representation and undermines a Magna Carta-rooted democratic safeguard.

articles.title: European progressives must tackle housing crisis to beat far right, say researchers
articles.trailText: Centre left can win broad support by addressing soaring house prices and rents, according to data analysis
articles.summary: Researchers at PPRNet warn that Europe’s housing crisis—house prices up ~50% and rents up ~25% since 2000, far outpacing wages—has eroded centre-left support and driven voters toward the far right. Once champions of social housing, many social-democratic parties have reduced public build, deregulated mortgages and favored ownership as an asset. To reclaim voters, progressives must reframe housing as public infrastructure: boost social housing with moderate rents, enable affordable, non-speculative ownership for low/middle incomes, reform financing and change the narrative. Failure risks farright gain via nativist “housing-as-patrimony” appeals.

articles.title: Jakarta overtakes Tokyo as world’s most populous city, according to UN
articles.trailText: The rankings were changed after the UN used new criteria to give a more accurate picture of the rapid urbanisation driving the growth of megacities
articles.summary: Applying a more consistent UN geospatial methodology in the World Urbanisation Prospects 2025 report, Jakarta’s metro population now ranks first at 42 m, ahead of Dhaka (37 m) and Tokyo’s expanded region (33 m), which led in 2018. This reflects rapid urbanization—urban residents now account for nearly half of 8.2 b people, and the number of megacities (≥ 10 m) has quadrupled since 1975 to 33, nine of which are in Asia (the exception being Cairo). Two‐thirds of future global population growth is projected for cities by 2050.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Witkoff peace plan call angers Republicans
articles.trailText: Several Republicans condemn the White House over its handling of proposed plan they say favours Russia.
articles.summary: Steve Witkoff’s Trump-endorsed 28-point Ukraine peace plan is under fire from GOP figures—Senators Wicker, Bacon and Fitzpatrick accuse him of pro-Russia bias after leaks of his coaching Moscow; McConnell suggests Trump change advisers. US special forces and NATO vets condemn it as betrayal. Russia calls talks “serious” pending expert review; von der Leyen warns against legitimizing border changes. Meanwhile, Russian forces seize 467 sq km/month in Donetsk, threatening key towns, as the IMF agrees a four-year $8.2 bn aid package.

articles.title: Tom Phillips case: New Zealand to hold public inquiry into disappearance of fugitive father and children
articles.trailText: Hearings will be held in private to assess ‘whether government agencies took all practicable steps to protect the safety and welfare of the Phillips children’, says attorney general
articles.summary: New Zealand will hold a public inquiry into authorities’ handling of fugitive father Tom Phillips’s 2021 disappearance with his three children—who hid in the North Island wilderness for nearly four years without legal custody—after Phillips was killed in an armed shootout with police in Piopio in August. Two children were found at a Waitomo campsite; a third died with him. Now in Oranga Tamariki care, the children’s welfare and agencies’ actions will be scrutinized. Led by Justice Simon Moore KC through private hearings, the inquiry reports back by July 2026.

articles.title: Death toll in Hong Kong tower block fire rises to 44 with hundreds still missing
articles.trailText: Three arrests made after huge blaze broke out at Wang Fuk Court residential complex in Tai Po district on Wednesday
articles.summary: A massive five-alarm blaze at Tai Po's Wang Fuk Court, eight 31-storey towers housing about 4,800 residents, has left 44 dead, 45 critical and hundreds missing. Some 800 firefighters with 128 engines battled flames fueled by external bamboo scaffolding. Authorities arrested three men on manslaughter suspicions and launched a taskforce probe. Chief Executive John Lee declared the fire "under control" as shelters opened. The inferno—Hong Kong's deadliest in decades—has intensified public anger over building safety, scaffolding practices and soaring property costs ahead of December's legislative election.

articles.title: Bamboo scaffolding may be to blame for spread of Hong Kong tower block fire
articles.trailText: Hong Kong is one of the last places in the world where bamboo is widely used by construction workers
articles.summary: A deadly blaze tore through the 31-storey Wang Fuk Court complex in Tai Po on Nov 26, killing dozens in Hong Kong’s worst fire in decades. Police say traditional bamboo scaffolding and green mesh sheathing accelerated vertical spread across eight towers housing 4,800 residents. Valued for low cost and millennia-old craft heritage, bamboo remains ubiquitous even as mainland sites adopt metal frames. After 23 scaffold-related deaths since 2018, the government plans to phase out bamboo in favour of fire-resistant steel—mandating metal on 50% of public works—drawing fierce opposition from the Bamboo Scaffolding Workers Union over livelihoods.

articles.title: Guinea-Bissau military takes ‘total control’ amid election chaos
articles.trailText: Officers say they are closing borders and suspending poll as president and main rival both claim victory
articles.summary: Three days after a disputed presidential vote, Guinea-Bissau’s army declared "total control", closing borders, suspending the poll and installing a High Military Command for Order. Incumbent Umaro Sissoco Embaló and rival Fernando Dias both claim first-round victory; each accuses the other of orchestrating gunfire near the election commission, presidential palace and interior ministry. The junta said it will govern until stability returns. Since 1974 independence, Guinea-Bissau has seen at least nine coups; its economy is one of the world’s poorest and was labeled a narco-state in 2008.

articles.title: Von der Leyen warns against ���carving up’ of Ukraine amid crunch US-led talks
articles.trailText: Commission president says undermining of sovereign European nation would ‘open the doors for more wars’
articles.summary: Commission president Ursula von der Leyen warned MEPs against any unilateral carving up of Ukraine, asserting that forced border changes risk new conflicts. While welcoming the US’s 28-point plan and Trump envoy Steve Witkoff’s upcoming talks in Moscow as a “starting point,” she stressed Russia shows no real ceasefire intent. EU foreign ministers, led by Kaja Kallas, reaffirmed Ukraine’s sovereignty, rejected limits on its armed forces and called for robust security guarantees. Brussels aims to use €183bn of frozen Russian assets to fund a 2026-27 reconstruction loan, tighten sanctions, sustain defence aid and secure the return of nearly 20,000 forcibly deported Ukrainian children.

articles.title: As France prepares military expansion, how is Europe beefing up its armies?
articles.trailText: European nations are rushing to bolster their defences amid Russia threat and uncertainty of US support
articles.summary: France will restore a voluntary military service nearly 30 years after ending conscription as Europe rushes to rebuild forces amid Russia’s growing threat and uncertain US backing. With many armies missing recruitment and retention targets, EU states weigh conscription models: Nordics and Baltics use universal or selective draft (Sweden’s male/female registry, Finland’s universal male), Denmark extended service, Estonia universal, Latvia/Lithuania lotteries, Croatia reinstated conscription, Poland plans adult-male training. Germany kept voluntary but may revisit mandatory call-up. Volunteers offer professionalism but are costlier; conscripts boost reserves at political risk, requiring sustained public debate.

articles.title: Can Europe prevent an unjust ‘peace’ in Ukraine – and what is at stake if it fails?
articles.trailText: Seizing Moscow’s money to bail out Kyiv may be all that stands between a fair outcome and a ‘deal’ that brings war in the rest of Europe a step closer
articles.summary: In Europe’s moment of truth, leaked US-backed 28-point peace draft, suspected partly Kremlin-authored, would freeze front lines, force Ukraine to cede occupied and held lands, cut its army, grant amnesty for Russian war crimes and bar Kyiv from Nato. Trump’s Thanksgiving ultimatum threatened to halt US aid, spurring emergency Geneva talks that slightly bolstered sovereignty. France, Germany and the UK have resisted. Europe’s key leverage: a €140bn reparations loan secured on frozen Russian central bank assets. Failure risks a lopsided deal, emboldening Putin and undermining continental security.

articles.title: Trump threatens Venezuela’s Maduro with ‘the easy way … or the hard way’
articles.trailText: Venezuela president vows to defend ‘every inch’ of the country amid military buildup in Caribbean
articles.summary: Nicolás Maduro rallied supporters in Caracas in camouflage, vowing to defend “every inch” of Venezuela against what he framed as US imperialism, after President Trump threatened to act “the easy way … or the hard way.” Trump has deployed a major military buildup in the Caribbean, ostensibly to crack down on drug trafficking, and branded Maduro’s “Cartel of the Suns” a foreign terrorist organization, though experts question its actual existence. While Trump has not clarified his endgame, analysts warn future air or sea strikes could backfire, bolster Maduro’s standing and further dim prospects for a peaceful transfer of power.

articles.title: ‘Progress is happening’: gender pay gap narrows but Australian women still earn $28,000 less than men
articles.trailText: Western Australian employers reported the biggest pay gap and Tasmanian employers the smallest, but all states reported an improvement, study finds
articles.summary: Australia’s gender pay gap narrowed slightly in 2024–25 to 21.1%, with women earning 78.9¢ for every dollar men earn—about A$28,000 less annually—across 5.4m workers at 8,200+ employers. The gap improved by 0.7 percentage points year-on-year, with Western Australia recording the largest divide (28.8%) and Tasmania the smallest (10.6%). Yet at the CEO level, the gap widened to 26.2%, leaving women leaders paid A$83,493 less in base salary (A$185,335 less including bonuses). Women fill just 20% of CEO roles, 33% of board seats and 40% of management posts. Primary carer leave uptake by men rose to 20%. Employers urged to bolster equal-opportunity policies.

articles.title: ‘Fearing for our lives’: Australians tell of Chilean mountain horror where five hikers perished
articles.trailText: Hikers say authorities should have closed popular trail due to horrendous weather conditions, and camp staff offered minimal assistance
articles.summary: In Chile’s Torres del Paine national park, a group of 30 hikers, including 13 Australians led by Emily Dong, endured 190 km/h winds and –5 °C temperatures (–20 °C wind chill) on the remote O Circuit. After camp staff assured them the trail was safe despite accumulating snow, they encountered locked huts and no rangers on duty due to Chile’s presidential election. Five trekkers—a British woman, a German couple and a Mexican couple—died of hypothermia before rescue teams arrived over 24 hours later. Survivors accuse Conaf and private operator Vertice of systemic failures and demand hiker logs, emergency equipment and better communication; Conaf has launched an internal inquiry.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy convicted of illegal campaign financing in failed 2012 re-election bid
articles.trailText: Verdict is fresh blow for former French president who was released from prison only this month in connection with separate conviction
articles.summary: France’s Cour de Cassation has upheld former president Nicolas Sarkozy’s conviction for illegal overspending in his failed 2012 re-election bid, rejecting his final appeal in the Bygmalion affair. Prosecutors proved he ignored warnings and nearly doubled the €22.5m spending cap by spending over €42.8m on American-style rallies filmed by events firm Bygmalion. Sentenced on appeal to one year (half suspended) and freed earlier this month on a separate Gaddafi funds conviction, Sarkozy must now serve a six-month term via electronic tag. He continues appealing other post-presidential legal cases.

articles.title: Americans helping Ukrainian war effort call US peace plan a ‘betrayal by Trump’
articles.trailText: US volunteers who have poured into Ukraine to help amid war are dismayed by Trump’s continuing pressures on Kyiv
articles.summary: US volunteers and veterans helping Ukraine condemn Donald Trump’s leaked 28-point peace plan as a betrayal, arguing it echoes Putin’s maximalist demands. Critics—including a former special forces adviser and GOP figures like Rep. Don Bacon—denounce calls to cede Donetsk and Luhansk, bar NATO membership and shrink Ukraine’s military as a surrender. Confusion surrounds the plan’s authorship, while volunteers fear Kyiv is being forced into a catastrophic deal and lament US foreign policy decline.

articles.title: Hundreds of Israeli soldiers raid Palestinian town in West Bank
articles.trailText: Israeli military and security service say ‘broad counter-terrorism operation’ in Tubas to continue for several days
articles.summary: In late November, hundreds of Israeli soldiers with armored vehicles raided Tubas near Nablus—the largest West Bank deployment since last month’s Gaza ceasefire—imposing curfews, sealing roads, and evicting families. The army and Shin Bet launched a 'broad counter-terrorism operation', warning Tubas resembled Jenin and Tulkarm. In Gaza, six Hamas militants were killed near Rafah, and Hamas returned the remains of an Israeli hostage; Israel will release 15 Palestinian bodies per hostage. Since October 2023, Israeli forces have killed 1,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and 70,000 in Gaza, while Human Rights Watch decries forced displacement of 32,000 West Bank refugees as war crimes.

articles.title: Bahrain to argue at UK supreme court it has immunity from surveillance claims
articles.trailText: Gulf nation is accused of placing monitoring software on computers of two dissidents living in London
articles.summary: Bahrain is appealing to the UK Supreme Court for sovereign immunity after lower courts ruled under the State Immunity Act 1978 that it can face damages claims for allegedly using German-made FinFisher spyware to hack computers of London-based dissidents Dr Saeed Shehabi and Moosa Mohammed in 2011. The appeal focuses on whether the men can pursue personal injury claims, including psychiatric harm, despite Bahrain’s immunity plea. A ruling upholding immunity would reshape accountability for authoritarian digital surveillance abroad. The case also tests the Act’s Section 5 territorial exception and sets a precedent for similar spyware claims.

articles.title: ‘It’s heartbreaking’: how 30 captive beluga whales have become pawns in row over animal cruelty
articles.trailText: As the government, Marineland of Canada and activists remain at loggerheads over whales’ fate, health and freedom of beloved animals hangs in balance
articles.summary: Thirty belugas at Marineland near Niagara Falls face euthanasia after Canada’s fisheries minister blocked their sale to China. Marineland demands federal funds or threatens to kill the whales, citing mounting care costs and tank disrepair. With at least 19 belugas dead since 2019 and tanks crumbling, urgency mounts. Former trainer Kristy Burgess highlights the animals’ intelligence, social bonds and captivity-related vulnerabilities. Proposed solutions—release to the wild, a Nova Scotia sea-pen sanctuary, US rehoming or provincial seizure—are contested by activists, officials and scientists. Stakeholders clash over legal authority, ethics and logistics as whales die amid stalled negotiations over their future care.

articles.title: US to send envoy to Moscow to discuss proposals to end Ukraine war
articles.trailText: Despite recent efforts and White House optimism, recent negotiations have failed to secure a breakthrough on key issues
articles.summary: President Trump plans to send envoy Steve Witkoff to Moscow to negotiate a peace deal ending the Ukraine war, but US, Russian and Ukrainian talks in Abu Dhabi stalled over territorial control and security guarantees. Trump said he would only meet Presidents Zelenskyy or Putin once the deal is ‘final or in its final stages’ and may dispatch US Army Secretary Dan Driscoll to Kyiv this week. Kyiv officials say they’re near agreement on a framework—including raising Ukraine’s force cap from 600,000 to 800,000—but Russia still demands cession of the remaining 30% of Donetsk. European leaders pressing to be included as Russia maintains nightly missile and drone assaults on Ukraine.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: peace plan ‘fine-tuned’, Trump says, as president backs away from Thursday deadline
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says his plan to end the war has been ‘fine-tuned’ and he’s sending envoy Steve Witkoff – and possibly Jared Kushner – to meet with Vladimir Putin.
articles.summary: Former US president Donald Trump says he’s “fine-tuned” a 28-point US-backed peace plan to end the war in Ukraine, dispatching real-estate magnate Steve Witkoff—possibly joined by Jared Kushner—to meet Vladimir Putin in Moscow, and Army Secretary Dan Driscoll to consult Kyiv. He’s dropped his earlier Thursday deadline, deferring it “until it’s over,” and hinted Ukraine may have to cede territory already lost. Negotiations in Abu Dhabi involved US, Russian and Ukrainian officials. Meanwhile, Russia launched a mass drone strike on Zaporizhzhia, NATO jets tracked drones into Romania, and European leaders insist Ukraine’s consent is mandatory.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: What may be in – and out – of Rachel Reeves’s ‘hokey cokey’ budget
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As the chancellor prepares to deliver one of the most heavily briefed budgets ever, tax rises, the two-child benefit cap and a ‘mansion tax’ are all on the table
articles.summary: Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces a £20 billion gap in her highly anticipated ‘hokey cokey’ budget, balancing Labour values, NHS funding, cost-of-living relief and market confidence. Key measures include cutting the cash ISA limit from £20,000 to £12,000, freezing income-tax thresholds until 2030 instead of a 2p rate rise, revaluing properties over £2 million for extra council-tax revenue, scrapping the two-child benefit cap, freezing rail fares and NHS prescriptions, and funding electric-vehicle grants alongside a potential per-mile EV levy.

articles.title: Taiwan plans extra $40bn in defence spending to counter China’s ‘intensifying’ threats
articles.trailText: President Lai Ching-te declared there was ‘no room for compromise on national security’ in face of escalating harassment and espionage
articles.summary: Taiwan announces a $40bn special defence budget for 2026–33 to counter Beijing’s “intensifying” harassment, espionage and invasion preparations, raising spending to 3.3% of GDP in 2026 (targeting 5% by 2030). President Lai Ching-te vows “no room for compromise” on national security, framing this as a defence of “democratic Taiwan” and rejecting “one country, two systems.” Defence Minister Wellington Koo says funds will buy AI tools, missiles, drones, speed procurement, and protect expatriates. The American Institute praises the boost for deterrence. China denounces the move as courting foreign favour. This follows Xi-Trump talks and heightens China-Japan tensions over Yonaguni missile plans.

articles.title: ‘No topic is too difficult’: children’s series on life in communist East Germany wins an Emmy
articles.trailText: In Fritzi’s Footsteps tells story of a girl growing up in Leipzig who witnesses the fall of the Berlin Wall
articles.summary: In Fritzi’s Footsteps, a six-part animated series following 12-year-old Fritzi in Leipzig, uses avatars Julian and Anna to explore everyday life, protests and secret police in the GDR, culminating in the 1989 fall of the Berlin Wall. Awarded an International Emmy—first for German children��s TV in Kids: Factual & Entertainment—the long-gestating project (begun 2009) blends documentary and fiction to engage 8–12-year-olds and families on complex political history, aiming to spark intergenerational dialogue and global interest in East Germany’s legacy.

articles.title: ‘I love my country. I don’t want to leave’: readers reflect on the exodus from New Zealand
articles.trailText: As people continue to move away in record numbers, readers share their reasons for leaving and contemplate life in New Zealand
articles.summary: In the past year tens of thousands of New Zealanders—especially mid-career professionals and young graduates—have left for Australia, Germany and beyond, raising fears of a “hollowing out” back home. Guardian readers cite faster hiring abroad, 30% pay rises, cheaper IVF, reliable superannuation, and affordable property markets. They decry high living costs, unaffordable housing, overwhelmed healthcare and social welfare, underfunded research institutes, and governmental apathy on infrastructure, climate and indigenous rights. While many love Aotearoa’s landscapes and culture, they feel career progression, financial stability and personal growth lie overseas. The mass exodus, driven by necessity not adventure, leaves readers sad about abandoning the country they cherish.

articles.title: Nauru president accused in parliament of corruptly siphoning off millions of Australian funding
articles.trailText: Senator uses parliament to accuse Albanese government of knowing David Adeang was ‘seriously corrupt’ yet still signing $2.5bn deportation deal
articles.summary: In Parliament Greens senator David Shoebridge disclosed an unreleased Austrac report alleging Nauru president David Adeang and ex-president (now foreign minister) Lionel Aingimea diverted millions in Australian offshore-detention funding via suspicious 2020 transactions flagged by banks. Despite these corruption and money-laundering suspicions—Osko payments, construction transfers and ATM withdrawals linked to Aingimea’s 1402 LRC Car Rentals subcontractor—Australia signed a A$2.5 billion deportation deal to resettle 350+ NZYQ asylum seekers on Nauru. Shoebridge urged scrapping the “cruel, corrupt” processing arrangement.

articles.title: Jair Bolsonaro ordered to start 27-year prison term for plotting Brazil coup
articles.trailText: Ex-president to start serving term in 12 sq metre bedroom in police base in Brasília after time for appeals elapses
articles.summary: Brazil’s former president Jair Bolsonaro has been ordered by the supreme court to begin serving a 27-year sentence in a 12 m² cell at a Brasília police base after being convicted of leading a criminal conspiracy to block Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva’s inauguration. The far-right ex-leader, held under house arrest since August and recently arrested for cutting off his ankle bracelet, plotted to assassinate Lula and Alckmin but was thwarted when military chiefs refused to join. Six co-conspirators—ex-defence ministers, a navy commander and security officials—received 16–26 year terms or fled abroad. Small Bolsonarista protests erupted amid jubilation by progressives, while experts note his support has sharply declined.

articles.title: UK accused of caving-in to British Virgin Islands over access to companies register
articles.trailText: Parliamentary group urges government to clamp down on overseas territories before flagship anti-corruption summit
articles.summary: UK faces criticism for yielding to British Virgin Islands’ demands to restrict public access to its beneficial ownership register to those with “legitimate interest,” contravening a 2008 mandate. An all-party parliamentary group, led by Phil Brickell, warns this week’s talks between the Foreign Office and overseas territories are the “last chance” to enforce promised transparency measures before next year’s Global Illicit Finance Summit. Margaret Hodge backs calls for open registers. The BVI’s narrow “legitimate interest” test and power to withhold requests has drawn FATF grey-listing and Transparency International’s warning that nominee shareholders may mask ultimate beneficiaries.

articles.title: Protests erupt in China’s Guizhou province over cremation mandate
articles.trailText: Villagers demonstrate against drive for alternative funeral practices instead of burial to preserve land resources
articles.summary: Villagers in Shidong, Guizhou, have protested a local government directive requiring cremation over burial to conserve land. Many protesters, predominantly of the Miao ethnic minority, view traditional burials as essential cultural rites. Unverified videos show crowds confronting police vehicles and decrying ancestor graves being exhumed, echoing a broader 70% surge in rural unrest this year. Authorities cite a 2003 law promoting frugal funerals; critics report coercion and threats affecting multiple generations. Digital platforms like Douyin have rallied support. Experts note protests on personal heritage issues often sustain longer than economic grievances.

articles.title: Seven killed in Kyiv as Russia hits Ukraine’s energy sector with missiles and drones
articles.trailText: Wide-ranging assault included drones that crossed into Romanian and Moldovan territory
articles.summary: Russia launched a massive overnight assault on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure around Kyiv, firing 22 missiles—including four hypersonic Kinzhals—and 464 drones, four of which crossed into Moldovan and Romanian airspace, prompting Romania to scramble fighter jets. The strikes killed seven and injured 21 in Kyiv, damaged power and heat networks, and hit residential blocks and warehouses, including a Novus supermarket facility. Actor Vadym Tupchiy was among the dead. Explosions were also reported in Dnipro, Kharkiv, Chernihiv and Cherkasy. The attack coincided with US-brokered peace talks in Abu Dhabi. President Zelenskiy urged sustained military aid and sanctions pressure to prevent Russian gains.

articles.title: Nato scrambles jets as Russian drones make deepest incursion into Romania
articles.trailText: Fighter jets track two uncrewed aircraft in first daytime breach of Romanian airspace since full-scale Ukraine war
articles.summary: On November 25, German Typhoon and Romanian F-16 jets were scrambled after two uncrewed Russian drones penetrated Romanian airspace—the first daytime breach and deepest incursion since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine. The first drone returned to Ukraine; the second crashed near Puieşti, 70 miles from the border, likely due to fuel exhaustion. Wreckage analysis confirmed it was an unarmed Gerbera decoy. This marks the 13th overflight of Romanian airspace and follows similar incursions into Moldova and Poland, prompting NATO’s Eastern Sentry patrols and deployment of new drone-kill systems in Romania.

articles.title: Jacob Zuma’s daughter accused of tricking men into fighting for Russia in Ukraine
articles.trailText: South African police investigate allegations made against Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla by another of ex-president’s daughters
articles.summary: South African police are investigating a complaint by Nkosazana Zuma-Mncube accusing her sister, MP Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, and two associates of luring 17 men to Russia on false pretences of paramilitary training, then handing them over to fight for Russia in Ukraine. The men, including eight of Zuma-Mncube’s relatives, signed contracts in Russian they didn��t understand. Charges include people trafficking, fraud and aiding a foreign military. Zuma-Sambudla has filed counter-charges claiming she was deceived. The Hawks unit has opened a docket, and President Ramaphosa’s office is coordinating repatriation efforts. Zuma-Sambudla, an MP in her father’s uMkhonto weSizwe party, is also on trial for incitement over 2021 riots.

articles.title: Rebuilding ‘human-made abyss’ in Gaza will cost at least $70bn, UN says
articles.trailText: Report says Israel’s operations ‘significantly undermined every pillar of survival’ and reduced the economy by 87%
articles.summary: UNCTAD warns Israel’s Gaza offensive created a “human-made abyss,” destroying livelihoods and slashing Gaza’s economy by 87%, leaving GDP per capita at $161. Reconstruction of infrastructure, environmental and socioeconomic systems will exceed $70bn over decades. West Bank growth also collapsed under military violence, settlement expansion and fiscal restrictions, undoing 22 years of progress as GDP fell to 2010 levels and per capita output to 2003 levels. Plummeting revenues hamper essential services and recovery, while a fragile US-mediated ceasefire holds amid ongoing hostilities, casualties and contested hostage exchanges.

articles.title: Italian man ‘dressed as dead mother in order to claim her pension’
articles.trailText: Man from Borgo Virgilio investigated for benefit fraud and hiding body since woman’s death in 2022
articles.summary: A 56-year-old man in Borgo Virgilio, Italy, is under investigation for benefit fraud and corpse concealment after allegedly hiding his mother’s body at home since her death in 2022 and impersonating her—complete with a wig, makeup, jewellery and a feigned female voice—to renew her ID and claim thousands in pension payments. Council staff grew suspicious when his appearance and wrinkles didn’t match official photos; police then discovered the body in his laundry room. The unemployed former nurse, with €53,000 annual income from her pension and properties, faces fraud charges. Similar cases occurred in Verona and Puglia in 2023.

articles.title: Four more people arrested in connection with Louvre heist
articles.trailText: French media say those held include alleged final member of four-person gang who broke into museum
articles.summary: French authorities have arrested four more suspects—two men (38, 39) and two women (31, 40) from the Paris region—in connection with the Oct. 19 theft of €88 m of crown jewels from the Louvre. Among them is the alleged fourth member of the gang charged with organised theft and criminal conspiracy. The group used a stolen truck, ladder and freight lift to smash into the Apollo gallery, stealing eight pieces including a Napoleon-era emerald-diamond necklace and pearl-diamond tiara. Prior DNA evidence led to three earlier arrests and a fifth accomplice has also been charged. An audit criticized the museum’s security, which Louvre management has accepted.

articles.title: Dan Driscoll: envoy pushing Ukraine ‘peace’ plan belies Vance influence
articles.trailText: Army secretary presented a Russian wishlist to Ukraine, highlighting differences with the administration
articles.summary: US Army secretary Daniel Driscoll, an unlikely envoy with close Yale ties to senator JD Vance, presented a 28-point peace plan in Kyiv resembling Russian demands, sparking Ukrainian resistance and European anger over perceived capitulation. His mission underscores Vance’s revived isolationist influence—alongside Susie Wiles, Stephen Miller, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner—in Trump’s foreign policy. Vance defends the framework as a realistic ceasefire respecting sovereignty, while GOP hawks like Marco Rubio publicly endorse and privately question the Kremlin-linked proposal.

articles.title: At least 127 civilians killed in Israeli strikes on Lebanon since ceasefire, UN says
articles.trailText: A year since deal agreed, UN calls for investigation into possible violations of international law by all parties
articles.summary: Since the 27 Nov 2024 ceasefire, UN has verified at least 127 civilian deaths in Israeli strikes across Lebanon, part of 330 fatalities and 945 injuries reported by Lebanon’s health ministry. Spokesperson Thameen Al-Kheetan condemned rising attacks, notably the Ain al-Hilweh refugee camp strike that killed 13 civilians, and alleged continued Israeli military presence and infrastructure damage. Israel alleges Hezbollah and Hamas breaches. The UN demands prompt, impartial investigations into all potential international humanitarian law violations, justice for victims, and unimpeded return and reconstruction for 64,000 displaced Lebanese.

articles.title: Leading lawyers condemn ‘contrived’ Bangladesh trial of former UK minister
articles.trailText: Exclusive: High-profile lawyers suggest ex-City minister Tulip Siddiq has not enjoyed basic rights during her trial in absentia
articles.summary: Leading UK lawyers, including ex-Justice Secretary Robert Buckland KC and former Attorney General Dominic Grieve, have urged Bangladesh’s High Commissioner to rectify an “artificial, contrived and unfair” in absentia trial of Labour MP Tulip Siddiq. Siddiq, former City minister and niece of ex-Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, faces life sentences over alleged land-grant abuses. Lawyers cite denial of basic fair-trial rights: no formal charges, barred legal counsel after her appointed lawyer faced house arrest and threats, and pervasive political and media interference under Bangladesh’s interim government. Siddiq denies politically motivated accusations.

articles.title: Ukraine makes significant changes to US ‘peace plan’, sources say
articles.trailText: Some of Russia’s maximalist demands have been removed from original 28-point proposal, it is understood
articles.summary: Ukraine has slashed a US-draft 28-point peace plan to 19 points, removing Russia’s maximalist demands on Donbas withdrawals, army size caps and NATO/EU vetoes. In Geneva talks led by US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Andriy Yermak, Kyiv secured Europe’s involvement and anchored territorial talks to the present frontline, leaving sensitive issues for a potential Zelenskyy-Trump meeting. EU leaders (von der Leyen, Merz, Costa) have welcomed progress but insist Russia join talks directly, while Kremlin envoy Yuri Ushakov says Moscow will rework and rejects the EU counter-proposal. Fighting continues with casualties on both sides.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: Inside the latest Lords scandal – and the future of the peers
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: What the suspension of Richard Dannatt and David Evans tell us about standards and accountability in the Lords, and the prospect of reform
articles.summary: A Guardian undercover investigation revealed that Lord Richard Dannatt and Lord Evans of Watford offered paid introductions to ministers—Dannatt for companies he had a financial stake in, Evans for a commercial deal worth tens of thousands—breaching the Lords’ code in four instances each and earning four- and five-month suspensions. Led by Rachel Oldroyd with reporters Henry Dyer and Rob Evans, the probe used register-of-interest analysis and FOI requests to flag 90 potential conflicts among peers, sparking six disciplinary inquiries and intensifying calls for Lords reform under the Labour government.

articles.title: Former Greek PM Tsipras savages ‘celebrity’ ex-finance minister Varoufakis in memoir
articles.trailText: Alexis Tsipras says that during debt crisis Yanis Varoufakis was more interested in promoting his books
articles.summary: In his memoir Ithaki, Alexis Tsipras condemns former finance minister Yanis Varoufakis as an egotistical 'celebrity' fixated on personal fame and game-theory experiments rather than forging a rescue deal during Greece’s 2015 debt standoff. Tsipras describes underestimating Varoufakis’s combative, publicity-driven style, which alienated EU allies, spurred hawks like Wolfgang Schäuble toward Grexit and jeopardised eurozone talks. He criticises Varoufakis’s parallel-currency contingency plan, recalls the failed Kremlin bond plea, the austerity referendum and insists the minister’s self-serving agenda weakened Greece’s negotiating leverage. Tsipras, eyeing a political comeback, frames these events as a missed chance to challenge neoliberal austerity across Europe.

articles.title: Canada: ‘Inconvenient Indian’ author Thomas King says he is not Indigenous
articles.trailText: King has announced a genealogist working with the Tribal Alliance Against Frauds found no evidence of Cherokee ancestry in his family lineage
articles.summary: Canadian-American author Thomas King, celebrated for uncovering injustices against Indigenous peoples and appointed a Companion of the Order of Canada, has learned through research by the Tribal Alliance Against Frauds that he has no Cherokee ancestry. In a Globe and Mail essay, the 82-year-old says he’s “not an Indian at all,” will return his 2003 National Aboriginal Achievement award and denies any intent to defraud. His revelation follows a CBC investigation that similarly challenged Buffy Sainte-Marie’s Cree heritage claims.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia launches strikes on Kyiv, setting buildings ablaze
articles.trailText: Two people killed and six wounded in attack on capital hitting residential buildings and energy infrastructure. What we know on day 1,371
articles.summary: On day 1,371 of Russia’s invasion, Moscow launched early-morning strikes on Kyiv’s residential districts—Svyatoshynsky, Dniprovsky and Pechersk—killing six civilians, wounding six and crippling power and water supplies, igniting high-rise fires. Emergency crews rescued 18 people, including children. Kyiv struck back at Taganrog, killing one and damaging infrastructure. Ukraine revised a US peace plan to drop Russian maximalist demands and seeks EU involvement; President Zelenskyy may meet Trump in Washington. A Ukrainian drone hit a Moscow-region plant and a Vilnius court jailed a Ukrainian over a 2024 Ikea arson.

articles.title: China’s Xi Jinping raises future of Taiwan in call with Donald Trump
articles.trailText: China claims Taiwan as part of its territory and Xi told Trump that its return was an ‘integral part of the post-war international order’
articles.summary: In a Monday call, Xi told Trump Beijing’s claim to Taiwan—an “integral part of the postwar international order”—remains unchanged, despite Taipei’s elected government rejecting forced reunification. They reviewed October’s fragile US–China trade truce (China suspends certain critical-mineral export curbs; US cuts tariffs; pledges of 37 m tons of soy), discussed Ukraine peacemaking, and set reciprocal state visits. The call follows a Sino-Japanese row after Japan’s new PM signaled possible military intervention if Taiwan is attacked; Taiwan’s premier Cho Jung-tai reaffirmed 23 m citizens’ full sovereignty.

articles.title: What is the Muslim Brotherhood – explained in 30 seconds
articles.trailText: The Muslim Brotherhood one of the Arab world’s oldest and most influential Islamist movements
articles.summary: The Muslim Brotherhood, founded in Egypt in 1928 by schoolteacher Hassan al-Banna, is a pan-Islamist movement aimed at reviving Islamic principles to counter Western colonialism and secular nationalism. It expanded across the Arab world, often underground, and has been banned as a terrorist group in Egypt (since 2013), Saudi Arabia and Jordan (April 2025), despite maintained local support. After electing Mohamed Morsi president in 2012 and his 2013 ouster by Abdel Fattah al-Sisi, it drew US and French scrutiny: Macron in May 2025 ordered plans to curb its influence in France; in November, President Trump moved to designate its chapters as terrorist entities.

articles.title: Nauru president floats returning NZYQ refugees to home countries
articles.trailText: In newly translated excerpts of a February interview, David Adeang wrongly stated the people Australia has begun deporting to his country are not refugees
articles.summary: Nauru may return NZYQ refugees to their origin countries, president David Adeang said in a newly translated February interview, erroneously claiming they’re not refugees. Australia has recognised some NZYQ claims but has kept its official translation secret. At least five men are held in Nauru under a 30-year, A$2.5bn deal. Critics warn forced removal breaches non-refoulement via illegal “chain refoulement,” decrying the programme’s opacity and risk to detainee safety.

articles.title: Grizzly bear that attacked children and teachers in Canada still eludes searchers
articles.trailText: Eleven people were injured as three teachers fought the bear during attack on walking trail in British Columbia
articles.summary: Conservation officers in British Columbia continue hunting a female grizzly and her two cubs four days after an “exceedingly rare” attack on a school group near Bella Coola’s Nuxalk community at 4 Mile. Eleven people, including children as young as nine, were injured—three critically—when the sow emerged from the forest mid-lunch. Three teachers repelled it with spray, blows and crutches. Authorities warn the rocky, forested terrain and imminent hibernation complicate tracking. Residents blame habitat loss and climate change for rising bear encounters, while debates flare over hunting bans versus Indigenous stewardship models.

articles.title: US and Israel-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation to end operations in territory
articles.trailText: Four main food distribution sites operated by the opaque company had been flashpoints of deadly violence
articles.summary: The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), a US- and Israel-backed private aid company that ran four opaque food distribution sites in Israeli-controlled Gaza, has permanently ceased operations after claiming to “successfully complete its emergency mission,” having delivered over 187m meals since March’s blockade. Its sites, boycotted by international agencies and criticized by a UN expert panel for alleged covert agendas, saw clashes in which Israeli forces guarding queues killed or injured over 1,000 Palestinians. GHF says it will transfer efforts to the US-backed Civil-Military Coordination Center; Hamas demands accountability for civilian harms.

articles.title: Court ruling to remove children of UK-Australian couple living in woods divides Italy
articles.trailText: Decision to remove children comes after they and their parents ate poisonous mushrooms and ended up in hospital
articles.summary: An Italian juvenile court in L’Aquila has ordered removal of Utopia Rose, eight, and six‐year‐old twins Galorian and Bluebell from their UK-Australian parents, former chef Nathan Trevallion and ex-horse instructor Catherine Birmingham, who have lived off-grid in Abruzzo woods since 2021. Triggered by the family’s hospitalization after eating poisonous mushrooms and a social services report citing dilapidated housing without toilets, electricity or formal schooling, the ruling deemed the conditions harmful. A petition of thousands backs the family, Prime Minister Meloni and Deputy PM Salvini decry it as kidnapping, and an appeal is pending.

articles.title: Disarray over leaked US-Russia peace plan is ideal scenario for Putin
articles.trailText: Ukraine has been cornered into weighing terms it cannot accept and faces threat of losing its most important ally
articles.summary: The leaked 28-point US-Russia peace proposal drafted by Steve Witkoff and Kirill Dmitriev has thrown Washington, Kyiv and EU capitals into turmoil, creating a negotiation table skewed towards Putin. Trump has embraced the plan, accusing Ukraine of obstructing peace and threatening to halt US support. Moscow stayed silent before Putin endorsed it as a negotiation basis. The US demands Kyiv’s approval before final talks, risking domestic upheaval. Analysts warn Putin will insist on further concessions amid vague terms on neutrality and NATO, while Ukraine’s 19-point counterproposal is likely to be rejected, prolonging the stalemate.

articles.title: Venezuela accuses US of using ‘narco-terrorism’ allegations to justify ‘regime change’
articles.trailText: Venezuelan group known as Cartel of the Suns designated as terrorist organization despite doubts over its existence
articles.summary: Venezuela’s government denounces Washington’s formal designation of the ‘Cartel de los Soles’ as a terrorist organization—a group whose very existence is widely doubted—as ‘ridiculous hogwash’ and a pretext for US-led regime change. Since August, the US has deployed naval assets off Venezuela, struck alleged narco-trafficking vessels, and threatened further military intervention. Left-wing European figures warn of looming bloodshed, prompting France, the Netherlands, and the UK to restrict intelligence sharing. Major carriers like TAP, Iberia, Avianca and Gol have suspended Caracas routes amid FAA warnings of heightened military activity.

articles.title: UK wildfires devastated more areas in 2025 than at any time since records began, figures show
articles.trailText: Firefighters call for long-term investment and say UK is dangerously underprepared as climate crisis worsens
articles.summary: In 2025 the UK saw 47,026 ha scorched by wildfires—more than double 2022’s high and the largest area burned since 2012. The Fire Brigades Union, backed by Greenpeace, Tax Justice UK and Friends of the Earth, warns that a 30% real-terms funding cut since 2010 and loss of 12,000 firefighter posts have left services under-resourced and ill-equipped, as demonstrated at Dorset’s Holt Heath and Langdale Moor where mutual aid and makeshift crews struggled without specialist PPE. They urge substantial, sustained investment in staffing, equipment and strategic leadership to meet escalating wildfire and flood risks driven by climate change.

articles.title: Relatives of disappeared brace themselves as bodies are exhumed from notorious mass grave in Colombia
articles.trailText: Medellín’s Comuna 13 neighbourhood saw extraordinary violence in the 2000s, with hundreds of people detained, tortured or killed
articles.summary: Since 2002’s Operation Orión in Medellín’s Comuna 13—hailed as a victory over guerrillas but marred by army-paramilitary collusion—hundreds were detained, tortured or disappeared. Families like Teresa Gómez’s have spent two decades fighting to find her son Hermey Mejía’s remains. Excavations at La Escombrera, a notorious mass grave estimated to hold 400–600 victims, resumed under the Special Jurisdiction for Peace in late 2024. So far 56,000 m³ of rubble have been removed and seven bodies uncovered (four identified). Backed by satellite imagery and former combatant testimony, this massive forensic effort offers crucial hope for closure amid Colombia’s 120,000 unresolved disappearances.

articles.title: Questions for UK embassy in Tel Aviv over employee who owns home in illegal settlement
articles.trailText: Embassy’s employment of Gila Ben-Yakov Phillips is potentially violation of UK sanctions law, say experts
articles.summary: Gila Ben-Yakov Phillips, the British embassy’s deputy head of corporate services in Tel Aviv, purchased and declared a home in Kerem Reim—an Amana-built West Bank settlement sanctioned by the UK in 2024 for funding and incitement of violence. Experts say any economic link, however nominal, breaches UK sanctions law (which has no de minimis exception) and violates personnel security vetting rules for foreign embassy staff. They warn the embassy could indirectly fund the settlement through her salary, exposing it to legal and reputational risks amid international court rulings deeming Israel’s occupation illegal. The Foreign Office refused to comment.

articles.title: Monday briefing: What a new Guardian investigation reveals about a group ‘radicalising’ women into unassisted birth
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: A report dives into the disturbing story of a ‘wild’ pregnancy and freebirth business that ‘radicalises’ women, with tragic consequences
articles.summary: The Guardian’s year-long probe uncovers how the Free Birth Society, led by former doulas Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark, built a multimillion-dollar unassisted birth empire. Using social media, podcasts and paid online courses, FBS vilifies medical care, downplays risks and promises “euphoric” births without professionals. Investigators linked the group to at least 48 stillbirths, neonatal deaths or serious injuries across North America, Europe, Asia, Africa and Australia, exposing how new mothers are “radicalised” into rejecting doctors and midwives, often with tragic outcomes.

articles.title: ‘Stone-cold killers’: New Zealand to eradicate feral cats by 2050
articles.trailText: Feral cats are already caught and killed in some areas but will now be subject to coordinated targeting, with large-scale eradication programs
articles.summary: New Zealand’s conservation minister Tama Potaka has added feral cats to the Predator-Free 2050 strategy, committing to eliminate over 2.5 million feral cats by 2050 and deter biodiversity loss caused by these “stone-cold killers” that threaten species such as the Southern dotterel and bats. While ferrets, stoats, weasels, rats and possums are already targeted through coordinated eradication programs, detailed plans for cat removal will be unveiled in March 2026. Past campaigns sparked fierce activism—90% of public feedback now supports stronger cat control—driving calls from the SPCA and National Cat Management Group for humane methods plus national legislation mandating microchipping and desexing of domestic cats to protect native wildlife.

articles.title: Japan PM fails to achieve breakthrough in row with China – but polling shows public backs her
articles.trailText: Sanae Takaichi gets no meeting with Chinese premier Li Qiang at the G20 in Johannesburg after her comments about Taiwan sent tensions soaring
articles.summary: At the G20 in Johannesburg, Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi failed to meet Chinese premier Li Qiang amid fallout from her remark that Japan could militarily defend Taiwan. Relations remained frosty, with Beijing imposing travel warnings on Japan and banning imports of seafood and cultural exchanges. Takaichi called for renewed dialogue but refused to retract her 'collective self-defence' stance. China lodged a UN protest, warning of force to protect Taiwan. However, a Kyodo poll shows her approval at 69.9%, with 49% backing Japan’s right to joint defense over Taiwan. Analysts warn Beijing could escalate by restricting rare-earth exports or stepping up patrols around the disputed Senkaku/Diaoyu islands.

articles.title: Can Iran reinvent itself? A fragile charm offensive meets mounting internal strain
articles.trailText: In the wake of US strikes Tehran is exploring a softer diplomacy – even as its leaders fear further conflict and crackdowns intensify at home
articles.summary: After Trump’s June bombing and Israel’s fatal strikes on Hamas negotiators destabilized the region, Iran is exploring a modest soft-power push: hosting an international law forum, painting the US as the rule-breaker and offering lasting trust to Gulf neighbours. GCC states, shaken by Israeli aggression, show cautious interest. Yet Tehran retains hard-power priorities—enhancing air defenses, missile arsenals and shielding nuclear sites—and wrestles with a nuclear bomb debate. Domestically, soaring inflation, mass arrests (21,000 detained), record executions and strict social controls constrain its charm offensive amid deep political rifts.

articles.title: A united Ireland referendum must not be ‘another Brexit’, analysts say
articles.trailText: Two leading journalists from both sides of the border warn against another ‘vague, thumbs up-thumbs down’ vote
articles.summary: Two leading journalists, Fintan O’Toole and Sam McBride, warn that a future Northern Ireland referendum on unification risks echoing Brexit’s hasty, polarising vote without clear consequences. In their book For and Against a United Ireland (Arins), they argue Ireland and UK governments lack preparation and meaningful debate over constitutional models, economic impacts, identity and cohesion. They marshal arguments on flags, taxes, health services, pensions, debt and loyalist violence, urging detailed proposals and Westminster engagement to avoid a sudden, divisive “thumbs up–thumbs down” plebiscite.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian drones kill four in Kharkiv as officials discuss proposal to end war
articles.trailText: Seventeen wounded in ‘massive strike’; US-Ukraine statement announces ‘refined peace framework’. What we know on day 1,370
articles.summary: On day 1,370 of Russia’s invasion, a Russian drone strike on Kharkiv killed four civilians and wounded 17, igniting fires that damaged residential and infrastructure buildings, officials said. The attack coincided with US, Ukrainian and EU envoys meeting in Geneva to refine a US peace proposal seen as too Moscow-friendly by some allies. Talks yielded an updated peace framework preserving Ukraine’s sovereignty; Europeans suggest capping Ukraine’s forces at 800,000 rather than the US’s 600,000 limit. President Zelenskiy thanked the US, including former President Trump, amid wavering US support.

articles.title: US and Ukraine promise ‘updated’ peace framework after criticism of pro-Russian points in original plan
articles.trailText: US-Ukraine statement comes hours after European countries propose their own alternative peace
articles.summary: US and Ukraine announce an updated peace framework hours after European states unveil their own Kyiv-friendly proposal omitting pro-Russia terms from a leaked US-backed 28-point plan. In Geneva, Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Andriy Yermak hailed progress and affirmed Ukraine’s sovereignty. The original draft had demanded territorial concessions, army size caps and immunity for Russian war crimes. Europe’s alternative defers border talks until a ceasefire, starts from current lines, keeps NATO membership on the table, proposes IAEA oversight of Zaporizhzhia, a larger peacetime army and uses frozen assets for reconstruction with phased sanctions relief. Authorship of the US draft is disputed amid Russian influence claims, while diplomatic optimism grows against a backdrop of a deadly drone attack on Kharkiv.

articles.title: Hezbollah chief of staff killed in Beirut airstrike, Israeli military says
articles.trailText: Militant group confirms Haytham Ali Tabatabai was killed in attack that dramatically escalates tensions in the region
articles.summary: On Nov. 23 Israel struck Hezbollah’s southern Beirut stronghold in Haret Hreik, killing chief of staff Haytham Ali Tabatabai and at least five others, wounding 28. Three missiles hit the compound in a bid to thwart Hezbollah’s rearmament north of the border. PM Netanyahu vowed to fight “terrorism” on all fronts and uphold the ceasefire, while Lebanon’s president called for global intervention. Tabatabai, 58, sanctioned by the US for leading special forces in Syria and Yemen, was central to Hezbollah’s training efforts. Washington learned of the strike only after it occurred, according to US officials.

articles.title: Jair Bolsonaro claims ‘psychotic attack’ made him tamper with ankle monitor
articles.trailText: Brazil’s former president says he took a soldering iron to electronic tag as he was hallucinating that it was bugged
articles.summary: Brazil’s ex-president Jair Bolsonaro told a custody hearing he tampered with his court-ordered ankle monitor with a soldering iron after a medication-induced “psychotic attack” made him hallucinate it was bugged. Arrested at his Brasília home for suspected flight risk ahead of a 27-year jail term for a failed coup, Bolsonaro denied plotting escape despite prior refuge in the Hungarian embassy. Officials detected the damaged tag late Friday, prompting Saturday’s arrest. Critics noted he earlier claimed curiosity as motivation in video footage. Internationally, Trump’s backing has faded and Washington offered only muted protest.

articles.title: Cyril Ramaphosa closes G20 summit after US boycott and handover row
articles.trailText: South African president bangs gavel after rejecting plan from US, which hosts next meeting, for him to hand over to junior official
articles.summary: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa banged the gavel to close the two-day G20 summit in Johannesburg after rejecting a US proposal that a junior embassy official rather than the head of state should formally transfer the G20 presidency ahead of next year’s Florida meeting. Marred by a US boycott over discredited Afrikaner discrimination claims, the summit adopted a declaration on climate action, gender equality and global peace. Washington accused Pretoria of breaching protocol, while South Africa insists the handover now lies with the US. Key leaders—Putin, Xi and Sheinbaum—also skipped the gathering.

articles.title: ‘Stranded’: Palestinians who were in Israel on 7 October 2023 are suspended between exile and war
articles.trailText: Unable to reunite with their families in Gaza due to the closed border, Palestinian workers have spent two years in a refugee camp at Nablus stadium
articles.summary: Since Hamas’s 7 October 2023 attack, roughly 4,400 Palestinian workers and patients from Gaza remain stranded in the West Bank, including about 50 men and women living in converted Nablus municipal stadium locker rooms. Most were construction labourers swept from Israel in post-attack raids, now cut off from families under Gaza’s sealed borders. They endure stifling summer heat, sporadic PA stipends of 700 shekels every few months—half lost to fees—and constant 24/7 news streams. Watching bombardment unfold on television, they mourn killed relatives and debate giving up on return amid Gaza’s ruins or clinging to truce hopes.

articles.title: French winemakers ‘battle for survival’ as minister prepares for crisis talks
articles.trailText: Vineyard owners say sales slump, Trump tariffs and worst harvest in 70 years have put producers in danger of closure
articles.summary: Facing worst harvests in 70 years, Donald Trump’s 15% US tariffs, China’s 32.2% duties and Ukraine war–fueled cost hikes, French winemakers warn that up to a fifth of producers risk closure. Bordeaux exports to China have halved since 2017. Ahead of Monday’s crisis talks with Agriculture Minister Annie Genevard, thousands protested in Béziers for a rescue package. They seek compensation for hail- and drought-hit harvests, removal of 35,000 ha more vines (27,000 ha already uprooted at €4,000/ha), access to EU crisis reserves and funds to distill unsold wine into biofuel. The €92 bn sector could lose 100,000 jobs.

articles.title: Gaza hospitals running out of supplies as Israeli airstrikes continue, medics say
articles.trailText: ‘Severe lack’ in territory where Israeli strikes have killed more than 50 people and injured over 100 in recent days
articles.summary: Critically low stocks of gauze, antibiotics, thermometers and antiseptics are plaguing Gaza’s 13 still-functioning hospitals as renewed Israeli airstrikes since the US-backed October ceasefire have killed over 300 Palestinians and injured hundreds more. Medics warn of daily crises amid staff and ambulance shortages, malnutrition and disease outbreaks. Despite hundreds of tonnes of aid delivered by NGOs and WHO, supplies remain insufficient, with two MedGlobal lorries stuck at Israel’s crossings. The fragile ceasefire is strained by continued Israeli operations against alleged Hamas militants while aid flows struggle under security constraints.

articles.title: Safe haven to sanctions: how Jersey sheltered Roman Abramovich’s billions
articles.trailText: Court papers show the island cautiously welcomed the oligarch – with London’s approval – before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine
articles.summary: Court papers reveal how Jersey, with silent UK support, granted Roman Abramovich residency in 2017 and relocated $7bn of his assets in 2017 and 2021 under its ultra-high-net-worth scheme. London passed seven background checks and raised no objections despite Crimea and Salisbury incidents. Following Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Jersey froze his £5.3bn holdings and launched money-laundering and sanctions probes. Abramovich’s appeals, including asset-freeze challenges and judicial reviews, failed through Jersey courts and the Privy Council. He denies corruption and alleges political entrapment; investigations remain live.

articles.title: Five key findings from our investigation into the Free Birth Society
articles.trailText: Year-long investigation into multimillion-dollar business exposed serious concerns, from dangerous medical claims to FBS-linked stillbirths
articles.summary: Guardian’s year-long investigation into the North Carolina-based Free Birth Society (FBS), led by influencers Emilee Saldaya and Yolande Norris-Clark, exposed dangerous, medically unsupported freebirthing claims—from zero‐risk cord‐cutting and flawed shoulder dystocia protocols to passive newborn resuscitation—linked to 48 global cases of stillbirths, neonatal deaths and brain injuries. Saldaya directly coached laboring mothers, including the Holliday stillbirth and strokes for Bordeaux. FBS has generated $13m via paid memberships and expensive online “midwifery” courses, exploiting maternity‐care distrust. Despite expert criticism and a modest rebrand and disclaimer, its founders remain defiant, dismissing detractors as “pathetic losers.”

articles.title: ‘Ignorant and life-threatening’: experts condemn Free Birth Society misinformation
articles.trailText: Professionals say claims about birth, including excessive bleeding, blue babies and placenta care, are dangerous
articles.summary: The Free Birth Society, led by two untrained ex-doulas-turned-influencers, markets unsupervised home births via podcasts, social media and online schools. The Guardian links their advice—rejecting germ theory, endorsing cord cutting with rusty forks, non-professional placenta removal, delaying or refusing neonatal resuscitation, banning antibiotics, advocating births outside 38–42 weeks, and recommending postpartum “hormone sucking”—to infant fatalities and serious maternal harm. Leading midwives, obstetricians and nursing professors warn these claims risk sepsis, hemorrhage, asphyxia, neurological damage and death, calling the misinformation “ignorant and life-threatening.”

articles.title: Trump says Ukraine deal is not ‘final offer’ as officials gather for Geneva summit
articles.trailText: US president signals potential room for adjustments after Zelenskyy says proposals force Ukraine to choose between national dignity and losing the US
articles.summary: President Trump, after Ukrainian and Western outrage likening his 28-point “peace plan” to the 1938 Munich pact, said it is “not my final offer” as US, Ukrainian, French, British and German officials convene in Geneva. The proposal gives Kyiv until Thursday to cede territory, demobilise its army, abandon long-range weapons, bar EU/NATO membership and waive war-crimes sanctions. Kyiv’s Zelenskyy appointed a negotiating team, insisting real peace requires security guarantees and justice. G20 and EU leaders have rejected key terms, warning against appeasing Russia.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Macron says without deterrence in Ukraine plan, ‘Russians will come back’
articles.trailText: French president among European leaders pushing back against US proposal to end the war; Trump says deal is not his ‘final offer’. What we know on day 1,369
articles.summary: Macron warns that without credible deterrence Russia will break any peace deal and return if Ukraine trims its army, joining European leaders at the G20 in rejecting Trump’s one-sided proposal. The US draft plan—urging Kyiv to cede territory, limit its military and forgo NATO bids in exchange for some Russian withdrawals—will be negotiated in Switzerland and Geneva. Zelenskiy forms a team demanding security guarantees and justice. Nordic and Baltic states reaffirm support for Ukraine’s sovereignty. Fighting persists: Russia’s advance on Pokrovsk fails, while a Ukrainian drone strike in Russia’s Samara region kills two.

articles.title: Western leaders at G20 say US peace plan for Ukraine ‘will require work’
articles.trailText: European leaders say Washington’s proposal needs major changes, as Macron warns G20 risks losing relevance
articles.summary: At the G20 summit in Johannesburg Western leaders—including the UK, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, the Netherlands, Ireland, Finland, Norway, the EU, Canada and Japan—said Washington’s leaked 28-point peace proposal for Ukraine, which concedes demands such as ceding parts of the Donbas, capping Ukraine’s military and forgoing NATO membership, ‘requires additional work’. They stressed borders must not change by force and any EU/NATO clauses need their consent. UK PM Keir Starmer and US, Ukrainian and European advisers will convene in Switzerland for detailed talks. Emmanuel Macron warned the G20 risks losing relevance amid continued global crises.

articles.title: Jair Bolsonaro arrested after tampering with ankle tag ‘out of curiosity’
articles.trailText: Brazilian ex-president says he used soldering iron on device and is now in custody over fears he was going to abscond
articles.summary: Brazil’s former right-wing president Jair Bolsonaro, under house arrest since August and recently sentenced to 27 years for masterminding a coup, was arrested in Brasília after tampering with his ankle monitor 'out of curiosity' with a soldering iron. Supreme Court justice Alexandre de Moraes issued a preventive warrant amid fears Bolsonaro would abscond to a foreign embassy during a son-called 'vigil'. Held in federal custody, his detention drew cheers from Lula’s supporters and denunciations of political persecution by his allies.

articles.title: ‘The French people want to save us’: help pours in for glassmaker Duralex
articles.trailText: The brand, which evokes nostalgia and pride, hit its €5m fundraising target within hours and orders have soared
articles.summary: Duralex, maker of the iconic Picardie tumbler, raised its €5m emergency fundraising target in 5h40m and amassed €19m within 48h as French nostalgia fueled a surge in orders. Converted into a staff cooperative 18 months ago, 180 of 243 employees are now associates. The Loire-banked factory preserves a 1945 high-temperature glass-forming process. Retail investors bought up to €1,000 in 7-year, 8% bonds with no voting rights. Funds will modernise production, relieve energy costs and underwrite RF-branded sets, UK pint glasses and US expansion, targeting breakeven by 2027.

articles.title: US tells Nato if Zelenskyy does not sign peace deal Ukraine will face worse in future
articles.trailText: US army secretary briefs ambassadors at ‘nightmare meeting’ in Kyiv on Friday after talks with Ukrainian leader
articles.summary: US army secretary Dan Driscoll warned NATO ambassadors in Kyiv that unless President Volodymyr Zelenskyy accepts a US-proposed peace deal within days, Ukraine will face harsher terms later. Ambassadors, blindsided by the US-Russia draft negotiated without ally input, described a tense meeting and criticized provisions requiring Ukraine to cede occupied and additional territory and grant war-crimes amnesty. Donald Trump, pursuing agreement by Thanksgiving, says his plan isn’t final but urges an end to fighting. Zelenskyy calls this Ukraine’s toughest moment—between dignity and losing its main backer. Drafted by Trump aide Steve Witkoff and Kremlin adviser Kirill Dmitriev, Putin sees it as a peace basis. Driscoll will travel to Russia.

articles.title: Greek secondary school teachers to be trained in using AI in classroom
articles.trailText: Some teachers and pupils voice concerns about pilot programme after government’s agreement with OpenAI
articles.summary: Under a centre-right government agreement with OpenAI, 20 secondary school teachers in Greece will pilot a customised ChatGPT Edu programme this week, before a nationwide rollout in January. Workshops focus on AI-assisted lesson planning, research and personalised tuition; monitored student access begins next spring. Athens, aiming to host one of Europe’s first AI ‘factories’, follows Estonia in pioneering generative AI in education. While Education Minister Sofia Zacharaki calls AI inevitable and OpenAI pledges safe-use oversight, teachers’ union Olme and retired headteachers warn of screen addiction, underfunding (just 5% of budget) and erosion of critical thinking, as students protest loss of autonomy.

articles.title: Tense calm in far north as Israel prepares to ‘finish the job’ against Hezbollah
articles.trailText: On the border with Lebanon, communities have started to return and rebuild – even though some are in no hurry to return
articles.summary: On Israel’s northern frontier, communities from Manara to Metula and Kiryat Shmona are returning to rebuild homes and businesses battered by last year’s war with Hezbollah, even as a bipartisan consensus grows in Jerusalem for a fresh offensive "to finish the job". Local leaders like brewer Noam Erlich and Metula mayor David Azoulay tout economic revitalisation amid $8.5bn in damage and 1.2m displaced, but population levels remain below pre-war figures. Israeli forces have fortified the border with barriers and hilltop bases inside Lebanon, while Hezbollah maintains ceasefire compliance. Sporadic airstrikes hint at renewed hostilities over the "blue line".

articles.title: New Caledonia activist says France is impeding travel home after prison release
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Kanak leader Christian Tein, who was freed from prison in June, says France is ‘deliberately dragging out’ re-issue of his passport
articles.summary: Indigenous Kanak leader Christian Tein, arrested in June 2024 for allegedly instigating deadly pro-independence protests in New Caledonia, was flown to France and held in solitary until June 2025 when a Paris appeals court dropped most charges. Despite his clearance, French authorities have stalled re-issuing his passport, blocking his return. Tein, still under investigation for conspiracy and organised robbery, decries a deliberate restriction on his freedom of movement. Elected president of the Kanak National and Socialist Liberation Front in prison, he seeks to rejoin talks on his territory’s future sovereignty.

articles.title: ‘They decided to kill us with cold’: Ukrainians struggle against Russian assault on power network
articles.trailText: Chernihiv residents say they are without power for 14 hours a day as they gather in ‘invincibility points’ to charge up and warm up
articles.summary: Russia’s drone campaign aims to plunge Ukraine into darkness by targeting thermal power stations, substations and repair workers. In Chernihiv oblast, blackouts of up to 14 hours daily force residents to rely on head torches, wood stoves and “invincibility” tents with generators, Starlink and coffee. Destroyed substations and blown-up transformers have cancelled hospital operations and cut water above the fourth floor. Outrage over energy shortages merges with a corruption scandal at state nuclear agency Energoatom as Chernihivoblenergo technicians execute improvised repairs. Yet locals—from pensioners to families—profess unity, resilience and hope despite winter’s lethal toll.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: defeating Russia an ‘illusion’, says Putin, as he welcomes Trump deal
articles.trailText: Russia’s president says US-led plan ‘could form the basis of a final peace settlement’, bolstering concerns in Europe about one-sided nature of US-brokered deal. What we know on day 1,368
articles.summary: Ukraine war briefing: Putin dubs hope of defeating Russia “illusion”, endorses the US-backed 28-point plan as a “basis for peace”. He accuses Kyiv and its European allies of dreaming of strategic victory, while Zelenskyy warns acceptance would cost Ukraine its freedom and dignity. Trump demands Kyiv sign by Thursday; Vice-President Vance insists Ukrainian sovereignty be preserved. Berlin, Paris and London reaffirm full support, vetoing forced concessions. Keir Starmer and EU chiefs pledge to refine the deal at the G20. EU’s Kaja Kallas stresses terms must respect Ukraine’s red lines. Poland flags North Korea’s role.

articles.title: Survivor of Chilean blizzard that killed Briton says staff told trekkers they could proceed
articles.trailText: Tom Player speaks out about incident in which Victoria Bond died along with two Mexicans and two Germans
articles.summary: Tom Player, a London composer and blizzard survivor, says camp staff in Torres del Paine assured trekkers the weather was 'normal' despite forecasts warning of 100+ km/h winds. Nine hikers went missing on Nov 16 amid 120 mph gusts; four were rescued, five (including Briton Victoria Bond, two Mexicans and two Germans) died. No park rangers were on duty due to mandatory voting in Chile’s presidential election. Player disputes authorities’ claims hikers got lost, criticizes lack of emergency planning as his group—including ER doctors, a helicopter paramedic and a psychologist—led volunteer rescues using improvised gear.

articles.title: Mind-altering ‘brain weapons’ no longer only science fiction, say researchers
articles.trailText: UK academics say latest chemicals are ‘wake-up call’ and urge global action to stop weaponisation of neuroscience
articles.summary: British researchers Michael Crowley and Malcolm Dando warn in a forthcoming Royal Society of Chemistry book that the human mind is a “new battlefield”: advances in neuroscience, pharmacology and AI now enable sophisticated, targeted CNS-acting “brain weapons” to manipulate consciousness, memory, behaviour or coerce individuals. They trace state programs from Cold War experiments to Russia’s 2002 Moscow theatre siege using fentanyl derivatives, causing mass casualties. At November’s Hague CSP meeting, they call for proactive, holistic arms-control measures—new working groups, clearer definitions, monitoring and training—to prevent misuse while preserving scientific progress. They frame it as a “wake-up call” to safeguard the sanctity of the human mind.

articles.title: The sailor reviving the lost art of canoe building in New Caledonia
articles.trailText: Dozens of traditional boats made as part of a project to reconnect with culture and ‘start of conversation’ on ocean rights
articles.summary: Activist and sailor Aile Tikoure has led the Kenu Waan project since 2016 to revive lost Kanak canoe-building on New Caledonia’s Lifou Island, uniting clans and training youth in carving double-hulled boats. Dozens of canoes blending Polynesian hulls with Melanesian rigging have been launched, restoring maritime heritage erased by colonisation. Tikoure, now teaching navigation at the University of New Caledonia, met President Macron in 2024 to call for co-governed marine policies that recognise Indigenous ocean rights and environmental stewardship.

articles.title: Nigeria reels after 215 children taken in second mass school abduction in a week
articles.trailText: Twelve teachers also kidnapped from Catholic school amid threats from Trump to intervene over ‘Christian genocide’
articles.summary: Unknown gunmen abducted 215 pupils and 12 teachers from St Mary’s Catholic school in Papiri, Niger state, marking Nigeria’s second mass school kidnapping in a week amid threats by former US president Donald Trump to militarily intervene over alleged “Christian genocide,” a claim denied by Abuja. Security forces deployed after the early-hours raid; some children escaped. The incident follows a May 2021 abduction of 135 seminary students, Monday’s capture of 25 Kebbi state girls and a church abduction in Kwara. No group has claimed responsibility; analysts blame armed gangs—often ex-herders—seeking ransoms. President Tinubu ordered senior officials to coordinate rescue efforts as diplomatic tensions with Washington escalate.

articles.title: Zelenskyy says Ukraine has impossible choice as Trump pushes plan to end war
articles.trailText: US president demands that Kyiv accepts plan that would mean giving up territory to Russia
articles.summary: Ukraine President Zelenskyy warns of a historic crossroads as Trump demands Kyiv sign a 28-point US-Russia peace plan by Thanksgiving that would cede Donbas territories, shrink Ukraine’s army, bar NATO membership and long-range weapons. He rejects sacrificing sovereignty under threat of US intelligence and aid cuts, calling terms “capitulation.” European leaders Macron, Merz and Starmer back Ukraine’s red lines on current frontlines, EU’s Kaja Kallas warns conceding to invasion sets a dangerous precedent, while Trump presses an “aggressive timeline.” Negotiations continue with US advisers and VP Vance.

articles.title: Eleven injured after grizzly bear attacks schoolchildren and teachers in Canada
articles.trailText: Two critically hurt after attack on walking trail in British Columbia as police and conservation officers search for bear
articles.summary: In Bella Coola, BC, a grizzly bear emerged from the forest and attacked a group of fourth- and fifth-grade students and teachers eating lunch on a walking trail, injuring 11 people—three children and an adult hospitalized, two critically. Teachers, hailed as heroes, intervened with bear spray to protect students. Conservation officers and police are searching for the injured bear. The remote Nuxalk Nation community is on alert, with school closures, counseling and patrols in place. Grizzly attacks are rare in BC’s Great Bear Rainforest, where bears hold cultural significance and trophy hunting has been banned since 2017.

articles.title: US transportation department unveils first female-modeled crash test dummy
articles.trailText: Officials say the move is ‘long overdue’ and meant to close decades of safety gaps in vehicle crash testing
articles.summary: US Transportation Dept unveiled THOR-05F, the first US crash test dummy modeled on female anatomy, with 150+ sensors and 3× injury measurements, sampling pelvis, liver, spine, arms, brain and facial fractures, and enabling multidirectional movement. Studies show women face 73% higher serious injury risk; current Hybrid III dummy is a 1978 male design. A final rule will mandate THOR-05F in federal crash tests. Officials and senators Fischer and Duckworth say this long-overdue change will close safety gaps and improve standards under the She Drives Act.

articles.title: A translation of the Nauruan president’s remarks will stay suppressed for a decade – but secrecy in Australia’s offshore policy is nothing new
articles.trailText: From Scott Morrison’s ‘on-water matters’ to the Albanese government’s MOU with Nauru, successive governments’ attitude to legitimate scrutiny has been one of hostility
articles.summary: Australia’s secrecy in offshore policy extends to suppressing its translation of Nauruan President David Adeang’s February interview explaining a $400m pact to transfer the so-called NZYQ cohort—non-citizens with criminal histories—to Nauru. Adeang emphasized they had “served their time” in Australian prisons and would receive 30-year visas and resettlement rights.
