Canberra refuses to release its internal translation or the MOU and related PNG agreement, citing diplomatic risks. This opacity parallels decades of detention secrecy—from Howard’s imagery bans to Morrison’s “on-water matters”—underscoring government hostility to scrutiny.

articles.title: Trump may yet impose a Ukraine deal – but it threatens to be a disaster for Kyiv
articles.trailText: Ukraine could be forced into an agreement but plan as it stands seems too bizarre for Zelenskyy to sell to his public
articles.summary: Reports suggest the Trump administration has threatened to withdraw critical intelligence and military support if Ukraine doesn't sign a hastily drafted peace plan skewed toward Moscow’s demands. Zelenskyy warned of ‘losing our dignity’ while under intense pressure ahead of a dire winter power shortage and rising corruption scandals. European allies, blindsided, question the plan’s legitimacy, unknown signoffs, and efficacy of vague, fee-based US security guarantees. Provisions include Ukrainian withdrawal from held territory and blanket amnesty for Russian war criminals. Critics doubt its viability, urging any deal require solid European backing.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy to write prison memoir on his 20 days in jail
articles.trailText: Former French president complains about noise in extract from A Prisoner’s Diary, to be released next month
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, 2007–2012 French president, will publish A Prisoner’s Diary next month, chronicling his 20 days in La Santé prison as he appeals a five-year sentence for criminal conspiracy over alleged Libyan campaign funds. An extract highlights the incessant noise, solitary-confinement cell with private shower, and his internal reflections: “nothing to see, nothing to do” yet inner life fortified. He praises humane staff but calls his detention a nightmare at age 70. Before imprisonment he vowed to write, bringing a two-volume Jesus biography and The Count of Monte Cristo. His appeal and new trial are set for spring.

articles.title: Dubai bank is behind British businessman’s 30-year jail sentence, family claims
articles.trailText: Ryan Cornelius was arrested in 2008 over a bank loan and will be 84 years old when he is due to be released
articles.summary: Ryan Cornelius, a 71-year-old British entrepreneur, has been imprisoned in Dubai since 2008 over a disputed $432 m loan from Dubai Islamic Bank (DIB). Convicted of fraud in 2011 and initially given 10 years, his sentence was extended by another 20 years in 2018 at DIB’s request under anti-fraud asset-recovery laws. All his assets, including a development now valued at over $3 bn, have been seized. A UN panel judges his detention arbitrary. Some 146 UK MPs have petitioned the UAE for a royal pardon ahead of its national day.

articles.title: EU imposes sanctions on Russian prison officials responsible for death of Ukrainian journalist
articles.trailText: Viktoriia Roshchyna died aged 27 after a year in extrajudicial detention at a jail notorious for torture
articles.summary: The EU has sanctioned four senior Rostov region penitentiary officials—Andrei Polyakov, Aleksandr Shtoda, Andrei Mikhailichenko and Andrei Sapitsky—over torture and deaths, including Ukrainian journalist Viktoriia Roshchyna, who died aged 27 after more than a year in Taganrog pre-trial detention centre No 2. A Viktoriia Project probe found her hyoid bone fractured and organs missing. Sanctions freeze assets and impose travel bans on the officials; EU entities are barred from funding them. Roshchyna was posthumously awarded Ukraine’s Order of Freedom amid US pressure for a peace deal offering amnesty and sanction relief to Russia.

articles.title: TNT that Europe needs to defend itself is being used on Gaza, Polish MP claims
articles.trailText: Maciej Konieczny claims Europe’s sole supplier, in Poland, sends much of its production to US, which exports it for use by Israel
articles.summary: Polish MP Maciej Konieczny of the Razem party alleges that Nitro-Chem, Europe’s sole TNT producer, diverts roughly half of its 10–12 kt annual output to the US—under contracts through 2029 including a $310 m deal for 18 kt—where it is used in MK-84 and BLU-109 bombs supplied to Israel for Gaza. This export leaves Poland with barely a month’s TNT reserves and limits ammunition for Ukraine. The US, lacking domestic TNT and barred from Chinese imports, has approved a new Kentucky plant. Palestinian NGOs assert Polish-made TNT enabled the unprecedented Gaza bombardment; Nitro-Chem says it abides by all laws and oversight.

articles.title: South Africa’s dispute with US escalates amid row over G20 handover event
articles.trailText: Trump press secretary accuses Cyril Ramaphosa of ‘running his mouth’ after US boycott of summit in Johannesburg
articles.summary: On the eve of the Johannesburg G20, South Africa’s Cyril Ramaphosa clashed with the US over its boycott of the summit and proposal to send a junior envoy for the presidential handover to Florida’s Trump golf resort. Washington’s press secretary accused Ramaphosa of false claims, while Pretoria rejected what it sees as a diplomatic snub. Analysts warn the US stunt may backfire, damaging its global standing. SA, as the first African G20 host, is pushing on debt relief, critical minerals, just energy transition and an independent inequality monitoring body, amid nationwide femicide protests.

articles.title: Kirill Dmitriev: ‘ruthlessly ambitious’ Kremlin figure behind Ukraine plan
articles.trailText: Harvard-educated head of Russia’s wealth fund has risen to key role despite having little diplomatic experience
articles.summary: Kirill Dmitriev, Harvard-educated head of Russia’s sovereign wealth fund (RDIF), has leveraged his US ties and Trump back channels to draft a hardline Ukraine peace plan with Steve Witkoff, seeking political and economic control over Kyiv. Born in Soviet Ukraine, Dmitriev built fame in global finance, forged Kremlin links (including Putin’s daughter), and sidestepped diplomatic norms. Sanctioned since 2014, he resurfaced under Trump’s return, negotiating a high-profile U.S. schoolteacher swap and courting MAGA figures online. Ruthlessly ambitious yet diplomatically inexperienced, he clashes with Russia’s traditional foreign-policy elite while remaining indispensable to Putin.

articles.title: Colombian scientists recover first treasures from ‘holy grail of shipwrecks’
articles.trailText: Cannon, three coins and a cup taken from San José, a 1708 wreckage that could hold items worth billions of dollars
articles.summary: Colombian scientists have recovered a cannon, three coins and a porcelain cup from the 1708 Spanish galleon San José at 600 m depth off Cartagena. Discovered in 2015, the wreck—dubbed the “holy grail of shipwrecks”—is thought to contain up to 11 million coins plus emeralds and other riches worth billions. The government-authorized deep-sea expedition focuses on research, conservation and understanding the sinking rather than treasure extraction. Legal and diplomatic battles continue over salvage rights with US investors Sea Search Armada and claims from Spain. Conservation work is underway in a dedicated laboratory.

articles.title: Hundreds of English-language websites link to pro-Kremlin propaganda
articles.trailText: Thinktank says internet flooded with disinformation by Russia-aligned Pravda network, which many websites treat as credible
articles.summary: A London thinktank, ISD, found hundreds of English sites—mainstream and fringe—link to pro-Kremlin Pravda network articles, treating over 80% as credible and amplifying its narratives. The network, flagged by France last year, surged from 6,000 to 23,000 daily posts, targeting Asia, Africa and Europe. Some 40% of content covers the Ukraine war, but it also pushes US domestic policy or Elon Musk stories, aiming to seed search results and AI training data (“LLM grooming”). ISD warns this numbers-game operation risks legitimising Kremlin views.

articles.title: A lot of axolotls: the amphibian-themed banknote Mexicans don’t want to spend
articles.trailText: Nearly 13m people are hoarding millions of dollars’ worth of the stylish 50 peso note, featuring Mexico’s cutest critter
articles.summary: Since its 2021 launch featuring Gorda the axolotl, Mexico’s 50-peso note has become a collectors’ phenomenon: a Bank of Mexico survey finds 12.9 million holders hoarding roughly $150 million’ worth, with early prints trading at 100× face value. Only 12% of hoarders do this for other notes, underscoring axolotl’s cultural cachet. This neotenic salamander, long tied to Lake Texcoco and Aztec lore depicted alongside Rivera’s Tenochtitlán mural on the reverse, now survives mainly in Xochimilco. Gorda, one of six museum specimens, lent her likeness to boost awareness of a species teetering on extinction.

articles.title: Friday briefing: The end of the affair – why we’ve fallen out of love with the cinema
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Box office takings are tanking. Amid indulgent vanity products, endless sequels and the rise of streaming, how can Hollywood revive the magic?
articles.summary: Post-pandemic cinema is in crisis: North American box office plunged to 1990s lows, even horror flopped over Halloween. Studios bet on big-name ‘vanity projects’—from Dwayne Johnson’s mixed martial arts drama to Coppola’s Megalopolis—but these overhyped films bomb. Mid-range adult dramas and awards hopefuls are scarce, hampered by strikes and financing gaps. Meanwhile, streaming platforms’ two-week theatrical windows and auteur-driven releases (eg. Netflix’s Frankenstein) erode habitual cinema-going. Only fandom-fueled events (Wicked musicals), spectacle (Avatar-type epics) and communal horror still draw crowds. Reviving the magic requires rebuilding mid-budget slates and engineering must-see theatrical moments.

articles.title: Falls, feuds and fury: Miss Universe crowned after chaotic – and controversial – pageant
articles.trailText: Miss Mexico, Fatima Bosch, has been crowned the 74th Miss Universe, after accusing an organiser in Thailand of insulting her
articles.summary: Miss Mexico Fatima Bosch was crowned Miss Universe 2025 after a chaotic pageant: earlier accusing Thai director Nawat Itsaragrisil of insulting her, prompting a walkout and solidarity from fellow contestants and Mexico’s president. Two judges resigned amid alleged vote-rigging, stage mishaps included falls by Miss Jamaica and Miss Great Britain, and geopolitical tensions flared as Miss Palestine honored the Dome of the Rock while Miss Israel faced threats. Social media scandals, from snorting mimicry on TikTok to border clash accusations, swirled, but Bosch triumphed over crowd favourite Miss Thailand, framing her victory as a stand for respect and women’s rights.

articles.title: Serbian president faces legal complaint in Sarajevo ‘sniper-tourism’ case
articles.trailText: Milan allegations link Aleksandar Vučić to 1990s shootings of civilians in Bosnian capital by Italians and others
articles.summary: A Milan complaint filed by Croatian journalist Domagoj Margetić, based on evidence gathered by researcher Ezio Gavazzeni and Sarajevo’s ex-mayor, accuses President Aleksandar Vučić of involvement in 1990s ‘sniper tourism’ during Sarajevo’s siege. Prosecutors have opened a voluntary murder probe against unidentified Italians and other Western nationals who allegedly paid Bosnian Serb forces to transport them to sniper posts, killing civilians for sport. Witnesses and a 2022 documentary place Vučić at one such post. He denies any role, dismissing the claims as political manipulation.

articles.title: Ukraine banned from Nato, Russia readmitted to the G8 and territory ceded: what’s in Trump’s draft plan
articles.trailText: Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he expects to discuss the plan – which was reportedly drafted by Russian and US officials – with Trump
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s draft 28-point peace plan for Ukraine, reportedly co-drafted by US and Russian officials, would cede Crimea, Luhansk and Donetsk to Russia, freeze Kherson and Zaporizhzhia along current frontlines, demilitarise withdrawn Donbas zones and bar Ukraine from Nato membership. It calls for a reduced Ukrainian army (600,000 troops), no foreign forces on its soil, and ‘reliable security guarantees’ with European jets stationed in Poland. Russia would be readmitted to the G8, sanctions suspended unless it re-invades, and $100bn of frozen assets earmarked for Ukraine’s reconstruction. Kyiv’s cautious reception contrasts with officials’ fury, as Zelenskyy demands ‘dignified peace’ respecting sovereignty.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Buildings engulfed in flames as Russian air attack on Zaporizhzhia kills five
articles.trailText: Regional governor had issued warning of impending attack; Zelenskyy says he will negotiate with Trump over US-backed peace plan favourable to Kremlin. What we know on day 1,367
articles.summary: Russian guided-bomb strikes on Zaporizhzhia killed five and injured three, leaving buildings ablaze, the regional governor said. President Zelenskyy received a US-Russian draft peace plan urging Ukraine to cede Donbas and Crimea, abandon NATO aspirations, cap its armed forces at 600,000, and accept security guarantees while Russia rejoins the G8. He will discuss the plan with Trump despite internal objections. EU foreign-policy chief Kaja Kallas said any peace proposal must be just, lasting and developed with Ukrainian and European input. Moscow claims gains near Kupiansk and Pokrovsk, which Kyiv denies, as Britain’s NCA unveils a billion-dollar money-laundering network fueling Russia’s war.

articles.title: Zelenskyy to negotiate with Trump over US-Russia peace deal requiring painful concessions
articles.trailText: Ukrainian president’s office issues statement after other officials condemn ‘absurd’ plan to end conflict
articles.summary: Ukraine’s president Zelenskyy has agreed to negotiate with Donald Trump over a controversial 28-point US-Russian peace proposal that demands Kyiv cede Crimea and Donbas, freeze Kherson and Zaporizhzhia frontlines, limit its army to 600,000, bar NATO membership and foreign troops, in exchange for unspecified US security guarantees, basing European jets in Poland and $100 billion from frozen Russian assets. Drafted by Putin ally Kirill Dmitriev and Trump envoy Steve Witkoff without Kyiv’s input, it echoes Moscow’s 2022 terms. Ukrainian officials and MPs denounce it as a sovereignty-undermining provocation. Brussels and London—caught off-guard—stress any deal needs Ukrainian and European buy-in, while Trump pursues an “aggressive timeline” amid Zelenskyy’s domestic scandals.

articles.title: Brazilian president will take fossil fuel phase-out plan to G20 summit
articles.trailText: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva says he is ready to fight for transition roadmap despite opposition from some states
articles.summary: Brazilian president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva will take his roadmap to phase out oil, coal and gas to the G20 summit in Johannesburg, campaigning for it despite resistance from major producers. At COP30, 82 countries (7% of output) signed, but Russia, China, India, South Africa and like-minded states refused, and the proposal was dropped from draft texts. Lula faces internal splits—environment minister Marina Silva champions it, his foreign ministry seeks smaller wins—and its revival depends on funding and flexible pathways. Saudi Arabia and China show private openness, India hesitates, and a fire at Belém has further delayed negotiations.

articles.title: ‘Chaotic and indecisive’: key findings of report on UK’s Covid response under Tories
articles.trailText: Second pandemic report focuses on decision-making, organisation and messaging by senior politicians including Boris Johnson
articles.summary: Heather Hallett’s 760-page inquiry slams Tory Covid response as ‘too little too late’, exposing chaos in No 10 under Boris Johnson and Dominic Cummings’ toxic, sexist culture; slow, indecisive actions—missing a crucial 2020 ‘lost month’—cost ~23,000 lives; inconsistent lockdowns across England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland; failures to protect disabled and minority groups; mixed messaging (‘eat out to help out’, handshake campaign) eroded trust; ministers’ poor grasp of science undermined decisions; experts overworked, facing online abuse and threats; calls for earlier, harder interventions, central taskforces, scientific training and stronger advisory support.

articles.title: MI5 ‘very relaxed’ about proposed Chinese super-embassy in London, sources say
articles.trailText: Senior Security Service officers told Commons speaker in private meeting they can tackle espionage risks
articles.summary: MI5 senior officers told Commons speaker Lindsay Hoyle they are “very relaxed” about a proposed 20,000 sq m Chinese super-embassy at Royal Mint Court, advising ministers the espionage risks can be managed. Director General Ken McCallum cited MI5’s century-plus experience monitoring foreign missions. The planning decision, delayed twice, is due by December 10 amid security, traffic and optical concerns. Beijing has pressured London, blocking UK embassy renovation in retaliation. Former MI6 chiefs and IISS advisers judge the risk manageable. Separate MI5 alerts warn MPs of two China-linked LinkedIn headhunters working for the MSS.

articles.title: US in talks to attend G20 summit after initial boycott, South Africa says
articles.trailText: Cyril Ramaphosa says US has had ‘change of mind’ but does not confirm Trump’s attendance in Johannesburg
articles.summary: South African president Cyril Ramaphosa said the US has signaled a late change of mind about boycotting November’s G20 summit in Johannesburg, though Donald Trump’s attendance remains unconfirmed. Trump had accused South Africa of racial discrimination against white farmers, claims Pretoria denies. A US diplomatic note warned it will accept only a chair’s statement, accusing SA of coercion by absentia. South Africa pressed ahead, highlighting its G20 priorities—debt relief for low-income countries and a just energy transition—and championing wider multilateral inclusion.

articles.title: Blow to Spanish PM as attorney general found guilty in leak case
articles.trailText: Álvaro García Ortiz, who had denied sharing businessman’s personal details to journalists about a tax case, has been banned from post for two years
articles.summary: Spain’s Supreme Court has banned attorney general Álvaro García Ortiz for two years, fined him €7,300 and ordered €10,000 in damages after ruling he leaked confidential tax case details on businessman Alberto González Amador, partner of rightwing politician Isabel Díaz Ayuso. Ortiz, the first serving Spanish AG to face trial, denied the leak, but judges convicted him in a blow to PM Pedro Sánchez, under pressure from graft probes into his family and allies. Government respects but disputes the verdict and will appoint a successor soon. Opposition warns the conviction deepens institutional crisis.

articles.title: Ottawa officials to cull ‘mindblowing’ influx of thousands of goldfish in pond
articles.trailText: Scourge of goldfish has become growing problem as fish are released by pet owners into increasingly warm waters
articles.summary: With about 5,000 goldfish removed from Celebration Park stormwater pond earlier this year, Ottawa plans to cull another ≈1,000 feral goldfish under Ontario’s natural resources guidelines via percussive, electrical stunning or pithing. Councillor Riley Brockington called the approx. 6,000-fish population “mind-blowing.” Experts warn actual numbers, including millions of juveniles, may be far higher. Released aquarium goldfish thrive in warming waters, outcompete native species, disrupt ecosystems. Similar removals in Minnesota reached 50,000. Authorities urge pet owners not to dump fish.

articles.title: Biafran separatist leader sentenced to life on terrorism charges by Nigerian court
articles.trailText: Judge says Nnamdi Kanu used his Indigenous People of Biafra group to incite attacks on security officials and civilians
articles.summary: Nigerian court in Abuja sentenced 58-year-old Nnamdi Kanu to life in prison for using his Indigenous People of Biafra (IPOB) group to incite attacks on security forces and civilians during southeast unrest and Lagos protests. Judge Omotosho labeled him an international terrorist. Kanu, a British citizen who represented himself amid earlier bail and a 2021 extradition from Kenya, had faced treason and terrorism charges, with prosecutors seeking the death penalty. IPOB, proscribed since 2017, and its splinter BGIE have enforced violent ‘sit-at-home’ days linked to some 700 deaths post-2021. Kanu’s US lobbying and appeals to Trump underscore diaspora support.

articles.title: Nuremberg trial records made available online after painstaking 25-year project
articles.trailText: Launch of digitisation project marks 80th anniversary of start of legal effort to bring Nazi leaders to justice
articles.summary: Harvard Law School library has launched an open-access, fully digitized archive of the Nuremberg trials’ 750,000+ pages, marking the 80th anniversary. A 25-year effort by 30 historians, curators and librarians (since 1998) scanned delicate mimeographed transcripts, briefs and exhibits from 13 trials (main case of 19 senior Nazis including Göring, Hess, Speer; 12 follow-ups), preserving disintegrating records and enabling keyword or transcript-driven research. The collection reveals verbatim courtroom proceedings, Nazi planning for the Holocaust, multilingual translation layers and documentary authenticity, offering scholars and the public a detailed legal and historical resource.

articles.title: UK construction workers at risk from modern slavery, charity warns
articles.trailText: Helpline run by Unseen receives hundreds of calls a year from potential victims of exploitation
articles.summary: Unseen’s helpline logged 492 potential modern-slavery victims in UK construction in 2024—second only to care—spotlighting an emerging exploitation risk amid the government’s 1.5 million-home building drive. CCLA finds widespread non-compliance with the 2015 Modern Slavery Act, citing migrant labour, opaque subcontracting and isolated sites. Safeguarding minister Jess Phillips urged a cultural shift as the Employment Rights Bill and updated supply-chain guidance seek stronger protections, but Oxford research flags persistent data gaps. A Barbados migrant’s three-year ordeal on private sites illustrates the sector’s hidden brutality.

articles.title: Europe calls for role in Ukraine talks amid reported US-Russian peace deal
articles.trailText: Foreign ministers express misgivings about draft US-Russian peace plan favourable to Putin
articles.summary: EU foreign ministers insisted Europe and Ukraine must shape any peace talks after a leaked US-Russia draft plan would force Kyiv to cede territory and political control to Moscow. Kaja Kallas urged a just, lasting settlement; Johann Wadephul and Jean-Noël Barrot stressed Ukrainian consent and a ceasefire. Radosław Sikorski warned Europe’s security stakes. Brussels stalls on using €140bn of frozen Russian assets for Ukraine amid Belgium’s legal concerns and a Duma threat to sue. The EU doubled down on sanctions and Ursula von der Leyen flagged Ukraine’s €136bn 2026-27 funding gap.

articles.title: Brother Wang, a global manhunt and the Chinese-Mexican drug nexus
articles.trailText: Alleged trafficker Zhi Dong Zhang escaped via a tunnel in Mexico before flying to Cuba and reportedly Russia but now finds himself on trial in a Brooklyn courtroom
articles.summary: Alleged trafficker Zhi Dong Zhang, aka Brother Wang, tunneled out of house arrest in Mexico City in July and escaped via Cuba to Russia before being arrested, extradited to the US and arraigned in Brooklyn on charges of smuggling fentanyl precursors for Sinaloa and Jalisco cartels, trafficking cocaine and crystal meth, and laundering nearly $100 m through shell companies. His cultural fluency and alleged insider ties reveal corruption that facilitated his escape. Experts say his case highlights the deep integration of Chinese criminal networks and Mexican cartels and innovative cross-border money-laundering schemes.

articles.title: Spanish PM calls for nation to heed past lessons on anniversary of Franco’s death
articles.trailText: Pedro Sánchez says his country must defend the democratic freedom ‘wrenched from us for so many years’
articles.summary: On the 50th anniversary of Francisco Franco’s death, Spanish PM Pedro Sánchez avoided official commemorations but urged citizens to remember the dictatorship’s lessons and safeguard the democracy “wrenched from us” after 36–75. Citing polls showing rising authoritarian nostalgia among young Spaniards, he highlighted Spain’s transformation from repression to prosperity. His government has applied historical memory laws to rebrand Francoist sites, inventory seized assets, recover state archives from the Francisco Franco Foundation and dismantle regime symbols. The conservative PP and far-right Vox boycotted 50-year democracy celebrations, amid ongoing debates over civil-war mass graves and Spain’s post-Franco transition (1977 election, 1978 constitution).

articles.title: Israeli airstrikes kill 33 people in Gaza in escalation of post-ceasefire attacks
articles.trailText: Medical officials say 17 people killed in Khan Younis area and 16 in strikes on Gaza City
articles.summary: Since last month’s US-backed ceasefire, Israeli airstrikes on Gaza killed 33 and injured dozens on Nov 20: four strikes on displaced tents in Khan Younis killed 17 (5 women, 5 children), while two in Gaza City killed 16 (3 women, 7 children). Israel says it responded to fire on troops; Hamas denies involvement. Gaza’s health ministry reports over 300 deaths since ceasefire. Qatar and UN Security Council warn this escalation threatens peace efforts tied to Trump’s stabilisation force proposal. Residents describe ruined tents, closed crossings, and ongoing displacement.

articles.title: What do we know about the reported US-Russian plan to end the Ukraine war?
articles.trailText: Full details are not yet clear but 28-point deal is believed to include proposal for Ukraine to hand territory to Russia
articles.summary: US and Russian officials have quietly drafted a 28-point ceasefire proposal requiring Ukraine to cede the remainder of occupied eastern Donbas, halve its armed forces and long-range missile arsenal, cut or halt US aid, ban future Western troop deployments and grant Russian official language status and Orthodox Church rights. In return, Kyiv and Europe would receive vague US security guarantees. The plan—first reported by Axios, FT and NYT and linked to Kirill Dmitriev and US envoy Steve Witkoff—has not been confirmed by Washington. It clashes with Zelenskyy’s red lines, risks humiliating Ukraine and faces likely European rejection.

articles.title: Tell us: have you spotted or heard about escaped wallabies in your area?
articles.trailText: Escaped wallabies in Britain appears to be a widespread phenomenon. We would like to hear about any sightings
articles.summary: Escaped wallabies are increasingly being sighted across Britain, with confirmed clusters in the Chiltern Hills, Cornwall and Wiltshire and reports in Cumbria, Yorkshire, Northumberland, Lancashire, north Wales, Kent, Suffolk, Cambridgeshire, Norfolk, the Thames Valley, the Isle of Wight and the Isle of Man. The phenomenon shows no regional bias. Readers are asked to report sightings—including location, date, number observed, frequency and behavior—via the site’s submission form (see terms of service and privacy policy).

articles.title: Jailhouse shock: Brazil coup monger Bolsonaro finally faces life behind bars
articles.trailText: The former president’s far-right supporters have discovered a new interest in prison conditions as incarceration looms
articles.summary: Former president Jair Bolsonaro faces imminent incarceration after his 27-year sentence for plotting to “annihilate” Brazil’s democracy. House-arrested since conviction, he’ll likely be sent to Papuda maximum security or the adjacent Papudinha facility, provoking far-right allies’ outcry over his health and cell conditions. Senators visiting Papuda highlighted severe overcrowding and poor food, while Workers’ Party MPs insist on dignified prison treatment. Bolsonaro’s expected jailing marks a historic assertion of Brazil’s rule of law and deepens political polarization.

articles.title: Raiders of the lobster pot: wily wolves learn to haul in Canadian crab traps
articles.trailText: Researchers in British Columbia catch sea wolves in the act after placing camera to solve mystery of damaged traps
articles.summary: Camera traps in British Columbia’s Bella Bella region captured sea wolves diving to haul in floats attached to offshore crab traps, dragging ropes ashore and gnawing through bait cups to steal the bait. Published by Artelle and Paquet in Ecology and Evolution, the findings stem from a Heiltsuk First Nation monitoring programme targeting invasive European green crabs that threaten eelgrass beds. The coastal wolf’s efficient, focus-driven rope retrieval suggests learned tool-like behaviour shared within the pack. Coexisting unthreatened by hunting, these sea wolves exemplify heightened intelligence and expand our understanding of predator adaptation in human-shaped marine landscapes.

articles.title: Shelter and food in desperately short supply as Gaza braces for harsh winter
articles.trailText: Palestinians living in tent cities on shore of southern Gaza fear disease, cold and hunger following first storm of season
articles.summary: After the first winter storm struck Gaza’s southern al-Mawasi tent camps—home to some 500,000 internally displaced Palestinians—makeshift tarpaulin shelters collapsed under wind and rain, soaking families’ belongings. With more than two million Gazans facing their third winter since October 2023’s war, acute shortages of tents, poles, blankets, food, clean water and fuel persist amid bureaucratic and security restrictions on aid entry. Overcrowding and standing water threaten disease outbreaks as temperatures plunge, and NGOs warn relief remains grossly insufficient.

articles.title: Secret translation of Nauruan president’s interview on NZYQ deal with Australia to stay suppressed for decade
articles.trailText: Penny Wong says translation notes were ‘taken hastily’ by official who was not accredited translator and were ‘for internal purposes only’
articles.summary: Newly released documents show that a translation of Nauruan president David Adeang’s February interview on Australia’s deal to send about 350 NZYQ asylum-seekers to Nauru will remain suppressed for ten years after the Albanese government labeled its publication “inappropriate.” Nauru declined to endorse Australia’s hastily prepared, non-accredited translation, prompting foreign minister Penny Wong to cite damage to bilateral ties. Federal and high court judges upheld a suppression order in a deportee’s legal challenge to shield the confidential memorandum and transcript. The A$400m-year-one, A$2.5bn-life-span arrangement deepens secrecy around Australia’s offshore detention and coincides with a discreet Canberra visit by Adeang.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: What fresh claims of racism and antisemitism at school mean for Nigel Farage
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With the Reform leader now a serious contender for PM, we look at the impact the allegations about his behaviour as a schoolboy could have on Britain
articles.summary: The Guardian’s chief reporter, Daniel Boffey, compiled evidence from over 30 classmates at Dulwich College who allege that Nigel Farage, now Reform UK leader and serious prime ministerial contender, habitually uttered racist slurs (‘Paki’, ‘Wog’), praised Hitler Youth, marched with Nazi songs and performed the Sieg Heil salute between ages 13 and 18. Peter Ettedgui, whose grandparents escaped Nazi Germany, described Farage as a “precociously racist teenager.” Others recall only his provocateur antics. Farage’s legal team flatly denies these decades-old claims. Labour’s Keir Starmer demands an explanation as voters weigh the allegations’ impact on his credibility.

articles.title: British Jews turn to Greens and Reform UK as support for main parties drops
articles.trailText: Study finds new party divide as backing for Labour and Conservatives plunges from 84% in 2020 to 58% in 2025
articles.summary: JPR data on 11,000 British Jews shows support for Labour and Conservatives plunged from 84% in 2020 to 58% by mid-2025, marking a historic low. Greens rose from 9% to 18%, driven by younger, anti-Zionist and secular voters, while Reform UK climbed from 3% to 11%, buoyed by older, Orthodox, Zionist men. British Jews are now twice as likely as the general electorate to back Greens and half as likely to back Reform UK. Gaza war polarisation, rising antisemitism and distrust in mainstream parties are driving this political fragmentation.

articles.title: Australian living in Thailand faces trial over alleged criminal defamation of Malaysian government
articles.trailText: Murray Hunter charged with offence which carries a potential penalty of two years in jail, or a 200,000 baht (AUD$9,500) fine
articles.summary: Australian journalist and academic Murray Hunter, a long-time resident of southern Thailand, faces a December trial in Bangkok on criminal defamation charges brought by Malaysia’s MCMC. He’s accused of defaming the regulator in four April 2024 Substack posts alleging censorship and conflict of interest. Arrested at Suvarnabhumi Airport in September, he’s out on bail with his passport seized. Conviction could bring two years’ jail or a 200,000-baht fine. Thai Lawyers for Human Rights and the Foreign Correspondents’ Club call it a transnational SLAPP to muzzle critics.

articles.title: Samoa PM suspends country’s only daily newspaper from press briefings amid dispute over coverage
articles.trailText: Prime minister has accused the Samoa Observer of inaccurate reporting during his eight-week medical stay in New Zealand
articles.summary: Samoa PM La’aulialemalietoa Leuatea Polataivao Fosi Schmidt has barred the Samoa Observer, the nation’s only daily newspaper, from his weekly press conferences after accusing it of inaccurate reporting during his eight-week medical stay in New Zealand, trespassing at his private residence and publishing divisive editorials. The Observer rejected Schmidt’s claims, reaffirming its commitment to independent public-interest journalism and questioning the timing of the ban. The Samoa Alliance of Media Practitioners for Development, Pacific Freedom Forum, Journalists Association of Samoa and opposition leaders Fiame Naomi Mata’afa and Tuilaepa Aiono Sailele Malielegaoi condemned the measure as disproportionate and harmful, warning it undermines transparency, accountability and press freedom in Samoa.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Rescuers comb through rubble after Russian attack kills at least 26
articles.trailText: Nearly 100 hurt and many missing in western city of Ternopil, official says, amid reports of new US-drafted peace plan involving capitulation from Kyiv. What we know on day 1,366
articles.summary: Russian forces launched 476 drones and 48 missiles in an overnight strike on western Ukraine, tearing off upper floors of a Ternopil apartment block, killing at least 26 (including three children), injuring nearly 100 and leaving many missing. Emergency crews comb rubble amid power cuts after energy and transport infrastructure was hit in seven regions. Meanwhile, US and Russian envoys drafted a peace proposal forcing Ukraine to cede territory and halve its military, a plan Zelenskiy rejects. He traveled to Turkey for talks urging more air-defense aid. Poland denounced a rail sabotage as "state terrorism" and closed Russia’s last consulate.

articles.title: New Zealand bans puberty blockers for young transgender people
articles.trailText: Critics warn move could have devastating impact on lives and wellbeing of those affected
articles.summary: From December 19, New Zealand will ban new prescriptions of gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues—puberty blockers—for transgender or gender-diverse youth not already on treatment, citing a lack of high-quality evidence, health minister Simeon Brown said. Existing users and prescriptions for early puberty, endometriosis or prostate cancer remain unaffected. Critics—including Elizabeth McElrea of the Professional Association for Transgender Health Aotearoa—warn of worsening mental health, increased suicidality and discrimination; opposition MPs decry ‘culture wars’ and insist doctors, families and patients should decide treatment. Usage fell from 140 users in 2021 to 113 in 2023; Britain has a similar temporary ban for under-18s.

articles.title: US and Russian officials draft plan to end Ukraine war based on capitulation from Kyiv
articles.trailText: It is unclear if Trump administration backs deal that would mean Kyiv giving up territory and slashing size of military
articles.summary: US and Russian envoys including Trump’s Steve Witkoff and Kremlin adviser Kirill Dmitriev secretly drafted a 28-point peace plan urging Kyiv to cede eastern territory, halve its armed forces, curb US military aid and accept Russian oversight—terms Zelenskiy deems unacceptable. It remains unclear if the Biden administration has endorsed the proposal. Meanwhile, Russia’s intensified drone and missile strikes on Ternopil killed 25 civilians and wounded 73, as Kyiv warns of systematic winter power-grid attacks. President Zelenskiy met Turkey’s Erdoğan to rally “just peace” negotiations and pressed allies for more air-defense missiles, while US officials signal “difficult but necessary concessions” to end the war.

articles.title: US charges ex-Olympic snowboarder turned drug kingpin with murder of witness
articles.trailText: Unsealed indictment says Ryan Wedding tracked down witness who was then murdered before he could testify
articles.summary: US prosecutors unsealed charges against Ryan Wedding, 43, former Canadian Olympic snowboarder turned drug kingpin, accusing him of orchestrating the killing of Colombian witness Jonathan Acebedo-Garcia to prevent testimony in a massive cocaine-trafficking network. Dubbed “El Jefe,” Wedding allegedly moved hundreds of kilos of cocaine from Colombia through Mexico and California into Canada, generating over $1 billion annually. The indictment also names Ontario lawyer Deepak Paradkar and Montreal resident Atna Onha in the murder plot. In an international takedown, a dozen suspects were arrested, the US raised Wedding’s reward from $10 m to $15 m, and Treasury sanctions were imposed.

articles.title: Rome decries ‘Italian-sounding’ pasta sauces on sale in EU parliament store
articles.trailText: Agriculture minister calls for investigation over marketing of carbonara sauce containing wrong type of cured meat
articles.summary: Italy’s agriculture minister, Francesco Lollobrigida, has demanded an investigation into ‘Italian-sounding’ sauces sold in the EU parliament supermarket, notably a carbonara sauce labeled “Italiaanse pancetta” despite carbonara traditionally using guanciale, and a tomato sauce claiming “oignons de Calabria”. Sold under Delhaize’s own-brand with an Italian flag, the jars don’t claim Italian origin but risk misleading consumers under EU labelling rules. The dispute coincides with Italy’s UNESCO intangible cultural heritage bid for its cuisine. Coldiretti warns Italy loses €120bn annually to fake products—over two-thirds of global “Italian” agrifood goods—and cites the US and “mafia”-themed items among chief offenders.

articles.title: Christie’s withdraws rare ‘first calculator’ from auction after French court halts export
articles.trailText: Move comes after French scientists issued urgent appeal to prevent La Pascaline from leaving the country
articles.summary: Christie’s has withdrawn the 1642 Pascaline—one of eight surviving examples of Blaise Pascal’s first mechanical calculator—from a Paris sale after the administrative court provisionally suspended its export license. Responding to an urgent appeal by Nobel laureate Giorgio Parisi and fellow scientists, the court cited the machine’s “national treasure” status, blocking flights out of France pending a final ruling. Expected to fetch over €2m, the ebony-inlaid surveyor’s model is crucial to computing history and must remain in French public collections for study. Its final fate may take months to decide.

articles.title: European Commission accused of ‘massive rollback’ of digital protections
articles.trailText: Proposed changes to AI Act would make it easier for tech firms to use personal data to train models without consent
articles.summary: The European Commission’s “digital omnibus” would delay key provisions of the AI Act (including an 18-month extension for high-risk systems) and amend GDPR to streamline consent and reduce cookie prompts, easing personal data use for AI training without explicit permission. Aimed at cutting €5 billion in compliance costs by 2029 and boosting EU innovation, it draws backlash from privacy NGOs over rights erosion, while industry lobbies demand deeper deregulation.

articles.title: Plan to speed tanks and armies across Europe in case of war with Russia
articles.trailText: European Commission seeks to ease rules on cross-border movements to create ‘military Schengen’ zone
articles.summary: The European Commission unveiled a military mobility plan to cut bureaucratic barriers and upgrade critical infrastructure—bridges, tunnels, roads, ports and airports—for rapid cross-border deployment of troops and heavy equipment by 2030. In response to intelligence suggesting Russia could strike an EU state within five years, the “military Schengen” scheme would reduce notice requirements from 45 to three days, grant convoys priority on transport networks, waive customs and driver-rest rules in emergencies, and earmark €100bn to retrofit 500 bottlenecks. Described as a critical insurance policy underpinning NATO, it proposes €17.6bn in funding for 2028-34 plus access to €150bn in EU defence loans.

articles.title: Denmark announces one of the world’s most ambitious climate targets, while the rest of the EU looks away
articles.trailText: Governments across the continent have attacked green rules with increasing ferocity – all while professing their commitment to existing climate targets
articles.summary: Denmark unveiled an 82% greenhouse gas cut by 2035 vs 1990—surpassing the UK’s 81% goal and the EU’s 66.3���72.5% range—emphasising front-loaded action over end-century net zero. At COP30 in Brazil, most EU states are weakening domestic green policies: the European Parliament voted to water down deforestation rules and scrap mandatory corporate climate transition plans, with centre-right parties aligning with the far-right. Professor Alberto Alemanno warns this realigns EU politics until 2029. Concurrently, the EU approved a 90% emissions reduction by 2040 (allowing 5% via carbon credits), maintaining its minimal COP30 commitment.

articles.title: Poland closes last Russian consulate after ‘act of state terrorism’ on railway
articles.trailText: Foreign minister orders closure of Gdańsk consulate and says four people now arrested after sabotage attack
articles.summary: Poland’s FM Radosław Sikorski labeled last weekend's Gdańsk-area rail sabotage “an act of state terrorism” by Russia and ordered closure of the final Russian consulate. Security services have arrested four suspects and are hunting principals; PM Donald Tusk cited two Ukrainian citizens allegedly working with Russian intelligence. The blast near Mika disrupted key Warsaw-east lines but caused no casualties; power cables were also cut. Moscow vowed reciprocal diplomatic cuts and denied involvement. Poland and Ukraine will form a joint working group, while Warsaw plans Operation Horizon—deploying 10,000 troops to secure critical infrastructure ahead of winter.

articles.title: Israel used widely banned cluster munitions in Lebanon, photos of remnants suggest
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Images are first indication that Israel has used cluster munitions in nearly 20 years
articles.summary: In south Lebanon, photos examined by six arms experts reveal remnants of two new Israeli cluster munitions—155 mm M999 Barak Eitan and 227 mm Ra��am Eitan—marking the first Israeli deployment of such weapons since the 2006 war. Discovered in valleys south of the Litani River after the 13-month conflict that began in October 2023, these guided munitions scatter dozens of bomblets and carry high dud rates, posing long-term civilian hazards. Though cluster bombs are banned by 124 states, Israel is not a signatory; the IDF denies unlawful use, but rights groups decry their indiscriminate, lasting impact.

articles.title: Pope Leo condemns US’s ‘extremely disrespectful’ treatment of immigrants
articles.trailText: Pontiff backs statement by US bishops condemning raids and mass deportations under Trump administration
articles.summary: Pope Leo, the first US-born pontiff, rebuked President Trump’s mass deportations and immigration raids as “extremely disrespectful,” endorsing a US bishops’ statement that calls for humane treatment and due process for long-term undocumented residents. While affirming nations’ rights to secure borders, he warned against inhuman practices and challenged the consistency of pro-life positions that ignore immigrant dignity. In a separate video to COP30 bishops, Leo decried global leaders’ lack of political will on climate change—citing floods, droughts and heatwaves—and hailed the 2015 Paris Agreement as the strongest tool to protect people and the planet.

articles.title: Ukraine’s energy sector corruption crisis – what we know so far and who was involved
articles.trailText: Anti-corruption investigators allege high-level kickback scheme involving Energoatom
articles.summary: Ukraine’s anti-corruption bureau Nabu uncovered a $100m kickback scheme in state nuclear operator Energoatom, where insiders allegedly extracted 10–15% from suppliers under threat of blacklisting. Codenames like “Professor�� and couriered cash in bags formed “Operation Midas” evidence, including 1,000 hours of recordings. Prime suspects include Timur Mindich—Zelensky’s former Kvartal 95 partner who fled abroad—and ex-deputy PM Oleksiy Chernyshov, plus fired justice and energy ministers. Public fury grows amid war-induced blackouts. Zelensky has sanctioned Mindich and vows prosecutions. Nabu hints corruption reaches defence and banking, with possible Kremlin links via ex-politician Andriy Derkach.

articles.title: Disease fears as Argentina child vaccination rates hit historic lows
articles.trailText: Sharp drop since 2024 in country regarded as a Latin American leader in childhood and adolescent immunisation
articles.summary: Argentina’s childhood and adolescent vaccination coverage plunged in 2024 to record lows – under 50% for MMR (46%), polio booster (47%) and DTP (46%), far below the 95% herd-immunity threshold. Over 115,000 infants missed six-month pentavalent and polio doses. Since 2024 the country lost 48% of its health budget under President Milei’s austerity, crippling outreach, clinic hours and school campaigns. Access barriers, economic crisis and rising post-pandemic vaccine mistrust compounded the decline. Experts warn of resurgent measles, polio, whooping cough and hepatitis A: whooping cough cases are three times higher in 2025, causing five child deaths so far.

articles.title: What happened to Jamal Khashoggi? Trump resurfaces memories of journalist’s brutal murder
articles.trailText: President’s claim that Mohammed bin Salman had nothing to do with 2018 killing contradicts US intelligence
articles.summary: During his Oval Office meeting with Mohammed bin Salman, Donald Trump claimed the Saudi crown prince had no role in the 2018 murder of Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi. That contradicts a 2019 UN probe and a 2021 US intelligence report concluding MBS approved a 15-man hit squad that drugged, strangled and dismembered Khashoggi inside Istanbul’s consulate. Turkish intelligence bugged the operation and CCTV showed body parts in bags. MBS denies ordering the killing. Khashoggi’s widow demands justice.

articles.title: Social Democrats in Denmark suffer sweeping election losses
articles.trailText: PM Mette Frederiksen’s centre-left party loses control of Copenhagen for first time in more than 100 years
articles.summary: In Denmark’s municipal and regional elections on Nov 19, PM Mette Frederiksen’s Social Democrats dropped more than five points nationwide (28.4% to 23.2%), lost key municipalities including Copenhagen—where Socialistisk Folkeparti’s Sisse Marie Welling won the lord mayor post with 17.9% and the Red-Green Alliance led with 22.1%—marking the first non-Social Democrat mayor since 1938. The far-right Danish People’s Party rose to 5.9%. Frederiksen blamed food inflation, urban-rural divides and immigration issues. Other losses hit Frederikshavn, Køge, Fredericia, Gladsaxe and Holstebro.

articles.title: Watch out for online contact with Chinese spies, UK defence minister warns public
articles.trailText: After MI5 issues China espionage alert to parliament, Luke Pollard says message should be heeded by all citizens
articles.summary: UK defence minister Luke Pollard has urged ordinary citizens to heed an MI5 alert that Chinese operatives are targeting individuals with access to sensitive information via online platforms such as LinkedIn. Security services revealed two LinkedIn accounts—Amanda Qiu and Shirly Shen—allegedly posing as headhunters to recruit parliamentary staff. Pollard warned that increasing online engagement makes espionage attempts more plentiful. Beijing dismissed the warning as hype. The advisory follows the collapse of an espionage trial into two British suspects. Pollard emphasised both threats and opportunities in UK-China relations and said the government is reviewing Chinese technology procurement.

articles.title: China suspends seafood imports from Japan as Taiwan row escalates
articles.trailText: Beijing reimposes 2023 ban, citing Japan PM’s comment that military would respond to Chinese attack on island
articles.summary: China has again suspended all seafood imports from Japan, reviving a 2023 ban amid escalating tensions after PM Takaichi’s remark that Japan might militarily defend Taiwan against China. Beijing cited failed technical documentation and public outrage. Before the initial ban China (including Hong Kong) took over 20% of Japan’s seafood exports. The move follows coastguard maneuvers near disputed islands, travel warnings, flight refunds, cultural cancellations, market sell-offs and UN comments downgrading Japan’s Security Council bid.

articles.title: Moscow passes laws to boost defences against Ukrainian strikes
articles.trailText: Vladimir Putin authorises the guarding of fuel sites, internet blackouts and tighter sentencing for acts of sabotage
articles.summary: Russia’s president signed sweeping laws to defend against near-daily Ukrainian drone strikes and sabotage, authorising the deployment of about 2 million reservists to guard key energy sites without fresh mobilisation. Measures include a 24-hour sim-card “cooling-off” for returnees to disrupt drone controls, denser air defences around refineries and elite enclaves, and tougher penalties—lowering the age of criminal responsibility for sabotage to 14 and imposing life sentences for involving minors. The moves, reflecting Kremlin expectations of a protracted conflict, also deepen state controls and prepare citizens for further wartime sacrifices.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: Why strangulation during sex has become so common among teenagers
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Despite the risks, many young people now see choking during intimacy as acceptable or even expected, which experts put down to the proliferation of increasingly violent online pornography
articles.summary: A study by the Institute for Addressing Strangulation (Royal College of Physicians) finds 43% of UK under-18s have either strangled or been strangled during sex; 36% felt scared and 21% experienced serious symptoms—including dizziness, loss of consciousness and stroke risk. Men more often enact choking, but prevalence is nearly equal across genders. Experts attribute the surge to ubiquitous, increasingly violent online pornography: 58% of teens report seeing choking acts (average first exposure age 13). Researchers warn repeated non-fatal strangulation can cause cumulative brain injury, cognitive decline and reproductive harm. They urge public health campaigns, sex education reform, strict Online Safety Act enforcement and the new domestic-abuse choking offence.

articles.title: ‘Dangerous nostalgia’: did Spain’s ‘pact of forgetting’ after Franco leave new generation open to far right?
articles.trailText: Events to mark the 50th anniversary of dictator’s death are intended to remind Spaniards, particularly the young, of the dangers of fascism
articles.summary: On the 50th anniversary of Franco’s death, Spain’s socialist government is staging nationwide events to highlight the perils of fascism and enforce new democratic memory laws. With polls showing over 20% of under-30s open to authoritarian rule, officials blame a 1977 “pact of forgetting” that whitewashed Francoist crimes. PSOE and PP clash over memory budgets while far-right Vox scorns commemorations. Educators warn macho “manosphere” tropes foster nostalgia and historical ignorance. Campaigners press for exhumations and justice, lamenting impunity under the amnesty law that keeps Franco’s legacy alive.

articles.title: ‘Exceptionally rare’ pink grasshopper spotted in New Zealand
articles.trailText: The native species is typically grey or brown and the pink hue is thought to be caused by a genetic mutation
articles.summary: An exceptionally rare dark pink robust grasshopper (Caedicia robusta) was spotted by Department of Conservation researchers in South Island’s MacKenzie Basin near Lake Tekapo during their annual survey. Native to New Zealand’s braided rivers, adult robust grasshoppers are typically grey or brown; this female’s pink hue is attributed to erythrism, a genetic mutation causing excess red pigment. With just 250–1,000 mature individuals remaining and facing habitat loss, climate warming and predators, the species is nationally endangered. Though a small predator-exclusion sanctuary exists, this sighting outside the enclosure underscores both the insect’s vulnerability and potential for discovering more pink variants.

articles.title: UN to hear human rights complaint over New Zealand’s treatment of Māori
articles.trailText: UN committee to consider claim by prominent Māori leader Tureiti Moxon that alleges government policies have harmed Indigenous people
articles.summary: Prominent Māori leader Lady Tureiti Moxon has lodged a 42-page complaint under the UN CERD’s early warning and urgent action procedure, accusing New Zealand’s coalition government of persistent discrimination against Māori through recent reforms—scrapping Māori language provisions, disbanding the Māori Health Authority and weakening Treaty obligations. The UN has accepted the case, likely prompting formal responses and possible recommendations. Moxon, chair of the national urban iwi authority, will present in Geneva as the CERD committee reviews NZ’s racial discrimination record, aiming to compel policy change after domestic legal and tribunal challenges failed.

articles.title: Australia’s peak health body for men distances itself from conservative group’s International Men’s Day campaign
articles.trailText: Australian Men’s Health Forum says it is not affiliated with Dads4Kids group espousing anti-feminist, anti-LGBTQI+ views
articles.summary: Australia’s government-funded peak men’s health body, the Australian Men’s Health Forum (AMHF), has clarified it is not affiliated with the conservative Christian group Dads4Kids (Fatherhood Foundation), which runs a separate International Men’s Day (IMD) campaign promoting anti-feminist and anti-LGBTQ+ views. Both campaigns share similar logos and domains and cite IMD founder Dr Jerome Teelucksingh, but only AMHF—coordinating IMD since 2017 under theme “supporting men and boys”—endorses an inclusive approach. AMHF CEO Glen Poole emphasized there is no affiliation, copying or shared ownership between the parallel campaigns. Dads4Kids’ founder Warwick Marsh has long campaigned against feminist and LGBTQ+ rights. Experts like Michael Flood acknowledge IMD’s shift towards mental health without anti-feminist framing.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv seeks $44bn from Russia for climate-warming war emissions
articles.trailText: The move marks the first time a country is claiming damages for such an increase in emissions. What we know on day 1,365
articles.summary: Ukraine will seek $44bn from Russia for climate-warming emissions from war—covering fossil fuel use, cement, steel and deforestation—the first such damages claim. A Russian missile strike wounded 32 in Kharkiv, including two children. President Zelensky travels to Ankara to revive stalled peace talks with Erdoğan after failed Istanbul rounds. The US approved a $105m sale of Patriot parts, training and services to bolster air defenses. Poland accused two Ukrainians working for Russian intelligence of a rail-line explosion. Spain pledged €615m military aid, including €300m in new defense equipment, while Zelensky viewed Picasso’s Guernica.

articles.title: British woman among four tourists killed in blizzard at nature reserve in Chile
articles.trailText: Four people also rescued alive at popular Torres del Paine reserve in Patagonia amid heavy snowfall and strong winds
articles.summary: In southern Chile’s Torres del Paine reserve, a blizzard with heavy snowfall and winds up to 120 mph left nine tourists missing; rescue teams of police, soldiers, mountain rescue and a search dog recovered four survivors but confirmed the deaths of two Mexicans, two Germans and one British woman near Los Perros camp. Adverse weather grounded helicopters delaying evacuations; consular and evacuation procedures are underway. President Gabriel Boric offered condolences and praised rescue teams’ tireless efforts. The national park, which saw over 367,000 visitors in 2024, draws explorers to its mountains, glaciers and rivers.

articles.title: Caribbean slavery reparations body decries claims it aims to ‘break UK Treasury’
articles.trailText: On first official visit to UK, group calls for mutually beneficial programme to clean up ‘mess’ left by colonialism
articles.summary: In its first UK visit, the Caricom Reparations Commission, chaired by Prof Sir Hilary Beckles, refuted claims it seeks to “break the British Treasury” with multi-trillion-pound demands, instead calling for a collaborative restorative justice programme. Highlighting centuries of wealth extraction, post-independence debt, health, education and climate vulnerabilities, the CRC urges debt cancellation, formal apology and joint development strategies with the UK. A six-member delegation has briefed MPs, diplomats and civil society to advance a moral and ethical dialogue on reparations and shared global resilience.

articles.title: China in ‘covert and calculated’ effort to recruit MPs and peers, minister says
articles.trailText: Dan Jarvis gives Commons statement after MI5 alert about LinkedIn profiles of Amanda Qiu and Shirly Shen
articles.summary: MI5 has warned MPs and peers of a ‘covert and calculated’ Chinese intelligence campaign using two LinkedIn profiles, Amanda Qiu and Shirly Shen, to recruit parliamentarians and gather non-public insights. Security minister Dan Jarvis told the Commons the MSS-linked operatives posed as recruiters at BP-YR Executive Search and InternshipUnion, offering consulting roles to access sensitive government information. China’s embassy condemned the alert as fabrication. MI5 outlined typical recruitment tactics—freelance geopolitics reports paid in cash or crypto—and Jarvis announced steps to brief parties, tighten donation rules and remove Chinese surveillance cameras.

articles.title: Ukrainians working for Russia were behind rail blasts, alleges Polish PM
articles.trailText: Donald Tusk says two saboteurs crossed border from Belarus hoping to cause divisive ‘catastrophe’
articles.summary: Poland’s PM Donald Tusk has announced that two Ukrainian nationals, allegedly working for Russian intelligence, carried out unprecedented rail sabotage on a strategic aid corridor for Ukraine. The saboteurs planted military-grade explosives and clamps under freight tracks, causing minor damage but risking a major catastrophe. Identified suspects reportedly crossed from and back to Belarus; one had a prior Ukrainian sabotage conviction, the other hails from Russian-occupied Donetsk. Tusk links this to a wider pattern of Russian-instigated sabotage across Europe, often recruiting via Telegram. Poland will seek diplomatic action against Belarus and Russia; the Kremlin denies the accusations.

articles.title: EU confirms it wants UK to pay into its budget in exchange for closer ties
articles.trailText: ‘Politically realistic’ for UK to make financial contribution so it can access European single market, Irish minister says
articles.summary: Ireland’s Europe minister, Thomas Byrne, confirmed that EU member states have agreed the UK must pay into the EU budget to join the European electricity single market, describing it as ‘politically realistic.’ Although Britain already covers legacy membership costs, it now faces fresh contributions—and a proposed entry fee of up to €6 billion—to access a €150 billion EU defence programme. Negotiations are underway on veterinary checks, with hopes of streamlining food and animal border controls by late 2026 during Ireland’s EU Council presidency. Commission officials warn that talks will require ‘nerves of steel,’ while the UK insists any deal must represent clear value for British industry.

articles.title: Pension changes row threatens Germany’s coalition government
articles.trailText: Youth wing of conservatives say younger people will be left carrying can for older generation
articles.summary: A revolt by 18 young MPs from Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s conservative Junge Union threatens to derail a pension reform guaranteeing six years of pension rises, arguing it offloads €120bn of costs onto younger Germans. Led by 28-year-old Johannes Volkmann, grandson of Helmut Kohl, they could swell to 40–50 rebels. With Merz’s 12-seat majority in the 630-seat Bundestag at risk and a vote due in December, dissenters demand a 1-point cut in the 48% salary replacement rate, citing demographic pressures, rising contributions (19%), and polls showing eroding pension confidence. Merz has signaled sympathy but remains noncommittal.

articles.title: Sheinbaum again dismisses Trump’s threat of sending troops to Mexico: ‘We do not want intervention’
articles.trailText: Mexico’s president responds to Trump’s latest warning that he could authorize strikes against drug cartels in country
articles.summary: Mexico President Claudia Sheinbaum again rejected Donald Trump’s threat to deploy US troops into Mexico to strike drug cartels, insisting no foreign intervention and recalling the 19th-century US occupation. After Trump claimed he could authorize cross-border strikes under “major surveillance”, his administration clarified it would require Mexico’s consent, which she refuses. Trump has also amassed an armada led by the USS Gerald R. Ford near Venezuela and ordered the destruction of 21 alleged drug-trafficking boats, killing at least 83, as part of a tougher US approach to Latin America.

articles.title: UK introduces voluntary health assessment for flat-faced dog breeds
articles.trailText: Breeders welcome initiative from all-party parliamentary group on animal welfare, but question its usefulness
articles.summary: An all-party parliamentary group has launched a voluntary Innate Health Assessment (IHA) for flat-faced dog breeds, scoring 10 traits—wrinkled skin, bulging eyes, drooping eyelids, bite alignment, muzzle length, merle coloration, tail carriage, etc.—and requiring an 80% pass rate to qualify for breeding. Aimed at reducing extreme conformation disorders in English and French bulldogs and pugs, the scheme wins cautious support from breeders and the Kennel Club, which is developing its own vet-led nose-to-tail assessment, but questions remain over enforcement among the 70% of unregistered breeders.

articles.title: The Kessler Twins sisters Alice and Ellen die together aged 89
articles.trailText: German pop duo who last year said their wish was ‘to leave together’ had joint assisted death at their home in Grünwald
articles.summary: Identical twins Alice and Ellen Kessler, German pop duo famed across Europe in the 1960s, died together at 89 via joint assisted suicide at their Grünwald home, fulfilling their long-held wish to ‘leave together.’ Celebrated for bringing glamour to Italy’s TV—nicknamed “the legs of the nation”—they reprised West Germany at Eurovision 1959, performed at Paris’s Lido with Elvis Presley, and on Rai’s Studio Uno. Pioneering female independence, they challenged conservative dress codes. Ashes will share an urn alongside their mother and dog in line with their pact.

articles.title: Venezuela’s top opposition leader claims ‘new era’ is coming despite lack of clear plan
articles.trailText: María Corina Machado pens a ‘freedom manifesto’ as plan to force Nicolás Maduro from power remains unclear
articles.summary: Venezuela’s top opposition figure María Corina Machado, winner of this year’s Nobel Peace Prize, has published a ‘freedom manifesto’ declaring her country on “the edge of a new era” with a 100-hour and 100-day plan to topple Nicolás Maduro and block future despots. Details remain vague as Donald Trump orders a US naval buildup – including the USS Gerald R. Ford – offers a $50m bounty and readies a Cartel of the Suns terror designation. Experts note Maduro’s regime shows no cracks, raising doubts about transition and stability.

articles.title: UN plan just ‘first step’ toward peace in Gaza, says Palestinian foreign minister
articles.trailText: Varsen Aghabekian Shahin backs resolution, while Hamas rejects idea of international force inside territory
articles.summary: Palestinian FM Varsen Aghabekian Shahin hails the UN Security Council’s 13-0 endorsement (China/Russia abstaining) of Trump’s Gaza peace plan as a vital first step toward ceasefire and eventual statehood, despite Hamas rejecting an international force inside Gaza and mandated weapon decommissioning, demanding any UN deployment remain at borders under full UN oversight. Arab states pressed for details on the technocratic committee, ISF leadership and “board of peace”. Abbas plans PA reforms with Macron. Israel’s Netanyahu welcomes demilitarisation; UK secures aid delivery reference and offers IRA-based disarmament ideas.

articles.title: New Slovenian law treats entire Romany minority ‘as a security threat’
articles.trailText: Parliament approves law giving police powers to raid and surveil homes in what are demarcated as security risk areas
articles.summary: Slovenia’s parliament has passed the ‘Šutar law’, granting police warrantless entry, raids, drone surveillance and license-plate recognition in government-designated ‘security-risk areas’, largely encompassing Roma neighbourhoods. Enacted after the killing of officer Aleš Šutar in Novo Mesto, the law empowers authorities to seize weapons immediately and demarcate zones based on security assessments. Critics, including the Roma Foundation for Europe, denounce it as discriminatory—treating an entire minority as a security threat—and call for EU scrutiny. Left-wing parties boycotted the vote, yet a poll found over 60% public support. Passed ahead of March elections, it underscores tensions between security policy and minority rights.

articles.title: Four ‘active club’ members sentenced to prison in Sweden for racist assaults
articles.trailText: Men aged 20 to 23 convicted at trial that showed pattern of far-right activists assembling in gyms
articles.summary: Stockholm district court jailed four members (aged 21–23) of Aktivklubb Sverige, the Swedish branch of the international far-right "active club" network, for three racially motivated assaults on 27 August. In Sweden’s first hate-crime verdict against the gym-based group, defendants convicted of aggravated assault, hate crimes and vandalism received six-month to three-year sentences and must pay damages. CCTV footage and Nazi salutes linked them to white-nationalist extremism. Victims, including a Syrian man left with concussion and lasting trauma, say Sweden’s political climate emboldens such violence. Authorities warn of about 10 active clubs nationwide and call for coordinated prevention.

articles.title: Saudi entourage for US visit may include official implicated in Twitter spy plot
articles.trailText: Senior aide to Mohammed bin Salman allegedly led campaign to identify users who were posting critically about Saudi regime
articles.summary: Bader al-Asaker, Mohammed bin Salman’s chief of staff since before 2014, may join the crown prince’s first US visit in seven years despite a US superseding indictment accusing him of leading a 2014-15 covert operation to infiltrate Twitter and identify regime critics. Identified as ‘Foreign-Official-1’, al-Asaker allegedly recruited insiders, offered bribes and coordinated with Saudi agents on behalf of the regime. Though never charged criminally, he faces a civil suit with Saud al-Qahtani over an alleged plot to target ex-intelligence official Saad aljabri. Sovereign immunity has shielded MBS from related legal claims, including a Khashoggi wrongful death case.

articles.title: Chinese travellers cancel hundreds of thousands of trips to Japan amid rising tensions
articles.trailText: Chinese airlines offer free cancellations and film releases postponed after Japanese PM’s comments on Taiwan
articles.summary: After Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi warned Japan could intervene militarily if China attacked Taiwan, about 500,000 flights to Japan were cancelled Nov 15–17 as seven Chinese carriers offered free refunds. Visa processing, student exchanges, cultural surveys and screenings of Japanese films were halted amid nationalist backlash. Japanese travel and retail stocks slid. Tokyo dispatched a top diplomat to Beijing. Japan advised its citizens in China to exercise caution, highlighting elevated tensions and the broader US-Japan security implications.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What Labour hopes to learn from Denmark’s hardline asylum stance
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Shabana Mahmood is pitching radical new limits on whether asylum seekers can ever gain settled status – but it may come with political consequences
articles.summary: Labour under Shabana Mahmood will introduce “core protection” asylum status—30-month renewable leave, no indefinite settlement for 20 years, end automatic family reunion, tighten benefits and appeals—mirroring Denmark’s hardline model. Plans include restarting enforced returns to Syria and capped safe/legal routes. The overhaul, billed as the “most sweeping asylum reforms in modern times,” has alarmed Labour MPs over perpetual limbo and economic fallout. Denmark’s policies deter asylum but face legal blocks and political backlash, warning Labour the approach risks internal revolt and voter erosion.

articles.title: One of the oddest UN resolutions in history seeks to solidify shaky Gaza ceasefire into an enduring peace
articles.trailText: The hazy UN resolution dictates that Trump’s ‘board of peace’ will supervise an International Stabilisation Force, whose membership is as yet undetermined
articles.summary: UNSC resolution 2803 passed 13-0 (Russia, China abstained) creating a two-year Gaza peace plan led by a Trump-chaired “board of peace,” with Tony Blair as deputy and membership unspecified. Outside UN authority, it mandates an International Stabilisation Force to demilitarize Gaza, a Palestinian technocrats’ committee and local police—both yet to be formed. Framed as transformative by the US, it tentatively invokes Palestinian self-determination and statehood, drawing cautious European support and fury from Israel’s hard-right.

articles.title: ‘They have total impunity’: West Bank settler violence surges after Gaza ceasefire
articles.trailText: UN logs 260 attacks in October alone, its highest monthly tally, as settlers attack farmers and burn olive trees
articles.summary: Since the Gaza ceasefire six weeks ago, armed Israeli settlers have escalated attacks across the occupied West Bank, vandalizing cars, raiding farmland, assaulting farmers and burning olive trees. The UN recorded over 260 incidents in October—the highest monthly tally since 2006—while Palestinian Farmers’ Union reports violence quadrupling. Settler impunity persists: only 5% of investigations lead to charges. Recent assaults injured Palestinians and soldiers, prompting rare condemnations from President Herzog and PM Netanyahu. Olive harvest revenues have plunged from $130 m to a fraction, deepening rural economic crisis amid rising fatalities—over 1,000 since 7 October, including many children.

articles.title: Centre-left tipped to lose Copenhagen for first time in electoral history
articles.trailText: Political rivals say PM’s divisive politics have encouraged voters to ditch the Social Democrats for the far right
articles.summary: Denmark’s capital is poised to end over a century of Social Democrat rule, with polls forecasting their defeat amid disillusionment with PM Mette Frederiksen’s divisive integration and immigration policies. Analysts say SF, Enhedslisten and Alternativet could form a leftist majority, likely installing SF’s Sisse Marie Welling as lord mayor. Critics charge the Social Democrats’ strategic rightward shift—cited by Alternativet’s Karoline Lindgaard—and fatigue over the 2020 Frank Jensen scandal primed disaffected supporters to back the far right. Political scientists warn nationwide unpopularity could erode their urban strongholds.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv to buy 100 Rafale warplanes, drones and air defence systems from France
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy hails ‘a historic deal’; families of Ukrainian children forcibly deported to Russia on Monday sounded the alarm about their fate. What we know on day 1,364
articles.summary: Ukraine signed a letter of intent with France to buy up to 100 Rafale warplanes, drones, air-defence systems and other equipment over 10 years—a deal Zelenskyy hailed as historic alongside Macron at the Élysée. Russian strikes killed civilians in Kharkiv and Dnipropetrovsk, destroyed a kindergarten and hit Donetsk power plants. Families of children deported to Russia say contact is cut. A drone attack set fire to Turkish tanker MT Orinda in Odesa, prompting Romanian evacuations. Trump signals support for new Russia sanctions, Poland probes sabotage on Ukraine-bound rail, and China vows deeper energy and agricultural ties with Moscow.

articles.title: Authors dumped from New Zealand’s top book prize after AI used in cover designs
articles.trailText: Ockham Book Awards dropped two titles from contention after new guidelines introduced on artificial intelligence use
articles.summary: Two award-winning NZ authors, Stephanie Johnson and Elizabeth Smither, were disqualified from the 2026 NZ $65k Ockham fiction prize after new guidelines rolled out in August retroactively barred their titles Obligate Carnivore and Angel Train for featuring AI-generated cover elements. Both authors said they were unaware of AI use, as covers are independently commissioned, and worry the issue overshadows their writing. Smither lamented designers’ meticulous work being disregarded; chair Nicola Legat defended consistent criteria to uphold creators’ copyrights and signaled future reviews as AI evolves.

articles.title: UN security council votes to endorse Donald Trump’s Gaza plan
articles.trailText: The resolution, which includes references to an independent Palestine, was passed by a vote of 13-0 with China and Russia abstaining
articles.summary: UN Security Council adopted a US-backed resolution 13-0 (China, Russia abstaining) endorsing former president Trump's Gaza peace proposals: an international stabilization force, conditional references to a sovereign Palestinian state once the Palestinian Authority reforms and Gaza reconstruction are underway, and a Board of Peace chaired by Trump. Israel’s Netanyahu rejects Palestinian statehood; Hamas refuses disarmament and opposes international “guardianship.” No troop commitments yet; operational details for the technocratic committee and reform criteria remain undefined, while supporters hope for lifted aid curbs and ceasefire extension.

articles.title: Sydney’s $60 road toll cap to be made permanent with plan for two-way fee on Harbour Bridge to fund it
articles.trailText: ‘It’s a massive cost-of-living relief measure for hundreds of thousands of people who live in western Sydney,’ premier Chris Minns says
articles.summary: NSW Premier Chris Minns announced the permanent extension of the $60 weekly cap on Sydney tolls—drivers can reclaim up to $340/week after spending $60 per vehicle—originally due to expire end-2025. Costing roughly $200m/year, the relief aids hundreds of thousands in western Sydney. To fund it, the government proposes reinstating two-way tolls on state-owned routes, including the Harbour Bridge, Harbour Tunnel and the future Western Harbour Tunnel/M6 (due 2028). Opposition leader Mark Speakman brands this a broken promise. Negotiations to consolidate all tolling under NSW Motorways with Transurban continue, with a year-end update expected.

articles.title: Ireland to act if tougher asylum rules create Belfast back door for migration
articles.trailText: Jim O’Callaghan says he will closely monitor changes proposed by Britain amid concerns over impact
articles.summary: Jim O’Callaghan, Ireland’s justice minister, warns UK’s proposed tougher asylum rules—aimed at speeding removals and the largest migration overhaul in 40 years—could drive migrants to exploit the open Belfast-Dublin route, which accounts for over 80% of irregular arrivals via Great Britain. He pledges to monitor UK changes closely, consider legislative adjustments in his upcoming international protection bill, and ensure Ireland isn’t deemed more favourable. Deputy PM Simon Harris reaffirmed that the Common Travel Area’s invisible border was not intended for asylum control. Sinn Féin’s Matt Carthy argues this risk underscores Ireland’s caution over the EU migration pact.

articles.title: Poland railway blast was unprecedented act of sabotage, says Donald Tusk
articles.trailText: Polish PM vows to ‘catch the perpetrators, regardless of who their backers are’ after blast on track used for deliveries to Ukraine
articles.summary: Polish PM Donald Tusk called Sunday’s explosion on the Warsaw–Lublin freight line to Ukraine an unprecedented act of sabotage and launched a terror probe into possible foreign-intelligence involvement.
