Although no one was hurt, a gap in the track could have derailed a high-speed train. A second incident near Puławy saw overhead wires damaged and a metal brace left on the rails. Officials, citing a recent wave of fires, blasts and mall explosions, suspect Russian services recruiting locals via Telegram. A government security committee will meet as ministers vow to inspect the remaining 120 km of track to the Ukrainian border.

articles.title: Letter: Martin Mansergh obituary
articles.trailText: Greg Quiery writes: It may well explain Martin’s loyalty to Fianna Fáil.
articles.summary: Greg Quiery’s obituary letter in the Guardian traces Martin Mansergh’s loyalty to Fianna Fáil back to a defining family trauma: the Manserghs, an Anglo-Irish landowning clan in Tipperary, revered their pet dog. When it was shot by the Black and Tans in 1920 at the family estate, they abandoned British allegiance and embraced Irish Republicanism. This switch, sparked by a single act of violence, offers insight into Mansergh’s political convictions and deep-rooted commitment to Fianna Fáil. As Quiery notes, this episode 'may well explain' Mansergh’s enduring party loyalty decades later.

articles.title: Ousted Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for crimes against humanity
articles.trailText: Hasina sentenced in absentia by court in Dhaka over deadly crackdown on student-led uprising last year
articles.summary: Bangladesh’s ousted PM Sheikh Hasina, living exiled in India since August, was sentenced to death in absentia by Dhaka’s international crimes tribunal for her role in the “July revolution” crackdown on student-led protests last year. A three-judge bench found she incited violence, ordered killings via drones, helicopters and live ammunition, and failed to prevent atrocities that killed up to 1,400 civilians. The UN human rights office welcomed the verdict as accountability but opposed the death penalty. Former home minister Asaduzzaman Khan also received a capital sentence. Hasina calls the trial a political charade. Bangladesh’s first election since her ouster is scheduled for February, with her Awami League barred from participation.

articles.title: UN to vote on Gaza stabilisation force plan that references Palestinian state
articles.trailText: Benjamin Netanyahu faces pressure from far-right ministers after Saudi insistence on ‘credible pathway’ to statehood
articles.summary: The UN Security Council will vote on a US-drafted resolution Monday to deploy a two-year international stabilization force (ISF) in Gaza, per Trump’s 20-point plan, to secure borders, protect civilians, aid corridors and decommission non-state weapons. A late Saudi-backed insertion refers to establishing “conditions...for a credible pathway to Palestinian statehood.” Russia and China table a rival draft. Gulf states, France and the UK back the US text despite Arab unease, seeking Trump’s buy-in for Israel’s consent. Netanyahu opposes the statehood clause amid far-right cabinet pressure. Troop contributions from Arab/Muslim states hinge on sensitive political mandates and Hamas disarmament.

articles.title: Incredible story of Irish labourer buried alive in coffin for 61 days told in new documentary
articles.trailText: Mick Meaney made global headlines when he beat world record in 1968, but returned to Ireland penniless
articles.summary: In 1968 Irish labourer Mick Meaney, with barely funds to his name, spent 61 days buried alive beneath Kilburn to claim a world record of endurance, outlasting Texan Bill White’s 55-day stunt. Organised by impresario Michael “Butty” Sugrue, Meaney survived in a foam-lined coffin fed through an air pipe and phone line, attracting initial publicity but little reward—no official recognition or sponsorship. His loved ones allege Sugrue swindled him. Beo Faoin bhFód, airing 26 November on TG4, features interviews with family and archival footage to explore the stunt’s triumph and poignant aftermath.

articles.title: ‘There is so much corruption’: hundreds of thousands protest in Manila over missing flood funds
articles.trailText: Huge rally organised by megachurch whose members vote in a bloc could spell trouble for Philippine president
articles.summary: In Manila, an estimated 650,000 protesters from megachurch Iglesia ni Cristo rallied in white T-shirts across Rizal Park demanding 'transparency for a better democracy' amid revelations that billions in flood mitigation funds vanished. Government investigators uncovered more than 400 ghost projects and estimate up to 70% of flood-relief budgets were embezzled. The absence of protection worsened recent typhoon disasters that killed hundreds and displaced over a million. President Marcos Jr has vowed arrests by year’s end, but INC’s bloc voting power and shift away from Marcos signal mounting political risk. Organizers insist they seek only anti-corruption reforms, not regime change.

articles.title: Far-right group with links to neo-Nazi leader offers online military training
articles.trailText: Experts say Observations Group’s connections to the Base and Rinaldo Nazzaro present ‘urgent danger’
articles.summary: Observations Group, an accelerationist neo-Nazi network operating via Telegram, markets an online "military course"—from basic command skills to drone warfare tradecraft—priced in cryptocurrency. It claims ties to Rinaldo Nazzaro (aka Norman Spear), leader of The Base and alleged Russian intel asset, and allies across Europe and the US. Experts warn its open-access, veteran-led training and drone manuals pose urgent national security risks, potentially channeling battlefield tactics into domestic far-right attacks. EU has proscribed The Base; US authorities warn of first-person view drones poised for domestic terror.

articles.title: China and Japan are in a war of words over Taiwan – what happens next?
articles.trailText: Japan’s hawkish new PM has angered Beijing after suggesting her country could become involved in a military conflict between China and Taiwan
articles.summary: Japan’s new PM Sanae Takaichi suggested military involvement if China invades Taiwan, citing a 2015 collective self-defence law. Beijing responded with fury—summoning diplomats, issuing travel warnings, threatening a “resolute counterattack,” deploying a coastguard ship near the Senkaku Islands and using state media to condemn Japan. Taiwan, once under Japanese rule, remains claimed by the PRC. Analysts warn heightened ADIZ/Senkaku activities risk accidental clashes and economic fallout from Chinese travel bans. Japan will boost defence spending to 2% of GDP by March 2026. Envoys are en route to Beijing as Taiwan’s president calls for global vigilance.

articles.title: China travel warning for Japan sends shares in tourism and retail companies plunging
articles.trailText: China warns citizens not to travel to Japan amid escalating row over comments about Taiwan made by PM Sanae Takaichi
articles.summary: China has warned citizens against travelling to Japan after PM Sanae Takaichi suggested Japanese Self-Defense Forces could intervene if China invaded Taiwan, prompting Beijing to call a boycott. Shares in tourism and retail firms plunged, with Shiseido down 9%, Takashimaya over 5% and Fast Retailing more than 4%. The row escalated amid a Chinese coastguard sail-by the Senkaku isles and indefinite postponement of two Japanese animations in China. Tokyo has sent envoy Masaaki Kanai to Beijing to reassure ministers that Japan’s Taiwan policy remains unchanged and urge de-escalation. China is Japan’s top tourist market with high consumer spending.

articles.title: ‘His role is to recruit’: the Sheffield-based propagandist for Sudan’s RSF militia
articles.trailText: Abdalmonim Alrabea has appeared in hundreds of videos in which he expresses support for paramilitary group accused of committing genocide
articles.summary: Abdalmonim Alrabea, a 44-year-old British citizen in Sheffield, has become one of the RSF’s most prolific online propagandists. Using TikTok, YouTube and X, he posted daily monologues, appeared in live streams celebrating mass killings in El Fasher and used ethnic slurs to glorify genocidal violence. Platforms have since removed his accounts for extremist content, but he resurfaced repeatedly, amassing over 240,000 followers. Sudanese diaspora groups and human rights lawyers are pressing UK authorities to sanction him for hate speech, incitement and recruitment, noting his on-the-ground trips to Darfur and ties to RSF commanders underscore his pivotal role in spreading and legitimising atrocity narratives.

articles.title: At least 98 Palestinians have died in custody since October 2023, Israeli data shows
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Real toll likely substantially higher as hundreds of detainees from Gaza are missing, says NGO Physicians for Human Rights - Israel
articles.summary: Physicians for Human Rights–Israel reports at least 98 Palestinians died in Israeli custody since October 2023 from violence, neglect and malnutrition, but the toll is likely higher, with hundreds unaccounted for. Official data cover the war’s first eight months; researchers found 35 more deaths after May 2024. Most victims are civilian detainees held without charge or trial; systemic abuse, torture, forced disappearance and near-total impunity persist. Only one soldier has faced trial. Under the October ceasefire 1,950 prisoners were released, yet 1,000 remain detained indefinitely amid minimal transparency or accountability.

articles.title: Monday briefing: How Trump and his allies flipped and flipped again on the Epstein files
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Having once demanded full disclosure, senior Maga figures have attempted to block efforts to publish the records
articles.summary: Monday Briefing details how four senior MAGA figures—Trump, VP J.D. Vance, AG Pam Bondi, and Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene—have flip-flopped repeatedly on releasing the Justice Department’s files on Jeffrey Epstein. Initially demanding full disclosure to implicate Democratic and Hollywood elites, they later disparaged the records as a partisan hoax and moved to block their release after Trump’s 2025 return. Facing GOP infighting and public pressure, Trump and his allies have now pivoted again, urging House Republicans to vote to unseal the Epstein documents.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Greece signs deal to supply gas to Kyiv over ‘difficult’ winter
articles.trailText: Agreement comes as Volodymyr Zelenskyy starts European tour aimed at shoring up Ukrainian energy supply and defences. What we know on day 1,363
articles.summary: From December to March 2026, Greece will supply US-sourced LNG to Ukraine to shore up gas during a ‘difficult winter,’ agreed during Zelenskiy’s Athens visit. The pact follows fresh Russian drone strikes on Odesa’s energy assets and deadly shelling in Balakliia, plus Russian advances near Orikhiv in Zaporizhzhia. Ukraine struck Russia’s Samara oil refinery and a drone warehouse in Donetsk. Zelenskiy also unveiled management shake-ups at state energy firms amid a $100m kickback probe. Finland warns no ceasefire before spring, Greenpeace criticizes France’s uranium trade, and Kyiv pursues POW swaps.

articles.title: Indifferent, nostalgic or plain pragmatic: Indonesia Gen Zs react to strongman Suharto’s national hero status
articles.trailText: Decision seen by some as ‘blatant whitewashing’ but many Gen Z have responded with indifference and even nostalgia
articles.summary: Following President Prabowo Subianto’s decision to designate former dictator Suharto a national hero, Indonesia’s Gen Z showed muted opposition, some expressing indifference or nostalgia for Suharto’s economic stability. Born after his 32-year authoritarian rule marked by mass killings, many young Indonesians lack formal education about his abuses, focusing instead on current cost-of-living pressures. Polling finds Gen Z views of Suharto more positive than negative, though less so than older cohorts. Critics with familial trauma decry “whitewashing,” while analysts warn of historical amnesia amid curriculum revisions emphasizing national pride.

articles.title: Schools close in New Zealand after play sand recalled over asbestos fears
articles.trailText: Six coloured sand products recalled in New Zealand after testing in Australia found asbestos in similar items
articles.summary: Multiple NZ schools and hundreds of early childhood centres have closed or sought guidance after tremolite asbestos was detected in coloured play sand sets sold by Kmart, including Magic Sand and sandcastle kits. A voluntary recall began after Australian tests found asbestos in similar products and expanded when additional batches tested positive. Officials advise halting use and professional disposal. As of Sunday, 150 schools and 90 centres contacted the education ministry; closures include Clearview Primary and Tuia Burnside. Authorities deem inhalation risk low but urge caution and testing; over 70 schools and preschools in Australia’s capital territory also shut.

articles.title: Far-right candidate José Antonio Kast favourite to become Chile’s next president after first round vote
articles.trailText: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel
articles.summary: Kast, a 59-year-old ultraconservative, advanced to Chile’s December 14 runoff after securing 24% in the November 17 first round; Communist former labour minister Jeannette Jara led with 26% but right-wing rivals’ 30% means broad conservative backing. Libertarian Johannes Kaiser (14%) and conservative Evelyn Matthei (13%) endorsed Kast, who pledges Trump-style “Chileans first” Escudo Fronterizo border walls to curb 500k+ Venezuelans and a Bukele-inspired crime crackdown. President Boric hailed the vote; US conservatives tout a regional right-wing surge.

articles.title: Shabana Mahmood warns Labour MPs ‘dark forces are stirring up anger’ over migration
articles.trailText: There is understood to be growing unease in party over home secretary’s sweeping overhaul of refugee rights
articles.summary: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood is set to unveil the most sweeping refugee rights overhaul in a generation, including biennial status reviews, restricted asylum appeals, tougher family life rules and expanded deportations. She warns “dark forces” could harness anger over illegal migration to fuel hate, urging MPs to unify. Proposals include three new safe routes with temporary status, visa bans threats for uncooperative states and ECHR reinterpretation prioritising public safety. Senior Labour figures fret over uprooted families and Windrush echoes, with legal challenges and backbench rebellion looming.

articles.title: Roman Abramovich makes claim of ‘conspiracy’ against Jersey government
articles.trailText: Move threatens to throw open parts of secretive legal battle on Channel island about ex-Chelsea owner’s wealth
articles.summary: Roman Abramovich has lodged a claim of conspiracy against the Jersey government after authorities opened a criminal probe in 2022 into alleged corruption and money laundering tied to his wealth. Following a Swiss court’s order to release banking records, he dropped his gagging order and forced ministers and officials to produce private messages and emails. The Royal Court master described Jersey’s conduct as “unreasonable” and ordered the government to pay Abramovich’s costs. Jersey froze over $7bn in assets post-Ukraine invasion and denies all conspiracy and bad-faith allegations.

articles.title: Iran says it could rejoin US nuclear talks if treated with ‘dignity and respect��
articles.trailText: Iran’s foreign minister says it has had requests to reopen negotiations, which collapsed after nuclear site bombings
articles.summary: Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi told the Guardian Tehran is prepared to restart nuclear negotiations with Washington provided it is treated with “dignity and respect”. He revealed intermediaries have offered to reopen talks that collapsed in June when Israeli-US strikes destroyed Iranian nuclear sites. Emphasising Iran’s military and psychological resilience, Araghchi reiterated Iran’s inalienable right to enrich uranium, denied undeclared facilities, and said a previous US-Iran-EU enrichment consortium is off the table but could return. No coherent offers have emerged yet, and UN inspections at bombed sites remain suspended for security reasons.

articles.title: Five people killed and three injured in car crash in County Louth, Ireland
articles.trailText: Gardaí appeal for witnesses and Simon Harris pays tribute to first responders after two-vehicle collision on Saturday
articles.summary: A two-vehicle collision near Dundalk, County Louth on Saturday evening killed five young people (three men and two women aged 21-23) traveling in a Volkswagen Golf and injured three others. Victims were named as Shay Duffy, Chloe McGee, Alan McCluskey, Dylan Commins and Chloe Hipson. Three survivors--one occupant of the Golf and two in a Toyota Land Cruiser--suffered non-life-threatening injuries. Taoiseach Micheál Martin and Tánaiste Simon Harris paid tribute to first responders and mourned the victims, while Gardaí appealed for witnesses or dashcam footage from 8:30-9:15pm. Ireland's road death toll has reached 157 this year.

articles.title: Zelenskyy pledges to clean up Ukraine’s energy sector amid corruption scandal
articles.trailText: President to overhaul state energy firms after $100m kickback scheme alleged by anti-corruption investigators
articles.summary: Ukraine’s president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, facing his worst scandal yet, announced a full overhaul of state energy firms after anti-corruption investigators uncovered a $100m Energoatom kickback scheme implicating senior officials and his former business partner Timur Mindich. He ordered new management at Energoatom, urgent legislation to reform the energy regulator and sacked implicated ministers. The reform pledge coincides with a US LNG import deal via Greece for winter, mounting EU accession pressure over corruption and upcoming military aid talks in France and Spain.

articles.title: Climate crisis or a warning from God? Iranians desperate for answers as water dries up
articles.trailText: As rainy season fails to bring relief, authorities try cloud seeding – while others across the country pray for a miracle
articles.summary: Iran faces an unprecedented drought: more than 20 provinces with zero rainfall since start of season, dam reserves plunge, snow cover down 98.6%. Authorities have launched cloud seeding after imams led rain prayers and MPs blamed moral decay and lax hijab enforcement for divine punishment. Critics cite climate change warnings ignored by authorities, including ex-EPA official Kaveh Madani. President Pezeshkian warns of possible mid-December evacuation of Tehran, while academics debate feasibility. Water rationing curbs use by 10%, but a 20% cut is needed. Environmental movement calls for practical adaptation measures.

articles.title: At least 120 hurt in gen Z protests over corruption and drug violence in Mexico
articles.trailText: Clashes erupt between protesters and riot police in the capital as rallies take place in cities across the country
articles.summary: Thousands of Gen Z protesters, many bearing the One Piece pirate flag, across Mexico—from Mexico City’s Zócalo to Guadalajara—clashed with riot police over corruption, drug violence and the Nov 1 assassination of Uruapan mayor Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez. In the capital, hooded demonstrators threw rocks, prompting police to use shields, batons, tear gas and fire extinguishers, injuring at least 120 people (100 officers, 20 protesters) and detaining 47 in Guadalajara. Journalists reported officer assaults. President Claudia Sheinbaum, despite high approval, denounced the violence amid claims of right-wing infiltration.

articles.title: ‘She went through hell’: widow of Chornobyl engineer is killed in Russian drone strike on Kyiv
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says Nataliia Khodymchuk is victim of ‘new tragedy caused by Kremlin’, four decades after disaster
articles.summary: Nataliia Khodemchuk, whose husband Valerii—the only Chornobyl reactor-4 engineer whose body was never recovered—was killed on Nov 16 when a Russian drone struck her Kyiv apartment block, known as Chornobyl House, killing six others. A Pripyat evacuee who raised two children, Oleh and Larysa, amid chronic health issues from radiation exposure, she had been due at a 40th-anniversary photoshoot. Zelenskiy condemned her death as “a new tragedy caused by the Kremlin” as Ukraine calls for reinforced air defenses against intensified drone and missile strikes on its energy infrastructure.

articles.title: This Palestinian human rights group was sanctioned by Trump. Its chief wishes US allies would take a stand
articles.trailText: Shawan Jabarin says US colleagues and funders have distanced themselves from West Bank-based Al-Haq over the sanctions
articles.summary: Since the Trump administration sanctioned West Bank–based Al-Haq in September for supporting ICC investigations of alleged Israeli crimes, its bank accounts were closed, US funders and partners withdrew, and platforms like YouTube, Meta and Mailchimp pulled services. Director Shawan Jabarin decries the silence of US human-rights groups and calls for defiance against what he terms “draconian” orders. Part of a broader crackdown on pro-Palestinian and civil-society organizations, Al-Haq vows to continue peaceful documentation of abuses.

articles.title: Caribbean reparations leaders in ‘historic’ first UK visit to press for justice
articles.trailText: CRC mission will seek to deepen public understanding of Britain’s colonial legacy and its lasting impact
articles.summary: From Nov 17-20, the Caricom Reparations Commission (CRC) makes its first official UK visit, led by chair Prof. Sir Hilary Beckles and Dr. Hilary Brown, to meet MPs, diplomats, academics and civil society. They seek formal apologies, financial reparations and debt cancellation for Britain’s transatlantic slavery, aiming to boost public understanding, correct misconceptions and forge strategic partnerships. The initiative follows UK rejection of payouts at the 2024 Commonwealth summit; a recent poll finds 63% of Britons back an apology, 40% financial reparations. CRC’s revised 10-point plan and petition to King Charles via the Privy Council will guide future legal claims.

articles.title: China sends coast guard to Senkaku islands amid row with Japan
articles.trailText: Activity around Japanese-held islands, also claimed by China, comes after PM Sanae Takaichi said Japan might respond militarily to an invasion of Taiwan
articles.summary: Following Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi’s warning of possible military response to a Chinese invasion of Taiwan, Beijing dispatched coastguard vessels through waters around the Senkaku/Diaoyu islands for “rights enforcement patrols” and flew military drones near Japan’s Yonaguni. Taiwan reported 30 Chinese warplanes, seven navy ships and a coastguard vessel operating near its air defense zone, prompting Taipei to scramble its assets. China summoned Japan’s ambassador, issued travel and study warnings and state media criticized Tokyo’s stance, heightening regional tensions with US allies.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Drones hit Russia’s Ryazan oil refinery
articles.trailText: Russian attacks kill four on Saturday; Serbian government faces deadline to oust Russian owners from state oil company. What we know on day 1,362
articles.summary: Ukraine’s military said it struck Russia’s Ryazan oil refinery 200 km southeast of Moscow with a 25-drone swarm to disrupt missile- and bomb-launch capabilities, triggering explosions and fire that Moscow officials attributed to falling debris. Meanwhile Russian strikes in Kherson and Zaporizhzhia killed four civilians. Washington warned Serbia to sever Russian majority ownership in NIS by Feb 13 or sustain sanctions, risking a winter energy crunch. Ukraine reports a tripling of rail attacks since July as Moscow targets logistics, and President Zelenskiy ordered an overhaul of state energy firms amid a $100 m graft scandal.

articles.title: Trump pressures Thailand to recommit to Cambodia ceasefire with ‘threat of tariffs’
articles.trailText: Bangkok had earlier said it was suspending ceasefire, accusing Cambodia of laying landmines along the border
articles.summary: After Thailand suspended its Donald Trump–brokered ceasefire with Cambodia over fresh landmine accusations—including a Thai soldier’s life-altering injury��Washington warned it would halt trade talks addressing a 19% tariff unless Bangkok recommits to the truce. On receipt of a US Trade Representative letter, Thai officials confirmed negotiations are paused pending reaffirmation, though another spokesperson later argued tariff discussions remain separate from border tensions. Trump, speaking aboard Air Force One, touted the “threat of tariffs” as instrumental in averting renewed hostilities along their contested colonial-era border, where July’s worst clashes killed dozens and displaced 300,000.

articles.title: Viktor Orbán begins ‘anti-war roadshow’ as Hungary gears up for 2026 elections
articles.trailText: PM makes opposition to support for Ukraine central to Fidesz campaign as it loses ground over cost of living crisis
articles.summary: Orbán has launched a weeks-long ��anti-war roadshow” in five Hungarian cities, positioning opposition to EU arms support for Ukraine as the centerpiece of Fidesz’s 2026 election campaign. He opened in Győr days after securing a US one-year sanction waiver from Trump, and continues to court ties with Putin. Meanwhile Péter Magyar’s Tisza party leads by 7% in polls amid public anger over inflation, healthcare and education. Analysts warn that foreign policy messaging may not offset the cost-of-living crisis at the ballot box.

articles.title: $170,000 a minute: why Saudi Arabia is the biggest blocker of climate action
articles.trailText: Desert kingdom depends on oil dollars but its people already face a climate ‘at the verge of livability’. What’s going on?
articles.summary: Saudi Arabia, propelled by oil super-profits from Aramco—$170k per minute—has systematically delayed global climate action at UN summits, wielding veto-style consensus rules and procedural smokescreens to block fossil-fuel phase-outs, carbon taxes and plastic caps. While investing domestically in solar and renewables to curb oil use at home and fund Vision2030, Riyadh’s economy and royal legitimacy hinge on exporting every barrel before demand collapses. Yet the kingdom faces “verge of livability” heat, drought and floods, making swift decarbonisation both an existential threat—and necessity.

articles.title: Israel breaching international law by limiting Gaza aid, says Unrwa official
articles.trailText: Natalie Boucly says supplies are ready but only about half of what is needed is getting into territory
articles.summary: In Brussels, UNRWA deputy commissioner Natalie Boucly accused Israel of breaching international humanitarian and human rights law—including the Fourth Geneva Convention and a 22 October ICJ advisory opinion—by allowing only about half of the 500–600 daily aid truckloads into Gaza. UNRWA holds enough food, tents and essentials for 6,000 trucks outside Gaza and could feed the population for three months, yet faces a $200 million funding shortfall. Boucly urged the EU and US to press Israel to lift restrictions, ensure unfettered aid flows, resume cooperation with UNRWA and back a political settlement to prevent further trauma, orphaned children’s vulnerabilities and the risk of renewed violence.

articles.title: Icelandic is in danger of dying out because of AI and English-language media, says former PM
articles.trailText: Katrín Jakobsdóttir and her co-author want the 350,000 people who speak the language to fight for its future
articles.summary: Former Icelandic PM Katrín Jakobsdóttir warns that Icelandic—with just 350,000 speakers—could vanish within a generation as AI models and English media supplant native usage. She and co-author Ragnar Jónasson call for urgent action: training AI on Icelandic texts, nationwide AI education pilots via an Anthropic–education ministry partnership, and a grassroots campaign to reinforce the language’s cultural value. Drawing on past Danish influence, she stresses that preserving Icelandic is crucial to national identity and urges governments to prioritize AI’s risks and opportunities for minority languages.

articles.title: Orbán’s claims of Trump summit triumph mask growing doubts over his grip on power
articles.trailText: Embattled Hungarian leader says he won an indefinite reprieve from sanctions on oil and gas from Russia, but the US has since disputed this
articles.summary: Visiting the White House last week, Hungarian PM Viktor Orbán claimed he secured an indefinite US exemption from sanctions on Russian oil and gas to shield Hungarians from rising energy costs ahead of next year’s elections. Washington counters it granted only a one-year waiver, with no binding deal formalized. Orbán also touted $600m of US LNG purchases, $700m in arms deals and a potential $20bn financial shield. Trump allies and Republican lawmakers remain skeptical of the terms and Orbán’s Russia ties, while Hungary’s opposition questions the reliance on verbal promises.

articles.title: From Hollywood to holy water: Pope Leo invites stars to the Vatican
articles.trailText: Observers say that welcoming of guests including Cate Blanchett, Monica Bellucci and Spike Lee is a move to raise pontiff’s profile
articles.summary: Pope Leo, the first US pope, hosted Hollywood stars—Cate Blanchett, Monica Bellucci, Chris Pine, Adam Scott—and directors Spike Lee, George Miller and Gus Van Sant at the Vatican’s Apostolic Palace. The audience, tied to the Jubilee of Artists, aims to boost Leo’s profile by deepening church-cinema dialogue. Ahead of the meeting, Leo revealed his favorite films (The Sound of Music; It’s a Wonderful Life; Ordinary People; Life Is Beautiful). Observers say this PR push follows earlier high-profile audiences (e.g., Robert De Niro, Al Pacino, Jannik Sinner) to cast the modest pontiff in a more visible, culturally engaged light.

articles.title: Russia increasingly targeting trains as attacks on Ukraine’s rail network intensify
articles.trailText: Ukrainian minister says more than 800 attacks recorded since start of year as Moscow seeks to destroy country’s logistical capabilities
articles.summary: Since Jan 2025 Ukraine has recorded 800 attacks — tripling since July — on its rail network, damaging over 3,000 assets and causing $1bn loss, Deputy PM Oleksii Kuleba reports. Russia uses precise Shahed drones to strike locomotives, drivers, targeting cargo including grain exports, passenger transit and military aid shipments. Ukrzaliznytsia head Oleksandr Pertsovskyi says new electronic counter-drone systems and air-defence teams deployed. Key junctions like Lozova, vital for routes to Dnipro, Sloviansk, Poltava and Kharkiv, have been struck. Swift rail repairs offset track damage, but rolling stock attrition risks crippling logistics to southern ports, Chernihiv/Sumy frontlines and the Donbas.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: mass production of Ukrainian ‘Octopus’ interceptor drones begins
articles.trailText: Defence ministry says locally developed technology tested in combat and shown to work against Russia’s deadly Shaheds. What we know on day 1,361
articles.summary: Ukraine’s defence ministry announced the start of mass production of domestically developed “Octopus” interceptor drones—three manufacturers are online with 11 more ready—tested in combat at night, under jamming and low altitude, as Kiev seeks to build 1,000 units daily to counter Russia’s escalating Shahed attacks. Last night’s wave—430 drones and 18 missiles—killed six in Kyiv, damaged dozens of buildings including the Azerbaijani embassy. Ukrainian intelligence reports Russia plans 120,000 glide bombs this year, firing 200–250 daily. Kyiv also struck Novorossiysk port, Saratov refinery and Engels fuel depot. President Zelensky will visit Madrid after Paris.

articles.title: Kashmir is focus of arrests after Delhi car blast linked to ‘terror module’
articles.trailText: Investigators believe an explosion that killed 13 people may be linked to group operating in the disputed region
articles.summary: Police raids across Kashmir have led to seven arrests after a Delhi car bomb killed 13. Authorities suspect a transnational “terror module” linked to Jaish-e-Mohammad and an Islamic State affiliate, involving radicalized professionals—two Kashmiri doctors among detainees. Investigators seized 2.9 tonnes of explosives, chemicals and weapons during a Haryana raid. The National Investigation Agency has taken over, treating Monday’s rush-hour explosion near a major monument as terrorism. Following a hospital blast in Srinagar killing seven, security forces remain on high alert, while Modi vows to hunt down all culprits.

articles.title: The scientist who helped win the fight to protect a sacred piece of the Pacific
articles.trailText: Respected ocean expert Katy Soapi continues to advocate to protect Tetepare, one of the last untouched places in Solomon Islands
articles.summary: Ocean scientist Katy Soapi, the first Solomon Islander woman with a PhD in natural sciences, led the grassroots Friends of Tetepare movement into the Tetepare Descendants’ Association to halt commercial logging on sacred Tetepare island. Blending ancestral knowledge and conservation science, she secured national and global support—highlighted in the Australian documentary Since the Company Came—and helped win legal protection. Today TDA manages Tetepare’s intact rainforest, clear rivers and nesting turtles through community rangers and eco-lodge revenues. Ongoing advocacy by Soapi and descendants fends off new development pressures, making Tetepare a Pacific-led conservation model.

articles.title: US military planning for divided Gaza with ‘green zone’ secured by international and Israeli troops
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Almost all Palestinians have been displaced to ‘red zone’ where no reconstruction is planned
articles.summary: US military planning envisions Gaza split into an Israeli/international ‘green zone’ for phased reconstruction and a ‘red zone’ left devastated, displacing nearly 2M Palestinians. A proposed 20,000-strong UN-mandated International Stabilization Force (ISF) — initially staffed by Israeli, European, Jordanian, and other partners but without US ground troops — would secure the green zone east of Israel’s current ‘yellow line’. Plans for fenced ‘alternative safe communities’ were scrapped as fluid. Large-scale rebuilding, Israeli withdrawal, UN resolution passage, and Palestinian self-rule lack timelines, risking a protracted limbo. Over 80% of Gaza’s infrastructure is destroyed, and Israeli restriction of items deemed dual-use hampers aid.

articles.title: Patricia Crowther obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Member of the Wicca religion who promoted ‘the Craft’ through books, interviews and lectures
articles.summary: Patricia Crowther, who died aged 97, was a pioneering elder of Wicca, known as “the Craft.” Born in Sheffield, she worked in theatre before marrying magician Arnold Crowther in 1956; he introduced her to Wicca founder Gerald Gardner. Initiated and handfasted in 1960, the Crowthers founded the Sheffield coven in 1961, now ancestral to thousands of initiates. Patricia co-hosted a 1971 BBC radio series, authored influential books (e.g., The Witches Speak, Lid Off the Cauldron) and lectured internationally. Survived by partner Ian Lilleyman, she leaves a global legacy in modern paganism.

articles.title: Russian attacks on Kyiv ‘calculated and wicked’, says Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: Pictures posted on social media showed different sites in flames and residents gathering in rubble-strewn streets outside apartment buildings
articles.summary: President Zelenskyy condemned Russia’s Nov 14 night assault on Kyiv as “deliberate, calculated and wicked” after Shahed drone swarms and 18 missiles killed six and injured dozens across every district. Air-raid sirens drove residents into shelters as Ukraine’s air defenses shot down hundreds of drones, but multiple apartment blocks—including one on the left bank—and the Azerbaijani embassy were struck. Kyiv’s heating network and power lines were disrupted. Zelenskyy appealed to Europe and the US for additional air-defense batteries, celebrated Ukraine’s first Long Neptune missile strike on Novorossiysk oil terminals, and renewed his plea for US Tomahawks amid global condemnation.

articles.title: AfD hails US ban on European leftwing groups as historians fear crackdown on anti-fascists
articles.trailText: German far-right party urges Berlin and other European nations to also designate ‘antifa’ groups as terrorist organisations
articles.summary: Germany’s far-right AfD praised the US State Department’s decision to list Germany’s Antifa Ost, Italy’s International Revolutionary Front (Fai/Fri) and two Greek cells as terrorist groups, and urged Berlin to adopt similar bans. The designation entails US asset freezes and travel bans for members. Historians warn it conjoins distinct anti-fascist and insurrectionist groups, from black-clad activists to peaceful campaigns, threatening broader repression of left-wing dissent. Antifa Ost’s key member Maja T faces up to 23 years in Hungary after alleged attacks.

articles.title: South Africa to investigate ‘mysterious’ arrival of 153 Palestinians on plane
articles.trailText: Passengers held on runway for 12 hours after landing in Johannesburg without travel documents
articles.summary: South Africa’s president Cyril Ramaphosa has ordered a probe into the ‘mysterious’ November 14 arrival of 153 Palestinians at OR Tambo Airport from Kenya, held on the tarmac for 12 hours by border police for lacking departure stamps, return tickets or accommodation details. None had sought asylum; a pastor recounted children “screaming and crying” in sweltering heat. Gift of the Givers says this is the second recent influx, accusing an unregistered broker of exploiting Gaza residents. Authorities later admitted 130 under a 90-day visa waiver; 23 flew onward. The incident reignites debate over South Africa’s pro-Palestinian stance and national security.

articles.title: Polls of western countries find deep dissatisfaction with democracy
articles.trailText: Ipsos survey reveals fake news, lack of accountability, extremism and corruption seen as biggest threats
articles.summary: Ipsos polled 10,000 people in nine western democracies, finding <50% satisfaction in all but Sweden (65%). Satisfaction rates: US 20%, UK 26%, France 19%, Italy 29%, Spain 27%, Croatia 18%; Netherlands (36% vs 37% dissatisfied), Poland (40% vs 31%). Majorities worry democracy will worsen (France 86%, Spain 80%, UK/Poland 75%). Top threats: fake news, lack of accountability, extremism, corruption—disinformation cited in France (56%), UK (64%), Sweden (67%), Netherlands(75%), Poland (76%); corruption in US (63%), Spain (73%), Croatia (80%), Italy (47%). Despite strong democratic ideals, >50% favour radical change and seek anti-corruption laws, social media regulation, civic education, judicial independence, prefer consensus-building leaders.

articles.title: Carney’s ‘nation-building’ programme misses mark to be truly transformative for Canada
articles.trailText: The $C56bn plan focused on investing in a resource economy falls short of changing Canadians’ day-to-day lives
articles.summary: Mark Carney’s government unveiled C$56 billion in fast-tracked ‘nation-building’ projects focusing on mines, LNG and a 280 mile power line in BC to secure private investment. The first cohort, announced in September, includes critical-mineral mines, a BC LNG terminal, an Ontario nickel mine, a New Brunswick mine, a Quebec graphite battery plant and an Iqaluit hydroelectric project, plus a conservation corridor to the Yukon. Critics say the resource-heavy slate lacks everyday infrastructure—public transit, water systems, housing—and misses an opportunity to reimagine Canada’s future beyond its traditional strengths. No new oil pipelines or Ontario highway tunnel were included as Carney prioritizes fast returns before a 2030 deadline.

articles.title: Venezuela’s Maduro urges Trump to avoid Afghanistan-style ‘forever war’
articles.trailText: Authoritarian leader calls for US to make peace amid military buildup and strikes against alleged drug smuggling boats
articles.summary: In Caracas outside Miraflores, President Nicolás Maduro implored President Trump to avoid an Afghanistan-style ‘forever war’ as the USS Gerald R. Ford arrived and US strikes on suspected drug-smuggling boats intensified. His peace appeal came alongside Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth’s unveiling of Operation Southern Spear—a rebranded ‘war on drugs’ targeting Caribbean narco-terrorists despite Venezuela’s negligible role in cocaine or fentanyl trafficking. Observers view the largest US deployment since Panama 1989 as a bid to oust Maduro. Reports say senior US officials offered Trump strike options on Venezuelan soil. Caracas has drafted guerrilla-war and ‘anarchisation’ plans, and Foreign Minister Yván Gil warned the North American ‘empire’ that Venezuela is ready to resist any assault.

articles.title: Dick Harris obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Disability sector worker who served in various roles at Scope and Leonard Cheshire
articles.summary: Dick Harris, who died aged 71, spent his life championing independent living for people with disabilities. Born with cerebral palsy in Wrexham and raised in institutions, he moved in 1979 to accessible Camden flats, organized disability holiday breaks, and served as volunteer coordinator at the Islington Disabled Association. From 1987 to 2005 he held various roles at Scope before joining Leonard Cheshire until retirement in 2020, continuing local volunteer work until his death from kidney cancer. He fought for care funding, pioneered Access to Work–supported independence, married volunteer Angi Donnelly in 1981, raised two sons, and leaves three grandchildren and a newfound half-brother.

articles.title: British-Egyptian activist stopped from flying to UK, says family
articles.trailText: Egyptian authorities prevented Alaa Abd el-Fattah from attending human rights awards in London
articles.summary: Alaa Abd el-Fattah, the British-Egyptian writer and human rights campaigner pardoned by President Sisi in September after over a decade in jail for “spreading fake news,” was barred by Egyptian passport control from flying to London. He had planned to attend the Magnitsky awards—where his sister Sanaa Seif accepted their Courage Under Fire prize—and reunite with his 13-year-old son in Brighton. His travel status remains unclear amid ongoing talks with authorities, while their mother, Laila Soueif, recently ended a 287-day hunger strike for his release.

articles.title: Friday briefing: Inside the dispute driving resident doctors back to the picket line
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As England’s doctors plan further walkouts, we look at what’s at stake for patients, the NHS and the health secretary, Wes Streeting
articles.summary: In England, around 13–14 years’ experience doctors known as resident doctors (formerly juniors) have resumed strikes over pay and training bottlenecks. They argue their real incomes have fallen by over 20% since 2008 despite a 29% pay rise in three years, and now seek a further 26% restoration. They also face blocked pathways to specialty training. More than one million outpatient appointments and planned surgeries have been cancelled across 12 walkouts. Health secretary Wes Streeting has condemned BMA demands as “unreasonable”, but with no quick fix, further monthly strikes loom into 2026.

articles.title: The UK wants to emulate Denmark’s hardline asylum model – but what does it actually look like?
articles.trailText: Denmark has slashed asylum numbers by granting only short-term status and by targeting ‘ghettoes’, which critics say has damaged the country’s values
articles.summary: Denmark switched in 2015 from five- to seven-year refugee permits to one- to two-year temporary status with no automatic path to permanence; refugees must learn Danish and hold full-time jobs to qualify for permanent residency. Asylum arrivals plunged from about 14,800 in 2014 to roughly 2,100 in 2021. Critics argue this deterrence strategy—a centre-left consensus that includes ‘parallel societies’ demolition laws—undermines integration and human rights. The UK Labour government is considering adopting elements amid ageing populations and rising populism.

articles.title: Two hours a night: Japan PM’s sleep schedule prompts concerns about work-life balance
articles.trailText: Takaichi caused a stir last week after she summoned aides to her office for a 3am meeting to prepare for a budget committee hearing
articles.summary: Japan's prime minister, Sanae Takaichi, admits she survives on just two to four hours' sleep per night, echoing Margaret Thatcher, after summoning aides for a 3am budget prep meeting. Her extreme schedule spotlights Japan's chronic overwork culture, blamed for karoshi and low birth rates. Critics worry she'll raise overtime caps despite pledging to prioritize worker health and work-life balance. Since becoming the first female PM in October, Takaichi has juggled ASEAN and APEC summits, a US state visit, and a brewing Taiwan Strait row with China.

articles.title: ‘Reframes history’: fears Māori knowledge diluted in plan to revise New Zealand curriculum
articles.trailText: Minister rejects claims Māori history is being sidelined in rewrite which includes cutting some references to the Treaty of Waitangi
articles.summary: New Zealand’s government has proposed revising the primary-to-junior-high history curriculum, cutting references to the Treaty of Waitangi, Māori words and indigenous perspectives in favour of a ‘discipline-driven’, eurocentric approach. Critics—teachers, principals like Adrianne McAllister, academics including Nepia Mahuika and Vincent O’Malley—warn the changes erase Māori knowledge, re-introduce rigid methods and sideline foundational Māori history taught since 2023. Education Minister Erica Stanford and ACT leader David Seymour defend the reform as ‘balanced’, knowledge-rich and aimed at lifting OECD rankings, while Māori educators fear a step backwards in cultural inclusion and critical thinking.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Flamingo flies into battle, Zelenskyy defers to commanders over Pokrovsk
articles.trailText: President suggests leaders on the ground will decide whether holding city is costing too many lives; Kyiv apartments hit in ‘massive’ attack. What we know on day 1,360
articles.summary: Ukrainian forces used domestically made Flamingo (FP-5) cruise missiles and drones to strike several dozen targets in Russian-occupied Crimea and Zaporizhzhia, hitting oil terminals, airfields, radar stations and forward command posts inside occupied territory and Russia. In retaliation, Russia launched a ‘massive’ drone and missile assault on Kyiv, damaging apartment blocks. Gen. Oleksandr Syrskyi visited frontline units defending Pokrovsk, saying no encirclement exists and deferring any withdrawal decision to commanders on the ground. President Zelenskyy pledged support for troops, stressed civilian safety, and hailed EU’s €6bn loan commitment.

articles.title: Canada says Russia and China are ramping up spy efforts in Arctic region
articles.trailText: Canada’s spy agency says it has observed intelligence threats targeting country’s government and private sector
articles.summary: CSIS director Dan Rogers warns Russia and China have a significant intelligence interest in Canada’s Arctic, conducting cyber and human collection against both government and private sectors. With melting ice opening navigable routes and rich critical minerals, Canada has proposed C$1 billion for airports, seaports, roads, plus new icebreakers and patrol submarines. CSIS also disrupted Russia-linked front companies seeking Canadian goods for Ukraine, and says Chinese agents tried recruiting Canadians with military know-how. For the first time Rogers confirmed the agency foiled lethal Iranian plots targeting dissidents on Canadian soil.

articles.title: ‘The pain remains’: France remembers victims of 2015 Paris attacks
articles.trailText: Bells ring out across French capital marking 10th anniversary of country’s deadliest peacetime attack
articles.summary: On Nov 13, 2025, France marked the 10th anniversary of the 2015 Paris attacks that killed 130 people at Bataclan, restaurants and the Stade de France. President Macron visited each site, rang bells and vowed to foil threats—85 attacks prevented in a decade—and punish perpetrators. Survivors and relatives gathered for a ceremony where Life for Paris president hailed their shared resolve. Eagles of Death Metal’s Jesse Hughes sang “You’ll Never Walk Alone.” Sole surviving attacker Salah Abdeslam, serving life, may engage in restorative justice talks. France plans a terrorism memorial museum in 2029 showcasing artifacts from the attacks.

articles.title: Serbia secretly agreed deal with Jared Kushner firm to develop protected Belgrade site
articles.trailText: Government established joint venture with Trump’s son-in-law in February 2024 to build hotel, apartments and museum complex
articles.summary: Leaked Feb 2024 agreement shows Serbia and Jared Kushner’s Atlantic Incubation formed a joint venture (Kushner 77.5%, state 22.5%) to redevelop Belgrade’s protected 1999-bombed armed forces HQ—Nikola Dobrović’s sole modernist work—into a hotel, apartments and museum. A new law strips cultural status, requires demolition by May 2025 or lets the US firm terminate with penalties; grants a 99-year lease convertible to ownership. The opaque deal spurred mass protests, human chains and media freedom threats amid Vučić’s push to ease US sanctions over Russian oil ties.

articles.title: Irish government announces plan to build 300,000 homes within five years
articles.trailText: Proposal includes 72,000 social homes to tackle housing crisis, but critics call it ‘old wine in a new bottle’
articles.summary: The Irish government unveiled an ambitious five-year plan to build 300,000 homes — including 72,000 social units — by 2030, backed by €28.2bn for land zoning, construction capacity, water, wastewater and power infrastructure. Measures include converting vacant shops, refurbishing derelict properties and creating a housing activation office to unblock planning and delivery bottlenecks, with dedicated support for homeless and vulnerable groups. Critics from Sinn Féin and trade unions denounced it as a repackaged failure, highlighting the removal of annual targets and underestimation of actual demand.

articles.title: Germany decides against conscription to replenish post-cold war military
articles.trailText: Voluntary model with incentives will instead aim to attract young people into forces in face of growing Russian threat
articles.summary: Germany’s new coalition has opted against reinstating universal conscription, choosing a voluntary enlistment model with incentives—free driving licences, €2,600 pre-tax entry pay and other benefits—and mandatory registration (medical screening and questionnaire) for all 18-year-olds from 2026. Women may volunteer but are exempt from obligatory steps. If voluntary numbers fall short of targets to expand the Bundeswehr from 180,000 to 270,000 active troops plus 200,000 reservists by 2029, parliament could activate a ‘needs-based’ draft through new legislation. The move responds to mounting Russian threats, US pressure for higher European defence contributions and debates between CDU and SPD over rebuilding Germany’s post-Cold-War military capacity.

articles.title: EU court rules non-alcoholic drinks cannot be called gin
articles.trailText: Judges in Luxembourg say EU law prohibits use of term ‘non-alcoholic gin’, in case brought by German lobby group
articles.summary: In a case brought by German lobby group Verband Sozialer Wettbewerb, the EU’s Court of Justice in Luxembourg ruled that only juniper-flavoured spirits with at least 37.5% ABV may be called “gin,” banning labels such as “non-alcoholic gin” under the 2019 spirits regulation. PB Vi Goods’ “Virgin Gin Alkoholfrei” product was deemed misleading despite its qualifier. The judgment, aimed at protecting consumers, ensuring fair competition and safeguarding the EU’s spirits reputation, could slow growth in the bloc’s booming alcohol-free drinks market.

articles.title: ‘The car belongs in Berlin’: city backpedaling on bike-friendly policies, critics say
articles.trailText: Car-critical measures have been slashed since the conservative CDU came into power in 2023, triggering protests and dividing communities
articles.summary: Since the CDU-SPD coalition took power in 2023, Berlin has reversed several bike- and pedestrian-friendly measures: a Friedrichstrasse pedestrian pilot was scrapped, 2026–27 budgets for cycle lanes and safer school routes were halved to €2.6 m, parking permits remain capped at €10/year, speed limits on 20 major streets rose to 50 km/h, and bike-share subsidies may vanish. Critics say the city is reverting to its postwar “car-friendly” model, lagging behind Paris or Copenhagen. Controversial plans to extend the A100 autobahn and redesign Torstrasse—cutting mature trees but retaining four traffic lanes—have sparked protests from residents and businesses fearing a loss of public space and quality of life.

articles.title: ‘Trumpist’ Czech PM-elect refuses to sell business empire amid conflict-of-interest row
articles.trailText: Billionaire populist Andrej Babiš insists he will meet legal obligations before taking office but does not explain how
articles.summary: Czech PM-designate Andrej Babiš has refused to sell his Agrofert conglomerate despite EU and Czech rules barring ministers from holding firms that receive state or EU support. President Petr Pavel demands specific measures to resolve Babiš’s conflict-of-interest before appointing him, citing a 2020 constitutional court ruling. Babiš vows to comply with Czech and EU law but won’t outline his plan. Transparency International says he must divest, reject public contracts, or abandon office. His ANO party leads a coalition with the far-right SPD and Motorists for Themselves. Pavel also seeks explicit NATO and Ukraine support from the incoming government.

articles.title: State-sanctioned fuel smuggling cost Libya $20bn over three years – report
articles.trailText: Policy body calls for western-backed investigation into oil officials known to be at heart of illegal enterprise
articles.summary: Sentry's report finds that state-sanctioned fuel smuggling in Libya from 2022-24 cost $20bn in lost revenue, orchestrated by politicians and security leaders under NOC chair Farhat Bengdara’s swap system. Refined fuel imports rose from 20.4m to over 41m litres/day, with more than half diverted abroad—into Sudan, Chad, Tunisia, Europe and Turkey—profiting criminal networks and prolonging Sudan's war. The scheme deprived the central bank of revenues, deepened domestic shortages, and enriched kleptocrats. Sentry urges a western-backed probe into corrupt oil officials. NOC claims it ended swaps in March 2025 amid falling fuel quality.

articles.title: Mexico takes action to combat sexual abuse after president publicly groped
articles.trailText: Secretary for women presents plan, including prison sentences, after Claudia Sheinbaum was groped on street
articles.summary: After Mexico’s president Claudia Sheinbaum was publicly groped, Secretary for Women Citlalli Hernández unveiled a national plan to combat sexual abuse, including uniform prison sentences across all 32 states, mandatory prosecutorial training, and multi-sectoral awareness campaigns in schools, workplaces, public transport and communities. Seven in ten Mexican women report violence in their lifetime; 25,000 harassment complaints and over 500 femicides this year underscore the crisis. Legislators will align state penal codes with federal law (6–10 years’ imprisonment), while activists warn legal reforms alone won’t suffice, urging long-term educational and cultural shifts in masculinity.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Is Wes Streeting a traitor or a faithful?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: By publicly accusing the health secretary of leading a coup, Starmer’s aides have scored a massive own goal, making the PM’s position seem all the more shaky
articles.summary: Wes Streeting, the UK health secretary, swiftly denied claims he was plotting a leadership challenge against PM Keir Starmer, quipping he’s a ‘faithful’. A late-night No 10 leak warning of ‘feral’ MPs spectacularly backfired, exposing internal paranoia and denting Starmer’s command of the narrative after the budget. Guardian deputy political editor Jessica Elgot argues the fiasco reflects Starmer’s struggle to define a clear vision, fueling renewed speculation around rivals including Streeting, Andy Burnham, Bridget Phillipson, Shabana Mahmood and Angela Rayner. Streeting’s on-air agility contrasts with an unclear policy agenda, intensifying questions over Labour’s unity.

articles.title: Amid Japan’s surge in bear attacks, a torrent of AI-generated videos is adding to anxiety
articles.trailText: Videos show schoolgirls fighting off animals, while others show people feeding bears, with some so realistic that users struggled to distinguish between fact and fiction
articles.summary: Amid record-high bear attacks in Japan this year—13 fatalities and over 100 injuries—experts warn that a flood of AI-generated videos on social media is heightening public anxiety and risking safety. On platforms like TikTok, around 60% of sampled clips are fake, showing bears destroying solar panels, carrying pets, or interacting with humans in realistic scenes that blur fact and fiction. These misleading videos could undermine official guidance to avoid feeding or confronting 130–400 kg bears just as poor natural food supply and urban encroachment drive animals into towns, prompting service suspensions and military-assisted culls.

articles.title: Putin opponents criticise EU ban on multi-entry visas for Russians
articles.trailText: Restrictions for entry to Schengen zone announced last Friday because of sabotage attacks linked to Russia
articles.summary: EU’s recent ban on multi-entry Schengen visas for Russian citizens, announced by foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas as a response to Russian drone incursions and sabotage, has drawn ire from exiled opposition figures. Ilya Yashin denounced it as punishing ordinary Russians while elites evade restrictions, undermining anti-war activists. Journalist Sergey Parkhomenko called the move “idiotic” and ineffective. Exceptions for relatives, human rights workers and journalists exist but risk exposing opponents to Kremlin retaliation. Member states like Hungary and Italy are enforcing the ban. Ukrainian and EU officials welcomed the measure as collective accountability for Russia’s aggression in Ukraine.

articles.title: Fatal clash on Thai-Cambodia border after Trump-brokered peace deal breaks down
articles.trailText: The truce broke down this week after a Thai soldier lost a leg to a landmine blast, prompting Thailand’s PM to say the peace deal was ‘now over’
articles.summary: Days after a Trump-brokered truce in Malaysia, a Thai soldier lost a foot to a landmine, leading Thailand to suspend the ceasefire. Cross-border gunfire between Sa Kaeo (Thailand) and Banteay Meanchey (Cambodia) wounded civilians, killed one in Prey Chan and echoed July’s five-day clashes that left 43 dead and 300,000 displaced—worst in a decade. Thai PM Anutin Charnvirakul declared the peace deal over, while Cambodian PM Hun Manet decried attacks on civilians. Underlying colonial-era map disputes over temples remain unresolved, despite US threats to withhold trade privileges to enforce peace.

articles.title: Bill to restrict abortions later in pregnancy defeated in South Australia after emotional debate
articles.trailText: Amendment would have watered down law to allow abortion only where it would save life of mother or another foetus, or for significant risk of abnormalities
articles.summary: South Australia’s parliament narrowly rejected an amendment (11–8) to ban virtually all abortions after 22 weeks 6 days except to save a mother’s life or for severe fetal abnormality. Former One Nation MLC Sarah Game, working with anti-abortion campaigner Joanna Howe (now barred amid intimidation allegations), faced tearful debate. Attorney-General Kyam Maher and RANZCOG decried the proposal as medically ill-informed. Opponents warned it would deny care in rape, domestic violence or health-risk cases; supporters called it a compassionate safeguard. Critics branded it ‘forced birth’ and part of imported US anti-abortion tactics, following earlier failed state and federal moves.

articles.title: Alleged gambling kingpin linked to scam centres extradited from Thailand to China
articles.trailText: She Zhijiang’s empire includes gambling complex Shwe Kokko that US has tied to regional scam and trafficking networks
articles.summary: She Zhijiang, accused by Beijing of operating over 200 illegal online gambling sites and a $15 billion Shwe Kokko casino complex on the Thai–Myanmar border, was extradited from Bangkok after Thai courts upheld an Interpol red notice. He faces charges in China for running illegal casinos, money laundering and using Myanmar as a base. The US has sanctioned nine entities tied to Shwe Kokko for links to regional scam and trafficking networks, and imposed fresh sanctions on a Myanmar militia over cyber scams and human trafficking.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Fire sale of Lukoil assets before start of US sanctions on Russia
articles.trailText: Foreign properties may be nationalised if Lukoil doesn’t sell, or the proceeds frozen if it does; Zelenskyy grapples with corruption scandal fallout. What we know on day 1,359
articles.summary: With US sanctions on Lukoil assets looming on 21 November, Russia’s state-linked oil major is racing to offload refineries—from KazMunayGas weighing a Kazakhstan bid to Shell eyeing deepwater assets in Ghana and Nigeria—amid threats of nationalisation in Moldova, Bulgaria and Egypt. On day 1,359 of the Ukraine war, Russian troops overran three Zaporizhzhia settlements, pressing fiercely near Pokrovsk, Kupiansk and Lyman as civilians flee. Kyiv Mayor Klitschko urged lowering conscription to 22, while President Zelenskyy dismissed two ministers in a graft scandal and called for sanctions on ally-turned-suspect Timur Mindich.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Top banker’s straight talk to Putin over troubled economy
articles.trailText: Sberbank head German Gref gives unusually frank assessment; Zaporizhzhia situation has ‘significantly worsened’, says Syrskyi. What we know on day 1,358
articles.summary: Sberbank chief German Gref told Putin Russia’s economy faces ‘challenging macro conditions’, modest bank growth and loan shrinkage, marking a rare high-level admission of weakness. Ukraine’s Gen Oleksandr Syrskyi reported ‘significantly worsened’ fighting in Zaporizhzhia with Russia capturing three settlements. Kyiv struck an oil refinery in Orsk, and Romania found drone fragments near its NATO border after Russian strikes. Lavrov denied US allegations of secret nuclear tests, inviting seismic checks. Serbia negotiates a Russian exit from NIS under US sanctions. Ukraine seeks prisoner-swap talks in Istanbul, plans to boost imports to 2,300 MW and ousted Energoatom’s board amid graft probes. The UK will ban services for Russian LNG exports from 2026.

articles.title: China sharpens its language on Taiwan as part of ‘longer-term’ strategy
articles.trailText: A series of statements, articles, photos and even a new national holiday indicate a shift in Beijing’s stance over the island, analysts say
articles.summary: Analysts say Beijing is escalating its Taiwan messaging as part of a two- to three-year ‘longer-term’ strategy, deploying sharper rhetoric in state-media explainer articles, designating 25 October as ‘Retrocession Day,’ and sharing ‘under one sky’ high-def satellite photos to underscore sovereignty claims. New texts propose ‘one country, two systems’ rule under vetted ‘patriots,’ vow to remove secessionist threats, and rebuke foreign calls to preserve the status quo. Experts see this as normalizing previously restrained actions ahead of potential US–China talks.

articles.title: MPs call for release of 15 penguins ‘trapped’ at London aquarium
articles.trailText: Cross-party group wants environment secretary to urgently examine moving the birds to a facility ‘better aligned with their needs’
articles.summary: Seventy-five MPs across parties have urged environment secretary Emma Reynolds to relocate 15 gentoo penguins held at Sea Life London Aquarium in a 2.1m-deep indoor pool described as ‘un-British’ for lacking daylight and fresh air. Led by Labour’s David Taylor, the open letter cites 37,000-strong petition support and endorsements from Chris Packham and Feargal Sharkey. Merlin Entertainments, part-owned by Blackstone and CPP Investment Board, defends its climate-controlled Penguin Point as meeting UK zoo standards, while ministers promise an overhaul of animal welfare regulations and a new strategy later this year.

articles.title: Israel attacked Palestinian water sources over 250 times in five years, data reveals
articles.trailText: Armed forces and settlers used bombs, dogs, poison and machinery to attack people and infrastructure at key sites
articles.summary: From 2020–2025 Israeli forces and settlers attacked Palestinian water infrastructure over 250 times. Between Jan 2024 and mid-2025 alone they struck at least 90 drinking, irrigation and sanitation sites in the West Bank and Gaza using bombs, poison, dogs and heavy machinery. Sniper fire killed eight in Gaza in Feb 2024; airstrikes destroyed school latrines and a desalination unit in April. An estimated 90% of Gaza’s water and sanitation facilities are damaged or inaccessible. UN experts call these systematic assaults war crimes and part of a genocidal, apartheid strategy. Pacific Institute data shows global water-related violence surging amid climate stress.

articles.title: Milan prosecutors investigate alleged ‘sniper tourism’ during Bosnian war
articles.trailText: Groups from Italy and elsewhere alleged to have paid Serb soldiers to shoot Sarajevo residents during siege
articles.summary: Milan prosecutors led by Alessandro Gobbi opened a probe into Italians accused of paying Bosnian Serb soldiers from Radovan Karadžić’s army large sums to travel into Sarajevo’s hills during the 1992–96 siege and randomly kill civilians as ‘sniper tourists.’ More than 10,000 died under sniper fire in the longest modern siege. Triggered by writer Ezio Gavazzeni’s complaint and ex-mayor Benjamina Karić’s report, the case aims to charge suspects with voluntary murder aggravated by cruelty and abject motives, tracing networks via Trieste and Belgrade to sniper positions exposed in the documentary Sarajevo Safari.

articles.title: China removes two popular gay dating apps from Apple and Android stores
articles.trailText: Withdrawal of Blued and Finka raises fears of further crackdowns on LGBT rights amid growing restrictions
articles.summary: China this week delisted two leading gay dating apps, Blued and its 2020 acquisition Finka, from its Apple and major Android storefronts under a Cyberspace Administration order—though existing users can still access them and both remain on their own websites. Apple said it had complied with local law. The move stokes fears of a wider LGBT crackdown after years of shrinking public spaces and suspended Pride events. Advocates warn that silencing online communities further isolates sexual minorities in an already constrained environment.

articles.title: Catherine Connolly sworn in as Ireland’s president on day of pomp and celebration
articles.trailText: New president pledges ‘all voices’ will be heard and vows to promote climate action, tolerance and a Gaelic revival
articles.summary: Catherine Connolly, a 68-year-old independent leftwing former barrister, was sworn in Ireland’s 10th president at Dublin Castle with a 21-gun salute, pledging to champion diversity, climate action, decolonisation and a Gaelic revival. After winning 64% in a shock landslide that energised young voters, she vowed a 'republic worthy of its name' where all voices are heard, invoking colonial legacy, neutrality amid EU security talks and the Good Friday Agreement, and declaring Irish 'first place' at Áras an Uachtaráin.

articles.title: Men with family stuck in Gaza say lack of action from UK government is breach of human rights
articles.trailText: Two fathers in Britain enlist law firm to get government to follow through on evacuation promises made months ago
articles.summary: Two British fathers have launched legal action against the UK government for failing to reunite them with relatives in Gaza after promising evacuation months ago. Represented by Leigh Day, they argue this breaches their families’ human rights and contrasts with limited evacuations of injured children and scholarship students. Blocked by the absence of a Gaza visa centre and unfulfilled biometric checks in Jordan, their loved ones now live in tents amid food shortages, violence and a death toll exceeding 67,000. The Foreign Office declines comment during ongoing proceedings.

articles.title: Indian police investigating fatal Delhi car blast under anti-terror law
articles.trailText: Statements from government ministers suggest they do not see explosion that killed eight people as an accident
articles.summary: Delhi police, invoking anti-terror legislation, are probing a car blast outside the Red Fort that killed eight and injured around twenty during peak evening traffic. Officials cite CCTV showing the masked driver parking the Hyundai for hours; two suspects have been detained. Home Minister Amit Shah and PM Modi vow to pursue perpetrators under the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act. The case is now with the National Investigation Agency, and forensic explosives analysis is pending while Delhi and Mumbai remain on high alert.

articles.title: German man with alleged neo-Nazi links arrested over darknet assassination calls
articles.trailText: Prosecutor says suspect ran platform with lists of politicians’ names and requests for crypto donations, to be offered as ‘bounties’
articles.summary: German-Polish software developer Martin S, 49, alleged neo-Nazi links, arrested in Dortmund for running ‘Assassination Politics’, a darknet platform listing over 20 top politicians (including Merkel, Scholz), judges and ministers, soliciting cryptocurrency bounties for their murder. His site published personal data, ‘death sentences’, bomb-making instructions and racist conspiracy theories. Prosecutors charge him with financing terrorism, incitement to violence and illicit data dissemination. Investigated since June after a domestic intelligence tip, he is believed to have acted solo amid right-wing extremist Covid protest networks.

articles.title: ‘People were screaming for help’: Delhi car blast witnesses describe scenes of horror
articles.trailText: Explosion near the Red Fort landmark was so loud and intense it was felt several kilometres away
articles.summary: On Nov 11, a white Hyundai parked at a Red Fort traffic light in Delhi exploded violently, sending a fireball skyward, igniting nearby vehicles and a fairground ferris wheel. Crowds drawn by the festival season fled as severed limbs, charred bodies, and flying glass littered the streets. Witnesses rescued burnt victims from flaming rickshaws; nearby stalls overturned. The blast shattered windows in surrounding buildings and sparked chaos outside the Red Fort metro station. Hospitals admitted dozens with severe burns; eight fatalities confirmed, including a taxi driver and an 18-year-old shop worker. Authorities worked overnight to identify charred corpses amid distraught families searching for missing relatives.

articles.title: Israeli embassy writes to US senators defending detention of Palestinian American teen
articles.trailText: The document describes Israel’s case against Mohammed Ibrahim but omits key details about his treatment
articles.summary: Israel’s Washington embassy circulated a letter defending its nine-month military detention of 16-year-old dual Palestinian-American Mohammed Ibrahim, charged with rock-throwing, to US senators. The embassy asserts he’s received regular medical checks and scabies treatment but omits his 25% weight loss, family’s lack of contact and his claim that interrogators threatened violence to force a confession. Twenty-seven Democratic lawmakers and over 100 rights groups have pressed the US and Israel for his release; a court hearing was delayed to mid-December.

articles.title: TikTok influencer killed in public ‘execution’ as Mali’s jihadist crisis worsens
articles.trailText: Mariam Cissé, who posted videos in support of ruling junta, received death threats before being abducted and killed
articles.summary: In Mali’s embattled north, TikTok influencer Mariam Cissé—who amassed over 100,000 followers for posting pro-junta combat videos—was abducted from a Timbuktu-area market on Nov. 10 and executed the following day in Tonka’s Independence Square by suspected Jama’at Nusrat al-Islam wal-Muslimin militants. No group claimed responsibility, but JNIM control is entrenched in rural towns as the 2012 Tuareg uprising morphed into an al-Qaida–linked insurgency. French and UN forces withdrew after Mali’s 2020–21 coups, and Russia-backed junta divisions, fuel blockades and rising kidnappings underscore the junta’s crumbling authority.

articles.title: A Dutch war cemetery added displays showing black US soldiers. Then they were quietly removed
articles.trailText: Relatives fear the move is part of ‘the same virus affecting the US’, as historians and politicians say it coincided with Trump’s DEI purge
articles.summary: At the Netherlands American Cemetery near Maastricht, which holds 8,301 US war dead including 174 African Americans, two educational panels on Black soldiers added in 2023 were quietly removed this spring by the American Battle Monuments Commission. Critics from Dutch politicians, historians and relatives decry the move as echoing the Trump administration’s DEI purge, noting panels on George H. Pruitt and a Jefferson Wiggins quote remain off display. The Limburg province has appealed to the ABMC and US ambassador to restore them. Meanwhile local families who adopt graves have honoured all soldiers equally for 80 years.

articles.title: Pakistan Taliban claim responsibility for deadly terror attack in Islamabad
articles.trailText: Defence minister says country is in ‘state of war’ after suicide blast kills 12 and injures 27 outside court buildings
articles.summary: The Pakistan Taliban (TTP) claimed responsibility for a suicide car bomb outside Islamabad district courts on Nov 11, killing 12 and wounding 27 as lawyers and court staff gathered. The attacker tried to breach court premises and struck a police vehicle after failing entry. TTP warned of further assaults until Pakistan adopts Islamic sharia. Defence minister Khawaja Asif declared a “state of war” amid a record 600-plus militant attacks this year, accusing the Afghan Taliban of sheltering TTP fighters. Simultaneous Baloch insurgent strikes in Balochistan underscore multi-front security threats.

articles.title: Next day delivery, no weapons allowed: the unstoppable postal service keeping Ukraine going
articles.trailText: Nova Poshta connects frontline cities to the capital, and to millions of refugees across Europe, delivering everything from home comforts to house moving boxes, even under fire
articles.summary: Nova Poshta, Ukraine’s main private postal service, operates under missile fire to connect frontline cities like Kharkiv, Balakliia and Kherson with Kyiv and 15 European countries. For £1.50–£2.20 it delivers 5–10 kg parcels—winter tyres, skincare, Starlink parts, car bumpers, homemade pies, furniture, humanitarian aid—often next day, using mobile offices, bomb shelters, generators and bulletproof-equipped staff. Automated hubs process 1.5 m parcels daily; branches reopen days after liberation, return fallen soldiers’ effects and sustain businesses and refugees despite power outages and mass mobilization.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What the BBC’s new crisis reveals about its failures – and future
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The nation’s public service broadcaster is at a critical juncture as it deals with governance misfires and a political agenda against it
articles.summary: After the abrupt resignations of DG Tim Davie and News head Deborah Turness following right-wing and Tory-linked assaults on the BBC over a misedited Trump clip and alleged liberal bias, insiders warn that weak governance—including board member Robbie Gibb’s influence and Michael Prescott’s critical letter—has left the corporation vulnerable. As charter renewal looms in 2027, questions swirl over defending editorial independence, funding via the licence fee, and finding a successor equipped to navigate political pressure, culture-war attacks and trust rebuilding.

articles.title: Hopes of Irish language revival in public life as Catherine Connolly takes office
articles.trailText: Advocates say presidency could be ‘transformative moment’ for Ireland after Gaelic’s cultural breakthroughs
articles.summary: Catherine Connolly’s inauguration as Ireland’s president ushers in hopes of a transformative Irish-language revival. A fluent Gael, the independent left-wing ex-barrister won 64% of the vote by making Irish the centrepiece of her campaign and pledging to use it as the working language of Áras an Uachtaráin. Following cultural breakthroughs—from the Oscar-nominated film An Cailín Ciúin (The Quiet Girl) to punk-rap group Kneecap and a boom in Gaelge-podcasts, schools and TikTok content—advocates say Connolly’s symbolic post could shift Irish from the margins to mainstream public life and bolster gains in Northern Ireland under a new language commissioner.

articles.title: Japan and China in growing row after PM Takaichi says Taiwan conflict could trigger military deployment
articles.trailText: New prime minister says an attack on Taiwan could trigger the deployment of her country’s self-defence forces if the conflict poses threat to Japan
articles.summary: Japan and China in escalating dispute after Japan's new PM Sanae Takaichi asserts Tokyo could deploy Self-Defense Forces if a conflict over Taiwan threatens Japan's survival. Takaichi invoked collective self-defense rights under a 2015 law and warned the "Taiwan contingency" demands preparation for worst-case scenarios. Beijing condemned her remarks, while its consul general in Osaka threatened Japan in a removed social media post, prompting Tokyo protests. Takaichi, Japan's first female PM, stood firm but pledged cautious language.
