The spat follows her meeting with Taiwan's president's adviser at Apec and underlines regional security tensions amid China's claims over Taiwan.

articles.title: ‘I can’t breathe in this city’: inaction over Delhi’s suffocating pollution sparks rare protest
articles.trailText: The failure by state governments to do anything about pollution means it has often been met with apathy. But at a rare protest anger and frustration were rife
articles.summary: In Delhi, hundreds of residents—mothers, children, students, retirees and activists—gathered at India Gate on Nov 11 to protest record off-air quality (AQI >500) and government apathy. Despite police warnings, home visits and threats of legal action, officers violently dispersed the crowd, detaining around 100 people, including elderly and children, and filing cases against organisers. Protesters blamed vehicle emissions, crop burning, waste and coal plant combustion, as well as alleged BJP state government data-tamping and a failed cloud-seeding scheme for worsening smog. They demanded urgent anti-pollution policies, noting pollution now kills more than obesity or diabetes in Delhi.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: battle for Pokrovsk ‘raging on’ as Russia claims advance on town to east
articles.trailText: Kyiv says Moscow’s forces carrying out ‘fast manoeuvres’ in push for key city while sides give conflicting reports of combat around Myrnohrad. What we know on day 1,357
articles.summary: On day 1,357 of Russia’s war in Ukraine, fierce battles around Pokrovsk and embattled Myrnohrad rage, with Kyiv rotating troops and holding ground against Russia’s 150,000-strong mechanized and marine brigades. Moscow claims gains in Myrnohrad and Zaporizhzhia villages, while Ukraine hits a Crimean oil depot. Kyiv’s anti-corruption bureau probes Energoatom kickbacks; Germany boosts 2026 aid to €11.5 bn. Belgium tracks suspected Russian drones near strategic sites; Lukoil declares force majeure in Iraq.

articles.title: China’s CO2 emissions have been flat or falling for past 18 months, analysis finds
articles.trailText: World’s biggest polluter on track to hit peak emissions target early but miss goal for cutting carbon intensity
articles.summary: China’s CO2 emissions have been flat or falling for 18 months, signalling it may hit its peak emissions target ahead of its 2030 goal. Renewables surged in Q3 2025—solar output grew 46%, wind 11%—and China added 240 GW of solar and 61 GW of wind capacity in the first nine months. Emissions in travel, cement and steel have declined, leaving overall emissions unchanged year-on-year in Q3. Transport emissions fell 5% while petrochemicals rose 10%. Despite meeting peak ambitions, China risks missing its 2020–25 carbon-intensity target and must accelerate GDP-linked emissions cuts. The upcoming 2026–30 five-year plan will likely prioritise low-carbon energy.

articles.title: US declares partial suspension of sanctions on Syria after historic meeting
articles.trailText: Ahmed al-Sharaa and Donald Trump hold first White House summit between a US and Syrian leader since 1946
articles.summary: At the first White House summit between US and Syrian leaders since 1946, President Trump hosted Syria’s new leader Ahmed al-Sharaa, a former Hayat Tahrir al-Sham commander once under a US $10m bounty. After the meeting, Secretary of State Rubio announced a 180-day suspension of select Caesar Act sanctions on Syria’s energy sector, excluding Russian- or Iranian-linked transactions. The US cited aims to rebuild Syria, integrate Kurdish-led SDF into the Syrian army, and possibly form a US-led anti-ISIS coalition, with future security and diplomatic steps anticipated.

articles.title: Tell us: are you a New Zealander planning to leave the country?
articles.trailText: We want to hear from people in New Zealand who have or are thinking of leaving
articles.summary: Provisional data to August 2025 show nearly 74,000 New Zealand citizens left the country in the year—surpassing the 2012 record of 73,300—as mid-career workers depart amid fears of economic hollowing. Australia absorbed 58% of migrants due to higher average weekly incomes and unrestricted rights. This surge follows record departures through 2023 and into 2024, raising concerns about a brain drain among skilled professionals. The Guardian invites readers to share their emigration plans, motivations, experiences and family impacts via a form.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy says he wants to ‘prove his innocence’ as he is released from prison
articles.trailText: Former French president, who said his three weeks in jail had been a ‘nightmare’, will serve rest of sentence outside pending appeal
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, 70, was freed from La Santé prison after 20 days in solitary for his five-year sentence on criminal conspiracy charges over alleged Libyan campaign funding. He called his jail term “gruelling” and a “nightmare,” told a Paris appeal court he will focus on proving his innocence and prepare for a retrial next spring. Under strict release conditions, he must remain in France and avoid contact with justice ministry officials and co-defendants. Sarkozy, the first modern French head of state jailed, denies seeking Gaddafi funds and plans to appeal all convictions.

articles.title: Jailed climate activist wins appeal against deportation from UK
articles.trailText: Marcus Decker was served with deportation order while in prison for unveiling Just Stop Oil banner over Dartford Crossing
articles.summary: German activist Marcus Decker, jailed for 31 months after unfurling a Just Stop Oil banner on Dartford Crossing in October 2022, won his appeal against an automatic deportation order at Monday’s tribunal. The 36-year-old’s lawyers argued deporting him would breach his right to family life with partner Holly and their stepchildren and chill peaceful protest amid the climate crisis. The judge announced the ruling immediately. Decker, who served 16 months, was backed by climate experts, religious leaders, 22 Nobel laureates and hundreds of public figures, including Sir David King and Juliet Stevenson.

articles.title: Ukraine’s energy sector faces wide-scale investigation over ‘kickback’ allegations
articles.trailText: Anti-corruption agency says state nuclear power operator Energoatom taking illicit payments of 10-15%
articles.summary: Ukraine’s National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) is probing alleged kickbacks in state nuclear operator Energoatom contracts, accusing senior figures of forcing suppliers to pay 10–15% bribes. Media identified businessman Timur Mindich—co-owner of Kvartal 95 and former Zelenskyy partner—as a suspect; he fled Kyiv before a search. NABU says a criminal gang rigged payments, sparking friction with President Zelenskyy, who earlier weakened then restored anti-corruption agencies under public and EU pressure. The investigation comes as Russia’s bombardment damages Ukraine’s power grid amid its EU accession bid.

articles.title: UAE refuses to join Gaza stabilisation force without clear legal framework
articles.trailText: Decision reflects wider regional doubts about terms of US-drafted plan to disarm Hamas
articles.summary: UAE has declined to join a UN-mandated Gaza stabilisation force due to lack of clear legal framework, joining Jordan, Israel and Azerbaijan in rejecting the US-drafted plan. The draft resolution places a US-led force, outside UN oversight, in charge of disarming Hamas, securing borders, and enforcing security in Gaza without explicit Palestinian consent or reference to the West Bank or a Palestinian state. Arab states demand a stronger role for a Palestinian civilian police force, clearer mandate, consent requirements and funding guarantees from Gulf sponsors, while negotiations in New York risk delay and security vacuums.

articles.title: Eight people die and several injured after car explosion in Delhi, police say
articles.trailText: Several fire engines rushed to the scene after blast reported near the historic Red Fort, fire services said
articles.summary: On the evening of 10 November, a slow-moving car exploded at a red light outside Delhi’s historic Red Fort, killing eight and injuring 19, police said. Dozens of vehicles—cars, rickshaws and motorcycles—were damaged or set ablaze, and the car’s registered owner is detained. Fire engines and ambulances rushed victims to a government hospital. TV footage showed mangled bodies and panicked crowds. Authorities placed major train stations nationwide on high alert as the federal home ministry opened an all-angle probe, with Home Minister Amit Shah and PM Narendra Modi reviewing forensic findings at the site.

articles.title: Protesters target major new Nigerian museum embroiled in looted artefacts row
articles.trailText: Protest at Mowaa comes amid dispute over ownership of Benin bronzes looted by British colonial forces
articles.summary: At a Benin City preview event for the Museum of West African Art (MOWAA), protesters aligned with Oba Ewuare II disrupted proceedings, chanting “Oba ghato kpere ise” and vandalizing the reception pavilion. They claim the museum violates the Oba’s authority over Benin’s cultural heritage and oppose its custody of Benin bronzes looted during the 1897 British punitive expedition. Co-funded by French, German and private donors under a former governor, MOWAA remains bronze-free due to a feud between Edo’s current and previous administrations. Nigeria’s culture minister warned the unrest endangers preservation efforts. Observers urge a swift settlement to safeguard Edo state’s cultural standing.

articles.title: Terrorist turf war battle in north-eastern Nigeria leaves about 200 dead
articles.trailText: Fighting between Boko Haram and rival militants from Islamic State West Africa Province broke out on shores of Lake Chad
articles.summary: Fierce turf war erupted on the shores of Lake Chad in Dogon Chiku as Boko Haram forces clashed with Islamic State West Africa Province (ISWAP) militants, killing around 200 ISWAP fighters and seizing boats, according to local vigilantes and military sources. Since ISWAP’s 2016 split from Boko Haram, rivals have vied for control of shrinking riverine corridors across Nigeria, Niger, Chad and Cameroon, taxing fishers and herders. Saturday’s encounter marks one of the Sahel’s deadliest jihadist infighting episodes, shifting power dynamics.

articles.title: Jacob Zuma’s daughter goes on trial over deadly South African riots
articles.trailText: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla is accused of inciting terrorism and public violence after her father was jailed in 2021
articles.summary: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, 43, daughter of ex-president Jacob Zuma, has pleaded not guilty to incitement of terrorism and public violence over the July 2021 riots that left 350+ dead following her father’s jailing for contempt over a state-capture probe, spurring unrest in Gauteng and KwaZulu-Natal after he served two of a 15-month term and was released by President Ramaphosa. The Durban trial marks South Africa’s first terrorism-related prosecution based on social media, with prosecutors citing 164 WhatsApp groups. Zuma-Sambudla, now an MK MP after leaving the ANC in 2023, denies the charges, calling them politically targeted. Jacob Zuma Foundation insists her posts were reactive commentaries, not incitement.

articles.title: Lavrov’s absence sparks speculation he has fallen from favour with Putin
articles.trailText: Veteran foreign minister missed key Kremlin meeting, and is not part of Russia’s G20 delegation
articles.summary: Sergei Lavrov’s unexplained absence from a Kremlin security council meeting on nuclear testing plans and omission from Russia’s G20 delegation has fueled speculation that Putin may be sidelining his long-serving foreign minister. The Kremlin denies any rift, but insiders suggest Lavrov’s uncompromising handling of a failed US summit bid and clashes with rising power Kirill Dmitriev have eroded his influence. Once a key diplomat, Lavrov is now seen as peripheral, with younger officials increasingly shaping Russia’s foreign policy.

articles.title: Man goes on trial in Germany over deadly Christmas market car attack
articles.trailText: Taleb al-Abdulmohsen accused of murdering six and attempting to kill hundreds in Magdeburg last December
articles.summary: Taleb al-Abdulmohsen, a 51-year-old Saudi-born psychiatrist, stands trial in Magdeburg accused of intentionally driving his SUV into a crowded Christmas market on 20 December 2024, killing six people—including a nine-year-old boy and five women—and wounding 338 (31 severely). Prosecutors say he acted with premeditated intent to kill “an indeterminately large number” of victims, fueled by far-right, anti-Islam rhetoric and personal resentments after a legal dispute. Despite prior warnings from Saudi authorities, he breached festive barriers. The €4.5 m bullet-proof courtroom will host a 50-day trial through March, with life imprisonment the maximum sentence. The case has reignited scrutiny of security lapses and stoked immigration debates ahead of Saxony-Anhalt elections.

articles.title: ‘Drop in, have a coffee’: Bendigo’s Muslims celebrate milestone for new mosque – and community cohesion forged after backlash
articles.trailText: Worshippers prepare to start using first completed building and hope to host formal opening in early 2026
articles.summary: On Bendigo’s industrial fringe the city’s first mosque, featuring a visible minaret and an open, fence-free design to encourage “drop in, have a coffee” visits, nears use of its first multipurpose building. After a 2015 wave of right-wing backlash, vilification trials and a failed high-court challenge, a grassroots ‘Believe in Bendigo’ campaign and interfaith outreach shifted local attitudes. Construction began in 2019, paused during COVID, funded largely by donations (with $1m in grants). The site will host Friday prayers and community events pending occupancy permit, aiming for an early 2026 opening. The full complex will seat 375 and include sports facilities and a courtyard to foster multicultural dialogue.

articles.title: Eight dead and more than a million displaced after super typhoon Fung-wong slams the Philippines
articles.trailText: About 1.4 million people evacuated as storm sparks flash floods and landslides and leaves millions without power
articles.summary: Super-typhoon Fung-wong knocked out power to almost 3 million Filipinos, killed at least eight and displaced about 1.4 million after triggering flash floods, landslides and storm surges across two-thirds of the archipelago. In Catanduanes, floodwaters rose to rooftops, prompting rescues; in Nueva Vizcaya and Kalinga mudslides claimed six lives, including three children, and left several missing. Authorities opened some 6,000 evacuation centres housing 92,000 families. President Marcos Jr extended the state of national calamity declared after Typhoon Kalmaegi. Fung-wong, the 21st typhoon of 2025, is now weakening as it moves north, underscoring climate-driven storm intensification.

articles.title: Vatican Swiss Guard investigated for alleged spitting gesture at Jewish women
articles.trailText: Women, in St Peter’s Square for audience with Pope Leo in which he condemned antisemitism, say guard ‘noticeably hissed at us’
articles.summary: During a general audience at St Peter’s Square on 29 October marking the 60th anniversary of Nostra aetate, a Vatican Swiss Guard is under internal investigation after two Jewish delegates—author Michal Govrin and scholar Vivian Liska—alleged he hissed “les juifs” and made an act of spitting in their direction. Spokesperson Cpl Eliah Cinotti confirmed the standard inquiry and stressed the Guard’s distancing from antisemitism. In his address, Pope Leo reiterated the church’s repudiation of hatred and the original focus of Nostra aetate on outreach to the Jewish world.

articles.title: Netherlands presses on with plan to ban imports from illegal Israeli settlements
articles.trailText: Move follows rising Israeli violence against Palestinians and freeze on broader sanctions last month
articles.summary: The Netherlands is drafting legislation to ban imports from Israeli settlements in occupied Palestine, calling out settlement expansion and rising violence that threaten the two-state solution. Foreign Minister David van Weel said broader EU sanctions on Israel are paused pending Gaza ceasefire implementation, but a carve-out for settlement goods is essential despite legal and procedural hurdles. Spain and Slovenia have already banned settlement exports; Ireland and Belgium are preparing measures. While settlement trade with the EU is small, the ban serves as a political statement of support for Palestinian statehood under international law.

articles.title: Fury as Indonesia declares late authoritarian ruler Suharto a national hero
articles.trailText: Former leader presided over period marked by corruption, nepotism, censorship and claims of rights abuses
articles.summary: Indonesia’s government has posthumously honored former authoritarian president Suharto with the title of national hero, triggering protests and accusations of historical revisionism. President Prabowo Subianto, Suharto’s ex-son-in-law, officiated the ceremony despite objections from pro-democracy activists and victims’ families. Critics cite Suharto’s 32-year rule (1967-98) for systemic corruption, censorship and the 1965–66 anti-Communist purges that killed up to half a million. Culture Minister Fadli Zon defended the award for Suharto’s role in the 1949 struggle against Dutch rule, while Amnesty International decries it as “whitewashing” mass atrocities.

articles.title: Israeli soldiers speak out on killings of Gaza civilians
articles.trailText: IDF soldiers tell documentary of opening fire unprovoked and arbitrary designations of who was an enemy
articles.summary: Israeli soldiers in ITV documentary “Breaking Ranks” expose breakdown of IDF conduct in Gaza: arbitrary rules, unprovoked fire on civilians at aid lines, routine use of human shields (“mosquito protocol”), and senior commanders’ bias. Witnesses—some named, some anonymous—describe suspending “means, intent, ability” guidelines, tank attacks on laundry-hanging civilians, and ideological incitement from politicians and rabbis framing all Palestinians as legitimate targets. UN estimates 83% of Gaza deaths are civilian. IDF denies systematic abuses, insists on investigations. The film highlights soldiers’ shame and mental strain amid claims of legal immunity and lack of accountability.

articles.title: Living with the water: the Netherlands’ floating futures – photo essay
articles.trailText: Photographer Alessandro Gandolfi’s latest project looks at how sustainable floating neighbourhoods offer a way forward as the sea rises
articles.summary: Photographer Alessandro Gandolfi documents the Netherlands’ shift from fighting floods to “living with water” via meebewegen: the rise of architect-designed floating neighbourhoods with solar panels, heat pumps and advanced waste systems. Rooted in 17th-century land reclamation, post-1953 Delta Works and the 2006 Room for the River programme, modern districts like IJburg (158 homes), Schoonschip (30 homes, 516 panels) and Rotterdam’s floating office, farm and event space exemplify carbon-neutral, flood-resilient housing that could alleviate a 400k-home shortage and inspire global coastal adaptation. Coastal defence innovations like the Zandmotor sand engine further illustrate water-driven design.

articles.title: Monday briefing: What to expect from Cop30 as the crucial climate conference kicks off in Brazil
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: As the world’s leaders gather in Brazil, the urgency of the climate crisis collides with political inertia. The Guardian’s journalists will be following all the stories from Belém
articles.summary: Cop30 formally opens in Belém, Brazil amid warnings from UN chief Guterres that failing to curb warming under 1.5°C is “moral failure,” with 2023–25 the hottest years on record. Guardian environment head Natalie Hanman outlines urgent climate finance, fossil fuel phase-down and forest protection demands, critiques political inertia from Trump’s “Drill baby, drill!” to UK’s Reform UK, and previews Guardian’s extensive on-the-ground team—live blogs, deep-dives, podcasts, newsletter “Down to Earth”—and “This is climate breakdown” series spotlighting impacted communities. She stresses embedding Indigenous perspectives and equitable climate action as core demands. High hopes, low expectations.

articles.title: Syrian president holds talks with Trump at White House
articles.trailText: Ahmed al-Sharaa was expected to push for full lifting of remaining sanctions imposed during 13-year civil war
articles.summary: Syrian president Ahmed al-Sharaa made the first official White House visit by a Syrian leader since 1946, meeting Trump to push repeal of the 2019 Caesar Syria Civilian Protection Act and restore sanctions relief. The former HTS militant, removed from the US terror blacklist, seeks reversal of economic restrictions after toppling Assad, touting Syria’s workforce and promising stability. Trump has already lifted most sanctions, but Caesar Act repeal requires Congress. US officials cite Syrian cooperation on missing Americans and chemical weapons. Israel opposes full sanction relief amid normalization hopes.

articles.title: Waiting for the all-clear: how medics and villagers rallied when Ebola returned to DRC
articles.trailText: If no new cases are reported in Bulape by early December, the country will have vanquished its 16th outbreak of the deadly virus since it was discovered there in 1976
articles.summary: In early September 2025 the DRC declared its 16th Ebola outbreak in remote Bulape, Kasai, after a cluster of cases killed 16 of the first 35 confirmed patients, including health workers. MSF, WHO and the national health ministry crossed forests to build a 32-bed treatment centre, vaccinated over 35,000 people and trained local staff. Of 64 suspected or confirmed cases, 19 recovered and 45 died. Survivors like Bope Mpona Héritier received vital psychological support but now face community stigma. A 42-day no-case period from 19 October will signal the all-clear.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Lavrov reappears, ready to offer Marco Rubio same demands
articles.trailText: Ukraine answers Russia’s strikes on energy grid; Zelenskyy tells the Guardian how King Charles eased Trump tensions. What we know on day 1,356
articles.summary: Russia’s foreign minister Sergei Lavrov ended a weeks-long absence to offer US Secretary of State Marco Rubio talks on Ukraine, reiterating Moscow’s maximalist demands and that peace must ��take Russian interests into account.’ He also hinted at nuclear test planning, a claim later denied by the Kremlin. Ukrainian drone and missile strikes knocked out power in Voronezh, Belgorod and Kursk regions, triggering major repair operations. President Zelenskyy praised King Charles’s role in reinforcing US support, detailed Ukraine’s energy recovery and warned of brutal conflict and heavy Russian losses around Pokrovsk.

articles.title: Maggots in the meals, glass in the rice: Indonesia’s free school meals tainted by food poisoning
articles.trailText: Thousands of cases of food poisoning have been linked to programme launched with fanfare by the president, Prabowo Subianto
articles.summary: Indonesia’s flagship free school meals programme, launched by President Prabowo Subianto to curb malnutrition, has been plagued by mass food‐poisoning outbreaks—over 15,000 reported by NGOs (6,517 confirmed by officials). Thousands of students fell ill this year after meals contaminated with maggots, glass shards and bacteria. Social media posts and mass protests by parents highlight unsafe kitchens, poor storage and hygiene breaches. Facing criticism, Prabowo has issued new food‐safety regulations and BGN plans to expand to 32,000 smaller kitchens by 2026. Critics warn the rushed scale‐up lacks accountability, risking child health and transparency.

articles.title: More than 1 million evacuated in the Philippines as Typhoon Fung-wong makes landfall
articles.trailText: At least two people found dead as super-typhoon hits Philippines, days after Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 224
articles.summary: Typhoon Fung-wong has made landfall on Luzon’s east coast with sustained winds of 115 mph, gusts to 140 mph and torrential rain, prompting pre-emptive evacuation of over one million people. At least two deaths are reported as the super-typhoon—the 21st major storm this year—follows Typhoon Kalmaegi, which killed 224. Authorities halted searches for missing survivors, closed schools and canceled nearly 300 flights. Meteorologists warn of 200 mm of rain, a 1,118-mile-wide wind band and more intense cyclones driven by ocean warming. Fung-wong is expected to track north toward Taiwan after battering Aurora and Catanduanes provinces.

articles.title: Russian activist held in Poland admits he worked as FSB agent, court papers say
articles.trailText: Igor Rogov, who left Russia in 2021, due to go on trial accused of informing on other Russian opposition activists
articles.summary: Polish court papers reveal Igor Rogov, 30, exiled in Sosnowiec after leaving Russia in 2021, admitted serving as an undercover FSB agent, infiltrating opposition groups in Saransk—including Navalny’s Anti-Corruption Foundation and Khodorkovsky’s Open Russia—and reporting activists’ activities via burner phones and encrypted USBs. Coerced initially under threat to his family, he and wife Irina were arrested last summer amid Poland’s sabotage probe, including an undelivered explosive package. Their trial, starting 8 December, underscores rare direct FSB operations using a Russian citizen abroad.

articles.title: Palestinian man dismissed from Gaza border assistance role to sue EU
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Mohammad Baraka’s case alleges discrimination on basis of nationality after EU counterparts were transferred
articles.summary: After 20 years at EU Border Assistance Mission (EUBAM) in Rafah, Palestinian Mohammad Baraka, evacuated to Cairo during the Gaza war, was dismissed when the Rafah office closed while EU counterparts were relocated. Filing suit in a Brussels tribunal, he alleges nationality-based discrimination and breach of Belgian labor law: his rolling fixed-term contracts violated rules requiring permanent status after three renewals. Lawyer Selma Benkhelifa argues the closure was justified by security but discriminatory since EU staff were transferred, not sacked. The lawsuit decries a “shocking” circumvention of public policy. Baraka says he was left without rights. The EC declined comment.

articles.title: Utah’s oldest LGBTQ+ bar closes amid workers’ union push: ‘We feel extremely disposable’
articles.trailText: Workers at the SunTrapp – opened in 1973 in Salt Lake City – claim the shuttering was a ‘stunt’ to prevent unionization
articles.summary: In Salt Lake City, Utah’s oldest LGBTQ+ bar, the SunTrapp (est. 1973), abruptly closed on Oct. 31 amid workers’ push to unionize with CWA Local 7765. Staff allege owner Mary Peterson staged the shutdown to thwart their voluntary recognition request, firing and rehiring employees, enacting strict policies, and refusing dialogue. The bar served as a crucial safe haven in a Republican-dominated, anti-LGBTQ+ state. Workers demand fair election, accountability and reinstatement, deeming the closure a union-busting ‘stunt.’

articles.title: Three dead and 15 hurt after rough seas pull people into the ocean in Tenerife
articles.trailText: Two men and a woman died in separate incidents after sudden sea surges battered the Spanish island
articles.summary: Three died and 15 were injured after unexpected sea surges struck Tenerife on Nov. 9. A rescue helicopter airlifted a 43-year-old Spanish fisherman from La Guancha who died on arrival; lifeguards pronounced an unidentified man dead at El Cabezo beach; and a 79-year-old Dutch woman suffered a fatal heart attack when a giant wave swept ten people off the Puerto de la Cruz pier. At least three people were hospitalized and five French tourists were pulled from Roque de las Bodegas beach. Authorities urged visitors to avoid exposed piers amid autumn storm warnings.

articles.title: ‘It seemed like quite a do’: why East Grinstead hosts one of Scientology’s glitziest evenings
articles.trailText: Last week, 7,000 people – including Tom Cruise – descended on the West Sussex town for an event that divides local opinion
articles.summary: East Grinstead’s Saint Hill Manor, the UK headquarters of the Church of Scientology, hosted its annual Patrons Ball last week, drawing over 7,000 attendees – including Tom Cruise – to a night of live performances, lavish staging and wine. In a town of 26,000, such scale prompted local surprise and divided opinion: admirers mingled with residents wary of Scientology’s history of family separation, psychological drills via Narconon and leadership controversies. Protests outside the manor, removal of a rail station sign and ongoing lawsuits underscore the church’s contested presence in West Sussex.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia deliberately ‘endangering nuclear safety in Europe’ says Kyiv
articles.trailText: Ukraine says drones are targeting substations that power the Khmelnytskyi and Rivne nuclear plants. What we know on day 1,355
articles.summary: Ukraine’s FM Andrii Sybiha says weekend drone strikes on the Khmelnytskyi and Rivne nuclear power substations were deliberate threats to Europe’s nuclear safety. Russia launched over 450 drones and 45 missiles, killing at least seven—3 in Dnipro (12 wounded), 1 in Kharkiv, 3 in Zaporizhzhia—while Ukraine shot down most. Lavrov revealed plans for a Russian nuclear test after Trump’s testing announcement, deepening US-Russia rift. Meanwhile, an external power line to the seized Zaporizhzhia plant was restored to avoid meltdown. New data shows Australia imported 3m tonnes of Russian oil via Singapore, highlighting sanction gaps. Discarded French horsehair fishing nets are repurposed as anti-drone defences.

articles.title: Russian missile attacks on Ukrainian energy facilities kill at least seven
articles.trailText: Volodymr Zelenskyy calls for more sanctions on Moscow after 45 missiles and 450 drones launched at Ukraine
articles.summary: Russia launched over 450 drones and 45 missiles overnight, killing at least seven civilians—three in a Dnipro apartment strike, one in Kharkiv and three in Zaporizhzhia—and wounding dozens. Energy infrastructure in Kyiv, Poltava and Kharkiv regions was damaged, forcing reliance on generators for water, power and heating. President Zelenskyy called for sweeping sanctions on all Russian energy. Russia said its “massive strike” hit Ukrainian weapons production; Ukraine responded by hitting a Saratov substation. Ceasefire talks remain stalled.

articles.title: Tanzania police arrest opposition party official after deadly election protests
articles.trailText: Chadema party says deputy secretary general arrested and calls election of incumbent president fraudulent
articles.summary: Tanzanian police have detained Chadema’s deputy secretary general, Amani Golugwa, and are seeking nine more opposition figures, including secretary general John Mnyika and communications head Brenda Rupia, accusing them of orchestrating last week’s deadly election protests that rights groups say killed over 1,000. Authorities have charged more than 200 people with treason—a crime that can carry the death penalty. President Samia Suluhu Hassan, declared winner with 98% of the vote despite barring her rivals, maintains the polls were free and fair, but observers note ballot stuffing, internet shutdowns, enforced disappearances and excessive force.

articles.title: UPS and FedEx ground all MD-11 planes after deadly Louisville crash
articles.trailText: UPS cites ‘abundance of caution’ and manufacturer’s recommendation after 14 died when wing caught fire and engine fell off
articles.summary: UPS and FedEx have immediately grounded all MD-11 freighters, representing 9% and 4% of their fleets, after a UPS MD-11 crashed at Louisville’s Worldport on Nov. 8, killing 14 when the left wing caught fire and an engine separated. The decision, made “out of an abundance of caution” on manufacturer recommendation, is backed by contingency plans to sustain global delivery. NTSB probes maintenance records from a San Antonio repair stint in September–October, with intact black boxes recovered. Operations at the 300-flight-per-day hub, which handles 400,000 packages an hour, resumed next-day and night sort.

articles.title: ‘For the women who gave birth in the dark’: a portrait of motherhood in Gaza
articles.trailText: Diana Shams wrote a book because ‘no one explains how to carry your baby through fire, hunger and fear – and still sing to her at bedtime’
articles.summary: In A Different Kind of Motherhood, Diana Shams, 27, recounts raising two young children amid Gaza’s siege and bombardment. Having once fretted over screen time and birthday cakes, she now endures displacement, rubble and tents, writing her memoir on a phone after losing her laptop. Through her own story—and those of Palestinian mothers who gave birth in dark shelters or lost children—Shams offers an unvarnished portrait of motherhood under fire. Viral TikTok posts revealed the harsh daily struggle: cooking over fires, shelter floods, constant fear. The ebook gives voice to Gaza’s women who care for children in extremis.

articles.title: Guyana in turmoil after opposition leader arrested and faces US extradition
articles.trailText: Azruddin Mohamed had emerged as a surprise contender in the presidential election and claims political persecution
articles.summary: Guyana’s surprise opposition leader Azruddin Mohamed, 38, and his father, gold-miner Nazar Mohamed, were arrested in Georgetown on a US extradition request alleging money laundering, bribery, tax evasion and gold-smuggling. Released on bail, they face weekly court appearances and a Monday hearing in Florida. Mohamed—whose newly formed party won 16 of 65 seats��claims political persecution by President Ali’s administration. The case, under a 1931 UK-US treaty, unfolds amid booming US-led oil exploration and intensifying domestic political divisions.

articles.title: Israel’s underground jail, where Palestinians are held without charge and never see daylight
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Detainees at Rakefet include nurse deprived of natural light since January, and teenager held for nine months
articles.summary: Since January, Israel has held dozens of Gaza Palestinians—many civilians, including a nurse and an 18-year-old food seller—underground at the Rakefet complex near Ramla without charge, trial or daylight. Reopened by far-right minister Itamar Ben-Gvir after the October 2023 attacks, Rakefet was originally built in the 1980s for organised criminals and condemned as inhumane. Today roughly 100 detainees endure windowless cells, starvation-level rations, forced shackling, beatings, dog attacks and near-total isolation from family and news. Lawyers from the Public Committee Against Torture in Israel (PCATI) documented torture-consistent violence, legal hearings without counsel, and extreme psychological harm from prolonged subterranean confinement. Despite a mid-October ceasefire release of 1,950 prisoners, at least 1,000 remain held under wartime conditions PCATI says violate international humanitarian law.

articles.title: Death of Iranian activist who burned picture of supreme leader causes outcry
articles.trailText: Iran’s police say Omid Sarlak, 22, shot himself, but fellow activists suspect he may have been killed for his views
articles.summary: Omid Sarlak, a 22-year-old Iranian aviation student and amateur boxer, was found shot dead in his car hours after burning a portrait of Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei in a video. Police ruled it a suicide, but activists cite traces of gunpowder on his hands, a viral clip of his father claiming security forces “surrounded and shot” him, and warnings Sarlak sent that his life was in danger. His funeral saw chants of “Death to the dictator,” and solidarity protests online and in Iran recall Mahsa Amini’s 2022 unrest.

articles.title: Carney survives two confidence votes on budget, quashing fears of winter election
articles.trailText: Minority government benefitted from opposition members voting across the aisle, paving way for billions in spending
articles.summary: Canada’s PM Mark Carney’s minority Liberal government survived two of three finance confidence votes on its C$78.3bn–deficit budget, quashing immediate winter election fears. Thanks to floor-crossing Conservative MP Chris d’Entremont and other opposition support, the plan for tens of billions in “generational investments” amid a US trade war and slowing economy advances to a decisive mid-November vote. Carney, a former central banker turned technocrat, has cultivated non-partisanship even as he courts disaffected Tories to secure backing for the Liberals’ fiscal agenda.

articles.title: Old fishing nets from France become vital protection against Russian drones in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Fishers from the Brittany coast are sending horse-hair nets to catch weapons and shield civilians and soldiers
articles.summary: In Brittany, France, fishers discard some 800 tonnes of worn monkfish horsehair nets annually. The charity Kernic Solidarités has sent 280 km of these deep-sea nets to Ukraine, where frontline troops stretch them into tunnels and barriers that entangle Russian FPV kamikaze drones. Used also to shield roads, bridges and field hospitals, the nets supplement anti-drone defenses amid more than 500 daily drone attacks. Donations have come from Sweden and Denmark too. Volunteers have driven two 2,300 km convoys but now face funding shortfalls, prompting talks for Ukraine to collect future shipments.

articles.title: US and China seek to project power with huge and expensive aircraft carriers
articles.trailText: China launches £5.4bn ship capable of carrying 60 aircraft that Beijing values as much for maintaining its global influence as for its use in warfare
articles.summary: China and the US are doubling down on aircraft carriers for global power projection. Beijing’s new 80,000-tonne Fujian, a £5.4bn supercarrier carrying 60 jets, is its third platform, trailing America’s 11 active carriers. Washington’s $12.8bn USS Gerald R. Ford, armed with 70 aircraft and four destroyers, has been deployed as strategic deterrence. Despite Kyiv’s drone-driven “functional defeat” of Russia’s Black Sea fleet, carriers remain prized for operational flexibility, influencing Taiwan contingencies. The UK’s two carriers serve diplomacy. Carriers endure drone and missile threats but require complex defence networks. Russia lacks a modern carrier since 2017.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia unleashes attack on energy infrastructure, triggering power cuts
articles.trailText: Ukrainian minister says Moscow is ‘massively attacking’ grid; Volodymyr Zelenskyy says Russian troops gathering near north-eastern city. What we know on day 1,354
articles.summary: On day 1,354, a large-scale Russian strike on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure triggered emergency power cuts across most regions, prompting Kyiv to import 300 m m^3 of US LNG via Poland to secure winter supplies. President Zelenskyy reported Russian troop concentrations near Vovchansk and marginal advances around Pokrovsk, while think-tank ISW warns of artillery threats to Kharkiv. The Kremlin denied reports that Foreign Minister Lavrov has fallen from favor. The US exempted Hungary from oil and gas sanctions for US LNG contracts, and the EU ended Russian multiple-entry visas. Kyiv revealed African recruits in lethal front-line roles and appointed a drone air defense commander.

articles.title: Passengers start to feel bite of flight cuts amid US government shutdown
articles.trailText: Travellers forced to adjust their plans as longest shutdown on record continues with no sign of resolution
articles.summary: In response to the record US government shutdown, the FAA ordered 4–10% cuts in commercial flights between 6am–10pm to maintain safety amid unpaid controllers, triggering over 800 US-linked cancellations so far and risking 1,800 flights/268,000 seats (Cirium). Major hubs (JFK, LAX) and 40 high-traffic airports face rising delays; Transportation Secretary Duffy warned of 15–20% cancellations. United, Southwest and Delta are rolling schedule adjustments. White House economist Kevin Hassett warns of broader economic hit if curbs persist. Travel chaos looms ahead of Thanksgiving as shutdown stalemate persists.

articles.title: Flattery will get you everywhere: Orbán lays it on thick with Trump
articles.trailText: The Hungarian PM needed Trump’s help over Russia oil sanctions – so he deployed a tried-and-trusted method
articles.summary: Visiting Washington, Hungary’s Viktor Orbán lavished praise on Donald Trump—interjecting during White House remarks, courting the MAGA base with Christian-nationalist appeals—to secure a waiver from US sanctions on Russian oil, crucial for his landlocked country’s energy supplies. Flattery targeted Trump’s ego and bolstered Orbán’s pre-election standing as polls show the opposition Tisza party leading. He cast European support for Ukraine as Biden-driven, downplaying Putin’s invasion to win US economic relief and avoid secondary penalties.

articles.title: EU could water down AI Act amid pressure from Trump and big tech
articles.trailText: European Commission confirms reports it is looking at postponing parts of landmark legislation
articles.summary: Under pressure from Trump's administration and tech giants, the European Commission is considering delaying key parts of the AI Act, in force since August 2024 but with high-risk AI rules due by 2026–27. Draft amendments propose a one-year grace period for non-compliant high-risk and generative AI providers, postponement of transparency fines until August 2027, and relaxed monitoring obligations. Major firms like Meta and over 40 European companies, including Airbus and Mercedes-Benz, back the delay, while MEP Brando Benifei warns it risks legal uncertainty. Proposals will be published November 19 and require member-state and EU-parliament approval.

articles.title: China’s threat to academic freedom in the UK | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Sara Rydkvist , the Hong Kong programme director of Amnesty International, and Francis Bown on the threat from China to academic freedom on British campuses
articles.summary: Two letters warn that China’s transnational repression extends to UK campuses: students in Hong Kong and mainland China face intimidation, surveillance and self-censorship, dropping human rights research or avoiding sensitive topics. Amnesty International UK highlights cases like Tara Zhang, detained after activism, and silent university responses. Francis Bown cites Prof Laura Murphy’s ordeal and urges rejecting Beijing’s bid to expand its London embassy at Royal Mint Court, as token government statements won’t deter interference. Authors call on UK universities and government to publicly defend academic freedom and resist foreign political pressure.

articles.title: EU plans hub to tackle disinformation threat from Russia and others
articles.trailText: Move follows ‘escalating hybrid attacks’ by Russia and other foreign powers spreading fake articles across social media
articles.summary: The EU will create a Centre for Democratic Resilience to counter hybrid disinformation from Russia, China and other authoritarian regimes. A leaked draft describes a hub pooling expertise across member and candidate states for information-sharing, early warnings and public awareness. It targets Russian operations like the Doppelganger copycat sites and Chinese PR misinformation campaigns. Ursula von der Leyen’s ‘democracy shield’ includes voluntary participation—potentially open to the UK—plus independent fact-checker and influencer networks. In 2024 Romania annulled its election over Russian meddling, and Moldova reported alleged Kremlin vote-buying and propaganda.

articles.title: Civil rescue groups in Mediterranean cut ties with Libyan coastguard
articles.trailText: Accusations of violent interceptions and human rights violations levelled at EU-funded Libyan services by NGOs
articles.summary: Thirteen NGO rescue ships suspended all communication with the EU-funded Libyan coastguard, accusing it of violent interceptions and torture, rape and forced labour in camps. A 2021 UN mission deemed detainee abuses suggestive of crimes against humanity. Rejecting EU and Italian pressure to liaise with what they call an “illegitimate actor at sea,” they launched the Justice Fleet alliance to document abuses and legal cases. NGOs warn ending cooperation is a legal and moral imperative to oppose European complicity, even as they risk fines, detentions and vessel seizures.

articles.title: Italy’s centenarians grow in number as another 2,000 reach the milestone
articles.trailText: Southern European country has more than double the number of people aged over 100 than it did in 2009
articles.summary: In 2025 Italy counted 23,548 centenarians, up from 21,211 in 2024 and more than twice the number in 2009, with over 2,000 new cases (82.6% women). Among them are 724 semi-supercentenarians (105+) and 19 supercentenarians (110+), led by Lucia Laura Sangenito (115). Regions with highest per-capita rates include Molise, Aosta Valley, Liguria and Sardinia’s ‘blue zone’ Perdasdefogu. Factors driving longevity include the Mediterranean diet, strong social networks and robust healthcare. However, Italy’s record-low birthrate (370,000 in 2024) and a rising elderly population are intensifying fiscal pressure on pensions and health services.

articles.title: Film festival in New York cancelled after China puts pressure on directors
articles.trailText: Participants ask for their films not to be shown at IndieChina event, which was due to launch this weekend
articles.summary: The inaugural IndieChina independent film festival in New York, scheduled for 8–15 November, was cancelled after on- and off-shore directors, pressured by Chinese authorities contacting their families or colleagues, pulled 80% of screenings. Organizer Zhu Rikun said a Beijing associate was detained and anonymous threats arrived. He suspended the event to protect participants from real or fabricated reprisals. Human Rights Watch linked the shutdown to China’s transnational repression of arts, noting similar recent censorship in Bangkok and past film crackdowns.

articles.title: At Sydney’s mighty arms convention, weapons are sold as ‘solutions’. No one mentions the people they will target
articles.trailText: As protesters outside condemn war, inside the Indo-Pacific International Maritime Exposition the defence minister praises the ‘beautiful, menacing and extremely cool’ technology on show
articles.summary: At the Indo-Pacific International Maritime Exposition in Sydney, Australia’s defence minister lauded the display of “beautiful, menacing, extremely cool” maritime weapons and autonomous systems while protesters outside decried the arms fair as legitimising war. Clashes with police left demonstrators pepper-sprayed. Major firms like Elbit Systems (linked to Israeli drone strikes in Gaza), Lockheed Martin (F-35 components made in Australia), Raytheon/RTX (GBU-12 bombs used in Yemen) and Boeing (GBU-39) pitched “solutions” without acknowledging intended targets amid UN allegations of genocide and war crimes.

articles.title: Hit for six: why India’s Women’s Cricket World Cup win is victory for equality
articles.trailText: Sacrifices made to reach final – defying social stigma, lack of resources and juggling jobs between training – makes victory still more extraordinary
articles.summary: India’s first Women’s Cricket World Cup triumph, captained by Harmanpreet Kaur and ignited by 15-year-old Shafali Verma’s fearless batting, signifies a major push for gender equality. The players, hailing largely from rural towns, overcame entrenched stigma, scarce facilities and even manual-labour jobs until pro contracts began in 2017 and the WPL launched in 2023. The final drew hundreds of millions of viewers, triggered village-wide screenings and record female academy enrolments. Celebrated by PM Modi, this watershed moment promises expanded grassroots access, cultural change and inspiration for a new generation of Indian women athletes.

articles.title: China’s latest aircraft carrier enters service to extend reach into high seas
articles.trailText: Experts say hi-tech Fujian will help expand country’s military influence and reach farther beyond its own waters
articles.summary: China’s Fujian, its first indigenously designed and built carrier, entered service under Xi Jinping, becoming China’s third carrier and giving it more than the UK, India and Italy. Joining Liaoning and Shandong, it helps make China’s navy largest by ship count and second in carriers behind the US’s 11. With an electromagnetic launch system, Fujian can deploy heavier aircraft like the KJ-600 early warning plane and stealth J-35, boosting sortie rates. US analysts note it lacks concurrent launch/recovery capability. The new carrier expands China’s blue-water reach, complicating Taiwan defense and power projection across the Indo-Pacific amid rapid PLA shipbuilding.

articles.title: Orbán to visit US to try to broker another Putin summit but questions raised over motives
articles.trailText: Hungarian PM also seeking exemption on US sanctions on Russian oil as he faces domestic challenge before elections
articles.summary: Hungarian PM Viktor Orbán will meet Donald Trump in Washington to propose hosting a Trump–Putin summit in Budapest aimed at ending the Russia–Ukraine war and to seek exemptions from US sanctions on Russian oil. Insiders reveal Orbán’s true priority is to secure a high-profile Trump visit before Hungary’s April elections to rally his conservative base. The meeting will test Trump’s commitment to enforcing sanctions abroad and underscores Orbán’s role as a pro-Kremlin maverick within the EU.

articles.title: Friday briefing: Six lessons from three years of bringing you this newsletter
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: After more than 450​ early alarms, countless headlines and one rogue squirrel​, it’s time ​for me to say goodbye. ​It’s been a privilege to share the biggest stories – and some very small ones – with you
articles.summary: After 468 First Edition newsletters, the outgoing editor signs off, marking her move to editing and passing the reins to Aamna, Martin Belam and Karen McVeigh. Reflecting on three years covering stories from ICC abuse allegations and Gaza and Ukraine crises to UK politics, AI, climate urgency and corporate pay, she distils six lessons: seek sideways expertise, track online ideologues, spotlight disabled injustice, leverage humor (squirrel GIFs), embrace UK’s political volatility and the power of listicles.

articles.title: ‘Long on talk and short on action’: Papua New Guinea leader criticises Cop climate summits ahead of Brazil meeting
articles.trailText: James Marape skipped the meeting last year in protest but will attend Cop30 due to ‘encouraging signs’ on climate finance
articles.summary: Papua New Guinea prime minister James Marape, who skipped Cop29 in protest at major emitters’ inaction, criticized UN climate summits as “long on talk and short on action” but will attend Cop30 in Belém, Brazil on Nov 10, citing “encouraging signs” in climate finance commitments. He framed PNG as both a victim and solution provider, aiming to secure fair finance for landowners, recognition for its rainforests and oceans, and to connect Pacific and Amazon conservation. Marape discussed cooperation with Brazil on agriculture, energy and tech, including hydropower expansion and LNG exports, and backed an Australia-Pacific bid for Cop31. Environmentalists urge PNG to end illegal logging.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukrainian court jails Russian soldier for killing PoW in landmark sentence
articles.trailText: The soldier is the first to be jailed for such a crime after being found guilty of shooting dead a Ukrainian soldier who had surrendered in Zaporizhzhia region. What we know on day 1,353
articles.summary: Ukrainian court in Zaporizhzhia sentenced 27-year-old Russian soldier Dmitry Kurashov to life for shooting Vitalii Hodniuk, a surrendered Ukrainian POW, marking Ukraine’s first conviction and life term for such a war crime; Kyiv prosecutors probe 322 cases of Russian-perpetrated POW killings since 2022. Meanwhile, Ukrainian drones struck Russia’s Volgograd refinery, saboteurs in Russia’s south disrupted military logistics by firebombing locomotives, and Sweden and Ukraine signed a weapons-tech hub LOI. Zelenskiy reports daily restorations to power grid under Russian strikes; trader Gunvor withdrew Lukoil bid amid US opposition; occupied Donetsk court jailed two Colombian fighters for 13 years.

articles.title: Single mothers in China find a new kind of partner – other single mothers
articles.trailText: Posts from women seeking like-minded parents to share a home and child-rearing responsibilities are appearing on social media
articles.summary: Faced with surging divorce rates, rising living costs and scant state welfare, China’s estimated 30 million single mothers are posting on social media to find fellow single moms to share homes and childcare duties. On Xiaohongshu, women like Zhu Danyu and Fei Yuan in Nanjing and Jiang Mengyue and Shi Mengyue in Guizhou have formed co-living households and joint businesses since 2022, pooling resources and parenting tasks. Experts say these informal, digital networks highlight state support failures and lack legal protections, yet offer financial relief and “double the love” for the children.

articles.title: Canada pushes on with ‘complete depopulation’ plan to cull 400 ostriches
articles.trailText: Country’s top court declines to block controversial cull of hundreds of birds amid fears of an avian flu outbreak
articles.summary: Canada’s Supreme Court refused to block a CFIA order to cull nearly 400 ostriches at Universal Ostrich Farms in BC over H5N1 flu fears. Officials, citing a stamping-out policy, seized the flock after 69 deaths and potential human and animal transmission. Farm owners and US figures like RFK Jr., Mehmet Oz and billionaire John Catsimatidis lobbied against the cull, citing herd immunity and calling the kills government overreach. Protesters have gathered, livestreaming doubts about the outbreak. Animal groups demand further testing, while Ottawa defends the depopulation to protect public health.

articles.title: Israel carries out wave of airstrikes on southern Lebanon
articles.trailText: Three towns attacked despite truce with Hezbollah in what Israeli military says was effort to prevent group rearming
articles.summary: Israeli warplanes struck Kfar Dounine, Tayr Debba and Zawtar al-Sharqiya in southern Lebanon after issuing 500m evacuation warnings, in a bid to prevent Hezbollah rearming. No casualties were reported. The strikes, more intense than Israel’s near-daily raids, violated a December 2024 ceasefire requiring Hezbollah disarmament and Israeli withdrawal, though Israel still holds five positions. Hezbollah, which has fired just once since the truce, reiterated its “legitimate right” to resist occupation but affirmed commitment to the deal. Lebanon’s government claims to have disarmed 85% of Hezbollah caches and aims to finish by year-end, amid Israeli pressure for full ceasefire enforcement.

articles.title: Famed Florentine diamond surfaces in Canada after century-long disappearance
articles.trailText: Empress Zita brought stone to Canada as Nazis took over Europe in 1940s and it remained in bank vault ever since
articles.summary: After vanishing post–WWII, the 137-carat pear-shaped Florentine Diamond, a fine citron-hued gem long linked to the Medici and Habsburg dynasties, has emerged from a secret Montreal bank vault. Empress Zita smuggled the jewel via cardboard suitcase in 1940 and sealed its whereabouts under a 100-year secrecy pact. Passed through her sons to grandsons, it remained hidden in Quebec until now. AE Köchert confirms its authenticity. The Habsburg family will exhibit the diamond in Canada, with no plans to sell or disclose its value.

articles.title: Sudanese militia group accused of war crimes agrees to a ceasefire
articles.trailText: International mediators broker three-month halt to civil war as further evidence emerges of mass civilian killings
articles.summary: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), accused of ethnically motivated mass killings in El Fasher and facing UN and Yale lab evidence of mass graves and civilian atrocities, has agreed to a three-month “humanitarian ceasefire” brokered by the US, Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia. Critics warn the move may deflect attention from alleged war crimes—including tens of thousands killed, mass grave burials, a hospital massacre of at least 460 and widespread sexual violence. The UAE’s backing of the RSF is under scrutiny, Sudan’s army vows to continue fighting, ICC prosecutors are gathering evidence, and Saudi-mediated talks seek a lasting peace.

articles.title: Bolivia’s ex-president who oversaw bloody crackdown on protesters freed from prison
articles.trailText: Release follows supreme court ruling that overturned Jeanine Áñez’s conviction for allegedly staging coup to seize power
articles.summary: Former interim president Jeanine Áñez, condemned for a 2019–20 crackdown blamed for systematic torture and over 20 protester deaths, has been freed after nearly five years when Bolivia’s supreme court annulled her ten-year sentence for allegedly staging a coup. The court ruled her succession after Evo Morales’s ouster a constitutional necessity. Áñez’s release—days before president-elect Rodrigo Paz Pereira’s inauguration—signals a shift away from the long-ruling leftwing MAS party.

articles.title: Dolphin seen near St Mark’s Square inspires Venetian rescue effort
articles.trailText: Safety of apparently fearless Mimmo at risk as the acrobatic bottlenose attracts admirers and selfie tours
articles.summary: Venice activists have launched a ‘Save Mimmo’ campaign to protect an acrobatic bottlenose dolphin that has been routinely appearing in St Mark’s Basin since June. While Manuel Tiffi, a water-taxi driver, reports it fearlessly swimming near bows, rising tourist selfie tours and reckless boat-chasing risk serious propeller injury. Cristina Romieri insists Mimmo is a wild animal, not a novelty, and should be guided back to open sea. University of Padova’s CERT team and the coastguard are monitoring the dolphin, urging vessels to keep 50m distance to avoid disturbance and potential harm.

articles.title: Letter: Felicity Oppé obituary
articles.trailText: Hannah Kanter writes: Fizzy never lost her awareness of the absurd
articles.summary: Hannah Kanter’s obituary for Felicity Oppé, known as Fizzy, recalls meeting her at a 1970s Cambridge women’s liberation gathering, where Oppé��s charm, glamour and playful wit balanced the era’s earnest “personal is political” ethos. Kanter highlights a spirited debate card that quipped about “not worrying the ins and outs of penetration,” encapsulating Oppé’s trademark mix of political seriousness and absurd humor.

articles.title: Unesco adopts global standards on ‘wild west’ field of neurotechnology
articles.trailText: UN body’s recommendations driven by AI advances and proliferation of consumer-oriented neurotech devices
articles.summary: Unesco has adopted global ethical standards for the emerging “wild west” field of neurotechnology, driven by AI breakthroughs and consumer gadgets that read brain and nervous-system signals. The guidelines create a new data class, “neural data,” and offer over 100 recommendations—from enshrining mental privacy and freedom of thought to pre-empting futuristic risks like subliminal dream marketing. Backed by surging investments in AI-powered BCIs (e.g., Merge Labs, Neuralink) and devices like Meta’s AI wristband, the move follows the World Economic Forum’s privacy framework and the US Mind Act. Critics warn that broad rules could stifle medical advances in Parkinson’s, ALS and speech-decoding research.

articles.title: South Africa launches investigation into 17 citizens fighting in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Men aged 20 to 39 ‘lured to join mercenary force’ in Donbas region have requested assistance to return home
articles.summary: South Africa has opened an inquiry after 17 men aged 20–39, reportedly lured with bogus job offers, ended up fighting as mercenaries in Russia-occupied Donbas and have sought government help to return. The case underscores Russia’s use of coercion and deceptive recruitment campaigns across Asia, Africa and Latin America, often via social media ads promising high pay for non-combat roles. While both Moscow and Kyiv enlist foreign fighters, analysts say these recruits are marginal numerically but key to propaganda efforts. State-backed North Korean troops further bolster Russia’s ranks amid Ukraine’s manpower shortages.

articles.title: ‘We need help’: devastated Jamaican communities still await aid after Hurricane Melissa
articles.trailText: Ravaged communities near Montego Bay recount what last week’s category 5 storm took from them
articles.summary: In Montego Bay’s Catherine Hall, families displaced by Hurricane Melissa describe homes filled with silt, with beds, appliances and personal belongings in soggy heaps, and report no shelter, clean water or food despite slow government distributions. NGOs—Operation Blessing, World Central Kitchen and local churches—run aid centres as US$24m from the US, 40 tonnes of French relief and the UK’s £7.5m and Royal Navy support arrive. PM Holness estimates damages at one-third of GDP, seeks regional funding; scientists warn warming oceans fuel stronger storms and calls grow for reparations beyond colonial-era debt.

articles.title: Mohamed Al Fayed accuser criticises Met refusal to investigate trafficking claims
articles.trailText: French police are investigating Pelham Spong’s allegations but she says Met ‘are not calling it sex trafficking’
articles.summary: Pelham Spong, 40, from South Carolina, alleges she was trafficked to Paris on Mohamed Al Fayed’s orders in 2008, then sent to London for sexual assault. French prosecutors have opened a human trafficking and pimping inquiry after interviewing her this week. Spong criticises the Metropolitan police for closing her 2017 assault report and refusing to classify it as sex trafficking. Her lawyer is investigating whether Ritz staff facilitated recruitment and transfer. Experts liken these systematic abuses to Epstein-style trafficking. The Met now counts 146 related reports and has referred itself to the UK police watchdog.

articles.title: Mexican women outraged by public sexual assault on their president
articles.trailText: ‘Humiliating’ groping of Claudia Sheinbaum by drunken man prompts widespread condemnation
articles.summary: President Claudia Sheinbaum was publicly groped by a drunken man in Mexico City, despite heavy security, and the assailant was arrested as she vowed to press charges. The episode ignited widespread outrage among women—who see their own fears mirrored in her experience—and fueled criticism of endemic gender violence in Mexico, where an average of 10 women are killed daily and over 500 femicides occurred in six months. Feminists and female politicians across parties condemned the assault and promised tougher legislation, while PRI leader Alejandro Moreno accused the government of staging a political distraction.

articles.title: Malaysian rapper Namewee arrested over alleged murder of Taiwanese influencer
articles.trailText: Namewee detained after Hsieh Yu-hsin found dead in a Kuala Lumpur hotel room on 22 October
articles.summary: Malaysian rapper and filmmaker Namewee (Wee Meng Chee) was detained after Taiwanese influencer Hsieh Yu-hsin, 31, was found dead in a Kuala Lumpur hotel room on 22 October. Authorities reclassified her death as murder after unspecified new evidence. Police initially charged Namewee with ecstasy possession; he was bailed then remanded for six days to assist the homicide probe. He denies drug use and any involvement in Hsieh’s death, criticising media sensationalism, alleged blackmail attempts and slow emergency response. Hsieh, known as Nurse Goddess with 1.5 million followers, was in Malaysia for a commercial video project. Taiwan’s foreign ministry has informed her family and requested privacy.

articles.title: Louvre heist a ‘deafening wake-up call’, says auditor
articles.trailText: Report says Paris museum prioritised ‘visible and attractive’ projects over security in run-up to robbery
articles.summary: France’s state auditor labels October’s €88m Louvre crown jewels theft a “deafening wake-up call,” criticizing years of underinvestment in security and maintenance in favor of public-facing projects. A 2018–24 report finds only 39% of rooms camera-equipped, security upgrades delayed until 2032, and technical facilities neglected despite ample funding. Four suspects detained after a seven-minute daylight heist via a stolen ladder truck into the Apollo gallery, escaping with eight priceless items. Recommendations include boosting surveillance, raising ticket prices, cutting art acquisitions and implementing ten audit proposals, which management has largely accepted amid a larger museum revamp.

articles.title: US military buildup off Venezuela coast stirs echoes of 1989 Panama invasion
articles.trailText: Some see anti-Noriega operation as model for deposing Maduro but others say US-orchestrated military coup is more likely option
articles.summary: Since August, the US has deployed roughly 10,000 troops, the USS Gerald R. Ford, B-52 bombers, Reaper drones and warships off Venezuela’s coast—its largest Latin America buildup since 1989’s Operation Just Cause. Officially targeting drug traffickers (over 60 killed), many suspect regime-change objectives to topple Nicolás Maduro. Opposition figures like Leopoldo López back direct intervention, but a YouGov poll finds 48% of Americans opposed to military force. Analysts warn of no permanent bases, unknown loyalty of Maduro’s armed forces and high risk of casualties. They predict limited airstrikes or CIA-style psychological operations over a full ground invasion.

articles.title: Ukraine faces ‘forever war’ unless Europe steps up pressure on Russia, says ex-Nato chief
articles.trailText: Anders Fogh Rasmussen calls for air shield on Nato territory and deployment of European protection force for Ukraine
articles.summary: Ex-NATO secretary general Anders Fogh Rasmussen warns Ukraine faces a “forever war” and territorial erosion unless Europe sharply increases pressure on Russia. He proposes NATO allies (e.g., Poland) host an air defense umbrella—missile and drone shields on allied soil—to shield Ukrainian infrastructure plus deploy a European protection force before any ceasefire. Rasmussen also urges supplying long-range strikes into Russia (US Tomahawks or German Taurus), iron-clad security guarantees akin to those for Qatar, and tapping €150 billion in frozen Russian assets as loans for arms and reconstruction to force Putin to negotiate peace.

articles.title: Climate crisis means super-strength Hurricane Melissa is ‘dangerous new reality’
articles.trailText: Winds of Melissa’s strength are now five times more frequent due to the climate crisis, research says
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa was Jamaica’s strongest storm ever, intensifying to Category 5 with 185 mph winds that scientists attribute to a 1.3 °C warmer climate. Research by World Weather Attribution finds climate change increased max winds by 7%, rainfall by 16% and made five-day downpours 30% more intense, rendering Category 5 storms five times likelier. Melissa’s 1.5 °C-hotter waters fueled rapid intensification, causing $6 bn in damage (one-third of GDP), displacing hundreds of thousands and killing 61. Caribbean leaders urge scaled-up climate finance at COP.

articles.title: Threats, fear and hope as Mumbai slum dwellers await the bulldozers
articles.trailText: Many of Dharavi’s 1m residents fear community hub will become playground for rich under Adani Group’s redevelopment plan
articles.summary: Facing threats and police intimidation, Dharavi residents oppose Adani Group’s $950m redevelopment to replace 220ha slum of 1m migrants with luxury towers, shopping malls and parks. Promised modern homes and infrastructure, fewer than half may receive apartments; others face relocation to distant wastelands like polluted Deonar dump. Artisans, tailors, chai sellers warn project fragments organic community, disrupt $1–2bn informal economy and displace lower-caste migrants. Critics allege cronyism, lack of consultation and coercion; Adani and state insist plan is transparent, more generous than past slum schemes. With demolitions looming, uncertainty and fears of erasure of Dharavi’s social fabric persist.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: ​Inside Labour’s ambitious rethink of the national curriculum
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: After decades of political tinkering, a new review of England’s national curriculum promises change without chaos – but can it really add without overwhelming​?
articles.summary: In a Bridget Phillipson–commissioned review led by Prof Becky Francis, England’s national curriculum is overhauled to streamline content, shorten exams and add citizenship, financial and digital literacy and fake-news detection without expanding workload. It recommends reframing PE as GCSE Sport Science, sequencing topics to avoid redundancy and protecting enrichment activities alongside core GCSEs, A-levels and SATs. The government has broadly welcomed shorter GCSEs and a new Year 8 reading test, but faces an ambitious 2029 implementation timetable and uncertain political continuity before pupils first sit the revised exams in 2040.

articles.title: As Japan experiences a surge in bear attacks, survivors share grisly stories of blood, bites and broken bones
articles.trailText: A record 13 people have died in bear maulings in Japan this year, with experts blaming food shortages as the animals venture further into residential areas
articles.summary: Japan has recorded a record 13 bear-related deaths and over 100 injuries this year amid some 20,000 sightings from April to September, double last year’s tally. Experts link the surge in Asiatic black and Ussuri brown bear incursions into towns and farms—especially in Akita, Gifu and Hokkaido—to acorn and beechnut shortages driven by climate anomalies, rural depopulation blurring satoyama borders, and expanding human footprint. Authorities have deployed 15 SDF troops to set traps, eased gun restrictions for hunters, and recommend hikers carry bells, whistles or plastic bottles. Urban deterrents now include drones simulating fireworks, while emergency measures to hire more sharpshooters arrive later this month.

articles.title: Putin’s repressive machinery turns inward to target pro-war figures
articles.trailText: Analysts say a purge of the Russian regime’s own supporters is under way as rival factions turn on each other
articles.summary: In recent months, the Kremlin has begun to label long-time pro-war figures—political analyst Sergei Markov, blogger Roman Alyokhin and RT commentator Tatyana Montyan—as “foreign agents” or “extremists,” exposing them to harsh legal and financial controls. Observers see a power struggle between state-aligned “loyalists,” led by broadcaster Vladimir Solovyov, and independent ultranationalist “militarist” bloggers over funding and influence on the Ukraine war effort. Experts warn this inward purge reflects an autocracy’s fear of any independent mobilization and a battle for resources, as rival factions turn on former allies to justify continued repression.

articles.title: Belgium to hold security meeting after drone sightings at airports and military bases
articles.trailText: Source says Russia ‘very probably’ responsible amid surge in incursions into European airspace since mid-September
articles.summary: Belgium’s national security council will convene Thursday after coordinated drone incursions grounded flights at Brussels and Liège airports and were sighted over Schaffen and Kleine-Brogel military bases. Defence minister Theo Francken described large drones flying in formation as hybrid tactics, likely orchestrated by a state actor “very probably Russia.” The surge follows mid-September airspace breaches across Europe. Brussels airport cancelled 95 flights, stranding 400–500 passengers. Interior minister Bernard Quintin urged calm, coordinated action. The meeting, chaired by PM Bart De Wever, aims to bolster security amid Russia tensions and stalled EU talks on frozen-asset aid to Ukraine.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Bulgaria moves to seize Russian refinery while Poland seeks to be US gas conduit
articles.trailText: Lukoil’s Burgas plant is Bulgaria’s only refinery; Slovakia running out of reasons to buy Russian gas as US import deal takes shape. What we know on day 1,352
articles.summary: Bulgaria is moving to seize Lukoil’s Burgas refinery, its sole plant, and reassign ownership under draft legislation after US and UK sanctions on Lukoil and Rosneft threaten shutdown. Meanwhile Poland, the US, Slovakia and Ukraine are finalizing an LNG import deal—up to 4–5 billion m3 annually via southern Poland—to wean central Europe from Russian supplies as the EU aims to end oil and gas imports by 2027. On day 1,352 of the war, heavy street fighting engulfs Pokrovsk amid Ukrainian efforts to repel encirclement, while Angelina Jolie reportedly toured Kherson and Mykolaiv hospitals in a bulletproof vest.

articles.title: Troubled New Zealand wildlife park euthanizes two lions, fate of five more unclear
articles.trailText: Members of the public have pleaded for a reprieve for the remaining lions, while former staff members hope the sanctuary will reconsider putting them down
articles.summary: Kamo Wildlife Sanctuary, closed due to financial issues, Facebook update: two of seven elderly lions (18–21 years) euthanized (Imvula, Sibili) for untreatable conditions; five survivors face uncertain fate—potential buyers express interest despite tight timeframe; relocation deemed non-viable given age and care complexity; public and ex-staff plead reprieve amid mounting pleas and operator-targeted threats; privately owned by Bolton Equities, 32.5 ha site on market since August; MPI oversight ensures humane euthanasia; sanctuary featured on 2000s “Lion Man,” shuttered 2014 for upgrades, reopened 2021, liquidated 2023, hopes for new ownership and capital infusion.

articles.title: Disgraced former king of Spain’s memoir details ‘enormous respect’ for Franco
articles.trailText: Memoir chronicles Juan Carlos’s anointment as heir to dictator and death of younger brother when playing with pistols
articles.summary: Juan Carlos’s memoir Reconciliation recounts being summoned at age 10 by Franco to be his heir—an experience he now describes with “enormous respect”—and saving Spain’s democracy by thwarting the 1981 coup. He reveals lifelong grief over his brother Alfonso’s pistol accident, and bitterness at being sidelined by son Felipe VI, family and country (he’s uninvited to Franco’s 50th anniversary). The ex-king, in exile since 2020 in Abu Dhabi, laments loss of freedom despite founding democracy, regrets his Danish-German mistress affair, the lavish Botswana hunt during Spain’s 2012 crisis and accepting a €65 million Saudi gift. He highlights his lack of pension.

articles.title: Louvre heist suspect is social media star and former museum guard, reports say
articles.trailText: Man, identified as Abdoulaye N, is one of four accused over theft of historic jewels worth tens of millions of pounds
articles.summary: Abdoulaye N, 39, aka social-media rider Doudou Cross Bitume, is charged with organised theft and conspiracy after the €88 m Louvre crown-jewels heist on 19 October. A former Pompidou security guard from Aubervilliers, his DNA linked him to a smashed display case and discarded gloves, hi-vis vest and cutters. Investigators say he helped break in via a stolen truck with ladder, then fled on a Yamaha TMax. Four suspects are held; trial postponed amid intense media scrutiny.

articles.title: Libyan general accused of crimes against humanity arrested in Tripoli
articles.trailText: Osama Almasri Najim was arrested in Italy in January on an ICC warrant, only to be released and flown back to Libya
articles.summary: Libyan prosecutors arrested Gen. Osama Almasri Najim in Tripoli over ICC charges of war crimes, torture and murder at the capital’s main prison, following new evidence including the death of one inmate and abuse of ten others. Najim had been arrested in Turin in January on the ICC warrant but controversially released and repatriated on an Italian air force plane under PM Giorgia Meloni’s government, which cited national security concerns amid migration cooperation with Libya. Critics in Italy and the ICC condemned Rome for breaching its Rome Statute obligations; opposition leaders denounced the repatriation and called for accountability. The case spotlights the 2017 Italy-Libya migration pact.

articles.title: Man gropes Mexican president as she speaks to citizens on the streets
articles.trailText: Visibly drunk man tries to kiss and embrace Claudia Sheinbaum, highlighting security risk and harassment women face in Mexico
articles.summary: A video captured a visibly drunk man groping and attempting to kiss President Claudia Sheinbaum as she mingled in Mexico City; her aides intervened seconds later. Sheinbaum, who plans to press charges against the arrested suspect, framed the attack as emblematic of the sexual harassment faced by women nationwide: “If they do this to the president…” Commentators linked the incident to entrenched patriarchy and questioned her sparse security, noting recent killings of public officials, including a mayor on Day of the Dead and 37 electoral candidates. Sheinbaum vows to retain open-crowd access while reinforcing a “no consent” message.

articles.title: Russian forces appear to tighten grip on strategic city of Pokrovsk
articles.trailText: Military analysts say situation in Pokrovsk has deteriorated, while Kremlin says it plans to explore resumption of nuclear testing
articles.summary: Russian forces have intensified street fighting in Pokrovsk, edging within miles of encircling Ukrainian defenders in this critical Donetsk highway hub. Ukraine’s general staff denies encirclement, reinforcing flanks near Pokrovsk and Myrnohrad, while President Zelensky visits front-line troops. Open-source analysts report a sharp deterioration, with dismounted assault groups giving way to a broader offensive. Amid this, Putin has ordered proposals for possible nuclear tests in retaliation to US threats, following recent trials of the Burevestnik missile and Poseidon drone. Kyiv deployed special forces under fire to prevent a rout, but critics warn of a costly, perhaps futile stand. Pokrovsk’s fall could pave the way towards Kramatorsk and Sloviansk.
