articles.title: Mary was not co-redeemer, Vatican says amid spread of cult of the Madonna
articles.trailText: Pope Leo approves decree saying co-redeemer title risks eclipsing exclusive role of Jesus in saving humanity
articles.summary: Vatican doctrinal office decree approved by Pope Leo instructs Catholics to reject calling Mary "co-redeemer" or "co-redemptrix", emphasizing Jesus alone saved humanity through his sacrificial death. The move responds to a surge of social-media driven Marian apparitions and warns the title risks eclipsing Christ’s exclusive role. It follows objections from Francis and Benedict XVI and reverses John Paul II’s past use. Cardinal Fernández framed it as clarifying acceptable Marian devotion amid proliferating hoaxes.

articles.title: France moves to suspend Shein over sex dolls as debut store opens in Paris
articles.trailText: The fast-fashion retailer has faced a backlash after the childlike dolls were discovered for sale on its website
articles.summary: France’s government, acting on prime ministerial orders, will suspend fast-fashion site Shein over its sale of childlike sex dolls, triggering a 48-hour compliance review as prosecutors open investigations. The announcement coincided with Shein’s first Paris store launch at BHV under heavy police guard and queues for €4 T-shirts. Shein says it will seek urgent talks with authorities, ban all sex dolls and remove third-party products in France. Shoppers praise low prices, while politicians and protesters decry ecological, social and moral risks, with Socialist MP Grégoire warning of societal “disposability.” Seven Galeries Lafayette outlets may need to rebrand if they host Shein pop-ups.

articles.title: High-speed rail network possible by 2040, says European Commission
articles.trailText: Plan to cut journey times between major cities could reduce Berlin-Copenhagen trip from seven to four hours
articles.summary: The European Commission unveiled a vision for a unified high-speed rail network by 2040, with trains above 250 km/h cutting cross-border times: Berlin–Copenhagen to 4h by 2030 (from 7h), Sofia–Athens to 6h by 2035 (from 14h), Tallinn–Riga to 1h45 (from 6h10) and Lisbon–Madrid to 3h (from 9h). It estimates €546 bn is needed to triple the 12,128 km network, covering infrastructure, rolling stock, signalling and ticketing. The plan promises EU financing incentives and legislative proposals in early 2026 to enable seamless cross-border booking and expanded passenger rights. Consumer and industry bodies praised the push for sustainable travel, while experts warn it remains an aspirational outline lacking concrete projects and funding details.

articles.title: Lessons for liberals: what can Dutch progressives’ victory over populism teach the world?
articles.trailText: Rob Jetten beat far-right firebrand Geert Wilders in the recent election, but that doesn’t mean it’s the start of Europe’s progressive surge
articles.summary: Rob Jetten’s centrist D66 clinched 26 seats to Geert Wilders’s PVV’s 26, winning by just 28,400 votes thanks to an optimistic ‘het kan wél’ campaign that blended progressive patriotism with a big-tent appeal and direct challenges to the far right. Voter frustration with the previous PVV-led coalition’s dysfunction and the Netherlands’ fragmented proportional system fuelled D66’s rise from nine seats. Yet far-right parties collectively gained ground, and Jetten faces lengthy four-party coalition talks amid VVD reluctance to partner with leftists, tempering any notion of a broad progressive surge.

articles.title: Danish authorities in rush to close security loophole in Chinese electric buses
articles.trailText: Investigation launched after discovery that Chinese supplier had remote access to vehicles’ control systems
articles.summary: Denmark’s Movia (469 Chinese electric buses, 262 by Yutong) and Norway’s Ruter have uncovered that the Chinese supplier’s remote-access for updates and diagnostics could allow buses to be deactivated in transit. Norwegian tests in isolation identified risks that could be mitigated by removing SIM cards—yet that severs other vital systems—prompting plans for stricter procurement security standards. Denmark’s civil protection agency, Samsik, is advising on internet-connected subsystems (cameras, microphones, GPS) but reports no known incidents. Yutong insists it complies with EU regulations, encrypts data in AWS Frankfurt, and restricts access, while critics warn against Denmark’s dependency on Chinese technology amid broader security concerns.

articles.title: Five injured after man ‘deliberately’ drives car into people on French island
articles.trailText: Two people in ‘very serious condition’ and suspect arrested after pedestrians and cyclists hit on Île d’Oléron
articles.summary: On 5 November on Île d’Oléron, a 35-year-old local fisherman drove his car deliberately into pedestrians and cyclists over a 35-minute rampage between Saint-Pierre d’Oléron and Dolus-d’Oléron, injuring five people—two in very serious condition, including a parliamentary aide to National Rally MP Pascal Markowsky. The suspect, known for alcohol-related incidents and petty crime but not on any security watchlist, shouted “Allahu Akbar” at arrest, tried to set his vehicle alight and was subdued with a stun gun. Authorities have not invoked anti-terror charges as they probe his motive and mental state.

articles.title: This machine could keep a baby alive outside the womb. How will the world decide to use it?
articles.trailText: For parents who have buried infants born too soon, a device like the AquaWomb is a miracle in waiting – and an impossible choice
articles.summary: Scientists are developing artificial womb devices like AquaWomb and the “biobag” to sustain extremely premature infants (22–24 weeks) by circulating synthetic amniotic fluid and an external placenta, bypassing immature lungs. After promising lamb trials, FDA advisory panels weigh human studies. Parents bereaved by prematurity, like painter Beth Schafer, confront hopes for survival, emotional bonding challenges and ethical dilemmas over consent, viability limits and potential coercion. Bioethicists stress the need to balance life-saving benefits with parents’ psychological needs and societal definitions of parenthood, life and reproductive agency.

articles.title: Facebook’s job ads algorithm is sexist, French equality watchdog rules
articles.trailText: Regulator found ads for mechanics skewed towards men while those for preschool teachers targeted women
articles.summary: France’s Défenseur des Droits ruled Facebook’s (Meta) targeted job-ads algorithm is indirectly discriminatory by sex, after a Global Witness study found 9/10 mechanic ads shown to men and 9/10 preschool-teacher ads shown to women (likewise 8/10 psychologists to women, 7/10 pilots to men). The non-binding ruling gives Meta three months to adopt non-discriminatory measures. Complainants—including La Fondation des Femmes and Femmes Ingénieurs—welcome the precedent; Meta rejects the decision, citing ongoing legal review.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: Improbable victory for city’s first Muslim mayor offers new playbook for fight against Trump
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With more than 50% of the vote, Mamdani tells supporters: “In this moment of political darkness, New York will be the light”
articles.summary: Zohran Mamdani, a 34-year-old democratic socialist and son of Ugandan immigrants, won New York’s mayoral race with over 50% of the vote and record turnout since the 1960s, becoming the city’s first Muslim and youngest mayor in a century. His upbeat, grassroots revolt focused on rent, wages, transit and childcare defied racist, anti-socialist attacks and positioned him as the new face of resistance to Trump. Alongside Democratic wins in Virginia, New Jersey and a California redistricting win, his landslide offers a fresh blueprint for progressives, though GOP smears and federal pushback loom over his ambitious platform.

articles.title: Return of Chinese astronauts delayed after spacecraft struck by debris
articles.trailText: The three astronauts from the Shenzhou-20 mission flew to the Tiangong space station in April, and were expected to return on Wednesday
articles.summary: The Shenzhou-20 spacecraft was struck by orbital debris, delaying its Nov. 5 Earth return for three astronauts aboard Tiangong since April. Replacements from Shenzhou-21 arrived last weekend. The China Manned Space Agency is assessing impact risks and keeping a backup Shenzhou-22/Long March 2F launch on standby. Officials have not disclosed when the debris strike occurred. Commander Chen Dong holds Chinese records for cumulative spaceflight (380+ days) and six spacewalks. China has flown 37 missions, aims for a moon landing by 2030, and seeks international partners on Tiangong given its ISS exclusion.

articles.title: Shock as Orbán allies take ownership of Hungary’s most-read newspaper
articles.trailText: Blikk, a tabloid with about 3 million online monthly readers, bought by pro-Orbán media group Indamedia
articles.summary: Pro-Orbán media group Indamedia has acquired Ringier’s Hungarian titles, including Blikk—the country’s most-read tabloid with 3 million monthly online readers. Journalists expressed shock: outgoing editor Ivan Zsolt Nagy and another senior manager left, replaced by Balázs Kolossváry. Critics say the timing—six months before elections—signals Fidesz’s push to tighten media control. Opposition leader Péter Magyar and watchdog Mérték warn that propaganda in Blikk could sway voters. Indamedia’s co-owner, pro-government businessman Miklós Vaszily (CEO of TV2), underscores Orbán’s long-term strategy to dominate Hungary’s illiberal media landscape.

articles.title: Canada budget adds tens of billions to deficit as Carney spends to dampen Trump tariffs effect
articles.trailText: Budget envisions significant increase in defence spending, cuts to civil service and ‘generational investments’
articles.summary: In his first federal budget "Canada Strong," finance minister Mark Carney raised the projected 2025-26 deficit to C$78.3bn—up from a C$42.2bn forecast—citing US trade tariffs and a slowing economy. The plan funds C$84bn of defence spending over five years to meet a 3.5% NATO GDP target, "generational investments" to reshape competitiveness, and civil service cuts via retirement rules by 2028-29. Conservative MP Chris d'Entremont crossed the floor to back the minority Liberals ahead of a 17 November vote.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy visits troops near embattled Pokrovsk
articles.trailText: Deep Ukrainian drone strikes hit petrochemical plant 1,300km inside Russia and Lukoil refinery east of Moscow. What we know on day 1,351
articles.summary: President Zelenskyy toured front-line positions of the National Guard’s 1st Corps near Pokrovsk in Donetsk, where Russian forces are digging in after advancing amid ‘critical’ fighting. DeepState and ISW reports confirm Russian gains in Pokrovsk and Ukrainian counter-attacks in nearby Dobropillia. Kyiv launched drone strikes on Russia’s Sterlitamak petrochemical plant and a Lukoil refinery in Kstovo, prompting new Kremlin laws assigning reservists to refinery defense and year-round conscription. Zelenskyy pressed the US for long-range weapons, urged tougher EU sanctions and accelerated EU membership. Germany pledged €3 billion more aid; Norway’s Nammo signed an ammunition pact in Ukraine. Italy summoned Russia’s deputy ambassador over offensive Kremlin remarks.

articles.title: Malaysia defends Trump trade deal after critics warn it will compromise country’s sovereignty
articles.trailText: Former Malaysian prime minister Mahathir Mohamad said the deal amounted to ‘handing over’ the country’s independence
articles.summary: Malaysia’s government defended a US trade deal signed during Donald Trump’s Kuala Lumpur visit after critics warned it compromises sovereignty. Investment minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz called it “the best possible outcome” with the US, Malaysia’s top trading partner. Former PM Mahathir Mohamad argued provisions effectively hand over independence—mandating purchases of US planes, gas and machines, first claim on rare minerals and digital rules. Opposition MP Azmin Ali added Malaysia must mirror US sanctions, undermining neutrality. Civil society groups flagged risks of bypassed procurement laws and oversight. The ministry launched a microsite and a 15-page FAQ, stressing the right to unilaterally terminate and prepare for parliamentary review next week.

articles.title: Babies born to black mothers 81% more likely to die in neonatal care, NHS study shows
articles.trailText: Analysis of England and Wales units also finds 63% higher risk to babies whose mothers live in most deprived areas
articles.summary: A University of Liverpool analysis of 700,000+ NHS neonatal admissions (2012–22) in England and Wales finds stark ethnic and socioeconomic disparities. Babies born to Black mothers face an 81% higher risk of death before discharge than those born to White mothers (29.7 vs 16.9 per 1,000), while those from the most deprived areas have a 63% higher risk than least deprived peers (25.9 vs 12.8 per 1,000). Infants of Asian mothers also exhibit a 36% increased mortality. Researchers say maternal and birth factors explain just over half the gap, urging integrated clinical improvements and social interventions to tackle root inequalities.

articles.title: Munich's surfers left stunned after famed river wave vanishes
articles.trailText: Eisbach wave in the Bavarian city had been a surfing magnet for decades but disappeared after a recent cleanup
articles.summary: After its annual cleanup, Munich’s iconic Eisbach standing river wave—hailed as the birthplace of freshwater surfing since the early 1970s—failed to materialize, leaving only unstable rapids. Maintained over decades with wooden planks to stabilize its currents, the wave attracts surfers worldwide. City officials found no structural changes or damage during inspection and are probing whether water levels or cleaning procedures are to blame. Mayor Dieter Reiter says the administration, together with the Water Management Office and local surfers, will divert additional flow to restore the delicate balance needed for the ‘mother of all river waves.’

articles.title: Sudan civil war spiralling out of control, UN secretary general says
articles.trailText: António Guterres calls for the violence to end but there appears little appetite for ceasefire proposed by US
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General António Guterres warns Sudan’s two-year conflict between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and UAE-backed Rapid Support Forces (RSF) is “spiralling out of control” after the RSF seized El Fasher in North Darfur, besieging civilians and posting videos of shootings in hospitals. The war has killed 150,000+, displaced 14 million and prompted ICC probes into mass killings and rape. Guterres urged immediate talks. Doha debates a US-backed humanitarian pause and ceasefire stall as the SAF demands RSF withdraw from cities. Fears grow of Darfur’s partition amid stalled diplomacy. The UK envoy urged US to label the RSF a terrorist group and ban UAE arms sales.

articles.title: Brazil to seek independent inquiry into deadly police raid that killed 121 people
articles.trailText: Brazilian president Lula called police assault on two of Rio’s largest clusters of favelas ‘disastrous’ and a ‘massacre’
articles.summary: President Lula da Silva has announced his government will seek an independent federal inquiry into last week’s police assault on Rio’s Complexo do Alemão and Complexo da Penha favelas that killed at least 121 people, in what he labeled a “disastrous” state-led massacre beyond arrested suspects. While Rio Governor Claudio Castro praised it as a blow against the Red Command drug gang, human rights groups, security experts, and families are demanding forensic scrutiny. The raid’s unprecedented death toll has provoked domestic and international condemnation and overshadowed Brazil’s Cop30 summit.

articles.title: Sheinbaum denies reports US will send troops to Mexico: ‘It’s not going to happen’
articles.trailText: President says she’s repeatedly rejected such offers from Trump for US to confront Mexico’s powerful drug cartels
articles.summary: Mexico’s president Claudia Sheinbaum has denied NBC News reports that the Trump administration is planning to deploy US troops and CIA officers on Mexican soil to directly confront powerful drug cartels, noting that she has repeatedly rejected such offers. While US officials say early-stage training and scope talks are underway, Sheinbaum insisted “It’s not going to happen,” defended national sovereignty and condemned recent US naval strikes in the eastern Pacific that killed 14 suspected traffickers. She highlighted a new bilateral security agreement based on cooperation and ruled out any militarized “war on drugs” strategy.

articles.title: Let’s have a level playing field on publicising the ethnicity of suspects | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: The selective reporting of ethnicity creates the impression that a disproportionate amount of crime is committed by ethnic minorities, writes Martin Forde KC
articles.summary: Martin Forde KC responds to a Guardian report on police forced to disclose suspects’ ethnicity to counter far-right speculation, arguing that since 2020 police and media publicise ethnicity only when suspects are non-white, skewing public perception towards viewing ethnic minorities as disproportionately criminal. He cites scenarios where unspecified ethnicity—for instance a “Brixton rapist” headline—leads readers to default to white suspects, thus fueling racist stereotypes and attributing crime to a supposed “criminal gene.” Forde urges a level playing field where every suspect’s ethnic background is uniformly disclosed to promote transparency and counter bias. He frames the issue as intersectional, linking selective disclosure to entrenched racism, socio-economic disadvantage and nebulous “British values” that exclude minority communities.

articles.title: EU could admit new members by 2030, says its foreign policy chief
articles.trailText: Kaja Kallas tells reporters more countries could join 27-country bloc, including Montenegro, Albania and Ukraine
articles.summary: Kaja Kallas said the EU could realistically admit new members by 2030, citing Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and geopolitical shifts. Montenegro and Albania lead the accession process, while Ukraine pursues sweeping wartime reforms. Moldova achieved the fastest progress amid Russian hybrid threats. Georgia’s democratic backsliding and Serbia’s erosion of freedoms drew criticism. Hungary’s veto is blocking Ukraine and Moldova, spurring talks on bypassing unanimity. Officials say small-state accessions need no major treaty changes, though some advocate ending the foreign policy veto to streamline enlargement.

articles.title: Friedrich Merz says Syrians no longer have reason for asylum in Germany
articles.trailText: Chancellor suggests deportations could begin ‘in the near future’ as government seeks to counter rise of AfD
articles.summary: Chancellor Friedrich Merz declared that Syrians have no grounds for asylum in Germany following the collapse of Assad’s regime 11 months ago, urging the over 1 million Syrians to return and warning of deportations in the near future. His stance contrasts with Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul’s skepticism about voluntary repatriations given Syria’s devastation. The coalition faces pressure from the far-right AfD ahead of five state elections, while Germany’s health sector, which employs 7,000 Syrian doctors, depends on many integrated refugees. Amid security concerns after a foiled Islamist attack, Merz invited Syria’s interim president to discuss deporting migrants with criminal records.

articles.title: Spain grants citizenship to descendants of civil war’s International Brigades
articles.trailText: About 32,000 volunteered to fight Franco dictatorship, including 2,500 men and women from Britain and Ireland
articles.summary: Spain granted citizenship to 170 descendants of International Brigades volunteers who fought Franco’s dictatorship in the civil war. Around 32,000 anti-fascist volunteers—including 2,500 from Britain and Ireland, 530 of whom died—joined between 1936 and 1939. PM Pedro Sánchez hailed the new citizens as compatriots defending democracy amid global threats. Campaigners like Jim Jump view it as undoing Franco’s legacy and fulfilling the Republic’s promise. Among the recipients is Peter Crome, son of brigade doctor Len Crome. The government also moves to outlaw the Franco Foundation, remove fascist symbols and honour 18 dictatorship victims.

articles.title: Manslaughter inquiry opened after death of worker in Rome tower collapse
articles.trailText: Contractor was trapped for 11 hours under fallen masonry at medieval landmark near the Colosseum
articles.summary: Prosecutors in Rome have launched manslaughter and culpable-disaster probes after 66-year-old Romanian restorer Octav Stroici died at Umberto I hospital following an 11-hour entrapment under fallen masonry when the medieval Torre dei Conti near the Colosseum partially collapsed during EU-funded (€7m) restoration works. A fellow worker was injured; two others were rescued. Investigators are examining structural safety checks, a recent 3.3-magnitude quake and nearby metro construction as potential causes. The city declared a day of mourning. Italy’s largest union, Cgil, decries lax workplace safety.

articles.title: ‘We don’t have enough to eat, to live’: how Milei’s ‘chainsaw’ cuts are driving homelessness in Argentina
articles.trailText: Those hit hard by far-right leader’s zero-deficit policies fear worse to come after his election win
articles.summary: Under President Javier Milei’s “chainsaw” austerity plan, Argentina’s homelessness has surged, with Buenos Aires street occupancy rising 38% to over 4,500. Since his December 2023 inauguration, inflation tumbled from 200% to 30%, but 200,000 formal jobs vanished and 18,000 businesses closed, collapsing purchasing power. Pensioners and people with disabilities faced benefit suspensions, deep income losses and frozen services, while a boosted La Libertad Avanza bloc in Congress threatens further cuts. NGOs warn the crisis could worsen, as poverty already exceeds 30% and social safety nets fray under zero-deficit policies.

articles.title: As criticism grows, is UAE ready to walk away from Sudan’s RSF militia?
articles.trailText: After mass killings in El Fasher and four years on from a coup, UAE now admits its Sudan policy has gone wrong
articles.summary: The UAE has publicly admitted errors in its Sudan policy after supporting the RSF militia—responsible for mass killings in El Fasher—and failing to sanction the 2021 RSF-army coup. Senior envoy Anwar Gargash said Gulf states should have labeled the overthrow a coup. Early Emirati loans and covert arms to RSF commander Hemedti fueled civil war, resource plunder and gold smuggling. After losing the $6bn Abu Amama port deal and facing US-Saudi-Egypt pressure, the UAE now claims neutrality, urges a three-month truce under the Quad and must enforce UN embargoes to back an inclusive civilian transition.

articles.title: Torture in Israeli prisons rose sharply during war, says freed Palestinian author
articles.trailText: Nasser Abu Srour says prisons became like ‘another front’ in Gaza conflict and tells of struggle to adjust to life outside
articles.summary: Nasser Abu Srour, a 56-year-old Palestinian author freed last month after 32 years in Israeli prisons under a US-brokered Gaza ceasefire, says torture surged in his final two years as guards treated jails as “another front” in the Gaza war. He describes severe beatings, food and warmth deprivation and 75 recorded Palestinian deaths in custody since October 2023. Exiled with 153 others to Egypt, he faced culture shock in a Cairo five-star hotel and emotional family reunions after decades apart. His memoir, The Tale of a Wall, is translated into seven languages and shortlisted for major literary awards.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: Why Labour won’t press the ‘big red button’ to lift 450,000 children out of poverty
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The Labour Party recently sounded resolute in its intention to cut the two-child benefit cap. But against an ugly fiscal backdrop, the chancellor may be having second thoughts
articles.summary: Labour’s pledge to abolish the two-child benefit cap—widely derided as the worst UK social security policy—could instantly lift 330,000 children out of poverty (another 150,000 by 2030), but Chancellor Rachel Reeves, citing severe fiscal constraints, is now expected to stop short of full repeal. Instead, ministers may opt for limited measures—raising the cap to three children, delaying its application, or exempting families with disabled children—which critics say won’t stem rising child poverty (currently 31%) or fulfil Labour’s promise to reduce it by 450,000.

articles.title: Backlash after New Zealand government scraps rules on incorporating Māori culture in classrooms
articles.trailText: Minister says obligations for school boards to ‘give effect’ to the treaty are unfair while critics argue the move will sideline Indigenous education
articles.summary: New Zealand’s education minister Erica Stanford has removed a 2020 legal obligation requiring school boards to implement Treaty of Waitangi provisions—ensuring curricula and policies reflect local Māori customs, knowledge and language—in classrooms. The change replaces it with non-binding duties to “seek equitable outcomes” for Māori students and accommodate te reo Māori upon request, plus cultural diversity measures. Teachers, principals and board members warn the repeal risks sidelining Indigenous children, weakening social cohesion and undoing progress in valuing Māori history, language and identity.

articles.title: ‘Judges doing politics’: can Spanish PM survive corruption cases against family and allies?
articles.trailText: Facing allegations he insists are politically motivated, Spain’s PM has cast doubt on independence of some members of judiciary
articles.summary: Article about Spanish PM Pedro Sánchez facing corruption allegations targeting his family, allies and himself, which he insists are politically motivated. He has challenged the judiciary’s independence, accusing some judges of “doing politics.” Key legal battles include the trial of Attorney General Álvaro García Ortiz for leaking information on Isabel D��az Ayuso’s partner; investigations into his wife Begoña Gómez for alleged influence-peddling; and a probe of his brother’s appointed job. Sánchez also ousted PSOE organiser Santos Cerdán over alleged kickbacks. Leading a wavering minority coalition, Sánchez remains defiant as polls favour PSOE, but upcoming court rulings threaten his survival.

articles.title: ‘I felt violated’: the Italian women taking on pornography sites over doctored images
articles.trailText: Giorgia Meloni, Sophia Loren and writer Francesca Barra among prominent figures to have ‘nudified’ photos circulated online
articles.summary: In Italy, dozens of women—including journalist Francesca Barra, actor Sophia Loren and prime minister Giorgia Meloni—have found AI-manipulated 'nudified' photos posted without consent on sites like Social Media Girls, Mia Moglie and Phica. Barra filed the first legal complaint against Social Media Girls, sparking calls to close these ‘virtual rape’ forums amid investigative and prosecutorial action. A class-action led by Bernardini de Pace’s team faces obstacles: younger women fear reputational damage, limited funds and foreign site operators. Italy’s new AI law imposes penalties for nonconsensual doctored content, but experts urge cross-border cooperation, political unity and enhanced consent education to stem rising digital exploitation.

articles.title: Bali and the not-so-great glass elevator: construction on Kelingking beach prompts outrage from locals
articles.trailText: Construction of 182-metre tall lift has been halted after outrage from locals on the Indonesian tourist island
articles.summary: China Kaishi Group’s 182m glass elevator project at Bali’s Kelingking Beach on Nusa Penida, launched July 2023 to boost tourism and ease hazardous cliff access, has been suspended amid local outrage over ruined vistas and missing permits. Balinese authorities halted work pending spatial regulation review, despite the tourism ministry citing a 35% visitor increase and pledging sustainability, safety and rescue benefits. The design includes two external elevators, a sky café, restaurant and 400sqm overlook, but critics—including a local senator and residents—decry it as unnecessary, environmentally intrusive and distracting from deadly currents that have closed the beach to swimmers.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Kyiv gets more US-made Patriots and says its forces are holding on in Pokrovsk
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says the air defence systems being put into action while in embattled eastern city Russian troops haven’t advanced over past day. What we know on day 1,350
articles.summary: Ukraine has deployed additional US-made Patriot air-defence systems provided by Germany, President Zelenskyy announced, urging more deliveries to shield strategic targets. Russian drones killed a man and wounded five in Sumy; missiles damaged a Dnipro business and struck energy assets in Mykolaiv. Kyiv says its troops hold Pokrovsk against Moscow’s push and massed forces near Dobropillia; around 30% of fighting occurs there. ISW data shows Russia gained 461 sq km in October, controlling 81% of Donetsk and 19.2% of Ukraine. Kyiv is fielding a viral drone-control system, planning arms-export offices in Berlin and Copenhagen, and seeking EU energy aid and reforms.

articles.title: Worker dies after being rescued from partially collapsed medieval tower in Rome
articles.trailText: Romanian worker was taken to hospital in ‘serious condition�� after being saved from Torre dei Conti rubble, but died soon after
articles.summary: A Romanian construction worker, Octay Stroici, died after being rescued from rubble following two partial collapses of the 13th-century Torre dei Conti adjacent to Rome’s Colosseum. The first section fell at 10.30am, the second about 90 minutes later during aerial-ladder operations, intermittently re-burying Stroici. He was conscious when freed, then died in hospital. A second Romanian colleague suffered serious head trauma; two others sustained minor injuries. Funded by EU post-pandemic recovery, the restoration works now face scrutiny. PM Meloni and city authorities offered condolences as the site remains cordoned off.

articles.title: Activists could be jailed for six months for protesting outside MPs’ homes
articles.trailText: Law aimed at tackling harassment will criminalise protests outside homes of MPs in England and Wales amid rise in complaints
articles.summary: Under a new amendment to the crime and policing bill, protesting outside the homes of MPs, peers and councillors in England and Wales will become a criminal offence punishable by up to six months’ imprisonment. Triggered by a 96% harassment rate among MPs and high-profile stunts by groups such as Just Stop Oil, the measure defines such protests — intended to influence officials’ public or private lives — as “toxic” intimidation. Backed by ministers, the Jo Cox Foundation and Speaker Lindsay Hoyle, it excludes official residences but expands police clarity and powers.

articles.title: Chile to end Pinochet henchmen’s pampered prison life of tennis and barbecues
articles.trailText: Punta Peuco – where military human rights offenders enjoy privileged conditions – set to join public prison network
articles.summary: President Gabriel Boric announced that Punta Peuco, Chile’s high-security prison housing 141 mostly octogenarian ex-Pinochet security officers convicted of dictatorship-era human rights abuses, will be integrated into the public prison system to relieve overcrowding. Inmates will lose amenities such as tennis courts, barbecue facilities, library and TV room. Boric said the move ends “first and secondary category prisoners” and restores equal treatment based on security criteria. Far-right candidate José Antonio Kast condemned the decision, while communist contender Jeannette Jara praised it. Structural works, including new offices on former sports fields, are underway. Renamed Tiltil Penitentiary, the facility will start receiving common inmates early next year, marking a symbolic step towards a more democratic Chile respecting human dignity.

articles.title: UN resolution on international stabilisation force for Gaza could be ready within two weeks
articles.trailText: Resolution may be delayed without agreement over the force’s mandate and a timetable for Israeli withdrawal
articles.summary: UN Security Council resolution on deploying an international stabilisation force in Gaza could be finalised within two weeks but hinges on agreement over US military leadership, coordination with Palestinian police and a timetable for Israeli withdrawal. In Istanbul, Muslim states—Turkey, Indonesia, Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar and Jordan—debated troop commitments, deconfliction with Israel and the role of a technocratic Palestinian commission. Jordan will train a vetted Gaza police force, while Turkey remains cautious. Surging violence threatens the ceasefire, prompting calls for rapid force deployment, humanitarian coordination and a clear Hamas disarmament process.

articles.title: Canada’s Liberal party says budget of ‘sacrifice’ needed to avoid recession
articles.trailText: Country set to unveil PM Mark Carney’s spending plan as it battles trade war with US and protracted cost of living crisis
articles.summary: Facing a US-led trade war and a cost-of-living crisis, PM Mark Carney���s minority Liberal government will present a ‘budget of sacrifice’ on 4 Nov outlining steep deficits and spending cuts to ward off recession. Finance Minister François-Philippe Champagne’s plan blends tax relief, infrastructure outlays and defence boosts to shield industries battered by US protectionism. With no opposition backing yet lined up, a failed confidence vote could topple the government and trigger a federal election. Carney has lobbied all party leaders to secure support ahead of the 17 Nov vote.

articles.title: Why is Donald Trump threatening military intervention in Nigeria?
articles.trailText: US president’s remarks about alleged persecution of Christians seemingly in response to pressure from his evangelical base
articles.summary: Trump threatened a “guns-a-blazing” US military intervention in Nigeria over alleged Christian persecution after conservative and evangelical pressure to list Nigeria as a Country of Particular Concern. Posting on Truth Social, he blamed “radical Islamists,” warned of halting US aid and warned that Washington could invade. Nigeria’s roughly even Muslim-Christian split faces complex violence: herder-farmer clashes, Boko Haram/ISWAP insurgency in the northeast, bandit kidnappings in the northwest and Biafra separatist attacks in the southeast. President Tinubu defended Nigeria’s religious liberty, demanded data-driven assessments and warned against unilateral action that could strain aid, arms sales and fuel secessionist lobbying.

articles.title: At least 36,000 Sudanese have fled since fall of El Fasher to RSF, says UN agency
articles.trailText: International Organization for Migration says displaced are heading to Tawila, which is already sheltering 652,000 displaced people
articles.summary: After RSF captured El Fasher on October 26, the IOM reports 36,825 Sudanese from five North Kordofan localities have trekked to Tawila, already sheltering 652,000 displaced. The RSF–SAF battle now centers on El Obeid, a strategic hub linking Darfur and Khartoum. The ICRC warns of dire humanitarian conditions—famine in El Fasher and Kadugli, exhausted refugees collapsing en route—and the ICC is gathering evidence of alleged mass killings, rapes and abductions by RSF. UN officials decry “large-scale atrocities,” noting over 150,000 killed and 14 million displaced in Sudan’s two-year war as calls grow for a ceasefire and aid corridors.

articles.title: Israel top military lawyer arrested after she admitted leaking video of soldiers’ abuse
articles.trailText: Rightwing politicians and pundits have called the soldiers accused of attack on Palestinian detainee ‘heroes’ and military investigators traitors
articles.summary: Israel’s military advocate general Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi was arrested on suspicion of fraud, breach of trust, obstruction of justice and unauthorized disclosure after admitting she leaked footage showing soldiers violently assaulting a Palestinian detainee at Sde Teiman. She says she released it to defend investigators targeted by right-wing politicians and pundits who hailed the accused troops as heroes. Her detention underscores mounting concerns over rule-of-law, accountability for documented torture in detention and alleged war crimes against Palestinians during Israel’s Gaza campaign.

articles.title: Five climbers and two guides killed in Nepal avalanche, say officials
articles.trailText: Bad weather hampering rescue efforts after avalanche that swept through Mount Yalung Ri base camp on Monday
articles.summary: Officials report an avalanche struck the Mount Yalung Ri base camp (4,900m) on Monday, killing five foreign climbers—local media cite three US citizens, one Canadian and one Italian—and two Nepali guides. Five others were injured. Ongoing snowstorms have grounded rescue helicopters; teams are reaching the site on foot with a helicopter retry planned at dawn. At 5,600m, Mount Yalung Ri is considered beginner-friendly, attracting hundreds of foreign climbers each autumn between the monsoon and winter seasons in Nepal.

articles.title: Powerful Afghan earthquake leaves at least 20 dead and hundreds injured
articles.trailText: Northern provinces of Balkh and Samangan worst hit by magnitude 6.3 quake, which also damaged Mazar-i-Sharif’s Blue Mosque
articles.summary: At 12:59 am local time on November 3, a magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck 22 km southwest of Khulm in Balkh province at a depth of 28 km. Balkh, Samangan, Sar-e-Pul, Kunduz and Badakhshan provinces reported at least 20 deaths and 643 injuries (25 critical), with around 800 mud-brick homes destroyed in Shahr-e-Bozorg. Mazar-i-Sharif’s UNESCO-listed Blue Mosque lost some bricks but remained intact. Taliban and UN teams dispatched rescuers, cleared a rockslide blocking the Kabul–Mazar highway, and transported victims to hospitals. Pakistan offered condolences amid bilateral tensions and upcoming peace talks. The quake echoes August’s 2,200-fatal eastern tremor and October 2023’s 4,000-death event.

articles.title: Australian scientist who alerted world that Covid is airborne wins top science prize
articles.trailText: Prof Lidia Morawska says recognition of her research comes at a fraught time – an ‘age of anti-science’
articles.summary: Prof Lidia Morawska of QUT won the $250,000 Prime Minister’s Prize for Science for her leading work on airborne Covid-19 transmission—mobilising 239 experts to persuade WHO to revise guidelines—and her current research on ultrafine particles’ health impacts. In its 26th year, the awards also honoured Prof Michael Wear, a Malgana custodian, with the inaugural Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledge systems prize for founding Tidal Moon, an Indigenous-led sea cucumber fishery that funds seagrass restoration. Other recipients included Yao Zheng for seawater hydrogen production and Vikram Sharma for quantum cybersecurity applications.

articles.title: A single shell, fired by the IDF at a fertility clinic: peace prize recipient explains what lies behind her genocide finding
articles.trailText: Former UN inquiry chair Navi Pillay says ‘what’s so unusual about this genocide’ is that ‘we are all witnesses to it’
articles.summary: Former UN commission chair Navi Pillay, awarded the Sydney Peace Prize for her advocacy, spotlights the December 2023 IDF strike on Gaza’s Al-Basma fertility clinic—which destroyed 4,000 embryos—as a stark example underpinning her panel’s July finding that Israel has committed genocide. After two years of forensic field investigations documenting war crimes by Hamas and systematic assaults on healthcare, she condemns global inaction despite absolute legal duties to prevent genocide, draws parallels to Rwanda’s dehumanization rhetoric and calls for accountability, Palestinian self-determination and an end to occupation.

articles.title: Israel and Hamas hand over bodies as part of Gaza ceasefire deal
articles.trailText: Hamas hands remains of three soldiers to Israel and bodies of 45 Palestinians are returned to Gaza amid fragile ceasefire
articles.summary: Israel and Hamas exchanged remains under a US-brokered ceasefire, with Hamas handing over three Israeli soldiers killed on 7 October 2023—identified as a colonel, an Israeli-American tank commander, and a sergeant—while Israel returned 45 Palestinian bodies (270 total since the truce) to Gaza. Hamas freed living hostages in exchange for nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners. The deal covers all 28 deceased hostages; eight bodies remain. Gaza’s shattered health system struggles to identify remains. Both sides accuse each other of violations as Trump’s 20-point plan stumbles over Gaza governance and Hamas disarmament.

articles.title: Abortion is on the ballot in three US states, from supreme court to governor
articles.trailText: Reproductive justice has changed the face of judicial and gubernatorial races as abortion sanctuaries fight back
articles.summary: In three key 2025 US state contests—New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Virginia—abortion rights are the central issue. In NJ’s governor race, Democrat Mikie Sherrill (supports current unrestricted access) leads Republican Jack Ciattarelli (favours a 20-week ban, defunding Planned Parenthood) by about five points. In Pennsylvania, voters decide whether to retain three Democratic supreme court justices whose 5–2 majority in 2024 struck down a Medicaid abortion-funding ban; outside groups have poured $15m–$16m into the campaign. In Virginia, Democrat Abigail Spanberger backs abortion to 27 weeks and a constitutional amendment, while GOP Lt Gov Winsome Earle-Sears—who once called abortion “genocide”—insists she’ll follow majority opinion. Democrats must also hold the state house to advance the VA amendment.

articles.title: ‘Olives are everything for us’: West Bank farmers prevented from harvesting by settler violence
articles.trailText: About 70% of town’s olives are inaccessible without risking a potentially fatal clash with Israeli settlers
articles.summary: In As-Sawiya, rolling hills hide 70% of olive groves cut off by settler violence, military barriers and withheld permits. Since October PFU and UN recorded 86 harvest-related attacks, 3,000 trees uprooted and 112 Palestinians hurt. Backed by Israel’s far-right ruling coalition, annexation bills won preliminary Knesset support, fueling settlement expansion. With 110,000 farmers and 50,000 processors dependent on olives—once a $130 m industry—production fell from 150,000 to 30,000 L. Rural life and economies teeter.

articles.title: Pregnant UK teenager Bella May Culley freed from Georgian jail
articles.trailText: Culley, 19, who was arrested on drug-smuggling charges in May, is released after plea deal
articles.summary: Nineteen-year-old Bella May Culley, pregnant and from Teesside, UK, has been released from a Georgian prison after six months on drug-smuggling charges via a plea deal. Arrested at Tbilisi airport in May for allegedly carrying 12 kg of marijuana and 2 kg of hashish, she was sentenced to five months and 25 days—equal to her time served—and fined 500,000 lari (£137,000). Georgian authorities dropped further imprisonment, acknowledging time served. Culley, who maintains she was tortured and forced to transport drugs following a disappearance in Thailand, will recover her passport and may depart Georgia.

articles.title: Xi Jinping cracks joke about spying with phones given to South Korean president
articles.trailText: Chinese leader says ‘check if there is a backdoor’ in reply to Lee Jae Myung’s quip about security of Xiaomi devices
articles.summary: In a rare display of humor at the APEC summit in Gyeongju, Chinese president Xi Jinping laughed off South Korean leader Lee Jae-Myung’s quip about the security of two Xiaomi smartphones Xi had gifted him, inviting Lee to “check if there is a backdoor.” The exchange, Xi’s first public joke in years, underscored lingering US concerns over Chinese device surveillance; Beijing denies any espionage allegations. It marked Xi’s first South Korea visit in over a decade and highlighted growing personal rapport, cemented by reciprocal gifts including a hand-carved Go board.

articles.title: Valencia president Carlos Mazón resigns over botched handling of deadly floods
articles.trailText: Leader of Spanish region’s People’s party had clung to power despite calls for him to stand down over 2024 disaster
articles.summary: Carlos Mazón, PP president of Valencia, has resigned amid outrage over his mishandling of the October 2024 floods that killed 229 people. Evidence he spent over three hours at lunch while residents drowned, and delayed emergency alerts until after 8pm, sparked mass protests under slogans like "Mud on our hands, blood on his" and a survey showing 75% demanded his departure. A judicial inquiry is investigating potential reckless homicide and negligence. Mazón offered no timetable for elections or his parliamentary seat, leaving his political future uncertain.

articles.title: Monday briefing: ‘Heroic’ rail worker fights for life after 15 minutes of horror
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The attack left nine in life-threatening condition but the police have ruled out any suggestion that it was a terrorist incident
articles.summary: A knifeman onboard the LNER service from Doncaster to King’s Cross wounded nine people over a 15-minute rampage before police arrested a 32-year-old black British national on suspicion of attempted murder. One victim, an LNER staff member who confronted the attacker, remains in life-threatening condition; CCTV confirms his intervention saved lives. The train, driven by Royal Navy veteran Andrew Johnson, made an unscheduled stop at Huntingdon where emergency crews treated the injured. Police have ruled out terrorism, recovered the weapon and sparked debate by disclosing the suspect’s ethnicity under new guidance. Detectives are exploring mental health and any prior warnings.

articles.title: Sole survivor of Air India crash says death of brother ‘took all my happiness’
articles.trailText: Vishwash Kumar Ramesh describes his survival as ‘miracle’ but says his sibling’s death in disaster has left him broken
articles.summary: Briton Vishwash Kumar Ramesh, sole survivor of the June Air India 787-8 crash near Ahmedabad that killed 241 on board and 19 on the ground, describes his survival as a “miracle” overshadowed by the loss of his brother Ajay. Four months later he battles constant flashbacks, sleeping just three to four hours nightly, and remains largely isolated. He credits family and advisers for support but says he’s “broken” and has “lost all my happiness.” A preliminary probe found both fuel switches moved to “cut-off” after takeoff; the reason remains unclear.

articles.title: Ukrainian computer game-style drone attack system goes ‘viral’
articles.trailText: System rewards soldiers who achieve strikes with points that can be used to buy more weapons in an online store
articles.summary: Ukraine’s Army of Drones Bonus System gamifies warfare, rewarding drone crews with points for confirmed kills—18,000 Russian casualties logged in September—redeemable in the Brave1 online arms store offering 100+ drones and autonomous vehicles. Since launching a year ago, participation rose from 95 to 400 units, spawning competitive leaderboards (teams like Achilles, Phoenix) and extensions to artillery, reconnaissance (“Uber targeting”), logistics and AI-assisted drones. Point values were doubled for infantry kills and assign 25 points for shooting enemy drone operators, 120 for capturing POWs. Ukrainian officials say the system yields real-time data on battlefield effectiveness but NATO experts warn that heavy drone reliance faces growing Russian defenses. Russia may mimic the model.

articles.title: South Korea’s tattooists win legal recognition but their fight isn’t over
articles.trailText: After 33 years underground, tattoo artists celebrate a landmark law as prosecutions continue
articles.summary: Kim Do-yoon (Doy) remains under prosecution for tattooing a celebrity despite South Korea’s new Tattooist Act, passed in late 2025 to lift a 33-year medical monopoly on ink. The law, effective October 2027, introduces national licensing with exams, training and liability insurance—doctors keep exclusive removal rights and must consent for minors��while non-medical tattooing stays illegal until then. Younger Koreans have embraced “K-tattoos” fine-line, color techniques, fueling an estimated 16m clients. Underground artists, backed by the Tattoo Union, welcome recognition but face uncertainty and no amnesty for past convictions.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Trump ‘not really’ considering supplying Tomahawks
articles.trailText: Turkish refineries cut back on Russian oil in response to sanctions; Ukrainian special forces join defence of embattled Pokrovsk. What we know on day 1,349
articles.summary: Donald Trump said he’s not really considering supplying Ukraine with Tomahawk cruise missiles despite Pentagon stockpile readiness, though he could reverse course. Ukraine continues long-range strikes via drones and missiles, recently hitting Russia’s Tuapse oil port. Turkey’s STAR and Tupras refineries are cutting back Russian crude—shifting 77,000-129,000 bpd to non-Russian grades ahead of EU sanctions. In Donetsk’s embattled Pokrovsk, Ukrainian special forces, bolstered by Germany’s Patriot air defences, push back a major Russian assault. Russian strikes killed six civilians, including two children, and cut power across eastern Donetsk and Zaporizhzhia regions.

articles.title: Louvre jewel heist by petty criminals, not organised professionals, says Paris prosecutor
articles.trailText: Laure Beccuau said ‘upper echelons of organised crime’ unlikely to be involved as one perpetrator remains at large
articles.summary: Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau says the €88m Louvre daylight heist was executed by petty amateurs, not organised crime. A local couple from Seine-Saint-Denis (a 37-year-old man, 38-year-old woman with children) and two other men have been charged after thieves parked a stolen truck, used a furniture lift to smash into a first-floor room, and fled on scooters with Napoleonic gems—including an emerald/diamond necklace of Napoleon I and a diadem of Empress Eugénie. Dropped crown and DNA-marked tools suggest amateur errors. One suspect remains at large; jewels still unrecovered amid a black-market probe.

articles.title: Five German climbers die in Italian Alps after being swept away by avalanche
articles.trailText: Bodies of missing man and 17-year-old daughter who had fallen 200 metres found on Sunday morning in South Tyrol
articles.summary: Five German climbers, including a 17-year-old girl, died after an avalanche struck Cima Vertana (3,500 m) in South Tyrol near the Swiss border. Three independent parties were climbing Saturday afternoon when a snow torrent buried three alpinists (two men and one woman), whose bodies were recovered the same day. Two teammates escaped and were hospitalized for shock. A father and his daughter fell some 200 m and were missing overnight; their bodies were located Sunday after searches with helicopters, drones and thermal imaging. Rescuers noted low avalanche forecasts but suggested sudden wind or summit snowdrifts may have triggered the slide. The victims were mere hundreds of metres from the summit when the incident occurred.

articles.title: More pets being abandoned in England as food and vet bills soar, say charities
articles.trailText: Firefighters report rise in rescue callouts as RSPCA says some who got pets during Covid have ‘realised it costs a lot more money than they want it to’
articles.summary: Firefighter callouts for animal rescues in England up 27% in five years, domestic rescues up 38%, driven by surging food and vet costs—vet fees 50% higher than 2020, dog food price climb from 60p to ��1.03. RSPCA saw record 22,503 abandonment reports. London accounted for over a third of 3,462 rescues to June 2025 (costs from £261k to £686k) and Essex saw an 84% rise. Charities warn the pandemic pet boom left owners unprepared; CMA probes vet sector consolidation after finding 16.6% higher fees at large groups. Younger owners and falling neutering rates fuel unwanted litters, Cats Protection says.

articles.title: Israel threatens to step up attacks against Hezbollah in Lebanon
articles.trailText: Israel’s defence minister accuses Beirut of delaying efforts to disarm militant group a day after deadly Israeli airstrike
articles.summary: After an Israeli airstrike in Kfar Reman killed four Radwan Force members, Defence Minister Israel Katz warned he would intensify operations against Hezbollah in southern Lebanon, accusing Beirut and President Aoun of stalling on US-brokered ceasefire terms requiring Hezbollah’s disarmament. Despite Lebanon’s army seizing arms caches—reportedly exhausting explosives—and Hezbollah’s public compliance in the south, the Iran-backed group remains armed and politically entrenched. Katz vowed “maximum enforcement” to protect northern Israel. This follows ground raids prompting Aoun to order troop confrontations with Israeli incursions amid diplomatic pressure from the US and Saudi Arabia.

articles.title: Ukraine deploys special forces to Pokrovsk in effort to hold key city
articles.trailText: Escalating battle for city comes as overnight Russian drone and missile strikes kill six people, including two children
articles.summary: Kyiv has dispatched special operations units to reinforce Pokrovsk, the ‘gateway to Donetsk,’ as Russia presses a multi-thousand-strong assault. At least 200 Russian troops have breached its southern defenses amid pincer movements, though Ukraine’s commander-in-chief, Oleksandr Syrskyi, insists the city isn’t encircled and a counter-offensive is underway. Overnight Russian drone and missile strikes killed six civilians, including two boys, and cut power to tens of thousands. Moscow claims it wiped out a Ukrainian special forces team, which Kyiv denies. In parallel, Ukraine struck Russia’s Tuapse oil terminal, while Russia launched a record 270 missiles in October, crippling energy infrastructure across Donetsk and Zaporizhzhia.

articles.title: The grim task of recovering thousands of bodies from the rubble of Gaza
articles.trailText: Relatives and experts tell of the human and societal need to find and identify the dead, while images and data shed light on the scale of the job
articles.summary: In Gaza, amid fragile ceasefire talks, Palestinians face one of modern warfare’s most gruelling recovery efforts: sifting through 61m tonnes of rubble—20× the debris of all conflicts since 2008—to find at least 10,000 (possibly 14,000) bodies. Civil defence teams, using shovels and bare hands, await Israeli approval for excavators. Since 16 days of truce, 472 bodies recovered and 195 returned by Israel. Families queue daily for news. Hospitals lack DNA kits, hampering identification. Experts warn nine months needed with heavy machinery. Hazardous ordnance and damaged roads impede efforts, prolonging grief and health risks.

articles.title: ‘You can do hard things!’ The young cycling enthusiasts reclaiming the streets of Johannesburg
articles.trailText: Bike culture, once seen as an elite hobby or a last resort for the poor, is flourishing in the post-apartheid City of Gold
articles.summary: Karabo Mashele, 32, founded Girls on Bikes after learning to cycle at 29, leading fortnightly 10km rides for 20–25 black South African women across Johannesburg’s suburbs to challenge apartheid-era transport divides. With only 1.5% of commuters cycling, her group reclaims streets, making a political statement about colour and mobility. Simultaneously in Soweto, Percy Zimuto’s Sentech Croozers crew (ages 12–20) pioneered 'Stance culture,' welding extra-long lowrider bikes for spinning tricks. Sponsored by brands like Red Bull, they blend art, sport and community, riding from FNB Stadium to Sandton and reshaping urban inclusion.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukraine says its troops still holding out in embattled Pokrovsk
articles.trailText: Ukraine military says it has improved positions in several districts, while Moscow says its troops are enclosing in on Ukrainian forces.
articles.summary: Ukraine’s top commander Oleksandr Syrskyi said Ukrainian forces continue to hold the eastern city of Pokrovsk despite Moscow’s alleged pincer, improving positions in key districts as Kyiv boosts its 7th Rapid Response Corps amid a “difficult and dynamic” battle. Russia claims it shot down a Ukrainian helicopter, killing all 11 troops onboard and thwarted special forces reinforcements. October saw a 46% spike in Russian missile strikes on Ukraine’s energy grid. Additional shelling killed at least two in Dnipropetrovsk and a Ukrainian drone set fire to a tanker at Russia’s Tuapse oil terminal.

articles.title: Man killed in South Yorkshire helicopter crash named as Peter Smith
articles.trailText: Seventy-year-old, who died in incident near Bentley, said by family to be ‘a beloved husband, father and grandfather’
articles.summary: South Yorkshire Police named the 70-year-old man killed in a Doncaster helicopter crash as Peter Smith. His family described him as a passionate aviator, devoted husband, father and grandfather who loved crafts with grandchildren, time with his son and dining outings with his wife. Three others aboard—a 41-year-old pilot, a 58-year-old woman and a 10-year-old boy—sustained minor injuries. The AAIB and police have launched a joint probe after flight-path analysis showed the craft abruptly stopped near Bentley. Kuki Helicopters and Smith’s family are cooperating and urge privacy and no speculation.

articles.title: Chelsea defender Wesley Fofana gets driving ban for speeding on hard shoulder
articles.trailText: Footballer pleads guilty to one count of driving dangerously after his offence was caught on camera
articles.summary: Chelsea defender Wesley Fofana, 24, pleaded guilty at North East Surrey magistrates court to dangerous driving after dashcam footage showed him speeding his Lamborghini Urus on the A3 Esher bypass hard shoulder on April 20. Judge Julie Cooper imposed an 18-month community order with 300 hours’ service, an 18-month driving ban and £199 costs. This offence predates eight May convictions for speeding in his Rolls-Royce, Audi and Lamborghini, resulting in a two-year ban, £5,328 in fines and 38 penalty points. Fofana apologised for the 15-20 second reckless manoeuvre; any breach of his ban risks imprisonment and could end his career.

articles.title: How al-Qaida-linked jihadist group JNIM is bringing Mali to its knees
articles.trailText: Political instability and fuel shortages caused by rebel group is driving Mali to brink of becoming Islamist republic
articles.summary: Al-Qaida-linked JNIM has blocked fuel routes from Ivory Coast, Mauritania and Senegal, triggering severe shortages in Bamako, where queueing, blackouts and business closures have stalled daily life. The group’s expanding offensive, including attacks on army convoys and imposition of dress codes and summary sharia courts, risks pushing Mali into an Islamist republic. US, Australian, German and Italian advisories urge citizens to evacuate amid fears of a third coup by year-end. Isolated junta, tied to Wagner and pro-junta militias, struggles under sanctions and an ECOWAS break. Analysts warn of domino instability across the Sahel. JNIM eyes Benin and Nigeria expansions.

articles.title: Huge crowds gather on first anniversary of Serbian train station disaster
articles.trailText: Student-led movement continues to demand political change as embattled president issues rare apology
articles.summary: Tens of thousands rallied in Novi Sad on the first anniversary of the lethal 2024 railway station canopy collapse that killed 16. The student-led movement, Serbia’s largest youth uprising since Milošević, began by demanding a transparent probe but swiftly broadened into protests against corruption, nepotism and for early elections. Marchers traversed 340 km from Novi Pazar over 16 days; residents greeted them with flags and whistles. Their pressure forced ex-PM Vučević’s January resignation and elicited a rare apology from President Vučić. Serbia, now in EU accession talks, observed a national day of mourning as investigations and anti-corruption inquiries continue.

articles.title: US public health officials vigilant as newer mpox variant detected
articles.trailText: Risk to general public is low but cases in California suggest virus is spreading undetected in some communities
articles.summary: US health authorities warn that clade Ib, a newer mpox variant first detected mid-2023 in DRC, is spreading undetected in US and Europe. In October, California reported three hospitalized cases (two in LA, one in Long Beach) with no travel or known links, marking first community transmission. WHO data show over 44,000 mpox cases in 2025, surpassing 2024 totals. Low detection (<3%) and vaccine-attenuated mild illness hamper surveillance, prompting calls for proactive testing and wastewater monitoring. Risk to the public remains low, but gay, bisexual and MSM, transgender and nonbinary individuals—especially with multiple partners or attending sex venues—face higher risk. CDC staffing cuts complicate response, boosting reliance on community-based outreach and vaccination.

articles.title: ‘You’re either poor or rich’: the Argentinians struggling under Milei’s chainsaw austerity
articles.trailText: Despite falling inflation, a majority are failing to make ends meet as wages and purchasing power have nosedived
articles.summary: Amid a decisive midterm win backed by fears of losing a $40 bn US bailout, President Javier Milei’s deep “chainsaw” austerity—massive spending cuts, wage and pension freezes, 55 % peso devaluation and a $20 bn IMF loan—has tamed inflation from 211 % to 32 % but gutted real incomes, drove poverty above 50 % (now 31.6 %), erased the middle class and eliminated some 200 000 formal jobs. Delivery riders like Francisco Jiménez face rent crises, shop owners like Nicolás Pedrosa diversify to survive, informality climbs to 43.2 % and sectors from textiles to wine reel under a stark rich-poor divide.

articles.title: ‘I try to make them feel as ignorant as possible’: German museum’s ‘grumpy guide’ is surprise hit
articles.trailText: Performance artist’s aggressive art historian shouts at visitors and insults curators – and his tours are sold out
articles.summary: Performance artist Carl Brandi’s alter ego Joseph Langelinck spearheads the Kunstpalast Düsseldorf’s twice-monthly “Grumpy Guide” tour: a 70-minute, €7 walk in which he berates visitors for their “inferred ignorance,” shouts at phone-checking patrons and lampoons curators for mixing “Aldi to Rubens” exhibits. Launched in May and sold out through next year, it riffs on rude-waiter restaurants and high-brow provocateurs like Peter Handke, subverting museum etiquette and flipping the power imbalance between institution and audience. Visitors emerge amused, chastened and debating niche curation—though few plan an immediate return.

articles.title: ‘We don’t feel safe’: after week of bombings, people in Gaza are losing faith in ceasefire
articles.trailText: After initial enthusiasm, people fear ceasefire does not mean end to war but just less frequent, more unpredictable violence
articles.summary: After a three-week ceasefire that began 10 October, Gazans’ hopes have been shattered by renewed Israeli bombardments: in 24 hours this week, 115 civilians were killed and 352 injured, including Ameen al-Zein, who was killed minutes after urging his return from exile. Strikes followed Hamas’s return of a hostage’s remains and militant attacks, breaking the fragile truce. Healthcare workers, like nurse Hussain Abu Munir, risk daily passing Netzarim checkpoint, while teacher Ikram Nasser sees children’s fleeting return to tents-as-classrooms undone. Random violence and over 1,722 medical staff killed fuel growing distrust that the ceasefire will hold.

articles.title: Spain expresses regret over ‘injustice’ suffered by Mexico’s Indigenous people during conquest
articles.trailText: Acknowledgment shows shift in tone after six years of diplomatic spats over colonial-era abuses
articles.summary: Spain’s foreign minister, José Manuel Albares, has for the first time publicly expressed regret for the ‘pain and injustice’ inflicted on Mexico’s Indigenous peoples during the 1519–21 conquest, marking a shift after six years of diplomatic tensions following Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s 2019 letter to King Felipe VI and Pope Francis demanding apologies for colonial-era massacres and oppression. Spain had initially rejected judging 16th-century acts by contemporary standards. Speaking at a Madrid exhibition on Indigenous Mexican women, Albares acknowledged shared history’s “shadows.” Mexico’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, welcomed the admission as “a first step,” saying “apologies ennoble governments and peoples.”

articles.title: Trump’s military pressure on Maduro evokes Latin America’s coup-ridden past
articles.trailText: US forces and CIA actions target Venezuela’s leader, recalling coups and assassinations across the region
articles.summary: Under Trump, the US has deployed its largest naval force in Latin America since the 1962 missile crisis—aircraft carrier, destroyers, bombers—and authorized the CIA to target Nicolás Maduro, branding him a narcoterrorist. Washington doubled its bounty to $50m dead-or-alive and pre-positioned strikes on Venezuelan military sites. Analysts warn parallels to CIA-backed coups in Chile (1973), Guatemala (1954) and assassination plots against Trujillo, Arbenz and Castro. US plans hinge on fomenting a military coup even as experts doubt an internal uprising, warning any snatch would likely prove fatal for Maduro.

articles.title: Thousands join protests in Rio favela after deadliest ever police raid
articles.trailText: Demonstrators demand inquiry after operation on Tuesday in which at least 121 people were killed
articles.summary: After a police assault killed 121 people, including four officers, in Rio’s Complexo da Penha and Alemão favelas, thousands rallied demanding an independent inquiry, removal of governor Cláudio Castro, and an end to militarized security policies turning the neighborhoods into “war zones.” Activists and Amnesty International decried a “massacre” targeting poor Black communities, while authorities defended the raid as a blow to the Red Command drug faction. Critics warn that such operations fuel violence rather than curb it; many rightwing politicians praised the crackdown as effective law-and-order.

articles.title: UN expert urged to investigate Lebanon over alleged torture of Egyptian-Turkish poet
articles.trailText: Abdulrahman al-Qaradawi has been imprisoned in the UAE for almost a year for criticising Emirati, Egyptian and Saudi governments
articles.summary: Legal team for Egyptian-Turkish poet Abdulrahman al-Qaradawi has urged the UN special rapporteur on torture to probe Lebanon’s role in his arrest and transfer to the UAE, where he’s been held over 10 months in solitary confinement without charge or legal counsel. Arrested in December 2024 after a Syria trip and extradited under UAE’s request via the Arab Interior Ministers Council, the dissident faces alleged “fake news” charges after criticizing Emirati, Egyptian and Saudi regimes online. Rights groups warn his conditions violate human rights and set a chilling precedent for regional free speech.

articles.title: Tanzania’s Hassan declared landslide winner in election that triggered violent protests
articles.trailText: The result hands Hassan, who took power in 2021, a five-year term following opposition repression
articles.summary: Tanzania’s President Samia Suluhu Hassan secured a controversial landslide with over 97% of votes, extending CCM’s decades-long rule for another five years after excluding her two main opponents—Chadema’s Tundu Lissu and ACT-Wazalendo’s Luhaga Mpina—from the ballot. The election was preceded by a pattern of enforced disappearances, arbitrary arrests and extrajudicial killings, documented by Amnesty International and a UN panel citing 200+ disappearances since 2019. Protests on voting day saw demonstrators tear down banners and set fire to buildings, met with teargas and gunfire; the UN confirmed at least 10 deaths while opposition claims run into the hundreds. The government dismisses these figures as exaggerated.

articles.title: Xi Jinping’s moment and whirlwind diplomatic tours: key takeaways from the Apec summit in South Korea
articles.trailText: With Trump electing to fly back to Washington on the eve of the main summit, what did Apec’s remaining leaders achieve in his absence?
articles.summary: In Gyeongju, Trump’s early departure left Xi Jinping to assert leadership at APEC, positioning himself as a free-trade champion in contrast to US protectionism. The summit yielded only a vague, non-committal declaration on resilient, inclusive trade, underscoring deep rifts within the 21-member forum. Canada and China seized a diplomatic breakthrough as PM Mark Carney and Xi agreed on a “turning point” in bilateral ties despite US tariffs. Japan’s newly appointed PM Sanae Takaichi navigated her first multilateral stage deftly, securing “future-oriented” cooperation with South Korea and balancing ties with Washington and Beijing. The summit highlighted APEC’s struggle to uphold its founding multilateral ethos in a fractured geopolitical climate.

articles.title: A Sudanese massacre foretold: the grim familiarity of the RSF’s rampage through El Fasher
articles.trailText: Atrocities unfolding in El Fasher since it fell to paramilitary forces follow a bleak pattern seen in Rwanda, Liberia and Sudan itself, including lack of international action
articles.summary: After RSF captured El Fasher on 26 October, fighters executed hundreds of civilians—including patients and staff at two hospitals—targeting primarily non-Arab Masalit, extorting fleeing residents and filming killings as psychological warfare. Since an 18-month siege, estimates of deaths run into the thousands amid a communications blackout. The rampage mirrors RSF-led massacres at Geneina (2023) and Zamzam IDP camp (1,500 killed in 72 hours), echoing historic genocide in Darfur, Rwanda and Liberia. Despite UN warnings and a stalled Quad truce roadmap, international inaction persists; experts urge sanctions on UAE, Saudi Arabia and Egypt over arms support to RSF.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian attacks on substations are ‘nuclear terrorism’, says Ukraine
articles.trailText: Ukrainian foreign ministry says deliberate strikes on civilian energy facilities violate international law as fears of a winter crisis grow. What we know on day 1,347
articles.summary: Ukraine’s foreign ministry condemned Russian strikes on power substations feeding its nuclear plants as "nuclear terrorism" and violations of humanitarian law, echoing IAEA reports of damage to lines at South Ukraine and Khmelnitskyi plants and reduced output at Rivne. With UN warnings of looming winter hardship, G7 energy ministers denounced Moscow’s assaults on gas networks and pledged Ukraine support. Kyiv deployed special forces to defend Pokrovsk amid a Russian advance. Meanwhile Russia reported downing dozens of Ukrainian drones, and Berlin and other European airports briefly closed after unidentified drone sightings blamed on Moscow.

articles.title: ‘How do you rebuild all this?’ Black River residents assess damage after Hurricane Melissa
articles.trailText: People of Jamaican coastal town described as storm’s ground zero are traumatised and desperate for help
articles.summary: In Black River, Jamaica��ground zero for Category 5 Hurricane Melissa—nearly every building lost its roof amid flooding, landslides and silt-choked roads. Residents face a humanitarian crisis: 19 Jamaicans dead, 462,000 without power, communications down. Families shelter in bus stops and scavenge debris. Locals and tourists report unprecedented winds, damaged boats and hotels, and urgent calls for zinc, cement and food aid. Military convoys deliver supplies while officials warn that stronger, wetter storms driven by climate change will make rebuilding costly and protracted.

articles.title: Stop calling Georgia ‘the former Soviet republic’ | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Paul Heineman compares the use of this ‘quaint terminology’ to describing Britain as ‘the former Roman province’
articles.summary: Letter writer Paul Heineman of Maryland criticises the Guardian’s habit of calling Georgia a “former Soviet republic,” arguing that this outdated label undermines its full sovereignty and plays into Russian narratives. He points out that Russia currently occupies about 20% of internationally recognised Georgian territory and urges the paper to acknowledge Georgia as an independent nation—else, by the same logic, one might call Britain a “former Roman province.”

articles.title: Sudan’s RSF accused of ‘PR stunt’ after arresting fighters behind civilian killings
articles.trailText: Reports of indiscriminate violence and ethnic targeting in El Fasher have led to growing global outrage
articles.summary: After global outrage over the massacre in El Fasher, Sudan’s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces announced the arrest of commander Abu Lulu, featured in videos executing civilians. Human rights groups and activists branded the move a PR stunt meant to deflect blame from RSF leaders like Mohamed “Hemedti” Dagalo; social media users countered with the hashtag ‘You are all Abu Lulu.’ Open-source investigators placed Hemedti’s deputy on site. UN and aid agencies report hundreds killed, systematic rape and looting, 60,000+ displaced, with MSF treating malnourished children at Tawila camp. Activists warn RSF self-investigations are a farce.

articles.title: Liberal-progressive party D66 wins election, Dutch media report
articles.trailText: Party will take lead in first round of talks to form coalition government after securing most votes
articles.summary: Liberal-progressive D66, led by 38-year-old Rob Jetten, won the most votes in the Oct. 30 election, securing an expected 27 seats and positioning Jetten as the Netherlands’ youngest prime minister candidate. Geert Wilders’ PVV stalled, while far-right support fragmented across smaller parties, leaving public trust in politics at just 4%. By convention D66 will lead coalition talks in a divided parliament. Jetten urged all mainstream parties to unite on housing, migration, climate and economic reforms, but forming a majority faces challenges given the VVD’s refusal to govern with left-leaning partners.

articles.title: About 700 killed in Tanzania election protests, opposition says
articles.trailText: Demonstrators took to streets after president’s main challengers were excluded from ballot
articles.summary: Chadema says about 700 protesters have been killed since Wednesday’s polls—around 350 in Dar es Salaam, 200+ in Mwanza and others nationwide—after key presidential challengers were barred, sparking mass demonstrations. Security forces imposed a night curfew, used live ammunition and teargas, and cut internet access countrywide. UN OHCHR and Amnesty International have raised alarm over disproportionate force and civilian deaths. Opposition demands an end to police brutality, a transitional government and free elections; the government has yet to comment.

articles.title: Six arrested after €12m armed raid on gold refining lab in France
articles.trailText: Robbery in Lyon left five employees slightly injured after explosion in latest high-profile incident to hit country
articles.summary: Six suspected career criminals were arrested after a daylight raid on Lyon’s Laboratoires Pourquery, where they used explosives and military-grade weapons to blow out windows and escape with an estimated €12 million in precious metals. Five of the 28 staff were slightly injured. Police seized assault rifles, handguns and explosives in Vénissieux, and also arrested a female accomplice. It was the second attack on the lab this year. The heist follows a string of brazen precious metals and jewellery robberies across France, including the Louvre crown jewels (€88 m) and Paris’s Natural History Museum.

articles.title: Gaza risks sliding into deadly limbo of ‘no war, no peace’, top Qatari diplomat warns
articles.trailText: Majed al-Ansari calls for international force to be set up urgently to pave way for Israeli withdrawal
articles.summary: Majed al-Ansari, Qatar’s foreign ministry spokesperson, warns Gaza could slide into a deadly limbo of “no war, no peace” unless an international security force and new administration are deployed swiftly to facilitate full Israeli withdrawal. He urges UN-backed deployment to uphold the ceasefire’s 20-point plan, though its mandate and membership remain undefined. After airstrikes killed over 100 Palestinians, Qatar and regional allies seek a UN Security Council resolution to stabilise Gaza, oversee reconstruction and demilitarise Hamas, while US engagement remains vital.

articles.title: Sudan’s brutal civil war – what has happened in El Fasher?
articles.trailText: Paramilitary Rapid Support Forces captured the city from the army after an 18-month siege – but who are they and what do they want?
articles.summary: After an 18-month siege, Sudan’s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces seized El Fasher, Darfur’s last army-held city, raising partition fears. Witnesses, geolocated footage and Yale satellite analysis document RSF’s door-to-door ethnic cleansing of Fur, Zaghawa and Berti—summary executions, forced displacement, ransom kidnappings. Formed from the Janjaweed in 2013, the RSF has waged civil war with Khartoum’s army since April 2023, accused of genocide and mass rape. Global actors convened in London amid UAE arms-smuggling allegations linked to Sudan’s gold and Yemen deployments.

articles.title: Era of free trade and investment is over, Canada’s PM tells Apec summit
articles.trailText: Mark Carney warns Asia-Pacific leaders global economy undergoing profound change, as China’s president mounts defence of free trade
articles.summary: At the Apec summit in Gyeongju, PM Mark Carney declared that the postwar era of rules-based free trade and investment is over, urging Canada to diversify by doubling exports beyond the US within a decade. He welcomed closer ties and an invitation from Xi Jinping to build a sustainable, inclusive international system, marking the first Canada-China leader meeting since 2017.
