Carney signaled resuming US negotiations only when Washington is ready, following a Sino-US tariff truce. Meanwhile Xi defended open trade amid rising protectionism as Apec discussions focused on supply chains and US-India defense cooperation.

articles.title: UN leaders condemn ‘horrifying’ mass killings in Sudan
articles.trailText: Emergency security council session criticises killings of civilians in El Fasher and external supply of arms to RSF
articles.summary: UN diplomats condemned mass, ethnically targeted killings by Sudan's Rapid Support Forces in El Fasher at an emergency Security Council session, citing credible reports of summary executions during house-to-house searches, up to 500 killed at a Saudi maternity hospital and widespread displacement. Assistant Sec-Gen Martha Pobee warned communications cut and external arms flows fueling atrocities. UK and US officials called for arms-sale bans on the UAE, while NGOs and lawmakers urged recognising a responsibility to protect, imposing targeted sanctions, enforcing a humanitarian truce, and classifying the attacks as potential genocide to trigger broader UN action.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: British ex-soldier arrested in Kyiv and accused of spying for Russia
articles.trailText: Prosecutors allege man was conducting training for Ukraine’s army when he was recruited by the FSB, Moscow’s spy bureau. What we know on day 1,346
articles.summary: A British ex-army instructor in Kyiv has been arrested on charges of spying for Russia: prosecutors say he trained Ukraine’s forces, passed training centre coordinates and adviser locations, and received explosives instructions, a handgun and ammo for $6,000; he faces up to 12 years in prison. Meanwhile, Russia’s overnight strikes injured 11 in Sumy, Ukrainian drones hit an Oryol plant limiting heat and water, and Kyiv confirmed Russia used 9M729 cruise missiles 23 times since August. A new investigation reveals Russian commanders execute or abandon soldiers who refuse orders. A massive drone-missile barrage on Ukraine’s energy grid killed 7 and forced nationwide power cuts; Zelensky says air defences downed most attackers.

articles.title: Sudan’s latest massacre has been exposed from satellite images – how much longer can the world look away?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: From the skies above El Fasher, analysts are uncovering evidence of mass killings – with questions raised about UAE involvement
articles.summary: After RSF forces seized the strategic Zamzam camp and El Fasher army base, new satellite imagery and open-source analysis reveal evidence of mass killings—over 2,000 unarmed civilians executed and bloodstains visible on the ground. Yale University’s Humanitarian Research Lab documents clusters consistent with bodies and door-to-door clearance operations targeting Fur, Zaghawa and Berti communities. Journalists geolocate videos that identify RSF commanders and document atrocities. Analysts also use imagery to track military buildups and warn of impending attacks. Meanwhile, UN experts suspect UAE arms smuggling to the RSF amid Sudan’s worst humanitarian crisis, yet global response remains muted.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa death toll nears 50 as Jamaica relief efforts intensify and storm heads north
articles.trailText: Haiti death toll reaches 30, and 19 in Jamaica, as Bermuda weathers tropical storm conditions on Thursday night
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa’s Caribbean rampage has killed 49 people: 30 in Haiti (20 missing, 20 injured) and 19 in Jamaica, where roads are being cleared, towns remain flooded, power and networks are down in the southwest, and the main airport has reopened for aid. Bermuda faced tropical-storm conditions with 100 mph winds, causeway closures, school and ferry shutdowns. In eastern Cuba 735,000 were evacuated with no casualties so far. The storm, now a 100 mph category 2, is moving northeast at 38 mph, expected to weaken on Friday. UK has chartered repatriation flights.

articles.title: Egypt’s vast $1bn museum to open in Cairo after two-decade build
articles.trailText: Grand Egyptian Museum near Giza pyramids billed as world’s largest archaeological facility for single civilisation
articles.summary: Egypt unveils its $1bn Grand Egyptian Museum after a 20-year build near the Giza pyramids. Spanning 470,000 sq m with 24,000 sq m of galleries, it houses over 50,000 artefacts from prehistoric to Roman eras, including an 83-tonne Ramesses II colossus and Khufu’s 4,500-year-old boat. Featuring mixed-reality exhibits, education and conservation facilities and commercial spaces, it aims to bolster tourism—projecting 15,000–20,000 daily visitors—and inject foreign currency amid infrastructure expansion. Opening, delayed by regional conflicts, also raises security concerns after recent artefact thefts.

articles.title: ‘Seed of hope’: Gaza grandmother is reunited with her Australian family after more than a decade
articles.trailText: A kiss to the forehead marks the culmination of years of work to get Shamikh Badra’s 79-year-old Palestinian mother, Fatma, to Australia
articles.summary: After 11 years apart, 79-year-old Fatma Badra, a Palestinian visa holder and genocide survivor, was reunited with her son Shamikh in Sydney. She lost 10 kg amid Israel’s blockade, endured food and medicine shortages, a gruelling solo evacuation via Karem Abu Salem and the death of her husband. Her brother Ehab’s fate remains unknown. Advocates say 60 Gazans arrived post-ceasefire, but 600–700 valid visa holders remain trapped as the Rafah crossing stays closed.

articles.title: Ex-EPA head urges US to resist Trump attacks on climate action: ‘We won’t become numb’
articles.trailText: Expanded climate action from cities and states could slash planet-heating pollution despite Trump working against it
articles.summary: Former EPA head Gina McCarthy urged US cities and states to press ahead with climate action despite Trump’s legal challenges and clean-energy rollbacks, ahead of COP30 in Brazil. Co-chairing America Is All In, she said over 100 subnational leaders—including governors, mayors and officials—will push for policies that, with federal re-engagement after 2028, could cut US emissions by up to 56% below 2005 levels by 2035. Senator Sheldon Whitehouse urged lawsuits to block federal obstruction, blasted fossil-fuel front groups for spreading doubt, and called UN rules on lobbyist funding “inadequate,” demanding full transparency to expose industry interference.

articles.title: More than half of UK businesses changing DEI approach due to Trump’s criticism
articles.trailText: Leading UK organisations reacting to pushback against diversity initiatives in the US by reviewing or even scrapping policies
articles.summary: Research by law firm Freeths finds 54% of UK businesses (250+ surveyed general counsels) have reviewed or scrapped DEI and sustainability programs in response to Trump’s ‘woke’ backlash. 28% abandoned initiatives entirely, 26% made specific changes, 32% are discussing adjustments. 83% say profit outweighs ethics regularly; 22% report frequent conflicts. Amid US rollback by Amazon, Disney, Meta and UK political pressure from Reform, Blue Labour, and calls to repeal the Equality Act, companies like BT have scaled back DEI incentives. Freeths highlights risk to principle vs practice gap despite looming race/disability pay-gap reporting rules.

articles.title: The Rev Peter Cruchley obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : United Reformed Church minister who served congregations in Cardiff before moving on to the World Council of Churches
articles.summary: United Reformed Church minister Peter Cruchley (died aged 59) served Cardiff congregations for 15 years after his 1992 ordination, earning a PhD from Birmingham. Renowned for flamboyant style and creative outreach—from graffiti-style art to resurrection congas—he joined the Council for World Mission in Singapore, founding the Onesimus Project to address the London Missionary Society’s historic slave-trade ties, then directed world mission and evangelism at the World Council of Churches in Geneva. A published theologian, he married twice—first to Rhiannon Jones (two daughters), then to Lena Borgers—and is survived by his wife, daughters, grandson and two brothers.

articles.title: Geert Wilders faces shutout as centrists hail huge gains in knife-edge Dutch election
articles.trailText: Far right neck and neck with liberal D66 but all major mainstream parties have ruled out working with anti-Islam firebrand
articles.summary: In the Dutch election with 99.7% counted, centrists and liberals led by D66’s Rob Jetten tied far-right PVV on 26 seats, edging ahead by c.15,000 votes in Amsterdam returns. All major parties refuse to partner with Geert Wilders, effectively shutting him out of government. D66 surged from nine to 26 seats; CDA won 18, VVD 22 and GL/PvdA 20. A broad D66-led coalition with CDA, VVD and GL/PvdA is favored, though talks could stretch on for months.

articles.title: Rob Jetten: anti-Wilders, ‘yes we can’ candidate poised to be next Dutch PM
articles.trailText: As liberal-progressive D66 party makes huge gains in election, former junior athlete with ‘positive story’ and ‘vision’ leads race for power
articles.summary: D66 leader Rob Jetten, 38, former junior athlete and ex-ProRail manager, is poised to become the Netherlands’ next prime minister after his liberal-progressive, pro-EU and pro-climate party surged to 26 seats, tying with Geert Wilders’ PVV but securing backing from other mainstream parties. Jetten’s Obama-style “het kan wél” (“yes we can”) campaign combined optimism and pragmatism, appealing to centrists weary of populism. If confirmed, he’d be the first out gay PM, tasked with uniting a divided electorate, tackling the housing crisis and sustaining economic stability through coalition-building.

articles.title: Lebanese president orders army to confront Israeli incursions after deadly raid
articles.trailText: IDF says it was attacking Hezbollah infrastructure when it fired at a ‘suspect’ and the incident is under review
articles.summary: An Israeli army raid on Blida near the Lebanon–Israel border killed Ibrahim Salameh, a municipal worker, after troops said they were striking Hezbollah infrastructure and fired at a “suspect.” Lebanon’s president, Joseph Aoun, condemned the killing, ordered the Lebanese army to confront any future Israeli incursions, and stressed defence of sovereign territory. The incident violates the November 2024 ceasefire, under which Israel remains in five positions in southern Lebanon and conducts near-daily airstrikes. Foreign envoys, including US envoy Morgan Ortagus, press Beirut to bring all arms under state control by year-end.

articles.title: German dentists hold memorial recognising sadistic practices of profession under Nazis
articles.trailText: Recent studies have exposed theft of gold fillings, excruciating extractions, human experiments and forced sterilisations
articles.summary: German dentists’ professional body, the DGZMK, held its first memorial at Berlin’s Humboldt University to acknowledge its members’ systemic involvement in Nazi-era crimes, including sadistic tooth extractions without anesthesia, forced sterilizations, human experiments and the theft of gold fillings from corpses and living victims to fund the war. Research reveals over 60% of dental academics and 55% of practitioners joined the Nazi Party, with hundreds serving in the Waffen-SS and assisting in selections and murder at camps. While 15 were executed postwar, most evaded punishment. The ceremony included apologies, recognition of persecuted Jewish colleagues and the inaugural Hans Türkheim research prize.

articles.title: Russian army chiefs torturing and executing soldiers who refuse to fight in Ukraine, report says
articles.trailText: Investigation lists 101 superiors accused of tactics such as using drones to ‘finish’ off retreating troops and sending soldiers on death missions
articles.summary: Independent outlet Verstka’s investigation names 101 Russian commanders accused of torturing, executing or sending soldiers on suicide missions for refusing orders in Ukraine. Based on soldier testimonies, leaked footage and complaint records, it documents ‘execution shooters,’ drone and grenade strikes on retreating or wounded troops, gladiator-style pit battles, water dousing torture and extortion schemes. Victims include unarmed “beacons” sent ahead of assaults. Despite at least 150 verified deaths and 29,000 complaints lodged by mid-2025, few officers have faced prosecution, highlighting a culture of impunity in the Russian army.

articles.title: Geert Wilders convinced Dutch voters the far right could run the country. What is their verdict now?
articles.trailText: A failed two-year experiment has lessons for the rest of Europe about the appeal – and the limits – of populism • Don’t get This Is Europe delivered to your inbox? Sign up here
articles.summary: After two years in government, Geert Wilders’ PVV-led right-wing coalition failed to address voters’ top concerns—housing shortages, healthcare gaps, and asylum backlogs—and delivered no major reforms beyond briefly raising speed limits. Exit polls show centrist D66 poised for gains, while mainstream parties united to exclude Wilders despite his enduring 'Netherlands is full' rhetoric, now normalized across the political spectrum. Analysts warn the PVV’s collapse eroded trust in institutions, fuelled anti-elite sentiment and offers copycats a warning yet blueprint. Voters’ hunger for stable 'boring' governance may signal Europe’s broader populist verdict.

articles.title: Five new suspects arrested in connection with Louvre robbery
articles.trailText: Public prosecutor says arrests were made in and around Paris but suspects ‘did not help us find the stolen goods’
articles.summary: Five new suspects arrested in Paris and Seine-Saint-Denis in connection to the October 19 Louvre crown-jewel heist that netted €88m in stolen gems remain missing. Public prosecutor Laure Beccuau said one suspect’s DNA was linked to the crime, while four others may shed light on the operation. Two earlier arrestees partially confessed and will face charges of organised theft (15 years) and criminal conspiracy (10 years). The four-man gang used a stolen removal truck with a lift disguised as maintenance workers to break into the Apollo gallery in under seven minutes, escaping on motorcycles with eight royal jewels, including Napoleon I’s emerald necklace and Empress Eugénie’s diadem.

articles.title: Centrist D66 party makes huge gains in Dutch election
articles.trailText: Result opens a path for D66 leader Rob Jetten to form a government as the youngest ever prime minister of the Netherlands
articles.summary: Exit polls with 90% counted show centrist D66 making record gains—almost tripling its seats—to 26, matching Geert Wilders’ PVV, which fell sharply from its 2023 high. With all mainstream parties ruling out PVV, D66 leader Rob Jetten, 38, is set to become the Netherlands’ youngest prime minister and lead coalition talks. The fragmented 150-seat chamber saw 15 of 27 parties win seats; CDA rose to 19 and VVD holds 22 despite a slight loss, while GL/PvdA dropped to 20, prompting Frans Timmermans’s resignation. Coalition options include broad centre alliances or more right-wing pacts with JA21. Housing, migration and healthcare top the agenda.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Israel’s new bombardment breaks an uneasy peace – is this a ceasefire in name only?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: After Israeli airstrikes killed more than 100 Palestinians overnight, the illusion of peace in Gaza lies in ruins. Will the ceasefire hold?
articles.summary: Israeli airstrikes overnight killed at least 104 Palestinians (35 children), including at the Insan cancer camp, shattering a truce agreed three weeks earlier. PM Netanyahu ordered the strikes after clashes that killed one Israeli soldier and followed disputes over Hamas’s handover of hostage remains. US President Trump, who brokered the ceasefire, defended its validity but urged Israel to respond if attacked. Both sides allege violations—Gaza media reports 80 Israeli breaches, while Israel accuses Hamas of staging false recovery footage and attacks. Aid deliveries remain at 750 tonnes daily versus a 2,000-tonne survival minimum, underscoring dire humanitarian needs. With far-right calls for full-scale war and reliance on Trump’s leverage, the ceasefire’s future is uncertain.

articles.title: Wives, mothers, fighters, activists: the millennial women keeping Ukraine going
articles.trailText: Born into an independent Ukraine, the lives of these young women changed for ever when Russia invaded their country, forcing them to shoulder huge burdens of responsibility
articles.summary: Born after independence, Ukraine’s 29–40-year-old women have become fundraisers, fighters, medics, activists and NGO leaders sustaining the home front. Raised amid economic collapse, revolution and full-scale invasion, they run crowdfunding campaigns, arm and train soldiers, champion tech for displaced women and document the war internationally. Unlike men barred from leaving, they juggle service or emigration, grief for fallen peers and agonizing choices over childbearing against a plunging birthrate and demographic crisis. Their purpose-driven resilience masks burnout, stress and family separation.

articles.title: Donald Trump praises ‘great’ Washington meeting with Anthony Albanese as leaders dine at Apec
articles.trailText: US president tells reporters he and Australian PM ‘working on a lot of things together’
articles.summary: At the APEC leaders’ dinner in Gyeongju, PM Anthony Albanese sat beside US President Donald Trump, who lauded their recent Washington meeting and touted collaboration on rare earths and other initiatives. Their bilateral agenda follows a multibillion-dollar minerals-access deal inked last week. Albanese told reporters he hopes for eased US–China trade tensions but reaffirmed Australia’s commitment to free, fair trade, in contrast to Trump’s tariff stance. Trump announced the completion of a South Korea trade agreement, notably dismissing further talks with Canada’s PM amid tariff disputes. Albanese, amid a global tour, will remain home for parliament instead of attending the Cop30 summit, while Australia bids to host Cop2026.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Putin boasts of nuclear-driven torpedo that would swamp cities with radioactive tsunami
articles.trailText: Russian president proclaims test of Poseidon which would launch from submarine and carry nuclear engine and warhead. What we know on day 1,345
articles.summary: Vladimir Putin said Russia successfully tested the Poseidon nuclear-powered torpedo-drone, whose reactor ran underwater and whose warhead could trigger a radioactive tsunami to render coastal cities uninhabitable. Officials call it a new retaliatory weapon that upends nuclear deterrence norms. In Ukraine, Kyiv rejects Russian claims of encirclement in Pokrovsk and Kupiansk despite heavy fighting and ambushes, with President Zelenskiy warning the 1,250 km frontline is under intense pressure. A Russian strike on a children’s hospital wounded nine. In Russia, a Kopeysk factory blast killed 23. Kyiv detained ex-Ukrenergo chief Kudrytsky on embezzlement charges, while anti-war busker Diana Loginova remains jailed.

articles.title: ‘The town is devastated’: the mayor picking up the pieces at Hurricane Melissa’s ��ground zero’
articles.trailText: Richard Solomon, mayor of Black River, describes terror of 16ft storm surges and hours of fierce winds when storm hit, as focus now moves to aid and rescue efforts
articles.summary: Black River mayor Richard Solomon called the St Elizabeth parish town “ground zero” after Hurricane Melissa’s Category 5 storm unleashed 16ft (4.8m) surges and nine hours of savage winds. With five confirmed dead and unverified reports of more, the town is without power, water or roofs on most buildings. Landslides and flooding have blocked roads, crippling search, rescue and relief. Solomon, whose own home and vehicle were submerged, is prioritizing aid to the vulnerable and clearing routes for supplies. PM Holness, after surveying 80–90% roof loss, pledged billions for reconstruction.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa hits Cuba after turning Jamaica into ‘disaster area’
articles.trailText: Most intense tropical cyclone to hit Jamaica in nearly two centuries leaves trail of devastation in its wake
articles.summary: Category 5 Hurricane Melissa, with 185 mph winds at landfall, battered Jamaica on Oct 29, marking the strongest cyclone in almost 200 years. PM Andrew Holness declared a disaster area as 530,000 lost power, 15,000 sheltered, roofs torn off across St Elizabeth, Clarendon and Manchester parishes. At least four died on the island; 25 perished in Haitian floods and one in the Dominican Republic. After weakening to category 3, Melissa made Cuban landfall with 100 mph gusts, displacing over 735,000 residents. Scientists warn rapid intensification stems from human-driven ocean warming.

articles.title: What is Apec - explained in 30 seconds
articles.trailText: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation club has 21 members that represent more than 50% of global GDP and are home to about 2.7 billion people
articles.summary: Established in 1989 after Australian PM Bob Hawke’s Seoul proposal, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum launched with 12 members and now comprises 21 economies—including China, the US, Russia, Japan, Australia, Canada and ASEAN nations—accounting for over 50% of global GDP and 40% of the world’s population. APEC promotes free trade, reduced investment barriers and annual leader summits, but its nonbinding decisions and rising nationalism hinder consensus. Recent agendas address digital transformation, AI, sustainable energy, food security, demographic shifts and gender and disability inclusivity.

articles.title: Tributes paid after death of Mary McGee, who helped end Ireland’s ban on contraception
articles.trailText: Mother-of-four brought legal case against government after customs seized her contraceptives package from UK
articles.summary: Mary “May” McGee, mother of four whose 1972 challenge with husband Seamus “Shay” McGee against Ireland’s 1935 ban on contraception—sparked by health advice after complicated pregnancies and the seizure of their UK-ordered diaphragm—led the Supreme Court to rule 4-1 that contraceptive use by married couples was a private matter, effectively ending the ban and igniting a social revolution. She died peacefully in a Dublin hospital on 29 October 2025. Tributes from writers Paul Duane and Fintan O’Toole and historian Laura Kelly praised her courage and legacy. Shay McGee predeceased her in January 2024.

articles.title: French parliament votes to add consent to rape law after Gisèle Pelicot case
articles.trailText: A historic move to change French criminal law would bring its legislation in line with many other European countries
articles.summary: Spurred by Gisèle Pelicot’s trial—in which her husband and 50 men were convicted of drugging and raping her—French MPs and senators have voted to redefine rape and sexual assault as “any non-consensual act” requiring “informed, specific, prior and revocable” consent. The revision, pending President Macron’s signature, retains existing violence-based clauses, explicitly covers oral and anal penetration, bars inferring consent from silence, passed 327–0 in the Senate, and aligns France with European consent-first standards.

articles.title: ‘This was a slaughter, not an operation’: the favela reeling from Rio’s deadliest police raid
articles.trailText: Residents of Vila Cruzeiro gather bodies after more than 130 were killed in pre-dawn assault
articles.summary: In a pre-dawn operation on Oct. 29, Rio de Janeiro police sent 2,500 officers to raid Vila Cruzeiro, killing at least 132 people—four of them police officers and most tied to the Red Command—in the deadliest action in city history. Mutilated and blood-smeared bodies were recovered from forested hills and displayed on tarpaulins along the favela’s main street. Residents, activists and clergy denounce mass executions as “genocide” and demand the removal of governor Cláudio Castro, while the UN human rights office expresses horror. Castro defends the assault as a necessary blow against “narco-terrorists” ahead of the COP summit.

articles.title: Hundreds reportedly killed at Sudanese hospital as evidence of RSF atrocities mounts
articles.trailText: Rapid Support Forces, which claimed control of El Fasher on Sunday, reportedly killed at least 460 people ‘in cold blood’
articles.summary: After capturing El Fasher in Darfur, RSF fighters reportedly executed at least 460 patients and staff inside the Saudi maternity hospital, according to WHO and the Sudan Doctors Network. Yale Humanitarian Research Lab satellite analysis shows mass graves and “reddish discoloration” consistent with mass killings at hospital and detention sites. RSF now controls all regional capitals in Darfur amid allegations of genocide and systematic atrocities—house-to-house shootings, sexual assaults, extortion and mass executions—while thousands more civilians remain missing or displaced.

articles.title: Louvre suspects ‘partially admit’ their role in jewel heist
articles.trailText: Police are no closer to recovering gems valued at £76m, despite the arrest of two men last week
articles.summary: Two men arrested on suspicion of stealing €88m (£76m) in crown jewels from the Louvre have “partially admitted” involvement, but the gems remain unrecovered, prosecutor Laure Beccuau said. The suspects face organised theft and criminal conspiracy charges carrying up to 15 years in prison. Investigators say the four-man gang used a stolen furniture truck with a lift to smash into the Apollo gallery, fleeing on motorbikes with eight Napoleon-era pieces, including a diamond-studded crown and emerald necklace. DNA links them to a display case and scooter. A 100-strong unit is probing accomplices amid criticism of the museum’s outdated security.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa: a visual guide to the storm devastating Jamaica and Cuba
articles.trailText: Melissa slams into Cuba while lingering over Jamaica as the Bahamas braces to be next
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, a catastrophic Category 5, struck Jamaica with 180 mph winds—the strongest since records began in 1851—after intensifying from 70 to 140 mph in 24 hours. The slow-moving storm caused severe flooding, widespread power outages affecting over 500,000 residents, and structural damage including a hospital roof loss. Downgraded to Category 3, it lingers over Cuba with 735,000 evacuated and is forecast to hit the Bahamas. Rapid intensification over 1.4 °C-warmed seas underscores the climate-change link, posing a major recovery challenge to Jamaica’s tourism-dependent economy.

articles.title: Israel strikes Gaza again after overnight bombardment that killed at least 104
articles.trailText: Attacks shatter Palestinians’ short-lived relief since start of ceasefire that now looks increasingly fragile
articles.summary: Israel’s strikes in northern Gaza on Oct 29 killed at least 104 Palestinians—including 46 children and 20 women—and wounded 200, marking the gravest breach of the US-brokered ceasefire. The IDF said it targeted weapons caches in Beit Lahia, while Gaza’s civil defense reported hits on displacement camps and a cancer patient camp. Hamas condemned the attacks as attempts to undermine the truce, vowed to uphold it, and delayed a hostage-remains handover. US officials insisted the ceasefire still holds despite “skirmishes.” Qatar is intensifying diplomacy to preserve the agreement. Domestically, far-right Israeli ministers demand renewed war even as Netanyahu reaffirms measured compliance.

articles.title: Greek police increase security after protests against Israeli cruise ship
articles.trailText: Measures are being taken at the harbours of Patras and Katakolo after demonstrations earlier this week
articles.summary: Greek authorities have bolstered security at Patras and Katakolo harbours to shield the MS Crown Iris, an Israeli cruise ship, after activists blocked its Kalamata docking and forced a detour to Cyprus in July. Demonstrators, angered by ongoing Gaza attacks despite a ceasefire, have intensified protests on Syros and Crete, demanding an end to Greek-Israeli collaboration and closure of Souda Bay base. While campaigners decry Israel’s actions, some critics warn of antisemitic rhetoric. Athens faces a delicate balance between public sentiment and a deepening strategic alliance with Israel. Over 600,000 Israelis visited in 2024, raising economic stakes.

articles.title: Corruption in French politics is nothing new |. letter
articles.trailText: Letter: It is the scale and egregiousness of Nicolas Sarkozy’s corruption that mark out his case most starkly, writes Dr David Lees
articles.summary: Dr David Lees argues that while French political graft is familiar—Chirac’s 1970s Paris conviction and Fillon’s 2017 family-funding scandal—Nicolas Sarkozy’s case stands out for its scale and audacity. His “bling-bling” Élysée lifestyle and covert Gaddafi financing mark a new low. Far-right frontrunner Marine Le Pen also faces a corruption appeal. Public approval of Sarkozy’s imprisonment is tempered by his two police bodyguards, underscoring his privileged status. Amid a parliamentary stalemate, fresh corruption revelations threaten to deepen public distrust ahead of the 2027 presidential election.

articles.title: Violent protests erupt as Tanzanian president nears election victory
articles.trailText: Government critics abducted, killed or arrested in run-up to vote as global monitor records internet blackout
articles.summary: Tanzania’s Oct. 29 vote in Dar es Salaam was marred by violent protests—rock-throwing, a burning petrol station and a nationwide internet blackout recorded by NetBlocks—as incumbent President Samia Suluhu Hassan moves to solidify CCM’s six-decade grip. Major opposition parties Chadema and ACT-Wazalendo were barred, while critics, including former ambassador Humphrey Polepole, face abduction, enforced disappearance or arrest; UN experts cite over 200 disappearances since 2019. Analysts predict low competitiveness and voter apathy. Hassan touts economic growth, healthcare and education gains, while minor rivals like Chaumma’s Salum Mwalimu lack resources to challenge her victory.

articles.title: Press Israel to release Marwan Barghouti, former world leaders urge Trump
articles.trailText: Elders group set up by Mandela and chaired by Colombia’s former president says Palestinian leader would play ‘unifying’ role
articles.summary: At a London meeting, the Elders, founded by Mandela and chaired by Juan Manuel Santos, urged President Trump to press Israel to free Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouti, calling it vital to revive a two-state solution, unify Palestinian politics and prevent Hamas filling the vacuum. The group—including Mary Robinson, Helen Clark and Graça Machel—also condemned Israeli attacks on Gaza City, demanded humanitarian aid deliveries and decried Barghouti’s torture and arbitrary detention. Imprisoned since 2004 with five life terms, Barghouti remains the most popular Palestinian figure and a non-violent two-state advocate. The Elders welcomed Mahmoud Abbas’s pledge for free elections within 12 months.

articles.title: Defence lawyers would have used Tories’ statements to dismiss China spy case, attorney general says
articles.trailText: Richard Hermer says failure by Kemi Badenoch and James Cleverly to describe China as a threat would have been seized on in trial
articles.summary: Attorney general Richard Hermer told MPs that defence lawyers in the aborted trial of ex-researcher Christopher Cash and teacher Christopher Berry on 1911 Official Secrets Act espionage charges would have exploited Conservative ministers’ own statements—like James Cleverly’s 2023 Mansion House speech refusing to call China a 'threat' or Kemi Badenoch’s insistence it was a 'challenge'—to argue China wasn’t legally an 'enemy'. He defended prosecutors’ good faith, blamed outdated legislation (replaced by the 2023 National Security Act) for the collapse, denied improper ministerial intervention, and rejected claims that the government’s reluctance to label China an adversary would hamper future prosecutions.

articles.title: ‘A colony of the US’: Argentinians contemplate future after Trump-backed Milei coasts to victory
articles.trailText: Big win leaves many wondering if result reflects genuine support for president or corrosive US influence
articles.summary: President Javier Milei achieved a surprise 41%–32% midterm win despite recession and corruption claims, buoyed by Trump’s $40bn conditional bailout. Enforced “chainsaw” cuts slashed inflation from over 200% to ~30%, yet real wages, purchasing power and 200k jobs fell, 18k businesses closed, and IMF support doubled down on dollar dependence. Milei’s La Libertad Avanza plus Macri’s PRO now hold Congress. Experts cite anti-Peronist bias, devaluation fear and US leverage���fears echoed in warnings Argentina risks becoming a US “colony,” questioning the depth of genuine support and future autonomy.

articles.title: Voting opens in Netherlands as narrowing polls suggest second Geert Wilders win
articles.trailText: Major parties rule out coalition with rightwinger, giving his party little chance of being part of government
articles.summary: Netherlands holds a razor-thin parliamentary election, polls project Geert Wilders’s far-right PVV leading with 24–28 seats, down from 37 in 2023. Though likely to top the 150-seat chamber, every major party—from centre-left GL/PvdA (22–26 seats) under Frans Timmermans, to liberal D66 (21–25) led by Rob Jetten, and centre-right CDA (18–22)—rules out joining a PVV-led government. With migration, healthcare and housing dominating debate and about half the electorate undecided, analysts foresee protracted coalition talks to form a broad centrist or moderate-right cabinet.

articles.title: Kremlin-linked operatives scramble to stop extradition of mercenary accused of plotting coup
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Inside a Russian bid to free Horațiu Potra, a mercenary held in Dubai accused of conspiring to ‘overthrow constitutional order’ in Romania
articles.summary: Russian-linked actors Igor Spivak and Alexander Kalinin are mobilising lawyers and diplomatic channels to halt the extradition from Dubai of Romanian-French mercenary Horațiu Potra, detained on 24 September alongside kin. Potra, ex-French Foreign Legionnaire turned PMC operator in CAR and DRC, faces Romanian charges of conspiring with far-right politician Călin Georgescu to overthrow constitutional order, illicit arms, financing, tax evasion. Prosecutors cite a December horse-farm meeting, photos of Kremlin contacts and evidence of Russian embassy ties. UAE courts weigh Romania’s request amid Potra’s alleged asylum bid in Moscow.

articles.title: BBC journalist barred from leaving Vietnam and interrogated repeatedly
articles.trailText: BBC ‘deeply concerned’ for journalist’s wellbeing after Vietnamese police withhold their ID card and passport
articles.summary: A BBC journalist—Vietnamese national based in Thailand—has been barred from leaving Vietnam since returning in August to renew their passport; authorities have withheld their ID card and renewed passport while interrogating them for days about their journalism. The case surfaced amid the UK visit of Vietnam’s Communist party leader Tô Lâm. The BBC and rights groups, including Asia HRLA and Reporters sans Frontières (which ranks Vietnam 173/180 in media freedom), are urging Prime Minister Keir Starmer to demand the journalist’s immediate release and protest Vietnam’s harsh press censorship.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: ���Catastrophic’ reports as Jamaica reels from worst storm since records began
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Meteorologists have called it ‘a dire situation unfolding in slow motion’ – what will it leave behind?
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, the strongest storm to hit Jamaica since records began in 1851, made landfall on Oct 29 with 185 mph winds and torrential rain, knocking out power, internet and demolishing infrastructure. Officials describe ‘catastrophic’ damage; initial death toll stands at three, with up to 1.5 million people affected and 50,000 displaced. Slow‐moving Category 5 storms prolong destruction, triggering flash floods, landslides and 9–13 ft storm surges. Over 700,000 have been evacuated in Cuba. Aid agencies have pre‐positioned food, water, generators and medical supplies, but recovery will test Jamaica’s limited infrastructure amid a warming climate driving stronger hurricanes.

articles.title: South Korea awards Trump gold crown amid deal to unlock $350bn trade talks
articles.trailText: Seoul says it has reached broad agreement on investment and shipbuilding as attention shifts to US-China meeting
articles.summary: During his APEC visit in South Korea, President Trump received a replica Silla gold crown and the Grand Order of Mugunghwa as Seoul clinched a broad $350bn trade package—$200bn in US direct investment and $150bn in shipbuilding—in return for tariff negotiations. Attention now shifts to his first face-to-face meeting with Xi Jinping in Busan, where Trump aims to cut a 20% fentanyl-related tariff. A North Korea summit seemed unlikely despite recent missile tests. Seoul also pressed for US visa reforms after a Georgia raid. Talks touched on defense cost-sharing and immigration reforms.

articles.title: Weatherwatch: what is the difference between a hurricane and a typhoon?
articles.trailText: Both are cyclones, or circular storms, but they form in distinct places and vary in terms of scale and impact
articles.summary: Cyclones in the Atlantic are called hurricanes; in the Pacific they’re typhoons. Typhoons tend to be larger due to the Pacific’s vast size, though peak sustained wind speeds are similar. Hurricanes use the five-category Saffir-Simpson scale (Category 5: >157 mph/253 km/h); Pacific storms follow regional scales defining 74–114 mph as typhoons and >115 mph as super typhoons. Typhoons occur year-round (peak August–October; ~16 annually); hurricanes run June–November (~8 annually). Economic losses often spike in affluent US hurricane zones, but typhoons exact higher death tolls in the Philippines, Bangladesh, China and Vietnam due to limited storm protection.

articles.title: ‘Storm of the century’: record-breaking Hurricane Melissa hits Jamaica and heads for Cuba
articles.trailText: Minister says parish of St Elizabeth is ‘under water’ and that families were trapped in their homes in the community of Black River in western Jamaica
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, a record-setting Category 5 storm with 185 mph winds, made landfall in Jamaica’s St Elizabeth parish on 28 Oct, inundating roads, triggering landslides and flooding, cutting power to over 530,000 residents and forcing nearly 15,000 into shelters. Officials reported extensive infrastructure damage, trapped families in Black River and unconfirmed fatalities. After lingering, it weakened to Cat 4 and is advancing toward Cuba, the Bahamas and Bermuda, prompting evacuations of 500,000+ in Cuba. Jamaica’s prime minister declared a disaster area. Meteorologists warn of catastrophic surge and structure failures. Rapid intensification—doubling winds from 70 mph to 140 mph—is linked to record-warm oceans driven by climate change, raising concerns over recovery and long-term resilience.

articles.title: Director of Bataclan terror attack drama rejects accusations of ‘indecency’
articles.trailText: Jean-Xavier de Lestrade defends decision to film mini-series inside Paris theatre where 130 people died in 2015
articles.summary: Jean-Xavier de Lestrade, Oscar-winning director of the eight-part dramatisation Des Vivants, defends filming inside Paris’s Bataclan—scene of the 2015 ISIS attack that killed 130—arguing the seven former hostages (“les potages”) demanded authentic re-creation and a joint letter secured permission. Critics like Life for Paris president Arthur Dénouveaux denounce this “indecent” blend of fiction and trauma, while victims’ association 13onze15 reports mixed feelings. Lestrade insists location shooting was vital to honour survivors’ accounts, not exploit tragedy for commercial gain ahead of the 10th anniversary.

articles.title: Israel strikes Gaza after Netanyahu accuses Hamas of breaching ceasefire
articles.trailText: Prime minister accuses Hamas of ‘clear violation’ of truce as far-right ministers clamour to resume war
articles.summary: After accusing Hamas of breaching the US-brokered ceasefire by returning remains of a hostage recovered two years earlier, PM Netanyahu ordered powerful airstrikes on Gaza City and Khan Younis, killing at least seven, including two children. The strikes followed militants’ attack that killed an Israeli soldier and have delayed a planned hostage-remains handover. Far-right ministers are demanding full war; the US backs Israel’s right to retaliate while urging the truce to hold.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Moscow under drone siege for third night running
articles.trailText: EU edges towards using ‘reparations loan’ using Russian frozen assets; Kremlin pressing ahead with year-round conscription. What we know on day 1,344
articles.summary: Ukraine launched drones at Moscow for a third night, halting flights at Sheremetyevo, Domodedovo and Zhukovsky. Officials claim all UAVs were downed; Russia reported 35 destroyed over two nights. Kyiv targets military-industrial sites, including a fire at a Budyonnovsk petrochemical plant. The EU edges toward a €140bn reparations loan from frozen Russian assets by December. Russia’s parliament moves to adopt year-round conscription, boosting active forces by 180,000 amid reports of coerced volunteers. Zelenskiy will meet EU counterparts on a ceasefire framework, plans limited weapons exports and boosts domestic drone production by 50%. Poland to reopen two Belarus crossings under tighter controls after drone and smuggling incidents.

articles.title: Nusantara, Indonesia’s planned new political capital – explained in 30 seconds
articles.trailText: The new city remains under construction, one year on from its scheduled 2024 inauguration, and has been downgraded from its planned status as a replacement for Jakarta
articles.summary: Nusantara, the planned $32bn replacement for Jakarta in Borneo’s jungles, was announced in 2019 but its 2024 inauguration has been postponed amid logistical, financial and political setbacks. A new regulation downgraded it to a “political capital” for 2028, with budget cuts under President Prabowo Subianto and failure to secure 80% private foreign funding. Of the 6,600ha core area only 800ha—including a Garuda-shaped presidential palace—are built. Phase two covers transport, civil service housing and government buildings. Critics warn of indigenous rights, biodiversity loss and a looming white elephant by the 2045 completion with 2M residents goal.

articles.title: Indonesia’s new capital, Nusantara, in danger of becoming a ‘ghost city’
articles.trailText: State funding for the project has plunged, while construction has slowed and few civil servants have been eager to move away from Jakarta
articles.summary: Nusantara, Indonesia’s planned forest capital launched under Jokowi to replace sinking Jakarta, stands nearly deserted three years in, with boulevards empty and only 2,000 civil servants vs a 1.2 million target. Under President Prabowo, state funding plunged from £2 bn to £700 m in 2025 and private investment missed targets by over £1 bn. Downgraded to a “political capital,” major infrastructure exists but construction slowed, local businesses collapsed, mangroves cleared and indigenous communities face flooding and water shortages. Officials insist funding was reallocated and commitment endures, yet analysts warn Nusantara risks becoming a ghost city or boutique tourism hub. Prabowo prioritises a £15 bn school meals program over the capital.

articles.title: ‘We had no warning’: Britons sheltering from Hurricane Melissa criticise lack of travel alerts
articles.trailText: Travellers to Jamaica say neither government nor airlines raised concerns before the storm forced them into lockdown
articles.summary: British nationals in Jamaica say no travel warnings were issued by the FCDO, travel agents or airlines before Hurricane Melissa, a slow-moving category 5 storm with 180 mph winds that killed three. Stranded guests at a Sandals resort and Negril hotels report lockdown conditions, anxious families and disrupted return flights amid airport closures. Travellers claim neither British Airways nor agents discouraged their departures and that Heathrow offered minimal storm advice. The FCDO urges Brits on the island to register for updates, has deployed a consular team and stands ready to support Jamaica at its request.

articles.title: Brazil: at least 64 reported killed in Rio’s worst day of violence amid police favela raids
articles.trailText: Governor says city ‘at war’ after gunfights between troops and Red Command drug traffickers who reportedly used weaponised drones
articles.summary: In Brazil’s deadliest single-day raid, security forces deployed 2,500+ police and special units in pre-dawn assaults on Red Command strongholds in Alemão and Penha favelas near Rio’s airport. Intense gunbattles erupted, traffickers used weaponised drones, and at least 64 people, including four officers, were killed; 80+ arrested and 93 rifles seized. Governor Cláudio Castro declared the city “at war” against “narco-terrorism.” Critics call it a “state-sponsored massacre,” warning the militarized crackdown risks deepening poverty-driven crime rather than curbing it. Violence and road closures persisted into Tuesday.

articles.title: False claims online damaged Brigitte Macron’s quality of life, daughter tells court
articles.trailText: Tiphaine Auzière spoke at trial of 10 people accused of harassment by posting claims that French first lady was born a man
articles.summary: Tiphaine Auzière told a Paris court that online harassment by ten defendants—eight men and two women aged 41–60—who falsely claimed Brigitte Macron was born a man has undermined the French first lady’s health and forced her into constant self-monitoring of clothing and posture. Private photos were circulated with malicious commentary, impacting her quality of life and family, including grandchildren. Defendants face up to two years in prison. The Macrons have also filed a US defamation suit against podcaster Candace Owens for amplifying the Jean-Michel Trogneux hoax.

articles.title: Back in the spotlight: decoding the Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau romance
articles.trailText: As the singer and former Canadian PM get together, we look at the history of romances between artists and politicians
articles.summary: Canadian former PM Justin Trudeau, 53, and singer Katy Perry, 41, have been spotted together in Montreal and Paris, sparking speculation about their romance. They join a rare list of politician-singer couples—like Pierre Trudeau and Barbra Streisand—amid more common actor-politician pairings. Comedy writer Gráinne Maguire argues that celebrity relationships follow universal patterns, revealing insecurities and career tensions. Both parties face career lulls—Perry’s latest album underperformed, Trudeau recently resigned from politics and divorced—and are navigating post-peak public lives. Their liaison revives memories of Pierre and Streisand’s 1969 affair, raising questions about what comes next: love story, podcast or foundation.

articles.title: Mass killings reported in Sudanese city seized by paramilitary group
articles.trailText: Rapid Support Forces accused of killing more than 2,000 unarmed civilians in El Fasher in recent days
articles.summary: Rapid Support Forces seized El Fasher, Darfur’s last army-held city, over the weekend. Videos show RSF fighters executing unarmed civilians and burning vehicles. Joint Forces claim more than 2,000 civilians killed; Yale’s Humanitarian Research Lab documents ethnic cleansing of Fur, Zaghawa and Berti communities via door-to-door clearance, comparing it to the first 24 hours of the Rwandan genocide. The UN warns of summary executions and growing ethnic atrocities. Over 260,000 civilians remain trapped, 1 million+ have fled; Tawila hospital admitted 130 wounded. RSF now controls all five Darfur capitals, pushing Sudan toward partition. Satellite imagery shows mass graves and red soil discolouration. Communications are cut; survivors learn of loved ones via social media. Experts warn this may be the final stage of the Darfur genocide.

articles.title: UK steps up review of headlight glare as drivers complain of being dazzled
articles.trailText: Considerations include changes to headlight standards and clampdown on illegal sale of overly powerful bulbs
articles.summary: As nights lengthen and clocks go back, the UK government is stepping up a review of headlight glare, considering tighter vehicle lighting standards and a clampdown on illegal high-power bulbs. An RAC survey found over 25% of drivers feel nervous driving at night due to dazzling beams. A new road safety strategy by year-end will draw on 18 months of independent research and propose amendments to UN lighting regulations. Officials will probe design factors—brighter LEDs, higher SUV lights and older drivers’ sensitivity—while DVSA MOT checks and £1,000 fines target illegal retrofits. Eye-care experts advise clean windscreens, adjusted mirrors and slowing or pulling over until vision recovers.

articles.title: British teen on Georgia drug charges could give birth in prison after plea bargain
articles.trailText: Family of Bella Culley, 19, paid £138,000 in deal that could result in a two-year sentence in former Soviet republic
articles.summary: Billingham student nurse Bella Culley, 19, pleaded guilty in Tbilisi to smuggling 14 kg of cannabis after her family paid 500,000 lari (£137,870) under a plea bargain reducing her maximum 20-year term to two years. Arrested in May after being reported missing in Thailand, the pregnant teen could give birth under house arrest rather than in prison. Sentencing is scheduled for 3 November; Culley had claimed she was tortured into carrying drugs and initially faced up to life imprisonment. Her parents lacked property to secure bail.

articles.title: Russian drone attacks on civilians in Ukraine are war crimes, UN report concludes
articles.trailText: Rights commission inquiry focused on south-east of country found drones targeted gathering points and critical infrastructure
articles.summary: A UN inquiry finds Russia’s small, short-range drones systematically targeted civilians and civilian objects in Kherson, Mykolaiv and Dnipropetrovsk—killing over 200 and wounding 2,000 in the past year. Under centralized command, operators struck homes, gathering points, humanitarian distribution sites, critical infrastructure and even ambulances and fire brigades, often repeatedly. The report labels these acts murder, war crimes and crimes against humanity (forcible transfer) intended to terrorize or expel residents near the frontline. Russia denied civilian targeting, refused to cooperate with investigators and blocked examination of alleged Ukrainian strikes in occupied zones.

articles.title: As Netherlands goes to the polls again, Geert Wilders faces isolation
articles.trailText: With other parties refusing to govern with the far-right leader, months of political deadlock may lie ahead
articles.summary: Netherlands votes again after Geert Wilders’ PVV triggered last year’s collapse over a hardline refugee crackdown. Polls forecast PVV may top ballots but all major parties, repelled by Wilders’ anti-immigrant platform and past government chaos, refuse to join him, effectively isolating him from power. Centre-right CDA and liberal-progressive D66 are surging, pledging “responsible” government, while centre-left GL/PvdA also improves. With 16 parties vying for seats and chronic housing and healthcare crises top voter concerns, analysts expect protracted coalition talks likely to produce a broad-based administration excluding the PVV.

articles.title: Japanese PM promises golden age in relations with US during Trump visit
articles.trailText: Sanae Takaichi says she will nominate Trump for peace prize as two leaders sign agreement on rare earths
articles.summary: Japan’s new PM Sanae Takaichi vowed a “golden age” in US ties and stronger defence as Donald Trump opened his Asia tour in Tokyo. They signed a rare earths supply framework to counter China’s export curbs and pledged joint investment in critical minerals resilience. Takaichi, Japan’s first female premier and Abe protégé, offered to nominate Trump for a Nobel peace prize. They exchanged personal gifts honoring Shinzo Abe, discussed trade concessions, North Korean abductees and expanded US arms purchases. Both hailed the US–Japan alliance as key to regional security and prosperity.

articles.title: Elizabeth Warren urges US regulators to investigate Jes Staley ties to Epstein
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Senator asks watchdogs to look at whether US bankers, including ex-Barclays boss, aided late sex offender
articles.summary: Senator Elizabeth Warren has urged the Federal Reserve, OCC and FDIC to probe current and former US banking executives, notably ex-JP Morgan chief Jes Staley, for allegedly facilitating Jeffrey Epstein’s illicit conduct. In a private letter, Warren cites media reports and court evidence that Staley protected Epstein’s access to the banking system, tipped him off to internal concerns and oversaw at least 134 accounts and $1bn in transactions. Already banned from the UK sector in 2023, Staley could face US fines and industry bans. Warren demands public investigation announcements by Nov 7 and private confirmation by Nov 14, also calling for probes of other executives tied to Epstein.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What the mistaken release of Hadush Kebatu reveals about a Prison Service in crisis
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Rising numbers of prisoners released by accident are laying bare systemic failings in England and Wales, from overworked staff to issues with probation
articles.summary: The mistaken release of Hadush Kebatu, a sexual assault prisoner due for deportation, from HMP Chelmsford after officers misflagged him for standard release has laid bare systemic breakdowns in England and Wales’ Prison Service. With 262 inmates inadvertently freed in 2024–25—more than double the previous year—experts cite chronic understaffing, soaring staff turnover (12.5% annual exits), overcrowding and underfunding across prisons, probation (30% officer vacancies) and courts. A five-page release checklist and an inquiry chaired by former deputy commissioner Lynne Owens are under way, but researchers warn that without boosting resources and rebuilding expertise, these “slow-motion collapse” failures will continue.

articles.title: ‘Mud on our hands; blood on his’: fury lingers one year after Spain’s deadly floods
articles.trailText: Survivors in Valencia call for consequences, particularly for regional president, after country’s worst natural disaster this century
articles.summary: One year on from 29 October 2024’s unprecedented flash floods in Valencia—which killed 229 people, wrecked 60,000 homes, 105,000 cars and 10,000 shops—survivors remain enraged at regional president Carlos Mazón. Critics note he dined for four hours as waters rose and only issued a mobile alert at 8.11 pm, after most victims had perished. More than 50,000 protested this month demanding his resignation. The disaster has exposed Spain’s climate vulnerability, politicised emergency planning and sparked calls for green urban reforms, judicial inquiries and long-term flood resilience.

articles.title: ‘It’s more about life than death’: the growing popularity of Berlin’s cemetery cafes
articles.trailText: While cemeteries in the German capital have long been rooted in communities, some cafe owners have gone one step further
articles.summary: Berlin’s dozen cemetery cafés have transformed historic, community-rooted burial grounds into tranquil coffee retreats. Boßmann opened Germany’s first Finovo in 2006 amid the AIDS crisis at Old St Matthäus cemetery; others, like Lisbeth in Sophien run by Chiara de Martin Topranin, balance reverence for grieving visitors with casual brunch crowds. As cremation rises and grounds face upkeep shortfalls, repurposed chapels and former crematoria—from Kreuzberg’s Cafe Friedberg and Neukölln’s 21 Gramm to Wedding’s Mars—offer green oases where life, empathy and ritual intersect.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russian drones hunt civilians in crime against humanity, UN inquiry finds
articles.trailText: Ukraine strengthens Pokrovsk positions amid infiltration by estimated 200 Russian troops; Lukoil selling overseas assets after US sanctions. What we know on day 1,343
articles.summary: The UN’s independent inquiry finds Russia is deploying camera-equipped drones to chase and bomb civilians near Ukraine’s southern frontline, forcing mass displacement in what it classifies as a crime against humanity of forcible transfer, based on 226 interviews and video evidence. Meanwhile, Ukraine fortifies Pokrovsk amid small-scale Russian infiltration, with ISW assessing tactical Russian gains but no imminent collapse. Lukoil begins selling overseas assets under US sanctions on Russian oil giants. Norway monitors for radiation after Russia’s test of the nuclear-powered Burevestnik missile. Kenya seeks repatriation of nationals lured to fight for Russia, and North Korea reaffirms military backing to Putin.

articles.title: Man finds surfboard that drifted 2,400km from Australia to New Zealand – and tracks down owner
articles.trailText: Board was found covered in barnacles and mussels in Raglan, nearly 18 months after it was lost during a boat trip near Tasmania
articles.summary: French surfer Alvaro Bon discovered a barnacle-coated, custom-shaped surfboard in Raglan, NZ, on 15 October after drifting from a kite surfing mishap. The board, yellowed but intact with wax, was covered in mussels, hinting at a long ocean journey. Bon posted photos in global surfing groups; within hours he identified the owner, Liam, who lost it off Tasmania’s coast on 10 May 2024. Experts suggest the East Australian or Antarctic Circumpolar currents carried it 2,400 km. Returned by air to its grateful owner, the board’s odyssey underscores oceanic connectivity.

articles.title: Jamaicans take shelter as Hurricane Melissa bears down as category 5 storm
articles.trailText: Landfall expected in coming hours amid warnings of catastrophic flooding, and landslides
articles.summary: Jamaica braces for Hurricane Melissa, a record-breaking Category 5 with 175 mph winds and a snail-paced advance of 2 mph, set to make landfall near St Elizabeth early Tuesday. Forecast path diagonally across the island toward St Ann threatens up to 40 in of rain, 4 m storm surge, catastrophic flooding, landslides and widespread infrastructure collapse. Three Jamaicans have died; power is out in St Elizabeth. Authorities have opened nearly 900 shelters, issued compulsory evacuations on the south coast and warned no coastal infrastructure can withstand the storm, signaling a potential humanitarian crisis requiring international aid.

articles.title: Hamas returns remains of Israeli hostage after Red Cross’s help in search
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Red Cross acts as ‘neutral intermediary’ to recover hostages’ remains in areas under Israeli control
articles.summary: Under the US-brokered ceasefire of 10 October, Hamas is obliged to return all Israeli hostages’ remains in exchange for 15 Palestinian bodies per return. On Monday, supported by the ICRC acting as neutral intermediary and an Israeli-approved Egyptian technical team, Hamas delivered another hostage’s remains and inspected sites beyond the IDF’s “yellow line.” To date 15 sets have been repatriated; about 12 remain inaccessible amid Gaza’s extensive war-torn rubble. Trump issued a 48-hour ultimatum; Hamas insists it cannot disarm until occupation ends.

articles.title: At least 174 racehorses died from racing or training injuries in past 12 months in Australia, report finds
articles.trailText: That’s the highest number recorded by the Coalition for the Protection of Racehorses since they began tracking deaths 10 years ago
articles.summary: The Coalition for the Protection of Racehorses reports 174 thoroughbreds died in the past 12 months from racing or training injuries—the highest in a decade—using data from stewards’ reports, media and whistleblowers. Of these, 85 were fatal front limb injuries; a GIPA request to Racing NSW logged 138 deaths in 2023–24. Victoria’s 2024–25 flat season saw 20 race-day fatalities and 40 jump or training euthanasias. Meanwhile, Racing Victoria denies allegations its vet GM faced pressure to relax 2021 safety protocols requiring CT/MRI scans and multi-stage exams, credited with zero Spring Carnival fatalities. CPR calls for universal CT screening nationwide.

articles.title: Alassane Ouattara wins landslide fourth term as Ivory Coast’s president
articles.trailText: Low turnout said to have made for most peaceful election in years, as 83-year-old accused of clampdown on dissent wins 89.77% of vote
articles.summary: Alassane Ouattara, 83, secured 89.77% (3.75m votes) in Ivory Coast’s presidential election, winning a fourth term to 2030. Opposition heavyweights Laurent Gbagbo and Tidjane Thiam were barred; former first lady Simone Gbagbo and ex-ministers Jean-Louis Billon (3%), Ahoua Don Mello and Henriette Lagou Adjoua (1.15%) trailed far behind. With 8.7m registered voters, turnout was about 50%, notably low in Abidjan’s Yopougon and Cocody, yielding Ivory Coast’s most peaceful poll in years amid allegations of crony capitalism and a security crackdown; forces enforced curfews after youth unrest and 250+ arrests.

articles.title: Missing ‘critical element’ caused UK China spying trial to collapse, say prosecutors
articles.trailText: Refusal to describe China as security threat meant ‘all routes were closed’, says director of public prosecutions
articles.summary: Prosecutors say the UK government’s failure to designate China as a national security threat deprived the espionage case against two men of its essential statutory element, forcing its collapse. Director of Public Prosecutions Stephen Parkinson told MPs evidence couldn’t sustain the charge that China is an “enemy.” Senior civil servant Matthew Collins said he detailed China’s economic, cyber and democratic threats but was bound by Conservative policy not to label China generically as a threat. The hearing revealed prosecutors felt Collins’s wording fell short of the precise threat formulation needed to avoid a “no case to answer” submission, and both sides disagreed over whether the jury should have decided the issue.

articles.title: Ten people go on trial in Paris accused of online harassment of Brigitte Macron
articles.trailText: Trial is latest phase in legal battle against false claim that French first lady is a man named Jean-Michel Trogneux
articles.summary: Ten individuals (eight men, two women, aged 41–60) face trial in Paris, charged with online harassment of French first lady Brigitte Macron for spreading the baseless claim she was born a man named Jean-Michel Trogneux. Stemming from her 2024 complaint, this case is separate from the Macrons’ US defamation lawsuit against Candace Owens’s “grotesque narrative.” Defendants, who deny wrongdoing and label their posts satirical, face up to two years’ prison for “hateful” gender-based insults that deeply hurt the first family.

articles.title: Reform MP’s claim about ‘adverts full of black and Asian people’ omits profitability for companies
articles.trailText: Sarah Pochin’s anger not shared by brands who find that more diversity in commercials is great for their bottom line
articles.summary: Reform MP Sarah Pochin’s remark that she was “driven mad” by adverts “full of black and Asian people” sparked a racism row and apology, but ignored brands’ financial motives. Since 2020 black representation in UK ads climbed from 37% to 51% (peaking in 2022) despite black people comprising 4% of the population. A 2024 global study found inclusive campaigns deliver a 3.5% short-term sales lift and 16% long-term brand growth. Yet DEI investment is waning, risking tone-deaf campaigns like Heinz’s accused stereotypes and an ASA-banned Sanex ad. LGBTQIA+ and pregnant women remain under-represented, highlighting persistent diversity gaps.

articles.title: Ronnie Sim obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Former teacher who helped translate the Bible into various African languages
articles.summary: Ronnie Sim, 81, Glasgow-born teacher turned linguist and missionary, spent decades with Wycliffe Bible Translators in Kenya and Ethiopia. After chemistry teaching in Scotland, he earned MAs in linguistics (Nairobi), led the Hadiyya Bible translation project (1980–87), configured non-Latin scripts for early computing, and completed a Hadiyya grammar PhD (Edinburgh, 1990). Back in Kenya, he established Pan Africa Christian College and Nairobi Evangelical Graduate School degree programs in Bible translation. From 2008 he consulted in Zambia, Ethiopia and Nigeria. He is survived by wife Margaret, five children, eight grandchildren and sister June.

articles.title: King Charles lays flowers at national memorial to LGBT armed forces veterans
articles.trailText: Monument honours those whose careers were cut short by the ‘gay ban’ in place from 1967 to 2000
articles.summary: King Charles laid flowers at An Opened Letter memorial, the UK’s first national LGBT armed forces tribute at the National Memorial Arboretum in Staffordshire. The sculpture—a crumpled bronze letter inscribed with testimonies—honours veterans discharged under the 1967–2000 military "gay ban." He met serving and former personnel, including Brig Clare Phillips, who reflected on 30 years of service; Carol Morgan, Carl Austin-Behan and Claire Ashton, who described forced discharge, pension loss and lifelong trauma. Funded by a £350,000 MoD grant, the dedication follows PM Rishi Sunak’s 2023 state apology.

articles.title: Kathryn Bell obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Founder member of several organisations promoting creativity and human rights
articles.summary: Kathryn Bell, who has died aged 91, was a Glasgow-born pioneer of LGBTQ+ and disability rights. After serving as the first female inspector in the Northern Rhodesia Police Force, she returned to London in 1966 with partner Elsa Wallace Beckett and co-founded Gemma (1976), Action and Rights of Disabled People, Docklands Drop In, the Gay Authors Workshop (1978) and, in 1999, the Paradise Press collective. A poet and short-story writer, she worked in the NHS until 1994, nurtured emerging writers, and received the Sappho in Paradise award in 2024. She is survived by cousins William and Anne.

articles.title: China spy row: Berry knew some of his contacts were non-commercial, messages suggest
articles.trailText: Man at centre of abandoned spy case has said he reported to Chinese company with clients that wanted ‘to develop trading links with UK’
articles.summary: Christopher Berry was charged under the Official Secrets Act for providing over 30 reports to a Chinese “handler” between December 2021 and February 2023, receiving about £20,000. He maintained his analyses covered economic and commercial issues drawn from public sources for a firm with UK trading clients. The CPS alleged the client was a Chinese intelligence agent, but defence WhatsApp messages show Berry knew some contacts were non-commercial, met a secretive stranger in July 2022 and googled them, prompting colleague Christopher Cash’s warning, “You’re in spy territory.” Logs reveal joked plans to plant disinformation to spark “regime collapse.” Charges were dropped in September 2025.

articles.title: Warming oceans probably fueling Hurricane Melissa’s rapid intensification
articles.trailText: Climate scientists have long warned that warming oceans are making such explosive storm development more common
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa underwent one of the fastest intensifications on record in the Atlantic, jumping from 70 mph to 140 mph in 24 hours and upgraded to a 160 mph category 5 storm. Approaching Jamaica, Cuba and the Bahamas, it threatens catastrophic flooding and landslides. Scientists link the rapid strengthening, one of four such events this season, to human-driven ocean warming: Atlantic surface temperatures near 30 °C (2–3 °C above normal) and anomalously warm deep waters. Climate Central reports fossil-fuel emissions made this heat spike 700 times more likely, and a 2023 study found rapid intensification odds have more than doubled.

articles.title: Here’s why Poland’s birth rate is falling | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: Marta Zboralska highlights the country’s abortion laws and says women are scared that if they experience complications, they will not receive adequate care
articles.summary: In a letter, Polish woman Marta Zboralska argues that Poland’s plummeting birth rate stems largely from draconian abortion laws rather than loneliness or cash incentives. She cites the 2020 constitutional tribunal ruling—under judges loyal to the Law and Justice party—and the widely reported 2021 death of 22-week-pregnant Izabela from sepsis as key examples. Zboralska says women now fear seeking care if complications arise, and despite promises to liberalise the law, the government has done little to address these fears.

articles.title: Trump’s bailout threat may have been key to Milei’s electoral triumph in Argentina
articles.trailText: Voters appear to have responded to idea that US president’s ‘generosity’ would evaporate if Milei failed to win
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s $40bn bailout and warning to withdraw support if Javier Milei lost appear to have swayed voters, helping the libertarian president secure 41% in midterms versus the Peronists’ 32%. Milei, reeling from economic crisis and a prior provincial defeat, won backing after Trump offered a $20bn dollar swap and $20bn in further aid—and declared “if he doesn’t win, we’re gone.” Critics decried overt US meddling, but markets rallied on Milei’s shock-therapy agenda. Experts label Trump’s Latin America strategy—combining aid and threats—“bold,” citing similar leverage with Mexico, Panama and Brazil.

articles.title: Javier Milei hails ‘tipping point’ as his far-right party wins Argentina’s midterm elections
articles.trailText: Result falls short of giving Milei a congressional majority but surprises many analysts after series of scandals
articles.summary: Javier Milei’s far-right La Libertad Avanza won 40.8%, securing 64 lower-house and 13 senate seats in Argentina’s midterms—short of a majority but, combined with PRO’s bloc, enough to uphold presidential vetoes. The result surprised analysts after scandals and austerity cuts, and followed a $40 bn US bailout tied to Trump’s endorsement. Turnout hit a democracy-era low (67.8%). Markets rallied—shares +40%, bonds +23%—on optimism his libertarian reforms, which cut jobs and tamed inflation from 200% to 30%, can endure, though he still needs 20 more deputies to pass new laws.

articles.title: Italian ski pass price rises mean sport may become only for wealthy, watchdog warns
articles.trailText: Price increases of as much as 40% poised to make sport exclusive privilege of the wealthy, says Assoutenti
articles.summary: Assoutenti warns up to 40% ski-pass hikes this winter threaten to price out all but wealthy Italians. Daily rates like €86 for a Dolomiti Superski pass and ���60 in Roccaraso, plus seasonal tickets from €755 to €1,800, join rising equipment, hotel and restaurant costs. The watchdog’s president decries the “completely unjustified” increases amid controlled inflation and normalized energy tariffs, noting 1 m fewer domestic skiers in 2024-25. While still cheaper than France, Austria or Switzerland, concerns mount ahead of the Milan-Cortina 2026 Winter Games, where Italy will push a UN-backed global truce.

articles.title: World’s oldest serving head of state declared winner in Cameroon election
articles.trailText: Paul Biya, 92, said to have won 53.66% of vote after volatile two weeks since election when opponent claimed victory
articles.summary: Paul Biya, 92, Cameroon’s president since 1982, has been declared winner of the 12 October vote with 53.66% against former ally Issa Tchiroma Bakary’s 35.19%, securing an unprecedented eighth term that could extend his rule near age 100. Tchiroma, who had claimed victory with 54.8% from 80% of polling stations, denounced the results as fraudulent and called for protests. A ban on public gatherings and internet disruptions in Douala heightened tensions. Clashes between security forces and opposition supporters in Douala and Garoua left at least six dead, while protests continued in Yaoundé, Bafoussam and other cities.

articles.title: Grave fears for civilians after Sudanese paramilitary claims capture of El Fasher
articles.trailText: RSF says it has seized control of army’s main base in Darfur, home to famine-stricken displacement camp
articles.summary: Following more than a year-long siege, Sudan’s paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) claimed capture of El Fasher—Darfur’s main army base and site of a UN-declared famine displacement camp—raising alarm for hundreds of thousands trapped residents. The UN’s humanitarian chief warned RSF advances cut off escape routes, urging a ceasefire, safe civilian passage and humanitarian access, while RSF insisted it would open corridors. Communications blackouts, reports of civilians killed fleeing, and allegations of UAE arms support underscore fears this victory cements RSF control over all Darfur states, potentially deepening national partition.

articles.title: Lithuania says it will shoot down smuggling balloons from Russia’s ally Belarus
articles.trailText: PM blames Alexander Lukashenko for not stopping ‘hybrid attacks’, which closed Vilnius airport four times last week
articles.summary: Lithuania's PM Inga Ruginiene has authorised shooting down of contraband cigarette balloons sent from Belarus, calling them 'hybrid attacks' orchestrated by Alexander Lukashenko's regime. Incursions forced closure of Vilnius airport four times and temporary shutdown of Medininkai and Salcininkai border crossings—now limited to diplomats and EU citizens outbound. Vilnius may invoke NATO's Article 4 for security consultations. In parallel, Lithuania summoned Russia's chargé d'Affaires after a Sukhoi SU-30 and IL-78 tanker briefly penetrated its airspace from Kaliningrad, an incursion Moscow denies. Tallinn and Riga have also reported repeated Russian airspace violations, which Baltic leaders deem calculated provocations against NATO unity.

articles.title: Trump describes Russia’s new cruise missile test as ‘not appropriate’
articles.trailText: US president says Vladimir Putin should focus on ending war with Ukraine rather than testing missiles
articles.summary: Donald Trump called Putin’s nuclear-powered Burevestnik cruise missile test “not appropriate,” urging focus on ending the war in Ukraine. Putin hailed the successful 15-hour, 14,000 km flight as proof of Russia’s “unique” invincible weapon and ordered infrastructure build-out. Experts like Jeffrey Lewis dispute its invulnerability. The launch—a reminder of Moscow’s intensified nuclear posture, recent drills and softened use thresholds—escalates an arms race as US-Russia talks stall. Trump noted the US has a nuclear submarine off Russia’s shores and decried missile shield tensions. Russia bristles at US sanctions and Trump’s ceasefire push.

articles.title: Tell us if you’ve been affected by Hurricane Melissa
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people about the impact Hurricane Melissa is having in their area
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa, deemed “life-threatening” by the US National Hurricane Center, made landfall in Jamaica’s St Elizabeth parish as a Category 5 storm with 160 mph winds and up to 40 in of rain. Forecasts warn of catastrophic flash flooding, landslides and destructive winds as Melissa weakens to Cat 4 moving toward Cuba and the Bahamas. Nearly 250,000 Jamaicans are without power. The Guardian invites first-hand accounts, photos and videos from those affected—please prioritise personal safety and adhere to our terms of service and privacy policy when submitting.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa strengthens to category 5 as evacuations ordered in Jamaica’s capital
articles.trailText: Storm could intensify further, threatening to cause catastrophic flooding in northern Caribbean
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa rapidly intensified to Category 5 with 145 mph sustained winds and a slow 5 mph track as it nears Jamaica, triggering mandatory evacuations in Kingston, Port Royal and six other flood-prone zones. Authorities closed both international airports, opened 881 shelters, and warn of 30–40 inches of rain, catastrophic flooding, power and communications outages. Some residents refuse to leave due to past shelter conditions. Melissa is forecast to impact Cuba by Tuesday, then the Bahamas, after already causing deaths in Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

articles.title: ‘Open hostility has become normalised’: Dutch Muslims fear rise of far right as general election looms
articles.trailText: The poll is seen as a litmus test for the Netherlands and its democratic ideals, as activists decry a hardening of political discourse driven by Geert Wilders
articles.summary: With the Netherlands�� 29 October election framed as a referendum on its democratic values, far-right leader Geert Wilders’ anti-Muslim campaign—seen in a propaganda-style social media post that triggered 14,000 discrimination complaints—symbolizes a broader hardening of political discourse. After the PVV’s shock 2023 victory and brief coalition role, open hostility toward Muslims, asylum seekers and migrants has normalized. Other parties echo his rhetoric, while proposed measures include border closures, mass deportations, citizenship revocations and slashed integration funding. In response, refugee advocacy groups have surged in support and young Dutch Muslims intensify political activism to defend equality, human rights and religious freedom.

articles.title: Monday briefing: How radical views became normalised – from TV ads to deportation policy
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The language that once belonged to Tommy Robinson and the BNP is now the preserve of the Conservatives and Reform UK – and represents a shift so vast we barely notice it
articles.summary: Mainstream UK politics has absorbed policies once confined to the BNP: Conservative and Reform UK figures propose deporting settled migrants, boosting birthrates over immigration, scrapping minority 'special treatment', limiting black and Asian representation on TV and equating whiteness with Englishness.
