From remigration and 'two-tier' policing claims to 'great replacement' rhetoric on family policy, the Overton window has shifted, normalising far-right tropes across government, media and public debate. Key actors include Reform UK under Nigel Farage, Tory junior minister Katie Lam and media outlets like the Daily Mail and GB News.

articles.title: Japan’s new PM will hope the Abe effect endears Trump to her at crucial talks
articles.trailText: Sanae Takaichi leads a minority government and needs a successful meeting with the US president on Tuesday. Thankfully her mentor, Shinzo Abe, is one of Trump’s ‘favourites’
articles.summary: Japan’s first female prime minister Sanae Takaichi, heading a minority LDP-led coalition, faces a critical meeting with Donald Trump in Tokyo to reset US-Japan ties strained by retaliatory tariffs under his America-first policies. Eager to showcase her credentials, she seeks further trade relief in exchange for increased US agricultural and industrial imports, while aligning on security: boosting defence spending to 2% of GDP, acquiring US counterstrike capabilities and countering Chinese assertiveness. Her mentor Shinzo Abe’s rapport with Trump may smooth personal diplomacy.

articles.title: South Korea grapples with surge in anti-China sentiment as Xi Jinping prepares to fly in
articles.trailText: Maga-inspired protests regularly take place on streets of Seoul amid chants of ‘Korea for Koreans’ as South prepares to host crucial Apec summit
articles.summary: Thousands of Maga-inspired protesters in Seoul, waving US and Korean flags and chanting “China out,” have staged weekly rallies ahead of Xi Jinping’s Apec visit in Gyeongju. Led by Freedom University youth and older evangelical rightwing activists, they decry alleged Chinese interference, illegal fishing and economic retaliation, spurred by visa-free entry for Chinese tourists. Anti-China sentiment in South Korea rose from 16% in 2015 to over 71% in 2025. President Lee Jae Myung and PM Kim Min-seok condemned racist slurs, ordered lockdowns of Myeongdong demonstrations and proposed anti-discrimination laws amid US–China rivalry and domestic anxiety around sovereignty, unemployment and housing.

articles.title: Archaeological dig to unearth wreckage of WW2 hero pilot crash under way
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Excavation, overseen by the US Department of Defense, will feature in More 4’s Hidden Wonders TV series
articles.summary: US DPAA, UK MoD and Cotswold Archaeology are excavating in Essex the 1944 crash site of 2nd Lt Lester Lowry’s P-47 Thunderbolt, MIA for over 80 years. Archaeologists have recovered engine cylinder heads, pistons, fuselage fragments, M2 Browning gun parts, cockpit instruments and Lowry’s parachute harness clips. Lowry, orphaned at nine, flew on minimal training (47 hours). The dig features on More4’s Hidden Wonders (from 4 Nov), co-hosted by Sandi Toksvig. Post-excavation analysis in Nebraska will inform UK/US museum displays, underscoring global POW/MIA recovery and training-accident sacrifices.

articles.title: Bear attack survival tips released in Japan as encounters surge
articles.trailText: Governor of one prefecture says he is considering asking the military for help to tackle increasing attacks amid thousands-strong bear population
articles.summary: Following a record nine bear-attack fatalities since April, Japan’s authorities, especially in Akita and Hokkaido, are urging city dwellers and hikers to learn survival tactics as thousands-strong Asian black and Ussuri brown bears encroach urban zones amid food shortages and warmer winters. Experts advise avoiding eye contact and sudden moves, backing away slowly, lying face-down with head and neck protected if attacked, using bells or whistles, travelling in groups, and carrying repellent spray. Local governments, short of licensed hunters, are even considering Self-Defense Force assistance, while the environment ministry pledges more hunters and population management.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Russia claims test of nuclear-powered missile condemned as ‘flying Chornobyl’
articles.trailText: Burevestnik stayed in air for 15 hours, defence minister tells Vladimir Putin; Ukrainian drones close Moscow airports. What we know on day 1,342
articles.summary: On 21 October Russia claimed to have test-fired Burevestnik (Nato's SSC-X-9 Skyfall), a nuclear-powered cruise missile dubbed the "flying Chornobyl" by arms-control experts after a fatal 2019 reactor accident. Gen. Gerasimov told President Putin it flew 14,000 km over 15 hours. Simultaneously, Ukrainian drones prompted closures at Moscow's Domodedovo and Zhukovsky airports; 28 were shot down. US sanctions on Russian oil spiked prices by 6%, threatening about $7.4 bn in monthly Kremlin revenue. Kirill Dmitriev arrived in Washington blaming external forces for stalled US-Russia dialogue just days after Trump scrapped a potential Budapest summit.

articles.title: Australia ‘increasingly alone’ in countering China’s influence in Pacific, aid report shows
articles.trailText: US aid cuts hurt Washington’s standing as China recasts itself as a ‘steady’ alternative partner, Lowy Institute report finds
articles.summary: Australia remains the dominant aid donor in the Pacific, providing 43% of official development finance as US and Western funding fell 16% in 2023 to US$3.6bn. The Lowy Institute finds Australia’s steady infrastructure lending cushions the region, leaving Canberra increasingly alone against Beijing’s narrative of a consistent, non-interventionist partner. China now deploys smaller, targeted grants to deepen grassroots ties despite flat spending. By 2028 Australia will likely outpace combined support from Japan, New Zealand, the US, UK, France and Germany, while also leading regional disaster response and a shared Pacific response group headquartered in New Zealand from mid-2026.

articles.title: Susan Griffin obituary
articles.trailText: Author who devised the concept of ecofeminism and also wrote about war, memory and the private lives of public events
articles.summary: Susan Griffin (1943–2025) was a pioneering ecofeminist author and playwright whose 1978 book Woman and Nature: The Roaring Inside Her sold over 100,000 copies and remains the movement’s manifesto. Across 21 titles—essays, poetry, memoirs and plays—she traced links among environmental destruction, sexism, racism and war. A civil‐rights and free‐speech activist, Pulitzer finalist and Emmy winner, she taught at Berkeley, Stanford and beyond. Griffin’s landmark works on rape, pornography, trauma and democracy fused personal narrative with political philosophy. Born in Los Angeles and openly lesbian, she is survived by daughter Chloe and grandchildren Sophie and Jasper.

articles.title: The Dutch election: key players and main issues in the snap poll
articles.trailText: Voters could swap a rightwing government for a more moderate coalition – but the fragmentary political system makes many outcomes possible
articles.summary: In the Netherlands’ Oct 2025 snap election, triggered by Geert Wilders’ PVV quitting a frail right-wing coalition, polls forecast the anti-immigration PVV remains the largest party but unable to attract partners. Fragmented results—with up to 16 parties winning seats—mean weeks of coalition talks. Main contenders include Wilders’ PVV (up to 25 seats), the GreenLeft/Labour alliance (26), D66 (23), CDA (22), VVD (18) and JA21 (14). Top voter concerns are immigration controls, housing shortages and cost-of-living pressures. Likely coalitions involve centrist and moderate right parties excluding Wilders.

articles.title: French police arrest two men over €88m Louvre jewel heist
articles.trailText: One man arrested at Charles de Gaulle airport and another just outside Paris, officials confirm
articles.summary: French police have detained two suspects in their 30s—one at Charles de Gaulle airport bound for Algeria, the other near Paris planning to travel to Mali—over last Sunday’s €88 million Louvre crown-jewels heist. Both men, with prior robbery convictions and under surveillance, were identified via forensic analysis of gloves, a helmet, power tools and other items abandoned at the Apollo gallery. Over 150 DNA and fingerprint traces are being processed as investigators mobilise 100 officers to recover eight gem-studded royal pieces and pursue remaining accomplices.

articles.title: Fears Gaza ‘temporary’ ceasefire line could become permanent new border
articles.trailText: Yellow markers installed by IDF entrench divide that cuts strip in two, as hopes of moving to next phase of truce fade
articles.summary: With Gaza’s ‘temporary’ ceasefire stalling, the IDF has begun installing yellow concrete markers every 200 m to bisect the Strip, reinforcing a de facto border. Troops, drones and free-fire orders prevent civilians from crossing into areas under Israeli control, where daily casualties still mount. Netanyahu’s right-wing coalition opposes further withdrawal or multinational peacekeepers, raising fears this vague US-brokered truce will solidify Gaza’s partition and trap over half its population in a shrinking enclave.

articles.title: ‘Every day’s a fight’: join the commuters in Africa���s rapidly growing cities
articles.trailText: With more and more people moving to big cities such as Nairobi and Abidjan, daily commutes are becoming tougher
articles.summary: Africa’s urban population jumped from 28% in 1990 to 44% today and will double by 2050, yet public transport lags. In Nairobi, 10,000+ privately owned matatus (13–30 seats) blare music, breach safety rules and shunt commuters in 45–120 min rides for ~50 KSh. Johannesburg’s Metrorail runs on 35 of 40 lines, pushing workers into 2.5 hr trips via overcrowded trains (12 ZAR) and 15-seat taxi vans (27 ZAR) amid deadly route conflicts. In Abidjan, woro-woro shared taxis, gbaka minibuses and “22-Place” badjan clog roads; Sotra buses overflow and a metro project remains years away. Experts cite colonial segregation and post-independence mismanagement as root causes.

articles.title: ‘There is no life’: Kupiansk’s slow demise reflects the fate of cities on Ukraine’s frontline
articles.trailText: After more than two years of attacks, much of the population has left and the remaining soldiers are stuck in a war ‘going nowhere’
articles.summary: In Kupiansk, a frontline city with a prewar population of 27,000 intermittently bombarded since its 2022 liberation, most residents have fled, shops and services closed, and roughly 600 civilians remain west of the Oskil river. With no electricity or gas, its slow demise epitomizes Ukraine’s attritional, stalemated war. Seventy-seven-year-old nurse Lyubov Lobunets recalls destroyed homes; mayor Andrii Besedin warns of daily evacuations amid partial encirclement. Ukrainian defenders, notably the 15th brigade under 'Caesar,' use drones and razor-wire nets to repel Russian river crossings via gas pipes.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: US reportedly mulling further sanctions on Russia that could hit banking sector
articles.trailText: Trump said he would not schedule any talks with Putin unless it was clear that the Russian leader was serious about ending the war. What we know on day 1,341
articles.summary: On day 1,341 of Russia’s invasion Reuters reports the Trump administration has drafted new sanctions targeting Russia’s banking sector and oil-export infrastructure if Putin fails to pursue a peace deal. Trump, who imposed his first Russia sanctions since January, says he won’t meet Putin until there’s serious commitment to end the war. Meanwhile, fresh Russian missile and drone strikes killed at least seven civilians and wounded dozens across Kyiv and Dnipropetrovsk, prompting Zelenskiy to urge G7 allies to supply Patriot air defences.

articles.title: British tourist dies after 20ft fall from Lanzarote hotel balcony
articles.trailText: Another man in critical condition after railing reportedly breaks off in Costa Teguise
articles.summary: In Costa Teguise, Lanzarote, a 56-year-old British tourist died instantly after falling 20ft when a hotel balcony railing collapsed around 1.30am; a 54-year-old fellow Briton was critically injured and taken to Doctor José Molina Orosa hospital in Arrecife. The Spanish Civil Guard has launched an investigation into the railing’s maintenance and hotel security. It remains unclear whether the two were friends or related, and the hotel’s name has not been released.

articles.title: Leftwinger Catherine Connolly wins Ireland presidential election by landslide
articles.trailText: Independent pledges to be ‘president for all’ after taking 63% of vote in upset for political establishment
articles.summary: 68-year-old former barrister Catherine Connolly, an independent backed by Social Democrats, People Before Profit, Labour and Sinn Féin, won Ireland’s presidency with 63% (914,143) of first-preference votes of 1.44m valid ballots, beating Fine Gael’s Heather Humphreys (424,987, 29%) and Fianna Fáil’s Jim Gavin (103,568, 7%). Turnout was 46% with a record 213,738 spoiled votes (up to 20% in Dublin). She vows an inclusive, climate-focused presidency defending neutrality and diversity. Her victory, fueled by youth and social media, marks a rare left-wing triumph and a rebuke to the centre-right government, potentially straining ties with the US and UK.

articles.title: Catherine Connolly’s landslide shakes Ireland’s establishment – but not its politics
articles.trailText: Connolly’s stunning victory humbles old parties and energises the left, yet it’s no revolution: the presidency remains symbolic
articles.summary: Independent left MP Catherine Connolly won Ireland’s presidency with 64% of the vote, backed by small left-wing parties and Sinn Féin. Centre-right giants Fianna Fáil and Fine Gael fielded weakened candidates who self-sabotaged amid scandals and withdrawals. With turnout near 46% and record spoilt ballots signifying voter apathy, Connolly’s seven-year term will remain largely ceremonial, constraining policy impact despite her emphasis on equality and Irish neutrality. Her landslide victory shakes the establishment’s authority but won’t alter centre-right governance, and rival missteps plus low engagement temper broader leftward momentum.

articles.title: Japanese tourist dies in fall from Pantheon in Rome
articles.trailText: The 69-year-old man plunged 7 metres from an outer wall after becoming unwell and losing his balance
articles.summary: A 69-year-old Japanese tourist died after falling 7m from the Pantheon’s outer wall in Rome on Friday night. According to reports, he had been sitting on the wall when a sudden illness caused him to lose balance and plunge into the moat; rescuers forced open a nearby gate to reach him, but he was pronounced dead at the scene. Rome police have launched an investigation. He was visiting with his daughter. The Pantheon, built by Hadrian, introduced a €5 ticket in 2023 but still drew over 4 million visitors in 2024. This follows other tourist fatalities in Rome this year amid record arrivals.

articles.title: Argentina goes to polls amid economic crisis and Trump ‘interference’
articles.trailText: Poor showing in Sunday’s election would deal hammer blow to country’s radical libertarian president, Javier Milei
articles.summary: Argentina’s midterm vote on 25 October poses a stark test for President Javier Milei’s radical libertarian agenda. After two years of shock therapy—slashing spending, curbing triple-digit inflation, and pursuing austerity—Milei faces scandals involving relatives, a peso sell-off and a damaging 40% defeat in Buenos Aires province. His US ally Donald Trump, offering up to $40 bn in aid, warned he would withdraw support if Milei underperforms, prompting opposition charges of foreign interference. Polls show 60% of Argentines struggling to make ends meet, and analysts predict a punishing backlash could trigger renewed financial turmoil, while a mixed result may stall Milei’s reform drive.

articles.title: ‘We’ll march as many times as necessary’: Peru’s youth protesters defy state of emergency
articles.trailText: Rapper shot dead by police becomes symbol of resistance in Peru, amid wave of gen Z rallies sweeping the world
articles.summary: Peruvian Generation Z Collective says it will defy a new 30-day state of emergency in Lima and Callao—authorised by interim president José Jerí to stem a 35.9% spike in homicides—by marching again on Saturday. They honour rapper Eduardo Ruiz (Truko), killed by a plainclothes officer during recent protests, and demand Jerí’s resignation, Congress’s dissolution and an end to laws they say empower organised crime. Reflecting global Gen Z uprisings from Madagascar to Nepal, youth leaders decry entrenched corruption, limited opportunities and repeated failed crackdowns.

articles.title: ‘Dare to change’: Ivory Coast heads to the polls as rivals seek to oust Ouattara
articles.trailText: Incumbent leader, 83, is accused of cracking down on political dissent and overseeing unequal economic growth
articles.summary: Incumbent President Alassane Ouattara, 83, seeks a controversial fourth term in Ivory Coast’s Oct 25 vote, touting 7% annual growth and major infrastructure but accused of silencing dissent and fueling unequal development. Four challengers—including former first lady Simone Ehivet Gbagbo and ex-minister Jean-Louis Billon—appeal to youth discontent over cost of living, unemployment, cocoa-sector climate risks and rural-urban gaps. Opposition leaders Laurent Gbagbo and Tidjane Thiam were barred amid transparency concerns at the electoral commission. Observers warn of post-vote unrest in a nation yet to see a peaceful power transfer.

articles.title: Turkey likely to be excluded from Gaza stabilisation force after Israeli objection
articles.trailText: Doubts over whether Ankara will be part of 5,000-strong force to be deployed to prevent postwar power vacuum
articles.summary: Israel has signalled it will bar Turkish troops from the planned 5,000-strong Gaza stabilisation force, a requirement underscored by US Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s insistence that Israel must be comfortable with all contributing nationalities. Turkey had offered to deploy its capable AFAD disaster-response specialists but now faces exclusion amid Ankara’s strained ties with Jerusalem. The Egypt-led force—supported by Indonesia, the UAE and coordinated with a US-led Civil-Military Coordination Centre hosting British, French, Jordanian and Emirati advisers in Kiryat Gat—will disarm Hamas and secure a transitional technocrat administration after Israel rules out Palestinian Authority involvement.

articles.title: Six metres below ground: inside the secret hospital treating Ukrainian soldiers injured by Russian drones
articles.trailText: Doctors at the secret facility are able to perform amputations while others monitor zigzagging drones overhead
articles.summary: Six metres below ground in Donetsk oblast, Ukraine’s secret underground hospital treats 30–40 soldiers daily injured by Russian FPV drones, performing amputations and complex surgeries in steel-bunker wards built by Metinvest. Staff monitor drone movements above while stabilising catastrophic leg, abdominal and concussion injuries. Patients like 28-year-old Artem Dvorskyi, 38-year-old Pavlo Filipchuk and Taras Mykolaichuk share accounts of battlefield rescues and evacuation by quadcopter and armoured vehicles. Capable of withstanding artillery and drone bombs, the 24-hour facility is part of a planned network of 20, praised by national security chiefs as vital for frontline casualty care.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Zelenskyy urges US to expand Russia oil sanctions
articles.trailText: At a meeting with European leaders, the Ukrainian president also discusses the supply of long-range missiles. What we know on day 1,340
articles.summary: During talks in London with EU leaders, President Zelenskyy urged the US to extend oil sanctions beyond Rosneft and Lukoil to the entire Russian sector and requested long-range missiles to strike back. PM Starmer backed bolstering Kyiv’s missile capabilities and rapid use of frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine, while NATO’s Mark Rutte confirmed Tomahawk aid is under US review. Amid fresh Russian drone and missile attacks causing civilian casualties, EU leaders also debated a ceasefire along current front lines as Moscow warned of reprisals.

articles.title: Lithuania shuts airports and Belarus border after weather balloon incursion
articles.trailText: Vilnius and Kaunas airports closed down after balloons drift into country’s airspace for third time this month
articles.summary: Lithuania on Oct 24 closed its two largest airports, Vilnius and Kaunas, until 2 am amid radar detections of “tens of” drifting helium weather balloons—third incursion this month—to prevent smugglers sending Belarusian cigarettes into the EU. Belarus border checkpoints remain shut until Sunday noon. PM Inga Ruginiene said a national security commission will seek measures to punish smugglers and Minsk. Lithuania also reported two brief Russian fighter and tanker incursions, prompting NATO Typhoons and a diplomatic protest after similar July drone violations.

articles.title: Napoleon’s soldiers who died in Russian retreat had unexpected diseases, study finds
articles.trailText: Analysis of DNA from teeth of troops buried in mass grave suggests soldiers had paratyphoid fever and relapsing fever
articles.summary: Researchers analyzing DNA from teeth of 13 Napoleon’s soldiers buried in a Vilnius mass grave used shotgun sequencing to detect, beyond previously identified typhus and trench fever, louse-borne relapsing fever (Borrelia recurrentis) in one soldier and paratyphoid fever (Salmonella enterica) in four, with one case of co-infection. The findings, published in Current Biology, align with historical fever and diarrhea accounts and suggest that, alongside cold, hunger and combat losses, these unexpected infections exacerbated the 1812 Russian retreat’s lethal toll.

articles.title: Ukraine wants US to stay involved, says Zelenskyy after meeting western allies
articles.trailText: Ukrainian leader joined ‘coalition of the willing’ in London to discuss how to ramp up pressure on Russia
articles.summary: In London Zelenskyy met King Charles and PM Starmer before joining 20+ European leaders in a hybrid coalition of the willing, stressing that US involvement — including eventual supply of Tomahawk cruise missiles to complement Storm Shadow and ATACMS — is vital for ending Russia’s war and securing Ukraine’s future. Starmer backed delivering long-range munitions after Kyiv’s Storm Shadow strike on a Russian arms plant. EU ministers again postponed using €140bn in frozen Russian assets as Moscow intensifies winter attacks on energy networks and civilian sites, deepening Ukraine’s humanitarian crisis.

articles.title: Palestinian factions say they agree to let independent technocrat committee run Gaza
articles.trailText: Administration will manage basic services ‘in cooperation with Arab brothers and international institutions’, says joint statement
articles.summary: Main Palestinian factions, including Hamas and Fatah rivals, have agreed in a Cairo meeting to transfer Gaza’s governance to a temporary committee of independent technocrats to manage services with Arab states and international bodies. The groups called to revive the PLO as the Palestinians’ sole representative. Meanwhile, Fadwa Barghouti appealed to Trump for her husband Marwan’s release from an Israeli prison, as the US weighs intervention. US Secretary of State Rubio’s Israel visit focuses on enforcing the Gaza ceasefire with a possible international policing force. WHO warns aid levels remain catastrophic despite a war halt guarantee from mediators.

articles.title: Literature offers insights into the rise of extremism | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to an article by Charlotte Higgins in which she reflects on Sally Carson’s Crooked Cross and its lessons about fascism
articles.summary: Letters reflect on Charlotte Higgins’s analysis of Sally Carson’s Crooked Cross, citing Katharine Burdekin’s 1937 Swastika Night as a prophetic study of toxic masculinity, women’s retreat to traditional roles, and fascism’s self-defeating violence, including predicted Nazi soldier suicides. D. B. Shaw underscores its warning; D. Wolinski parallels Agatha Christie’s Passenger to Frankfurt, likening charismatic extremist rhetoric to modern right-wing leaders. Readers also recommend Julia Boyd & Angelika Patel’s A Village in the Third Reich, Sinclair Lewis’s It Can’t Happen Here, and note Crooked Cross’s Radio 4 serialization.

articles.title: More than £250,000 of counterfeit weight-loss jab products seized in factory raid
articles.trailText: Unlicensed and potentially deadly products seized in Northampton in crackdown on illegal trade
articles.summary: In Northampton, officers from the MHRA and Northamptonshire police raided an industrial estate factory manufacturing counterfeit weight-loss injections, seizing more than 2,000 unlicensed retatrutide and tirzepatide pens, tens of thousands of empty pens, raw chemicals and packaging materials with a street value exceeding £250,000. Retatrutide remains experimental and unauthorized in the UK, while tirzepatide (Mounjaro) is NHS-regulated. Health secretary Wes Streeting and MHRA’s Andy Morling warned consumers against buying unregulated medications online or via illicit channels, citing serious health risks from toxins and contamination, and urged use of licensed obesity drugs under medical supervision.

articles.title: Prosecutor has ‘small hope’ of recovering Louvre jewels thanks to gear left by thieves
articles.trailText: French investigators are analysing DNA samples and fingerprints on tools and other items found at the scene
articles.summary: On 19 October a four-man gang brazenly stole €88 m of 19th-century French crown jewels from the Louvre’s Apollo gallery in under seven minutes, using a ladder-equipped furniture truck, hi-vis vests and disc cutters. In their haste they left a helmet, angle grinders and safety gear, yielding over 150 DNA samples and fingerprints now under analysis. Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau is optimistic that matches in criminal databases could yield leads within days. Investigators from the BRB and cultural-goods unit are probing all angles, including inside help, as they race to recover the gems before they’re dismantled.

articles.title: Bank of England finance chief Afua Kyei tops list of influential black Britons
articles.trailText: Kyei leads Powerlist showcasing black role models across business, science, technology and the arts
articles.summary: Afua Kyei, 43, chief financial officer and executive director at the Bank of England, has been named the UK’s most influential Black Briton in the 2026 Powerlist, which celebrates Black role models across sectors from business to the arts. Appointed CFO by Mark Carney, she replaces tech CEO Dean Forbes and rises from third place. As co-executive sponsor for diversity, equity and inclusion and climate disclosure, Kyei aims to increase Black representation—targeting 10% Black graduate intake by 2028 and 20% minority senior managers. The Powerlist also features Ian Wright, Dame Pat McGrath and Microsoft’s Pamela Maynard.

articles.title: West Bank resistance dies amid fears of becoming Israel’s ‘next Gaza’
articles.trailText: Once known as the ‘martyrs’ capital’ of Palestine, Jenin is now patrolled by Israeli soldiers as weary residents seek quiet life
articles.summary: Once famed as Palestine’s ‘martyrs’ capital,’ Jenin has been sealed off and patrolled by Israeli forces since January���s ‘Iron Wall’ operation, which expelled 14,000 residents and crushed its unified battalion. Daily raids, house-to-house searches, earthen berms and mass arrests—often via administrative detention—have silenced resistance. Weary Jeninites, scarred by past intifadas and haunted by Gaza’s devastation, now prioritize survival amid expanding occupation and rising settler violence, debating quieter forms of resilience as annexation bills loom in the Knesset.

articles.title: Weather tracker: Tornadoes and Storm Benjamin lash northern France
articles.trailText: More than 100,000 homes lose power in heavy rain and strong winds of storm, following fatal tornado near Paris
articles.summary: In northern France a tornado hit Val-d’Oise, toppling cranes and uprooting trees in Ermont, killing one and critically injuring four; a possible tornado struck Dereham, Norfolk, causing property damage. Storm Benjamin then brought yellow-orange alerts to the Paris region, 70 mph gusts, 40 mm rain and power cuts for 100,000+ homes. In Australia a low-pressure system lashed Victoria with 75 mph winds, outages in Melbourne, two surf deaths and a canceled Geelong Cup, as record October heat (39 °C in Sydney) spurred fire bans. Tropical Storm Melissa formed near Haiti/Jamaica, while South Africa sweltered at mid-30s.

articles.title: Two dead and dozens arrested amid Cameroon election crackdown
articles.trailText: Wave of unrest as polling suggests victory in presidential race for 92-year-old incumbent Paul Biya
articles.summary: In Cameroon, security forces killed two—including a teacher struck by stray bullets—and arrested dozens amid protests against 92-year-old president Paul Biya’s expected re-election. Opponent Issa Tchiroma, claiming 54.8% support vs Biya’s 31.3%, denounces electoral malpractice after the Constitutional Council dismissed opposition petitions. Clashes in Garoua and Yaoundé saw tear gas and lethal force; internet blackouts hit Douala and other cities. In Maroua, youths threatened to join Boko Haram over entrenched poverty. Authorities plan military trials for over 20 detainees, while the National Episcopal Conference urges peace.

articles.title: Politics continues by other means as Toronto Blue Jays face LA Dodgers
articles.trailText: International sport takes on new meaning in Canada after Trump’s threat to transform country into US’s ‘51st state’
articles.summary: Canada views the Blue Jays–Dodgers World Series opener as a political and cultural contest. After Trump’s threats to annex Canada, sports symbolize resistance. The Jays, buoyed by prime minister Mark Carney’s taunts and a miraculous win over the Mariners, embody national pride in a hockey nation. Designer Liam Mooney’s “Canada is Not For Sale” hats and viral Celine Dion–scored home-run clips underlined unity. Despite LA’s $509m payroll dwarfing Toronto’s $253m, the underdog Jays rally a nationwide fanbase and honour deep Canadian roots in baseball.

articles.title: Ireland votes for next president as polls predict landslide for Catherine Connolly
articles.trailText: Leftwing independent widely expected to succeed Michael D Higgins, amid concerns about turnout and spoilt ballots
articles.summary: Irish voters are choosing a new president amid predictions of a landslide victory for Catherine Connolly. Polls give the left-wing independent 55% to 35% for Fine Gael’s Heather Humphreys, though sluggish turnout and high spoilt-ballot rates worry observers. Connolly, 68, a former psychologist and barrister from Galway, mobilized young voters with viral podcasts and backing from Sinn Féin, Labour, Greens and others. She champions equality, Irish neutrality and critiques Western militarism. Humphreys, a former cabinet minister, struggled in debates. A Connolly win would rebuke the centre-right government; counting begins Saturday with results due by afternoon.

articles.title: India trials Delhi cloud seeding to clean air in world’s most polluted city
articles.trailText: Bharatiya Janata party launches first test flight as brown haze blankets city after Diwali – but experts decry ‘gimmick’
articles.summary: Delhi regional govt under BJP trials cloud seeding using silver iodide–flares launched Oct 24–aiming to induce artificial rain by Oct 29 to clear hazardous post-Diwali haze in world’s most polluted city. Experts warn effects are modest, rely on existing clouds, and ignore root causes like crop burning, traffic emissions. Professors call it a 'gimmick' likening it to ineffective smog towers and caution on long-term health/agricultural impacts of silver iodide. Delhi’s PM2.5 and PM10 surge each winter, ranking it top polluted city globally, up 6% in 2024.

articles.title: ‘Still work to be done’: Iceland marks 50 years since Women’s Day Off protests
articles.trailText: President says country is not free from feminist backlash being seen around world
articles.summary: On 24 October 1975, 90% of Iceland’s women downed tools and 25,000 marched in Reykjavík in the ’kvennafrí’ strike, sparking five decades of reforms. Today, Iceland has closed over 90% of its gender gap and holds all top national posts—president, prime minister, bishop and police chief—by women. President Halla Tómasdóttir warns that pay disparities, gender-based violence and global feminist backlash persist, urging boys and men to join an “inclusion revolution.” This Friday’s 50th-anniversary strike invites women and non-binary people to a historical walk and rally, with men covering domestic duties.

articles.title: China’s plenum has just finished – here are five key takeaways
articles.trailText: A tech investment surge, child-friendly policies and efforts to work with the US featured at the Chinese Communist party’s political gathering
articles.summary: China’s 4th plenum outlined priorities for its 15th five-year plan: ramping up AI, computing power and high-tech industries (including nuclear fusion), elevating the space sector; calling for US dialogue amid complex geopolitics ahead of Xi–Trump talks; advancing “birth-friendly” policies on childcare, education, elder care and raising retirement age to tackle demographic challenges; continuing a crackdown on “involution” by boosting regional economies, addressing deflation, local debts and youth unemployment; signaling an ongoing anti-corruption drive in the PLA through key personnel changes after low military attendance; and pledging health system improvements to address uneven distribution.

articles.title: Friday briefing: How Plaid beat Reform (and left Labour in Senedd byelection dust)
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Labour has been the largest party in Wales at every general election since 1922. Last night, that history came to an abrupt and painful end – but it was also a disappointing evening for Nigel Farage
articles.summary: In Caerphilly’s October Senedd by-election, Labour—long dominant in Wales—plummeted to third with 11%, while Plaid Cymru’s veteran candidate Lindsay Whittle won 47% against Reform’s 36%. Nigel Farage campaigned but failed to secure victory for Reform. The result signals a dramatic shift: smaller parties on both left and right displacing Labour amid midterm blues, immigration and cost-of-living concerns, and disillusionment with Westminster. Polling suggests Plaid resonates with younger voters, Reform with over-55s. Analysts warn this could reshape May’s Senedd elections and UK politics.

articles.title: Why the climate crisis is especially bad news for frightened flyers
articles.trailText: There are three common types of turbulence – and our volatile atmosphere is making them worse
articles.summary: Climate change is intensifying the three main forms of flight turbulence: clear-air turbulence in the high-altitude jet stream, mountain-wave turbulence from strong winds crossing ranges like the Rockies (impact felt hundreds of miles downstream) and thunderstorm-driven convective turbulence in towering cumulus clouds. Rising atmospheric instability and a more volatile jet stream expose intercontinental flights cruising for fuel efficiency to sudden wind shear and air waves, often invisible in clear skies. The Met Office is refining prediction models to flag high-risk zones; passengers should stay belted when airborne.

articles.title: Putin says he will never bow to US but concedes sanctions may cause ‘some losses’
articles.trailText: China and India likely to scale back Russian oil imports as Trump tries to bring an end to war in Ukraine
articles.summary: Vladimir Putin vows Russia won’t yield to US pressure but admits new sanctions on energy giants Rosneft and Lukoil could inflict “some losses”. The US targeted nearly 36 subsidiaries to choke oil revenues funding the Ukraine war, while the EU phases in an LNG embargo and blacklists two Chinese refiners. Early signs show India’s Reliance and China’s state firms pausing Russian crude imports. Moscow warns of price spikes and promises tough retaliation, even as analysts note Russia’s “shadow fleet��� could adapt to evade restrictions.

articles.title: In the depths of the ocean, a new contest between the US and China emerges
articles.trailText: Around the Cook Islands, the world’s two most powerful countries are exploring the possibility of deep-sea mining for critical minerals
articles.summary: Amid surging demand for cobalt, nickel and manganese, the US and China are jostling over polymetallic nodules offshore the Cook Islands. This Pacific nation—prohibiting mining but granting exploration licences—hosts US mapping missions (backed by a $250,000 aid package and a controversial Trump order) and a Chinese seabed research agreement. Both powers eye the rich Clarion-Clipperton zone as land reserves dwindle. Commercial mining remains untested, opposed by 38 countries and scientists who warn of seismic damage, sediment plumes and fragile ecosystem collapse. With the US outside UNCLOS and China pledging compliance, local stakeholders call for rigorous independent oversight to protect their vast marine territory.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Lithuania accuses Russia of further Nato airspace violation
articles.trailText: Eurofighters scramble after incursion by fighter and tanker; Russian anti-tank drone kills two Ukrainian journalists at petrol station. What we know on day 1,339
articles.summary: Lithuania accused Russia of a NATO airspace breach after a Sukhoi SU-30 and IL-78 tanker flew 700m into its airspace for 18 seconds, prompting Typhoon fighter scrambles; Moscow denies the incursion. In Ukraine, a Russian Lancet drone strike at a Kramatorsk petrol station killed two state TV journalists, sparking a war crime probe. Ukrainian partisans sabotaged power lines to the occupied Zaporizhzhia plant to thwart Russia’s grid tie-in. Kyiv also claimed drone hits on Russia’s Ryazan refinery and a Belgorod ammo depot. In Brussels, Zelenskiy pressed EU leaders to unlock frozen Russian assets, while Starmer announced plans to accelerate and supply over 5,000 air-defence missiles to Ukraine.

articles.title: Is it a critical mineral or a Tolkien invention? Take the Guardian’s nerdiest quiz yet
articles.trailText: Do you know your ores from your orcs? Your rare earths versus Middle-earth? Test your knowledge here …
articles.summary: Guardian Australia's latest quiz challenges users to distinguish between the jargon of modern mining and the fantasy of Tolkien's universe. It presents a list of obscure critical minerals—often sounding like Elvish artifacts—and invites participants to pick which are real rare-earth elements and which hail from Middle-earth. The interactive quiz features names such as xenotime, mithril, coltan and orichalcum, testing both your geology savvy and your Tolkien trivia. Whether you're more at home in the lab or the library, this nerdy face-off between ores and orcs will prove whether you truly know your minerals from your Middle-earth lore.

articles.title: EU leaders fail to agree to use frozen Russian assets to defend Ukraine
articles.trailText: Belgium derails proposal to use billions located in Brussels to fund €140bn loan to Ukraine for its war effort
articles.summary: At its Brussels summit EU leaders declined to commit to tapping €183 bn of Russian central bank assets immobilized at Euroclear for a proposed €140 bn reparation loan to Ukraine, after Belgium objected to liability guarantees and unanimity concerns. Instead they merely tasked the European Commission with exploring financial support options without explicit reference to frozen Russian funds. Presidents Zelenskyy pressed for swift action to fund Ukraine’s defence, while von der Leyen and Costa said the loan principle was agreed but technicalities remain. The issue returns in December.

articles.title: Vance says Knesset votes on annexing West Bank are an ‘insult’ as Netanyahu halts progress
articles.trailText: US vice-president suggests votes were ‘stupid political stunt’ as Israeli PM orders a stop to any further work on bills
articles.summary: After preliminary Knesset approval of West Bank annexation bills, PM Netanyahu halted further progress following US Vice-President JD Vance’s condemnation as an “insult” and assertion that Trump policy forbids annexation. A US delegation, including Marco Rubio, warned annexation would jeopardize the Gaza ceasefire and US support, while a dozen Arab and Muslim states condemned the move. Trump reiterated the red line and floated releasing Palestinian leader Marwan Barghouti. Meanwhile, Israel’s far-right government accelerated settlement expansion and settler violence.

articles.title: ‘Bibi-sitting’: US heavy-hitters take turns to supervise Israeli prime minister
articles.trailText: Marco Rubio warns Israeli politicians not to disrupt Gaza ceasefire after Knesset vote to annex West Bank
articles.summary: In October 2025 the White House dispatched envoys Steve Witkoff, Jared Kushner, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, and VP JD Vance to Israel to pressure PM Benjamin Netanyahu and right-wing Knesset factions against disrupting the fragile Gaza ceasefire or annexing the West Bank. Two bills asserting Israeli sovereignty over occupied territory passed narrowly, prompting public rebukes warning of a US–Israel rift, potential military aid suspension, and Arab states’ condemnation. Critics dub the oversight “Bibi-sitting,” as Trump vows US backing hinges on preserving the ceasefire and two-state prospects.

articles.title: Ukrainian attack spoiled planned Zaporizhzhia birthday gift for Putin
articles.trailText: Plan to connect nuclear plant to Russian grid was foiled and it has now been reconnected to Ukrainian power
articles.summary: In early October, Russian occupiers planned to link Zaporizhzhia NPP to the Russian grid as a birthday gift for Putin, but Ukrainian partisans sabotaged a new high-voltage connection on 6 October. After 30 days relying on diesel generators to cool its six cold-shutdown reactors, engineers on 23 October restored external power via a repaired 750 kV line to Ukrainian territory under an IAEA-brokered ceasefire. The IAEA confirmed reconnection, averting a slow-motion Fukushima-style crisis, while Ukraine accuses Russia of self-sabotage to force a switch to its grid.

articles.title: Louvre thieves’ slow-motion getaway using furniture lift was caught on video
articles.trailText: Footage showing two men appears to have been filmed from nearby window in museum
articles.summary: A verified 36-second clip shows two men in black—one in a yellow hi-vis vest and one in a motorcycle helmet—descending on a stolen furniture lift from the Louvre’s Apollo gallery and fleeing on scooters with €88 million (£76 million) of crown jewels, including Napoleon I’s emerald-diamond necklace and Empress Eugénie’s diadem. The raid began at 9.30 am via a smashed window and disc cutters and lasted under seven minutes. Interior minister Laurent Nuñez has deployed over 100 investigators after museum director Laurence des Cars admitted “highly insufficient” external camera coverage.

articles.title: Palestine rights group seeks prosecution of UK citizens who fought for Israel
articles.trailText: Highly unusual court application alleges more than 10 individuals breached foreign enlistment laws
articles.summary: International Centre for Justice for Palestinians has filed a private prosecution under section 4 of the Foreign Enlistment Act 1870, alleging that over ten British nationals voluntarily enlisted in the Israel Defense Forces to fight a state (Palestine) at peace with the UK. The ICJP lodged a summons against one named individual in a magistrates’ court while withholding other names to avoid prejudicing evidence. It contends Israel’s military operations in Gaza and the West Bank constitute a war against all Palestinians, claims Palestine is a UK-recognized state, and argues waging such a war breaches UK enlistment laws. The group cites recent International Court of Justice advisory opinions on Israel’s occupation of East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza to bolster its case. The prosecution must prove UK nationality, IDF engagement, a state of war between Israel and Palestine, and Palestine’s peace with the UK.

articles.title: Irish police brace for more unrest at Dublin hotel housing asylum seekers
articles.trailText: Gardaí deployed at Citywest facility as police issue statement urging people to stay away from violent standoff
articles.summary: Irish police at Citywest hotel in Saggart, SW Dublin, braced for renewed clashes as anti-immigration activists threw fireworks, missiles and set a police vehicle ablaze this week after an alleged sexual assault by an asylum seeker. A heavy Garda presence—300 officers, riot squads, dogs, horses and water cannon—remained on standby. Authorities arrested sixteen and urged community leaders to steer youths away from violence. Taoiseach Micheál Martin condemned the disorder as part of a rising trend of anti-refugee protests across Ireland and Britain.

articles.title: Colombia urges US to halt strikes on alleged drug-smuggling boats: ‘It is murder’
articles.trailText: Plea comes after Pete Hegseth announced two new strikes that left at least five people dead
articles.summary: Colombian foreign ministry and President Gustavo Petro condemned US airstrikes on vessels alleged to traffic drugs in the Pacific and Caribbean—the first Pacific strikes killed at least five and bring nine strikes since September with 37 dead—to cease operations they call illegal “murder.” The US, framing the campaign as counternarcotics against Venezuelan cartels, has deployed destroyers, F-35s, a submarine and troops in the Caribbean. Mexico’s president also criticised the raids. Experts warn the strikes, hitting low-level smugglers, won’t dent drug flows, and Trump has threatened land strikes next.

articles.title: Brazilian president will seek fourth term at age 80: ‘I’ve got as much energy as when I was 30’
articles.trailText: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who first ran for elected office in 1982, announced he will run again in next year’s election
articles.summary: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, about to turn 80, has declared he’ll seek a historic fourth term in Brazil’s October 2026 election, which could extend his tenure to 16 years. First elected in 2002 after earlier unsuccessful bids—he first ran in 1982—Lula’s stamina and sharpness are touted by his biographer amid comparisons with aging leaders elsewhere. With Jair Bolsonaro jailed and the right in disarray, polls show Lula leading contenders like São Paulo governor Tarcísio de Freitas. Failed US tariffs under Trump even strengthened his position ahead of looming Lula-Trump talks.

articles.title: Will US sanctions on Russian oil companies be effective, and why is Trump imposing them now?
articles.trailText: Measures against Rosneft and Lukoil mark first time US has imposed sanctions on Russia since Trump’s return to office
articles.summary: On 23 Oct, the Trump administration imposed its first Russia sanctions of his second term, targeting Rosneft and Lukoil—responsible for nearly half of Russia’s crude exports—by freezing their US assets, banning US dealings, and threatening secondary sanctions on banks handling Russian oil in China, India and Turkey. The US Treasury cites funding for Putin’s war in Ukraine; EU and UK have imposed parallel measures. Early reports show India and China halting imports, but experts doubt Moscow can’t reroute trade. Impact hinges on enforcement. Debates rage over seizing frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine and approving allies’ long-range missiles, while Putin endures economic pain.

articles.title: ‘Quiet as a whisper’: German firm  launches ad campaign after lift used in Louvre heist
articles.trailText: After watching the news about the Paris robbery, managers at Böcker decided to make the most of the publicity
articles.summary: Family-owned German firm Böcker turned the notoriety of its Agilo furniture lift—used by thieves to scale a Louvre window, steal €88m (£76m) of Napoleonic jewels and flee in under 10 minutes—into a cheeky ad campaign on Facebook and Instagram. With the tagline “When you need to move fast…as quiet as a whisper,” the campaign launched within 24 hours, boosting reach from 20,000 to 1.7 million and drawing largely positive feedback. Böcker sold the lift in 2020 to a Paris rental outfit, which reported it stolen during a demo. Founded 1958, 600 staff.

articles.title: A rift that took 500 years to repair: King Charles prays with the pope
articles.trailText: Joint prayer in Sistine Chapel is symbolic act of rapprochement between Catholic church and Church of England after centuries of division
articles.summary: King Charles III joined Pope Leo XIV in prayer beneath the Sistine Chapel frescoes, symbolising a historic rapprochement between the Church of England and Roman Catholicism almost 500 years after Henry VIII’s break in 1534. The act, hailed by Westminster Abbey theologian Jamie Hawkey and historian Catherine Pepinster, follows decades of thawing ties—royal visits to Rome, the 2013 Succession to the Crown Act easing, and Charles’s attendance at Catholic ceremonies—and marks the first time a British monarch has knelt with the pope, signaling a healing of centuries-old mutual suspicion despite enduring doctrinal differences.

articles.title: Donald Trump says Australia will get the Aukus submarines – but the decision won’t be his to make
articles.trailText: If the US navy needs the subs, they cannot be sold to Australia, regardless of how much the president might wish it
articles.summary: Donald Trump’s vow that “they’re getting” Virginia-class nuclear-powered submarines under the AUKUS pact overlooks constitutional and statutory constraints: presidents limited to two terms (Trump leaves in 2029), and by law any sale in 2032 must be certified at least 270 days beforehand that US undersea capabilities won’t be degraded. With the US fleet at 49 of a 66-boat goal and Virginia-class build rates at 1.13/year (vs 2.33 needed for Australia), the navy will likely retain boats. Australia also lacks infrastructure—crewing, maintenance, nuclear-waste storage—and must demonstrate domestic capacity before transfer. Political pledges belie AUKUS’s substantial strategic, industrial and legal hurdles.

articles.title: French coastguards demand halt to ‘deadly plans’ to intercept small boats
articles.trailText: Union says UK-French Channel deal is inhumane and contravenes international conventions
articles.summary: French coastguards’ union Solidaires Douanes has urged the suspension of a UK-France Channel plan to intercept small boats up to 300m off the French coast, calling it “deadly” and in breach of international conventions. In a letter to customs chief Florian Colas, they warned interceptions risk shipwrecks and deaths. The Home Office confirms France is reviewing its new “maritime doctrine,” while UK officials, including border security chief Martin Hewitt, express frustration at delays. Observers say the tactic may never be implemented, and a police union says it’s on hold. Meanwhile, the UK’s “one in, one out” repatriation already suffered setbacks after an Iranian asylum seeker returned by small boat.

articles.title: Latest EU sanctions against Russia target liquefied natural gas
articles.trailText: Measures also add 117 shadow fleet vessels to list of those suspected of illegal oil shipments and banned from ports
articles.summary: The EU's 19th sanctions package against Russia introduces, for the first time, a phased ban on Russian liquefied natural gas imports, aiming to halt all LNG trade by January 2027. It also blacklists 117 additional ‘shadow fleet’ vessels—bringing the total to 558 ships barred from EU ports and insurance—to enforce the G7 oil price cap. New rules restrict Russian diplomats’ intra-EU travel. Adopted after Slovakia lifted its veto and alongside US sanctions on Rosneft and Lukoil, the measures underscore EU solidarity with Ukraine, even as debates continue over using €140bn of frozen Russian assets to fund Kyiv.

articles.title: Catherine Connolly: the outspoken leftwinger set to be Ireland’s next president
articles.trailText: Independent candidate’s smooth campaign has enthused younger voters but views on Nato and Hamas may concern European allies
articles.summary: Independent leftwinger Catherine Connolly, a former barrister and clinical psychologist turned independent TD, is poised to become Ireland’s next president, leading Heather Humphreys by wide margins. Her campaign, fueled by youth anger over housing and cost-of-living crises, deft social-media outreach and backing from Labour, Sinn Féin and other left parties, has resonated at Vicar Street rallies. Yet her radical stances—opposing NATO, criticizing EU treaties and describing Hamas as part of Palestinian identity—alarm some European allies, and low turnout and spoilt-ballot rates threaten legitimacy despite the presidency’s largely ceremonial role.

articles.title: Is Shell to blame for a ‘super typhoon’? Philippines survivors to sue oil giant in legal first
articles.trailText: Typhoon Rai killed more than 400, displaced nearly 3.2 million, and destroyed more than a million homes in 2021
articles.summary: Trixy Elle and 66 fellow survivors of 2021’s Super Typhoon Rai (Odette), which killed 400+, displaced 3.2 million and wrecked over 1 million homes in the Philippines, have issued a letter before action to Shell in the UK, demanding compensation and injunctive relief. In a global first, they’ll file a UK high court suit in December, alleging Shell’s decades-long CO₂ emissions and climate disinformation intensified Rai’s impact, violating their constitutional right to a healthy environment. Backed by attribution science from Imperial College and a Philippine Human Rights probe, the case argues Shell knew fossil fuels’ harms yet expanded operations and concealed risks, seeking accountability for past injuries.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: While the ceasefire holds, Gaza continues to starve
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: With most border crossings remaining closed and aid deliveries falling catastrophically short, will the International Court of Justice’s ruling force change for those left behind?
articles.summary: After the ICJ ruled Israel the occupying power in Gaza and the West Bank, it ordered cooperation with UN aid agencies and warned against using starvation as a weapon. A fragile ceasefire has enabled hostage exchanges and modest aid increases—but with only two crossings open, deliveries remain far below the 2,000-tonne daily target. Gaza faces a man-made famine: soaring food prices, widespread malnutrition, water shortages and a power vacuum driven by Israeli restrictions. Eyad Amawi reports desperate needs for nourishment, heavy machinery to clear rubble and tents for the displaced.

articles.title: Wildfires have consumed vast chunks of Ukraine. Is Russia deliberately fuelling the flames?
articles.trailText: In 2024, nearly a million hectares of Ukraine’s land burned. Heat, mines and shelling contributed, but footage of drones targeting firefighters has raised the question of war crimes
articles.summary: In 2024 nearly a million hectares of Ukraine burned—more than twice the EU’s total—mainly along frontline forests in Kharkiv, Donetsk and Zaporizhzhia. Hot, dry conditions, stray mines and unexploded ordnance from Russia’s invasion sparked hundreds of low-intensity fires. Satellite and video analysis shows Russian drones deliberately targeting firefighters and using ‘double-tap’ strikes. Prosecutors are probing these attacks as potential war crimes. Ecologists warn the combined effects of shelling, mines and climate change could delay forest and agricultural recovery by decades.

articles.title: Tens of thousands to attend rival rallies as Hungary’s election campaign kicks off
articles.trailText: Budapest marches by ruling Fidesz party and opposition Tisza will take place in a highly polarised political climate
articles.summary: As Hungary’s election campaign begins for April 2025 polls, Fidesz’s Viktor Orbán and opposition newcomer Péter Magyar will each lead tens-of-thousands-strong rival rallies in Budapest on the 1956 uprising anniversary. Orbán presents a “peace march” amid record inflation, deepening Kremlin ties after a scrapped Trump–Putin meeting and nationalist pledges on migration and Ukraine neutrality. Magyar’s Tisza, neck-and-neck with Fidesz in polls (37% vs 27%), accuses Orbán of state-funded voter shuttles, corruption and media bias, pledges anti-corruption, pro-Ukraine energy diversification after touring 158 towns. Analysts deem the race “free but unfair,” with 25% undecided voters making the outcome unpredictable.

articles.title: New Zealand ‘mega strike’: 100,000 public sector workers demand better conditions
articles.trailText: Teachers, nurses and public service staff among those walking off job and pressing for more government investment in health and education
articles.summary: About 100,000 New Zealand public sector workers—including 60,000 teachers, 40,000 nurses and 15,000 public servants—launched a “mega strike” after collective bargaining stalled, demanding urgent government investment to address pay inequity, unsafe staffing levels and worsening service cuts in health and education. Despite severe weather, nationwide rallies warned of patient harm from hospital overcapacity, long wait times and teacher exodus to Australia. The coalition government dismissed the strike as “politically motivated,” but a Talbot Mills poll showed 65% public support, with opposition parties backing the action.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Ukrainians may get Gripen fighter jets bought with Russian money
articles.trailText: Double dose of Russian oil sanctions from EU and US; freezing war at current frontlines is ‘good compromise’, says Zelenskyy. What we know on day 1,338
articles.summary: Ukraine has agreed to buy up to 150 Swedish Gripen E fighters—built to operate from roads as well as airfields—financed by frozen Russian assets and allied contributions. President Zelenskyy aims to field them next year to complement F-16s and Mirages; analysts highlight Gripen’s advanced radar, electronic-warfare systems and long-range Meteor missiles. In parallel, the EU and US announced fresh oil sanctions on Rosneft, Lukoil and Moscow’s shadow tanker fleet, accelerating an LNG ban to 2027. EU leaders will pledge €140 billion in loans from frozen Russian funds. Zelenskyy favors freezing frontlines as a ‘good compromise’ while Russia’s drones and missiles continue striking Kyiv.

articles.title: What is South Korea’s ‘monster missile’, and what does it mean for relations with the North?
articles.trailText: The Hyunmoo-5 ‘bunker buster’ missile can reportedly carry an eight-tonne warhead and will be ready for deployment at the end of the year
articles.summary: South Korea will deploy at year-end its largest conventional missile, the Hyunmoo-5 “monster missile,” a 36-tonne, 16m long surface-to-surface “bunker buster” capable of carrying an 8-ton warhead and striking targets 600–5,000km away. Developed after 2010 North Korean attacks and enabled by lifted US payload limits, it aims to achieve a “balance of terror” under the NPT and bolster self-reliant defense under President Lee. The move follows North Korea’s Hwasong-20 ICBM unveiling, may deter but risk further regional escalation. Seoul spends 1.4 times North Korea’s GDP on defense yearly and ranks fifth globally, with arms exports surging post-Ukraine war.

articles.title: ICJ orders Israel to allow aid into Gaza and says restrictions breached international obligations
articles.trailText: UN’s top court also finds Israel failed to justify blocking Unrwa and other relief agencies
articles.summary: The ICJ advisory opinion found Israel’s two-year blockade on Gaza violated the UN Charter and Geneva Conventions, ordering unimpeded humanitarian access via UNRWA and NGOs, deeming starvation as a prohibited method of warfare, and requiring respect for UN immunities and property. It dismissed Israeli claims that UNRWA was compromised, highlighted catastrophic civilian casualties and deaths of aid workers, and ruled Israel must cooperate in good faith. Israel rejected the findings. Norway plans a UN General Assembly resolution; some states may seek damages for breaches of UN immunities.

articles.title: Louvre director acknowledges ‘terrible failure’ after €88m jewel heist
articles.trailText: Laurence des Cars questioned by senators about daring daytime break-in at Paris museum
articles.summary: Laurence des Cars, director of Paris’s Louvre, called the €88m daytime jewel heist a “terrible failure” after four men used a truck-mounted ladder and hoist to enter the Apollo gallery via a balcony, cut a window, and steal gems in seven minutes. She admitted “highly insufficient” security camera coverage on exterior walls before senators criticized perimeter vulnerabilities and slow response. Although alarms triggered and guards prevented the escape van’s destruction—preserving evidence—a diamond-and-emerald crown was damaged. Des Cars offered her resignation, which was refused, and defended the museum’s €80m security plan. President Macron has ordered faster installation of full façade video surveillance and an internal police post.

articles.title: ‘Hogwash’ that Israel is a US client state, says Netanyahu
articles.trailText: Israeli PM dismisses claim despite Washington providing estimated 68% of country’s foreign-sourced weapons
articles.summary: Israel’s PM Benjamin Netanyahu on Oct 22 rejected as “hogwash�� suggestions that Israel is a US client state despite Washington supplying 68% of its foreign arms, asserting an alliance of equals during talks with US VP J.D. Vance in Jerusalem. Vance echoed this, rejecting vassal-state claims amid a fragile Gaza ceasefire. The US is pushing to disarm Hamas and rebuild Gaza, debating Turkey’s role. Meanwhile, the ICJ urged Israel to readmit UNRWA in Gaza and the Knesset preliminarily approved a West Bank sovereignty bill, risking US red lines. Ceasefire violations and hostage-body exchanges highlight ongoing tensions.

articles.title: Zelenskyy calls Trump’s proposal to freeze war at current frontlines ‘good compromise’
articles.trailText: US president’s remark seen as modest win for Ukrainian leader, who acknowledges Russia will not accept proposal
articles.summary: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy backed former US president Donald Trump’s plan to freeze the war at current frontlines, calling it “a good compromise,” while warning Moscow would reject it. Trump, who has fluctuated on ceasefires and peace negotiations, floated the proposal before postponing a potential summit with Vladimir Putin. Russia’s hardline leadership, represented by Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, swiftly dismissed the idea, reiterating demands to control the Donbas and reshape Ukraine’s sovereignty. Meanwhile, Russian forces have intensified missile and drone strikes on Ukrainian cities and conducted strategic nuclear drills.

articles.title: As the US flip-flops on the path to peace, Europe’s ‘coalition of the willing’ rallies round Ukraine
articles.trailText: From unanimity on a reparations loan to the unpredictability of Trump, EU leaders will gather this week with agreement on ending the war still fraught with hurdles
articles.summary: Amid President Trump’s oscillating Ukraine policy—first endorsing Kyiv’s territorial recovery, then urging Zelenskyy to cede land after consulting Putin—Ukraine and ten EU states have formed a “coalition of the willing.” Ahead of Brussels and London summits, they backed an immediate ceasefire along current lines, a 12-point peace roadmap and an interest-free €140 billion reparations loan sourced from Russian frozen assets. Persisting hurdles include the need for unanimous EU sanctions renewals (blocked by Hungary and Slovakia) and stalled EU accession talks due to Orbán’s veto.

articles.title: The Louvre’s new must-see? The broken window smashed by thieves in €88m jewel heist
articles.trailText: Visitors flock to visit Paris museum as it reopens, but some are more interested in evidence of Sunday’s dramatic robbery than the art works inside
articles.summary: The Louvre reopened after Sunday’s €88 m Napoleonic jewellery heist in its Apollo gallery, but visitors queueing for the Mona Lisa detoured to inspect the smashed window thieves—disguised in hi-vis vests—used with an extendable ladder and disc cutters. In under four minutes they fled on motorbikes with eight pieces, including Marie-Louise’s emerald-diamond necklace and Empress Eugénie’s diadem. With 100 investigators probing possible security lapses amid staff cuts, Interior Minister Laurent Nuñez vows swift progress and President Macron orders reinforced protections.

articles.title: Letter: Jenny Cox obituary
articles.trailText: Stephen Cox writes: I discovered that my mother was not allowed to do her botany research on South Georgia because of a letter from Vivian Fuchs
articles.summary: Stephen Cox reveals that in a newly released letter dated 7 October 1959, Sir Vivian Fuchs barred his mother, botanist Jenny Cox, from conducting her PhD field research on South Georgia solely because she was a woman. Fuchs offered UK-based laboratory work on existing Antarctic specimens but insisted no women could endure the island’s harsh conditions or lodging. That gender-biased policy, common among mid-20th-century Antarctic explorers, effectively ended Cox’s career in polar botany. Despite this setback, Jenny Cox persevered, building a legacy of resilience and demonstrating how to forge new paths when institutional barriers arise.

articles.title: Louvre jewel heist: other daring art thefts from the museum
articles.trailText: How the Guardian reported the stealing of art works from the Paris museum including the Mona Lisa in 1911
articles.summary: From the 1911 theft of da Vinci’s Mona Lisa—purloined by Louvre handyman Vincenzo Peruggia and recovered in Florence in 1913—to the 1939 disappearance of Watteau’s L’Indifférent, the 1946 burglary of Second Empire jewels, the twin 1990 daylight raids that saw a Renoir and a Hebert portrait cut from their frames, and the 1998 Corot heist of Le chemin de Sèvres, the Louvre has weathered repeated breaches. Each incident exposed security lapses—from hoax theories and guard shortages to failed alarms—and spurred major overhauls in surveillance, staffing and artifact protection.

articles.title: Children among six killed in Kyiv after Russian missile and drone attack
articles.trailText: Strikes, involving over 400 drones and 28 missiles, launched hours after Putin-Trump meeting in Budapest cancelled
articles.summary: Overnight Russian forces unleashed a sustained barrage—more than 400 Shahed drones and 28 missiles—on Kyiv and other Ukrainian cities hours after a planned Putin–Trump meeting in Budapest was abruptly cancelled. The attack killed six civilians, including a six-month-old baby and a 12-year-old girl, and struck a Kharkiv kindergarten, a hospital and multiple high-rise residential blocks. Key energy facilities were damaged, triggering rolling blackouts and leaving thousands without heat or power. President Zelenskyy condemned the strikes as terrorism, while Ukraine reported retaliatory Storm Shadow missile and drone raids on Bryansk and Mordovia in Russia.

articles.title: Jewish figures across the globe call on UN and world leaders to sanction Israel
articles.trailText: Exclusive: In an open letter, Israeli ex-officials, artists and intellectuals say ‘unconscionable’ actions in Gaza amount to genocide
articles.summary: Over 450 Jewish figures worldwide—former Israeli officials (Avraham Burg, Daniel Levy), artists (Michael Rosen, Naomi Klein, Ilana Glazer), Oscar and Pulitzer winners—have penned an open letter to the UN and world leaders urging targeted sanctions, arms‐embargoes, and enforcement of ICJ/ICC rulings against Israel, accusing its Gaza, West Bank and East Jerusalem operations of genocide. They call for humanitarian aid, reject antisemitism charges, cite US and EU polling on war crimes perceptions, and demand an end to occupation and apartheid. They highlight Gaza’s toll (65,000+ killed, 167,000 injured, 90% displaced) and urge world to uphold safeguards born from Holocaust lessons.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: Making sense of the Maccabi Tel Aviv saga, where law and disorder fumbled with fandom
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Inside a tortuous political saga where fandom and antisemitism once again became a political football
articles.summary: In a protracted saga, Birmingham’s safety advisory group, backed by West Midlands police, banned Maccabi Tel Aviv fans from attending their away match at Aston Villa after citing the club’s history of football violence—including 2023 Amsterdam clashes—and fears of extremist opportunism, notably Tommy Robinson supporters. UK politicians condemned the ban as antisemitic, but Maccabi ultimately declined any ticket allocation, citing “hate-filled falsehoods” and unacceptable risks to fan safety. The episode spotlights tensions between hazard-based policing decisions, political interference, and debates over antisemitism versus legitimate security assessments.

articles.title: ‘They can’t dismiss Leo so easily’: how the pope has confounded conservatives
articles.trailText: As pontiff prepares for visit of King Charles, the contours of his papacy are slowly becoming apparent
articles.summary: First North American pope Leo XIV, ahead of King Charles’s Vatican visit, is consolidating his predecessor Francis’s priorities on migration, climate and poverty. Though he has adopted traditional papal formalities—red mozzetta, Latin Mass—and held private meetings with conservative cardinals, his measured pronouncements urge US bishops to oppose inhuman migration policies, denounce hunger as a weapon of war and endorse bold climate action. His inaugural exhortation Dilexi te decries inequality and economic “dictatorship,” prompting conservative Catholics to label him the “woke pope.”

articles.title: JD Vance expresses ‘great optimism’ over Gaza ceasefire deal during Israel visit
articles.trailText: US vice-president to visit Netanyahu while Hamas joins talks in Cairo meant to iron out differences
articles.summary: US VP JD Vance toured southern Israel, met envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, and held talks with PM Netanyahu, declaring “great optimism” that the 10-October Gaza ceasefire is “durable” despite 80 Israeli breaches, 26 Palestinian and two Israeli combatant deaths. Concurrent Cairo negotiations with Hamas target disarmament clauses and formation of a technocratic Gaza authority. Sticking points include return of 13 remaining hostage bodies, stalled aid—986 of 6,600 trucks delivered—and Israel’s insistence on full Hamas demilitarisation before reconstruction. Qatar’s emir condemned settlement expansion, while aid agencies warn deliveries remain below a third of needs, risking famine in northern Gaza.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Storm Shadow missiles ‘hit gunpowder plant in Russia’
articles.trailText: Russians confirm attack on Bryansk region home to explosives factory; Trump-Putin talks shelved, US diplomacy ‘going in circles’. What we know on day 1,337
articles.summary: Ukraine's military said Britain-France Storm Shadow cruise missiles breached Russian air defenses to strike a gunpowder, explosives and rocket-fuel plant in Bryansk region, confirmed by Moscow. Concurrent Russian drone and missile raids on Kyiv killed two, damaged infrastructure and spurred secondary drone waves; Zaporizhzhia, Dnipro and Izmail were also hit. Diplomatic efforts stalled: a planned Trump-Putin Budapest summit was shelved after fruitless Rubio-Lavrov talks, while U.S. and European mediators draw up a ceasefire along current frontlines with a proposed Trump-chaired peace board. In Ukraine's north, Russian kamikaze drones killed four in Novhorod-Siverskyi and strikes plunged Chernihiv region into power outages.

articles.title: ‘A perfect coincidence’: rare red lightning captured in New Zealand skies
articles.trailText: The extremely unusual phenomenon – also known as red lightning – lasts for a millisecond and is rarely visible to the naked eye
articles.summary: On 11 October, New Zealand photographer Tom Rae and Spanish colleagues Dan Zafra and José Cantabrana unexpectedly captured rare ‘red sprites’ – millisecond-long crimson lightning flashes shooting upward from thunderstorms – while aiming to photograph the Milky Way over South Island’s Ōmārama Clay cliffs. Red sprites, first accidentally recorded in 1989, form carrot- or jellyfish-like columns high in the upper atmosphere and are invisible to the naked eye. This marks perhaps the only frame combining southern-hemisphere Milky Way panoramas with a red sprite display, a feat requiring split-second timing and expert astrophotography.

articles.title: Dublin police condemn ‘thuggery��� after protest outside hotel housing asylum seekers turns violent
articles.trailText: Six arrests made after crowd hurled fireworks and other missiles at officers during protests following alleged sexual assault on a young girl
articles.summary: Up to 2,000 people gathered outside the Citywest hotel in south-west Dublin���used to house asylum seekers—on Tuesday night, following news that a 26-year-old asylum seeker was charged with allegedly sexually assaulting a 10-year-old girl. Protesters burned a Garda van and hurled bricks, bottles, fireworks and traffic cones at officers, prompting six arrests. Commissioner Justin Kelly called it ‘thuggery,’ while Justice Minister Jim O’Callaghan and Taoiseach Micheál Martin condemned the violence. Tusla said the victim, in state care, had absconded earlier. The unrest reflects growing far-right anti-immigrant sentiment.

articles.title: Kosovo offers to become first country to accept Britain’s refused asylum seekers
articles.trailText: However, Kosovo is an outlier in the region, whose other leaders say ‘looking for places to dump immigrants’ is evidence the UK is in ‘a very dark place’
articles.summary: Kosovo prime minister Albin Kurti has offered to host refused UK asylum seekers in ‘return hubs’ abroad, holding talks with British officials to transfer failed claimants once appeals are exhausted. In exchange, Kosovo seeks security assistance, strategic agreements and equipment. Balkan neighbours are divided: Albania’s PM Edi Rama condemned Britain for ‘dumping immigrants’, Bosnia and Herzegovina rejected the idea, Montenegro is open only with significant UK infrastructure investment. Ahead of a London summit, Labour leader Keir Starmer proposes a western Balkans migration taskforce deploying drones to curb illegal crossings. Refugee charities warn of punitive detention’s ineffectiveness and fear-driven compliance.

articles.title: US shelves plans for Trump-Putin talks in Budapest
articles.trailText: White House says there are now no plans for summit ‘in the immediate future’ as latest efforts to end Ukraine war falter
articles.summary: Washington shelved a planned Trump–Putin summit in Budapest after last week’s diplomacy produced no breakthrough on Ukraine. The White House said there are “no plans” for an immediate meeting following stalled talks between Secretary of State Rubio and Foreign Minister Lavrov, who reaffirmed Russia’s demand for unchanged territorial terms. Trump, unwilling to risk a “wasted meeting,” rejected ceding Donetsk. Kyiv and its Western allies, including the UK, France and Germany, now push a ceasefire on existing frontlines, back a 12-point proposal and eye using frozen Russian assets (€140 bn) to fund Ukraine’s defence from 2026.

articles.title: Black History Month now year-round event at Fulham Palace as it addresses its past
articles.trailText: Museum wants to confront history of ‘bishops of the colonies’ and their involvement in slavery
articles.summary: At Fulham Palace Trust, CEO Siân Harrington turned Black History Month into a year-round initiative, confronting the colonial and slavery roles of the bishops of London. After George Floyd’s death, the museum joined Black History 365 and reconfigured permanent displays with the Resistance exhibition on anti-slavery movements. It applied to be an anti-racist museum and plans a permanent show on how plant collecting facilitated land seizures. Recently it hosted tapestry panels on Black Britons, freely exhibited then set to tour, and will commission new tapestries on Roman Africans and the 60th Notting Hill Carnival.

articles.title: Louvre heist losses put at almost €90m as museum’s head prepares to face senators
articles.trailText: Police continue to search for the criminal gang behind the brazen robbery targeting France’s crown jewels
articles.summary: France’s Louvre estimates the Oct 19 brazen seven-minute heist of eight Napoleonic jewels at €88m–€90m. Museum president Laurence des Cars will face the senate’s culture committee over security flaws—window breach, display-case quality, absence of rapid-response unit—while culture minister Rachida Dati defends CCTV and plans further security upgrades. Investigators from the Paris prosecutor’s BRB and the central agency for trafficking in cultural property recovered DNA from a hi-vis vest, a stolen crown and other trace evidence. The museum has remained closed for three days, and its reopening remains uncertain. With no external insurer, the French state self-insures the national museum’s losses.

articles.title: Nicolas Sarkozy enters prison to begin five-year sentence over criminal conspiracy
articles.trailText: Former president organised stage-managed departure from his Paris home before becoming first French postwar leader to be jailed
articles.summary: Nicolas Sarkozy, France's rightwing president from 2007–12, began a five-year prison term for criminal conspiracy in a scheme to secure Gaddafi regime funds, becoming the first French postwar head of state jailed. He staged a departure from his Paris home with wife Carla Bruni and children, has appealed the verdict and awaits an appeals court decision that could grant supervised release. Held in solitary at La Santé with basic amenities, Sarkozy plans to write and denounces his sentence as a “judicial scandal.”

articles.title: Case of a single ballot that decided a vote in Canada sparks uproar
articles.trailText: Legal teams are midway through a hearing over whether one vote truly swayed a federal election in a Montreal suburb
articles.summary: Quebec courts are hearing arguments on whether a single miscounted ballot should void the April federal result in Terrebonne, north of Montreal. After an administrative error and recount, Liberal Tatiana Auguste was declared winner over incumbent Bloc Québécois MP Nathalie Sinclair-Desgagné by one vote.
