articles.trailText: When 50 men went on trial in France, accused of raping a woman who had been drugged by her husband, Manon Garcia was in the courtroom – and in the prosecutors’ closing arguments. How does she make sense of what happened?
articles.summary: In Avignon, feminist philosopher Manon Garcia attended the trial of 50 men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot, drugged by her husband. With 20,000 photos and videos, prosecutors invoked Garcia’s work on consent and chemical submission, featured in her forthcoming book Living With Men. Pelicot, who waived anonymity at 71, faced daily confrontations with her assailants. On appeal, Husamettin Dogan’s sentence rose from nine to ten years after her lawyers barred old sexual images, a potential jurisprudential milestone. Garcia diagnoses a “cultural scaffolding of rape” where perpetrators deny wrongdoing, comparing their banality to Eichmann’s, exposing entitlement to women’s bodies.

articles.title: Portugal’s far-right Chega falls well short of expectations in local elections
articles.trailText: Party hoped to take 30 municipalities but secured three after share of vote halved from parliamentary elections
articles.summary: Portugal’s six-year-old far-right Chega party, campaigning on nationalist policies like stricter immigration controls and chemical castration for paedophiles, fell far short of its 30-municipality target in October’s local elections, winning just three mayoralties—S��o Vicente (49%), Albufeira (40.5%) and Entroncamento (37%)—after its vote share plunged from 23% in May’s parliamentary poll to 11.86%. Leader André Ventura claimed a “great victory” as Chega almost trebled its 2021 local tally but underperformed without him on ballots. The centre-right PSD led with 136 mayoralties (including Lisbon and Porto), Socialists took 128, independents 20 and Communists 12. A presidential election is set for January.

articles.title: ‘An environment of terror’: deadly resurgence of Pakistan Taliban gathers pace
articles.trailText: Surge in militancy in region bordering Afghanistan is now one of greatest security threats facing Islamabad
articles.summary: Pakistan faces one of its gravest security threats from the revived Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP) in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, where militants have executed over 600 attacks this year—targeting police, paramilitary and civilians with bombings, assassinations and extortion. Operating checkpoints, they exploit safe havens across the Afghan border, benefiting from Afghan Taliban’s leniency and advanced weapons including night-vision gear and drones. Islamabad’s cross-border airstrikes have sparked clashes, yet locals warn strikes fuel civilian casualties and mistrust. Political fragmentation, stoked by Imran Khan’s imprisonment, has eroded public trust and aided TTP recruitment, risking spread to Punjab and Sindh.

articles.title: Hamas releases 20 remaining living Israeli hostages after two years in Gaza
articles.trailText: Group handed over to Red Cross as Israeli ministers approve list of more than 1,700 Palestinians for release
articles.summary: Hamas released the final 20 living Israeli hostages, held since Oct 7, 2023, handing them to the Red Cross in Gaza before IDF reunification. Families of Omri Miran and soldier Matan Angrest hailed the return as a victory, thanking Israeli forces and Donald Trump, credited with brokering the deal. Israeli ministers approved freeing 1,718 Palestinian prisoners and returning 28 deceased hostages. Thousands in Tel Aviv’s Hostages Square cheered live broadcasts. President Herzog and PM Netanyahu welcomed the releases; Trump, in Jerusalem, called “the war is over.” The swap initiates a ceasefire and first phase of a 20-point Gaza peace plan.

articles.title: Sharp global rise in antibiotic-resistant infections in hospitals, WHO finds
articles.trailText: Experts describe findings as deeply concerning and predict 70% increase in related deaths by 2050
articles.summary: Hospitals worldwide report a sharp rise in antibiotic-resistant bacterial infections, with one in six confirmed cases resistant in 2023 and over 40% of antibiotics losing potency since 2018. WHO’s Global AMR Surveillance report, covering 23m infections from 104 countries, highlights the worst impact in low/middle-income regions—one in three infections in south-east Asia and the eastern Mediterranean and one in five in Africa are drug-resistant. Resistance exceeds 40% for E coli and 55% for Klebsiella pneumoniae against first-line cephalosporins, with rising carbapenem resistance. Experts warn of a 70% rise in AMR deaths by 2050 and call for targeted new antibiotics, improved surveillance, diagnostics, hygiene and R&D.

articles.title: Monday briefing: How social media is mainstreaming far-right rhetoric
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: It used to be that the far right were set apart from polite society, but it’s easy to find views once seen as extreme on Facebook today. And frontbench politicians are taking note
articles.summary: A Guardian analysis shows far-right views once confined to extremist subcultures have migrated into ordinary Facebook groups, where posts demonize migrants, Muslims and non-white people using coded dog whistles like “grooming gangs” and “military-aged men.” Data projects editor Pamela Duncan mapped networks of admins and moderators whose content echoes historical fascist tropes, conspiracy theories and anti-establishment myths. She finds this rhetoric bleeding into mainstream politics—from Reform’s leaders calling immigration an “invasion” to senior Conservatives lamenting “no white faces.” Experts warn social media’s failure to moderate gives fringe ideas misleading legitimacy when echoed by public figures.

articles.title: Record number of babies born to foreign parents in Japan amid political row over migration
articles.trailText: More than 20,000 children were born to non-Japanese couples, accounting for more than 3% of all newborns
articles.summary: In 2024 Japan recorded 22,878 births to non-Japanese parents—3.2% of newborns, up 50% in a decade—while Japanese births dropped to 686,173, per health ministry. Surging migrant workforce (3.95m legal residents, many aged 20s–30s) fuels this rise, led by Chinese, Filipino and Brazilian mothers, offsetting over half the native decline. The demographic shift has ignited political debate: right-wing parties demand stricter immigration and integration policies, even as business and experts push measures to support foreign families and social cohesion.

articles.title: As Donald Trump heads to Gaza ‘peace summit’ in Egypt, who is going – and who isn’t?
articles.trailText: Trump and Egyptian president Abdel Fatah al-Sisi will co-host a summit of more than 20 world leaders in Sharm El Sheikh
articles.summary: Donald Trump and Egyptian president Abdel Fatah al-Sisi will co-host a Gaza ‘peace summit’ in Sharm el-Sheikh on Oct 13, following Trump’s Israel visit. The meeting aims to end the Gaza war, bolster the ceasefire and advance his 20-point plan for Middle East stability. Over 20 leaders are attending, including Qatar’s emir Sheikh Tamim, Palestinian Authority’s Mahmoud Abbas, EU figures (Macron, Starmer, Sánchez, Meloni, Merz, Mitsotakis), Arab heads (King Abdullah II, Hamad bin Isa), UN’s Guterres, Arab League’s Aboul Gheit and PMs from Canada to Pakistan. Notably absent: Israeli officials, Hamas representatives and Iran.

articles.title: Tony Blair wins nod from Palestinian Authority for role in postwar Gaza
articles.trailText: Senior PA leader confirms readiness to work with former UK PM on post-ceasefire recovery
articles.summary: Former UK prime minister Tony Blair has secured Palestinian Authority endorsement for a role in Gaza’s post-war reconstruction after meeting PA deputy president Hussein al-Sheikh in Amman. Al-Sheikh welcomed cooperation to consolidate a ceasefire, deliver aid, release hostages and rebuild infrastructure, while stressing the need to restore Israeli-withheld PA revenues and uphold a two-state solution. Hamas and PA justice minister Sharhabeel al-Zaeem oppose Blair’s proposed ‘foreign guardian’ board, whose relationship to a technocratic Palestinian committee remains undefined. The US administration, Israeli government and Arab partners must still agree on his mandate and the timing of PA-led elections.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Moscow voices ‘extreme concern’ at Trump threat to send Tomahawk missiles to Kyiv
articles.trailText: US president says he may warn Russian counterpart ‘look, if this war is not going to get settled, I’m going to send them Tomahawks’. What we know on day 1,328
articles.summary: Donald Trump warned Vladimir Putin that if Russia does not end its invasion he may supply long-range Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, following a request from Volodymyr Zelenskiy. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov voiced “extreme concern,” and Belarus’s Alexander Lukashenko questioned the seriousness of the threat. Ukraine’s leadership is awaiting a U.S. decision as a delegation heads to Washington. Meanwhile, Russia stepped up strikes on energy infrastructure, wounding two DTEK employees, as Kyiv presses for tighter secondary sanctions on Russian oil buyers and reports counteroffensive gains in Zaporizhzhia and Donetsk.

articles.title: Israel expects all 20 living hostages to be freed from Gaza on Monday morning
articles.trailText: Government says it is also preparing for release of 2,000 Palestinian detainees in crucial next phase of ceasefire deal
articles.summary: Israel expects all 20 living hostages held in Gaza to be released Monday morning via Red Cross into military custody, followed by the release of about 2,000 Palestinian detainees under the next phase of a US-brokered ceasefire. With 48 hostages still unaccounted for, an international taskforce will search Gaza’s rubble for remains. President Trump will visit Jerusalem and co-chair a Sharm el-Sheikh peace summit. Humanitarian aid into Gaza will resume pre-war levels with 600 daily trucks, while 200 US troops advise stabilization.

articles.title: UK to host international summit on Gaza recovery plan
articles.trailText: Representatives from Palestinian Authority, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Germany and Italy among those to attend conference
articles.summary: The UK will host Wilton Park’s three-day conference from Monday to shape Gaza’s recovery post-ceasefire, emphasizing a Palestinian-led reconstruction with 'absolutely no role for Hamas.' Downing Street shifts £20m of pledged aid to water, sanitation and hygiene via UNICEF, WFP and the Norwegian Refugee Council. PM Keir Starmer joins 20 national leaders, including Donald Trump, in Sharm el-Sheikh discussions aiming for lasting peace. Attendees include the Palestinian Authority, Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Germany, Italy, EBRD, World Bank and private financiers. Foreign Sec. Yvette Cooper highlighted urgency; Education Sec. Bridget Phillipson backed a viable Palestinian state, while Shadow FS Priti Patel downplayed Britain’s role.

articles.title: ‘My heart is broken’: Palestinians begin searching the Gaza rubble for their dead
articles.trailText: Using manual tools and their bare hands, people start the immense task of trying to find their loved ones’ remains
articles.summary: Following the Gaza ceasefire, thousands of Palestinians have returned to northern Gaza, using manual tools and bare hands to search 60m tonnes of rubble for an estimated 10,000 bodies trapped under collapsed buildings. Families like Ghali Khadr, who recovered only skull shards of his parents after two days of sifting debris, face destroyed roads, stray dogs, unexploded ordnance and a shortage of heavy equipment. Gaza civil defense workers warn full recovery could take six months to a year if Israel allows machinery. Meanwhile relatives, such as Yahya al-Muqra, dig themselves to find any trace of missing loved ones and gain closure.

articles.title: In Venezuela’s ���darkest hours’, will peace prize boost opposition or backfire?
articles.trailText: María Corina Machado’s Nobel award puts focus on country but analysts doubt it will produce democratic change
articles.summary: María Corina Machado has won the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize for her struggle against Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian regime in Venezuela. Supporters, including EU Commission president Ursula von der Leyen, hope the award cements her as the credible opposition leader and shields her from reprisals. Skeptics like Tulane’s David Smilde and political scientist Ronald Krebs warn peace prizes rarely alter entrenched autocracies and may even provoke harsher repression. Meanwhile, former Chávez minister Andrés Izarra sees US pressure under Trump’s Caribbean naval deployment as performative brinkmanship likely to be resolved at the negotiating table rather than by force.

articles.title: Heavy clashes erupt along Pakistan-Afghanistan border
articles.trailText: Escalation comes after Pakistani airstrike in Kabul, with Taliban launching reprisals against military posts
articles.summary: Heavy fighting broke out along the Pakistan-Afghanistan Durand Line after Taliban forces attacked and seized multiple Pakistani army posts in reprisal for alleged Pakistani airstrikes on Kabul. Islamabad’s military reported 23 soldiers killed and 29 wounded, claiming to have killed 200 Taliban in counterstrikes, while the Taliban claimed 58 Pakistani fatalities. The clashes underscore mounting hostility over Kabul’s alleged sanctuary for Tehreek-e-Taliban Pakistan militants. Analysts warn the tit-for-tat could intensify insurgent attacks and destabilize regional security amid calls for de-escalation.

articles.title: Survivor of 7 October Nova festival attack in Israel found dead
articles.trailText: Roei Shalev, 30, whose girlfriend and best friend were killed in front of him at festival, took his own life on Friday night
articles.summary: Roei Shalev, 30, who survived the Hamas-led 7 October 2023 Nova festival massacre in Israel—where his girlfriend Mapal Adam and best friend Hili Solomon were killed—was found dead by suicide in his burned car near Tel Aviv days after the attack’s second anniversary. Hours earlier he posted online that he could no longer endure the pain. His mother also took her own life weeks after the massacre. Survivors and politicians, including Democrats leader Yair Golan, are urging expanded mental-health support. The Nova Tribe Foundation remembered him for his bravery and community leadership.

articles.title: Thousands attend pro-Palestine rallies across Australia as organisers vow to keep protesting after Gaza ceasefire
articles.trailText: ‘We’ll absolutely continue to protest for a free Palestine,’ Sydney organiser says, as others express hope US-brokered deal will ‘end the genocide’
articles.summary: Thousands rallied across Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane protesting in support of Palestine despite a US-brokered Gaza ceasefire deal. Sydney’s Palestine Action Group claimed 30,000 participants, while police estimated 8,000, reporting no major incidents. Organiser Josh Lees vowed sustained protests for Palestinian self-determination, humanitarian aid and Gaza’s reconstruction. Palestinian Australian Shamikh Badra appealed to bring his ailing mother from Gaza and recover missing relatives, lamenting lack of Palestinian input. Activists plan a Unite Against Racism rally, some urging Canberra to sanction Israel. Jewish community members held commemorations for the October 2023 Hamas attacks. Former Sumud flotilla detainees and Greens MP Jenny Leong addressed crowds.

articles.title: Madagascar’s president says illegal power grab by military is under way
articles.trailText: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit have announced they are taking over after weeks of youth-led protests
articles.summary: Weeks of Gen Z-led protests over water and power shortages and calls for President Andry Rajoelina’s resignation have escalated as he accuses elite Capsat troops of an illegal power grab by seizing army command. Capsat, which backed his 2009 coup, refused to fire on demonstrators and installed General Demosthene Pikulas as army chief. Rajoelina says he remains in the country managing affairs and is open to dialogue. Protesters demand systemic reforms; at least 22 people have died. Observers warn military intervention risks violent escalation in the Indian Ocean island nation, one of the world’s poorest with high corruption.

articles.title: Move over, Alan Turing: meet the working-class hero of Bletchley Park you didn’t see in the movies
articles.trailText: The Oxbridge-educated boffin is feted as the codebreaking genius who helped Britain win the war. But should a little-known Post Office engineer named Tommy Flowers be seen as the real father of computing?
articles.summary: Popular lore credits Turing with building the first computer at Bletchley Park, but this story reveals that degreeless working-class Post Office engineer Tommy Flowers designed and built Colossus—the world’s first electronic digital computer—to crack the Tunny cipher in 1943. Ostracized by Oxbridge boffins and silenced by secrecy, Flowers led a team that delivered ten Colossi by VE Day. His landmark achievement, classified and overshadowed for decades, is now finally recognized through murals, foundations and museum reconstructions.

articles.title: Australian Madeleine Habib released from Israeli jail after aid flotilla intercepted en route to Gaza
articles.trailText: It’s not yet known if Habib signed waiver as demanded by Israel before being taken to Jordan border on Sunday
articles.summary: Australian mariner and activist Madeleine Habib was released from Israel’s Ketziot prison on Sunday, four days after her Gaza-bound aid ship, the Conscience, was seized by the Israeli navy in international waters. Arrested on October 8 for allegedly breaching Israel’s naval blockade, Habib refused to sign a waiver admitting wrongdoing and endured “stale bread” and “brown” water but no physical abuse. She and fellow activists were taken to the Jordan border. Habib is the eighth Australian detained from flotillas. Canberra has urged Israel to allow sustained humanitarian aid into Gaza while warning citizens of blockade risks. Habib’s Conscience, carrying about 100 volunteers, was among nine vessels intercepted before a US-mediated ceasefire, and pro-Palestine protests in Australia continue as activists vow to renew sea-based relief efforts.

articles.title: European far right follows Trump in calling for antifa to be declared terrorists
articles.trailText: Netherlands and Hungary move towards designation as draft resolution reportedly backed by 79 MEPs in 20 countries
articles.summary: After Trump’s Truth Social call to label antifa a terrorist organisation, Geert Wilders�� PVV-led Dutch parliament, Viktor Orbán’s Hungary and MEP Tom Vandendriessche (Vlaams Belang) backed a draft EU resolution supported by 79 MEPs from 20 countries. Experts say antifa is a decentralised anti-fascist movement, not a structured network, and warn such a designation risks politicised prosecutions and undermines security focus. Europol reports scant left-wing/anarchist violence, while critics like MEP Ilaria Salis and Martin Schirdewan denounce the move as a threat to dissent and democracy.

articles.title: Cameroon’s 92-year-old president set for another term as country goes to polls
articles.trailText: Paul Biya, in power since 1982, has brushed off calls to retire but is rarely seen in public
articles.summary: Cameroon’s 92-year-old president Paul Biya, in power since 1982, is favourite for an eighth term against a fractured 11-candidate opposition. Accused of sidelining credible rivals and presiding over a biased electoral commission, Biya bids amid economic hardship—one third of citizens live on under $2 daily and rampant youth unemployment—and armed conflicts: jihadists in the north and anglophone separatists displacing 700,000. Disillusioned voters and low turnout raise legitimacy concerns. Critics from defected ministers to the president’s daughter have challenged his fitness to rule, yet Biya insists only he can fix security and infrastructure deficits.

articles.title: What is the new EU border system EES, and how will it work?
articles.trailText: Digital entry and exit scheme means most travellers will have to register biometric information at the border
articles.summary: From Sunday the EU’s long-delayed Entry/Exit System (EES) begins registering most non-EU travellers’ biometrics—facial images and fingerprints—in place of passport stamps across the Schengen area (25 EU states plus Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland). Using self-service kiosks or automated gates at ports, airports and rail terminals (starting at Dover, Eurotunnel and St Pancras, then rolling out to airports like Stuttgart and Frankfurt), entrants submit passport data, finger scans (children under 12 exempt) and photos. Records are retained three years for border, visa, immigration and law-enforcement use; refusal means denied entry. Full implementation runs through April 10, 2026.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Latest refinery strike shows ‘no safe places in Russia’s deep rear’
articles.trailText: Bashneft oil refinery in Ufa is 1,400km from Ukrainian border; Zelenskyy says Trump can repeat Middle East peace success in Ukraine. What we know on day 1,327
articles.summary: Ukrainian SBU drones struck Bashneft oil refinery in Ufa, 1,400km from the border, marking the third deep strike in Bashkortostan this month and underscoring Kyiv’s reach into Russia’s rear. Zelenskyy urged Trump to broker a Middle East–style ceasefire in Ukraine. Russian attacks killed at least five Ukrainians and cut power in Odesa region; Kyiv partially restored electricity. Ukraine shot down or jammed 54 of 78 Russian drones; Russia claims 42 Ukrainian drones downed. Cuba denies state deployment of mercenaries despite over 1,000 Cubans contracting with Russian forces.

articles.title: Donald Trump and Abdel Fatah al-Sisi to chair Gaza peace summit on Monday
articles.trailText: Meeting will take place in Sharm el-Sheikh and include leaders of the UK, Italy, Spain and France
articles.summary: Donald Trump and Egyptian president Abdel Fatah al-Sisi will co-chair a Gaza peace summit Monday in Sharm el-Sheikh with UN chief António Guterres, UK PM Keir Starmer, Italy’s Giorgia Meloni, Spain’s Pedro Sánchez, France’s Emmanuel Macron and leaders from over 20 countries. Hamas has declined to attend and Israel’s Benjamin Netanyahu’s status is unconfirmed. The meeting follows an Egypt-, Qatar- and Turkey-mediated ceasefire and prisoner-swap deal after intense indirect US talks. Over 67,000 Palestinians and 1,200 Israelis have died since the Gaza war began. The summit aims to cement the truce, scale up humanitarian aid and set a roadmap for regional stability amid widespread destruction and displacement.

articles.title: Soldiers from elite Capsat unit join protests against Madagascar’s president
articles.trailText: Demonstrators march alongside regiment, who earlier in the day said they would not fire on the crowds
articles.summary: Thousands of young demonstrators in Antananarivo were joined on October 11 by soldiers from the elite Capsat unit, who deployed armoured vehicles and addressed crowds urging security forces to refuse orders to fire on civilians and block airport flights. Prime Minister Ruphin Fortunat Zafisambo, newly appointed defence minister, appealed for calm and dialogue after the government’s dissolution. Gen Z-led protests, sparked by water and electricity cuts on September 25, have morphed into demands for President Andry Rajoelina’s resignation. Activists voiced concern over Capsat’s 2009 coup legacy and opportunistic politicians, stressing the need for democratic renewal.

articles.title: Agencies prepare to bring aid to starving people in Gaza as ceasefire appears to hold
articles.trailText: Unicef says ‘humanitarian crisis continues’ and expects to scale up aid deliveries on Sunday
articles.summary: Under a fragile ceasefire, UNICEF and UNRWA are mobilising some 600 daily truckloads of food and medical supplies from Egypt and Jordan to Gaza to avert famine and disease, urging Israel to reopen all crossings, including Rafah on Tuesday. UNRWA holds three months’ food stocks. About 500,000 displaced Palestinians have begun returning to Gaza City. The US-brokered truce stipulates Hamas must free Israeli hostages within 72 hours and Israel will release approximately 1,950 Palestinian detainees, though high-profile figures like Marwan Barghouti remain excluded. Tensions persist after Israeli strikes in Lebanon, risking collapse of the deal.

articles.title: Zelenskyy urges Trump to use Gaza ceasefire momentum to broker peace in Ukraine
articles.trailText: Ukrainian leader discussed request for Tomahawk cruise missiles in phone call with US president
articles.summary: On Oct 11, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged Donald Trump to leverage the Gaza ceasefire momentum to broker peace in Ukraine. In their phone call, they discussed Kyiv’s request for Tomahawk cruise missiles to enhance long-range strike capability, following Trump’s indication of approving transfers via NATO. Zelenskyy highlighted Russia’s massive drone and missile assault on Ukraine’s energy grid. Commander-in-chief Oleksandr Syrskyi warned of escalating air raids—465 Shahed-type drones and 32 cruise/ballistic missiles—and stressed the need to boost defenses beyond the current 74% effectiveness. Zelenskyy praised Trump’s willingness to support air defense agreements. Concurrently, UK PM Starmer, President Macron, and Chancellor Merz proposed using frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine and compel Russia to the negotiating table.

articles.title: The Gaza effect: how a global pro-Palestine protest movement met repression and resistance
articles.trailText: Across the west, solidarity marches are testing governments’ tolerance for dissent. From arrests to bans, free-speech boundaries are shifting
articles.summary: From October 2023 to late 2025, mass pro-Palestine demonstrations in the US, UK, Germany, France, Italy, Ireland and Spain tested free-speech and assembly rights in varied ways. US campus encampments spurred arrests, visa screenings and funding cuts under the Trump administration. In the UK authorities proscribed Palestine Action and detained ~1,900 protesters. Germany, torn by Holocaust legacy, has banned chants deemed antisemitic and faced police brutality claims. France moved to dissolve Urgence Palestine. Italy’s general strikes mobilised millions under PM Meloni’s cautious stance. Ireland’s hands-off policing coexists with reported Garda abuses. Spain saw up to 200,000 peaceful marchers lauded by PM Sánchez amid overwhelming public support.

articles.title: Thousands gather in London in march for ‘lasting peace’ in Gaza
articles.trailText: Director of Palestine Solidarity Campaign says ceasefire agreement says nothing about ‘system of apartheid’ in Palestine
articles.summary: Thousands gathered in central London on Oct. 11 in a Palestine Solidarity Campaign march from Victoria Embankment to Whitehall a day after the Israel-Hamas ceasefire. Demonstrators sold keffiyehs and held placards reading “from the river to the sea” and “Starmer has blood on his hands.” PSC Director Ben Jamal criticised Trump’s plan for ignoring apartheid and Palestinian self-determination, pledging to protest until liberation. Scotland Yard imposed Public Order Act conditions ahead of a Stop the Hate counter-demonstration. Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood had urged postponement after a synagogue attack in Manchester. This 32nd demonstration since Oct. 2023 coincided with displaced Palestinians returning to Gaza.

articles.title: Militia strikes kill at least 60 in Sudan displacement camp, says El Fasher group
articles.trailText: Drone and artillery strikes by RSF paramilitaries hit Dar al-Arqam shelter in western city, says resistance committee
articles.summary: RSF drone and artillery strikes hit the Dar al-Arqam displacement camp at El Fasher university grounds on Oct 10–11, killing at least 60—including children, women and elderly—and trapping bodies under rubble. Local resistance and medical groups report two drone and eight shelling attacks, calling it a “massacre” amid a 500-day siege. El Fasher remains the last Darfur capital outside RSF control in Sudan’s civil war that has killed 150,000+ and displaced 14 million. UN rights chief Volker Türk condemned the assault, urging protection of civilians under international law.

articles.title: ‘It’s a question of humanity’: how a small Spanish town made headlines over its immigration stance
articles.trailText: Mayor explains why Villamalea unanimously backed call to regularise undocumented migrants – across party lines
articles.summary: In Villamalea, a 4,200-resident town in central Spain, conservative mayor José Núñez Pérez led a unanimous, cross-party council motion urging Madrid to regularise undocumented migrants. Once attracting global labour to its mushroom farms and agriculture, the town now reflects 32 nationalities. Councillors from the PP, Socialists and United Left cited economic need and “humanity” to ensure fair wages and integration—mirroring Spain’s pro-migration stance and EU data on migrant-driven growth. Initiatives include interfaith visits. Neighbouring Tarazona de la Mancha passed a similar motion, underscoring local consensus despite national political shifts.

articles.title: Boycotting Israel has gone mainstream: ‘We’ve never seen such traction before’
articles.trailText: After decades of being dismissed as fringe, the boycott call has been taken up by leading figures across arts, sports and politics
articles.summary: After decades of fringe status, global calls to boycott Israel have gained unprecedented mainstream momentum amid the Gaza war. From the closure of Washington’s Israeli-inspired Shouk chain under boycott pressure to cultural and sporting bans—writers like Zadie Smith and film workers, Eurovision participation votes, musicians such as Björk, and football figures like Eric Cantona—activists invoke BDS tactics reminiscent of anti-apartheid South Africa. Fueled by images of civilian suffering and a UN experts’ genocide finding, these actions reflect generational shifts and political anger at Netanyahu’s right-wing government, though opponents warn of silencing dissenting Israelis.

articles.title: ‘The Algarve is Chega’s kingdom’: resort city’s voters tempted by far-right party
articles.trailText: Chega voters in Albufeira hope party can use Sunday’s local elections as springboard for nationwide takeover
articles.summary: In Albufeira, traditionally centre-right territory, far-right Chega has plastered posters promising to fix health, education and housing woes, hoping Sunday's local election will cement a foothold in the Algarve 'kingdom' and fuel nationwide gains. After rising to second place in May’s general election and topping polls, André Ventura’s party capitalizes on soaring rents, overtourism and resentment toward low-wage migrants. Supporters praise Ventura’s populist outreach, while critics warn anti-migrant rhetoric threatens a tourism-driven economy. A strong local showing could springboard Chega into Portugal’s next general election.

articles.title: ‘Gateway to hell’: young reporter’s harrowing two years in besieged Gaza
articles.trailText: Malak A Tantesh’s grim experience of living with perpetual fear and uncertainty amid Israel’s war after 2023 Hamas attack
articles.summary: Over two years, Gaza reporter Malak A Tantesh endured the war triggered by the 7 October 2023 Hamas attack: from rocket alarms and frantic evacuation of her Beit Lahia family under Israeli bombing to transient shelter in Deir’s cold floors, Rafah’s tents amid water, food and hepatitis outbreaks, the death of her grandmother and uncle, attempts to plant crops under siege, repeat displacements during ground invasions, Gaza City’s starvation siege with one loaf shared among kin, fleeting ceasefires (Jan 2025 and recent), rebuilding homes amid rubble, and constant fear that peace will again collapse before normal life can return.

articles.title: ‘Our job is to maximise their losses’: how Ukraine’s forces attempt to claw back against Russian advances
articles.trailText: Along Donetsk’s frontline, a small counteroffensive by Ukrainian troops aims to help change perceptions about the war among Kyiv’s western allies
articles.summary: Along Donetsk’s frontline, Ukraine’s 93rd brigade mounted a small counteroffensive to recapture the Russian salient around Hruzike and Vesele. Using machine-gun robots, tanks, drones and clearing operations, an eight-man platoon led by “Tarantino�� reclaimed 330 sq km (170 sq km secured), inflicting 3,520 Russian casualties (1,988 KIA) with no losses. Successes boosted Western perceptions after initial Russian advances, even shifting Donald Trump’s view of Russia as a “paper tiger.” Russia’s summer push slowed; Kyiv’s morale and drone strikes on oil sites remain high.

articles.title: ‘I deserve to heal’: freed British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah on his prison ordeal and next steps
articles.trailText: The campaigner, who spent more than a decade in an Egyptian ‘vortex of incarceration’, wants to join his son in the UK while he reflects on the fight for freedom
articles.summary: After 12 years of intermittent detention under President Sisi, British-Egyptian activist Alaa Abd el-Fattah was freed by presidential pardon. He describes a ‘vortex of incarceration’ marked by solitary confinement and his mother’s 287-day hunger strike, and now seeks to heal and reunite with his 14-year-old autistic son in the UK. Grateful for domestic and UK campaign support, he rejects prison as a rite of passage, plans a pause from frontline organising, and intends to focus on writing, analysis and new forms of political engagement safely based abroad.

articles.title: ‘To the men who ran the world, I was just a photo op’: Malala Yousafzai on growing up, getting cynical – and how getting high nearly broke her
articles.trailText: The global icon of women’s education is ready to tell the full story of her turbulent recent life, from arguing with her parents to being ghosted by the statesmen who were once desperate to be seen with her
articles.summary: Ahead of her memoir Finding My Way, Malala Yousafzai revisits her turbulent early 20s: from a PTSD flashback triggered by smoking a bong at Oxford—unearthing memories of her Taliban shooting—to navigating parental and public scrutiny over her surprise marriage to cricket manager Asser Malik. She reflects on earning a 2.1 at Oxford while funding family and supporting Afghan partners ignored by world leaders during the US withdrawal. Yousafzai addresses backlash in Pakistan, her Gaza and Afghan activism through the Malala Fund, growing cynicism about photo-op politics, and launching Recess, an investment fund for women’s sports.

articles.title: Unease at slow pace of change in Nepal one month on from gen Z protests
articles.trailText: Promised crackdown on corruption is not happening fast enough for many who saw government toppled within a day of protests
articles.summary: One month after Nepal’s Gen Z-led uprising toppled the government and installed anti-corruption hardliner Sushila Karki as interim prime minister, young demonstrators remain frustrated at the lack of arrests and slow reforms. Prakash Bohora, shot by police on 8 September and hospitalized, joins calls for former leaders like ex-PM Oli and ex-home minister Lekhak to face graft and protest-killings probes. While Karki’s interim cabinet promises to remove political obstruction and accelerate corruption investigations ahead of March elections, bureaucratic hurdles and resistance from major parties—who deem her administration illegitimate—threaten the movement’s goals and Nepal’s stability.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Power restored to Kyiv after Russia drone attacks
articles.trailText: Zelenskyy says attacks targeted energy infrastructure as winter looms; boy killed as drones and missiles hit Zaporizhzhia. What we know on day 1,326
articles.summary: After Russian drone and missile strikes on energy infrastructure, power for 270,000 Kyiv households was restored following overnight blasts that left blocks of flats ablaze. In Zaporizhzhia, 12 apartment buildings were damaged, a seven-year-old boy was killed and four injured; Kyiv mayor Vitali Klitschko reported 12 more wounded. President Zelenskiy warned of winter hardships and pressed Europe to deploy frozen Russian assets for Ukraine’s defense and recovery. Meanwhile Putin distanced himself from a deputy foreign minister’s stark US-Russia rupture claims, pledging continued dialogue, and Melania Trump said eight Ukrainian children had been reunited with families after her appeal.

articles.title: Macron reappoints Sébastien Lecornu as French prime minister
articles.trailText: Lecornu, who resigned as PM on Monday, is tasked with urgently delivering a budget to parliament
articles.summary: Days after his unprecedented 14-hour government collapse, Macron has reappointed centrist ally Sébastien Lecornu as prime minister to rush France’s 2026 budget through parliament by year-end and curb public frustration. Tasked with ending a political crisis that has fragmented the legislature into left, centre and far-right blocs, Lecornu faces fierce opposition: Marine Le Pen’s National Rally vows a no-confidence vote, Greens and Socialists demand inclusion, and Les Républicains decry the move as a provocation. With Macron’s approval at historic lows, Lecornu must build a broader, stable coalition within days.

articles.title: ‘I expect to find a ghost city’: Gaza residents on the long, arduous journey back home
articles.trailText: Returnees anxious if the homes they left behind will still be standing after Hamas-Israel ceasefire takes effect
articles.summary: As thousands of Gaza residents risked return amid a new Hamas–Israel ceasefire, they encountered ghostly destruction: collapsed buildings, flattened neighborhoods and checkpoints strewn with debris. Abdel Fattah al-Kurdi struggled to navigate north Gaza City to Sheikh Radwan, finding his home badly damaged; Ahmad Salem waited days at Netzarim checkpoint only to discover his house erased; Asmaa Zuheir glimpsed nothing but leveled earth around Beit Lahia. Despite ongoing Israeli troop presence and drone fire, returnees salvage memories from ruins, clinging to hope even as ceasefire durability and reconstruction remain uncertain.

articles.title: Nobel peace prize officials investigate surge in bets for winner
articles.trailText: Bets for Maria Corina Machado spiked on Polymarket gambling site hours before she was awarded prize
articles.summary: Norwegian Nobel officials are probing a spike in Polymarket bets on Venezuelan opposition leader Maria Corina Machado hours before she won the 2025 Peace Prize, suggesting a possible leak. On Oct 10, Machado’s odds jumped from 3.75% to 72.8% shortly after midnight Norwegian time. One bettor earned $65,000; another account was newly created. Head of the Nobel Institute Kristian Berg Harpviken called it a criminal exploitation of insider information, while Nobel Committee chair Jørgen Watne Frydnes stressed the process’s secrecy. An official investigation to trace the betting irregularities and confirm any leak is expected.

articles.title: Palestinians displaced to southern Gaza begin journey home as ceasefire comes into effect
articles.trailText: Thousands walk north along coastal road after Israel-Hamas agreement puts stop to fighting for first time in six months
articles.summary: Under a US-mediated ceasefire that took effect Friday—the first pause in Gaza fighting since March—tens of thousands of displaced Palestinians began returning north along the coastal road as Israeli forces withdrew to pre-agreed positions. Hamas will release 20 Israeli hostages early next week, prompting Israel to free nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners. The deal, rooted in Donald Trump’s 20-point peace plan, raises hopes for a durable truce, though Netanyahu warned of renewed combat if Hamas resists disarmament—a demand Hamas rejects. With over 90% of homes damaged, acute malnutrition and famine spread, humanitarian aid flows remain insufficient amid debates over Gaza’s future governance.

articles.title: A plea for compassion to counter blind hatred over Israel and Gaza | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: A reader is heartened by Sharone Lifschitz’s article about the second anniversary of 7 October and her parents’ kidnapping by Hamas
articles.summary: A reader commends Sharone Lifschitz’s reflection on the second anniversary of 7 October and her parents’ abduction by Hamas, urging compassion over tribal hatred in the Israel–Gaza conflict. They express grief for all civilian victims—mourning children killed by Hamas and Israeli forces alike—and denounce using past injustices to justify present slaughter. The letter criticizes rising antisemitism on social media, where Jews are vilified regardless of politics, and warns against equating a government’s actions with its people. Ultimately, the writer hopes for mutual empathy and a brighter future for everyone.

articles.title: Blair, Kushner, Trump: who are the key people behind the Gaza ceasefire?
articles.trailText: Eight political figures who played parts in the agreement
articles.summary: An Israel–Hamas ceasefire, pausing Gaza bombardment and enabling captives exchange, was brokered by eight figures: former US president Donald Trump (whose 20-point “peace plan” underpins the deal and who has been Israel’s main arms backer); his envoy Steve Witkoff, who oversaw US approval; Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu, wanted by the ICC; Hamas chief negotiator Khalil al-Hayya; Trump adviser Jared Kushner; ex-UK PM Tony Blair, floated as interim Gaza governor; Israeli strategic affairs minister Ron Dermer; and Qatari PM Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani, Qatar’s lead mediator.

articles.title: Britons travelling to EU to undergo new biometric checks at border from Sunday
articles.trailText: Most non-EU nationals entering Schengen area will have photo and fingerprints taken as part of entry-exit system
articles.summary: From Sunday the EU’s long-delayed Entry-Exit System (EES) begins, requiring most non-EU/EEA nationals, including Britons, to have photos and fingerprints scanned at Schengen borders. Passport stamps persist during a phased rollout—initially checking coaches and HGVs at Eurotunnel and Dover, with limited Eurostar controls until January—to prevent queues at ports. Banks of EES kiosks across airports and cross-Channel terminals may also log accommodation, return tickets, funds and insurance. Stamping ends by April 10 ahead of summer. The UK has launched an info campaign as Abta warns many remain unaware and overstayers face auto-detection; Logistics UK is pushing for a driver pre-registration app.

articles.title: Venezuelan politician María Corina Machado wins Nobel peace prize
articles.trailText: Opponent of Maduro regime receives award and praise for keeping ‘flame of democracy burning’
articles.summary: Venezuelan opposition leader María Corina Machado, 58, wins the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize for her sustained fight against Nicolás Maduro’s authoritarian regime. Living underground since the contested 2024 election won by her ally Edmundo González, Machado galvanized volunteers to document vote-rigging and mobilized mass rallies despite exile threats. Praised by the Nobel committee for “civilian courage,” she dedicated the award to Venezuelans and thanked US support, especially former president Trump. The prize bolsters her protection against Maduro’s crackdown, intensifies international scrutiny, and energizes the decadelong struggle for democracy amid economic collapse and mass migration.

articles.title: Seven people killed after twin earthquakes off coast of Philippines
articles.trailText: Quakes of 7.4 and 6.8 magnitude trigger tsunami alerts as people living near coast advised to evacuate
articles.summary: Two offshore earthquakes of magnitude 7.4 and 6.8 struck off Manay, Davao Oriental, southern Philippines on Oct 10, killing at least seven and triggering tsunami alerts for coasts within 300km. Warnings for the Philippines and Indonesia were later lifted; advisories urged coastal residents to evacuate to higher ground amid fears of waves over 1m. Structural damage reported to homes, bridges (Magsaysay Bridge), schools and utilities, with power trips in Mindanao. Authorities, led by President Marcos Jr and Phivolcs director Bacolcol, mobilised search, rescue and damage assessments. Frequent aftershocks and panic among students and residents followed. Indonesian warnings were also issued.

articles.title: Hamas will be disarmed, Netanyahu vows after ceasefire begins
articles.trailText: In combative speech, Israeli prime minister says Gaza will be demilitarised ‘the easy way or the hard way’
articles.summary: After a fragile Gaza ceasefire, PM Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to demilitarise Hamas “the easy way or the hard way,” framing the deal—20 hostages freed, Israeli pullback, 2,000 Palestinian detainees released—as victory over the Iranian axis and a pre-election security platform. Analysts see his combative address as early campaigning amid stagnant Likud polls and coalition fractures. He faces corruption charges, calls for inquiries into the October 7 failures and a fragile truce, even as Trump’s upcoming Knesset speech may bolster his “Mr Security” image against a fragmented opposition.

articles.title: ‘It gets a bit dirty after 2am’: overtourism debate centre stage as Abta meets in Mallorca
articles.trailText: Home to Magaluf, a major draw for boozed-up Britain, the island has become emblematic of the most heated debate in travel
articles.summary: At ABTA’s annual conference in Calviá, Mallorca – home to party hotspot Magaluf – industry leaders grappled with overtourism as the Balearics welcomed 3.5m UK visitors last year. Delegates debated “slow travel,” off-season growth and diversifying beyond boozy sun-seekers. Spain’s new campaign promotes inland, astrotourism and olive-oil trails while Calviá has upgraded 80% of hotels to 4-5 stars, launched a literary festival and bid for European Capital of Culture. Jet2 boss Steve Heapy warned targeting only richer tourists is unfair; Tui’s Neil Swanson emphasised tourism must work socially for locals. ABTA’s Mark Tanzer said if hosts resist, operators will redirect capacity elsewhere. Locals now return to Magaluf, but balancing incomes and community remains contentious.

articles.title: Man fined for burning Qur’an in London wins appeal against conviction
articles.trailText: Judge says Hamit Coskun has ‘right to offend’ and overturns conviction for religiously aggravated public order offence
articles.summary: Hamit Coskun, who set fire to a Qur’an outside the Turkish consulate in London in February while shouting anti-Islam slogans, has had his June conviction for a religiously aggravated public-order offence overturned by Southwark Crown Court. Judge Bennathan ruled that even outrightly offensive protests are protected speech, saying freedom of expression must include the right to offend. The Free Speech Union, National Secular Society and Humanists UK hailed the decision as a victory for free speech; shadow justice secretary Robert Jenrick, who opposes Qur’an burning, agreed it should not be criminalised.

articles.title: Macron summons parties for crunch meeting in frantic effort to appoint PM
articles.trailText: All parties except National Rally and La France Insoumise called on by president to show ‘collective responsibility’
articles.summary: President Macron summoned leaders of all major parties except the far-right National Rally and Mélenchon’s La France Insoumise to the Élysée, demanding collective responsibility as he races to name a new PM by Friday night amid France’s worst political crisis since 2017. Socialists, Greens and Les Républicains were invited at 2am after PM Sébastien Lecornu resigned 14 hours into his tenure, the third premier in a year. With parliament split among left, centre and far right and a 2026 budget due, Macron seeks a sixth PM capable of brokering cross-bloc compromise to avert economic fallout, warns central bank head.

articles.title: No family, no stability, no social fabric: the anguish of Gaza’s wounded orphans
articles.trailText: As the number of WCNSFs – wounded child no surviving family – grows, charities struggle to find adults to look after them
articles.summary: Since the war began, Gaza’s ‘WCNSF’ (wounded child, no surviving family) population has surged amid relentless Israeli bombing and mass displacement. UN figures cite 2,596 double orphans and 53,724 single-orphaned children, many critically injured with the highest modern conflict amputation rates. Emergency teams and charities like War Child, UNICEF and MSF face chronic shortages of foster caregivers, intact social structures and evacuation transport, leaving traumatized youngsters—exemplified by three-year-old Wesam and teens Radeh and Ahmad—physically wounded, isolated and facing lifelong psychological harm.

articles.title: ‘Massive’ Russian attack on Ukraine capital causes widespread blackout
articles.trailText: At least 20 injured after hundreds of drones and dozens of missiles target energy infrastructure in Kyiv
articles.summary: Russian forces launched a “massive” overnight barrage of 465 drones and 32 missiles at Kyiv’s energy infrastructure, downing 405 drones and 15 missiles, wounding 20 and igniting a 17-storey block of flats. The strike caused widespread blackouts for 28,000 families, damaged thermal power plants and targeted civilian energy ahead of winter, Zelenskyy said, urging the G7 for decisive air defences and sanctions. Regional raids killed a child in Zaporizhzhia and hit Belgorod’s power grid. Kyiv’s mayor and PM called it among the war’s heaviest energy assaults.

articles.title: DRC says EU’s minerals deal with Rwanda is ‘obvious double standard’
articles.trailText: Brussels urged to impose stronger sanctions against Rwanda, as it has in response to Russia for its war in Ukraine
articles.summary: DRC foreign minister Thérèse Kayikwamba Wagner accused the EU of a “double standard” for upholding a 2024 minerals MoU with Rwanda—supplying Europe’s EV battery and microchip industries—while imposing far tougher sanctions on Russia over Ukraine. She urged Brussels to adopt stronger measures against Kigali for backing the M23 rebel insurgency in eastern DRC, citing UN findings that Rwandan troops fight alongside M23 and commit human rights abuses, including forced child labour. Despite limited EU sanctions on individuals and a gold refiner, Wagner called the MoU “void of credibility” and warned ongoing violence has displaced 7.8 million people and killed over 1,000 this summer.

articles.title: Weather tracker: South-east China swelters in summer-like heat
articles.trailText: Inland areas have neared 40C, while in northern China a cold air mass clashed with warmth to produce heavy rain
articles.summary: Summer-like heat in southeast China persists into October as high pressure drives inland temps close to 40C (Xiushui 38.9C), with Hong Kong logging a record four “very hot days” over 28C. Models predict 8–10 more days of abnormal warmth before a cold front arrives. In northern China, Beijing recorded its coldest early October day since 1951 (max 10.6C) amid 36+ hours of heavy rain (up to 140.4mm in Daxing), underscoring extreme rain events linked to each 1C of warming boosting atmospheric moisture by 7%. Meanwhile, Tropical Storm Nakri nears typhoon strength, threatening Japan’s Izu Islands with 105mph gusts before turning extratropical.

articles.title: Australian on pro-Palestinian aid flotilla told she will be ‘indefinitely detained’ by Israel unless she signs waiver
articles.trailText: Madeleine Habib, who captained the Conscience ship, was arrested by Israeli forces on 8 October and detained in Israel’s Ketziot prison
articles.summary: Madeleine Habib, a Tasmanian mariner and captain of the Conscience aid vessel, has been held since 8 Oct in Israel’s Ketziot high-security prison after attempting to breach the Gaza naval blockade. Israeli authorities say she will remain indefinitely detained unless she signs a waiver admitting to illegal blockade violation. Unlike other detainees deported after 72 hours, Habib refused. Australian consular visits noted harsh conditions—stale bread, brown water—suspected bedbugs but no physical abuse and nothing worse than hostels. DFAT officials, citing privacy at a Senate hearing, expect her release Sunday amid holiday shutdowns.

articles.title: Friday briefing: How a historic case accusing two men of spying for China dramatically fell apart
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: For weeks, the precise reason the trial broke down remained opaque. Then, prosecutors said the government wouldn’t hand over the evidence
articles.summary: The CPS dropped charges against Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry under the Official Secrets Act, accusing them of spying for China between 2021-23. The case collapsed weeks before trial when prosecutors could not obtain government confirmation that China posed a “threat to UK national security” under the 1911 Act. DPP Stephen Parkinson blamed No 10 for withholding evidence, revealing friction between the CPS and ministers reluctant to label China an enemy. Cash, a former parliamentary researcher, and Berry, a China-based analyst, deny passing more than open-source political gossip. The outcome raises questions about Britain’s espionage laws, the definition of “enemy” and UK-China policy.

articles.title: Non-stop snow, instant noodles and yaks: tales of being trapped on Everest
articles.trailText: More than 1,000 people were stuck in mountain hiking areas for days, sparking extensive rescue efforts by local authorities and villagers
articles.summary: On Mount Everest’s eastern flank, unusually heavy snowfall trapped over 1,000 mainly Chinese hikers for days during China’s National Day holiday. Guides consolidated trekkers in a dining tent, lit fires to stay warm and delayed descent until a clear morning. A narrow evacuation route was carved with yaks and supported by local villagers who provided food, hot water and instant noodles. Authorities halted ticket sales but faced criticism over allowing treks amid forecasts. State media coverage was muted until officials evacuated almost 900 people to nearby Qudang, while one Taiwanese trekker died of hypothermia in Qinghai.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: 23 children and adolescents brought out of Russian-occupied areas
articles.trailText: Rescue carried out under the president’s ‘Bring Kids Back UA’ programme; power cut in capital and several injured - What we know on day 1,325
articles.summary: Ukrainian officials reported that a major Russian ballistic missile and drone strike on central Kyiv sparked a high-rise fire, injured nine people, and cut power on the Dnipro’s east bank. Under President Zelenskyy’s “Bring Kids Back UA” scheme, 23 children and adolescents were evacuated from Russian-occupied areas. Donald Trump said Washington and NATO are intensifying pressure on Russia and may impose new sanctions. Moscow accused Ukraine of blowing up an ammonia pipeline; the IAEA began restoring power to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant. Kyiv touted successful long-range missile strikes on Russian energy facilities. Zelenskyy plans a US mission to discuss air defense, energy, sanctions, and frozen assets.

articles.title: Hamas and Israel prepare to implement ceasefire as Netanyahu says deal approved by government
articles.trailText: Israel’s government ratified the ceasefire and hostage deal on Friday, clearing the way to suspend hostilities in Gaza within 24 hours
articles.summary: With Israel’s cabinet ratifying a ceasefire and hostage-swap deal brokered in Sharm el-Sheikh, Hamas and Israel are set to suspend Gaza hostilities within 24 hours. Israel will free about 2,000 Palestinian prisoners (excluding Fatah leader Marwan Barghouti) in exchange for roughly 48 hostages, of whom under half are believed alive, to be released within 72 hours. Israeli forces will pull back to control 53% of Gaza; the US will deploy 200 troops to monitor the truce. Celebrations in Gaza and Tel Aviv were tempered by anxiety, as UN agencies urge rapid aid access and infrastructure rebuilding.

articles.title: President Petro accuses US of killing Colombians in attacks on ‘narco-boats’
articles.trailText: Gustavo Petro demands US release names of victims: ‘A new theatre of war has opened up: the Caribbean’
articles.summary: Colombian president Gustavo Petro has accused the US of killing at least 21 people, including Colombians, during four aerial strikes on alleged drug-trafficking boats in the Caribbean since early September, demanding Washington release victim names and evidence. The US Department of Defense says it targeted “narco-terrorists” trafficking cocaine from Venezuela, part of a major maritime buildup critics argue masks regime-change ambitions against Nicolás Maduro. Caracas has warned of retaliation, while regional states like Grenada weigh US requests to host radar installations amid divided views over Washington’s presence.

articles.title: ‘Trump is like a juggernaut’: how the Gaza ceasefire deal was done
articles.trailText: Sidelines chat at UN was turning point for US president, but others also have right to claim role in end of two-year war
articles.summary: In September’s UN sidelines meeting organized by the UAE, President Trump, urged by Jared Kushner and Tony Blair, rolled out a 20-point Gaza ceasefire-and-hostage-release plan. He dropped forced displacement rhetoric, insisted on a “day after” governance blueprint, pressured Netanyahu after the Doha airstrike, secured Arab backing, and brokered talks in Egypt where Hamas agreed to hostages-for-truce terms pending further governance negotiations. Trump’s personal guarantor role, no West Bank annexations pledge, and Blair-led reconstruction board underpinned this collective diplomatic push to end the two-year Gaza war.

articles.title: New film explores how Caribbean workers helped win second world war
articles.trailText: Commissioned by the Imperial War Museum, Cornwallis Cloth ends ‘archival silence’ around invaluable West Indian contribution to war effort
articles.summary: Cornwallis Cloth, a short film commissioned by the Imperial War Museum, uncovers the overlooked role of thousands of Caribbean workers recruited from British West Indian colonies to build US air and naval bases across Antigua, Barbados, Bermuda, Jamaica, St Lucia, Trinidad and British Guiana in exchange for destroyers under the 1940 “destroyers for bases” deal. Combining 30 years of research, oral histories, diaries and testimonies, the film traces how base construction secured Allied victory in the Atlantic, galvanized Caribbean civil rights and independence movements, and shaped music, fashion and UK–US ties. It premieres at the Old Royal Naval College from 11 October alongside an exhibition.

articles.title: ‘Everyone is still afraid’: ceasefire deal brings relief to Gaza but fears remain over future
articles.trailText: Two previous short-lived ceasefires have left many in Gaza doubtful about the staying power of the latest agreement
articles.summary: Cautious relief greeted Gaza’s latest ceasefire as residents, scarred by two short-lived truces, wait for guarantees on open crossings, food imports and halted bombings. In al-Mawasi tent camps they celebrate with gunfire yet remain fearful of renewed hostilities. Aid agencies, under Trump’s 20-point plan and WHO and UNRWA commitments, are poised to flood Gaza with supplies, but stocks still fall short for 2.3m people. With over 90% of homes destroyed, 67,000+ Palestinians killed and infrastructure in ruins, Gazans worry the truce may break and leave them vulnerable to chaos, hunger and displacement.

articles.title: Anti-protest proposals put free speech at risk | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Readers respond to the proposal to give police further powers to curb ‘cumulative’ protests, in response to actions by the proscribed group Palestine Action
articles.summary: Reader letters condemn the home secretary’s bid to let police impose protest conditions for ‘cumulative’ disruption, noting similar measures were rejected by peers in Jan 2023 and that existing public order laws already cover intimidation, noise, harassment and hate. Writers warn of police overreach, chilling lawful dissent and penalising groups for another’s actions. Another correspondent, Prof Tony Booth, draws parallels between his 2025 arrest at an anti-genocide Palestine Action demonstration and his father’s 1936 anti-fascist stand, urging a progressive movement against state repression, genocide and rising far-right threats.

articles.title: French appeal court increases sentence of Gisèle Pelicot rapist
articles.trailText: Husamettin Dogan loses appeal after jury at retrial finds him guilty of raping Pelicot while she was sedated
articles.summary: Husamettin Dogan, 44, lost his appeal at the Nîmes court of appeal and had his prison term for raping a drugged unconscious Gisèle Pelicot raised from nine to ten years. A jury found he responded to an online invitation from Pelicot’s husband, Dominique, convicted for drugging and facilitating dozens of rapes—to assault the 72-year-old in her bedroom in 2019. Video footage showed Pelicot comatose while Dogan assaulted her over three‐and‐a‐half hours. Dogan maintains he did not rape her, blaming the husband’s invitation, while Pelicot, international feminist icon, demands recognition of the crime and a shift to a culture of consent.

articles.title: Norway braces for Trump’s reaction if he does not win Nobel peace prize
articles.trailText: US president may impose tariffs, demand higher Nato contributions or even declare Norway an enemy, analyst says
articles.summary: Norwegian politicians are braced for possible US retaliation—tariffs, higher NATO contribution demands or even an “enemy” designation—if Donald Trump, long convinced he merits the 2025 Nobel Peace Prize, is passed over. Experts note the Norwegian Nobel Committee’s independent five-member panel finalized its decision before the Israel-Hamas ceasefire under Trump’s Gaza plan, making an award to him highly improbable. Analysts highlight other contenders (Sudan’s Emergency Response Rooms, Committee to Protect Journalists) and stress the prize’s apolitical integrity.

articles.title: First phase of ceasefire deal to end war in Gaza agreed by Israel and Hamas
articles.trailText: Donald Trump announces all hostages will be released ‘very soon’ and Israel will withdraw troops to an agreed timeline
articles.summary: Donald Trump announced on Truth Social that Israel and Hamas have signed 'phase one' of a US-brokered ceasefire in Sharm-el-Sheikh, pausing a two-year Gaza war that killed tens of thousands. Under the accord, Israel will withdraw to a line controlling 53% of Gaza, free 20 surviving hostages within 72 hours and release hundreds of Palestinian prisoners (excluding Marwan Barghouti). The truce takes effect within 24 hours of Israeli cabinet ratification. Backed by the US, Qatar, Egypt and Turkey, it faces hurdles on disarmament, governance and urgent humanitarian needs.

articles.title: ‘It feels like a dream’: protests come to end as Israelis sing in ‘hostages square’
articles.trailText: After 733 days, news of agreement greeted with celebration in Tel Aviv and stickers saying: ‘They’re coming home’
articles.summary: In Tel Aviv’s Hostages Square, protesters marking 733 days of Hamas captivity replaced yellow tally stickers with “They’re coming home” after Israel and Hamas agreed to swap all remaining 20 living hostages for nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners by Monday, plus return of 28 deceased. Crowds sang, waved flags and praised US mediation—many cheering Trump and scoffing at Netanyahu—while families awaited loved ones freed from Gaza. Despite relief, participants remained wary given past ceasefire collapses and ongoing Gaza bombardment, which has killed over 67,000 Palestinians. The deal ends a national rallying cry but stops short of a permanent ceasefire or Gaza’s governance plan.

articles.title: Gaza ceasefire deal: what has been agreed for first phase and why now?
articles.trailText: Donald Trump says Israel and Hamas have reached a deal to pause fighting and release some hostages and prisoners
articles.summary: Under Trump’s US-backed plan Israel and Hamas have agreed to pause fighting within 24h, free about 20 living hostages within 72h plus remains of others, and release 2,000 Palestinian prisoners (including 250 serving long sentences). Israeli forces will pull back to new positions and aid deliveries will rise. Ratified by Netanyahu’s security cabinet after indirect Egypt talks, Hamas agreed under pressure from Qatar, Egypt and Turkey. Key uncertainties include territorial control, Hamas disarmament, Gaza governance and reconstruction. The ceasefire’s durability hinges on regional engagement, US follow-through and unresolved phase-two negotiations. While a swift resumption of hostilities seems unlikely, failure to negotiate further phases risks reigniting the two-year war.

articles.title: Two years of displacement and destruction in Gaza – photo essay
articles.trailText: Enas Tantesh’s photography captures not only the despair and insecurity but also moments of normality and human connection
articles.summary: A UN human rights report deemed Israel’s actions in Gaza genocide. Enas Tantesh’s photo essay chronicles two years of Israeli bombardment: 66,200 killed, nearly 169,000 injured, over 80% civilians, 70% buildings ruined. A former swimming instructor, Tantesh began photographing devastation with a mobile phone in spring 2024 as Gaza’s journalists dwindled. Her images document destroyed homes, forced displacement—nine in ten uprooted, her own family moved eleven times—improvised tents, starvation, and moments of normality—children playing, family meals, cats amid ruins. Facing threats from all sides, she persists in bearing witness under constant fear.

articles.title: China steps up control of rare-earth exports citing ‘national security’ concerns
articles.trailText: Tightened grip on minerals used in smartphones and fighter jets coincides with tense US-China trade talks
articles.summary: China's commerce ministry on Thursday imposed immediate, expanded export controls on rare-earth minerals and related technologies, requiring state approval for mining, processing, recycling or magnet production over national security fears of dual-use transfers to foreign militaries. The rules bar Chinese entities from assisting overseas operations, deny defense users outright, handle advanced semiconductor applications case by case and force approvals even for items with trace Chinese rare earths. Beijing’s move, leveraging its ~70% share of global rare-earth mining and near-total processing, heightens pressure in US-China trade talks ahead of the Xi-Trump Apec summit.

articles.title: Increase sentence for Gisèle Pelicot rapist, prosecutor tells court of appeal
articles.trailText: Dominique Sie recommends 12-year jail term after Husamettin Dugan’s ‘refusal to take responsibility’ for assault
articles.summary: French prosecutor Dominique Sie urged the Nîmes appeals court to raise builder Husamettin Dogan’s rape sentence from nine to 12 years after he appealed his 2019 conviction for raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was drugged unconscious by her husband. Sie denounced Dogan’s denial of guilt as emblematic of “archaic” rape culture and male dominance. Dogan, the sole appellant among 51 convicted men in a high-profile trial of Pelicot’s husband’s accomplices, claimed he performed merely “sexual acts” with the victim at her husband’s invitation. Pelicot, 72, a feminist icon who waived anonymity, and the prosecution await Thursday���s verdict.

articles.title: New French PM to be named by Friday as Macron resists pressure to call snap elections
articles.trailText: Government spokesperson says it may be ‘last chance’ for politicians to regain credibility and cut risk of far right taking power
articles.summary: President Emmanuel Macron will appoint a new prime minister by Friday, aiming to secure passage of a budget amid a 5.5% GDP deficit in France’s fragmented parliament. Sébastien Lecornu resigned after 27 days, forcing Macron to choose between snap elections or a cross-spectrum coalition. With far-right and hard-left MPs vowing to block any Macron nominee, momentum grows for a moderate left PM ready to revisit the 2023 pensions reform. Macron rejects early elections and vows to serve until 2027.

articles.title: Venice opera house staff to strike over hiring of Meloni-linked conductor
articles.trailText: La Fenice’s musicians and staff claim Beatrice Venezi lacks experience and was picked because of government ties
articles.summary: Staff at Venice’s La Fenice opera house will strike on Oct 17 over the planned appointment of 35-year-old conductor Beatrice Venezi as music director, accusing the government-connected appointee of insufficient experience and alleged cronyism under Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s far-right administration. Venezi, whose father belonged to neofascist Forza Nuova, has conducted globally but never led a major opera house. Musicians’ unions demand her appointment be revoked before talks; culture minister Alessandro Giuli and La Fenice’s management defend her credentials and historic first female directorship.

articles.title: Creatures buried in soil for over a century burst back to life in Toronto waterfront
articles.trailText: A project to restore coastal wetland leads to astonishing discoveries of a host of life: seeds and plant scraps, as well as water fleas, worms, larvae and plankton
articles.summary: During Toronto’s Don River restoration, researchers recovered peat samples buried for over 130 years and watched dormant seeds, plant scraps, water fleas, worms, larvae and plankton spring back to life. U of T soil ecologist Shelby Riskin and paleoecologist Sarah Finkelstein will publish peer-reviewed findings on carbon-dated seeds, pollen (including American chestnut) and germination tests. The revival underscores the resilience of native soils, informs large-scale wetland engineering at Ookwemin Minising, and validates Indigenous ecological knowledge in creating three hectares of new coastal wetland and wildlife habitat.

articles.title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro was convicted but the military appetite for a coup lingers
articles.trailText: Armed forces academies teach troops that military control would be better for the country, historians and experts say
articles.summary: After Bolsonaro supporters toppled dozens of power-line pylons in January 2023 using advanced sabotage tactics, the ex-president and seven allies, including five "black cap boys" army officers, were convicted for plotting to overthrow democracy—the first such convictions in Brazil’s history. Yet experts say institutional accountability is lacking: military academies still indoctrinate officers with a coup mentality dating to 1964, special-forces tactics persist among rioters, and unindicted conspirators remain at large. Without structural reforms, researchers warn, the risk of another coup endures.

articles.title: Almost 55,000 preschool children in Gaza acutely malnourished, Lancet study estimates
articles.trailText: Study shows clear link between Israeli aid restrictions and malnutrition among children aged between six months and five years
articles.summary: UNRWA-led Lancet study estimates 54,600 Gaza children under six are acutely malnourished, including 12,800 severely wasted, based on mid-2024 to mid-2025 MUAC screenings of 220,000 preschoolers. Malnutrition rates rose from 5% in Jan 2024 to 16% in mid-2025, doubling after Israel’s end-2024 aid restrictions and spiking during blockades, then briefly improving during a six-week ceasefire. Researchers link these “enormous nutritional consequences” to supply constraints and warn of rising child mortality without unimpeded humanitarian aid. The study underlines urgent need for sustained food, medical, economic and social services in Gaza.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: What the first phase of a Gaza peace plan will bring
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas will see the release of hostages and the withdrawal of most of Israel’s troops
articles.summary: After two years of war, Israel and Hamas have agreed to the first phase of a US-brokered peace plan: a ceasefire, the release over coming days of 20 hostages in exchange for Palestinian detainees, and Israeli forces’ withdrawal from roughly 70% of Gaza. The 20-point proposal also calls for an amnesty for Hamas members, no future role for the group, a surge of humanitarian aid, reconstruction of essential infrastructure, and eventual transfer of governance to the Palestinian Authority. Trump hailed it as a step toward “everlasting peace,” while mediators warn the deal is fragile and hinges on full implementation.

articles.title: Tears of joy and celebratory gunfire: how Gaza and Israel reacted to news of ceasefire deal
articles.trailText: An initially improbable peace plan put forward by US president Donald Trump was on Thursday agreed to in its ‘initial phase’ by Israel and Hamas
articles.summary: Israel and Hamas have agreed to the ‘initial phase’ of Donald Trump’s improbable 21-point ceasefire plan after indirect talks in Sharm El Sheikh. Across Gaza—Gaza City, Khan Younis and Al-Mawasi—residents fired celebratory gunfire, wept and chanted “Allahu Akbar,” while in Tel Aviv families hugged, popped champagne and hailed the imminent release of up to 20 surviving hostages. Netanyahu called it a “great day,” preparing to approve a formal ceasefire, and Hamas pledged prisoner exchanges within 72 hours. But questions persist over demilitarization demands, future governance and ensuring humanitarian relief in the war-ravaged territory.

articles.title: ‘Humanitarian’ visa must be created for Pacific Islanders displaced by climate crisis, experts say
articles.trailText: Calls for reform to allow people across the Pacific threatened by climate crisis to more easily migrate, particularly to New Zealand
articles.summary: Amnesty International’s report calls for New Zealand to introduce a rights-based humanitarian visa for Pacific Islanders displaced by climate change, highlighting shortcomings in existing schemes. It highlights threats to clean water, food and housing caused by extreme weather and sea-level rise in low-lying states like Tuvalu and Kiribati, and an estimated 50,000 Islanders face displacement annually. Experts urge dedicated pathways, full residency options and labour mobility reforms that uphold human rights and dignity. The report notes past NZ proposals under Jacinda Ardern never materialized, current lotteries exclude older or disabled applicants, and cites Tuvalu’s Falepili Union treaty with Australia as a legal model.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Analysts flag Kremlin scare campaign against use of Tomahawks
articles.trailText: Russian lawmaker says of US missiles: ‘We will hurt those who cause us trouble’; Ukrainian counteroffensive causing heavy losses for Russia. What we know on day 1,324
articles.summary: The ISW warns Moscow’s “reflexive control” campaign, exemplified by senior Russian lawmaker Andrei Kartapolov’s threats, aims to deter US Tomahawk strikes by warning suppliers and users will be targeted. Deputy FM Sergei Ryabkov says momentum for a peace deal after Putin-Trump Alaska talks has “largely gone.” Ukraine’s counteroffensive in Donetsk, notably near Dobropillia, inflicts heavy Russian losses despite assaults around Kupiansk and Novopavlivka; Russia claims Novohryhorivka. Civilian deaths in Kherson, Sumy and Belgorod, power plant damage and 154 of 183 drones intercepted. Kyiv urges $1bn monthly US arms; Germany broadens drone-countermeasures; EU boosts hybrid-defence; Switzerland extends refugee status to March 2027.

articles.title: Trump says Gaza peace deal ‘very close’ and he may travel to Middle East in days
articles.trailText: US president optimistic after US, Qatari and Turkish officials join third day of indirect Israel-Hamas talks in Egypt
articles.summary: At the Sharm el-Sheikh talks on 8 October, US president Trump declared Gaza ceasefire negotiations 'very close' and raised the prospect of traveling to the Middle East this weekend. The third day of indirect Israel-Hamas talks in Egypt brought US envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner together with Qatari PM Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman al-Thani and Turkish intelligence head İbrahim Kalın. They aim to swap up to 48 remaining Israeli hostages for nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, disarm Hamas, end Israeli bombardment, and transfer Gaza governance to an international technocratic authority. Significant gaps persist over disarmament, troop withdrawal timelines, and force composition. Rightwing Israeli ministers oppose key prisoner releases. France will convene a parallel ministerial meeting on international stabilisation, aid and reconstruction.

articles.title: ‘The enemy of Israel’: Australian Gaza flotilla activist vows to return despite ‘humiliations’ in detention
articles.trailText: Juliet Lamont says she was beaten, groped and verbally abused by Israeli prison guards but will try again to ‘break the siege’ on Gaza
articles.summary: Juliet Lamont, a 54-year-old Australian documentary maker, was detained aboard the Global Sumud flotilla after Israeli forces intercepted her vessel in the Mediterranean. She describes freezing in a windowless prison van, witnessing ominous banners (“The eternal state never forgets”) at Ketziot, and enduring cavity searches, verbal abuse, and semiautomatic weapons trained on detainees. Fellow activist Bianca Webb-Pullman recounts a “new Gaza” propaganda poster and the humiliation of rowing for aid. Despite denied medical care, legal access, and personal safety, both vow to attempt another Gaza aid mission.

articles.title: Iran has taken care of millions of Afghan refugees with little international support | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Ayoub Heidari of the Iranian embassy contests the claim that hundreds of thousands of Afghan refugees may be released into neighbouring countries
articles.summary: Iran has hosted millions of Afghan refugees for over 40 years, providing education, healthcare and humanitarian aid despite unilateral sanctions and minimal international support. Contrary to a recent report suggesting Iran plans to release hundreds of thousands of refugees into neighboring countries, embassy spokesman Ayoub Heidari asserts no such policy exists. He emphasizes that Iran’s refugee approach is based on humanitarian principles, respect for dignity and cooperation with international bodies, warning that unverified claims risk misrepresenting the country’s decades-long support for Afghan refugees.

articles.title: Jamaica imposes local curfews after two deadly shootings rattle the island
articles.trailText: Shootings left six people dead, including a four-year-old, and nine others injured amid suspected gang violence
