articles.summary: Jamaica imposed curfews in Linstead, St Catherine parish, and Kingston after two suspected gang shootings killed six people—including a four-year-old and two nine-year-olds—and injured nine others. Unidentified gunmen opened fire Tuesday night in Kingston, later fatally wounding a teenager, while a Sunday attack north-west of the capital left five dead. Prime Minister Andrew Holness, denouncing “criminal terrorism,” visited victims’ families and urged national intolerance of gang violence. Police commissioner Kevin Blake called for community support to apprehend suspects. Linstead’s curfew runs 6pm Monday to 6pm Wednesday. Homicides are down 41% year-on-year to 522 as of October 4, though officials say more must be done.

articles.title: ‘Veggie burgers’ could be off EU menu as MEPs back renaming plant-based foods
articles.trailText: Proponents say move would strengthen position of farmers in supply chain but critics dismiss it as ‘hotdog populism’
articles.summary: European Parliament MEPs voted 355–247 to reserve meat-related terms like “burger”, “steak” and “sausage” exclusively for animal products, barring plant-based makers. Backed by French farmer-MEP Céline Imart to strengthen farmers’ position and mirror dairy-naming rules, it still requires approval by EU member states. Greens, major retailers (Aldi, Lidl) and consumer groups condemn it as populism that misleads shoppers, citing a 2020 EU survey showing 70% grasp vegetarian labels. The EPP is divided; a prior French ban was overturned by the ECJ in 2024.

articles.title: Outgoing French PM says ‘path still exists’ to avoid snap elections
articles.trailText: Sébastien Lecornu says majority of MPs willing to seek agreement on budget and avoid further instability
articles.summary: Caretaker PM Sébastien Lecornu says most MPs ‘reject the idea’ of snap elections and that a ‘path still exists’ for President Macron to appoint a new premier within 48 hours. He’s held talks with centre‐right, Socialist, Green and Communist groups on a 2026 budget deal—despite a projected deficit above 5.5% of GDP—and floated suspending the unpopular pension reform (raising retirement age from 62 to 64) as a bargaining chip. Far‐right RN and radical left LFI vow to block any government tied to Macron, leaving any coalition fragile.

articles.title: Israel halts another Gaza aid flotilla as MEPs demand activists’ release
articles.trailText: New group of vessels intercepted in international waters while at least seven people from previous flotilla still held
articles.summary: Israel’s navy intercepted nine aid vessels in international waters 120 nm off Gaza, boarding an FFC/Thousand Madleens flotilla carrying medics, supplies and a floating hospital. The seizure came days after over 450 activists, including Greta Thunberg and at least seven still detained, were held from a previous Gaza Sumud flotilla. 82 Council of Europe parliamentarians and MEPs demand their immediate, unconditional release, decrying violations of international law. Israel insists the naval blockade is legal; Turkey labels the action piracy. Detainees report abuse and denial of care; Israel denies mistreatment.

articles.title: Drone dilemma: How Russia’s ‘hybrid war’ is using fear to destabilise Europe
articles.trailText: As Moscow’s suspected drone incursions threaten chaos, Europe faces a dilemma: respond and risk escalation, or face accusations of weakness
articles.summary: Suspected Russian drones forced Munich, Copenhagen and Aalborg airports to close, part of a new wave of “grey zone” hybrid attacks across Germany, Poland and the Baltics. EU leaders face a dilemma: shoot down drones and risk escalation, or avoid action and appear weak. Ursula von der Leyen’s proposed “drone wall” lacks unanimous support—Germany’s Friedrich Merz, France’s Emmanuel Macron and Italy’s Giorgia Meloni remain unconvinced. Experts warn the operations aim not only to disrupt but to sow fear and erode trust in democratic institutions. They urge open communication and emulating Nordic and Baltic preparedness to limit panic as Europe confronts Russia’s subversive tactics.

articles.title: Gisèle Pelicot tells appeal trial she never gave consent to man convicted of rape
articles.trailText: Woman says at retrial of Husamettin Dogan that ‘no victim should feel shame’ as court shown video evidence
articles.summary: In her appeal retrial of Husamettin Dogan, Gisèle Pelicot, 72, reaffirmed she never consented to being raped while comatose after being drugged by ex-husband Dominique Pelicot, who orchestrated decade-long assaults by dozens of men in Mazan. Dogan was shown smiling in video footage of her unconscious body but denies rape, calling it “sex scenes.” Pelicot, who waived anonymity in the 51-defendant trial, urged victims to feel no shame and detailed lasting consequences: four STDs requiring treatment and an unresolved medical anomaly. She criticized Dogan’s denial and highlighted her daughter’s parallel abuse, praising her for founding a drug-assisted-rape support group. Verdict expected Thursday.

articles.title: Germany draws up law to allow police to shoot down drones
articles.trailText: Cabinet agrees draft legislation after spate of sightings, including over Munich airport
articles.summary: Germany’s cabinet has approved a draft law empowering federal police to shoot down unidentified drones posing immediate threats after multiple incursions over Munich airport, hospitals, canals and armaments plants. Chancellor Friedrich Merz says the rapid measure, now awaiting parliamentary approval, will bolster security amid suspected Russian ’hybrid war’ tactics. Interior Minister Alexander Dobrindt will form a dedicated counter-drone unit with guidance from Ukraine and Israel, clarifying police versus military roles for smaller and larger UAVs. Germany recorded 172 drone air-traffic disruptions to September.

articles.title: Paraglider bomb attack by Myanmar military kills at least 20 at protest
articles.trailText: Dozens more injured by night strike on anti-government demonstration held during national holiday
articles.summary: At least 20 people, including children, were killed and dozens injured when Myanmar’s military dropped bombs from a motorised paraglider on a sit-in protest in Chaung U, Sagaing region, during the Thadingyut festival. Witnesses described scattered body parts and confusion between civilians and anti-junta fighters. The low-tech aerial device, deployed twice in one evening, underscores a stepped-up campaign against opposition-held areas. Amnesty International warned of unchecked war crimes as the junta, which denies responsibility, presses on with a disputed December election.

articles.title: Polls and politics point to a sea change in US views on Israel. Will it matter?
articles.trailText: Fueled by dissent over the war in Gaza, the US public’s views are changing – and support for the Palestinians is rising
articles.summary: Two years after Hamas’s 7 October 2023 attack, US public support for Israel has plunged to record lows as Gaza war dissent mounts. A Pew survey finds 59% now view Israel negatively and 39% believe it’s “going too far”; other polls show pro-Palestinian sympathies edging out pro-Israel views (NYT/Siena 35% vs 34%) and 45% alleging genocide (Economist/YouGov). Politicians from Abdul El-Sayed in Michigan to New York’s Zohran Mamdani openly decry Gaza operations, AIPAC’s influence wanes, and both Democrats and younger Republicans signal a durable shift that may reshape elections and US foreign policy.

articles.title: Brazilian governor apologies after joking about deadly methanol poisoning crisis
articles.trailText: São Paulo’s teetotal governor, Tarcísio de Freitas, says of scandal that has killed three that he would only worry when ‘they start faking Coca-Cola’
articles.summary: São Paulo’s teetotal governor, Tarcísio de Freitas, apologized after joking he’d only worry about a deadly methanol poisoning crisis— which has killed at least three— when counterfeiters start faking Coca-Cola. A Bolsonaro ally and presidential hopeful, Freitas made the comment at a press conference amid warnings from Health Minister Alexandre Padilha to avoid white spirits. The quip went viral, drawing parallels to Bolsonaro’s Covid-era remarks. Freitas said he “cracked a joke,” claimed misinterpretation, and asked forgiveness from bereaved families and affected businesses.

articles.title: ‘I don’t feel safe any more’: Dearborn’s Arab Americans on rising Islamophobia
articles.trailText: Residents in Michigan city on edge as threats against their community rise, and some are reassessing their support for Trump
articles.summary: In Dearborn, Michigan — the first US city with an Arab American majority — a 73-year-old man’s October 2024 knife attack on 7-year-old Saida Sharhan has underscored a spike in Islamophobic violence: mosque-burn threats, terror plots and online vitriol. CAIR recorded a record 8,658 US Islamophobia complaints last year while synagogues also heighten security amid rising antisemitism. Many Arab Americans who backed Trump for peace are now reassessing support as Gaza’s death toll mounts, local hate crimes climb and community protests grow.

articles.title: The birth of France’s Fifth Republic – archive, October 1958
articles.trailText: On 4 October 1958, France adopted the constitution of the Fifth Republic, which established its current system of government
articles.summary: On 4 October 1958 France’s Fifth Republic was born via referendum (31 066 502 yes vs 5 419 749 no) on a constitution engineered by Charles de Gaulle and Michel Debré. It replaced the unstable Fourth Republic with a hybrid regime combining a five-year directly elected president—empowered to dissolve parliament, reshuffle cabinets and invoke emergency powers—and a parliamentary system. Framed by the Algerian insurrection and fears of executive overreach, the new charter extended state authority, promised stability and reshaped France’s ties with overseas territories. De Gaulle hailed the 85% approval and high turnout as a mandate to restore French greatness and manage decolonisation; only French Guinea rejected the plan, opting for independence.

articles.title: Starmer targets inflammatory chants at Palestine protests for further curbs
articles.trailText: PM says Labour will address suggestions of antisemitic hate as he orders review of protest policing powers
articles.summary: On 8 October 2025, following a terror attack at a Manchester synagogue, PM Keir Starmer ordered the home secretary to conduct a comprehensive review of public order powers—targeting inflammatory, potentially antisemitic chants like “globalise the intifada” at pro-Palestinian protests. The review may broaden recent measures enabling police to consider the cumulative impact of repeat demonstrations and reroute, restrict, or ban events under sections 12 and 14 of the Public Order Act 1986. Starmer, in talks with Jewish community leaders, plans Whitehall-wide reforms to enhance enforcement, despite civil liberties groups warning that curbing specific speech threatens the right to protest.

articles.title: ‘War is a business’: the Colombian mercenaries training Sudan’s child fighters to ‘go and get killed’
articles.trailText: A soldier of fortune tells of lucrative contracts, the siege of El Fasher and training child fighters to ‘go and get killed’
articles.summary: Carlos, one of over 300 Colombian ex-soldiers contracted via UAE-backed firms, arrived in Sudan to fight for the RSF. He describes training mostly child recruits in assault rifles, machine guns and RPGs—“to go and get killed”—before deploying them to the besieged North Darfur capital of El Fasher, under siege for 500 days. Mercenaries have also occupied the Zamzam displacement camp, linked to RSF assaults that killed up to 1,500 civilians. Paid $2,600 monthly, Colombians leverage decades of US-trained jungle warfare. Observers warn entrenched economic incentives and Colombia’s flawed military pension system fuel a resurging global mercenary trade.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: How to fight the right on reparations – and ‘rewire’ the architecture of inequality
articles.trailText: In this weeks newsletter: Many paint reparations as impossible, unprecedented, even absurd – world experts tell a different story
articles.summary: Amid Black History Month debates in the UK, reparations for transatlantic slavery face swift political backlash—Kier Starmer deeming them ‘not on the agenda’ after Pacific trip demands—yet experts like Kojo Koram argue reparative justice extends beyond cash, reshaping global power, economic and legal frameworks. Britain previously compensated enslavers (£450bn equivalent) while Caribbean nations still suffer colonial debts and structural adjustment constraints. Campaigners cite models like Caricom’s ten-point plan—museums, debt cancellation, health and education programs—and warn momentum is growing, linking historic redress to future-facing challenges such as climate policy, debt restructuring and institutional racism.

articles.title: ‘I can touch the clouds’: how it feels to cross the world’s highest bridge
articles.trailText: Opened last month in China, the Huajiang Grand Canyon Bridge sits 625 metres above the valley below
articles.summary: Opened on 28 September 2025, the new Huajiang Grand Canyon Bridge in Guizhou, China, holds records as the world’s highest (625 m above the Beipan River) and longest mountainous deck (1.42 km of its nearly 3 km span). It slashes canyon travel from two hours to two minutes on the Guizhou S57 highway and boasts glass-walled viewing platforms, a 580 m-drop glass walkway, a lift to a November-opening café, bungee jumps, slack-lining and planned BASE-jump events. Capped at 5,000 daily visitors, it has fueled local guesthouse bookings and viral social-media videos praising its “cloud-touching” vistas, though some users criticize its cost, parking and unfinished facilities.

articles.title: New Zealand oceans warming 34% faster than global average, putting homes and industry at risk, report finds
articles.trailText: NZ$180bn worth of housing and $26bn of infrastructure at risk of flooding and storm damage, new government report finds
articles.summary: New Zealand’s oceans are warming 34% faster than the global average, driving sea-level rise, intensifying marine heatwaves and acidification, the Our Marine Environment 2025 report finds. With 219,000 coastal homes (NZ$180 billion) and NZ$26 billion in infrastructure at flood and storm-damage risk, some regions face 20–30 cm sea-level rise by 2050, turning 100-year storms into annual events. Shifting currents and a 120 km westward Subtropical Front threaten ecosystems, species and the NZ$1.1 billion fishing and aquaculture sector. Experts warn gaps in understanding climate–ecosystem interactions hinder resilience planning.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Shadow fleet is launchpad for Russian drones harassing Europe – Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: Tankers being used for ‘reconnaissance and sabotage’, says Ukrainian president; drones hit faraway refinery in Siberia. What we know on day 1,323
articles.summary: President Zelenskyy warns Russia’s illicit “shadow fleet” of oil tankers is being used for revenue, reconnaissance and sabotage—launching drones that harassed European airports, exemplified by the Boracay tanker boarding in France. Kyiv launched a drone strike on Tyumen’s Siberian refinery, its deepest strike yet, and fires still rage at Feodosiya oil terminal in occupied Crimea. Zaporizhzhia NPP remains on emergency generators; Russia claims a Ukrainian drone hit Novovoronezh’s cooling tower. Ukraine plans a 30% boost in gas imports after 26 Russian attacks. Poland refuses extradition of a Nord Stream suspect, and Taiwan refiners are ready to halt Russian naphtha purchases if the EU insists.

articles.title: ‘It made my day more meaningful’: the Japanese gen Zers attempting a two-hour limit on smartphone use
articles.trailText: Authorities in Japan are taking action against excessive phone time – but what is it like to restrict scrolling to 120 minutes a day?
articles.summary: In Toyoake, a town of 69,000, officials passed a nonbinding ordinance limiting daily smartphone use to two hours, aiming to combat rising online addiction and sleep deprivation among Gen Z. Office worker Shoki Moriyama cut his habitual eight hours to 1h50m, repurposing time for reading and gym; colleague Tomomi Hanaoka also reclaimed free hours. Students Akari Saito and Yuri advocated self-set rules and focus on screen-time quality, while Aya slashed her eight-hour average by 60%. With youths averaging just over five hours online daily, Mayor Masafumi Koki says the measure’s true power is in prompting reflection on sleep, family time and wellbeing.

articles.title: One year’s worth of bread lost in UK to wrecked harvests since 2020, report finds
articles.trailText: Worsening droughts and floods have destroyed wheat for 4bn loaves of bread and forced record levels of imports
articles.summary: Since 2020 extreme droughts and floods have wiped 7m tonnes of UK wheat, enough for 4bn loaves or a year's supply, ECIU reports. Two of the decade's three worst harvests fell in 2020 and 2024, and 2025 faces further declines amid record heat, dry springs and irrigation bans. Imports doubled last autumn, cutting wheat self-sufficiency from 96% in 2023 to 79% in 2024 and costing farmers billions. Growers call for revived green support schemes, while ECIU warns only net-zero emissions can curb escalating climate-driven losses.

articles.title: US delegation led by Steve Witkoff due to arrive in Egypt for Gaza talks
articles.trailText: White House says is it important ‘that we get this done quickly’ as indirect talks restart in Sharm el-Sheikh
articles.summary: On the conflict’s second anniversary, a US delegation led by envoy Steve Witkoff, joined by Jared Kushner, arrived in Sharm el-Sheikh to resume indirect Gaza ceasefire talks under Donald Trump’s 20-point proposal, broadly accepted by Netanyahu and Hamas but contested on disarmament, force withdrawal zones and governance. Egyptian FM Abdelaty says focus is a ceasefire, release of 47 hostages and Palestinian prisoners, and humanitarian aid via UN. Israel vows to crush Hamas; Hamas rejects foreign administration and arms surrender. Negotiators debate security forces, technocratic oversight by Trump/Blair, and prisoner-exchange details.

articles.title: China ‘spies’ case was dropped after government failed to provide evidence of Beijing threat
articles.trailText: Ministers and officials did not provide statements that China was threat despite ‘many months’ of effort to obtain them
articles.summary: Last month the CPS unexpectedly dropped espionage charges against researchers Christopher Cash and Christopher Berry after prosecutors could not secure government witness statements confirming China as a threat to UK national security—a legal requirement under the 1911 Official Secrets Act clarified by recent case law. DPP Stephen Parkinson told select committee chairs that despite “many months” of requests, no minister or official provided the necessary evidence, making conviction impossible. Government lawyers argued China was never formally designated a threat, and Downing Street denies any deliberate withholding of testimony. The episode exposes gaps in UK security legislation and policy.

articles.title: Gisèle Pelicot’s ex-husband tells court man convicted of rape knew she was sedated
articles.trailText: Dominique Pelicot says Husamettin Dogan’s attempt to overturn conviction in the mass rape case ‘is indecent’
articles.summary: Ex-husband Dominique Pelicot, 73, testified in the Nîmes appeal that rape convict Husamettin Dogan, 44, knew Gisèle Pelicot was sedated when he raped her in June 2019. Pelicot, serving 20 years for drugging his wife and inviting dozens to rape her between 2011–20, said he explicitly told Dogan on a chatroom and by phone to expect an unconscious victim. Dogan drove 60km to their Mazan home, followed detailed instructions—wash hands, no scent, no tobacco, undress outside—and stayed two hours filming the assault. Pelicot branded Dogan’s bid to overturn his nine-year sentence “indecent.” Trial continues.

articles.title: Palestine protests go ahead across UK on second anniversary of 7 October
articles.trailText: March through London and campus sit-ins in Glasgow and Edinburgh proceed despite prime minister’s pleas
articles.summary: Across the UK, pro-Palestine student-led demonstrations marked the second anniversary of 7 October, defying Keir Starmer’s plea to cancel “un-British” rallies. In London hundreds marched from central universities, draped in keffiyehs and Palestinian flags, listing Gaza casualties, while a German student counter-protested under an Israeli flag. Similar sit-ins took place at Glasgow and Edinburgh campuses despite university objections. Political figures—including Bridget Phillipson, Kemi Badenoch and Robert Jenrick—condemned the timing; Jewish student leaders voiced pain over overshadowed memorials. Protesters asserted their right to free speech, denouncing the ongoing Gaza “genocide”.

articles.title: ‘It broke the entire family apart’: Israel’s 7 October trauma remains plain to see
articles.trailText: As Israelis gather to mark two years since the Hamas attack, in Gaza there is hope a ceasefire could end their own despair
articles.summary: Two years after Hamas’s 7 October 2023 assault killed 1,200 Israelis and took 251 hostages, hundreds gathered at Nova festival and kibbutz memorials, where grieving families wipe sand from pictures and affix red flowers under portraits of the 400 victims. Survivors recount frantic escapes; communities like Be’eri remain half-ruined, with some new housing built amidst charred remains. Meanwhile Israel’s war on Gaza has killed over 67,000 Palestinians amid famine warnings and genocide accusations. Displaced Gazans endure repeated flight and loss, yet budding ceasefire talks in Egypt offer cautious hope.

articles.title: Denmark plans social media ban for under-15s as PM warns phones ‘stealing childhood’
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen links social media use to anxiety, depression and lack of concentration
articles.summary: Danish PM Mette Frederiksen will ban social media for under-15s next year, citing links to anxiety, depression and poor concentration. Parents could grant access from age 13. The move follows February’s school phone ban and aligns Denmark with Australia (under-16 ban) and Norway (raising limit to 15). Frederiksen highlighted that 94% of seventh graders join platforms before 13 and 60% of boys see no friends offline. Digital minister Caroline Stage hailed the policy as a breakthrough to safeguard children’s wellbeing amid global calls for an EU digital adulthood age.

articles.title: Macron under pressure to call snap parliamentary elections or resign
articles.trailText: French president’s former allies join opponents in demanding he act to end a spiralling political crisis
articles.summary: Facing a hung parliament since 2024’s snap vote, Macron is urged by ex-PMs Édouard Philippe, Gabriel Attal and outgoing Sébastien Lecornu to call early legislative or presidential elections—or resign—to break France’s worst political impasse since 1958. After Lecornu’s 14-hour cabinet collapsed and RN refused talks, Macron gave him a last chance to rally support for 2026 austerity budget amid soaring debt and deficits. Opposition from the far right, left and centrist allies, plus Le Monde’s “tragic farce” verdict, deepens pressure ahead of 2027 ballot.

articles.title: Burning down the house: Milei plays rock star as Argentina economy crashes
articles.trailText: Facing protests and scandal, Argentina’s ‘rock star president’ performs in Buenos Aires, saying: ‘I’m human’
articles.summary: Argentina’s libertarian president Javier Milei, hailed for steep austerity that briefly tamed triple-digit inflation, now faces a political and economic meltdown: peso sell-offs have drained reserves, a scandal involving his sister-chief of staff Karina Milei fueled protests, and his party suffered electoral defeats. Furthermore, ally José Luis Espert withdrew after admitting a $200,000 payment from an alleged drug trafficker. A US-backed $20bn lifeline underscores the crisis. Milei’s rock-style concert at Buenos Aires’s Movistar Arena was a symbolic bid to reignite support ahead of perilous midterms.

articles.title: Diplomacy’s lowest point: how the Israel-Gaza conflict was mishandled
articles.trailText: In two years there have been many versions of a ‘day after’ plan for Gaza and many obstacles to overcome
articles.summary: After 730 days of failure and no breakthroughs, diplomacy over the Israel-Gaza war has reached its lowest point since 1939. US Democrats and Republicans alike misread Israeli dynamics—Biden’s empathy for Gazans fell short, Trump leveraged unpredictability—and ceded the process to French and Saudi initiatives. A UN conference produced a New York declaration linking ceasefire to Hamas disarmament, PA reform, elections and an international force, but Israel and the US voted it down. Subsequent Trump-Blair plans blurred withdrawal terms and excluded Gaza-West Bank unity. Hamas’s conditional acceptance offered hostage releases but no timeline. Arab, Western and global south outrage and rising dissent among American Jews highlight the moral and political breakdown of international diplomacy.

articles.title: Israelis gather to mark two years since 7 October Hamas attack that killed 1,200
articles.trailText: Commemorations held in kibbutzim whose members were killed or kidnapped as Tel Aviv rally to call for hostages’ release
articles.summary: Israelis convened nationwide on 7 October for the second anniversary of Hamas’s 2023 assault in southern Israel that killed about 1,200 people and abducted 251. Unofficial ceremonies in kibbutzim, notably at the Nova festival site where over 370 died, began at 6:29 am with silence. A Tel Aviv rally urged the government to secure hostages’ release amid indirect Egypt-brokered talks on swapping nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners and Israeli withdrawals. The anniversary coincides with mounting destruction in Gaza: over 67,000 Palestinians killed, famine threats, and international genocide inquiries, even as hopes for a ceasefire grow.

articles.title: Pope Leo to visit Turkey and Lebanon on first overseas trip
articles.trailText: Pontiff expected to appeal for peace across the Middle East and speak about the persecution of Christians in region
articles.summary: Pope Leo, elected in May after Francis’s death, will make his first overseas trip to Turkey (Nov 27–30) and Lebanon (Nov 30–Dec 2) upon invitations from state and church leaders. He will appeal for peace across the Middle East, highlight Christian persecution and back efforts for a Gaza ceasefire. In Turkey he meets Orthodox Patriarch Bartholomew to mark the 1,700th anniversary of the Council of Nicaea; Lebanon’s itinerary is pending. His predecessor Francis had planned similar visits but was sidelined by health. Leo also received a White House invitation from President Trump via US Vice-President Vance.

articles.title: How would tougher powers for police affect protests in England and Wales?
articles.trailText: The home secretary has announced plans to allow officers to consider the impact of repeated demonstrations
articles.summary: Home secretary Shabana Mahmood proposes new powers letting police factor in the “cumulative impact” of past demonstrations to impose tougher conditions on marches and static protests in England and Wales. Currently marches require six days’ notice of route and organisers, while static protests need no notice; police may restrict protests under the PCSC Act 2022 for serious disorder, damage, disruption, intimidation or noise, imposing limits on route, timing and size. Bans need home secretary approval and face a high threshold. Recent PCSC and Public Order Act 2023 measures expanded stop-and-search, noise triggers and public nuisance offences, chiefly targeting climate protesters. Labour’s primary-legislation route revives a court-quashed Braverman bid and is expected to be legally challenged by Liberty.

articles.title: The Zionist consensus among US Jews has collapsed. Something new is emerging | Shaul Magid
articles.trailText: Two years after the 7 October massacre and the onset of Israel’s slaughter in Gaza, American Jewry has been profoundly transformed
articles.summary: In the two years since the October 7 massacre and Israel’s Gaza campaign, the half-century Zionist consensus in American Jewry has fractured. Liberal Zionism’s post-1967 hegemony is eroding under Gaza’s destruction, driving some Jews rightward in defense of Israel and others leftward into non- or anti-Zionist identity. New institutions—from Jewish Voice for Peace, IfNotNow and non-Zionist day schools to Jewish Currents and campus groups—signal a generational pluralism that rejects Zionism as gatekeeper. Magid argues this schism, though painful, is essential for a diverse Jewish future. It’s sparked feuds, job losses, and institutional reevaluations, marking a pivotal shift towards pluralistic Jewish life.

articles.title: Venezuela on edge over Trump regime change whispers: ‘If it does happen we are ready’
articles.trailText: Allies of President Nicolás Maduro vow to resist any military intervention but experts suspect Venezuela’s leaders were rattled by Trump’s decision to bomb Iran
articles.summary: After Trump’s designation of Maduro as a narcoterrorist, deployment of warships, drug-smuggling boat strikes and a $50m bounty, Venezuelan leaders—Vice-President Delcy Rodríguez, Mayor Carmen Meléndez and Interior Minister Diosdado Cabello—launched nationwide drills and weapons training to resist a possible US intervention. Analysts say Trump’s Iran bombing rattled Chavistas and suspect the anti-narcotics campaign aims at regime change. Opposition figures like María Corina Machado and Leopoldo López welcome external pressure, while experts warn a US invasion could spark prolonged guerrilla warfare. A graduated escalation—marines, airstrikes on narco-planes or a multi-pronged assault—is under debate as Caracas braces for conflict.

articles.title: Sunder Katwala on race, patriotism and flag-waving: ‘The far right is vocal and angry because it is shrinking’
articles.trailText: The director of British Future has spent his career trying to find common ground when it comes to race and immigration. He describes his own experience of racism – and why he’s still hopeful for the UK
articles.summary: British Future director Sunder Katwala, of Indian and Irish heritage, contrasts visible multicultural everyday life in Dartford with far-right flag-waving rallies he calls “vocal and angry” because the movement is shrinking. He champions a “bridging” patriotism and outlines balanced immigration reforms—cracking down on small-boat crossings, creating safe legal routes and a US-style “routes and returns” mechanism—to undercut people-traffickers. His polling shows broad public support for this “compassion and control” approach. Katwala also warns that online hate, amplified by figures like Elon Musk, has spilled offline and urges legal enforcement against racism.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine activists ask court to make genocide ruling during battle over Sydney Opera House protest
articles.trailText: Palestine Action Group argues ongoing killing in Gaza means Sydney march scheduled for Sunday has prerequisite ‘seriousness and urgency’
articles.summary: The Palestine Action Group and Jews Against Occupation have asked NSW’s Supreme Court to authorize an Oct 12 march from Hyde Park to the Sydney Opera House, arguing Israel’s actions in Gaza amount to genocide and must be recognized to demonstrate the protest’s seriousness and urgency. They rely on Chris Sidoti’s affidavit and a UN inquiry report. Police cite safety, crowd size and Opera House rules; an appeal court will decide. Jewish groups plan to oppose, referencing past antisemitic incidents.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: What new plans to curb pro-Palestine Action demonstrations mean for our right to protest
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: New home secretary Shabana Mahmood has announced proposals to further curtail pro-Palestine Action protests – but what do they mean, and will they work?
articles.summary: New Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood announced amendments to sections 12 and 14 of the Public Order Act 1986 empowering police to factor in the cumulative impact of repeated protests, and reroute or shut them down if deemed seriously disruptive. Framed as a response to pro-Palestine marches igniting anxiety in British Jewish communities after the Manchester synagogue attack, the proposals echo Suella Braverman’s aborted Extinction Rebellion crackdown. LSE expert Dr Richard Martin warns that while Labour plans higher thresholds and parliamentary scrutiny, broad definitions of “serious disruption” risk uneven enforcement and leave protesters with limited grounds for judicial challenge. Critics note far-right rallies appear exempt.

articles.title: A place of ghosts and memories: kibbutz residents ponder return after 7 October
articles.trailText: Two years after Hamas raid, Israel has said the Holit community can go back – but memories are still raw
articles.summary: Following Hamas’s deadly 7 October 2023 raid that killed 15 of 230 residents—including two Thai farm workers—and took six hostage, Holit kibbutz stands abandoned and dust-covered just over a mile from Gaza. Barred from returning for two years, survivors like 23-year-old Shir Matias and mother of three Nir Sultan now face trauma versus hope as the government sets next July for resettlement. The community is building a new kindergarten, courting families, but still endures nearby bombings and raw memories.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Trump says he would want to know Kyiv’s plans for Tomahawk missiles before supplying them
articles.trailText: US president says he has ‘sort of made a decision’ on whether to supply long-range missiles; Denmark to step up checks on oil tankers after drone sightings. What we know on day 1,322
articles.summary: On day 1,322 of Russia’s war, US president Donald Trump said he’d need clarity on Kyiv’s intended use of long-range Tomahawk missiles before approving their supply, while Ukrainian leader Zelenskiy urged allies to re-export them. Denmark will tighten inspections of oil tankers in the Baltic-North Sea corridor to curb Russia’s “shadow fleet” after drone sightings. Ukraine reported downing 251 drones overnight and struck a major ammunition plant in Nizhny Novgorod, a Crimean oil terminal and a frontline depot; Russia said a Ukrainian strike killed two in Belgorod. Kyiv discovered over 100,000 foreign parts in Russian drones.

articles.title: New Zealand foreign minister Winston Peters’ home vandalised ‘during a protest’
articles.trailText: Man charged as police allege a window was smashed in a rare act of violence targeted at a New Zealand politician’s home
articles.summary: Winston Peters’ Auckland home was vandalized during a protest when a man used a crowbar to smash a window and left a “welcome to the real world” sign, injuring their dog with shattered glass. The suspect surrendered and faces burglary charges in Auckland District Court. Police stressed they support lawful protest but condemn property damage. Rare violence against New Zealand politicians drew condemnation from Labour leader Chris Hipkins and Green co-leader Chlöe Swarbrick. The attack follows pro-Palestine demonstrations against Peters’ refusal to recognize Palestinian statehood and pressure over detained Kiwi activists in Israel.

articles.title: Man convicted in Gisèle Pelicot case says he ‘never intended’ to rape her
articles.trailText: Appeal trial begins for Husamettin Dogan, the only man out of 51 in French case to challenge conviction
articles.summary: Husamettin Dogan, 44, the sole appellant among 51 men convicted of raping Gisèle Pelicot, told the Nîmes appeals court he “never intended” to rape the unconscious 72-year-old and had no knowledge she was drugged by her husband. Dogan, an unemployed builder originally jailed for nine years after video evidence, admitted sexual contact but denied intent. Pelicot—who waived anonymity again—watched with supporters as the court reviewed her ex-husband’s 20-year sentence for orchestrating decades of abuse. A verdict is due Thursday.

articles.title: Judge killed in courtroom shooting in Albania
articles.trailText: Man opens fire in Tirana court, killing judge and injuring two other people, and is arrested after fleeing scene
articles.summary: In Tirana on Oct. 6, a defendant in a property dispute opened fire at the Court of Appeal, fatally wounding presiding Judge Astrit Kalaja—who died en route to hospital—and injuring a father and son. Police swiftly arrested the shooter at the scene; the injured are hospitalized in stable condition. Prime Minister Edi Rama described it as a “tragic event” and called for tougher sentences on gun crimes. President Bajram Begaj condemned the attack as an assault on the justice system. Data from the South Eastern and Eastern Europe Clearinghouse show 213 firearm incidents in Albania during Jan–Jun 2025.

articles.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza war
articles.trailText: Hamas’s acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between camps
articles.summary: Israel and Hamas began indirect talks in Cairo on a US 20-point ceasefire plan targeting an end to the nearly two-year Gaza war. Phase one covers release of 48 hostages within 72 hours in exchange for almost 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, partial Israeli troop withdrawal and Hamas’s handover of power. Egypt, Qatar and US mediators, with ICRC support, have sparked cautious optimism despite disputes over political detainees, disarmament logistics and ongoing Israeli strikes. Subsequent phases will address Gaza’s governance, arms and a pathway to statehood.

articles.title: What happened on a chaotic day in French politics – and what next?
articles.trailText: Sébastien Lecornu agreed two days’ extension to his 27-day premiership in last-ditch effort to form government
articles.summary: After just 27 days in office, France’s prime minister Sébastien Lecornu resigned along with his cabinet, becoming the shortest-lived premier in modern history, blaming partisan intransigence over an austerity budget in a hung parliament split among left, far right and Macron’s centre-right alliance. President Macron asked Lecornu to stay on for two more days to salvage consensus. Markets slid on the uncertainty (CAC40 -2%). Faced with budget and deficit crises, Macron now must choose among appointing a fourth PM, dissolving the assembly or risking a far-right takeover ahead of 2027.

articles.title: Gaza flotilla members allege beatings and insults in Israeli detention
articles.trailText: Some of those held say guns were pointed at them, they were threatened with dogs and deprived of sleep
articles.summary: International activists, journalists and lawyers deported after intercepting the Global Sumud flotilla allege systematic physical and verbal abuse in Israeli detention: beatings, rifles pointed at heads, dogs set on them, sleep and medication deprivation, insults, forced watching of Hamas attack footage and symbolic humiliation. Notables include Italian journalists Saverio Tommasi and Lorenzo D’Agostino, former Barcelona mayor Ada Colau and activist Greta Thunberg, who was held in a bedbug-infested cell and coerced into holding flags. Israel’s foreign ministry denies the claims. Deportations have reached 341, prompting protests from Australia, New Zealand and Greece, while a new flotilla carrying medical staff and journalists is en route to Gaza.

articles.title: Brazil’s president asks US to scrap tariffs in ‘friendly’ call with Trump
articles.trailText: Presidents spoke on a video call as expert speculates that Haiti could be an area where the two leaders can cooperate
articles.summary: In their first extended conversation since January, Brazil’s President Lula and US President Trump held a 30-minute “friendly” video call, swapping numbers and recalling “excellent chemistry.” Lula urged Trump to lift 50% tariffs on Brazilian imports and sanctions tied to efforts to block the coup trial of ex-president Bolsonaro, and invited him to November’s Cop30 climate summit in Belém. Trump welcomed the exchange, focusing on trade and promising further talks. Analysts say the bilateral rift may linger but note potential cooperation, especially a UN-backed security mission in Haiti.

articles.title: Macron asks outgoing French PM to make last-ditch effort to resolve political crisis
articles.trailText: French president requests Sébastien Lecornu stay on for 48 hours after he quit complaining of ‘egos’
articles.summary: After PM Sébastien Lecornu resigned less than a month into office—the third premier to quit amid France’s hung parliament—President Macron asked him to stay 48 hours to negotiate a stabilization platform. Lecornu blamed partisan egos for blocking compromise. Macron must now choose between appointing a new PM or dissolving the National Assembly, risking divisive elections or a far-right government. Marine Le Pen’s RN calls for dissolution and readiness to govern, LFI demands Macron’s exit, while Les Républicains and Socialists propose compromise solutions. Markets tumbled on the reshuffle, as debt and deficit near EU limits with next year’s budget looming.

articles.title: ‘I hear him screaming’: brother of Israeli hostage describes agonising two years
articles.trailText: Guy Gilboa-Dalal was taken from Nova festival in 7 October Hamas attack that led to Israel’s devastating assault on Gaza
articles.summary: Gal Gilboa-Dalal has spent two years in agonizing limbo since his brother Guy was abducted by Hamas during the 7 October Nova festival attack near Gaza. With only around 20 hostages thought still alive and militants holding another 28 bodies, Gal endures relentless grief amid public campaigning and heated debate over military pressure versus ceasefire deals. He watches reunions with envy even as he backs Donald Trump’s latest hostage-release plan, fearing Israeli offensives in Gaza City could doom negotiations. Working remotely in tech support, sustained by a therapy dog and Avenged Sevenfold tattoo lyrics, Gal channels trauma into activism, determined to bring Guy home and fulfill their dream of visiting Japan together.

articles.title: ICC convicts former Sudan militia leader for war crimes in Darfur
articles.trailText: Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman, known as Ali Kushayb, found guilty over atrocities
articles.summary: In the ICC’s first Darfur conviction, judges found Janjaweed commander Ali Muhammad Ali Abd-al-Rahman (aka Ali Kushayb) guilty on 27 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity. Presiding judge Joanna Korner detailed mass killings, gang rapes and forced executions—such as loading 50 civilians onto trucks, beating some with axes, then ordering their execution—concluding his personal involvement. Abd-al-Rahman, who denies being Kushayb, fled to the Central African Republic in 2020 before surrendering. Prosecutors tied him to Omar al-Bashir’s genocidal campaign that killed 300,000+ and displaced 2.5 million. Sentencing is pending amid Sudan’s ongoing army-RSF conflict.

articles.title: ‘A club nobody wanted to be a part of’: Families of Americans killed by Israel face uphill climb to justice
articles.trailText: Dozens of American citizens have been killed by Hamas and Israel – but the US government has taken a very different approach to the latter
articles.summary: Since 2003, about a dozen US citizens—from Rachel Corrie and Ayşenur Ezgi Eygi to Louisiana teen Tawfic Abdel Jabbar and Florida’s Sayfollah Musallet—have been killed by Israeli soldiers or settlers, yet none of their deaths has prompted independent US investigations. Families, joined by the Corries of Washington state, have pressed Congress to challenge Israel’s internal probes—decried as “whitewashes” by rights groups—and demand accountability, contrasting Washington’s vigorous terrorism charges against Hamas for killing over 40 Americans on 7 October 2023. Amid rising West Bank violence, meetings with legislators including Bernie Sanders and Jeff Merkley signal a shifting US political climate and calls for an impartial inquiry.

articles.title: Eswatini confirms arrival of 10 more people as part of US deportation deal
articles.trailText: African kingdom receives second group of third-country nationals in what NGOs and lawyers say is violation of human rights
articles.summary: Eswatini has received ten more third-country nationals deported by the US under a $5.1m agreement NGOs and lawyers say breaches human rights. The group���three Vietnamese, one Filipino, one Cambodian and four to six others—will be held separately while the government and IOM arrange repatriation. This follows July’s transfer of five men to a maximum-security prison. Local NGOs have taken the deal to court—twice delayed—and Human Rights Watch notes Eswatini agreed to take 160 deportees overall. Lawyers report detainees lack private counsel and remain held without charge.

articles.title: Fianna Fáil’s Jim Gavin withdraws from Irish presidential race
articles.trailText: Election becomes unpredictable two-horse contest after political novice quits over debt revelations
articles.summary: Fianna Fáil’s Jim Gavin, 54, a former Dublin football manager, aviator and military officer, abruptly quit Ireland’s presidential race after revelations he failed to refund a €3,300 rent overpayment from 16 years ago. His exit narrows the contest to Heather Humphreys, 62, a former Fine Gael minister criticized over housing and Irish-language record, and Catherine Connolly, 68, an independent left-wing MP backed by Sinn Féin. Gavin’s departure triggers a crisis for Fianna Fáil leader Micheál Martin and leaves voters to decide in the 24 October election under Ireland’s ranked-choice system.

articles.title: Mount Everest hikers describe ‘extreme’ conditions as huge rescue effort continues
articles.trailText: At least 200 people still stranded after unseasonally heavy snowfall during China’s Golden Week holiday
articles.summary: An unseasonal snowstorm during China’s Golden Week dumped heavy snow on the Tibet-side Everest Scenic Area, trapping over 200 trekkers at campsites above 4,900 m as rescue teams cleared waist-deep drifts. Authorities evacuated about 350 hikers to Qudang in good health; roughly 200 remained stranded but contacted. Trekkers described violent convective storms burying tents, sleepless nights clearing snow and slippery trails punctuated by falls. Local power and communications faltered, prompting suspension of Everest Scenic Area access. Concurrently, heavy rains triggered deadly landslides and flash floods in Nepal.

articles.title: Monday briefing: Is Kemi Badenoch leading a Tory party on the brink of extinction?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Badenoch has tried to bring a rallying spirit back at conservative conference – but their prospects look far from fun
articles.summary: Kemi Badenoch opened the Manchester Tory conference by pledging to withdraw Britain from the ECHR and ramp up deportations, signaling a sharp right turn aimed at stemming defections to Reform UK. But with Tories polling in the mid-teens versus Reform’s 30%, depleted finances, eroded local structures and a hollowed-out membership, Sam Freedman warns the party risks terminal decline. Badenoch’s fundraising excuses and policy gaffes have failed to revive morale, while internal rivals like Robert Jenrick lurk. A centre-right reset could appeal to few constituencies, leaving the Conservatives trapped between two unbridgeable electorates.

articles.title: Trump urges negotiators to ‘move fast’ as Gaza ceasefire talks set to begin in Egypt
articles.trailText: Talks on Monday expected to focus on release of hostages and end to war, after Israel kills 63 people in Gaza in past day
articles.summary: Donald Trump urged negotiators in Sharm el-Sheikh to “move fast” as talks begin on the first phase of his Gaza peace plan: exchanging 48 Hamas-held hostages for over 1,000 Palestinian prisoners and securing an immediate ceasefire. US envoy Steve Witkoff, Israeli and Hamas delegations aim to conclude the swap within days, after Israel killed 63 Gazans in 24 hours. The deal would see Hamas surrender governance to a US-led technocratic authority, disarm within 72 hours, and prompt Israeli troop withdrawals behind a 2-4 km buffer line, unlocking humanitarian aid and reconstruction funds. Challenges remain over logistics, long-term governance and Israeli PM Netanyahu’s insistence on retaining forces in Gaza.

articles.title: Gaza flotilla passengers allege poor conditions in detention as Israel prepares to deport dozens of activists
articles.trailText: Families of some aboard the Global Sumud Flotilla say they are being held without access to clean water or legal representation
articles.summary: 437 activists aboard the Global Sumud flotilla were intercepted in international waters by Israeli forces; among them three New Zealanders (Rana Hamida, Youssef Sammour and Samuel Leason) are held at Ktzi'ot Prison allegedly without clean water, food or legal counsel. Greta Thunberg and others report bedbugs, forced photo ops; over 70 nationals from France, Greece, Italy and Sweden face deportation. Families worry over injuries and lack of legal access; MFAT confirms Tel Aviv consular visits. Israel denies mistreatment, while Adalah alleges abuse and forced hijab removal. NZ Greens demand sanctions, PM Luxon stresses safety, and Winston Peters criticizes activists as 'headline-hunting'.

articles.title: Australian Gaza flotilla activists detained by Israel complain of ‘degrading and humiliating’ treatment
articles.trailText: One tells consular officials his arm was dislocated and head slammed into ground while another fears she may have a stroke
articles.summary: Seven Australians, among 450 activists on the Global Sumud Flotilla, are held in Ketziot prison in Israel’s Negev after interception at sea. Surya McEwen reports being slapped, his arm dislocated, head slammed into the ground, sleep-deprived and caged with 80 people; passport pages were torn. Juliet Lamont has had daily medication confiscated, endures dehydration, high blood pressure, risk of stroke, and “dystopian” detention without adequate medical care. Dfat confirms consular visits and urges Israel to ensure humane treatment and allow unimpeded humanitarian aid. Meanwhile, 171 other activists were deported; Australians remain detained pending deportation documents they refuse to sign.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Snag for EU’s support of Kyiv after aid opponent wins Czech election
articles.trailText: Andrej Babis’s pledge to halt military aid aligns him with PMs of Hungary and Slovakia; Cubans fight in their thousands for Russia, says US. What we know on day 1,321
articles.summary: Andrej Babis’s election victory in the Czech Republic threatens EU military support for Ukraine after he vowed to halt arms shipments, aligning with Hungary’s Viktor Orbán and Slovakia’s Robert Fico. Although he insists he remains pro-European, Babis plans to review a Czech-led aid initiative that delivered 3.5m shells since 2024 and says Ukraine must end the war before EU accession. In a separate development, a US cable alleges up to 5,000 Cubans fight for Russia, while Zelenskiy decries Western inaction amid intensified Russian strikes and France probes a drone killing of a photojournalist.

articles.title: ‘We’re not afraid’: London vigil remembers 7 October and Manchester synagogue attacks
articles.trailText: Thousands come together in Trafalgar Square despite fears over the rise of antisemitism in the UK
articles.summary: Thousands gathered in Trafalgar Square on 6 October to mark the second anniversary of the Hamas-led 7 October attacks and mourn two victims of the Manchester synagogue shooting on Yom Kippur. Organised by the Board of Deputies of British Jews, the vigil featured 23 candles, the Kaddish led by Chief Rabbi Sir Ephraim Mirvis and speeches by Jewish Leadership Council chair Keith Black and survivors Shaun Lemel and Sharone Lifschitz. Attendees chanted “bring them home” for Gaza hostages, warned of rising UK antisemitism and emphasised unity, tolerance and Israel’s right to self-defence.

articles.title: Civil liberty groups express concern over plan for more anti-protest powers
articles.trailText: Home secretary says police can consider ‘cumulative impact’ of rallies as Palestine Action ban opponents vow ‘escalation’
articles.summary: Home Secretary Shabana Mahmood will introduce primary legislation in England and Wales empowering police to impose stricter conditions on repeat static protests or marches by considering their “cumulative impact,” including limits on location, duration and attendance. Announced amid mass arrests of Palestine Action supporters after a Manchester synagogue attack, the plans amend sections 12 and 14 of the Public Order Act 1986. Civil libertarians, Labour MPs and opposition parties warn of draconian overreach and potential legal challenges echoing Suella Braverman’s failed curbs on protest. Defend Our Juries has vowed mass civil disobedience from 18–28 November in response.

articles.title: Syria holds first elections since fall of Bashar al-Assad
articles.trailText: After more than a decade of civil war, committee members will choose transitional parliament
articles.summary: Syria is holding its first parliamentary elections since Bashar al-Assad’s fall via committee-selected transitional parliament. Interim leader Ahmed al-Sharaa will appoint one-third of the 210 seats, the rest chosen by province-based electoral colleges. With no direct popular vote—citing displacement and lost documents—over 1,500 candidates (14% women) compete for a 30-month mandate to draft a constitution. Rules bar ex-regime supporters and separatists; polls in Sweida and Kurdish areas were postponed. Notable candidate Henry Hamra is the first Jewish contender since the 1940s. Critics warn of bias toward Sharaa’s allies, while others hail it as Syria’s first genuine electoral process.

articles.title: Andrej Babiš to hold talks with other Czech parties on forming government
articles.trailText: Billionaire faces tricky task trying to secure enough support to become PM after ANO wins elections without majority
articles.summary: Andrej Babiš, whose ANO party won 34.5% of votes (80/200 seats) in Czech elections, met President Petr Pavel and starts talks to form a minority government. Mainstream parties refuse coalition, so Babiš seeks confidence-and-supply deals with right-wing SPD and Motorists, despite SPD’s “Czexit” stance and weaker 7.8% support. Pavel demands a pro-western, EU-and-NATO-aligned cabinet and scrutiny of Babiš’s business conflicts. Observers expect pragmatic EU cooperation, while Czech institutions like the Senate will limit any radical shifts.

articles.title: Tools to power up the European Union | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: An EU economic security council is an idea whose time has come, writes Luuk van Middelaar
articles.summary: Luuk van Middelaar argues the EU’s peacetime structure lacks security mechanisms but can adapt using existing bodies. He highlights the European Political Community, newly formalized to unite the EU, post-Brexit UK, Turkey and eastern-flank states, as a flexible diplomatic forum. He also proposes establishing an EU economic security council, modeled on its US counterpart, to hardwire economic statecraft into Brussels policymaking, deliver rapid geostrategic assessments and leverage EU economic power for continental security.

articles.title: Weary Israelis greet Trump as saviour as hostages deal inches closer
articles.trailText: Israelis in Tel Aviv cautiously optimistic but show little sympathy for Palestinians in war-ravaged Gaza
articles.summary: At Hostage Square in Tel Aviv thousands cheered Trump – represented by a papier-mâché mask and banners – crediting his mediation for Hamas’s conditional acceptance of a ceasefire plan that could free the 48 remaining of 251 hostages. While 66% of Israelis believe the Gaza war has gone on too long, only 6% cite Palestinian civilian suffering as a motive to end it. Protesters remain focused on hostages, express cautious optimism but fear Netanyahu might sabotage any deal to placate hardliners. Gaza’s death toll has surpassed 67,000 amid genocide allegations.

articles.title: Palestinian film-makers on their favorite Palestinian movies: ‘I felt like I was watching my own story’
articles.trailText: Mo Amer, Cherien Dabis, Basel Adra and others’ picks show Palestine’s rich, yet overlooked tradition of cinema
articles.summary: Amid rising Hollywood support yet ongoing distribution hurdles, five Palestinian filmmakers champion their touchstones: Mo Amer hails Cherien Dabis’s All That’s Left of You for its multigenerational Jaffa-to-Nablus portrait and emotional precision; Dabis praises Elia Suleiman’s Divine Intervention as a daring, deadpan study of life under occupation; Hany Abu-Assad elevates Mahdi Fleifel’s To a Land Unknown for its intimate refugee odyssey and visual artistry; Basel Adra spotlights the animated The Wanted 18’s critique of economic dependency; Tamer Nafar honors Ajami’s raw, gang-scarred depiction of Arab-Israeli life.

articles.title: John Searle obituary
articles.trailText: American philosopher whose Chinese Room thought experiment rebuts the idea that computers can think as humans do
articles.summary: John Searle (1932–2025) was an American philosopher whose six-decade career at UC Berkeley spanned philosophy of language, mind and society. In Speech Acts (1969) he expanded Austin’s performative theory; his Chinese Room thought experiment (1980) challenged the idea that running a program equates to human understanding and underpins his biological naturalism—mental states as irreducibly subjective neurobiological phenomena. In The Construction of Social Reality (1995) and Making the Social World (2010) he argued that social facts emerge from collective intentionality via language. Known for clashes with Daniel Dennett and Jacques Derrida, he was stripped of emeritus status in 2019 after a 2017 harassment finding.

articles.title: Georgia’s prime minister announces crackdown on dissent after Tbilisi protests
articles.trailText: Irakli Kobakhidze accused EU ambassador of supporting ‘attempt to overthrow constitutional order’
articles.summary: Georgia’s PM Irakli Kobakhidze announced a sweeping crackdown on dissent after some 7,000 protesters tried to storm Tbilisi’s presidential palace during local elections, accusing them and the EU of plotting an 'attempt to overthrow the constitutional order.' Riot police used pepper spray and water cannon to disperse crowds, detaining at least five demonstrators – including two United National Movement members and activist Paata Burchuladze – and injuring 21 security officers and six protesters. Kobakhidze vowed to hold organisers to 'political responsibility' and bar the main opposition from politics, as EU accession talks remain frozen amid pro-Western protests over alleged 2024 parliamentary election fraud.

articles.title: Zelenskyy accuses west of ‘zero real reaction’ to Russia’s bombardment
articles.trailText: Six people killed and 18 injured in heavy drone and missile attacks across Ukraine early on Sunday
articles.summary: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy accused western allies of “zero real reaction” after Russia’s most sustained Lviv bombardment since February: a five-hour volley of Shahed drones, cruise and Kinzhal missiles killed six, wounded 18—among them a 15-year-old girl in Lapaivka—and knocked out power, damaged schools, a church and an industrial park. Over 500 drones and 50 missiles hit multiple regions pre-winter using western-made parts, he said, urging tighter export controls, boosted air defenses and a no-fly zone. EU’s Kaja Kallas condemned Moscow’s terror strategy.

articles.title: ‘We all need someone’: the hairdressers tackling stigma of mental health issues in west Africa
articles.trailText: In Cameroon, Ivory Coast and Togo, where therapy services are almost absent, some stylists are being trained to listen, comfort and guide
articles.summary: In Yopougon, Abidjan, hairdressers in Cameroon, Ivory Coast and Togo are being trained by the Bluemind Foundation’s Heal by Hair initiative as ‘mental health ambassadors.’ Since April 2022, over 400 stylists have completed three-day intensive training in active listening, depression and gender-based violence identification, gaining certificates and peer support. They counsel clients in salons—trusted spaces in regions with 1.4 mental health workers per 100,000—and refer serious cases to psychologists or police. Inspired by founder Marie-Alix de Putter’s loss and a 2021 study showing 77% of women confide in stylists, the program leverages this trust to break mental health taboos.

articles.title: Gisèle Pelicot to attend appeals court as man convicted of raping her contests verdict
articles.trailText: Husamettin Dogan, 44, was sentenced to nine years in prison at trial of 51 men last year that found them all guilty
articles.summary: Gisèle Pelicot, who survived nearly a decade of drug-facilitated rapes orchestrated by her ex-husband Dominique Pelicot, will attend a four-day appeal hearing in Nîmes after builder Husamettin Dogan, 44, contested his nine-year sentence for raping her while unconscious in 2019. Pelicot waived anonymity at the 2024 trial of 51 men to spotlight drug-induced sexual violence. The lone appeal has reignited global feminist support and underscored France’s low rape conviction rates and calls for consent-based legal reform.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: China providing Russia with intelligence on missile targets, Ukrainian official claims
articles.trailText: Ukrainian intelligence official says ‘evidence of a high level of cooperation between Russia and China in conducting satellite reconnaissance’. What we know on day 1,320
articles.summary: Ukrainian intelligence official Oleh Alexandrov claims China is sharing satellite reconnaissance data with Russia to refine missile targeting in Ukraine, including facilities with foreign investment. Overnight, Russia intensified air and drone strikes: Zaporizhzhia’s regional head reported civilian casualties; a drone attack on Sumy trains killed one and injured about 30; Lviv faced incoming missiles prompting Polish jet patrols and flight diversions in Poland and Lithuania. Ukraine retaliated with a drone strike on Russia’s Kirishi oil refinery, while Czech election victor Andrej Babiš threatens to revisit artillery aid to Kyiv.

articles.title: Police make almost 500 arrests at Palestine Action protest in London
articles.trailText: Officers arrest activists at silent vigil in support of banned organisation, as demos go ahead despite PM’s pleas
articles.summary: Almost 500 people were arrested by the Metropolitan Police during a silent vigil in central London supporting Palestine Action, proscribed as a terror group in July. Of 492 arrests—488 under the Terrorism Act and four for offences like public order—297 suspects remained in custody; the rest were bailed. Protesters, around 1,000 seated demonstrators aged 18–89, persisted despite Keir Starmer’s calls to cancel. Police federation chair Paula Dodds warned officers are “emotionally and physically exhausted” by relentless protests. Related pro-Palestine rallies occurred in Manchester, and mass demonstrations swept Spain and Italy against Israel’s Gaza campaign.

articles.title: Israel accused of detaining Greta Thunberg in infested cell and making her hold flags
articles.trailText: Activist tells Swedish officials she has been subjected to harsh treatment, including insufficient food and water
articles.summary: Israel intercepted the Sumud flotilla aiming to break Gaza’s naval blockade, detaining 437 activists—including Greta Thunberg—aboard 40+ aid vessels. Swedish embassy officials report Thunberg held at Ketziot (Ansar III) in a bedbug-infested cell, given inadequate food, water and forced long periods on hard surfaces, causing dehydration and rashes. Fellow detainees allege she was dragged by her hair, beaten, forced to hold or kiss Israeli flags for photos, and paraded wrapped in a flag. NGO lawyers and participants accuse Israel of systematic rights violations—denied sanitation, medical care and prompt legal counsel—claims Israel denies. Itamar Ben-Gvir labelled activists “terrorists.” Thunberg declined to sign documents she didn’t understand, and Sweden demands swift processing, medical access and repatriation.

articles.title: Populist billionaire Andrej Babiš wins Czech parliamentary election
articles.trailText: With Babiš’s victory the Czech Republic looks set to join Hungary and Slovakia in refusing support for Ukraine
articles.summary: Andrej Babiš, self-styled 'Trumpist' and former PM (2017–21), led his ANO party to a plurality in the Czech parliamentary vote with 35% against incumbent PM Petr Fiala’s coalition at 23% in a 69% turnout. Falling short of an outright majority in the 200-seat lower house, Babiš plans talks with anti-immigration SPD (7.9%) and right-wing Motorists (6.8%) to form government. He promises higher welfare, wage and pension increases, tax cuts and reduced foreign aid—targeting Ukraine—signaling a tilt towards Hungary and Slovakia.

articles.title: ‘I feel like we are in a trap’: Gaza residents hopeful but wary of Trump��s plan
articles.trailText: Hamas’s agreement to release all hostages and surrender power hailed internationally as Israeli attacks continue
articles.summary: Gaza residents express cautious optimism but deep mistrust of Donald Trump’s latest ceasefire proposal after Hamas’s partial acceptance, including releasing hostages and relinquishing power. Despite international praise, civilians like teacher Arij al-Farra and editor Abu Faris note no reduction in Israeli airstrikes that have displaced them multiple times and killed over 67,000 Palestinians. Critics, including academic Ashraf Maghari, warn the US-drafted plan heavily favors Israel and omits meaningful Palestinian safeguards. Still, war-weary Gazans prioritize halting the bombing over political rights, seeing any truce as a chance to regroup, even if it demands painful compromises from their leadership.

articles.title: ‘People are dying’: Belarusians warn Lukashenko’s crackdown is far from over
articles.trailText: Those recently freed from jail say authoritarian leader is using political prisoners as bargaining chips to ease sanctions
articles.summary: Belarus’s president Alexander Lukashenko released 52 political prisoners (among 1,168 still detained) in one of the largest pardons to date, deporting them to Lithuania to win Western sanctions relief and diplomatic overtures. Freed activists—including journalist Mikola Dziadok and opposition figures Sergey Sparysh—describe brutal prison conditions: torture with stun guns (‘disco’), isolation, medical neglect and deaths. Critics say releases are bargaining chips for US and EU concessions while repression continues, with new arrests matching freed numbers. Exiled activists warn against substituting prisoner swaps for democratic change and urge the West to demand a permanent end to political persecution.

articles.title: Israel orders military to halt Gaza City campaign but continues strikes on the territory
articles.trailText: IDF says it was directed to ready for first part of Donald Trump’s plan to end war in Gaza after Hamas agrees to release hostages
articles.summary: Israeli political leaders ordered the IDF to suspend its Gaza City ground offensive and limit operations to defensive strikes while preparing to implement the first phase of Donald Trump’s 20-point peace plan, after Hamas conditionally agreed to release 48 remaining hostages. Despite official halt orders, Israeli air raids continued, killing at least six Palestinians in Gaza City and al-Mawasi and “dozens” near a bakery. Hamas’s tentative acceptance and U.S. backing have raised hopes for a ceasefire, as Israeli PM Netanyahu faces domestic and international pressure to finalise terms including hostages’ return, prisoner swaps and phased force withdrawal.

articles.title: ‘The fear was immense’: al-Shabaab exploits fragmented politics to reclaim land in Somalia
articles.trailText: With Islamist militant group 40km from Mogadishu, a ‘strategic stalemate’ has been reached, but some fear worst is yet to come
articles.summary: Since launching a February offensive, al-Shabaab has retaken all territory lost to Somali forces and allied militias in 2023, seizing strategic towns such as Moqokori and Maxaas and advancing to within 40 km of Mogadishu, triggering mass civilian flight. Despite intensified US airstrikes and support from Turkey, the UAE, Uganda, Egypt and the AU, government troops—hampered by political divisions, uneven funding and low morale—remain defensive. Analysts warn of a ‘strategic stalemate’ that leaves rural areas exposed and displacement rising.

articles.title: Japan poised to get first female PM after Sanae Takaichi wins ruling party leadership
articles.trailText: Margaret Thatcher admirer beat her more moderate rival to become leader of Liberal Democratic party
articles.summary: Sanae Takaichi, a 64-year-old rightwing LDP veteran and Margaret Thatcher admirer, won the ruling party’s presidential runoff in Tokyo, defeating moderate Shinjiro Koizumi by 185 votes to 156. She succeeds Shigeru Ishiba and is widely expected to be confirmed as Japan’s first female prime minister around 15 October. Takaichi inherits a party weakened by funding scandals and election losses, and must unite the LDP, address living-cost pressures, immigration, gender-equality skepticism and a tense East Asian security environment.

articles.title: Starmer on horns of dilemma over China’s seven-year mega-embassy saga
articles.trailText: Decision time is coming after Labour called in the planning application for a new building in east London
articles.summary: In 2018 China bought the historic Royal Mint Court site for £255m to build a 20,000 sqm “super-embassy”. Amid years-long lobbying by Beijing with Tower Hamlets community figures, the council blocked plans in Dec 2022 over local opposition. After Labour came to power in July 2024, China resubmitted its application and Starmer raised it with Xi Jinping. Housing secretary Angela Rayner called in the planning decision, prompting an inquiry that wrapped on 10 June 2025. Now successor Steve Reed must decide by 21 October amid security and human rights concerns and potential judicial reviews.

articles.title: Europe needs to ‘get serious’ about threat posed to it by Russia, Ukraine minister says
articles.trailText: Sergiy Kyslytsya says Kremlin already at war with Europe and predicts that Vladimir Putin will ‘escalate escalating’
articles.summary: Ukraine’s deputy foreign minister Sergiy Kyslytsya warns Europe to “get serious” about Russia’s existential hybrid war — recent drone incursions into Poland, Estonia and airport closures in Munich and Copenhagen mark Kremlin probes of EU red lines. He accuses Moscow of embedding “konservy” agents to paralyse banking and military infrastructure, predicting Putin will “escalate escalating” absent decisive transatlantic resolve. While EU leaders, including Denmark’s Mette Frederiksen, acknowledge a post-WWII-level threat, many experts remain fixated on 20th-century warfare. Kyslytsya notes improved US cooperation despite Trump’s rhetorical stance and lauds Kyiv’s homemade drone strikes crippling Russian oil. He asserts Ukraine’s battlefield gains and strengthened alliances can deter further Kremlin aggression.

articles.title: ‘One rule for the rich’: the Salzburg mansion, the Porsche heir and the writer Stefan Zweig
articles.trailText: The car magnate, who is restoring the Jewish author’s former villa, has been given permission to dig out a 500-metre road leading to a garage, causing consternation in the city
articles.summary: Wolfgang Porsche bought Stefan Zweig’s former villa on Salzburg’s Kapuzinerberg in 2019 and is now restoring it. He secured city approval to bore a 500m tunnel and build a subterranean garage for eight cars at an estimated cost of €10m, paying a €48,000 fee for public land access. Neighbors and local Greens and communists decry the project as noisy, elitist and destructive of the hill’s historic, car-free character. Critics invoke “one rule for the rich,” argue it sullies Zweig’s Jewish literary legacy and note the city planning committee green-lit the scheme despite protests and shifted political leadership.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: ‘Political will’ needed to restore external power to Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, UN watchdog says
articles.trailText: Rafael Grossi says ‘security situation’ around plant must improve for repairs to be carried out; French photojournalist Antoni Lallican killed by Russian drone strike. What we know on day 1,319
articles.summary: IAEA chief Rafael Grossi said restoring off-site power to the Russian-held Zaporizhzhia plant is a matter of “political will,” urging improved security so technicians can repair lines after the Sept. 23 cutoff and reliance on diesel generators. French photojournalist Antoni Lallican was killed and Ukrainian journalist Georgiy Ivanchenko wounded by a Russian drone near Druzhkivka. Russia’s largest strike on Ukraine’s gas network damaged critical facilities in Kharkiv and Poltava, causing blackouts. A drone-caused farm fire killed 13,000 pigs. Ukraine severed ties with Nicaragua over its recognition of occupied territory.

articles.title: Donald Trump orders Israel to ‘immediately’ stop bombing Gaza as Hamas agrees to free hostages
articles.trailText: Palestinian militant group accepts part of US president’s plan but seeks further negotiations on many terms
articles.summary: Donald Trump ordered an immediate halt to Israel’s bombing of Gaza after Hamas conditionally accepted his plan: release all Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners and hand over Gaza governance to a US-backed technocratic authority. Hamas agreed to the swap but wants further talks on arms withdrawal, troop pull-out and permanent ceasefire. Netanyahu’s office said it will implement the first stage and he vowed to disarm Hamas “diplomatically or militarily.” Despite Trump’s call, Israeli strikes continued, inflicting civilian casualties. Major powers and the UN welcomed the ceasefire prospect.

articles.title: Dfat officials supporting five Australians in Israeli prison after they were detained on pro-Palestinian flotilla
articles.trailText: The Global Movement to Gaza group have raised concerns about the conditions in which the Australians are being held in detention
articles.summary: Australia’s DFAT has deployed consular staff to Ketziot prison to support five citizens—Surya McEwen, Abubakir Rafiq, Hamish Paterson, Juliet Lamont and Bianca Webb-Pullman—detained by the Israeli navy during the pro-Palestinian Global Sumud flotilla. The group, including activists like Greta Thunberg, sought to breach Gaza’s naval blockade with humanitarian aid. Detainees report harsh conditions—denied food, water, medication, forced to kneel, no legal counsel—claims DFAT is pressing Israel to investigate. Canberra warns against blockade breaches and calls for humane treatment under international law. One other Australian’s status is unconfirmed (Cameron Tribe). Israel says all are safe and will be deported.

articles.title: Failed by the NHS on chronic fatigue illness | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Prof Paul Garner , Dr Maria Pedersen and Dr Alastair Miller , plus two other readers, respond to Patrick Barkham’s article on his daughter’s Lyme disease diagnosis
articles.summary: Prof Paul Garner, Dr Maria Pedersen and Dr Alastair Miller respond to Patrick Barkham’s account of his daughter Milly’s chronic fatigue, blaming NHS failings for lack of clear diagnosis and ineffective care. They argue there is no proof of persistent Borrelia infection or long-term antibiotic efficacy, recommending mind–body rehabilitation—explaining brain-generated danger signals, stressor links and bespoke plans—backed by two Norwegian trials. Readers Tom Pond clarifies that pacing differs from banned graded exercise therapy, while Allison DeVries warns UK’s warming climate and rewilding raise insect-borne disease risks. All underline gaps in treatment and need for holistic, evidence-based care.

articles.title: Egypt foreign minister urges Hamas to accept Trump Gaza plan and disarm
articles.trailText: Hamas reportedly split on response to deal as US president sets Sunday deadline for militant group to reply
articles.summary: Egypt’s FM Badr Abdelatty said Egypt, Qatar and Turkey are urging Hamas to accept Trump’s ultimatum—lay down arms, quit politics and free remaining hostages by Sunday—so Israel ends its Gaza offensive. Trump threatens “all hell” if Hamas refuses. The plan swaps hostages for nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, installs a Trump-led transitional authority and international force, and sees partial Israeli troop withdrawal. Hamas is split, its military chief opposes the deal, analysts doubt Israeli compliance. Meanwhile Gaza faces daily bombardments, mass displacement, humanitarian collapse and international criticism. Friday’s strikes killed 28 Palestinians amid ‘safe zones’ deemed deadly by the UN.

articles.title: ‘Starting to be very afraid’: Italy’s Gaza protests raise pressure on Meloni
articles.trailText: With strikes and demonstrations, intensifying Italian opposition to Israel’s war is challenging the PM’s stance
articles.summary: In early October, Italian dockworkers from Livorno to Taranto staged strikes blocking Israeli-owned ships, halting weapons shipments in solidarity with Gaza. Thousands joined CGIL-led general strikes and spontaneous protests after Israeli forces detained flotilla activists, including Greta Thunberg. Surveys show widespread Italian support for a Palestinian state, pressuring PM Giorgia Meloni, who criticizes Israel’s actions yet maintains alliance with it and the US, while exploiting unrest to attack left opposition. Despite strong public sentiment, her Brothers of Italy party remains at 30% in polls and won recent regional votes. Protest leaders warn Meloni’s government is “very afraid.”

articles.title: Madagascar president who took power in coup accuses protesters of trying to trigger another one
articles.trailText: Young people take to streets to voice anger at water and power cuts, and corruption in political system
articles.summary: Andry Rajoelina, Madagascar’s president who seized power in a 2009 coup, accused youth-led protesters of orchestrating a foreign-funded attempt to trigger a coup after demonstrations over water and power cuts escalated into corruption and political reform demands. Since Sept 25, at least 22 protesters have died, per UN figures disputed by authorities. Rajoelina dissolved his government and sacked the PM; Gen Z activists refuse to stand down, calling for his resignation and overhaul of top institutions.
