Demonstrators, inspired by global Gen Z movements, reject his claims as baseless in one of the world’s poorest countries despite rich natural resources.

articles.title: Fears Quebec Starbucks gang shooting could signal shift to brazen tactics
articles.trailText: Local media named victim as Charalambos Theologou, shot as groups vie for power after arrests of alleged mafia bosses
articles.summary: On Wednesday at 10.30am in Laval, Quebec, gunmen fatally shot 40-year-old convicted trafficker Charalambos “Bobby the Greek” Theologou, leader of the Chomedey Greeks, inside a Starbucks, injuring two others. Police and Quebec’s security minister link the brazen daylight attack to organised-crime turf wars after June arrests of mafia figures, notably Leonardo Rizzuto. Criminologist Valentin Pereda warns the killing reflects a breakdown of old hierarchies and a scramble by younger, looser street gangs for control.

articles.title: Final boat of 42-strong pro-Palestinian flotilla intercepted by Israel
articles.trailText: Protest vessel intercepted in the early hours of Friday morning 42.5 nautical miles from the coast of Gaza
articles.summary: Israel’s navy intercepted the final vessel of the 42-boat Global Sumud Flotilla early Friday, seizing the Polish-flagged Marinette roughly 42.5 nautical miles off Gaza. The flotilla carried about 450 parliamentarians, lawyers and activists, including Greta Thunberg, aiming to breach Israel’s 16-year maritime blockade. The six-person Marinette crew—three Turks, a German, an Omani and the Australian captain—joined late after bad weather. Detainees face deportation under immigration measures. Prior unauthorised missions, notably the 2010 Mavi Marmara raid that killed 10 Turks, were similarly stopped by force.

articles.title: Sarah Mullally is named as first female archbishop of Canterbury
articles.trailText: Former chief nursing officer for England will legally assume role at Canterbury Cathedral ceremony in January
articles.summary: Dame Sarah Mullally, 63, ex-chief nursing officer for England and Bishop of London, has been named the Church of England’s first female archbishop of Canterbury. She will legally assume office at Canterbury Cathedral in January and later be enthroned before royal guests. Appointed by the Crown Nominations Commission and approved by PM Keir Starmer and King Charles, Mullally pledged to address past safeguarding failures by listening to survivors, confront antisemitism, and steer debates on assisted dying, refugees and same-sex marriage. Her elevation marks a defining milestone since women were first allowed bishops in 2014 amid liberal-conservative tensions across the global Anglican Communion.

articles.title: Sarah Mullally: the former nurse who will be archbishop of Canterbury
articles.trailText: Bishop of London, who has been named as first female leader of Church of England, is seen as a ‘theological liberal’
articles.summary: Dame Sarah Mullally, 63, the former chief nursing officer for England, has been appointed the 106th and first female archbishop of Canterbury. After a 35-year NHS career as a cancer nurse and youngest chief nursing officer at 37, she entered ordained ministry in 2004. As bishop of London since 2018 and third-ranking C of E bishop with a House of Lords seat, she is seen as a 'theological liberal': ordaining men and women, welcoming dissenters, opposing assisted dying and Rwanda policies, adopting a pro-choice stance on abortion, and overseeing 2023 blessings for same-sex couples. Traditionalists urge a return to historic doctrines.

articles.title: Chief rabbi urges ‘national soul-searching’ after Manchester synagogue attack
articles.trailText: Ephraim Mirvis says deadly attack followed ‘unrelenting wave of hated against Jews’ on Britain’s streets and campuses
articles.summary: UK chief rabbi Sir Ephraim Mirvis demanded 'urgent national soul-searching' after a terrorist attack at a Manchester synagogue killed two men, warning it followed an 'unrelenting wave of hatred against Jews' across Britain—on streets, campuses, social media and in protests some endorsing Hamas or chanting 'globalise the intifada'. He questioned why demonstrations, including calls to lift the ban on Palestine Action, are permitted, arguing they fuel antisemitism and extremism. Mirvis urged the government to reassert control, faith leaders to promote harmony, and faith communities to combat hateful rhetoric. Israel’s President Isaac Herzog and ex-BBC controller Danny Cohen urged an immediate inquiry into antisemitism.

articles.title: Weather tracker: wet conditions raise risk of flooding in south-eastern Europe
articles.trailText: Warnings issued for Serbia, Romania and Greek islands amid forecast of prolonged rainfall and strong winds
articles.summary: A Mediterranean low-pressure system is drenching the Balkans with 80–130 mm of rain in 48 h, prompting red alerts in Serbia, SW Romania, NE Greece and the Dodecanese/North Aegean islands amid flood and life-threat risks. Strong gales closed schools on Zakynthos, and cold eastern air has dumped up to 80 cm of snow in the Dinaric Alps. Earlier, Hurricane Gabrielle’s remnants caused record floods in eastern Spain and the Balearics (Gandia 356.8 mm/12 h; Ibiza 254 mm/24 h), while Typhoon Bualoi inundated Vietnam, killing 36, injuring 147 and inflicting over $350 m in damage.

articles.title: Munich airport reopens after halting flights because of drone sightings
articles.trailText: Travel disrupted for thousands on eve of national holiday in latest drone incident to hit European aviation
articles.summary: Munich airport halted operations late Thursday after multiple drone sightings, cancelling 17 departures and diverting 15 arrivals to Stuttgart, Nuremberg, Vienna and Frankfurt, stranding nearly 3,000 passengers on the eve of German Unity Day. Staff offered blankets, food and hotel rooms before flights resumed early Friday, with a Bangkok service landing at 5:25 am. The disruption follows similar incidents in Denmark and Norway, fueling EU concerns over potential Russian-linked incursions and urgent calls for integrated drone-defence systems.

articles.title: Captain of oil tanker linked to Russia’s ‘shadow fleet’ to go on trial in France
articles.trailText: Vladimir Putin denounces seizing of the vessel as an act of ‘piracy’ and warns it could provoke confrontation
articles.summary: France will try the captain of the Boracay, a tanker suspected of belonging to Russia’s ageing “shadow fleet,” on 23 February in Brest for failing to cooperate and misrepresenting the vessel’s nationality. Intercepted off France’s Atlantic coast while carrying 750,000 barrels from Primorsk to India, the ship is also under scrutiny for possible links to recent drone incursions that grounded Danish airports. President Macron hailed the action as striking at €30 bn of Kremlin war financing, while Vladimir Putin denounced the seizure as piracy and warned of confrontation. Meanwhile, a Finnish court deemed itself without jurisdiction in a related case against the Eagle S tanker.

articles.title: Friday briefing: Manchester mourns one of the worst acts of antisemitic terrorism in modern UK history
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Yom Kippur was marred by violence after a man armed with explosives sought to enter Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation synagogue. Here’s what we know so far
articles.summary: On the morning of Yom Kippur in Manchester’s Crumpsall, a 35-year-old British citizen of Syrian descent named Jihad Al-Shamie rammed his car into bystanders, stabbed victims and attempted to breach Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation synagogue wearing a fake bomb. Armed police shot him dead within minutes; two worshippers—Adrian Daulby, 53, and Melvin Cravitz, 66—were killed and three others seriously injured. The attack, among the worst antisemitic terror acts in UK history, has prompted nationwide synagogue security alerts and a major counter-terrorism investigation.

articles.title: Japan days away from running out of Asahi Super Dry due to cyber attack – reports
articles.trailText: The attack forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing its signature beer
articles.summary: Asahi Group, Japan’s largest brewery, is days away from exhausting inventory of its flagship Super Dry lager after a ransomware attack disabled its ordering and delivery systems, halting shipments from 30 domestic breweries. With no system recovery in sight, wholesalers, retailers and izakaya pubs face empty shelves in two to three days, prompting some to seek alternative suppliers. Convenience stores have posted notices but expect staggered shortages. The incident has also delayed a dozen new product launches. Asahi reports no customer data breach and says overseas operations remain unaffected, but offers no timeline for resuming normal production and distribution.

articles.title: Papua New Guinea considers age restrictions on social media amid fears voices will be ‘silenced’
articles.trailText: Proposed changes to address the spread of harmful content in PNG also include new rules for social media companies and more monitoring
articles.summary: Papua New Guinea’s proposed Social Media Policy 2025 would require users 14+ to obtain a SevisPass digital ID and force platforms like Facebook, TikTok, Instagram and X to register locally, comply with PNG laws and submit to a new e-Safety Directorate. Officials say the rules aim to curb abuse, scams and misinformation. PNG is in early talks with Meta on age enforcement, while Australia eyes AI-based under-16 bans. Critics—including a UPNG student, comedian Emmanuel Tipi and small-business owner Sylvia Pascoe—warn heavy-handed ID checks and past shutdowns risk silencing voices, harming livelihoods and eroding digital freedoms.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Putin warns of ‘new level of escalation’ if Tomahawk missiles supplied to Kyiv
articles.trailText: Volodymyr Zelenskyy tells European leaders that Moscow’s war ‘was never just about Ukraine’. What we know on day 1,318
articles.summary: In Sochi, Vladimir Putin warned that supplying US Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine—despite not altering Russia’s slow battlefield gains—would spark a “whole new level of escalation” with Washington. US officials say existing Tomahawks are committed to the Navy, exploring shorter-range alternatives and offering intelligence on deep-strike energy targets in Russia. In Copenhagen, Zelenskiy cautioned 45 European leaders about drone incursions that risk NATO’s airspace. Moscow dismissed fears of a NATO attack but vowed swift countermeasures. Domestically, liberal deputy Maxim Kruglov faces up to 10 years for ‘spreading lies,’ Ukrainian power grids in Sumy and Chernihiv are being restored after Russian strikes, and 185 military personnel plus 20 civilians were exchanged between the sides.

articles.title: Call to allow ‘safe and effective’ at-home abortions up to 12 weeks in UK
articles.trailText: Experts point to study showing procedures at home are no riskier or less successful than hospital care
articles.summary: Academics urge UK to permit at-home medical abortions up to 12 weeks’ gestation, citing a BMJ Sexual & Reproductive Health study of NHS Lothian cases from 2020–2025. Among 485 women at 10���12 weeks, 97% of home and hospital procedures succeeded, with serious complications rare. England and Wales currently limit home use to 10 weeks; Northern Ireland bans it. Researchers recommend extending provision, aligning with WHO guidance. The British Pregnancy Advisory Service calls for modernising the 1967 abortion law to enhance safety, choice and clinical innovation.

articles.title: Israel stops 41 boats in aid flotilla with one ‘still sailing strong’
articles.trailText: Activists from Global Sumud flotilla including Greta Thunberg arrested as final boat is presumed intercepted in Palestinian waters
articles.summary: Israel’s navy intercepted 41 of 42 vessels in the Global Sumud flotilla aiming to breach Gaza’s blockade, detaining around 500 activists—including Greta Thunberg, MPs from Ireland, Italy, Poland and others—at Ashdod and set for Ketziot prison or special courts. One ship, Mikeno, briefly entered Palestinian waters before capture. Spain, Britain and Turkey condemned the raid, protests erupted in Europe and Latin America, and Spain’s deputy PM demanded an EU break with Israel.

articles.title: Man described as a Caribbean serial killer gets 30-year prison sentence in Guadeloupe
articles.trailText: Kathron ‘Cuchi’ Fortune, 47, found guilty of torture and murder of a woman, one week after double murder sentence in separate case
articles.summary: Kathron “Cuchi” Fortune, 47, a Grenadian national dubbed the Caribbean’s first serial killer, received 30 years in Guadeloupe for the 2006 torture and murder of Angélique Chauviré in Saint Martin. The latest verdict, requiring 20 years served, followed his September life sentence (with 22-year minimum) for the 2005–06 killings of Jomo Maynard and Gilbert Hyman. Fortune, previously convicted in the Netherlands for three Sint Maarten murders but who escaped custody in 2016, was rearrested in Saint Kitts and extradited. His multi-jurisdictional trials spanned French and Dutch courts; he denies guilt and has appealed.

articles.title: Putin dismisses fears that Moscow plans to attack Nato as ‘nonsense’
articles.trailText: During speech in Sochi, Russian president also strikes conciliatory note towards Donald Trump
articles.summary: At the Valdai plenary in Sochi, Vladimir Putin branded Western fears of a Russian Nato attack “nonsense,” vowing swift countermeasures against Europe’s “escalating militarisation” to safeguard Russia. He struck a conciliatory tone toward Donald Trump—praising his potential to end the Ukraine war and seeking full US relations—while blasting European elites for “hysteria” and condemning France’s seizure of a Russian tanker as “piracy.” Reiterating maximalist demands in Ukraine, Putin claimed Russian forces were advancing confidently and urged Kyiv to negotiate. Zelenskiy, at a parallel Copenhagen summit, called for united European action to deter Russian threats.

articles.title: Netanyahu suggests ‘weakness on terrorism’ led to UK synagogue attack
articles.trailText: Israeli PM calls for ‘strength and unity’ while foreign minister accuses UK of inaction against antisemitism
articles.summary: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu and FM Gideon Sa’ar condemned the Manchester synagogue attack that killed two worshippers on Yom Kippur, blaming “weakness” on terrorism and accusing the Starmer government of allowing “rampant antisemitic and anti-Israel incitement” across UK cities and campuses. The lone attacker, wearing a fake explosive device, stabbed congregants and tried to ram the Heaton Park Hebrew Congregation before police shot him dead; two suspects were later arrested. Starmer flew home for an emergency Cobra meeting, condemned the “vile” terror act, and vowed stronger protections for British Jews amid rising antisemitic incidents. Netanyahu, who had criticized Labour’s recognition of a Palestinian state, pledged solidarity with UK Jewry.

articles.title: Wildfires are getting deadlier and costing more. Experts warn they’re becoming unstoppable
articles.trailText: Of 200 fires in the past 44 years, half of the fires that cost US$1bn or more were in the last decade
articles.summary: Analysis of 200 costliest wildfires (1980–2023) shows 43% occurred in the last decade and half of those exceeding US$1 billion in losses struck during this period. Blazes causing ≥10 deaths have tripled while population rose 1.8×. Rising temperatures and extreme dryness—often in the worst 0.1% of fire‐danger conditions—are driving ‘societally disastrous’ fires worldwide. Researchers warn climate change is making these events increasingly unstoppable and call for rapid greenhouse‐gas cuts, enhanced forest management near communities and proactive ember and fuel mitigation.

articles.title: Hamas could ask for revisions to Trump Gaza plan, sources and analysts say
articles.trailText: Turkey and Qatar putting pressure on group to make concessions – but condition it disarm is a sticking point
articles.summary: Hamas, under pressure from Turkey and Qatar, is poised to accept Donald Trump’s 20-point Gaza ceasefire plan as a negotiation framework but will insist on key revisions—most notably opposing the unconditional disarmament clause and demanding clearer guarantees on Israeli withdrawals and a political process toward statehood. The proposal, accepted by Netanyahu, includes a 72-hour hostage release, buffer-zone withdrawals, humanitarian aid and the freeing of over 1,000 Palestinian prisoners. Hamas’s geographically split leadership concurs on rejecting total disarmament despite severe battlefield losses, seeking to secure concessions without stalling talks under Trump��s looming deadline or risking further Israeli offensive.

articles.title: Branded New Forest ponies are well cared for | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Brice Stratford defends traditional practices and says New Forest ponies have a better quality of life than any others
articles.summary: In response to objections by Jason Rose, New Forest commoners care for free-roaming ponies under millennia-old grazing rights, using harmless tail cuts to assign agisters and temporary brands—causing only brief discomfort—to ensure clear, durable identification for health management and recovery from accidents or theft (notably two ponies stolen in July were located in a London borough in August). Brice Stratford, board member of the national park authority, argues these traditional practices guarantee superior welfare and out-perform removable chips or tags in legibility and reliability.

articles.title: Iran may release hundreds of thousands of Afghan refugees into Iraq and Turkey
articles.trailText: Tehran considers move as part of multi-pronged offensive after bombing of nuclear sites and restoration of sanctions
articles.summary: Iran is weighing expelling hundreds of thousands of undocumented Afghan refugees into Iraq and Turkey as part of an unpredictable strategy after recent strikes on its nuclear sites and renewed UN sanctions. The plan complements expanded missile development, halting cooperation with UN inspectors and blocking a UN sanctions oversight committee. Observers note echoes of Erdoğan’s migrant threat. Since June Iran expelled about 500,000 Afghans (1m in 2025), and the UN predicts up to 4m could be sent home. Revoking ‘headcount’ permits has stripped refugees of legal status and services. Tehran also recalled ambassadors amid stalled diplomacy over sanction relief proposals.

articles.title: Iran must move its capital from Tehran, says president as water crisis worsens
articles.trailText: Masoud Pezeshkian says subsidence is also ‘a disaster’ in city of 10 million, which consumes quarter of Iran’s water
articles.summary: President Masoud Pezeshkian says Iran must shift its capital from water-stressed, sinking Tehran to the Persian Gulf coast. He proposed to Ayatollah Khamenei moving to Hormozgan province for direct maritime access and economic growth, arguing over-expansion, subsidence up to 30cm/year and acute water shortages make Tehran unsustainable. The city of 10 million consumes 25% of national water amid a 50–60% drop in rainfall (100–140mm vs 260mm norm), dam inflows collapsing, and groundwater overuse. He warns water transfers could cost €4/m³ and insists development must align with resources.

articles.title: At least 53 Palestinians killed in fresh wave of Israeli attacks on Gaza
articles.trailText: Military offensive stepped up as Hamas leaders consider Trump’s 20-point peace plan
articles.summary: On Oct 2, Israeli airstrikes across Gaza killed at least 53 Palestinians—including nine in al-Masawi’s declared safe zone (a grandfather, four sons and a grandson), four siblings in al-Bureij and nine (mostly women) in Deir al-Balah—while sealing escape routes and warning remaining Gaza City residents they’d be treated as ‘terrorists.’ Amid a deepening humanitarian crisis (over 66,000 dead, 500,000 displaced), Hamas is weighing Trump’s 20-point peace ultimatum to disarm, release 48 hostages and exit politics in exchange for prisoner swaps, phased withdrawals under a peacekeeping force and reconstruction aid. International mediators urge rapid negotiation.

articles.title: Asylum seekers on Nauru going hungry despite government spending $1.5m a year for each person
articles.trailText: The Australian government is spending millions of dollars a year to house asylum seekers, yet many say they can not afford food and are forced to skip meals
articles.summary: Refugees and asylum seekers on Nauru report chronic hunger and meal skipping despite Australia paying US prisons operator MTC Australia $1.5m per person annually to house them. Their $230 fortnightly stipend fails to cover imported groceries; some quit jobs after assaults, worsening food insecurity and mental distress. MTC’s two-year, $364m contract extension – boosting its offshore processing revenue to $786m – provides no food or work provisions and was awarded without public tender or scrutiny. Critics decry “disgraceful cruelty” and secretive mismanagement as vulnerable detainees suffer starvation.

articles.title: Part of Pablo Escobar’s ranch to be given to female victims of Colombia conflict
articles.trailText: Estate was abandoned after Escobar’s 1993 killing and later became a theme park, and now the land has been granted to female farmers
articles.summary: President Gustavo Petro has reclaimed 120 hectares of Pablo Escobar’s former Hacienda Nápoles in northwest Antioquia and granted it to female farmers who endured displacement in Colombia’s decades-long conflict. The estate, abandoned after Escobar’s 1993 death and later converted into a theme park, once housed exotic animals and a private airstrip. Beneficiaries like Millinery Correa celebrate the land as a source of hope, while land agencies call it a historic victory. Despite opposition from tourism stakeholders and the ongoing menace of feral hippos, authorities say the restitution restores dignity and justice to rural women.

articles.title: Palestinian food brand says UK sales up 50% as shoppers show solidarity
articles.trailText: Zaytoun’s olive oil and dates provide a tangible way to help Palestinians, says the business’s managing director
articles.summary: Zaytoun, a Palestinian social enterprise, saw UK sales climb 50% to £3.2m in 2024 as consumers buy its extra-virgin olive oil, medjool dates, almonds and giant couscous in solidarity with Gaza and the West Bank. Its fair-trade model channels revenue back to small-scale farmers but has lost formal Fairtrade certification due to security challenges in Palestine. Despite higher prices (500ml bottles cost about £15) and shipping delays via Haifa port, demand rose amid a UK marketing push by the Fairtrade Foundation. Zaytoun’s MD Manal Ramadan White says the olive tree’s resilience mirrors Palestinian perseverance, and she hopes new local auditors will restore certification for the next harvest.

articles.title: Kenyan activists abducted after joining opposition rally in Uganda
articles.trailText: Pair had crossed border to support presidential campaign of reggae singer Bobi Wine
articles.summary: Following their arrival in Uganda to support Bobi Wine’s presidential campaign, Kenyan activists Bob Njagi (Free Kenya chair) and Nicholas Oyoo (secretary general) were seized by armed security operatives at a Kampala petrol station. Their whereabouts remain unknown amid accusations of coordinated transborder repression by East African regimes. Past abductions include lawyer Agather Atuhaire and activist Boniface Mwangi in Tanzania and opposition leader Kizza Besigye in Kenya. Critics say Museveni’s 37-year rule is cracking down on critics before January elections; Wine demands their unconditional release.

articles.title: Israel’s Gaza flotilla interception triggers protests, diplomatic expulsions and calls for strikes
articles.trailText: Thousands demonstrate around the world after flotilla was stopped and activists including Greta Thunberg detained
articles.summary: Israel’s navy interception of a pro-Palestinian aid flotilla carrying 500 activists, parliamentarians and Greta Thunberg sparked mass protests in Italy (10,000 in Rome, metro shutdowns, general strikes called by CGIL and USB), solidarity rallies in Brussels, Berlin, Buenos Aires and beyond, and calls to resign by PM Meloni. Global condemnations poured in—from Turkey’s Erdoğan, Spain’s government summoning Israel’s envoy, Ireland convening crisis talks, to Colombia expelling diplomats. Brazil, Mexico, Malaysia, Pakistan and the UK demanded detainees’ release and unhindered humanitarian access to Gaza.

articles.title: Organisers call for sixth night of protest as Morocco death toll rises to three
articles.trailText: Prime minister praises security response and says government is ready for talks
articles.summary: Morocco’s prime minister Aziz Akhannouch lauded security forces as the death toll rose to three—the first fatalities after police opened fire in Lqliâa during youth-led protests ignited by a hospital tragedy in Agadir that killed eight women. GenZ 212, an anonymous online movement on TikTok, Instagram and a Discord server swelling from 3,000 to 130,000 members, called for a sixth night of rallies. Demonstrations demanding better healthcare, education and anti-corruption measures spread to Salé and other cities, leaving 263 security officers and 23 civilians injured amid clashes, looting and arson. Authorities deny prioritizing 2030 World Cup spending over public services. Parliament will convene to discuss reforms, and further peaceful protests are set for 1600 GMT.

articles.title: Family of British couple detained in Iran express alarm over ongoing trial
articles.trailText: Lindsay and Craig Foreman were seized in January during a round-the-world motorbike trip
articles.summary: Lindsay and Craig Foreman, both 52, have been held in Iran since January on espionage charges after being seized in Kerman during a round-the-world motorbike trip. Their family, alarmed by recent Tehran hearings and a verdict due within ten days, say they’ve been denied UK consular access and fear for the couple’s welfare. Campaigning publicly after nine months of limited progress, relatives have enlisted MPs, the APPG on arbitrary detention and new foreign secretary Yvette Cooper, urging a special envoy and relentless diplomatic pressure to secure their release.

articles.title: US to give Ukraine intelligence on long-range energy targets in Russia, say reports
articles.trailText: Decision would signal a significant shift in White House support for Kyiv as Trump grows irritated with Putin
articles.summary: US officials told WSJ and Reuters the Trump administration will now share intelligence with Ukraine to target long-range Russian energy infrastructure—a significant policy shift intended to bolster Kyiv and pressure Putin. Timing is unclear and no decision has been made on supplying Tomahawk missiles, though Trump is weighing Kyiv’s 1,500-mile missile request. Ukraine has struck 21 of 38 Russian oil refineries, cutting daily output by roughly 20%. Russian spokespeople warned of heightened tension and potential retaliation.

articles.title: Canadian government asked to clarify whether Kneecap barred from country
articles.trailText: Opposition party says minister ‘either lied or has no clue how it works’ when he said band were ‘ineligible’ to enter
articles.summary: Canada’s opposition has pressed the government to clarify whether Belfast rap trio Kneecap have been barred after Liberal MP Vince Gasparro claimed on social media that, acting for the government, they were “ineligible” due to alleged glorification of Hamas and Hezbollah. The band denies any support for terrorist groups and plans legal action. Conservatives accused Gasparro of lying or ignorance. Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada has not responded. A UK magistrate recently dismissed a terror-related charge against member Liam Óg Ó hAnnaidh. Immigration lawyer Aidan Simardone warns that public allegations could prevent fair IRCC adjudication, leaving Kneecap’s Toronto and Vancouver tour in limbo.

articles.title: ‘We are the last hope’: Gen Z Madagascar vows to fight on until president resigns
articles.trailText: Protesting young people reject dissolution of government as insufficient and demand list of reforms
articles.summary: Since 25 September, leaderless youth group Gen Z Madagascar has staged nationwide protests after local councillors were arrested over Antananarivo’s water and power cuts. They reject President Andry Rajoelina’s Monday cabinet dissolution as insufficient, demanding his resignation, parliament’s dissolution, replacement of constitutional court and electoral commission members, and an end to entrenched corruption. The UN reports 22 killed and 100 injured. Inspired by Gen Z movements in Indonesia and Nepal, activists fly a One Piece–inspired flag, insist on fully transparent talks, deny looting charges and vow to press on until radical systemic reform is achieved.

articles.title: East or west? Czechs split over where possible return of ‘Trumpist’ could lead
articles.trailText: Former populist PM Andrej Babiš is eyeing a triumphant comeback days before the country goes to the polls
articles.summary: Andrej Babiš, 71-year-old billionaire ex-communist and former Czech PM who calls himself a ‘Trumpist’, leads polls with over 30% support ahead of elections. His ANO party morphed from a centrist anti-corruption movement into a populist right-wing bloc co-founding the EU’s Patriots for Europe group. He promises tax cuts, capped energy prices and pension reforms but opposes the EU migration pact and Ukraine aid. Critics warn his return could politicise media, civil service and tilt the Czech Republic toward illiberal partners, while supporters cite his pragmatic record and Senate veto power as safeguards.

articles.title: Fresh strikes held in France amid continuing political void
articles.trailText: Unions aim to keep up pressure on new PM, who has still not formed a government, over budget and super-rich tax
articles.summary: French trade unions staged nationwide strikes Oct 2 across 240 marches, drawing between 195,000 (police) and 600,000 (unions) demonstrators, to press new PM Sébastien Lecornu—appointed Sept 9 but yet to form a government—on reversing planned budget cuts, adopting a wealth tax on the super-rich and suspending Macron’s pension reforms. Lecornu, Macron’s ally, targets a 4.7% GDP deficit in 2026, rules out Zucman’s 2% wealth levy, and faces talks with Socialists for budgetary support.

articles.title: Historian uses AI to help identify Nazi in notorious Holocaust murder image
articles.trailText: Jürgen Matthäus has for years been investigating the killer – and is confident he has finally solved the mystery
articles.summary: US-based historian Jürgen Matthäus combines archival research, open-source journalism and AI facial analysis to identify the Nazi soldier who shot a kneeling Jewish man in a 1941 Berdychiv massacre photo. Published in Zeitschrift für Geschichtswissenschaft, his findings name SS-Untersturmführer Jakobus Onnen of Einsatzgruppe C, pinpoint the July 28 execution in Berdychiv, Ukraine, and correct the long-held belief it occurred in Vinnytsia. Bellingcat volunteers matched Onnen’s surviving family photos with 98% confidence. Matthäus argues AI complements traditional methods but emphasizes the indispensability of human scholarly judgment.

articles.title: China’s fifth-ranking official was suspect in dropped Westminster spy case
articles.trailText: Person who was thought to have received intelligence is understood to be Cai Qi, de facto chief of staff to Xi Jinping
articles.summary: British prosecutors alleged in April 2024 that Cai Qi, the fifth-ranked CCP politburo standing committee member and Xi Jinping’s de facto chief of staff, received politically sensitive Westminster intelligence from researchers Christopher Berry and Christopher Cash between December 2021 and February 2023. Last September the CPS dropped espionage charges for lack of evidence, prompting criticism from MPs and Downing Street. China experts say it’s implausible a politburo member would engage such contacts, exposing gaps in UK understanding of Chinese politics.

articles.title: Deaths, disappearances and forced recruitment: refugees recount horrors of relentless war in Sudan
articles.trailText: Refugees who left Darfur and Khartoum for South Sudan say they feared being targeted by both sides in conflict
articles.summary: Since April 2023 Sudan’s civil war between Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the army has killed over 150,000, displaced 14 million, and forced mass refugee flows into South Sudan. At Renk transit centre, Darfurians like 25-year-old Suba Dafallah recount witnessing RSF fighters massacre family members—his mother and two sisters—and abduct another sibling. Families report looting, air strikes, sexual violence, ethnic targeting of darker-skinned communities, forced recruitment by both armies, and mass graves. Ex-soldier Gamal Issa, farmer Nadir Omar and others describe perilous journeys, arbitrary detentions and no safe haven. Aid groups warn of one of the worst humanitarian crises of the 21st century as civilians flee torture and siege.

articles.title: Gaza aid flotilla: update on what we know so far about Israel’s interception of boat convoy
articles.trailText: A video from the Israeli foreign ministry showed the most prominent of the flotilla’s passengers, Greta Thunberg, sitting on a deck surrounded by soldiers
articles.summary: Israel’s navy has intercepted 23 of over 40 vessels of the Global Sumud Flotilla en route to Gaza with food and medicine, detaining around 500 activists—parliamentarians, lawyers and campaigners including Greta Thunberg—who denounce the boarding, involving water cannon and scrambled communications, as an “illegal” raid and war crime. The operation triggered protests in Italy, Brussels, Athens, Buenos Aires and Berlin, diplomatic rebukes from Turkey, Spain, Ireland, Mexico, Brazil and Malaysia, and led Colombia’s president to expel Israeli diplomats. Israel said it had warned the flotilla to turn back from an active combat zone and offered to deliver aid through monitored channels.

articles.title: Thursday briefing: Democrats gamble on another government shutdown
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Shutdowns have become a mainstay of the US political cycle – but will this one make a difference, or play into Trump’s hands?
articles.summary: Congress failed to pass an interim spending bill, triggering a government shutdown at 00:00 on Oct 2. Over 750,000 federal workers are furloughed, critical services paused, and GDP losses could reach billions if prolonged. Democrats are betting the shutdown will spotlight Republican healthcare cuts, Medicaid reductions and underscore their resistance to Trump’s agenda, though they risk voter backlash as blame usually falls on the shutdown’s instigators. Republicans, lacking the 60 Senate votes to pass funding, face Trump’s threats of partisan mass firings and permanent agency cuts, raising stakes ahead of midterms.

articles.title: No apology and no answers: parents in agony amid search for children trapped in Indonesia school collapse
articles.trailText: Officials say 59 people, mostly young male students, remain trapped in collapsed school in Sidoarjo amid growing questions about the quality of its construction
articles.summary: On Monday the four-storey Al Khoziny Islamic boarding school in Sidoarjo, East Java, pancaked during afternoon prayer, trapping over 100 students. Three days later, five bodies have been recovered and 59 pupils remain missing, with rescue teams doubting further survivors. Tearful parents, who had warned of substandard construction, camp outside demanding apologies and answers from school management. Preliminary investigations cite foundational failure under new fourth-floor additions. Rescuers, hindered by unstable debris, are digging narrow tunnels and deploying thermal drones as Indonesia’s disaster agency urges stricter building oversight.

articles.title: Israeli naval forces board pro-Palestinian flotilla 75 miles from Gaza
articles.trailText: Greta Thunberg arrested and taken into custody after six of the flotilla’s boats were boarded
articles.summary: On Oct 1, Israeli naval forces intercepted 13 of over 40 civilian vessels from the Global Sumud Flotilla roughly 75 miles off Gaza, boarding six boats including the lead ship Alma and detaining Swedish activist Greta Thunberg and other lawmakers, lawyers and aid workers among some 500 participants. Israel, citing a legal maritime blockade and offering to offload humanitarian cargo in Ashdod, faced protests in Italy and divided European reactions as the remaining flotilla vessels vowed to press on toward Gaza.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Attack cutting power to Chornobyl nuclear plant a ‘global threat’, says Zelenskyy
articles.trailText: Emergency diesel generators brought online after Russia accused of shelling substation supplying power to scene of 1986 disaster. What we know on day 1,317
articles.summary: Reacting to Russian shelling that cut power to the defunct Chornobyl nuclear plant, President Zelenskyy warned that attacks on Ukraine’s energy infrastructures, including nuclear sites, pose a global threat. UN atomic watchdog said emergency diesel generators are keeping Chornobyl’s confinement structure powered. This follows an eight-day blackout at the Zaporizhzhia plant. Meanwhile the US plans to share intelligence for Ukrainian strikes on Russian oil and energy targets, and the EU is pushing a “drone wall” and eastern flank defences against Russian hybrid warfare. G7 ministers vowed measures to curb Russian oil revenues, and France detained a tanker linked to mystery drone incursions.

articles.title: Vanuatu open to signing deal with Australia but will not be subject to ‘bullying’ from larger countries
articles.trailText: Country moves to deepen policing ties with China as Australia continues negotiations on Nakamal agreement, which was not signed last month as hoped
articles.summary: Vanuatu’s internal affairs minister Andrew Napuat says Port Vila remains willing to sign Australia’s $500m Nakamal security deal but only on terms respecting its sovereignty and without “bullying” from larger states. Negotiations stalled over concerns the pact would limit other infrastructure funding. Parallel talks are underway to formalise a policing MoU with China—an arrangement separate from the Australian accord—while Canberra insists it respects Vanuatu’s sovereign processes. Observers view the Nakamal treaty as a difficult sell, noting Chinese policing support risks authoritarian influence but Australia remains Vanuatu’s principal security partner.

articles.title: Nearly 100 years after her death, Oxford’s first female Indigenous scholar honoured
articles.trailText: Mākereti Papakura died weeks before handing in her thesis at Oxford university documenting the life and customs of her tribe, work that is still used by Māori today
articles.summary: More than a century after Māori trailblazer Mākereti Papakura died weeks before submitting her Oxford anthropology thesis on Te Arawa customs, Oxford has posthumously awarded her an MPhil. Believed to be the first female Indigenous student at the university, her descendants, who performed a haka during the ceremony, have long championed her recognition. Papakura’s detailed manuscript, published posthumously, remains vital for Māori language revival and land claims. The Te Arawa delegation also restored and returned a carved tōtara pou Papakura brought to England in 1911.

articles.title: Gym bros, monks, retirees: thousands descend on Taiwan town to clean up after devastating flood
articles.trailText: Trains packed with volunteers arrive at tourist town of Guangfu, days after typhoon sent millions of tonnes of mud and water crashing through its streets
articles.summary: Thousands of volunteers—students, monks, retirees, gym enthusiasts and migrant workers—have descended on Guangfu in Hualien county, Taiwan, following Typhoon Ragasa’s breach of a natural dam on the Matai’an river. When the dam collapsed under 15.4m tonnes of rain-triggered water and sludge, 18 residents, mostly elderly, perished, and mud buried homes and cars. With official responders stretched thin, more than 30,000 “shovel supermen” arrived by added train services over a long weekend, organized by police, military and Tzu Chi charity teams. Residents thank volunteers for early aid after delayed evacuation enforcement; political dispute rages over responsibility. Cleanup continues amid chaotic but hopeful crowds.

articles.title: Russia accused of sabotaging last power line into Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant
articles.trailText: Satellite images of damaged area show no sign of shelling that Moscow says prevents repair
articles.summary: Russia is accused of deliberately sabotaging the last external power line into Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, leaving it eight days without grid power and dependent on backup diesel generators. Greenpeace-commissioned satellite images analysed by McKenzie Intelligence Services found no shelling craters, contradicting Russian claims of Ukrainian fire. The IAEA warns generators have fuel for only ten days. Observers say Moscow’s political aim is to force a safety crisis and justify integrating the site into the Russian grid, raising meltdown risks if cooling fails.

articles.title: ‘A life of captivity’: Canada refuses marine park’s request to export its whales to China
articles.trailText: Fisheries minister says rehoming Marineland’s cetaceans in China would only ‘perpetuate the treatment’ the whales have endured
articles.summary: Canada has refused Marineland’s request to export its 30 beluga whales to China, citing potential mistreatment. Fisheries Minister Joanne Thompson denied the sale to Chimelong Ocean Kingdom, warning that continued captivity would harm the whales’ health. Marineland, home to one of the largest captive whale populations, has seen 20 cetacean deaths since 2019 and halted summer operations. A 2019 federal ban bars whale sales, breeding and captivity. Ontario inspectors made over 200 visits and issued 33 compliance orders. Critics, including former trainer Phil Demers, urge relocation under stricter welfare laws—possibly in the U.S.—and government custody to ensure proper care.

articles.title: French military detain two after boarding Russia-linked oil tanker suspected of launching drones
articles.trailText: Tanker, named on list of ‘shadow fleet’ vessels, may have been launchpad for drones that closed Denmark airports
articles.summary: French military boarded the Boracay, a Benin-flagged oil tanker tied to Russia’s “shadow fleet,” seizing two crew (captain and first mate) after they failed to justify the vessel’s nationality and refused cooperation. Carrying 750,000 barrels from Primorsk to India, the ship is suspected as a drone launchpad that closed Copenhagen and Aalborg airports on Sept 22 and 24. Now under investigation in Brest and diverted to Saint-Nazaire, it faces sanctions amid a wider European probe into Russia-linked drone incursions. President Macron backed the inquiry while the Kremlin denied awareness.

articles.title: A broader view of US Jews’ support for Israel | Letter
articles.trailText: Letter: Responding to an article by Mark Mazower, Roger Fisken writes that the six-day war led to a disastrous response from the Arab states
articles.summary: In this letter, Roger Fisken challenges Mark Mazower’s portrayal of US Jewish support for Israel as focused on redressing 1930s wrongs, arguing it stemmed from a far longer history of European antisemitic oppression—from Russian-empire pogroms to the 1929 Hebron massacre—and the Holocaust’s culmination of that suffering. He credits this legacy with Israel’s 1948 founding and defense against Arab assaults. While Mazower warns the 1967 Six-Day War victory risked being Pyrrhic, Fisken asserts the Arab states’ Khartoum resolution—no peace, negotiation or recognition—proved the true disaster, damaging both Palestinians and Israelis.

articles.title: Israel says ‘last opportunity’ for Gaza City residents to leave
articles.trailText: Defence minister issues warning, while Hamas reportedly considers seeking amendments to Trump plan
articles.summary: Israel’s military has issued its final evacuation order for Gaza City residents ahead of an intensified offensive, with Defence Minister Israel Katz warning those who stay will be deemed terrorists. At least 46 people were killed, including 36 in Gaza City, and the ICRC suspended operations amid heavy bombardment. International law experts say forced displacement orders don’t strip civilians of protection. Israel also closed the southern–northern route, effectively splitting Gaza. Meanwhile Hamas is reportedly considering amendments to Trump’s 20-point ceasefire plan—demanding disarmament, hostages release, and an Israeli withdrawal—while international mediators prepare talks in Doha.

articles.title: General strike against 13-hour work day brings Greece to a halt
articles.trailText: Transport systems, hospitals and schools hit, as workers say laws kill hopes of work-life balance
articles.summary: A 24-hour general strike paralysed Greece on Oct 1 as public- and private-sector workers, unions and civil servants protested government plans to legalise 13-hour workdays. Transport, hospitals, schools and ports came to a standstill as unions decried the measure—backed by PM Kyriakos Mitsotakis and labour minister Niki Kerameus—to boost “flexibility” by extending daily hours by up to five extra. Critics warn the change, set for passage this month, will exacerbate burnout, labour abuses and low wages (minimum €880/month) in a country already near the top of EU work hours. Union leaders liken it to “modern slavery.”

articles.title: Philippines earthquake death toll rises to at least 69 as Cebu hospitals struggle
articles.trailText: More than 700 aftershocks recorded while rescuers search for casualties in coastal city of Bogo
articles.summary: A magnitude-6.9 quake hit north Cebu near Bogo on Sept. 30, killing at least 69 people—30 in Bogo, 22 in San Remigio, 10 in Medellin, 5 in Tabogon and 1 each in Sogod and Tabuelan—and triggering over 700 aftershocks. Hospitals overflow under blue tents as rescuers drill through collapsed motels and landslide sites amid heavy rain and power cuts. Cebu authorities call for medical volunteers, impose price controls on essentials, and President Marcos pledges swift aid to quake-affected communities.

articles.title: Europe in ‘most dangerous situation’ since second world war, Danish PM warns
articles.trailText: Mette Frederiksen tells EU leaders all countries are affected by ‘Russian hybrid war’ via drones or sabotage
articles.summary: At an EU summit in Copenhagen, Danish prime minister Mette Frederiksen warned Europe faces its most dangerous security crisis since WWII amid a “Russian hybrid war” of drone incursions and sabotage across member states. She urged unity on defence by 2030, backed by proposals for a €800bn plan including a “drone wall,” eastern-flank surveillance, missile defences and a space shield. While Emmanuel Macron stressed cautious deterrence, leaders are split over a €140bn EU loan to Ukraine funded by frozen Russian assets—supported by Finland, Sweden and Ireland but opposed by France, Belgium and Luxembourg on legal and financial-risk grounds.

articles.title: The Moldova mandate: the former Soviet republic opted to defy Russia. Here’s why
articles.trailText: Voters have confirmed they want to be in the EU club. In standing up to Putin, they may have reminded Europe why its democracy is precious
articles.summary: Moldova’s recent vote delivered a decisive pro-EU mandate: President Maia Sandu’s PAS won an outright parliamentary majority, empowering reforms toward EU accession by 2030. Moscow’s campaign—spanning propaganda, cyber-attacks, vote-buying and leveraging the Orthodox Church and Transnistria—failed to sway a populace weary of energy shocks, double-digit inflation and a high refugee burden. With 24% still backing pro-Russia lists, Moldova remains vulnerable to hybrid meddling. Yet younger voters, fearing Russian expansion, see EU membership as existential. Observers warn interference will persist and note the EU’s slow decision-making, but Moldova’s resilience spotlights the bloc’s democratic appeal.

articles.title: UK government wins £122m pandemic case against Michelle Mone-linked firm over faulty PPE
articles.trailText: Trial heard 25m surgical gowns supplied by PPE Medpro to protect NHS staff were unusable and could ‘seriously harm or kill patients’
articles.summary: The UK high court has ordered PPE Medpro, linked to peer Michelle Mone and husband Doug Barrowman, to repay £122m for 25m surgical gowns supplied under a 2020 VIP-lane contract. Mrs Justice Cockerill ruled the gowns were unsterile and invalidly CE-marked, risking patient safety. PPE Medpro, now in administration with under £1m in funds, has until 15 October to repay. A separate £8m storage cost claim was dismissed. The National Crime Agency’s investigation into possible criminal wrongdoing continues amid Mone and Barrowman’s denials.

articles.title: Pope Leo criticizes Trump’s hardline immigration policies: ‘I don’t know if that’s pro-life’
articles.trailText: Pope questions what it means to be ‘pro-life’ amid the ‘inhuman treatment of immigrants’ in the US
articles.summary: Pope Leo, the first American pontiff, publicly challenged Donald Trump’s hardline immigration measures, questioning whether opposing abortion while endorsing the ‘inhuman treatment of immigrants’ aligns with Catholic ‘pro-life’ doctrine. Speaking at Castel Gandolfo, he emphasized life’s sanctity from conception to natural death and reiterated that support for the death penalty also contradicts pro-life teaching. Responding to the Chicago archdiocese’s decision to honor Democratic Senator Dick Durbin for his immigration advocacy—opposed by conservative bishops—Leo called for evaluating leaders’ broader service. Durbin ultimately declined the award, citing divisions within the Church over immigration policy.

articles.title: China replaces high-level diplomat after reported detention
articles.trailText: Liu Jianchao, previously tipped to be next foreign minister, has not been seen publicly in months
articles.summary: China’s ruling CCP quietly replaced Liu Jianchao as head of its International Department two months after he vanished during a July overseas trip and was reportedly detained on corruption and party-discipline charges. An Oxford-educated, English-fluent diplomat once tipped to become foreign minister, Liu’s personal profile was taken offline without announcement. His successor, Liu Haixing, former European Department director, now emerges as a potential future foreign minister. The unexplained purge follows the 2023 ouster of ex-FM Qin Gang and underscores Xi Jinping���s intensified graft crackdown, which has disciplined over six million officials since 2012.

articles.title: Pro-Palestine flotilla heading towards Gaza ‘harassed by Israeli naval boats’
articles.trailText: Account of ‘intimidatory operation’ comes as Italy and Greece repeat call for Israel to guarantee safety of flotilla
articles.summary: The Global Sumud Flotilla, carrying around 500 activists including Greta Thunberg and Ada Colau, reports that Israeli naval vessels circled its lead boat north of Egypt, jamming communications in an ‘intimidatory operation.’ Italy and Greece have urged Israel to guarantee participant safety and accept handover of its humanitarian cargo—offers the flotilla rejects, insisting its goal is to challenge the 2009 naval blockade of Gaza. Spain’s navy shadows the convoy after Italy withdrew its warship. Israel warns the mission risks undermining a US-brokered peace effort and has elite Shayetet 13 forces on standby.

articles.title: ‘This is strength’: stories of enslaved Africans in Grenada will be made into searchable archive
articles.trailText: Depths of Paradise project backed by British family and created by Stephen Lewis, a descendant of survivors
articles.summary: Stephen Lewis, a Grenadian descendant of enslaved survivors, is creating Depths of Paradise, the first searchable archive combining over 1,000 enslaved Africans’ narratives with records of British plantation owners compensated after the 1834 abolition. Supported by the Trevelyan family—who publicly apologized for their ancestors’ slaveholding and funded £100,000 in reparations—the database uses wills, letters and UCL’s Legacies of British Slavery to fill historical gaps. Aimed at schools, researchers and diaspora tracing genealogy, it features stories like Rebecca Ahmuty’s self-manumission. Backers hope it sparks wider digitisation of Caribbean archives ahead of the 2026 Commonwealth meeting and advances reparative justice.

articles.title: Taiwan now biggest importer of Russian naphtha despite being Ukraine ally
articles.trailText: Island imported $1.3bn of crude oil product in first half of 2025 despite joining sanctions against Moscow, report finds
articles.summary: Despite joining sanctions on Moscow and backing Ukraine, Taiwan imported $1.3 bn of Russian naphtha in H1 2025—six times its 2022 monthly average and 44 percent more than H1 2024. Naphtha derivatives are vital for Taiwan’s semiconductor sector, yet its reliance on Russian fuel—6.8 m tonnes worth $4.9 bn since February 2022, almost 20 percent of Russia’s exports—raises conflict and credibility risks. Experts warn this revenue aids the Kremlin, amid concerns over Taiwan’s 97 percent energy import dependency and potential China–Taiwan escalation, though some see it as petrochemical opportunism.

articles.title: Caribbean nations launch EU-style deal to let citizens work freely across borders
articles.trailText: Barbados, Belize, Dominica and St Vincent agree landmark pact letting citizens live and work freely across their borders
articles.summary: After decades of Caricom negotiations, Barbados, Belize, Dominica and St Vincent & the Grenadines launched an EU-style free movement agreement letting citizens reside, work and stay indefinitely without permits. This expansion of the Caricom Single Market & Economy aims to stem the exodus of skilled professionals in health, education and other sectors, foster economic and cultural integration, and pave the way for a unified Caribbean market. Officials plan to roll out the model to other members. Concerns include strain on social services and local job competition, though supporters view it as vital to retain talent.

articles.title: Jailed Georgian politicians allege links between ruling party and Iran in letter to UK
articles.trailText: Exclusive: Imprisoned opposition leaders call on foreign secretary to impose sanctions over ‘unprecedented expansion’ of Iranian influence
articles.summary: Seven jailed Georgian opposition leaders have written from Rustavi prisons to UK Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper warning of an unprecedented expansion of Iranian influence via ties between the ruling Georgian Dream party and Tehran. They urge British sanctions on party officials, oligarch Bidzina Ivanishvili’s associates and owners of alleged propaganda outlets such as Imedi TV, accusing them of amplifying pro-government and pro-Russian messaging. Citing solidarity gestures by Georgia’s deputy FM at Iran’s embassy and PM Kobakhidze’s Tehran visit alongside Hamas and Hezbollah, they decry the regime’s autocratic frontal assault on democracy.

articles.title: Government ‘deeply concerned’ about safety of Australians aboard Gaza flotilla
articles.trailText: The Global Sumud Flotilla is aiming to break Israel’s blockade of Gaza and deliver aid
articles.summary: Australia’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says it is deeply concerned for six Australians confirmed aboard the Global Sumud Flotilla—over 40 vessels carrying 500 people including Greta Thunberg—aiming to breach Israel’s Gaza blockade to deliver aid. Canberra has lobbied Israel, Spain, Italy and Greece over the risk of interception, drone fire and detention, urging all parties to respect international humanitarian law. Italy has halted its naval tracking, offering a Cyprus-port compromise. Canberra warns citizens to use official relief channels and stands ready to provide consular support.

articles.title: Wednesday briefing: The prime minister’s big conference speech promised renewal – can he deliver?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: Subdued vibes on the floor, poor polls and teetering party politics stand in the way of Keir Starmer’s plan to take Britain to the promised land
articles.summary: At Labour’s 2025 conference Keir Starmer delivered a forceful speech likening his mission to post-war rebuilding and declaring a ‘battle for the soul of the country,’ with clear attacks on Nigel Farage and racism. Think-tanks praised a new progressive vision, but a subdued conference floor, a 40% collapse in youth membership and steep poll deficits exposed a waning grassroots base. With votes hemorrhaging to Reform UK, the Lib Dems and Greens, and unaddressed demands on benefits and local investment, Labour needs more than rallying rhetoric—it must mobilise activists and articulate an inspiring, unifying plan to turn its election fortunes around.

articles.title: ‘A steampunk Mr Tayto’: why Irish critics hate Netflix’s House of Guinness
articles.trailText: While US and UK reviewers have praised the series, in Ireland it has faced a barrage of withering put-downs
articles.summary: In Netflix’s eight-part drama House of Guinness, Steven Knight’s lavish retelling of 1860s Dublin—shot in Liverpool with James Norton and a contemporary Irish rock soundtrack—has earned 89% audience approval and rave US/UK reviews for its style and intrigue. Yet Irish critics panned its ‘rudimentary’ colonial lens, anachronistic costumes, dim lighting, clumsy dialogue and caricatured Fenians. The Irish Times condemned its historical inaccuracies, the Irish Independent decried clichés and over-swearing, and social media mocked its ‘steampunk Mr Tayto’ hero and Halloween-style rebels.

articles.title: Slovakia marks ‘dark day’ as LGBTQ+ rights rolled back in parliament
articles.trailText: Amendment to constitution stipulates that male and female are the only recognised sexes and makes adoption nearly impossible for same-sex couples
articles.summary: Slovakia’s parliament has enacted a constitutional amendment defining sex strictly as male/female, banning legal gender recognition, and effectively preventing same-sex couples from adopting. Campaigners call it a “dark day” and warn it erodes LGBTQ+ rights under populist PM Robert Fico, echoing Russia’s and Hungary’s anti-LGBTQ+ measures. Critics say it conflicts with EU and international human rights law, risks Slovakia’s EU standing, and strengthens state power over individual freedoms. Advocacy groups report widespread fear among LGBTQ+ people and urge legal protections instead of “draconian” rollbacks.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Estonia warns of Putin distraction tactics as EU leaders meet to discuss ‘drone wall’
articles.trailText: Estonian leader Kristen Michal says Putin wants Europe ‘talking about ourselves, not Ukraine’ ahead of meeting in Copenhagen.
articles.summary: In Copenhagen ahead of a two-day EU summit, Estonia’s PM Kristen Michal warned that Putin’s recent airspace incursions and drone flights are designed to distract Europe from supporting Ukraine. EU leaders will debate boosting defences—including a proposed continent-wide “drone wall” to intercept Russian UAVs—and using €140bn in frozen Russian assets as a reparation loan for Kyiv. Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant has been offline for seven days under shelling, raising meltdown fears. Romania plans joint production of defensive drones with Ukraine, while Princess Anne visited Kyiv to express British solidarity.

articles.title: Indonesia school collapse: 91 missing and three dead as rescuers search rubble for second day
articles.trailText: More than 90 people missing and at least three dead after building collapses as students held prayers at school in Sidoarjo
articles.summary: Authorities in Sidoarjo, East Java, report 91 people missing and three confirmed dead after the fourth-floor collapse of the Al Khoziny Islamic boarding school during late afternoon prayers. Rescuers, using cameras and listening devices, detected at least six survivors under concrete slabs. An excavator and crane assist, but heavy machinery is limited to avoid further collapse. Ninety-nine students and staff have been accounted for, with 26 injured still hospitalized. Investigators blame foundation pillar failure amid a nine-month expansion, prompting calls for stricter building safety standards.

articles.title: Trump gives Hamas ‘three or four days’ to respond to his peace plan for Gaza
articles.trailText: US president warns militant group will ‘pay in hell’ if it rejects the deal, which seeks to end two-year-long war
articles.summary: Trump gave Hamas just three to four days to accept his 20-point Gaza peace and reconstruction plan, warning they���ll “pay in hell” if they refuse and promising full US backing for Israel’s continued offensive. The deal calls for Hamas’s disarmament, release of the remaining 48 Israeli hostages within 72 hours of a ceasefire, freeing nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, then a technocratic transitional authority headed by Trump overseeing Gaza. Netanyahu and many Arab states endorse it; Hamas is consulting internally and with allies. Some Palestinian factions and Israeli far-right ministers denounce its “impossible” conditions.

articles.title: Germany seeks to extradite Ukrainian over 2022 Nord Stream gas pipeline attack
articles.trailText: Man held in Poland on suspicion of causing explosions that damaged undersea pipelines between Russia and Germany
articles.summary: Germany seeks extradition of Ukrainian diver Volodymyr Z, arrested in Poland on a European arrest warrant for allegedly planting explosives on the Nord Stream 1 and 2 pipelines near Bornholm in September 2022. Investigators say he dove to the seabed from a rented yacht using forged documents. His lawyer contends Ukrainians can’t be criminally liable for attacking pipelines that funded Russia’s war, which Moscow also blames on Kyiv. If extradited, he’ll face trial in Karlsruhe, complicating German-Ukrainian wartime ties. A second Ukrainian suspect was arrested in Italy last month.

articles.title: ‘Fatal flaws’: analysts cast doubt on Tony Blair’s plan for future of Gaza
articles.trailText: Former PM seems a perfect fit for Trump’s new era but his track record in the Middle East is not reassuring
articles.summary: Tony Blair’s bid to join Donald Trump’s Gaza “peace board” as interim consul revives his Middle East ambitions but renews doubts over his record. Critics highlight his role in the Iraq invasion, his narrow focus on Islamist extremism and entanglement of personal business, and his toothless 2007–2015 Quartet envoy mission centered on economic development while sidelining Palestinian political rights. His 2006 rejection of Hamas election results and lobbying against Palestinian UN membership worsened Gaza’s crisis. Analysts warn his draft proposal prioritises economic over political progress and will be undercut by Israel’s “death by a thousand cuts.”

articles.title: Mass slaughter in Gaza stands apart from other genocides, Chris Sidoti says: ‘People cannot escape’
articles.trailText: Australian human rights expert who was on UN commission of inquiry labels Israel’s strategy a failure that ‘has not brought peace and has not destroyed Hamas’
articles.summary: Chris Sidoti, a former UN international crimes investigator, argues Israel’s Gaza operations constitute a unique genocide because Palestinians cannot flee. In a new UN commission report, Sidoti details mass slaughter, infrastructure destruction, imposed starvation and daily death rates of 75–300, with over 65,000 identified victims—half women and children. He cites direct incitement by Israeli leaders and systematic bombardment as evidence of genocidal intent under international law. He labels Israel’s post-7 October strategy a failure, criticizes Security Council inaction, and urges global legal and policy measures, including Australia suspending defence ties to Israel.

articles.title: Indonesia school collapse: three dead and over 90 missing as rescue effort continues
articles.trailText: Instability of building in East Java town hampers search but 99 boys and school staff known to have survived
articles.summary: At Al Khoziny Islamic boarding school in Sidoarjo, East Java, a four-storey building under construction collapsed as students gathered for prayers in a mosque on a lower floor, killing three and leaving 91 teenage boys and staff unaccounted for. Ninety-nine occupants survived; 26 injured are in local hospitals. Rescuers, fearing further collapse, rely on manual search alongside a crane and excavator. Families, clutching a whiteboard list of survivors, anxiously call missing names; one uncle still seeks nephew Rosi. Authorities suspect weak foundations couldn’t bear the added fourth-floor weight.

articles.title: Israel-backed militia groups potentially threaten new peace plan for Gaza
articles.trailText: Israeli military has been arming alternatives to Hamas, with up to a dozen new groups emerging
articles.summary: Israeli forces have armed and trained up to a dozen local militias in Gaza—most prominently Yasser abu Shabab’s Popular Forces and Hossam al-Astal’s new Khan Younis faction—to seize control of territory and oversee aid alongside the opaque Gaza Humanitarian Foundation. Rivalry with Hamas, extortion and looting by these groups have caused over 220 intra-Palestinian violent incidents since October 2023, killing roughly 400. This fragmentation deepens Gaza’s humanitarian crisis and risks derailing Trump’s 20-point Gaza plan—featuring a technocrat council and international stabilization force—by fostering criminality and lawlessness.

articles.title: US deports 120 Iranians back to Tehran in Trump immigration crackdown
articles.trailText: Uncommon instance of cooperation between the two countries reportedly came after months of talks
articles.summary: Under Trump’s immigration crackdown, the US plans to expel up to 400 Iranians and this week flew 120 detainees on a US-chartered flight from Louisiana via Qatar back to Tehran—a rare diplomatic cooperation after months of negotiation. Many returnees crossed from Mexico illegally or faced other immigration issues. Human rights advocates warn Iranian returnees, including activists, dissidents and LGBTQ+ individuals, risk persecution despite Tehran’s safety assurances, potentially breaching international non-refoulement obligations.

articles.title: AfD politician’s former aide convicted of spying for China
articles.trailText: Jian Guo jailed for five years after acting as agent for Chinese intelligence while working for Maximilian Krah
articles.summary: Jian Guo, a German national and former aide to AfD MP Maximilian Krah, was sentenced to 4 years 9 months for spying for Chinese intelligence from 2019–2024. He passed EU parliamentary documents, personal data on AfD leaders Alice Weidel and Tino Chrupalla, and monitored Chinese dissidents. Co-defendant Yaqi X, a Leipzig/Halle airport employee, received a suspended 1 year 9 months for supplying flight and military cargo details. Krah, who denies involvement, has had his immunity lifted amid a separate bribery and money-laundering probe into alleged Chinese payments. Beijing has dismissed European espionage claims as political smear.

articles.title: Men in wet clothes claiming to be Camino pilgrims arrested over alleged ‘narco-sub’ plot
articles.trailText: Three men had fled in taxi after allegedly piloting vessel carrying 3.65 tonnes of cocaine to Galicia, Spanish police say
articles.summary: Spanish National Police and the DEA arrested three men in Galicia suspected of piloting a semi-submersible carrying 3.65 tonnes of cocaine from South America. The probe began in August into a gang in Outes posing as a marine equipment company. On Sept 13, officers intercepted high-speed boats returning to port and seized bundles of cocaine—one tonne recovered after a trailer overturned; the rest found on a nearby beach. The alleged crew, a Colombian and two Ecuadorians, were captured by local police after fleeing in wet clothes in a taxi and posing as Camino de Santiago pilgrims. Authorities also detained 14 suspects, seized €54,680, two boats, five cars and a trailer.

articles.title: Afghanistan ‘blind without phones and internet’ on second day of telecoms blackout
articles.trailText: Taliban authorities cut fibre-optic network in nationwide shutdown of communications to prevent ‘vice’
articles.summary: On Sept 30, Taliban authorities, following orders from supreme leader Hibatullah Akhundzada, severed Afghanistan’s national fibre-optic network, plunging mobile and internet connectivity below 1% in a second day of nationwide blackout. Officially aimed at curbing “immorality” and online pornography, the shutdown halts banking, customs, commerce, education and healthcare—Najibullah, a Kabul shopkeeper, says the market is frozen without phones. Human Rights Watch and UNAMA warn the disconnection infringes fundamental rights, deepens the humanitarian crisis and suppresses dissent, particularly after bans on girls’ education and women’s work. Authorities say services will resume “when morality is restored.”

articles.title: ‘Not even animals escape the extreme barbarity’: wildlife caught in Rio’s rampant gun crime
articles.trailText: From capuchin monkeys to mantled hawks - Instituto Vida Livre has treated a myriad of shot animals in a city blighted by gun crime
articles.summary: At Rio’s Instituto Vida Livre wildlife hospital, medics have treated at least 69 animals shot in the past decade, from capuchin monkeys like Maria—paralysed and ultimately killed by a bullet in her spine—to mantled hawks, capybaras, parrots, alligators and a horse wounded during a police raid. This surge of gunshot wildlife injuries reflects Rio’s tangled biodiversity and rampant urban armed violence: 816 people suffered firearm wounds in six months. Activists blame Brazil’s pro-gun boom under Bolsonaro, noting pets and protected species alike fall victim to stray bullets, targeted cruelty and the city’s “banalisation” of firearms.

articles.title: ‘His drug is power’: Lukashenko reaches out to the west
articles.trailText: President of Belarus has been edging out of the diplomatic freeze, cautiously probing for space beyond Moscow
articles.summary: Belarus’s long-serving leader Alexander Lukashenko has begun to pry himself out of diplomatic isolation, leveraging a perceived opening with the Trump administration to secure personal meetings, symbolized by receiving White House cufflinks. While Europe debates if engaging him could reduce Russia’s sway, Lukashenko has cautiously offered gestures—such as releasing political prisoners and inviting US officers to observe Zapad-2025 drills—in hopes of sanctions relief. Economic strains, from shortages to stalled exports, have deepened his reliance on Russia, yet he continues a tightrope strategy of hedging between Moscow and the West to preserve power.

articles.title: Trump’s peace proposal welcomed by world leaders but Palestinians remain sceptical
articles.trailText: After being welcomed by Arab, Islamic and European leaders, experts say onus now rests on Hamas to accept plan
articles.summary: Donald Trump and Israel’s PM Benjamin Netanyahu unveiled a 20-point Gaza peace plan: immediate ceasefire, hostages-for-prisoners swap, phased Israeli military withdrawal, Hamas disarmament and an international-led transitional authority. While leaders in Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar, Jordan, Egypt, Turkey, Pakistan and EU governments including the UK, France and Germany welcomed it as the only US-backed roadmap to end genocide, Netanyahu has already backtracked on full withdrawal. Hamas, excluded from talks, remains sceptical and unlikely to concede power. Gaza residents and Palestinian figures warn the plan is unrealistic; US diplomatic veterans urge pressure on Hamas. Israelis and Gazans express cautious hope.

articles.title: Share your reaction to the Moldova election results
articles.trailText: We would like to hear from people in Moldova and what they think about Maia Sandu’s Action and Solidarity party (PAS) winning the election
articles.summary: Moldova’s pro-European Action and Solidarity party (PAS), led by President Maia Sandu, has narrowly retained its 101-seat parliamentary majority, winning 50.03% of votes with over 99.5% counted. Sandu deemed the vote the most consequential in Moldova’s history, casting it as a choice between continued Western integration and a return to Russia’s influence. A community callout (closed 23 Oct 2025) sought local perspectives on this pivotal result and its impact on Moldova’s future direction.

articles.title: Will pivotal election turn Czech Republic into another anti-EU agitator?
articles.trailText: ANO party, led by former PM Andrej Babiš, is leading polls and may form a Eurosceptic and pro-Russia coalition
articles.summary: Voters in the Czech Republic head to the polls on 3–4 October in a pivotal election that could see former PM Andrej Babiš’s populist ANO (30% in polls) lead a eurosceptic, pro-Russia coalition. ANO would likely rely on far-right SPD, left-wing Stačilo! or niche Motorists for Themselves to secure a minority government, risking clashes over migration, climate policy, EU green rules and Ukraine aid amid high inflation and living-cost woes. Centre-right Spolu, Stan and Pirates refuse alliances with ANO, SPD or Stačilo!, and President Pavel may veto ministers hostile to EU/Nato.

articles.title: Typhoon Bualoi death toll rises to at least 30 across Vietnam, Thailand and Philippines
articles.trailText: Vietnamese authorities say typhoon was the most devastating storm to hit the country this year
articles.summary: Typhoon Bualoi has killed at least 19 and left 21 missing in Vietnam, plus 11 dead in the Philippines and four fatalities in Thailand, bringing the regional toll above 30. The storm’s downpours and coastal swells triggered floods, landslides and flash-flood warnings after over 300mm fell in northern Vietnam and Hanoi. Thailand erected barriers to protect Ayutthaya’s Unesco temples. Now a tropical depression heading to Laos, Bualoi follows Ragasa, highlighting experts’ concerns that warming seas fuel stronger, wetter storms.

articles.title: Tuesday briefing: A roadmap for peace in Gaza – or an ultimatum?
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: The key details of a new proposal for peace, as Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu meet in Washington
articles.summary: At a simultaneous Washington press event, Trump hailed a “peace plan” for Gaza promising “eternal peace,” while Netanyahu cast it as fulfilling Israel’s war aims without advancing a Palestinian state and preserving Israeli forces. Hamas and the Palestinian Authority were excluded. The US 21-point proposal, reportedly with Arab backing, calls for no Hamas role, phased Israeli withdrawal, hostages’ return, and reconstruction overseen by a transitional board including Tony Blair, with vague future statehood and deradicalization steps. Observers warn it resembles an ultimatum negotiated without Palestinian input, leaving governance details unresolved.

articles.title: South Korea raises cyber threat level after huge data centre fire sparks hacking fears
articles.trailText: National cyber security centre raises alert level to ‘caution’ as technicians race to restore government systems after battery fire sparked nationwide chaos
articles.summary: After a lithium-ion battery fire at the national information resources service datacentre in Daejeon on 27 Sep paralysed 647 government systems—email, intranet, mobile IDs, banking and student records—South Korea’s cybersecurity centre raised its alert from “attention” to “caution,” fearing hackers could exploit the disruption. The fire injured one worker, took 22 hours to extinguish and destroyed an estimated 96 systems; 89 have been restored. Full recovery via a Daegu backup will take four weeks, spanning the Chuseok holiday. President Lee Jae Myung condemned the lack of backups ahead of the APEC summit in Gyeongju. Politicians spar over responsibility. Despite post-Kakao fire laws mandating redundancy and battery spacing, failures expose gaps in South Korea’s digital infrastructure.

articles.title: Ukraine war briefing: Europe ‘no longer at peace’ with Russia, says German chancellor
articles.trailText: Germany ready to defend Baltic region, Berlin says while Hungarian PM claims Ukraine ‘not a sovereign country’. What we know on day 1,315
articles.summary: German chancellor Friedrich Merz declared Europe ‘not at war but no longer at peace’ with Russia, endorsing EU plans to unlock frozen Russian assets for Ukraine’s war effort over 3–5 years. Defence minister Boris Pistorius pledged to station 2,000 German troops in Lithuania by mid-2026 to protect the Baltics. Hungarian PM Viktor Orbán dismissed Ukraine’s sovereignty amid drone disputes. Zelenskiy proposed a joint Polish-Ukrainian air-defence shield after Russian drone incursions; allies will bolster Denmark’s anti-drone measures. Putin lauded Russia’s “righteous battle,” conscripted 135,000 and quit the anti-torture convention. A Russian strike killed a family in Sumy; Zaporizhzhia plant remains without external power.

articles.title: Shane Christie sustained multiple head injuries playing rugby. In death, he is still fighting for change
articles.trailText: The former All Blacks Sevens player suspected he had CTE, a disease associated with head impacts, and has donated his brain to science to help understand the condition
articles.summary: Former All Blacks Sevens star Shane Christie suffered years of debilitating neurological symptoms—headaches, mood swings, paranoia and hallucinations—suspected to be chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), before dying by suicide at 40. After enduring multiple concussions in Super Rugby and Māori All Blacks, Christie campaigned for better concussion protocols and transparency from New Zealand Rugby and its players’ association, notably launching the Billy Guyton Foundation following his friend’s CTE-linked death. He donated his brain to Auckland’s human brain bank to advance CTE research. His case, now under coronial review, may drive reforms in player welfare, concussion management and recognition of CTE in rugby.

articles.title: China court sentences 11 people to death over alleged role in family-run Myanmar scam operations
articles.trailText: Another five people given suspended death sentences over alleged role in gang that operated scam centres and illegal gambling worth $1.4bn
